0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Articles citing this Article PubMed PubMed Citation Articles by Wang, X.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Related Collections Related Article Article.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	4	COPII-dependent export of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator from the ER uses a di-acidic exit code Xiaodong Wang1, Jeanne Matteson1, Yu An1,2, Bryan Moyer1, Jin-San Yoo1, Sergei Bannykh1, Ian A.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	5	1 Department of Cell Biology, The Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla, CA 92037 2 Department of Molecular Biology, The Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla, CA 92037 3 The Institute for Childhood and Neglected Diseases, The Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla, CA 92037 4 Mayo Foundation and S.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Johnson Medical Research Center, Mayo Clinic, Scottsdale, AZ 85259.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Matteson contributed equally to this paper.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	8	Abbreviations used in this paper: BFA, brefeldin A; BHK, baby hamster kidney; CF, cystic fibrosis; CFTR, CF transmembrane conductance regulator; COPII, coat complex II; endo H, endoglycosidase H; ERAD, ER-associated degradation; GAP, guanine nucleotide activating protein; NBD1, nucleotide binding domain 1; VSV-G, vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	9	Export from the ER now appears to involve specific exit codes that couple cargo to a common cytosolic budding machinery (Barlowe, 2003).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	10	 A conserved di-acidic exit code found in the cytosolic tail of many type I transmembrane proteins was first identified in mammalian cells (Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Nishimura et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	11	, 2000) and subsequently in yeast (Votsmeier and Gallwitz, 2001; Malkus et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The di-acidic code directs selective (Balch et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	13	, 1994) and efficient (Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Nishimura et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	14	, 1999) ER export by promoting interaction of cargo with the coat complex II (COPII) budding machinery.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	15	 COPII (for review see Antonny and Schekman, 2001) consists of the Sar1 GTPase, the cargo selection protein complex Sec23/24 that is a Sar1-specific guanine nucleotide activating protein (GAP; Aridor et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	16	, 2002), and a coat polymer assembly factor, Sec13/31 (Pryer et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The Sar1 GTPase is recruited and activated by the ER-localized transmembrane protein Sec12, a guanine nucleotide exchange factor specific for Sar1 (Barlowe and Schekman, 1993; Weissman et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Sar1 activation is essential for recruitment of the Sec23/24 complex to the ER membrane to select cargo and to initiate COPII coat assembly.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	19	Assembly and disassembly of the COPII coat can be rigorously controlled in vivo and in vitro by use of biochemically characterized Sar1 mutants.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Sar1[T39N] (referred to as Sar1-GDP) is restricted to the GDP-bound state and biochemically functions as a competitive inhibitor of wild-type Sar1 recruitment, thereby preventing Sec23/24 attachment to the ER membrane and coat assembly (Kuge et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Sar1[H79G] (referred to as Sar1-GTP) has a reduced rate of GAP-stimulated hydrolysis, remaining in the GTP-bound state after activation.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Although efficiently recruited to the ER membrane where it promotes cargo recruitment and the assembly of coat polymers, its inability to undergo hydrolysis interferes with subsequent COPII coat disassembly, resulting in inhibition of ER to Golgi transport (Kuge et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In addition, we have demonstrated that the protein kinase inhibitor H89 blocks recruitment of COPII coat components and prevents vesicle formation from the ER (Aridor and Balch, 2000).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	24	 These probes provide powerful approaches to dissect the role of COPII function in transport of cargo through the secretory pathway.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	25	To develop a therapeutic means to stimulate F508-CFTR trafficking from the ER to the cell surface, it is necessary to understand the mechanisms and pathways that regulate its export from the ER.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	26	 We have previously shown that CFTR exits the ER in a COPII-dependent fashion (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	27	 A recent paper (Fu and Sztul, 2003) proposed that COPII also regulates the delivery of wild-type CFTR to the ERAD pathway in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae (Xiong et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	28	 We have now examined in detail the contribution of COPII to the export of CFTR to the Golgi and its potential contribution to the ERAD pathway in mammalian cells.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Our results demonstrate that although COPII is essential for export of wild-type CFTR from the ER, we found no evidence that COPII contributes to the targeting of either wild-type CFTR or the F508-CFTR mutant to ERAD pathway.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Intriguingly, we report that export of CFTR is highly sensitive to mutation of a highly conserved, consensus di-acidic exit code (Nishimura and Balch, 1997) found in the NBD1 domain of CFTR.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	31	 We find that coupling to the Sec23/24 cargo selection complex through the di-acidic code is critical for diverting CFTR from the ERAD pathway.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	32	 We propose that the di-acidic exit code plays a key role in linking CFTR to the COPII coat machinery and is the primary defect leading to disease in F508-expressing patients.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	33	View larger version (43K):    Figure 1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Export of CFTR from the ER is COPII dependent.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	35	 BHK cells were transfected with pcDNA3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	36	1 plasmids containing either wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR or cotransfected with pcDNA3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	37	1 containing the indicated Sar1 mutants as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	38	 After a 30-min pulse with [35S]Met, CFTR was immunoprecipitated at the indicated chase time and quantitated using a Molecular Dynamics PhosphoImager as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Expression levels of Sar1 mutants (5 to 10-fold endogenous) were monitored by immunoblotting with specific antibody as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	40	 (A and B, top panels) Quantitation of CFTR in band B (ER form) reported as a percentage of total B plus C at the 0 time point.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	41	 (A and B, bottom panels) Quantitation of the CFTR band C glycosylated form reported as a percentage of total B plus C at the 0 time point.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Insets in A and B show representative autoradiographs containing band B and C (arrows).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	43	 In A (top right panel), a significant increase in amount of band B remaining in six independent experiments for cells transfected with Sar1-GTP compared with Sar1-GDP at 3 h is shown (P  <  0.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The dashed horizontal line indicates the level of band B remaining in the wild-type (mock) control.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	45	 In A (bottom right panel), the C/B ratios are shown for the 3-h time point.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Results in A and B are typical of at least three independent experiments.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	47	  We have previously reported (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	48	, 2002) that Golgi processing of band B to band C is inhibited by cotransfection with the Sar1-GTP mutant when overexpressed 5 to 10-fold, demonstrating that CFTR exits the ER by a COPII-dependent pathway (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Inhibition is clearly evident in the ratio of band C to band B (C/B ratio).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	50	 When compared with the mock control C/B value of 1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	51	8 at the 3-h time point, the C/B ratio in the presence of Sar1-GTP was  < 0.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	52	 To pursue the possibility that COPII is required for ER export but not ERAD, we examined the effect of the Sar1-GDP mutant that is restricted to the GDP-bound form on CFTR glycosylation or proteolysis.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	53	 As Sar1-GDP is a competitive inhibitor of recruitment of wild-type Sar1 to the Sec12 guanine nucleotide exchange factor (Weissman et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	54	, 2001) and Sar1 activation is essential for the recruitment of the cargo selection Sec23/24 complex to the ER membrane (Kuge et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	55	, 2001), Sar1-GDP competes with wild-type Sar1 to competitively reduce the efficiency of both COPII recruitment and coat assembly.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Although cotransfection of wild-type CFTR with Sar1-GDP (5 to 10-fold overexpression; Kuge et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	57	, 2002) strongly inhibited export as measured by processing of band B to band C (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	58	 1 A, inset and bottom panels, C/B ratio is  < 0.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	59	7), wild-type CFTR continued to be degraded efficiently in the presence of the mutant (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Identical results were observed at both early and late time points of transfection (unpublished data), indicating that the potential accumulation of other cargo in the ER in the presence of Sar1-GDP is unlikely to influence the effect of the Sar1-GDP on CFTR trafficking and degradation.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	61	 In contrast to Sar1-GDP, Sar1-GTP is a dominant-negative mutant that promotes cargo collection into stable COPII-coated intermediates.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	62	 As a consequence, targeting and fusion of these intermediates to the Golgi is blocked (Kuge et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Interestingly, cotransfection of wild-type CFTR with Sar1-GTP significantly (P  <  0.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	64	05) protected immature (band B) wild-type CFTR from degradation by the ERAD pathway when compared with degradation rate observed in the presence of the Sar1-GDP mutant (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	65	 This result raises the possibility that recruitment of CFTR to the assembling COPII polymer at ER exit sites prevents access to ERAD.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	66	We also examined the effects of both Sar1-GDP to  and Sar1-GTP to restricted mutants on F508-CFTR stability given that this protein is not exported from the ER and therefore completely degraded by ERAD (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Cotransfection of F508-CFTR with the Sar1-GTP to restricted mutant did not promote processing of band B to C (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	68	 1 B, inset and bottom panel), nor did it affect the kinetics of degradation by ERAD (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	69	 An identical result was observed with the Sar1-GDP to restricted mutants (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	70	 These results are consistent with the idea that failure to export from the ER reflects the inability of F508 to link to COPII.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	71	To provide additional evidence for the role of Sar1 in selection of wild-type CFTR for export, we took advantage of the protein kinase inhibitor H89 that we have previously shown to inhibit Sar1 recruitment and COPII coat assembly (Aridor and Balch, 2000).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Addition of H89 to cells stably expressing CFTR strongly reduced export (90%; Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	73	 ERAD continues efficiently, suggesting that COPII recruitment is not required for targeting for degradation as H89, like Sar1-GDP, uncouples cargo from the COPII coat machinery (Aridor and Balch, 2000).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	74	View larger version (21K):    Figure 2.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Export of CFTR from the ER but not degradation is inhibited by the kinase inhibitor H89.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	76	 BHK cells stably expressing either wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR were labeled with [35S]Met for 30 min as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	77	 After labeling, cells were chased for the indicated time in the absence or presence of 50  microM H89, and processing of CFTR from the band B ER form to mature band C was quantitated as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Results are typical of two independent experiments.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	79	  We conclude that conditions that enhance COPII assembly on the ER membrane stabilize wild-type CFTR from ERAD.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	80	 In contrast, conditions that interfere with COPII recruitment prevent the export of wild-type CFTR, but have little effect on delivery of either wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR to the ERAD pathway.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Thus, the ERAD pathway functions largely independently of the COPII machinery.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	82	Export, but not ERAD, is reversibly sensitive to a novel Sar1 temperature-sensitive (Sar1ts) mutant To ensure that the aforementioned results with the Sar1 mutants were not a consequence of targeting of either wild-type or mutant CFTR to a nonphysiological pathway, or reflect indirect effects of other cargo in the ER on CFTR export or stability, we developed a temperature-sensitive variant of Sar1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	83	 This mutant is dominant-negative at the permissive temperature (32 degrees C), where it is folded properly.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	84	 It loses this dominant-negative activity when transferred to the restrictive temperature (40 degrees C), where it misfolds.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	85	 When cotransfected with the type 1 transmembrane protein vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein (VSV-G) at 32 degrees C, Sar1ts shows strong inhibition of processing of VSV-G from the endoglycosidase H (endo H) to sensitive ER form to the endo H to resistant Golgi form (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	86	 3 A), indicative of an ER to Golgi transport block.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	87	 In contrast, at 40 degrees C, a condition that promotes destabilization of the mutant protein, inhibition of export is lost (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Thus, Sar1ts shows a thermoreversible temperature-sensitive ER export block.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	89	View larger version (24K):    Figure 3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	90	 ER export is reversibly sensitive to a novel Sar1 temperature-sensitive (Sar1ts) mutant.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	91	 (A) BHK cells were cotransfected with pcDNA3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	92	1 containing either VSV-G or VSV-G and the indicated Sar1 mutant.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The effect of Sar1-GTP (control) or Sar1ts on processing of VSV-G from the endoglycosidase H to sensitive (endo Hs) ER form to the endo H to resistant (endo Hr) Golgi form after a 5-min pulse with [35S]Met at 32 degrees C followed by a 30 min chase at the indicated temperature was determined as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	94	 (B) BHK cells were cotransfected with pcDNA3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	95	1 containing wild-type CFTR either with vector only (mock) or, where indicated, cotransfected with pcDNA3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The transport and processing of CFTR from band B to C was followed at the indicated temperature as described in Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The C/B ratios for the Sar1ts mutant at 32 and 40 degrees C are shown for the 3-h time point.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The asterisk in the top panel of B indicates that CFTR is exported very inefficiently from the ER as band C is only weakly processed to early Golgi oligosaccharide forms.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	99	 White lines indicate that intervening lanes have been spliced out.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Results are typical of three independent experiments.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	101	  Transient coexpression of Sar1ts and wild-type CFTR at 32 degrees C significantly inhibited the export of wild-type CFTR when compared with the mock control as measured by processing from the band B to the band C forms (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	102	 3 B, bottom right panel, C/B ratio is 0.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Sar1ts had no apparent effect on stabilizing wild-type CFTR from degradation at 32 degrees C (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	104	 3 B, top panel), which is consistent with the interpretation that Sar1ts interferes with COPII coat assembly but does not affect ERAD pathways.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Moreover, cotransfection of F508-CFTR with Sar1ts had no effect on either F508-CFTR export or degradation when compared with the controls expressing F508 alone at either 32 or 40 degrees C temperatures (unpublished data).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Importantly, we used a two-stage incubation protocol to examine the ability of CFTR to be exported from the ER after accumulation in the presence of the Sar1ts mutant at 32 degrees C.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Cells transfected for 14 h at 32 degrees C to prevent CFTR export were labeled for 30 min at 32 degrees C (stage 1).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Subsequently, cells were transferred to 40 degrees C (stage 2) to inactivate Sar1ts.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	109	 In contrast to incubation at 32 degrees C (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	110	 3 B, bottom right panel, C/B ratio is 0.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	111	5 at 3 h), upon transfer to 40 degrees C we observed normal processing of wild-type CFTR from band B to C (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	112	 3 B, bottom right panel, C/B ratio is >4 at 3 h).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Thus, reversible inhibition of processing of wild-type CFTR to band C imposed by incubation at 32 degrees C in the presence of Sar1ts interferes with the normal physiological pathway required for COPII-dependent export but not degradation.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	114	CFTR uses a di-acidic exit code for export from the ER To understand the requirement for COPII in the export of CFTR from the ER, we examined the CFTR sequence for the presence of the evolutionarily conserved tyrosine-based di-acidic code required for export of VSV-G (Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Nishimura et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	115	, 2000) and other transmembrane proteins from the ER in mammalian cells (Bannykh and Balch, 1998; Bannykh et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	116	, 1998) and yeast (Votsmeier and Gallwitz, 2001; Malkus et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Notably, CFTR contained a YKDAD motif (residues 563 to 567) in the first nucleotide binding motif (NBD1) that is evolutionarily conserved and similar to that found in VSV-G (YxDxE; Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Sevier et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The structure of the NBD1 domain of CFTR (1ROZ.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	119	pdb) reveals that the YKDAD motif is located in a surface-exposed loop linking the NH2-terminal helical domain containing Phe508 to the COOH-terminal sheet domain (Lewis et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Strikingly, transient expression of CFTR mutants in which either one (DAA-CFTR; Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	121	 4 B, inset and bottom panel) or both (AAA-CFTR; unpublished data) conserved Asp residues were mutated to Ala resulted in complete inhibition of export from the ER as measured by the inability of band B to be processed to band C and a morphological distribution consistent with localization to the ER (Bannykh et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Like F508-CFTR, cotransfection with Sar1-GTP failed to promote export or stabilize DAA-CFTR from ERAD, suggesting that mutation of the di-acidic motif uncoupled CFTR from COPII (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	123	 We also examined whether or not, like F508-CFTR, the DAA-CFTR phenotype is temperature-sensitive by examining its rate of export at the lowered temperature (30 degrees C).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Whereas transfer of F508-CFTR to 30 degrees C resulted in significant enhancement of transport to the cell surface reflecting its effect on conformational stability of NBD1 as observed previously (Denning et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	125	, 1996), we did not observe a similar increase in DAA-CFTR export at 30 degrees C (unpublished data).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	126	 These results suggest that the DAA mutation does not affect the fold of NBD1 in a similar fashion to the F508 mutation that can be stabilized by incubation at reduced temperature.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	127	View larger version (51K):    Figure 4.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	128	 CFTR uses a di-acidic code for export from the ER.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	129	 (A) Location of Phe508 and the di-acidic code in the NBD1 domain of CFTR (Lewis et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Shown in blue is Phe508; shown in red (carbon backbone) and yellow (side-chains) is the orientation of residues Asp565 and Asp567 (di-acidic code).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	131	 (B) Cells were either transfected or cotransfected with the indicated wild-type or mutant CFTR and the Sar1-GTP mutant as indicated.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Processing from band B to band C was quantitated as described in Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	133	 (C) Effect of BFA on stability of wild-type CFTR, F508-CFTR, or the DAA-CFTR mutant in the ER.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	134	 White lines indicate that intervening lanes have been spliced out.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Cells were pulse-labeled for 30 min with [35S]Met at 37 degrees C.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	136	 10  microg/ml BFA was added and incubation continued for 3 h at 37 degrees C.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	137	 (lanes a, d, and g) Total CFTR found in band B after pulse (expressed as a value of 100%).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	138	 (lanes b, e, and h) Fraction of CFTR found in band B after 3-h incubation in the absence of BFA.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	139	 (lanes c, f, and i) Fraction of CFTR found in band B after 3-h incubation in the presence of BFA.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The dashed bar in lane b indicates the total B + C at the 3-h time point in the absence of BFA.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Results are typical of at least two independent experiments for each condition shown.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	142	  To further characterize the biochemical properties of the DAA-CFTR mutant, we took advantage of the previous observation that treatment of CFTR-expressing cells with brefeldin A (BFA) reduces degradation of wild-type CFTR, but not F508-CFTR (Ostedgaard et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	143	 BFA triggers the collapse of the Golgi to the ER by preventing the recruitment of coat complex I to Golgi membranes (for review see Chardin and McCormick, 1999).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	144	 In contrast to its potent effect on coat complex I function in the Golgi, BFA has no effect on COPII function during ER export.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	145	 As a consequence, in BFA-treated cells ER-associated cargo is collected in export intermediates that accumulate in the absence of functional Golgi compartments (Lippincott-Schwartz et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	146	 As expected, addition of BFA prevented processing of wild-type CFTR from band B to C and partially stabilized wild-type CFTR from ERAD, likely reflecting recruitment to COPII intermediates (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	147	 In contrast, BFA did not prevent degradation of either the F508- or the DAA-CFTR mutant (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	148	 These results are consistent with the interpretation that both mutants fail to couple to the COPII machinery (Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Nishimura et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	149	, 1999), resulting in their delivery to the ERAD pathway.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	150	The biochemical interaction of CFTR with COPII is disrupted by the F508 and DAA mutations Although the results described in the previous section raise the possibility that CFTR may exit the ER through the di-acidic code, it remained to be shown that wild-type CFTR can engage the COPII machinery and whether interaction with COPII can be disrupted by the F508- or DAA-CFTR mutations.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	151	 For this purpose, we first examined the ability of CFTR to bind the Sec23/Sec24 cargo selection complex in immunoprecipitates recovered from detergent lysates of HEK293 cell lines stably expressing either wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	152	 5 A, in cells expressing wild-type CFTR, the protein is largely in the band C mature form with  < 5% in the band B ER form, an expected result given that wild-type CFTR accumulates in post-Golgi compartments.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	153	 In contrast, in F508-CFTR to expressing HEK293 cells, the only form is band B reflecting its ER localization, its level of expression reflecting continuous degradation by ERAD (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Despite the large difference in the steady-state level of CFTR in wild-type and F508-expressing cells, when we quantitated the recovery of Sec24 with respect to the total amount of wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR in band B using immunoblotting, we observed that F508-CFTR bound  < 25% of that observed for wild-type CFTR (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Sec24 was not recovered from HEK293 cells that do not express CFTR (unpublished data).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Because immunoprecipitations were performed on ice, it is likely that the temperature-sensitive phenotype of F508-CFTR resulted in partial folding after transfer to ice, accounting for the observed level of recovery of Sec24.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Although the band B ER form would be expected to be the only form of CFTR that would bind the ER-specific COPII coat machinery, we examined whether or not immunoprecipitation of Sec24 would recover band C, the cell surface form.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Despite the large excess of band C in the cell (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	159	 5 A), immunoprecipitation of Sec24 followed by immunoblotting for CFTR only recovered the band B forms of either wild type or F508 (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	160	View larger version (30K):    Figure 5.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Wild-type CFTR but not DAA-CFTR binds COPII.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	162	 (A) HEK293 stably expressing wild type or F508 were lysed in the presence of 1% Triton X-100, and Sec23/Sec24 complex recovered by immunoprecipitation with a CFTR-specific mAb was quantitated as described in Materials and methods.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	163	 CFTR (bands B and C) and Sec24 were detected by immunoblotting with specific antibody as described in Materials and methods.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	164	 (B) As in A except the amount CFTR recovered by immunoprecipitation with a Sec24-specific polyclonal antibody was quantitated as described in Materials and methods using immunoblotting.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	165	 HEK293 cells not expressing CFTR were used as a control.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	166	 CFTR (bands B and C) were detected by immunoblotting with specific antibody.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	167	 (C) HEK293 cells were transfected with pcDNA3.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	168	1 plasmids containing either wild-type CFTR or DAA-CFTR as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Cells were lysed in the presence of 1% Triton X-100, and the amount of Sec23/Sec24 complex recovered bound to band B of CFTR (expressed as a Sec24/band B ratio) was quantitated as described in Materials and methods.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	170	 CFTR (bands B and C) and Sec24 were detected by immunoblotting with specific antibodies.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	171	 (D) HEK293 stably expressing wild type or F508 incubated at 37 degrees C (wild type) or for the indicated time at 30 degrees C (F508) were lysed in the presence of 1% Triton X-100, and the amount of Sec23/Sec24 complex recovered bound to CFTR by immunoprecipitation with a CFTR-specific antibody was quantitated as described in Materials and methods.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Error bars indicates the SD for samples generated for each time point in triplicate.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	173	  To test the ability of the DAA-CFTR mutant to bind the Sec23/Sec24, we transfected HEK293 cells with wild-type CFTR or DAA-CFTR using the vaccinia expression system.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Strikingly, we observed that band B of the DAA-CFTR mutant bound  < 5% of that recovered in immunoprecipitates with wild-type CFTR (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	175	 These results support the conclusion that the marked inefficiency of DAA-CFTR to exit the ER is a consequence of its inability to couple to the cargo selection complex Sec23/Sec24.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	176	To correlate the effects of the di-acidic code DAA-CFTR mutant on COPII binding with the effects of Phe508 on the ability of the F508-CFTR to exit the ER after transfer to 30 degrees C, we performed a temperature-shift experiment.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	177	 5 D, with increasing incubation time at 30 degrees C, F508 showed a strong increase in its interaction with Sec24, approaching the value observed for wild-type CFTR at 37 degrees C at steady-state.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	178	 These results suggest that reduced temperature promotes maturation of CFTR and presentation of the exit code for interaction with the COPII coat machinery for export from the ER.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	179	COPII does not participate in ERAD A recent paper (Fu and Sztul, 2003) suggested that targeting of CFTR to the ERAD pathway in S.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	180	 cerevisiae requires COPII because in the absence of COPII function CFTR accumulates in an ER-like subcompartment rather than being degraded (Kiser et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	181	, 2001; Fu and Sztul, 2003; Sullivan et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	182	 In contrast, we found that COPII does not participate in ERAD of either wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR in mammalian cells.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The reasons for this discrepancy are now apparent.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	184	 First, CFTR will not exit the ER in yeast under any condition, limiting interpretation of the results (Kiser et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	185	, 2001; Fu and Sztul, 2003; Sullivan et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Second, all experiments used overexpression of a GFP-tagged variant of CFTR (GFP-CFTR).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	187	 A similar GFP-CFTR construct, when expressed in mammalian cells, has a markedly reduced rate of export and accumulates in ER tubular elements at 30 degrees C (comparable to experiments in yeast where cells are incubated at 24 degrees C) that significantly overlaps with calnexin (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	188	 This overlap is consistent with the fact that folding of nascent CFTR in the ER is likely to involve calnexin (Pind et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	189	 However, upon transfer to 37 degrees C, GFP-CFTR is efficiently exported to the cell surface of mammalian cells (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Thus, in mammalian cells, GFP-CFTR can accumulate transiently in a bona fide ER-like tubular network at reduced temperature that is unlikely to be a specialized COPII-regulated degradative subcompartment as suggested for yeast where export is blocked at all temperatures (Fu and Sztul, 2003; Sullivan et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	191	A third concern is that all experiments relied on temperature-sensitive COPII mutants to prevent degradation, leading to the interpretation that COPII is required for ERAD.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	192	 These experiments required prolonged incubation of yeast at the restrictive temperature (40 degrees C) to assess the effect of the mutant COPII component on ERAD.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	193	 It is well-established that elevated temperature (40 degrees ) in mammalian cells markedly stabilizes (approximately twofold) both wild-type CFTR and F508-CFTR from ERAD in response to induction of heat shock folding chaperones (Strickland et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	194	, 1999; Choo-Kang and Zeitlin, 2001; Farinha et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Thus, the twofold effect of the temperature-sensitive Sec12 variant on preventing CFTR degradation in yeast can be largely explained by the twofold difference in stability observed upon shift from the permissive to the restrictive temperature in control incubations in the absence of the Sec12ts (Fu and Sztul, 2003).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	196	Fourth, unlike the Sar1-GDP and -GTP mutants, the biochemical properties of the Sec13 and Sec23 temperature-sensitive mutants have not been characterized.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	197	 For example, both Sec13 and Sec23 temperature-sensitive variants may not be inactivated by shifting to the restrictive temperature as suggested (Fu and Sztul, 2003).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Rather they may promote stable coat assembly leading to partial segregation of CFTR from ERAD as we have observed during COPII coat polymer assembly promoted by the Sar1-GTP mutant.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	199	 We conclude that role of COPII is to direct CFTR selection into COPII vesicles, removing the protein from the ERAD COPII-independent targeted pool.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	200	A di-acidic code mediates CFTR export An important finding that provides new insight into the role of COPII in export of CFTR from the ER was that processing of band B to C was sensitive to mutation of the conserved di-acidic code exit motif originally detected in the cytoplasmic tail of VSV-G (Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Nishimura et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Consistent with this finding, a natural variant in the cystic fibrosis mutation database (http://www.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	202	ca/cftr/) has a substitution of G for D at position 565 (565DAD to 565GAD) that results in a severe deficiency phenotype, although this allele is complex (Tzetis et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The requirement for a di-acidic code in CFTR export is consistent with a similar requirement for a di-acidic motif for export of the multi-membrane-spanning K+ channel (Ma et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	204	, 2001; Ma and Jan, 2002) and yeast GAP permease (Malkus et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Given that transfer of the di-acidic code to an ER-retained protein is sufficient to promote efficient export (Nishimura and Balch, 1997; Nishimura et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	206	, 1999) and the fact that the di-acidic code recognizes the Sec24 subunit of the Sec23/24 complex (Miller et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	207	, 2002), it is now evident that the di-acidic motif may be used by CFTR to engage the Sec24.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Our CFTR coimmunoprecipitation results provide direct evidence that the DAD motif in NBD1 of CFTR serves as a functional ER exit code as loss of the code results in impaired binding to Sec23/24.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	209	 In the case of the GAP permease, it has been suggested that the di-acidic code, although necessary for export, is not sufficient ((Miller et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	210	 A similar constraint may apply to CFTR as the protein has a complicated cytosolic folding pathway involving numerous chaperones and cochaperones (Pind et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	211	, 1998; Brodsky, 2001; Zhang et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	212	, 2002) that may facilitate recognition of the Sec23/Sec24 complex (unpublished data).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	213	NBD1 domains of a large variety of ABC transporters have a similar structural organization (Schmitt and Tampe, 2002).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Structural alignment of the NBD1 domain of CFTR (Lewis et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	215	, 2004) with the NBD1 domain of the ABC transporter BtuCD reveals that the di-acidic code is found in a solvent-exposed loop connecting the NH2-terminal helical domain containing Phe508 with the more COOH-terminal sheet domain (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Given that the structure of Sar1 and the Sec23/24 complex containing a bound di-acidic peptide are available (Huang et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	217	, 2003), we built a homology model with the NBD1 of CFTR replacing the similar structural fold of NBD1 of BtuCD (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	218	 This new structure (BtuCD-NBD1CFTR) was then combined with the structure of the Sec23/24 -Sar1 complex to illustrate the ability of the di-acidic code loop in NBD1CFTR to insert directly into the Sec23/24 di-acidic code binding pocket (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	219	 S2 for a three-dimensional view, available at http://www.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Docking reveals little steric interference between residues within the binding pocket, or between residues defining the tertiary structure of BtuCD-NBD1CFTR and the Sar1/Sec24/23 complex.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Moreover, the orientation of the NH2 terminus of Sar1 (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	222	 6, red ss-strand; residues 25 to 34), which is linked to the flexible NH2-terminal tail involved in anchoring Sar1 to the membrane (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	223	 6, black dashed line; not observed in the crystal structure; Huang et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	224	, 2002), is oriented correctly to facilitate recruitment of Sec23/24 by activated Sar1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	225	 It is apparent that Sar1 and BtuCD-NBD1CFTR interact with Sec23/Sec24 independently as shown for the holo cargo-selection complex.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Thus, the general structural features of the CFTR-NBD1 domain presented within the structure of BtuCD are consistent with the role of the di-acidic code in directing interaction with COPII for exit from the ER.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	227	View larger version (61K):    Figure 6.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	228	 CFTR-COPII cargo selection complex.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	229	 (bottom) The structure of CFTR-NBD1 (1ROX.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	230	pdb) is oriented to show its structural homology with the NBD1 structural domain of the bacterial ABC transporter BtuCD (1L7V.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	231	 In CFTR-NBD1, Phe508 is shown in blue and residues Asp565 and Asp567 (di-acidic code) are shown in yellow.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	232	 In BtuCD, the cytosolic domains are shown in green and putative transmembrane spanning domains are shown in red.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	233	 The short loop shown in red in BtuCD corresponds structurally to the di-acidic code-containing loop in CFTR-NBD1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	234	 (middle) Homology structure containing CFTR-NBD1 and BtuCD (Btu-NBD1CFTR) docked to the Sar1/Sec23/24 complex (Bi et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	235	, 2003; see Materials and methods).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Gray rectangle illustrates the putative location of the membrane bilayer.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	237	 (top) The interaction of the CFTR-NBD1 di-acidic code with the binding pocket of Sec23/24 (Bi et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Shown in blue are Arg230, 235, 559, and 561 basic residues defining the di-acidic code pocket of Sec24 (Bi et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Only a minor steric interference is observed between Asp565 (CFTR-NBD1) and Leu616 (Sec24) in the homology model.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	240	 S2 for a three-dimensional rendering of the interface between CFTR-NBD1 and the Sec23/24 cargo complex.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	241	  Given the likely importance of the aromatic side-chain of Phe508 in stabilizing the conserved structural fold of the NH2-terminal helical domain of NBD1 (Fig.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	242	 6, blue residue), deletion of Phe508 in the F508-CFTR mutant may alter the orientation of the di-acidic motif-containing loop, thereby compromising its interaction with Sec24.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	243	 This notion was directly tested by the CFTR coimmunoprecipitation experiments where we found that binding of band B of F508 to Sec24 was much lower than that of wild-type CFTR.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Consistent with this interpretation, F508-CFTR-Sec24 interaction and transport to cell surface can be rescued by promoting folding at 30 degrees C.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Moreover, export of F508-CFTR from the ER can also be rescued in cis by additional point mutations in NBD1 that stabilize the structural fold (DeCarvalho et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Given that over 1,000 mutants have been reported to affect CFTR export and function leading to varying degrees of disease, it is not surprising that residues flanking the di-acidic code have also been reported in the mutation database.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Structural considerations strongly suggest that many of these flanking mutations, unlike the di-acidic code that is found in the solvent-exposed loop, are likely to affect the fold of the -helical and ss-strands that contribute to the structural organization of NBD1 and indirectly compromise presentation of the code (unpublished data).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	248	 We propose that the inability of the F508-CFTR mutant to engage the COPII machinery through Sec24 is the primary basis for the most common form of CF.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	249	Vaccinia transient expression Vaccinia transient expression and quantification was performed exactly as described previously (Yoo et al.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	250	 SEM were determined using the software program Prism.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	251	Immunoprecipitation of the CFTR-Sec24 complex HEK293 cells stably expressing wild-type CFTR or F508-CFTR, or vaccinia-transfected HEK293 cells transiently expressing wild-type CFTR and DAA-CFTR were lysed on ice in Triton X-100 lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	252	4, 150 mM NaCl, and 1% Triton X-100) supplemented with complete protease inhibitor cocktail tablets (Roche Diagnostics GmbH).
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Soluble fraction of the lysates were incubated with protein G beads coupled with anti-CFTR antibody M3A7 or anti-Sec24 polyclonal antibodies.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	254	 The immunocomplexes were washed and eluted with 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 6.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	255	 The protein components of the complexes were separated by SDS-PAGE.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	256	 CFTR and Sec24 were detected by immunoblot.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	257	 CFTR and Sec24 were quantitated by densitometry using a Molecular Dynamics Imaging System.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	258	 In brief, for CFTR detected by immunoblotting, immunoblots exposed in the linear range were quantitated by measuring the densities of band B or C.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	259	 A similar area immediately adjacent to bands B or C in each lane (background) were subtracted from the B or C value to obtain the indicated values shown in the Results.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	260	Structural alignment of CFTR-NBD1, BtuCD, and the Sec23/24 complex Fitting of CFTR-NBD1 to BtuCD and Sec23/24 was performed as follows.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	261	 The Sec24/NBD1 complex model was built from the Sec24/DXE peptide complex (1PD1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	262	pdb) coordinates by superimposing DXE peptide onto the corresponding part of NBD1.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	263	 The Sec24/NBD1/Sec23 complex model was built from the Sec24/NBD1 model and Sec24/Sec23 complex (1M2V.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	264	pdb) by superimposing Sec24 in both coordinates.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	265	 The Sec24/NBD1/Sec23/Sar1 complex model was built from Sec24/NBD1/Sec23 model and Sec23/Sar1 complex (1M2O.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	266	pdb) by superimposing Sec23 in both coordinates.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The Sec24/NBD1/Sec23/Sar1/BtuCD complex model was built from the Sec24/NBD1/Sec23/Sar1 model and BtuCD (1L7V.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	268	pdb) by superimposing CFTR-NBD1 and BtuD in both coordinates.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Fitting was performed using the McLachlan algorithm (McLachlan, 1982) as implemented in the program ProFit (http://www.
0.41072902.15479737.html.plaintext.txt	270	Online supplemental material Fig.

0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	0	Erythrocytes of humans with cystic fibrosis fail to stimulate nitric oxide synthesis in isolated rabbit lungs Griffith Liang,2 Alan H.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	1	Departments of 1Pharmacological and Physiological Science and 2Internal Medicine, Saint Louis University School of Medicine, St.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	2	Submitted 9 August 2004 ; accepted in final form 2 December 2004.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	3	adenosine triphosphate; red blood cells; pulmonary circulation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	4	IT IS WELL ESTABLISHED that the endothelium-derived relaxing factor nitric oxide (NO) is produced by endothelial cells and, when released, relaxes vascular smooth muscle (10, 14, 19).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Physiologically, an alteration in shear applied to the endothelium of blood vessels has been suggested to be a major stimulus for NO release (3, 22).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	6	 However, in the pulmonary circulation, a reappraisal of this viewpoint was required when it was reported that, in isolated rabbit (31) and rat (36, 38) lungs perfused with a physiological salt solution (PSS), alterations in shear stress alone did not evoke release of NO.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In contrast, when lungs of these species were perfused with either blood (36) or PSS containing washed erythrocytes (30, 38), inhibition of endogenous NO synthesis produced a shift in the slope of the pressure-flow relationship consistent with a decrease in vascular caliber, i.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	8	, NO was a determinant of vascular resistance.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The ability of the erythrocyte to stimulate NO synthesis in the pulmonary circulation of the rabbit and rat was reported to be independent of effects on viscosity or pressure (31, 36).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The property of the erythrocyte that was associated with the stimulation of endogenous NO synthesis was shown to be the release of ATP (26, 28, 30).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In support of the hypothesis that erythrocyte-derived ATP is a stimulus for endogenous NO synthesis in the lung, the addition of ATP to the perfusate of isolated rabbit lungs produces vasodilation that is, in large part, dependent on the stimulation of endogenous NO synthesis (30).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Importantly, in addition to rabbit erythrocytes, human erythrocytes were reported both to release ATP in response to physiological stimuli, such as mechanical deformation, and to stimulate endogenous NO synthesis in the isolated perfused rabbit lung (26).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	13	Recently, a signal transduction pathway that relates mechanical deformation to ATP release from human and rabbit erythrocytes has been described (17, 18, 27, 29).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	14	 This pathway includes the heterotrimeric G proteins Gs (17) and Gi (18), adenylyl cyclase (29), PKA (29), and the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) (27).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The activity of CFTR was shown to be required for deformation-induced ATP release from erythrocytes of both rabbits and humans (27).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Thus erythrocytes of humans with cystic fibrosis, a condition in which CFTR activity is absent or markedly reduced, and rabbit erythrocytes incubated with inhibitors of CFTR activity failed to release ATP in response to mechanical deformation (27).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Here, we demonstrate that CFTR is expressed in the membrane of both rabbit and human erythrocytes and that, in contrast to those of healthy humans, erythrocytes from humans with cystic fibrosis fail to stimulate endogenous NO synthesis in the isolated rabbit pulmonary circulation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	18	Rabbit and human blood was centrifuged at 500 g for 10 min at 4 degrees C.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The plasma, buffy coat, and uppermost erythrocytes were removed by aspiration and discarded.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The remaining erythrocytes were washed three times in buffer solution containing 140.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	21	5% BSA fraction V (ICN Biomedicals; Aurora, OH), with a final pH of 7.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	22	 The hematocrit of the washed erythrocytes was determined using an Autocrit Ultra 3 centrifuge (Becton Dickinson; Bedford, MA).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	23	Preparation of erythrocyte membranes.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Washed rabbit or human erythrocytes were diluted 1:100 with ice-cold lysis buffer (5 mM Tris HCl and 2 mM EDTA, pH 7.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	25	4) and stirred at 4 degrees C for 20 min.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	26	 The resulting mixture was centrifuged at 23,000 g for 15 min at 4 degrees C.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The supernatant was removed and discarded.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The membranes were resuspended in cold lysis buffer and centrifuged a second time.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The pellets were pooled, resuspended in ice-cold lysis buffer, and centrifuged at 23,000 g for 15 min at 4 degrees C a final time.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The supernatant was discarded, and the protein concentration was determined (BCA Protein Assay, Pierce; Rockford, IL).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Aliquots were frozen at  to 80 degrees C.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Immediately before electrophoresis, membranes were thawed on ice, sonicated briefly (W-220F sonicator, Heat Systems-Ultrasonics; Farmingdale, NY), vortexed with 5  microl of 10% SDS per 200 ml of sample, and heated to 95 degrees C for 90 s.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	33	Preparation of T84 human colon carcinoma cells.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	34	 T84 cells (American Type Culture Collection), which express large amounts of CFTR (4, 33), were grown to confluence in a 1:1 mixture of DMEM and Ham s F12 medium on a 70-mm culture dish.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The dishes were then washed for 5 min with PBS (pH 7.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	36	4) containing a cocktail of protease inhibitors (Complete, Roche Diagnostics; Mannheim, Germany).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Cells were removed by mechanical scraping and centrifuged at 8,000 g for 90 s.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The resulting cell pellet was resolubilized in ice-cold 250 mM sucrose, 1 mM EDTA, and 20 mM imidazole (pH 7.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	39	2) with the protease inhibitor cocktail.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	40	 After a 10-min incubation on ice, the suspension was briefly sonicated and centrifuged at 16,000 g for 30 s at 4 degrees C.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The supernatant (200 ml) was vortexed with 10% SDS (5 ml) and heated at 95 degrees C for 90 s.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Samples were stored at  to 80 degrees C for Western blot analysis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Membrane proteins were mixed in sample buffer [1.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	44	5% SDS, 6% (vol/vol) glycerol, 0.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	45	6% dithiothreitol, 10 mM Tris (pH 6.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	46	01% bromophenol blue], heated to 95 degrees C for 2 min, and resolved by electrophoresis in 5% SDS-polyacrylamide precast gels (Bio-Rad; Hercules, CA).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	47	 After electrophoresis, the proteins were transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) membrane (Millipore; Bedford, MA) in transfer buffer (25 mM Tris base, 192 mM glycine, and 10% methanol).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The PVDF membranes were blocked for 1 h in a buffer solution containing 5% nonfat dry milk, 10 mM sodium phosphate, 150 mM NaCl, and 0.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The PVDF membranes were then immunoblotted overnight with a mouse monoclonal anti-CFTR antibody (R and D Systems) in wash buffer solution containing 1% nonfat dry milk, 10 mM sodium phosphate, 150 mM NaCl, and 0.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The PVDF membranes were washed three times with 10 mM sodium phosphate, 150 mM NaCl, and 0.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	51	4 and immunoblotted with anti-mouse IgG secondary antibody conjugated to horseradish peroxidase (Amersham; Piscataway, NJ).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	52	 After the membranes were washed, protein was visualized using enhanced chemiluminescence (Amersham).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Rabbits were anesthetized, ventilated, and exsanguinated as described above.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The heart and lungs were removed en block during continuous ventilation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	55	 A catheter was placed in the main pulmonary artery through the right ventricle, and a second catheter was placed in the left atrium.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The heart and lungs were suspended in a humidified chamber maintained at 37 degrees C and ventilated with gas containing 15% O2-6% CO2-balance N2.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Residual blood present in the lungs was removed by perfusion with 200 ml PSS [118.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	58	1 mM glucose, and 5% hetastarch (Baxter Healthcare; Deerfield, IL)] without recirculation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The lungs were then perfused with PSS at 80 ml/min with a recirculating volume of 100 ml.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Pulmonary arterial pressure (PPA), left atrial pressure (PLA), and airway pressure (PAW) were recorded continuously.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	61	 PLA was set to a pressure of 2 to 3 mmHg with a screw clamp, and lungs were perfused under zone III conditions (PPA  >  PLA  >  PAW).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Pulmonary microvascular pressure (PMV) was determined by the double occlusion method (15).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The arterial and venous cannulae were simultaneously occluded with electronically controlled solenoid pinch valves that cause minimal fluid displacement.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Occlusions were maintained for 3 to 5 s, and the resulting equilibration pressures in the pulmonary arterial and venous catheters were recorded as an estimate of PMV.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Samples of perfusate were analyzed for pH, PO2, and PCO2 under control and experimental conditions (pHOx blood gas analyzer, Nova Biomedical; Waltham, MA).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	66	 After a minimum of 15 min of perfusion at 80 ml/min, the pressure-flow relationship was determined by measuring vascular pressures (PPA and PMV) at flow rates of 50, 100, 200, and 300 ml/min.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Within 20 s of a change in flow rate, PLA was adjusted to 2 to 3 mmHg and PMV was determined.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Finally, the flow rate was returned to 80 ml/min (recovery).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	69	 N-nitro-L-arginine methyl ester (L-NAME; Calbiochem) was then added to the perfusate to achieve a final concentration of either 30, 100, or 300  microM.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	70	 After 30 min, a second pressure-flow relationship was determined.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	71	 In separate studies, the isolated lungs were perfused with either PSS alone or PSS to which washed erythrocytes obtained from healthy humans or humans with cystic fibrosis were added.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Erythrocytes were obtained on the day of use and were added to the perfusate within 15 min of being washed.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Statistical significance between experimental periods was determined with ANOVA.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	74	 In the event that the F-ratio indicated that changes had occurred, a least-significant difference test was used to identify individual differences.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	75	 The slope of the pressure-flow relationships was determined by least-squares linear regression analysis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	76	05 or less were considered statistically significant.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Results are reported as means  plus or minus  SE.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	78	View larger version (80K):    Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Identification of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein in the membranes of humans and rabbit erythrocytes and T-84 colon carcinoma cells.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Cell membranes were prepared as described, and protein was resolved using a 5% SDS-PAGE gel.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Protein was transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane and incubated with mouse monoclonal anti-CFTR antibody.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Lane 1, rabbit erythrocyte membranes (15  microg protein, representative of 3 studies); lane 2, T-84 cell membranes (15  microg protein, representative of 3 studies); lane 3, human erythrocyte membranes (50  microg protein, representative of 5 studies).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	83	  Effect of L-NAME on pressure-flow relationships in isolated rabbit lungs perfused with PSS in the absence of erythrocytes.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The pressure-flow relationship was determined in isolated rabbit lungs perfused with PSS in the absence and presence of L-NAME at concentrations of either 30, 100, or 300  microM.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	85	 In the absence of erythrocytes, L-NAME had no effect on the pressure-flow relationship (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	86	View larger version (24K):    Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	87	 A: effect of N-nitro-L-arginine methyl ester (L-NAME) at perfusate concentrations of either 30, 100, or 300  microM on the relationship between flow rate and the pressure gradient across the pulmonary circulation [pulmonary artial pressure (PPA)  to  left arterial pressure (PLA)] in lungs perfused with physiological salt solution (PSS) in the absence of erythrocytes (n = 3 in all groups).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	88	 B: effect of L-NAME on the pressure gradient across the pulmonary circulation (PPA  to  PLA) in lungs perfused with PSS containing erythrocytes of healthy humans (n = 5) or humans with cystic fibrosis (n = 4).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	89	05 compared with all other groups.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Values are means  plus or minus  SE.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	91	  Perfusion of isolated rabbit lungs with PSS containing washed human erythrocytes.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Initial pH, gas tensions, and hematocrit in studies in which lungs were perfused with PSS containing erythrocytes from healthy human erythrocytes or from humans with cystic fibrosis are depicted in Table 1.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Humans with cystic fibrosis, identified as homozygous for the F508 genotype, were treated with medications including inhaled -agonists, ipratropium bromide, corticosteroids, antibiotics, DNAse, and inhibitors of mast cell degranulation as well as oral pancreatic enzyme replacement, antibiotics, proton pump inhibitors, and vitamins.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The addition of washed human erythrocytes to the perfusate of isolated rabbit lungs did not result in increased airway pressure or weight gain over the course of the experiment.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Perfusate pH and gas tensions in isolated perfused rabbit lungs perfused with PSS containing RBCs of healthy humans or humans with cystic fibrosis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	96	  Effect of L-NAME on pressure-flow relationships in isolated rabbit lungs perfused with PSS containing erythrocytes from healthy humans.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Under control conditions (perfusion at 80 ml/min), the addition of L-NAME to the perfusate resulted in an increase in perfusion pressure (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Moreover, the addition of L-NAME resulted in a shift in the pressure-flow relationship such that the pressure difference across the pulmonary circulation (PPA  to  PLA) was increased at each flow rate studied (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Importantly, the slope of this relationship was increased after L-NAME (P  <  0.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	100	01) consistent with the interpretation that, under these conditions, inhibition of endogenous NO synthesis was associated with an increase in Ohmic resistance (15).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Finally, the site of increased resistance was examined by determination of the effect of L-NAME on changes in both upstream (PPA  to  PMV) and downstream (PMV  to  PLA) vascular resistance.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The increases in vascular resistance were confined to the upstream vascular segment (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	103	View larger version (15K):    Fig.

0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	111	  Effect of L-NAME on pressure-flow relationships in isolated rabbit lungs perfused with PSS containing erythrocytes from humans with cystic fibrosis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	112	 In isolated rabbit lungs perfused with PSS containing erythrocytes from humans with cystic fibrosis, L-NAME administration did not result in any change in perfusion pressure under control conditions (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Moreover, in the presence of these erythrocytes, L-NAME had no effect on pressure-flow relationships (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	114	View larger version (13K):    Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Effect of L-NAME (100  microM) on the relationship between flow rate and the pressure gradient across the pulmonary circulation (PPA  to  PLA) in lungs perfused with PSS containing washed erythrocytes of humans with cystic fibrosis (n = 4).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Values are means  plus or minus  SE.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	117	Recently, a signal transduction pathway that relates mechanical deformation to ATP release from erythrocytes of rabbits and humans has been described.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Components of this pathway include the heterotrimeric G proteins Gs (17) and Gi (18), adenylyl cyclase (29), PKA (29) and CFTR (27).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	119	 A role for CFTR in this pathway was suggested by reports that this member of the ATP binding cassette could facilitate the movement of ATP out of cells either by acting as an ATP conduit (21, 22) or by regulating another channel for ATP release (20, 23).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The finding that CFTR activity is lost or markedly diminished in humans with cystic fibrosis (5, 6) provided a unique opportunity for investigation of the role of CFTR in the release of ATP from erythrocytes in response to the physiological stimulus of mechanical deformation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	121	 It was reported previously that erythrocytes of patients with cystic fibrosis as well as rabbit erythrocytes incubated with two chemically dissimilar inhibitors of CFTR, namely, glibenclamide (24, 25) and niflumic acid (7), failed to release ATP in response to mechanical deformation (27).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	122	A necessary step in establishing that CFTR is a component of a signal transduction pathway for ATP release from erythrocytes is the demonstration of its presence in erythrocyte membranes.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Recently, it was shown that CFTR protein is present in erythrocyte membranes of both healthy humans and humans with cystic fibrosis (1, 32).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	124	 In addition, it was reported that human erythroblasts contain CFTR mRNA (37).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	125	 However, it must be noted that neither CFTR protein in human erythrocytes nor mRNA in human erythroid progenitor cells were detected in another study (13).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	126	 In the present work, we confirm the finding that CFTR protein is a component of human erythrocyte membranes (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	127	 In addition, we show that the membranes of rabbit erythrocytes also possess CFTR (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Thus CFTR, a necessary component of a proposed signal transduction pathway for ATP release from erythrocytes, is present in the membranes of both rabbit and human erythrocytes, cells that release ATP in response to mechanical deformation (26, 27, 29).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	129	Although CFTR activity is required for deformation-induced ATP release from erythrocytes of humans (27), the loss of CFTR activity may have a different effect on basal ATP release from these cells.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	130	 It was reported that the concentration of ATP was increased in the blood of CFTR knockout mice as well as humans with cystic fibrosis compared with either wild-type controls or healthy humans, respectively (1).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	131	 It is important to note that, in these studies, ATP release was studied under quiescent conditions, i.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	132	, erythrocytes were not subjected to mechanical deformation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Thus it is possible that, although CFTR is required for deformation-induced ATP release from erythrocytes, another member of the ATP binding cassette, such as the multidrug resistance-associated protein 1, is involved in basal ATP release from these cells (1).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	134	The hypothesis that ATP, released from erythrocytes of healthy humans in response to deformation, stimulates endogenous NO synthesis in the isolated rabbit lung is supported by previous studies.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Erythrocytes of healthy humans release ATP in response to mechanical deformation as would be encountered as they pass through the pulmonary circulation.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The amount of ATP released in response to deformation was shown to be stimulus dependent (26, 27, 29).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	137	 In addition, the inclusion of human erythrocytes in the perfusate of isolated rabbit lungs resulted in the stimulation of endogenous NO synthesis (26).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Finally, the addition of ATP to the perfusate of isolated rabbit lungs resulted in concentration-dependent decreases in total pulmonary vascular resistance that were inhibited by pretreatment with the NO synthase inhibitor L-NAME (30).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	139	In view of the findings that CFTR is expressed in human erythrocyte membranes, that it is a component of a signal transduction pathway that relates erythrocyte deformation to ATP release (27), and that ATP release from erythrocytes is a stimulus for endogenous NO synthesis in the rabbit pulmonary circulation (30), we hypothesized that erythrocytes of humans with cystic fibrosis, a condition in which the activity of CFTR is defective, would fail to stimulate NO synthesis in the isolated perfused rabbit lung.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	140	 In the presence of washed erythrocytes from healthy humans, the administration of the NO synthase inhibitor L-NAME to the perfusate of isolated lungs resulted in a shift in the pressure-flow relationship in a manner consistent with an increase in Ohmic resistance (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	141	 This increase in vascular resistance was confined to the upstream vascular segment (PPA  to  PMV as a function of flow rate; Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	142	 In contrast, in the presence of erythrocytes of patients with cystic fibrosis, L-NAME was without effect on the pressure-flow relationship, i.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	143	, NO was not a determinant of pulmonary vascular resistance (Fig.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	144	Several studies suggest that endogenous NO synthesis in the lung may be decreased in humans with cystic fibrosis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	145	 It was reported that amounts of NO detected in exhaled gas are decreased in humans with cystic fibrosis compared with healthy humans (2, 15, 35).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	146	 It must be recognized that the source of NO that is measured in exhaled gas is unknown and could derive from the endothelium of blood vessels, the airways, or other resident cells.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	147	 However, it was reported that exhaled NO is reduced in neonates with cystic fibrosis before the development of detectable respiratory symptoms, suggesting that the decrease in exhaled NO is not the result of increased mucus accumulation and/or inflammation (9).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Thus the decrease in measurable NO in exhaled gas in cystic fibrosis patients compared with healthy controls could reflect, in part, the failure of erythrocyte-derived ATP to stimulate endogenous NO synthesis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	149	Importantly, it was reported that isolated blood vessels obtained from lungs of humans with cystic fibrosis, when precontracted with phenylephrine, relaxed in response to the application of ADP, the first degradation product of ATP (8).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	150	 This response was shown to be endothelium dependent, although the nature of the endothelium-derived relaxing factor was not determined.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Thus it is reasonable to hypothesize that if erythrocyte-derived ATP were released into the pulmonary circulation of humans with cystic fibrosis, endogenous NO synthesis could be stimulated.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	152	Failure of deformation-induced ATP release from erythrocytes and, thereby, the loss of a physiological stimulus for endogenous NO synthesis could be expected to lead, ultimately, to the development of pulmonary hypertension.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Pulmonary hypertension is seen in humans with cystic fibrosis; however, this condition has most often been attributed to the destructive lung disease and the subsequent loss of pulmonary capillaries and/or hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction (11, 34).
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The results presented here suggest that a defect in ATP release from erythrocytes of cystic fibrosis patients as they traverse the pulmonary circulation could be an additional factor leading to the development of pulmonary hypertension in these individuals.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	155	In summary, we demonstrate that CFTR is a component of the erythrocyte membrane of rabbits and humans.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Erythrocytes from humans in whom this protein is functional stimulate endogenous NO synthesis in the isolated rabbit lung.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	157	 In contrast, erythrocytes of humans with cystic fibrosis, a condition in which CFTR activity is impaired, do not stimulate NO synthesis in this model.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	158	 These findings provide support for the hypothesis that erythrocyte-derived ATP, released in response to a physiological stimulus, such as mechanical deformation, could serve to aid in the maintenance of normal pulmonary vascular resistance via the stimulation of endogenous NO synthesis.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	159	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   The authors thank Elizabeth Bowles for technical assistance and J.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	160	   FOOTNOTES   Address for reprint requests and other correspondence: R.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	161	 of Pharmacological and Physiological Science, Saint Louis Univ.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Louis, MO 63104 (E-mail: spraguer{at}slu.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	163	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.41338694.15591098.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	0	The Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator Is Regulated by a Direct Interaction with the Protein Phosphatase 2A* William R.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Thelin, Mehmet Kesimer, Robert Tarran , Silvia M.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the Department of Cell and Developmental Biology, Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics, and  Cystic Fibrosis/Pulmonary Research and Treatment Center, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, North Carolina 27599.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, July 6, 2005 , and in revised form, September 23, 2005.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	4	Less is known about the ability of serine/threonine phosphatases to regulate CFTR activity or how they are compartmentalized with CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Work from many laboratories suggests that multiple phosphatases, including PP2A, PP2B, PP2C, and alkaline phosphatase, are involved in the deactivation of CFTR (13-17).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In vitro, PP2A and PP2C are most effective in dephosphorylating purified CFTR and recombinant R domain.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Furthermore, exogenous PP2A and PP2C inactivate CFTR in excised membrane patches (13, 18).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In human sweat ducts, cardiac myocytes, 3T3 fibroblasts, and Hi-5 insect cells, inhibitors of PP2A increase CFTR channel activity (14, 16, 18, 19).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Likewise, PP2B inhibitors stimulate CFTR in NIH 3T3 fibroblasts (17).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	10	 However, the contribution of PP2A and PP2B to CFTR deactivation may vary in different cell types (15, 20).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In baby hamster kidney cells, PP2C co-immunoprecipitates with exogenously expressed CFTR (20).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Additionally, PP2C overexpression in Fischer rat thyroid cells decreases CFTR chloride conductance (15).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	13	 However, the ability of endogenous PP2C to regulate CFTR in native epithelial tissues is unclear, since no PP2C inhibitors have been identified.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	14	 To date, no single phosphatase has been demonstrated to be both necessary and sufficient to completely down-regulate CFTR channel activity, suggesting that CFTR is dephosphorylated by multiple phosphatases.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Here, we present evidence for a direct interaction between CFTR and the serine/threonine phosphatase PP2A.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	16	 This interaction involves the COOH terminus of CFTR and the PP2A B' regulatory subunit.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	17	 PP2A localizes to the apical cell surface, where it negatively regulates CFTR channel activity in Calu-3 cells and intact mouse jejunum.
