0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Furthermore, inhibition of PP2A increases the airway surface liquid in primary human bronchial epithelial (HBE) cells by a mechanism requiring CFTR channel activity.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	19	 We conclude that PP2A is indeed a relevant CFTR phosphatase in epithelial tissues.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	20	Affinity Purification of CFTR-interacting Proteins Peptides corresponding to residues 1375-1401, 1411-1441, 1451-1476, and 1471-1480 of human CFTR synthesized with an N-terminal biotin tag (Genemed Synthesis) were resuspended in 50 mM Tris-Cl (pH 7.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	21	 20 nmol of the peptides were immobilized on 100  microl of streptavidin-agarose (Sigma) and incubated with Calu-3 cell lysates.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Lysates were prepared by incubating twenty 100-mm dishes of Calu-3 cells in binding buffer (50 mM Tris-Cl, 150 mM NaCl, 0.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	23	2% CHAPS, and protease (Roche Applied Science) and phosphatase (Sigma) inhibitor mixtures) at 4  degrees C for 1 h.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Following ultracentrifugation, the soluble fraction was precleared over empty streptavidin beads and incubated with CFTR peptides conjugated to streptavidin beads for 1 h.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The bound fractions were washed extensively in binding buffer, eluted with 5% formic acid, and lyophilized.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Prior to MS analysis, the protein samples were reduced, alkylated, and digested with proteomics grade trypsin (Sigma).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The peptides were analyzed by liquid chromatography-MS/MS on a Q-Tof micro (Waters, Manchester, UK).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	28	 All data were acquired using Masslynx 4.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	29	0 software and than processed using Proteinlynx module.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The processed data were searched against updated NCBInr and Sprot data bases using the Mascot search engine.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Mascot probability-based Mowse individual ion scores of  > 46 were accepted as indicating identity or extensive homology (p  <  0.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The MS/MS spectrum scores between 20 and 45 were examined individually, with the acceptance criteria being that the parent and fragment ion masses were within the calibrated tolerance limits and that the spectrum contained an extended series of consecutive y- or b- ions.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Small scale experiments analyzed by Western blot were performed using lysates from two 100-mm dishes of Calu-3 cells and 2 nmol of CFTR peptide.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	34	In Vitro Binding Assays Binding assays were performed as described previously, with several exceptions (21, 23).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Briefly, the cDNA sequence of the human PP2A B' subunit was amplified by PCR and cloned into the BamHI and XhoI sites of pET-28C (Novagen, Madison, WI).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Recombinant B' subunit was produced in either rabbit reticulocyte lysates (Promega, Madison, WI) or BL21 Escherichia coli (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	37	 For reticulocyte lysates, the PP2A B' subunit was purified using Ni2+-nitrilotriacetic acid beads (Qiagen) in binding buffer (50 mM Tris-Cl (pH 7.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	38	 To remove any reticulocyte proteins that co-purify with the B' subunit, the beads were washed three times in binding buffer plus 2 M urea followed by three washes in binding buffer.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The B' subunit was eluted with binding buffer plus 10 mM EDTA.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Bacterially, expression of B' subunit was performed as previously described (24).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Purified PP2A core dimer consisting of the catalytic and A regulatory subunit was obtained from Promega (Madison, WI).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	42	Purified proteins were then incubated with indicated CFTR peptides immobilized to streptavidin beads in binding buffer plus 0.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	43	2% bovine serum albumin for 1 h at 4 degrees C.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Following extensive washing, the bound proteins were eluted, resolved by SDS-PAGE, and analyzed by Western blot or phosphorimaging analysis.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	45	Co-immunoprecipitation and Phosphatase Assays Calu-3 cells were scraped into a hypotonic lysis buffer (150 mM Tris-Cl, 10 mM NaCl, and protease inhibitors) and physically disrupted by Dounce homogenization on ice.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The lysates were centrifuged at 500 x g for 10 min to remove nuclei and unbroken cells.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The supernatant was subsequently centrifuged at 100,000 x g for 1 h to pellet cell membranes.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Membranes were resuspended in binding buffer for 1 h on ice.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	49	 CFTR was immunoprecipitated using CFTR 596 antibodies (gift of Dr.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Riordan, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC) or isotype-matched control antibodies covalently conjugated to Protein G dynabeads.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Bound proteins were washed extensively and analyzed by Western blot using specific antibodies for PP2A subunits or for phosphatase activity using a PP2A immunoprecipitation phosphatase assay kit (Upstate%20Biotechnology">Upstate Biotechnology).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	52	CFTR Currents in Outside-out Membrane Patches of Calu-3 Cells The procedures were essentially as described previously (6).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Briefly, CFTR Cl- channel activity was recorded at a membrane potential of 30 mV with a 6-8-megaohm resistance for an open pipette.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Both the pipette and the bath solutions were the same as described previously (6).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	55	 CFTR channel activity was recorded digitally (PClamp software) for 300 s following patch excision.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	56	 PP2A inhibitors or protein kinase A inhibitor was included in the pipette solution as indicated.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	57	CFTR Currents in Mouse Jejunum Details of this approach have been described previously (25, 26).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Briefly, sections of the midportion of mouse jejunum were studied under short circuit current (Isc) conditions during a 90-min recording.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	59	 A constant voltage pulse (1-5 mV, 1-s duration) was applied to the tissue every minute (Physiologic Instruments, San Diego, CA).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Potential difference and resistance were calculated by Ohm's law from the changes in Isc in response to the voltage pulse.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Tissues were treated with 100  microM endothall or vehicle.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	62	Confocal Microscopy Measurement of Periciliary Liquid (PCL) The technique has been described in detail (27).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Briefly, phosphate-buffered saline (20  microl) containing 2 mg/ml Texas Red-dextran (10 kDa; Molecular Probes, Inc.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	64	, Eugene, OR) and benzamil (10-4 M) was added to cultured bronchial epithelium, and excess was aspirated to bring PCL height to 7  microm.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The CFTR-specific inhibitor CFTRinh172 was also included where noted at a concentration of 10-5 M.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	66	 To measure the average height of the PCL, five predetermined points (one central and four 2 mm from the edge of the culture) were XZ-scanned as previously described (27).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	67	 For all studies, perfluorocarbon was added mucosally to prevent evaporation of the PCL, and the culture was placed on the stage of the confocal microscope over a serosal reservoir (80  microl of TES-buffered Ringer).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Okadaic acid was added to the apical surface as a dry powder in perfluorocarbon (5  microg of okadaic acid/25 ml of perfluorocarbon/cm2 of culture).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Perfluorocarbon has no effect on PCL height or ion transport, as previously described (27).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	70	View larger version (31K):    FIGURE 1.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	71	 MS analysis of PP2A subunits associated with the CFTR COOH terminus.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	72	 A, table of PP2A subunit peptides identified by MS/MS analysis of Calu-3 cell proteins associated with CFTR-(1451-1476).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	73	 B, example of an MS/MS spectrum used to specifically identify the B' subunit.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	74	 y ions and corresponding amino acids are labeled on the spectrum.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	75	  PP2A is a major cellular phosphatase that regulates many protein targets.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	76	 PP2A functions as a heterotrimeric complex composed of a catalytic subunit and two regulatory subunits, A and B (34).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The specificity of PP2A is determined by the unique combination of regulatory subunits associated with the catalytic subunit.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The A regulatory subunit is encoded by one of two genes and , which are 86% identical.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The A regulatory subunit is tightly associated with the catalytic subunit and functions as a scaffold to recruit the B regulatory subunit.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The B regulatory subunit is highly divergent in comparison with the other PP2A subunits.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The B regulatory subunit is divided into the B, B', B'', and B''' families, which are encoded by at least 14 different genes, some of which produce as many as five splice variants.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The diversity of regulatory subunits gives rise to over 75 distinct PP2A enzymes.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	83	 By mass spectrometry, we observe peptides from all three PP2A subunits (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Importantly, the MS/MS spectra provide amino acid sequence information that allowed us to precisely identify the PP2A regulatory subunits associated with CFTR-(1451-1476) as A and B' (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	85	By Western blot, we confirmed that the PP2A catalytic, A regulatory, and B' regulatory subunits associate with CFTR-(1451-1476) but not other CFTR C-terminal peptides (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Furthermore, these PP2A subunits also co-precipitate with endogenous CFTR from Calu-3 cell membranes (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	87	 2B), consistent with an interaction in vivo.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The PP2A B subunit, which is structurally unrelated to the B' family, does not co-purify with CFTR-(1451-1476) or co-immunoprecipitate with endogenous CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	89	 In addition, we asked whether PP2A phosphatase activity purified with full-length CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	90	 CFTR immunoprecipitates were assayed for PP2A using a colorimetric phosphatase assay.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	91	 We find that a PP2A-like activity specifically co-precipitates with CFTR, but not an IgG control (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Characteristic of PP2A, the phosphatase activity was inhibited by 1  microM okadaic acid or 1  microM endothall, potent inhibitors of PP2A (IC50 = 0.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Although okadaic acid and endothall can also inhibit PP1 (IC50 = 10 nM and 5  microM, respectively), previous studies have found no evidence to support the ability of PP1 to physically associate with CFTR, to dephosphorylate CFTR in vitro, or regulate channel activity (13, 18, 20).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Although PP2C has been shown to be associated with CFTR in baby hamster kidney cells, the assay buffer does not contain Mg2+, which is required for PP2C activity.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Taken together, these data suggest that the phosphatase activity associated with CFTR is PP2A.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	96	View larger version (35K):    FIGURE 2.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The PP2A heterotrimer co-purifies with CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	98	 A, biotinylated CFTR peptides were immobilized on streptavidin beads and incubated in Calu-3 cell lysates.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Bound proteins were resolved by SDS-PAGE and analyzed by Western blot using antibodies against the PP2A catalytic, A regulatory, B' regulatory, and B regulatory subunits.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	100	 B and C, Calu-3 cell lysates were incubated with either anti-CFTR monoclonal antibodies or isotype-matched mouse IgG covalently coupled to protein G dynabeads.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The beads were extensively washed and analyzed by Western blot using specific PP2A subunit antibodies (B) or assayed for serine/threonine phosphatase activity using an Upstate%20Biotechnology">Upstate Biotechnology phosphatase assay kit (C).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	102	 To determine the contribution of PP2A to the total phosphatase activity, the PP2A inhibitors okadaic acid or endothall were added during the phosphatase assay (n = 4 for each condition).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The data represent mean values (n = 5)  plus or minus  S.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	104	 IP, immunoprecipitation; IB, immunoblotting.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	105	  The PP2A B' Subunit Binds Directly to the COOH Terminus of CFTR It is clear that multiple phosphatases can regulate CFTR channel activity.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	106	 However, the degree to which PP2A contributes to this regulation varies in different functional assays and cell systems.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Given the diversity of PP2A enzymes, we were intrigued by the possibility that the B regulatory subunit may, in part, account for these differences.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Therefore, we asked whether the PP2A B' subunit could interact directly with CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	109	 We find that PP2A B' subunit expressed and purified from reticulocyte lysates binds to CFTR-(1451-1476) but not other CFTR C-terminal peptides (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	110	 NHERF-1, previously shown to interact with the extreme COOH terminus of CFTR, is enriched by the CFTR-(1471-1480) peptide, demonstrating the specificity of this assay (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Although we do not find the catalytic or A subunit associated with the purified B' subunit from reticulocyte lysates (data not shown), we cannot rule out the possibility that these subunits are present at low levels and may be influencing binding to CFTR-(1451-1476).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Using bacterially expressed, purified B' subunit, we observe direct and dose-dependent binding to CFTR-(1451-1476) (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Furthermore, we also find that the core PP2A dimer, composed of the catalytic and A regulatory subunit, do not bind to CFTR-(1451-1476) unless the B' subunit is present (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Whereas it is not clear whether the B' subunit alone is necessary and sufficient for targeting PP2A to CFTR, these data suggest that the B' subunit may play a critical role in the binding specificity.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	115	PP2A Localizes to the Apical Cell Surface of Airway Epithelia If PP2A is a physiologically relevant CFTR phosphatase, we reasoned that its subcellular localization should partially overlap with CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Given the large number of PP2A substrates, we expect the ubiquitously expressed catalytic and tightly coupled A regulatory subunits to have a broad cellular distribution.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	117	 However, specific B regulatory subunits, which target the PP2A enzyme to distinct subcellular compartments, should have a more restricted localization.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Using a pan-B' antibody, which recognizes all five gene products (, , , , and ), we examined the localization of PP2A in the human airway.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	119	 The B' subunits exhibit a broad subcellular distribution in the human airway (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	120	 We find that B' staining strongly localizes to the apical membrane of ciliated cells in superficial epithelia and gland ducts, consistent with the localization of CFTR in these tissues.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Although we cannot unambiguously attribute the apical localization to the B' subunit, it is likely that this staining reflects the distribution of one or a combination of the cytosolic B' subunits, B', B', B', and B' (35).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	122	 In addition, we observe staining of perinuclear membranes and nuclear speckles, which is consistent with the observation that the B' and B' localize to the nucleus (35, 36).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	123	View larger version (20K):    FIGURE 3.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The B' subunit directly interacts with the CFTR-(1451-1476).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	125	 A, the indicated CFTR COOH-terminal peptides were immobilized and incubated with radiolabeled B' subunit or NHERF-1.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The bound fraction was separated by SDS-PAGE and analyzed by phosphorimaging analysis.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	127	 B, 2  microM CFTR-(1411-1441) or CFTR-(1451-1476) was immbolized and incubated with bacterially expressed B' subunit at the indicated concentrations.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Bound proteins were washed and analyzed by Western blot using a pan-B' antibody.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	129	 C, immobilized CFTR-(1411-1441) or CFTR-(1451-1476) was incubated with purified PP2A core dimer (0.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	130	05 units) with or without B' (1  microg).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Samples were analyzed by Western blot using PP2A subunit antibodies.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	132	View larger version (99K):    FIGURE 4.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The PP2A B' regulatory subunit localizes to the apical compartment of ciliated airway cells.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Shown are representative images of the PP2A B' regulatory subunit localization in gland ducts and superficial epithelium of the human airway.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Confocal images were acquired in four channels with independent laser sources: left, differential interference contrast (DIC) and nuclear staining (4',6-diamidino-2-phenylindole; blue); center, actin cytoskeleton (rhodamine phalloidin; red); right, PP2A B' subunit family (green).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The arrowheads indicate regions of apical staining.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The bottom panel shows IgG controls on sections of superficial epithelium (S.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	138	  As we expected, the PP2A catalytic and A regulatory subunits are more broadly localized in airway epithelia (data not shown) but clearly localized to the apical cell surface of ciliated cells.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The antibodies directed against the catalytic and A regulatory subunits detect both gene products for each subunit.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Thus, these antibodies label every PP2A molecule that we expect to give a broad distribution in all cell types.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Whereas the pan-B' antibody detects five distinct gene products, this still only represents one of four families of the highly divergent PP2A B regulatory subunit.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Accordingly, the staining pattern for the B' subunit exhibits a more restricted distribution, including the apical cell surface.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	143	 These localization data support our biochemical evidence for an in vivo interaction between CFTR and PP2A.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Furthermore, the PP2A subunits are concentrated at the apical cell surface, suggesting a potential role in regulating the channel activity of CFTR at the plasma membrane.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	145	PP2A Inhibition Prevents CFTR Rundown in Excised Patches Our previous work and the results of others are consistent with the membrane localization of the cAMP signaling machinery that regulates CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	146	 In excised membrane patches, endogenous PKA activity activates CFTR when exogenous cAMP is added in excess or when membrane-associated adenylate cyclase is activated by receptors (6, 9).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	147	 In patch preparations, CFTR channel activity reflects the phosphorylation status of the channel, which is regulated by a balance between PKA and endogenous phosphatases (6, 18, 37).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Consequently, CFTR channel gating is increased under conditions in which PKA activity is elevated, such as increased cAMP or the inhibition of phosphodiesterases (1, 10).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	149	 We hypothesize that "rundown" of CFTR activity following excision results from a shift in the balance between endogenous PKA and phosphatase activities.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Based on our biochemical analyses demonstrating a physical association between CFTR and PP2A, we tested this hypothesis by examining CFTR rundown in excised patches under control conditions and in the presence of PP2A inhibitors.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	151	 We compared the average pipette current during the first 30 s of outside out recordings with the average pipette current measured from 270 to 300 s, as performed in previous studies (38).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Under control conditions, the pipette solution contained ATP and GTP, conditions that allow CFTR gating to reflect the activity of endogenous PKA (6).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Furthermore, current flow through the patch is mediated by Cl- traversing CFTR, since no channel events are observed, and pipette current is near zero with protein kinase A inhibitor (100 nM) in the pipette (0.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Under these conditions, CFTR activity declines variably over 5 min (I = -0.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	155	 However, the presence of the PP2A inhibitors okadaic acid or endothall in the pipette prevented channel rundown (I = 0.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	156	88, respectively, n = 10 for each treatment) (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Although endothall and okadaic acid inhibit PP2A most potently, they can also inhibit other phosphatases such as PP1, PP4, and PP5 (39, 40).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Therefore, we also tested the specific inhibitor I2PP2A, which does not inhibit PP1, PP2B, or PP2C (41, 42).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Similar to endothall and okadaic acid, I2PP2A (1.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	160	7  microM) also prevented CFTR channel rundown (I = 1.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	161	View larger version (32K):    FIGURE 5.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	162	 PP2A inhibitors functionally regulate CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	163	 A and B, basal CFTR currents measured in apical patches were generated from Calu-3 cells in the outside-out configuration.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Patches were recorded under control conditions as outlined under "Experimental Procedures.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	165	" Where indicated, patches were prepared in the presence of okadaic acid (OA; 3 nM), endothall (1  microM), and I2PP2A (1.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	166	 A, representative traces for each condition are shown.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	167	 For endothall and I2PP2A, traces were expanded on the x axis to clearly show discrete single channel events.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	168	 B, summary of the patch clamp data in Calu-3 cells.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The Isc values for each treatment are compared with Isc = 0 (t test, p  <  0.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	170	005) and compared with Isc of control samples (t test, p  <  0.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	171	017; Bonferroni's post hoc relative to control; *, p  <  0.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	172	 C, CFTR currents were measured in intact mouse jejunum in Ussing chambers as described previously.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Tissues were treated with endothall (100  microM) or vehicle for the duration of the recording.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Isc is represented as the change in CFTR chloride currents at time 0 versus 90 min.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The data represent mean values (n = 4)  plus or minus  S.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	176	View larger version (14K):    FIGURE 6.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	177	 PP2A inhibition increases PCL height in primary human airway cultures.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	178	 A, PCL height was assessed in primary cultures of human bronchial epithelia cells treated with vehicle (phosphate-buffered saline) or okadaic acid (OA;5  microg/25 ml of perfluorocarbon/cm2 of culture) in the presence or absence of CFTR inhibitor 172 (10-5 M) for 10 min.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The PCL was labeled with Texas Red dextran, and the height was measured by confocal microscopy.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Representative images taken at time 0 or 10 min for each condition are shown.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	181	 B, summary of confocal data represented as percentage change in PCL height at time 0 versus 10 min of the indicated treatments.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The data represent mean values (n = 6 for all conditions with the exception of n = 7 for okadaic acid)  plus or minus  S.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	183	 (Treatments were compared with controls by Mann-Whitney U test; *, p  <  0.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	184	  PP2A Inhibitors Prevent CFTR Rundown in an Intact Epithelium Consistent with our observation that CFTR and PP2A physically interact, the effect of PP2A inhibitors on CFTR in excised patches suggests that PP2A is present in the patches and is, therefore, compartmentalized in close proximity to CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Furthermore, the inhibitor data demonstrate that endogenous PP2A can regulate CFTR channel activity.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	186	 These results strongly suggest that PP2A functions as a relevant CFTR phosphatase in epithelial tissues.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	187	 We also tested whether PP2A inhibitors altered basal CFTR activity in an intact epithelium.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	188	 We measured basal short circuit chloride currents in freshly excised sections of mouse jejunum in Ussing chamber experiments.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Previous studies demonstrated that CFTR constitutes the major chloride channel in these preparations, since jejunum from CFTR-/- mice do not exhibit significant chloride conductance (43).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	190	 We find that over the course of control experiments, basal CFTR activity declined over time (Isc =-9.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	191	 In agreement with our patch clamp data, we find that the PP2A inhibitor endothall (100  microM) prevented rundown of CFTR activity, resulting in increased chloride conductance during the course of the 90-min recording (Isc = 12.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	192	Inhibition of PP2A Increases the Airway Surface Liquid Height Airway epithelial cells regulate the composition of the thin layer of PCL critical for innate host defense.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	193	 In CF lung disease, PCL volume is depleted, reflecting an imbalance in solute transport across the epithelium (44-47).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Ultimately, PCL depletion results in defective mucociliary clearance, which supports bacterial colonization and exposes individuals to life-threatening infections (27, 44-48).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Previous studies have demonstrated that CFTR mediates the majority of PCL secretion and plays a fundamental role in maintaining basal PCL volume (36, 49).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Therefore, we asked whether inhibition of PP2A would increase CFTR activity and thereby increase PCL levels in primary HBE cultures.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	197	 The PCL was labeled with florescent dextran as previously described (27).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	198	 PCL height was measured immediately before and 10 min after the indicated treatments.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Vehicle treatment did not significantly change PCL height (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	200	 However, cultures treated with okadaic acid exhibited an 30% increase in PCL height (PCL =+2.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Because PP2A inhibition is likely to influence the activities of many cellular proteins, we asked whether CFTR was required for the increase in PCL.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Consistent with previous data demonstrating the importance of CFTR in PCL secretion, we find that the CFTR inhibitor, CFTRinh172, causes PCL height to decrease by 30% (PCL =-3.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Furthermore, in the presence of CFTRinh172, okadaic acid was similar to the CFTRinh172 alone (PCL =-2.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Thus, the inhibition of PP2A with okadaic acid increases PCL height by a mechanism that requires CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	205	 These results are consistent with our biochemical and electrophysiological studies demonstrating that CFTR is physically and functionally associated with PP2A in epithelial tissues.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	206	The regulation of CFTR by phosphatases has been extensively studied.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Whereas it is clear from the work of many laboratories that multiple phosphatases can affect CFTR channel activity, the specificity of this regulation is poorly understood.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	208	 We identified PP2A in a biochemical screen for proteins that associate with residues 1451-1476 of the CFTR COOH terminus.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	209	 The power of our approach is illustrated by the fact that we unambiguously identified the exact PP2A regulatory subunits associated with CFTR by mass spectrometry as A and B'.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	210	 To date, at least 21 distinct PP2A regulatory subunits have been identified (2 A regulatory and 19 B regulatory subunits) (for a review, see Ref.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Importantly, it is the unique combination of regulatory subunits that governs the enzymatic activity, substrate specificity, and localization of PP2A enzymes (35, 51).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Thus, the identification of the exact subunits associated with CFTR provides insight into the specificity of CFTR channel regulation by phosphatases.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	213	Using purified proteins, we find that the divergent B' subunit interacts directly with CFTR-(1451-1476) and is required for the binding of the catalytic and A regulatory subunits.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	214	 These data suggest that the B' subunit may target the PP2A enzyme to CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	215	 It is intriguing to speculate that the expression of the B' subunit may account for the differences in the ability of PP2A to regulate CFTR channel activity in different cell types and tissues.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Many of the CFTR phosphatase studies have utilized heterologous expression systems such as Chinese hamster ovary cells (13), baby hamster kidney cells (20), and Hi-5 insect cells (19), which may or may not express relevant CFTR phosphatases and subunits (13, 19, 20).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	217	 We are unable to ask whether the PP2A B' subunit is expressed in these cell types by reverse transcription-PCR, since there is insufficient sequence information available at this time.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	218	 However, the expression of specific PP2A subunits in these cells should be an important consideration for future experiments.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	219	 (33) reported an interaction between CFTR and PP2A, which involves the direct binding of the ubiquitously expressed PP2A A regulatory subunit to the CFTR regulatory domain.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	220	 To demonstrate the specificity of the CFTR/A interaction, Vastiau et al.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	221	 (33) showed that the overexpressed heat repeats 1-10 cause a decrease in CFTR rundown, presumably due to the disruption of the A/CFTR interaction.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	222	 However, the PP2A B subunits also bind to heat repeats 1-10 of the A subunit and would have been dislodged from the phosphatase complex (52, 53).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Thus, in these assays, the observed decrease in CFTR rundown could be attributed to the disruption of the interaction between CFTR and both the PP2A A and B regulatory subunits.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Nonetheless, the anchoring of PP2A to the CFTR chloride channel may involve multiple sites of interaction mediated by the PP2A A and B' subunits.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	225	Previous studies have demonstrated a clear role for PP2A in the deactivation or rundown of CFTR in native sweat ducts, cardiac myocytes, baby hamster kidney cells, 3T3 fibroblasts, and Hi-5 cells (14, 16, 18, 19).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	226	 However, the importance of PP2A in CFTR regulation in epithelial tissues seems variable.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Thus, we chose to study the physical and functional association of CFTR and PP2A in airway epithelia.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Indeed, we found that CFTR and PP2A interacted in Calu-3 cells as the PP2A catalytic, A regulatory, and B' regulatory subunits specifically co-precipitate with endogenous CFTR (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Additionally, we examined the localization of PP2A subunits in the human airway.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	230	 If, in fact, PP2A regulates CFTR channel activity in epithelial tissues, we would expect the phosphatase to be present at the apical cell surface, consistent with the localization of CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The ubiquitously expressed PP2A catalytic subunit and A regulatory subunit had a diffuse staining pattern, which clearly included the apical membrane of the superficial epithelium (data not shown).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Alternatively, staining with a pan-B' regulatory subunit antibody showed a more restricted distribution, including strong staining at the apical plasma membrane (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Thus, the PP2A subunits associated with CFTR are present at the apical cell surface where CFTR functions.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Since the available B' antibodies detect all family members, we cannot rule out the possibility that other B' subunits other than B' may also associate with CFTR or localize to the apical surface of airway epithelia.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	235	 (54) identified an interaction between Chk2 and the PP2A B' subunit and found that the other highly similar B' family members, B', B', B', and B', were also able to bind to Chk2 in vitro.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Consequently, other PP2A B' regulatory subunits may interact with CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	237	 However, we did not find an association between CFTR and a structurally unrelated B regulatory family member, B (PR55a) by pull-down (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	238	 2A) or immunoprecipitation (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Thus, the PP2A molecules associated with CFTR at least appear to be specific for the B' family.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	240	We found that CFTR and PP2A are functionally associated in airway and intestinal epithelial cells.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	241	 In the presence of PP2A inhibitors, CFTR rundown was blocked in outside-out membrane patches from Calu-3 cells and intact mouse jejunum (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Consistent with our biochemical observations, the presence of PP2A in the membrane patches containing CFTR strongly suggests that these proteins are closely compartmentalized.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Furthermore, our data suggest that PP2A is a relevant CFTR phosphatase in epithelial tissues, in agreement with Vastiau et al.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	244	 (33), who found that the addition of okadaic acid in Caco-2 epithelial cells delayed channel rundown following forskolin treatment.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	245	 In T84 and airway epithelial cells, PP2A inhibitors did not block the rundown of CFTR following maximal activation by forskolin (15, 20).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	246	 A major difference between our data and data of other studies is that we chose to measure the effect of PP2A inhibitors on basal CFTR currents as opposed to CFTR currents following maximal activation with forskolin or PKA.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	247	 It is possible that endogenous PP2A plays a role in regulating basal CFTR currents but that other phosphatases contribute to the deactivation of hyperphosphorylated CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Future studies are needed to address the relative contribution of different phosphatases to the regulation of CFTR channel activity in epithelial tissues.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	249	In the airways, the mucus layer provides a defensive barrier that traps and clears bacteria and noxious particles from the airways (44-47).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The underlying PCL provides a low viscosity fluid that facilitates ciliary beating and mucus clearance (12, 55, 56).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Based on inhibitor studies, CFTR has been demonstrated to play a central role in the maintenance of basal PCL height (36, 49).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Furthermore, the loss of CFTR function results in decreased PCL height and increased viscosity.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	253	 If, in fact, PP2A is a relevant CFTR phosphatase in airway epithelia, we reasoned that the inhibition of PP2A should increase CFTR chloride conductance and ultimately increase PCL height in primary HBE cultures.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	254	 We find that the inhibition of PP2A by the addition of okadaic acid to primary HBE cultures produces a 30% increase in PCL height, consistent with an increase in CFTR activity (Fig.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Additionally, when CFTR channel activity is blocked by CFTRinh172, okadaic acid does not have a significant effect of the PCL.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Thus, okadaic acid treatment increases PCL height through a CFTR-dependent mechanism, consistent with our hypothesis that CFTR is compartmentalized with and regulated by PP2A in epithelial tissues.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	257	In addition to regulating channel activity by dephosphorylating CFTR, PP2A may also be important for mediating other signaling and trafficking events for CFTR.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	258	 For example, AMP-activated protein kinase, which directly binds to CFTR and negatively regulates channel activity, can also directly interact with PP2A via the A regulatory subunit (12, 56).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Moreover, the direct interaction between CFTR and AMP-activated protein kinase has been mapped to CFTR residues 1420-1457, adjacent to the residues where we observe PP2A binding (residues 1451-1476) (12).
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	260	 It is interesting to speculate that PP2A and AMP-activated protein kinase may function to stabilize each other's interactions with CFTR or may compete for binding to the CFTR COOH terminus.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	261	In summary, we establish that CFTR is physically and functionally associated with PP2A.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Our data demonstrate that PP2A directly interacts with CFTR via the B' regulatory subunit.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Furthermore, we provide the first evidence that PP2A regulates CFTR in airway epithelia, the major tissue affected in CF.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Finally, we demonstrate that the inhibition of PP2A in well differentiated HBE cultures increases PCL height.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Because decreased PCL underlies the basic defect in airway clearance observed in CF patients, our data suggest that PP2A may be a useful therapeutic target for CF.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	266	   FOOTNOTES   * This work was supported by American Heart Association Grant 0315363U (to W.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	267	), the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, and National Institutes of Health Grants HL34422 (to M.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	268	 The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	269	 This article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	271	1 To whom correspondence should be addressed: Dept.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	272	 of Cell and Developmental Biology, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, 506 Taylor Hall, Chapel Hill, NC 27599.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	273	: 919-966-9792; Fax: 919-966-1856; E-mail: milg{at}med.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	274	2 The abbreviations used are: CF, cystic fibrosis; CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; PKA, cAMP-dependent protein kinase; AKAP, A kinase-anchoring protein; HBE, human bronchial epithelial; MS, mass spectrometry; TES, 2-{[2-hydroxy-1,1-bis(hydroxymethyl)ethyl]amino}ethanesulfonic acid; PCL, periciliary liquid.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	275	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank T.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Rogers for excellent technical assistance.
0.41414222.16239222.html.plaintext.txt	277	HOME HELP FEEDBACK SUBSCRIPTIONS ARCHIVE SEARCH TABLE OF CONTENTS  All ASBMB Journals   Molecular and Cellular Proteomics   Journal of Lipid Research   Biochemistry and Molecular Biology Education  Copyright   2005 by the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	0	Characterization of 19 disease-associated missense mutations in the regulatory domain of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	1	Anne Vankeerberghen, Lin Wei1, Martine Jaspers, Jean-Jacques Cassiman, Bernd Nilius and Harry Cuppens*.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	2	Centre for Human Genetics and 1Department of Physiology, University of Leuven, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received May 14, 1998; Revised and Accepted July 17, 1998.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	4	In order to gain a better insight into the structure and function of the regulatory domain (RD) of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein, 19 RD missense mutations that had been identified in patients were functionally characterized.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Nine of these (I601F, L610S, A613T, D614G, I618T, L619S, H620P, G628R and L633P) resulted in aberrant processing.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	6	 No or a very small number of functional CFTR proteins will therefore appear at the cell membrane in cells expressing these mutants.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	7	 These mutations were clustered in the N-terminal part of the RD, suggesting that this subdomain has a folding pattern that is very sensitive to amino acid changes.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Mutations that caused no aberrant processing were further characterized at the electrophysiological level.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	9	 First, they were studied at the whole cell level in Xenopus laevis oocytes.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Mutants that induced a whole cell current that was significantly different from wild-type CFTR were subsequently analysed at the single channel level in COS1 cells transiently expressing the different mutant and wild-type proteins.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Three mutant chloride channels, G622D, R792G and E822K CFTR, were characterized by significantly lower intrinsic chloride channel activities compared with wild-type CFTR.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Two mutations, H620Q and A800G, resulted in increased intrinsic chloride transport activities.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Finally, T665S and E826K CFTR had single channel properties not significantly different from wild-type CFTR.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	14	Cystic fibrosis (CF), caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene, is the most common lethal autosomal recessive disorder in the Caucasian population.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The disease is characterized by abnormal salt transport across the apical border of epithelial cells (1).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The CFTR protein (2-4) is a transmembrane protein consisting of two repeated motifs, each composed of a transmembrane domain and a nucleotide-binding domain (NBD), separated by a highly charged regulatory domain (RD).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The RD consists of alternating clusters of positively and negatively charged amino acids and harbours multiple consensus sequences for phosphorylation by protein kinase A (PKA) and protein kinase C (PKC) (3).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	18	Reconstitution of the CFTR protein into proteoliposomes proved that it forms a linear low conductance chloride channel (5).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Activation of CFTR is complex and occurs in different steps.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	20	 First, the RD is phosphorylated by cAMP-dependent PKA.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	21	 This step is enhanced through pre-stimulation with PKC (6).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In a second step, ATP binds to and is hydrolysed at the first NBD, thereby opening the channel and allowing chloride ions to flow down the electrochemical gradient.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In a third step, ATP hydrolysis at NBD2 closes the channel (7).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	24	 As long as the RD is phosphorylated, ATP can re-open the channel.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Dephosphorylation of the RD by phosphatases (8) results in final closure of the channel.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	26	The precise mechanisms by which the RD regulates anion flow is far from understood.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Although the RD contains nine consensus sites for PKA, they all are redundant and phosphorylation at a single site is sufficient for channel activation (9).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Given the fact that activation of CFTR can only occur through PKA phosphorylation, this degeneration of phosphorylation sites is very puzzling.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	29	 On the other hand, the channel can be locked in the activated state through mutagenesis of Ser to Asp moieties at the PKA consensus sites (10).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	30	 This observation indicates that negative charges introduced by PKA phosphorylation are important for channel activation.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Deleting part of the RD (amino acids 708-835) will also yield a CFTR channel that escapes PKA regulation and that is constitutively active (11).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	32	 It was therefore hypothesized that the RD closes the chloride channel pore and that it will be repulsed from the pore when negative charges are introduced.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Although these [Delta]R-CFTR proteins are constitutively active, their open probability (Po) is only one third of that found for wild-type CFTR.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Moreover, addition of an unphosphorylated RD to [Delta]R-CFTR has no effect on this channel activity, while addition of a phosphorylated RD doubles the Po.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	35	 This increase in activity apparently results from a higher rate of channel opening because of a higher sensitivity of NBD1 for ATP.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Based on these findings it was hypothesized that phosphorylation of the RD changes the sensitivity of NBD1 for ATP (12,13).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	37	Given the crucial role of the RD in the regulation of channel activities, a thorough knowledge of its structure and function is warranted.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	38	 In this regard, the known RD missense mutations found in patients could provide important information about the metabolism and the function of the RD.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Our investigations of 19 missense mutations will show that some mutations affect protein maturation, others lead to decreased function or gain of function, while still others appear to have no effect in the assay systems used.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	40	RESULTS Cross-species analysis of the RD.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	41	When exon 13 sequences of CFTR from nine different organisms were aligned (Fig.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	42	 1), a high conservation of the N-terminal part (RD1, up to amino acid 650) was observed.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	43	 In the C-terminal two- thirds (RD2), only the PKA phosphorylation sites were conserved and they were all located in this subdomain.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The RD is highly charged, in part due to the presence of PKA consensus sequences which are highly basic.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Two acidic amino acid stretches were found.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The first one (amino acids 725-730) is located in the first half of RD2 and, although this region is poorly conserved, its negative charge was found in all species studied.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The second acid region (amino acids 822-828) was located at the end of the RD and was completely conserved.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Alignment of exon 13 sequences derived from different species.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Exon 13 derived from spiny dogfish (Squalus acanthias, GenBank accession no.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	50	 116141), African clawed frog (Xenopus laevis, GenBank accession nos 64623 and 1617482), cow (Bos Taurus, GenBank accession no.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	51	 461719), sheep (Ovis aries, GenBank accession no.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	52	 862652), human (Homo sapiens, GenBank accession no.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	53	 625338), European rabbit (Oryctolagus cuniculuc, GenBank accession no.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	54	 1100985), Norway rat (Rattus norvegicus, GenBank accession no.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	55	 382755) and house mouse (Mus musculus, GenBank accession no.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	56	 192567) were aligned using the GENALIGN multiple sequence alignment program of the Intelligenetics software.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Mutations detected in patients (I601F, L610S, A613T, D614G, I618T, L619S, H620P, H620Q, D622G, G628R, L633P, T665S, F693L, K698R, V754M, R766M, R792G, A800G, I807M, E822K and E826K) are indicated in bold and underlined, the PKA phosphorylation sites by an arrow and the two acidic domains are boxed.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	58	Of the 21 RD missense mutations, three (K698R, R766M and R792G) were located in PKA recognition consensus sites.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Only R766M and R792G disrupted a PKA recognition site and might therefore interfere with CFTR regulation.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The different RD mutations affected almost all, except D648V, V754M and A800G, amino acid moieties that were absolutely or highly conserved.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The high conservation of these mutated amino acids highlights their importance for structure and function.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Six of the 21 disease mutations affected the charge of the amino acid residue and two even resulted in an amino acid of opposite charge.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The latter two were located in the highly conserved C-terminal acidic domain.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	64	Effect of RD mutations on CFTR processing.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	65	At the beginning of this study, 19 different RD mutations (Table 1) had been described in patients.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Since then, it was found that the F693L mutation is a polymorphism (14,15) and that the I807M polymorphism is associated with congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens (CBAVD) (our unpublished data).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Two additional disease mutations, which were not characterized at the functional level in this study, were identified [K698R and V754M (15)].
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The nature by which all the RD mutations cause CFTR dysfunction is, however, unknown.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	69	 It is known that some CFTR mutations, like F508, cause misfolding of the protein in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), resulting in retention and degradation by the quality control system that operates in this cell compartment (16).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Therefore, we first determined the maturation pattern of the different mutant CFTR proteins listed in Table 1.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The different mutations were introduced into wild-type CFTR cDNA, inserted in the eukaryotic expression vector pcDNA3 and the mutant constructs were transfected into COS1 cells.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The corresponding proteins were analysed by means of pulse chase experiments.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	73	 When CFTR translation products enter the ER, they become glycosylated through addition of two high-mannose glycosyl groups on the fourth extracellular loop.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	74	 This event gives rise to the appearance of a 150 kDa protein, the most prominent form of wild-type CFTR after 30 min chase (Fig.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	75	 As the protein leaves the ER and enters the Golgi apparatus, the glycosyl groups become modified to complex sugar groups and this gives rise to a protein with lower mobility (190 kDa), as can be seen in lanes 2 and 3 of Figure 2.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Only the 190 kDa protein will move further to the plasma membrane and will contribute to chloride channel activity.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	77	 This maturation pattern was found not only for wild-type CFTR but also for some of the mutants (Table 2), such as I807M CFTR (Fig.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Some of the mutants, however, presented an abnormal maturation pattern, as can be seen for L610S and D614G CFTR (Fig.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	79	 These mutant proteins only yielded the 150 kDa form, even after 210 min chase, indicating that they gave rise to misfolded proteins that were retained and degraded in the ER.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	80	 In order to confirm that the 150 kDa form was indeed the ER form and the 190 kDa form was the complex glycosylated one, two enzymatic digestions were performed (results not shown).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	81	 When the immunopurified proteins were incubated with endoglycosidase H, an enzyme that only recognizes and cleaves off high-mannose residues, only the 150 kDa forms of the maturing and non-maturing mutants were digested.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	82	 N-glycosidase F, an enzyme that recognizes and degrades high-mannose and complex glycosyl groups, degraded the 150 kDa as well as the 190 kDa form.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The mutations that gave rise to a protein that was not able to proceed to the 190 kDa form (I601F, L610S, A613T, D614G, I618T, L619S, H620P, G628R and L633P; Table 2) are therefore class two mutations (17), where the disease phenotype is caused by the absence of sufficient CFTR protein at the cell surface.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Primers used for mutagenesis Primer Sequence I601F (a1933t) 5[prime]-CTA ACA AAA CTA GGT TTT TGG TCA CTT C-3[prime] L610S (t1961c) 5[prime]-CTA AAA TGG AAC ATT CAA AGA AAG CTG-3[prime] A613T (g1969a) 5[prime]-CAT TTA AAG AAA ACT GAC AAA ATA TTA-3[prime] D614G (a1973g) 5[prime]-CAT TTA AAG AAA GCT GGC AAA ATA TTA A-3[prime] I618T (t1985c) 5[prime]-GAC AAA ATA TTA ACT TTG CAT GAA GG-3[prime] L619S (t1988c) 5[prime]-GAC AAA ATA TTA ATT TCG CAT GAA GGT-3[prime] H620P (a1991c) 5[prime]-CAA AAT ATT AAT TTT GCC TGA AGG TAG C-3[prime] H620Q (t1992g) 5[prime]-AAT ATT AAT TTT GCA GGA AGG TAG CAG-3[prime] G622D (g1997a) 5[prime]-TTG CAT GAA GAT AGC AGC TAT TTT TAT G-3[prime] G628R (g2014c) 5[prime]-GCA GCT ATT TTT ATC GGA CAT TTT C-3[prime] L633P (t2030c) 5[prime]-CAT TTT CAG AAC CCC AAA ATC TAC AGC-3[prime] D648V (a2075t) 5[prime]-CTC ATG GGA TGT GTT TCT TTC GAC C-3[prime] T665S (a2125t) 5[prime]-CAA TCC TAA CTG AGT CCT TAC ACC G-3[prime] F693L (t2209c) 5[prime]-CAG ACT GGA GAG CTT GGG GAA AAA AG-3[prime] R766M (g2429t) 5[prime]-GCA CGA AGG ATG CAG TCT GTC CTG-3[prime] R792G (c2506g) 5[prime]-CAG CAT CCA CAG GAA AAG TGT CAC TG-3[prime] A800G (c2531g) 5[prime]-CTG GCC CCT CAG GGA AAC TTG ACT G-3[prime] I807M (a2553g) 5[prime]-CTG AAC TGG ATA TGT ATT CAA GAA GG-3[prime] E822K (g2596a) 5[prime]-GGC TTG GAA ATA AGT AAA GAA ATT AAC G-3[prime] E826K (g2608a) 5[prime]-GAA GAA ATT AAC AAA GAA GAC TTA AAG-3[prime] Selection primer BstBI 5[prime]-CTC TGG GGT CCG GAA TGA CCG AC-3[prime] Two primers were used for each mutagenesis reaction.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The first is the mutagenesis primer that contains the mutation to be introduced in the CFTR coding region.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The first column lists the amino acid change introduced by the mutation; the nucleotide change is given in parentheses (amino acid and nucleotide assignment according to ref.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The selection primer destroys the recognition site for BstBI.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	88	 This primer was used for selection of mutant constructs during the mutagenesis protocol (constructs that have lost this restriction enzyme recognition site will not be cut by BstBI and will contain the introduced CFTR mutation).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	89	Whole cell currents in Xenopus oocytes expressing wild-type and mutant CFTR.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	90	Since all studied mutations were identified in patients, they were expected to interfere with normal CFTR chloride channel function.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Mutations that caused no arrest in protein maturation were therefore analysed at the electrophysiological level.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	92	 To this end, CFTR RNA of the maturing mutants was prepared by in vitro transcription and injected into Xenopus laevis oocytes.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The basal and cAMP-induced whole cell chloride currents were measured using the two-electrode voltage clamp technique.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The results are shown in Figure 3.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Four mutations (T665S, R792G, E822K and E826K) caused a significant reduction in the cAMP-induced chloride current.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Interestingly, two mutations (H620Q and A800G) gave rise to chloride channels with significantly higher chloride transport activities.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The remainder (G622D, D648V, F693L, R766M and I807M) did not significantly affect chloride transport ability when compared with wild-type CFTR channels.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Maturation pattern of RD mutations and their associated phenotype found in patients with the indicated genotype (when the mutation is associated with CF, only the pancreas status is given) Mutation A-form B-form C-form Clinical data Genotype Phenotype Reference I601F + + - I601F/G542X PS M.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Schwarz, personal communication L610S + + - Unknown Unknown   A613T + + - Unknown Unknown   D614G + + - D614G/unknown PI 14 I618T + + - I618T/dF508 PS G.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Cutting, personal communication L619S + + - L619S/unknown PI B.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Tummler, personal communication H620P + + - H620P/R1158X PS M.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Schwarz, personal communication H620Q + + + H620Q/dF508 PI T.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Dork, personal communication G622D + + + G622D/unknown Oligospermia J.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Zielenski, personal communication G628R + + - Unknown Unknown   L633P + + - L633P/3659delC   M.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Schwarz, personal communication D648V + + + D648V/3849+10kb C/T PI C.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Ferec, personal communication T665S + + + Unknown Unknown   F693L + + + F693L/W1282X Healthy C.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Ferec; CF Genetic Analysis Consortium R766M + + + R766M/R792G CBAVD D.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Glavac, personal communication R792G + + + R766M/R792G CBAVD D.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Glavac, personal communication A800G + + + A800G/unknown CBAVD 34 I807M + + + I807M/unknown CBAVD Our observation E822K + + + E822K/unknown PI 35 E826K + + + E826K/unknown Thoracic sarcoidosis C.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Bombieri, personal communication +, the protein matures up to that form; -, the protein does not reach the respective maturation step.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Single channel measurements of wild-type and mutant CFTR chloride channels.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Pulse chase and immunoprecipitation of CFTR from COS1 cells transiently expressing wild-type, L610S, D614G or I807M CFTR.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Proteins were labelled with [35S]methionine and [35S]cysteine, chased for the indicated time periods and CFTR proteins were immunoprecipitated with an antibody directed against the C-terminal part of CFTR.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The immunopurified proteins were separated on a 4-12% SDS gel and visualized by autoradiography.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The core glycosylated 150 kDa and the mature 190 kDa forms are indicated.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Whole cell chloride currents measured in Xenopus laevis oocytes expressing wild-type and mutant CFTR proteins.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Xenopus laevis oocytes were injected with in vitro transcribed wild-type and mutant CFTR RNA and the basal (black bar) and cAMP-induced (white bar) chloride currents were measured by the two-electrode voltage clamp technique 72 h later.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Mutants that showed a significantly different cAMP-dependent chloride current (P  <  0.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	119	05), compared with wild-type CFTR, are marked with an asterisk and the number of cells analysed is indicated.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	120	Altered chloride transport activities can either be caused by a difference in the number of functional CFTR proteins incorporated into the apical cell membrane and/or by differences in the conductive and/or gating properties of these channels.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Mutants that affected whole cell currents were therefore studied at the single channel level.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The different wild-type and mutant CFTR cDNAs were incorporated into a bicistronic vector such that, after transfection into COS1 cells, a bicistronic transcript of CFTR and green fluorescent protein (GFP) was formed.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	123	 COS1 cells expressing GFP, and therefore also CFTR, were used for single channel measurements.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The current was measured before and after addition of forskolin and IBMX to the extracellular side of the cell.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Examples of tracings for the wild-type and H620Q CFTR proteins are shown in Figure 4A.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	126	 4B) and mutant CFTR chloride channels showed linear I-V relationships with single channel conductances not different from wild-type (Fig.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	127	 The Po of the different CFTR variants were determined (Fig.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Single channel activities correlated well with the whole cell currents measured in oocytes for the majority of the CFTR proteins studied.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	129	 G622D, R792G and E822K gave rise to a CFTR chloride channel with a significantly lower Po than wild-type CFTR; H620Q and A800G CFTR resulted in channels with significantly higher Po.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Activation of single channels by expressing wild-type and mutant CFTR (H620Q).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	131	 (A) Single channel current tracings of wild-type and H620Q CFTR before and after addition of the activation cocktail (1  microM IBMX and 0.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	132	1  microM forskolin) to the external site of the membrane patch.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	133	 0, closed state; 1-3, open channel events.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	134	 (B) Corresponding current-voltage (I-V) relationship obtained for wild-type CFTR.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	135	 (C) Single channel conductances of wild-type and mutant CFTR channels calculated from the current measured at -60 mV and the theoretical reversal potential at 0 mV.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The number of cells analysed is identical to that in Figure 5.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	137	 All measurements were done in the cell-attached configuration, using symmetrical chloride conditions, on COS cells transiently expressing wild-type and mutant CFTR.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Synopsis of changes in open probabilities (Po) of wild-type and mutant CFTR chloride channels expressed in COS1 cells.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	139	 COS1 cells were transfected with a bicistronic construct of GFP cDNA and wild-type or mutant CFTR cDNAs.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Cells expressing GFP were selected and used for single channel measurements.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The number of channels was estimated by overlapping sweep events.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Mutant CFTR chloride channels characterized by a Po value significantly different from that of wild-type CFTR are marked by an asterisk (P  <  0.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	143	05) and the number of cells patched is indicated.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	144	Since the discovery of the CFTR gene, 21 RD missense mutations have been identified in patients.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	145	 We studied the effect of 19 of these mutations (Table 1) on the maturation and electrophysiological properties of CFTR.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Nine mutations caused aberrant processing: I601F, L610S, A613T, D614G, I618T, L619S, H620P, G628R and L633P.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	147	 A very striking observation was that all mutations that caused a processing defect were clustered in the N-terminal part (amino acids 601-619) of the RD, while those that showed a normal maturation pattern were clustered in the C-terminal end (amino acids 648-826).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	148	 These effects were not caused by the different types of mutations that had been introduced, since similar amino acid changes were found in both subdomains.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	149	 In the region linking these two parts the effect of a mutation depends on the amino acid change introduced.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	150	 This is illustrated for amino acid 620, where two different mutations were detected in CF patients.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	151	 When His620 was changed to Gln, no effect on maturation was observed.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	152	 When His620 was changed to Pro, an amino acid that dramatically affects the secondary structure of the protein and therefore possibly its correct folding, a non-maturing protein was obtained.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	153	 It should be noted, however, that the effects of mutations involving Pro are not that dramatic when they are located in the second subdomain of CFTR, since a recombinant protein in which three wild-type Pro residues were mutated still formed the mature 190 kDa form (18).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	154	The RD has initially been assigned to that portion of the CFTR protein that is encoded by exon 13.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Accumulating evidence, however, indicates that the RD can be divided into two subdomains.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Cross-species analysis revealed that the N-terminal part of this domain has been highly conserved at the amino acid level during evolution, from shark to human, while in the C-terminal two-thirds only the phosphorylation sites are conserved (19).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Moreover, all the RD phosphorylation sites are exclusively located in this second part.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	158	 A new model for NBD1 was recently obtained by computational modelling, based on the X-ray structure of bovine mitochondrial F1 ATPase.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	159	 According to this model, amino acids 453-650, which have so far been attributed to the exon 13 RD, are in fact predicted to be part of NBD1 (20).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Here we found that missense mutations located in this part of the RD fail to mature, a characteristic of the majority of NBD1 mutations (21).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	161	Mutations that did not affect maturation (H620Q, G622D, D648V, T665S, F693L, R766M, R792G, A800G, I807M, E822K and E826K) were subsequently analysed at the electrophysiological level.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	162	Three of these (G622D, R792G and E822K) gave rise to chloride channels with significantly lower Po than the wild-type channel.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	163	 One of these mutations, R792G, disrupts a consensus recognition site for PKA.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Since it was shown that this site is phosphorylated in vivo by PKA (9) and that it is one of the strongest stimulatory sites for CFTR activation (22), elimination of this PKA recognition sequence might result in a chloride channel with aberrant regulation and, as a consequence, lower activity.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Strikingly, two mutations (H620Q and A800G) showed a significantly increased Po, when compared with wild-type CFTR.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	166	 So far, only the P574H mutation, located in NBD1, has been shown to give rise to a protein with higher intrinsic chloride transport properties.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	167	 This mutant, however, does not mature (23,24).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The `hyperactive' disease-causing mutations described here, H620Q and A800G, do mature.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	169	The remaining mutations (D648V, T665S, F693L, R766M, I807M and E826K) caused no significant alterations in intrinsic chloride channel activity.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	170	 F693L turned out to be a polymorphism (15), thereby explaining its normal function.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	171	Apart from being a chloride channel, CFTR is also a regulator of other channels.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	172	 It was found that CFTR is a negative regulator of amiloride-sensitive epithelial sodium channels (25-28) and a positive regulator of outwardly rectifying chloride channels (29,30), of potassium channels (31) and of an ATP channel associated with CFTR (32).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Therefore, mutant proteins that have a wild-type or an increased channel activity may cause a CF phenotype due to abnormal regulatory properties.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	174	 In view of the fact that the RD is quite unique for CFTR, compared with other ATP-binding cassette proteins, and that an interaction between the RD and the ATP channel has been shown, this domain becomes the prime candidate to play a crucial role in the regulatory activities of CFTR.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	175	We have recently shown that polymorphic alleles, like those found at the M470V locus, can also affect CFTR properties, both at the maturational and the electrophysiological levels (33).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The `normal' or `hyperfunctional' mutations could therefore cause CFTR malfunctioning when present on a particular haplotype background.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Since the haplotypes were not known for most of the mutations studied, their functional effect might have been masked.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	178	 On the other hand, it cannot be excluded that these patients carried an as yet undetected second mutation on the same CFTR allele.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	179	 As a result, the studied exon 13 mutation would then be a polymorphism.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	180	In conclusion, based on the maturation studies, the CFTR RD can be subdivided into two subdomains: the N-terminal one-third of exon 13, which is very sensitive to missense mutations, and the C-terminal part of exon 13, which shows less stringent structural requirements.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	181	 For some mutations, however, no defect in maturation could be detected.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Moreover, they gave rise to chloride channels with intrinsic activities that were similar to or even higher than wild-type CFTR.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Further experiments are required to clarify the mechanism by which the latter mutations cause disease.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	184	MATERIALS AND METHODS Construction of RD mutants.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	185	An XhoI-KpnI fragment containing the CFTR coding region was isolated from the prokaryotic vector pTG5960 (Transgene SA, Strasbourg, France) and inserted into the eukaryotic expression vector pcDNA3 (Invitrogen, Leek, The Netherlands).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	186	 In order to remove a potential ATG start codon derived from the multiple cloning site of pTG5960, the construct was digested with KpnI and EcoRV and the resulting linear plasmid was blunt-end ligated after T4 DNA polymerase treatment.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The CFTR coding region present in the resulting construct was characterized by dideoxy sequencing and one polymorphism, V470, was identified.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The sequence also contained three neutral amino acid changes (t930c, a933g and t936c) that had been introduced in order to inactivate a cryptic prokaryotic promoter (36).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	189	 All RD missense mutations that had been reported before May 23, 1996, to the Cystic Fibrosis Genetic Analysis Consortium (Table 1) were introduced using the Transformer Site-Directed Mutagenesis kit (Clontech Laboratories, Palo Alto, CA).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	190	 The primers used for mutagenesis are listed in Table 1.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	191	 The complete CFTR coding region of the 20 mutants was sequenced; no other mutations than the desired ones were found.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	192	For single channel measurements, the different mutant and wild-type CFTR cDNAs were transferred to the bicistronic GFP expression vector pCINeo/IRES-GFP (37).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	193	 For this purpose, wild-type CFTR cDNA derived from pcDNA3-CFTR was ligated as a T4 DNA polymerase-treated XhoI-SacI fragment in pCINeo/IRES-GFP.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	194	 The latter had first been linearized with NheI, blunt-ended with T4 DNA polymerase and dephosphorylated with bovine alkaline phosphatase.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	195	 The RD and its flanking sequences were subsequently removed from pCINeo/wtCFTR-IRES-GFP by complete digestion with XbaI and partial digestion with BstXI and was replaced by the corresponding mutant CFTR fragments that had been obtained by complete digestion of the different mutant pcDNA3-CFTR constructs with XbaI and BstXI.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	196	Expression, pulse chase and immunoprecipitation of CFTR.
