0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	197	Twenty micrograms of plasmid DNA were electroporated (BioRad Gene Pulser; Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA) into 1.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The transfected cells were cultured for 48-72 h at 37 degrees C in DMEM F12 (Life Technologies, Inchinnan, UK) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (HyClone Laboratories, Logan, UT) and subsequently selected with 480 mg/l G418 disulphate (Duchefa, Haarlem, The Netherlands).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	199	 After 2 weeks selection, the cells were starved for 30 min in RPMI 1640 medium (Life Technologies, Inchinnan, UK) without methionine and cysteine, labelled during a 30 min pulse in RPMI 1640 supplemented with 100  microCi/ml [35S]methionine and [35S]cysteine (ICN Pharmaceuticals, Costa Mesa, CA) and finally chased for different time periods in DMEM F12 supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Cells were scraped and subsequently lysed by sonication in ice-cold IPPA buffer (20 mM Tris, 150 mM NaCl, 1% Na desoxycholate, 1% Triton X-100, 0.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	201	4) supplemented with protease inhibitors (20  microg/ml soybean trypsin inhibitor, 1  microg/ml leupeptin, 1  microg/ml antipain, 1  microg/ml pepstatin, 1  microg/ml chymostatin and 1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The lysate was precleared with protein A-Sepharose CL-4B beads (Pharmacia Biotech, Uppsala, Sweden) and CFTR proteins were affinity purified by incubation for 1 h with an anti-CFTR monoclonal antibody directed against the C-terminal part of CFTR (Genzyme Diagnostics, Cambridge, MA).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The immunocomplexes were purified on protein A-Sepharose CL-4B beads and, after addition of loading buffer (1% [beta]-mercaptoethanol, 16 mM Tris-HCl, pH 6.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	204	8, 4% SDS, bromophenol blue and 10% glycerol), loaded on a 4-12% SDS gel (Novex, San Diego, CA).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	205	 After drying, the gel was exposed at -70 degrees C to a light-sensitive film for 3-4 h.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	206	All digestions with glycosidases were carried out on CFTR proteins that had been immunoprecipitated and purified on protein A-Sepharose CL-4B beads.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Endoglycosidase H digestion was performed overnight at 37 degrees C with 2.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	208	5 mU endoglycosidase H (Boehringer Mannheim, Mannheim, Germany) in 0.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	209	05 M citrate buffer containing 0.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	210	 In order to obtain complete deglycosylation, CFTR proteins were incubated for 15 min at room temperature in 0.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	211	3% SDS, followed by overnight incubation at 37 degrees C with 0.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	212	25 U N-glycosidase F (Boehringer Mannheim) in N-glycosidase F buffer (50 mM Tris, 25 mM EDTA and 1% Triton X-100, pH 8.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	213	The different CFTR constructs were in vitro transcribed using the T7 RiboMAX Large Scale RNA Production System (Promega, Madison, WI), according to the protocol of the manufacturer.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The quality of the RNA was determined by means of formaldehyde-agarose (1%) gel electrophoresis.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	215	Female toads (Xenopus laevis) were anaesthetized in ice-cold water containing 2 g/l 3-aminobenzoic acid ethylester (Sigma-Aldrich, Bornem, Belgium) and oocytes were subsequently collected via abdominal excision.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The oocytes were incubated in a calcium-free solution containing 2 mg/ml collagenase A (Boehringer Mannheim) for 1 h.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The oocytes were injected with 50 nl in vitro transcribed RNA (5  microg/ microl).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	218	Two-electrode voltage clamp assays.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	219	Three days after RNA injection, oocytes were mounted in a perfusion chamber, impaled with two electrodes and voltage clamped.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	220	 In order to block endogenous Ca2+-activated chloride currents, the perfusion solution (96 mM NaCl, 5 mM HEPES, 2 mM KCl, 1.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	221	8 mM CaCl2 and 1 mM MgCl2, pH 7.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	222	4) contained 100  microM niflumic acid.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	223	 CFTR currents were activated by addition of 10  microM forskolin and 1 mM IBMX.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	224	 All data were analysed by Student's t-test.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Data are reported as means  plus or minus  SEM.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Chloride currents were not activated in non-infected oocytes, water-injected oocytes or oocytes injected with RNA derived from in vitro transcribed pcDNA3.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	227	COS1 cells were transfected with the different pcINeo/GFP-CFTR constructs (37) and, 36 h later, seeded on glass coverslips.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The coverslips were mounted in a patch clamp set-up (EPC-7 amplifier; List, Darmstadt, Germany) containing a Zeiss Axiovert 100 microscope, a Xenon light source and epifluorescence optics (Zeiss, XBO 75 and Zeiss-EPI unit fluorescence condenser) 48-72 h after transfection.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	229	 A band-pass filter (Zeiss BP 450-490) was used for excitation of GFP.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Excitation was via a dichroic mirror (Zeiss FT 510).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Light emitted by GFP-expressing cells passed through a 520 nm long-pass filter (Zeiss LP 520) and was visually detected.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Only cells emitting green fluorescent light after excitation and, consequently, expressing GFP and CFTR proteins were used for single channel measurements.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	233	 All electrophysiological measurements were performed at room temperature in the cell-attached configuration with a pipette resistance of ~10 M[Omega] and the currents were digitized at 1 kHz and filtered at 500 Hz.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	234	 The data were collected continuously by the AXO Tape v.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	235	02 software package (Axon Instruments, Forster City, CA) and analysed with the ASCD software program (38).
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Only one patch per cell was studied; therefore, the number of patches is equal to the number of cells studied.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	237	 The pipette and bath solutions contained 140 mM N-methyl-D-glucamine chloride, 10 mM NaF, 10 mM HEPES, 2 mM MgCl2, 5 mM CsCl, 1 mM Mg-ATP, 1 mM EGTA, pH 7.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The channels were activated through addition of 1  microM IBMX and 0.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	239	1  microM forskolin to the bath (external) solution.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	240	 The open probability Po was calculated from Po = I/i&middot;n, where I is the averaged current during the whole stimulation period, i is the single channel current obtained from amplitude histograms and n is the number of channels estimated from overlapping events.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	241	 All data were analysed by Student's t-test.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Data are reported as means  plus or minus  SEM.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	243	We would like to thank Jan Eggermont, who kindly provided pCINeo/IRES-GFP, and Transgene SA (Strasbourg, France), who generously provided the pTG5960 vector.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	244	 We are also very grateful to Thilo Dork, Burkhard Tummler, Damjan Glavac, Claude Ferec, Cristina Bombieri, Julian Zielenski, Garry Cutting and Martin Schwarz for information concerning the phenotypes associated with the different mutations studied.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Anne Vankeerberghen is a fellow of Het Vlaams Instituut voor de Bevordering van het Wetenschappelijk-Technologisch Onderzoek in de Industrie and Harry Cuppens is a Postdoctoraal Navorser van het Onderzoeksfonds KU Leuven.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	246	 These investigations have also been supported by the Alphonse and Jean Forton grant of the Koning Boudewijn Stichting, by grant G.
0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	247	95 from theFonds voor Wetenschappelijk Onderzoek (to B.

0.4141868.9736778.html.plaintext.txt	289	uk' + u + '@' + d + ''//--> Last modification: 12 Sep 1998 Copyright Oxford University Press, 1998.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	0	EDITORIAL FOCUS Chaperoning the maturation of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator Jeffrey L.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Biological Sciences, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15260.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	2	THE ENDOPLASMIC RETICULUM (ER) serves as a way station during the biogenesis of nearly every integral membrane and secreted protein synthesized in eukaryotic cells.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	3	 As such, its primary role is to facilitate the folding of nascent polypeptides.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Thus plentiful among the ER resident proteins are 1) enzymes that catalyze conformational rearrangements, such as protein disulfide isomerase and peptidylprolyl isomerase; 2) enzymes that chemically modify the nascent polypeptide, such as signal sequence peptidase and oligosaccharyl transferase; and 3) molecules that retain the polypeptide in a soluble, aggregation-free state.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The factors constituting this last group are molecular chaperones, many of which were first identified as heat shock proteins (HSPs) because their synthesis is induced when cells are exposed to high temperatures or other stresses.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	6	 However, most HSPs have cellular homologs that are constitutively produced, and these are named heat shock cognate proteins (HSCs).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	7	 HSC and HSP molecular chaperones are defined by their molecular masses (in kDa), and a plentiful class found in every cell type are those with a molecular mass of ~70 kDa (i.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	8	HSP70 and HSC70 hydrolyze ATP concomitant with their binding to and release from polypeptide substrates, and their ATPase activities may be activated by another group of chaperones (21, 33) known as HSP40 or DnaJ homologs.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In some cases, the HSP40 cochaperone delivers a polypeptide substrate to the HSP70 or HSC70 (17, 37).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	10	 With the use of a variety of in vitro techniques, the HSC70 and HSP70 chaperones have been shown to bind preferentially to short stretches of amino acids with overall hydrophobic character (3, 13, 31).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Such motifs are normally buried within the core of a native protein but may become solvent accessible during protein folding and upon protein denaturation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Thus HSC70 and HSP70 chaperones are ideally suited to aid unfolded proteins en route to their native conformations by limiting protein aggregation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	13	Deletion of the phenylalanine at position 508 in the cystic fibrosis (CF) transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is the most common mutation associated with CF (27).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	14	 CFTR most likely functions as a chloride channel in the plasma membrane of airway and other epithelial cells, but cells containing only the F508 variant either lack or harbor variable amounts of the protein at the plasma membrane (7, 16).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Both wild-type and the F508 mutant form of CFTR are translocated into the ER membrane, at which time protein folding should commence.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	16	 However, in vitro studies by Qu and colleagues (25, 26) suggest that the efficiency of F508 CFTR folding is severely impaired compared with that of the wild-type protein.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	17	 It has also been shown that the F508 mutant protein is unable to undergo an ATP-dependent conformational change in the ER (20, 40).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Consistent with an inability of F508 CFTR to fold efficiently, incubation of cells expressing the mutant at lower temperatures, a condition that may favor protein folding and/or stability, permits some of this variant to traffic to the plasma membrane where it is active (10), albeit with a reduced open probability and half-life (9, 11, 19).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	19	 In contrast, if CFTR folding is retarded in the ER, the protein becomes a substrate for ER-associated degradation, a quality control mechanism that degrades aberrant proteins in the secretory pathway (4).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Degradation of CFTR, like most other ER-associated degradation substrates, requires ubiquitinylation and delivery to the multicatalytic cytoplasmic proteasome (14, 36, 38).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Although a significant proportion of even wild-type CFTR is degraded, nearly all of the F508 mutant is destroyed; therefore, cells expressing only the mutant form of the protein are phenotypically null.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	22	Because F508 CFTR is unable to attain a native conformation in the ER, it should not come as a surprise that it interacts with molecular chaperones.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Specifically, cytoplasmic HSC70 and HSP90, the luminal Ca2+-binding chaperone calnexin, and a cytoplasmic HSP40 homolog Hdj2 can be coprecipitated with CFTR (18, 22, 24, 39).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	24	 HSC70 and Hdj2 also prevent the in vitro aggregation of the first nucleotide-binding domain of CFTR (22, 34), the domain in which the phenylalanine at position 508 resides.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Although wild-type, folded CFTR is released from the chaperones on its transit from the ER to the Golgi apparatus, HSC70 and calnexin remain bound to the mutant until degradation ensues (24, 39).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	26	 A HSC70-interacting factor, CHIP, has recently been shown to facilitate the degradation of immature forms of CFTR (23).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	27	 One interpretation of these combined data is that the chaperone-CFTR complexes represent folding intermediates.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	28	Because several human diseases arise from defects in protein folding (4, 35), because of the devastating effects and widespread occurrence of CF, and because a profound amount of information is available on the mechanisms of molecular chaperones, the modulation of protein folding and chaperone activity has been attempted with small molecules and genetic manipulations.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	29	 For example, it was demonstrated by the Welch (5) and Kopito (32) laboratories that F508 CFTR-expressing cells incubated in glycerol, a polyol known to stabilize proteins in vitro, contain ER-matured forms of CFTR and display cAMP (forskolin)-activated plasma membrane chloride transport, a hallmark of functional CFTR.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Glycerol also facilitates the in vitro folding of the first nucleotide-binding domain lacking the phenylalanine at position 508 by preventing off-pathway intermediates from forming (25).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	31	 F508 CFTR-expressing cells incubated in trimethylamine oxide (TMAO), an osmotic stabilizer found in sharks to protect proteins from urea denaturation, exhibit similar properties (5).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Compounds such as TMAO and glycerol are now commonly known as chemical chaperones.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	33	Another means to alter protein folding in vivo is through the modulation of intracellular chaperone concentration.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	34	 (28) showed that sodium 4-phenylbutyrate (4PBA), an ammonia scavenger approved for the treatment of urea cycle disorders and a known transcriptional regulator, permits a fraction of F508 CFTR to mature in bronchial epithelial cell lines and primary nasal epithelial cells from patients with CF.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Maturation of the mutant coincides with cAMP-stimulated plasma membrane Cl conductance in the treated cells.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	36	 To determine the molecular basis of 4PBA-mediated rescue of the F508 CFTR phenotype, immunoprecipitations were performed to examine the amount of CFTR associated with HSC70, and a 4PBA dose-dependent decrease in the amount of CFTR-HSC70 complex was observed (30).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Because HSC70 was shown to facilitate ubiquitination of several test proteins in vitro (2), the authors suggested that HSC70 targets CFTR for degradation and that 4PBA, through an unknown mechanism, reduces the amount of the complex by which CFTR is delivered to the proteasome.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	38	The studies described above support the concept of using chaperone modulation as a means to rectify the pathophysiology associated with F508 CFTR.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Now, three papers in this issue of the American Journal of Physiology-Lung Cellular and Molecular Physiology (8, 12, 29) represent a significant leap in our understanding of the molecular basis of chaperone modulation, with the ultimate hope that such interventions may become clinically relevant for CF.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	40	Building on previous studies, Rubenstein and Lyons (29) show that the mechanism by which 4PBA downregulates HSC70 levels is through a decrease in the stability of HSC70 mRNA.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Although HSC70 mRNA is known to be relatively unstable, 4PBA appears to further accelerate its degradation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Coincident with an acceleration of mRNA degradation, an ~40% reduction in the amount of HSC70 is evident.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The mechanism by which this occurs is unknown, but it has been shown that inhibiting the initiation of yeast HSC70 translation leads to a rapid destruction of its message (1).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Because a large number of translation poisons are known, many of which were first isolated as antibiotics, this hypothesis can be tested.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	45	Does 4PBA only modulate HSC70 levels? Although previous data (30) suggested that this was so, new work from Choo-Kang and Zeitlin (8) indicates that 4PBA raises HSP70 levels, leading to increased HSP70-F508 CFTR complex formation and F508 CFTR maturation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	46	 One concern is that this phenomenon may arise from a secondary effect of decreasing HSC70 levels (see above), which, in turn, could induce a general heat shock or stress response.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	47	 However, the authors show that CFTR maturation is also facilitated by selectively increasing the intracellular levels of HSP70 by transient transfection with an HSP70 expression vector.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	48	These combined studies suggest that modulating the levels and thus the activities of HSC70 and HSP70 enhances CFTR maturation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	49	 They also point to the complexity of HSP70 or HSC70 function in the cell.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	50	, HSP70) facilitates protein folding, its homolog (i.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	51	, HSC70) targets a misfolded protein for degradation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Previous data suggest that multiple chaperones bind coordinately to nascent polypeptides.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Although the functions of many of these chaperones are likely to be redundant, it seems logical that a subset is required for folding and another subset is necessary for protein degradation.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	54	 If one group fails to fold the polypeptide, another is readily available to target the substrate for destruction.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The activities of the unique sets of chaperones may be further defined by the action of the HSP40/DnaJ cochaperones that regulate HSP70 and HSC70 function.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	56	 In other cases, the folding and degradation targeting activities may reside in one chaperone complex.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	57	 For example, HSP90 has been proposed to facilitate both CFTR maturation and degradation (18).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	58	Another means to catalyze CFTR folding is through the use of chemical chaperones, an attack that has shown promise in in vitro model systems as described above.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	59	 To determine whether this approach is feasible in an animal system, Fischer et al.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	60	 (12) examined whether TMAO corrects the F508 CFTR trafficking defect in mice.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Because the severity of the defect associated with the F508 form of CFTR is most prevalent in the rodent intestine, measurements of rectal potential difference (RPD) were undertaken in control mice, those lacking CFTR, and F508 CFTR mice.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Administration of TMAO over 24 h by subcutaneous injection reveals significant increases in forskolin-activated RPD hyperpolarization in the control and F508 CFTR mice, consistent with a partial rescue of the folding defects associated with the wild-type and mutant proteins.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Most promising from a clinical perspective is the observation that administering the flavinoid apigenin, a CFTR activator, further increases the forskolin-activated RPD in the F508 CFTR-expressing mouse.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	64	 This result supports the promise that combined therapeutic attacks may present the best option to lessen the pathophysiology of CF.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Combining small-molecule activators of CFTR function is warranted, particularly in this case, because the concentrations of TMAO used for these studies are quite high and the physiological effects of prolonged administration of TMAO are unknown.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	66	Might chaperone-based therapies become clinically relevant and generalized to the spectrum of diseases that arise from protein misfolding? The corrective effects of glycerol and 4-PBA on the maturation and secretion of another "conformational disease"-causing protein, the Z variant of antitrypsin, have been recently reported by Burrows et al.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	67	 In addition, other chaperone modulators are currently being examined for their ability to correct misfolded proteins.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	68	 15-Deoxyspergualin, a known HSC70 effector and immunosuppressant, increases the cAMP-stimulated plasma membrane Cl channel activity of F508 CFTR-expressing cells (15).
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	69	 However, because an increase in ER-matured forms of F508 CFTR could not be observed with 15-deoxyspergualin treatment, only a small amount of the mutant had likely trafficked to the plasma membrane and yielded the desired activity.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Nevertheless, with the advent of combinatorial chemistry and more defined methods to examine protein folding and chaperone action at the molecular level, I suspect that we will see a new convergence of chemical, cell biological, and biophysical tools geared to combat a variety of human diseases.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	71	Address for reprint requests and other correspondence: J.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	72	 of Biological Sciences, 267 Crawford Hall, Univ.
0.41579112.11404243.html.plaintext.txt	73	 of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA 15260 (E-mail: jbrodsky{at}pitt.

0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	0	A Combined Analysis of the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator: Implications for Structure and Disease Models Jian-Min Chen, Chris Cutler, Caroline Jacques, Gilles Buf, Erick Denamur, Guillaume Lecointre, Bernard Mercier, Gordon Cramb and Claude Ferec.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	1	Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale EMI 01 15, Etablissement Francais du Sang to Bretagne, Universite de Bretagne Occidentale, and Centre Hospitalier Universitaire, Brest, France; School of Biology, University of Saint Andrews, Saint Andrews, Fife, Scotland; Laboratoire de Biochimie-Biologie Moleculaire, CHU Angers, Angers, France; Observatoire Oceanologique, Universite Pierre et Marie Curie/Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Banyuls-sur-Mer, France; Institut National de la Sante et de la Recherche Medicale U458, Hopital Robert Debre, Paris, France; Service de Systematique Moleculaire, Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	2	The cloning of CFTR (Riordan et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	3	 1989 ) has promoted extensive research activities in two interrelated aspects: first, identification of CFTR mutations in classic and atypical CF patients, and second, elucidation of the functional role of CFTR in both the normal and the diseased states during the past decade.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	4	 However, while screening for CFTR mutations has become a purely molecular pursuit (currently, nearly 1,000 DNA variants of the gene are deposited in the CF Mutation Data Base: http://www.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	5	ca/cftr), the principal challenge is interpretation of these events in terms of their likely medical consequences.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	6	 This is especially the case with the vast number of missense mutations (40%), most of which are rare or even "private.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	7	" The formidable nature of this situation lies in the large size and complexity of the gene and, more importantly, in the complex multidomain structure of the protein.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	8	Although functional analysis, which unfortunately is still not routinely available, will continue to be used to bridge this gap, it can be complemented with other strategies.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In this regard, the impact of comparative sequence analysis has been tremendous.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Even the originally proposed CFTR structure, which has proved to be remarkably prescient, was largely based on a comparison of human CFTR with a number of other ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family members (Riordan et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Furthermore, cross-species sequence comparisons between the small number of CFTR homologs available in the early 1990s highlighted that identified mutations had occurred in evolutionary conserved residues (Diamond et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	12	 1991 ; Tucker, Tannahill, and Higgins 1992 ).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	13	 These early but necessarily limited analyses clearly demonstrated the importance of evolutionary information in interpreting the effects of mutations and have also frequently been taken into account in the design of functional studies.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Therefore, such a large number of missense mutations identified in the human CFTR and the abundance of structural and functional analysis data accumulated over the past decade, if evaluated together in the context of a sequence comparison of all of the currently available CFTR orthologs, will allow a significantly improved refinement of the domain structure of CFTR.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	15	 This will, in turn, facilitate interpretation of the identified mutations.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The central thesis of this work represents such an attempt, and, towards that end, the already large number of CFTR orthologs has been expanded by the determination of the sequences of two full-length CFTR orthologous isoforms from a single teleost fish species, the Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	17	The availability of this newly expanded number of CFTR sequences also offered an opportunity to reevaluate the use of mouse models for CF studies and, from a phylogenetic point of view, to check whether the paraphyly of the Glires (Lagomorpha and Rodentia), determined using CFTR sequences, was reliable or simply the result of a long-branch attraction artifact between the long rodent branch and the very divergent outgroup (Xenopus) (Vuillaumier et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In this regard, a partial coding sequence from the eastern gray kangaroo (Macropus giganteus; a marsupial mammal whose divergence time with placental mammals is about 120 Myr) was also produced in order to determine whether such an outgroup long-branch attraction artifact existed.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	19	Three steps were taken to isolate the salmon CFTR cDNAs by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	20	 First, three pairs of inosine (I) to containing degenerate oligonucleotide primers (sense 5'-TT(T/C) GG(I/C) (C/T)T(I/C) CA(I/C) C(A/G)(C/T) (A/C)T(I/C) GG(I/C) ATG CA(A/G) ATG (A/C)G-3', antisense 5'-(A/G)TC (I/C)A(A/G) (I/C)A(A/G) (A/G)TA (I/C)A(A/G) (A/G)TC (I/C)GC (A/G)TC (C/T) TT (A/G)TA-3'; sense 5'-GC(I/C) (I/C)T(I/C) TA(T/C) AA(A/G) GA(T/C) GC(I/C) GA(T/C) (C/T)T(I/C) TA(T/C) (C/T)T-3', antisense 5'-TGG TTC CT(C/T) TTC CGC (A/T)(G/T)(C/T) GAC ATI (A/C)TC TT 3'; and sense 5' TA(T/C) TT(T/C) GA(A/G) AC(I/C) (T/C)T(I/C) TT(T/C) CA(T/C) AA(A/G) GC-3', antisense 5'-A(A/G)(A/G) CAC AT(I/C) A(A/G)(T/C) TG(T/C) TT(A/G) TG(I/C) CC(A/G) T-3') which targeted highly conserved regions of the CFTR gene based on published CFTR sequences were synthesized and used to generate candidate PCR fragments.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Second, when a specific CFTR fragment was obtained, new specific primers were designed and further PCR fragments were amplified.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	22	 These efforts generated two sets of three overlapping clones covering most of the salmon CFTR-coding sequence.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Finally, the remaining translated and the 5' and 3' untranslated regions (UTRs) of the two cDNAs were obtained using a 5'/3' Rapid Amplification of cDNA Ends (RACE) Kit (Boehringer Mannheim, Mannheim, Germany) or a similar Marathon cDNA cloning kit (Clontech) utilizing isoform-specific primers.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	24	Cloning of CFTR Exon 13 to Coding Sequence from the Eastern Gray Kangaroo (M.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	25	 giganteus) To determine the possible presence of a long-branch attraction artifact between the long rodent branch and the very divergent outgroup (Xenopus) (Vuillaumier et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	26	 1997 ), and also to maximize the refinement of the boundaries between NBD1 and the R domain, the cloning of the coding sequence of exon 13 (the largest exon in the CFTR gene) from the eastern gray kangaroo was undertaken.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	27	 A pair of degenerate oligonucleotide primers, sense 5'-TGT IT(C/T) TG(C/T) AAA (C/T)T(G/A) ATG G(C/T)I A(A/G)C AAA AC-3' and antisense 5'-C(T/C)T (T/C)A(G/A) (A/G)TC (T/C)TC TTC (A/G)TT (A/T)AT ITC TTC-3', which targeted the highly conserved sequences between the published CFTR homologs at each end of exon 13, respectively, were synthesized.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Genomic DNA was used for PCR amplification.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	29	DNA Sequencing PCR products were purified by Centricon-100 (Millipore, Bedford, Mass.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	30	) and cloned into the pGEM-T vector (Promega, Madison, Wis.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Double-stranded DNA was sequenced using a combination of specific primers and the vector-specific T7/SP6 primers from both strands using the ABI PRISM BigDye Terminator Cycle Sequencing Kit (PE Applied Biosystems, Foster City, Calif.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	32	Multiple-Sequence Alignments Full-length CFTR sequences were collated from GenBank or SwissProt.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In order to refine the boundaries of NBD1, several partial sequences were also collated.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Multiple-sequence alignments were first performed with CLUSTAL W (http://www2.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Then, the alignment was corrected by eye using MUST (Philippe 1993 ) in order to take into account similarities in chemical properties of amino acid side chains.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	36	Missense Mutations and Single-Amino-Acid-Deletion Mutations All of the missense mutations and single-amino-acid deletions are from the CF Mutation Data Base (http://www.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	37	Phylogenetic Analysis Two CFTR sequence data sets were utilized for phylogenetic analysis.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	38	 One used 17 exon 13 to coding nucleotide sequences that provided 543 positions, of which 343 were informative for parsimony.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The other contained 16 full-length CFTR amino acid sequences, with 1,544 positions, among which 771 were informative for parsimony.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Phylogenetic analysis was performed principally using the branch-and-bound search of PAUP (Swofford 1999 ).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	41	 To check the impact of a suspected artifact on the tree reconstruction method, trees were also reconstructed using uncorrected distances and corrected distances (Kimura 1983 ) through the neighbor-joining approach (Saitou and Nei 1987 ) using the MUST package (Philippe 1993 ).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Moreover, absolute mutational saturation was tested by plotting pairwise observed differences against pairwise inferred substitutions in the most parsimonious tree using PAUP and MUST.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	43	 No saturation was detected, either from the nucleotide or from the amino acid data set.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	44	 For statistical robustness of nodes, 1,000 bootstrap replicates were generated, and Bremer (1994) supports were calculated using PAUP.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	45	Candidate PCR fragments were generated from salmon gill tissue using degenerate oligonucleotide primers.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	46	 After many rounds of cloning, sequencing, and sequence aligning (which was particularly complicated by the unexpected presence of two highly homologous but clearly different sequences), two CFTR transcripts were finally obtained.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Sequence accuracy of the two transcripts was ensured by isoform-specific PCR amplifications using cDNA samples prepared from individual salmon.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The general properties of the two transcripts, which were designated sCFTR-I (GenBank accession number AF155237) and sCFTR-II (GenBank accession number AF161070), respectively, are summarized in table 1 .
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Although there is no guarantee that the 5' UTR of each sequence is complete, the 3' UTR of each sequence is considered complete due to the presence of a polyA addition signal sequence 16 bp (for sCFTR-I) or 12 bp (for sCFTR-II) upstream of the polyA tail.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	50	View this table:    Table 1 Comparison of sCFTR-I and sCFTR-II Transcripts.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	51	  The possibility that the sCFTR-I and sCFTR-II genes represented two unique isoforms, rather than allelic variants, was first indicated by the sequences themselves.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	52	 At the nucleotide level, while sCFTR-I and sCFTR-II share a level of sequence identity as high as 93.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	53	2% in the coding region, they have a significantly lower homology in the 5' and 3' UTRs.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The 110-bp nucleotides immediately upstream of the translation start site are only 64.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	55	0% identical and the 3' UTR is 71.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	56	 At the amino acid level, a significantly lower sequence identity is observed in the R domain (85.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	57	0%) (domain structure in accordance with Riordan et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	58	 This is given wide support by recent in vivo expression data: although both sCFTR-I expression and sCFTR-II expression have been shown to increase in the gill following abrupt seawater exposure, the pattern of temporal expression for each gene is considerably different (Singer et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Moreover, the existence of two different genes encoding the same product is not entirely surprising, as many fish species, including salmonids (Hordvik 1998 ), have undergone tetraploidization events during their evolutionary histories, and duplication of certain hormone genes (e.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	60	, Takeo and Yamashita 1999 ) or ion and water transporter genes (Cutler et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	61	 2000 ; unpublished data) in certain fishes has been reported.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Furthermore, there is also circumstantial evidence suggesting the presence of two CFTR genes in another teleost fish, the killifish: two transcripts and two polypeptides were detected in the gill by Northern blotting (Singer et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	63	 1998 ) and Western blotting (Mickle and Cutting 2000) , respectively.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	64	 These observations, taken together, strongly suggest that sCFTR-I and sCFTR-II represent different isoforms and that the presence of duplicate CFTR isoforms may be a more general phenomenon in teleost fish species.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Although phylogenetic analysis indicates that their duplication occurred after the general radiation of teleost fish species (200 to 400 MYA, which may have been associated with a whole-genome duplication event; Meyer and Malaga-Trillo 1999 ) and even the salmonid-acanthomorph divergence (middle Cretaceous, about 100 MYA; Lecointre 1994 ) (fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	66	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The most parsimonious tree based on the full-length cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) amino acid sequences using the branch-and-bound search of PAUP* 4.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The sequence length utilized 1,544 positions, of which 971 were variable and 771 were informative for parsimony.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The tree length is 2,270, with a consistency index of 0.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Branch lengths are given using ACCTRAN optimization.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The numbers above the nodes are bootstrap proportions obtained from 1,000 replicates.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Bremer (1994) indices are all  > 5 except for the rhesus monkey + macaque clade, whose Bremer index was 1.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The same tree was recovered from the neighbor-joining method (Saitou and Nei 1987 ) using corrected distances (Kimura 1983 ).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	74	 See table 2 for the CFTR sequences except the eel (Anguilla anguilla) sequence (unpublished data), and refer to figure 2 for the sequence alignment (EMBL accession number ALIGN_000076).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	75	  During the cloning process, additional full-length CFTR sequences from several species, including killifish (Singer et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	76	 1998 ) and puffer fish (Davidson et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	77	 2000) , were also reported (summarized in table 2 ).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	78	 As indicated in figure 1 , sCFTR-I and sCFTR-II, along with the killifish and puffer fish sequences, are the most divergent CFTR homologs so far discovered.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The availability of this large number of CFTR homologs, which cover a wide range of vertebrate species representing evolutionary divergence of up to 420 Myr, has allowed important, broad cross-species sequence comparisons to be performed.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	80	View this table:    Table 2 CFTR Sequences Used for Analysis.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	81	  Implications of a Combined Analysis for the Global Structure-Function Relationship of CFTR Alignment of 15 full-length CFTR amino acid sequences is presented in figure 2 , where all of the current available missense mutations and single-amino-acid deletions are positioned along the aligned sequences.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	82	 To refine the boundaries of the NBD1, the new isolated partial exon 13 to coding sequence from the eastern gray kangaroo (GenBank accession number AF293978) and several other partial sequences were also aligned.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	83	 A global survey of figure 2 further highlights that the two NBDs are well conserved and that the most divergent region is the R domain.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	84	 There is also a general correlation between the level of sequence homology and the number of mutations identified throughout the entire CFTR.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Moreover, all of the 11 most common missense mutations or single-amino-acid deletions (i.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	86	, F508del, G551D, N1303K, R117H, R347P, I507del, G85E, R560T, A455E, R334W, and S549N) identified in classic and atypical CF patients worldwide (http://www.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	87	ca/cftr) occur in stringently conserved residues across the 15 CFTR sequences.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	88	 These observations strongly suggest that a combined analysis of the current available data in conjunction with a comprehensive sequence comparison of CFTR homologs is highly desirable.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Indeed, based on such an approach, a "functional R domain" has recently been defined (Chen, Scotet, and Ferec 2000 ; see also fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Importantly, this definition not only agrees well with that derived from a concurrent functional approach (Csanady et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	91	 2000) , but also appears to concur with the regulatory role of this unique domain (Baldursson, Berger, and Welsh 2000) .
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Here, we extend the study to refine the boundaries of the two NBDs and the COOH-terminal tail (C-tail) and to provide insights about the global structure-function relationship of the CFTR by exploiting the same approach.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	93	View larger version (134K):    Fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	94	 A broad alignment of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) amino acid sequences.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Dashes indicate gaps that were introduced to maximize alignment.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Identical residues between all the species are in bold letters.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The 12 membrane-spanning regions (TM1TM12) are sequentially underlined.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	98	 In particular, NBD1 and NBD2 are indicated by dotted lines, and the R domain and the C-tail are represented by continuous lines, wherein the upper lines correspond to the original definitions (Riordan et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	99	 1989 ) and the lower ones correspond to the new definitions.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	100	 All of the currently identified missense mutations and single-amino-acid deletions (http://www.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	101	ca/cftr) are positioned in the sequence accordingly.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	102	 See table 2 for the CFTR sequences used for alignment.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	103	The new definition of the NH2 terminus of NBD1 combines the following considerations.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The principal evidence comes from evolutionary data.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	105	 As illustrated in figure 2 , there is a sharp increase in sequence conservation beginning at P439 in comparison with the immediately preceding sequence.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The first six amino acids of the originally defined NBD1 (i.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	107	, F433 to T438) are quite divergent (even to the extent of deletions having occurred in several species), and the upstream region is a divergent sequence track of 20 amino acids.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	108	 In contrast, downstream of P439, not only is there a stringently conserved three-amino-acid motif (i.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	109	, P439-V440-L441), but also most of the nonstringently conserved residues from K442 to A457 have changes mainly involving substitutions between conservative amino acids, and this region is then followed by the highly conserved Walker A motif (GSTGAGKT, amino acid 458 to amino acid 465).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	110	 A similar transition from divergence to sequence conservation is also present in the equivalent location of the aligned sequences of other ABC transporter family members, as illustrated in a sequence comparison of the 17 bacterial membrane proteins that form the periplasmic permease gene family (Mimura, Holbrook, and Ames 1991 ).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Second, this definition is consistent with most of the structural models of human CFTR, where the NH2 terminus of NBD1 was regarded as T438 (Higgins 1992 ), L441 (Bianchet et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	112	 1997 ), and around V440 (Hoedemaeker, Davidson, and Rose 1998 ), respectively.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	113	 This definition also appears to correlate reasonably well with the three-dimensional crystal structure of HisP (the ATP-binding subunit of the bacterial histidine transporter), where P439 would be predicted to occur at the very beginning of the second ss strand of HisP (Hung et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Third, this definition falls within amino acids N432 to E449 the functionally defined NH2 terminus of NBD1 (Chan et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Finally, this definition is given further support by the mutational pattern in this transitional region (fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	116	However, one may argue that the new definition of the NH2 terminus of NBD1 might have inappropriately excluded the sequences aligned to the first ss strand of HisP (Hung et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Of particular relevance to this point is residue F433, an aromatic amino acid that corresponds to residue Y16 of the HisP.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The structure of HisP has been considered a good model for the binding of ATP to an NBD, in which the aromatic Y16 was confirmed to play a critical role (as determined by mutational studies by Shyamala et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Moreover, the structures of the other two prokaryotic NBD proteins, LivF and the amino-terminal NBD of RbsA, show a very similar binding interaction between the NBD and ATP, that is, the side chain of an aromatic residue (analogous to Y16 in HisP) interacts with the adenine ring of ATP to stabilize nucleotide binding.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Furthermore, an aromatic residue 20 to 30 amino acids upstream of the start of the Walker A motif (in a similar position relative to Y16 in HisP) is conserved in other ABC transporter NBDs (summarized in Berger and Welsh 2000) .
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	121	 By inference, F433 in the human CFTR may participate in ATP binding.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	122	 However, a recent functional analysis has refuted such a possibility and highlighted the unique structure of CFTR NBD compared with other NBD structures (Berger and Welsh 2000) .
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Undoubtedly, this finding adds further weight to the newly defined NBD1.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	124	We previously defined the NH2 terminus of the R domain as beginning at C647 (Chen, Scotet, and Ferec 2000) .
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Consequently, G646 could be considered the COOH terminus of NBD1.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	126	 However, the concurrent functional approach defined the COOH terminus of NBD1 as occurring between G622 and Q634 (Chan et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Nevertheless, G646 seems to be a more logical positioning of the true boundary linking NBD1 and the R domain in CFTR.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	128	 In addition to the previous arguments (Chen, Scotet, and Ferec 2000) , further supporting evidence also exists.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Again, the principal evidence comes from evolutionary data.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	130	 As indicated in figure 2 , the sequence from S623 to G646 is as well conserved as that from F587 to G622; the latter is the common part of the extended NBD1 in the two studies (Chan et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	131	 2000; Chen, Scotet, and Ferec 2000) .
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Perhaps a more important indication comes from a sequence alignment with other ABC transporter NBDs; for example, HisP ends exactly at residue G646 of the human CFTR homolog (see fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Moreover, it is important to note that the functional assembly of paired CFTR segments severed at L633/Q634 is not as good as that of those cleaved at N432/F433 (Chan et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	134	 In this regard, it will be interesting to compare paired CFTR fragments cleaved at the newly defined NBD1/R domain boundary (i.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	135	, G646/C647) with those cleaved at L633/Q634.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	136	Refinement of the Boundaries of NBD2 The original location in the amino acid sequence of NBD2 is from Y1219 to R1386 (Riordan et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Historically, NBD2 has received much less attention than NBD1.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Now, with the boundaries of NBD1 redefined, those of NBD2 can be similarly refined.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Accordingly, the NH2 terminus of NBD2 could be defined as going from A1225 by reference to the relative position of the highly conserved Walker A motif, and this also correlates fairly well with the mutational pattern (the appearance of missense mutations clustering around the Walker A motif: GRTGSGKS, at amino acid 1244 to amino acid 1251) in the transitional region in NBD2 (fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	140	 However, when the COOH terminus of NBD2 is extended to P1443 by reference to the redefined NBD1 (see also fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	141	 1998 ), the very COOH-terminal portion of this "new NBD2" shows poor sequence conservation.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Yet, this is not so surprising if it is considered in the context of the ABC transporter family, where for example, its counterpart region in the 17 bacterial periplasmic permeases is similarly divergent (Mimura, Holbrook, and Ames 1991 ).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Thus, it seems clear that the very COOH-terminal portions of NBDs are, in general, less functionally restrained throughout the ABC transporter family, although this is in stark contrast to the NBD1 of CFTR, where the very COOH-terminal portion is highly conserved (fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	144	 While it is not clear whether this sequence conservation is related to the immediately following R domain (which is unique to CFTR), it lends further weight to the unique structure of CFTR NBD1.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	145	Although P1443 could represent the COOH terminus of a "new NBD2," this should not be accepted without any reservations.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The significant sequence divergence of the very COOH-terminal portion of this "new NBD2," the different structural requirements of a CFTR NBD compared with other ABC transporter NBDs in general (Berger and Welsh 2000) , and the differential roles between the CFTR NBD1 and NBD2 in particular (discussed below) argue for an alternative definition.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Here again, it is reassuring how well the evolutionary data, clinical observations, and functional studies concur.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The initial location of sequence divergence in this transitional region was clearly situated at E1418 (fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	149	 In addition, the shortest truncation that is associated with CF disease (with pancreatic insufficiency and recurrent pulmonary infection) terminates at Q1412 (http://www.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Furthermore, a review of several functional studies clearly points to the fact that CFTR truncated at/or upstream of V1415 significantly affects the biogenesis, maturation, and stability of the protein, but those molecules truncated at or downstream of N1419 do not (Rich et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	151	 1999 ; Gentzsch and Riordan 2001 ).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	152	 These three lines of observation, together with the mutational pattern in this region, strongly suggest that residue E1417 can be confidently assigned as the COOH terminus of NBD2.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	153	 This new definition is also further validated by the analysis which has redefined the C-tail of the CFTR (discussed below).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	154	Functional Delineation of the C-Tail The COOH terminus of NBD2 could naturally be anticipated to be the NH2 boundary of the C-tail, and this appears to best delineate its functional role in the CFTR.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	155	 On the one hand, the newly defined C-tail is "nonessential," as the effects on the biogenesis, processing, and stability of the CFTR previously assigned to the original C-tail have now been relocated to within the newly defined NBD2.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Moreover, even the two trafficking signals thought to reside in the newly defined C-terminal tail, at Y1424 and the dileucine pair at L1430-L1431, have been demonstrated not to alter the steady-state amount of nascent or mature CFTR in recent functional studies (Gentzsch and Riordan 2001) .
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	157	 On the other hand, the newly defined C-tail does appear to be "essential," as the well-conserved motif involving the final three amino acids (TRL) represents a PDZ-interacting domain which is required for the polarization of CFTR to the apical plasma membrane in epithelial cells (Moyer et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Even so, it is important to note that this PDZ-binding motif alone is not sufficient for the polarized distribution of CFTR (Milewski et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Therefore, the C-tail as a whole would play a minor role in the pathogenesis of CF disease.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Indeed, neither S1455X (Mickle et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	161	ca/cftr) caused a severe CF phenotype.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	162	 By inference, any single missense mutations identified in the C-tail may not have a significant functional consequence.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Consistent with this hypothesis, none of the three missense mutations identified in this region (fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	164	 2 ) can be confidently assigned as causal for CF disease; for example, R1422W was identified in a CF patient who also carried the mutations F508del and D993Y, and R1453W was identified in a patient with diffuse panbronchiolitis (http://www.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Finally, attention may be drawn to the well conserved, negatively charged motif (E1469 to E1474) in the C-tail.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	166	Further Insights into the Differential Function of NBD1 and NBD2 That the two NBDs are not functionally equivalent was immediately noticed in the early 1990s.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Not only were CF-associated mutations found predominantly in CFTR's NBD1 as opposed to NBD2, but also mutations of homologous amino acid residues within NBD1 or NBD2 resulted in different effects on CFTR maturation and function (Cheng et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	168	 More recently, the different roles of NBD1 and NBD2 in the CFTR chloride channel and the regulation of other ion channels have been further investigated through a variety of approaches (e.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	169	Apart from the fact that there are more disease-associated mutations in NBD1 than in NBD2, and more than half of the most common missense mutations or single-amino-acid deletions occur in NBD1, figure 2 reveals an additional interesting observation regarding mutational patterns in the well-conserved motifs in the NBDs.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	170	 While there are 17 missense mutations clustered in the LSGGQ motif (LSGGQ, amino acids 548 to 552) and the Walker B motif (RAVYKDADLYLLD, amino acids 560 to 572) in NBD1, there are only four missense mutations in the equivalent regions (LSHGH [amino acids 1346 to 1350] and RSVLSKAKILLLD [amino acids 1358 to 1370]) of NBD2.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Conversely, while there is only one missense mutation in the Walker A motif (GSTGAGKT, amino acids 458 to 465) in NBD1, there are five mutations in the corresponding motif (GRTGSGKS, amino acids 1244 to 1251) in NBD2.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	172	 This finding is intriguing since, on the one hand, although Walker A and Walker B are presumably both involved in ATP binding and hydrolysis, the exact mechanisms remain largely unknown.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	173	 On the other hand, while it is generally believed that ATP hydrolysis at NBD1 and NBD2 may drive channel opening and closing, respectively (reviewed by Nagel 1999 ), recent biochemical analysis suggests that opening and closing may occur as a consequence of nucleotide binding and dissociation or hydrolysis at a functional unit involving both domains (Aleksandrov et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Therefore, it is tempting to ask whether the distinct mutational patterns in these important motifs are linked intrinsically to functional differences of the Walker A and Walker B sites within the two NBDs.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Elucidation of this question would improve our understanding of the basic physiology of CFTR, as well as that of other ABC transporters.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Nevertheless, this observation gives further support to the idea that NBD1 and NBD2 make different contributions to the gating of CFTR channels.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	177	Further Insights into the Differential Role of MSD1 (F81 to V350) and MSD2 (I860 to S1150) Each MSD was predicted to contain six transmembrane segments (TMs), three extracellular loops (ECLs), and two intracellular loops (ICLs).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	178	 As in the case of the two NBDs, functional differences have also been found for the two MSDs (e.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	179	, Yue, Devidas, and Guggino 2000) .
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	180	 A comparison of the stringently conserved residues in the TMs of the two MSDs reveals that the TMs in MSD1 are generally more conserved than those in MSD2 (data not shown; see also fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	181	 2 ); TM6 (12 out of 21 residues; 57.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	182	1%) and TM12 (11 out of 22 residues; 50.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	183	0%) are the most conserved motifs in the two MSDs, respectively, and TM6 is the most conserved of all.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The evolutionary conservation of these regions correlates perfectly with analysis that suggests that (1) TM6 and TM12 line the CFTR pore, (2) TM6 is the main determinant of the pore properties of CFTR, and (3) MSD1 and MSD2 each contribute differently to CFTR pore properties (Sheppard and Welsh 1999 ).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	185	A defining feature of ion channels is their selectivity, the ability to pass certain ions at a high rate while at the same time effectively excluding others.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	186	 While discrimination between different cations in certain cation channels is known to occur over a short region of the pore known as the selectivity filter, the existence of a discrete anion selectivity filter in the pores of Cl- channels is controversial (Linsdell, Evagelidis, and Hanrahan 2000) .
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Nevertheless, based on the above-mentioned evolutionary data, such a selectivity filter in the CFTR, if it indeed exists, would most likely be located in the most highly conserved TM TM6.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Not surprisingly, the anion selectivity (Br-  >  Cl-  >  I-) of the CFTR pore was found to be mainly determined by the first half of the protein (Yue, Devidas, and Guggino 2000) , and mutations in several residues in TM6, including K335 (Anderson et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	189	 1991 ), F337 (Linsdell, Evagelidis, and Hanrahan 2000) , T338 (Linsdell, Zheng, and Hanrahan 1998 ), and R347 (Cheung and Akabas 1997 ), were shown to significantly affect anion selectivity.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Moreover, the stringently conserved motif T351-R352-Q353 immediately downstream of TM6 has also been suggested to loop back into the channel, narrowing the lumen and thereby forming both the major resistance to current flow and the anion selectivity filter (Cheung and Akabas 1997 ).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Assuming that an anion selectivity filter resides in the vicinity of TM6, it is interesting to note the presence of another highly conserved motif also in this vicinity (Q359-T360-W361-Y362-D363).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Furthermore, there is also a similarly stringently conserved motif downstream of TM12 in MSD2, L1156-M1157-R1158-S1159-V1160.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	193	Inspection of figure 2 also reveals that the four ICLs are generally more conserved than the TM and ECL subdomains in the MSDs.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	194	 To date, most of the missense mutations identified in each ICL and a 19-amino-acid deletion concerning ICL2 have been investigated by functional analysis (reviewed in Sheppard and Welsh 1999 ).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	195	 These studies strongly indicated that the ICLs were critical for correct protein processing.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Among the four ICLs, ICL4 (amino acid Q1035 to amino acid R1102, with a sequence homology as high as 72% across the 15 CFTR species) turns out to be the most conserved subdomain in the entire CFTR sequence.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	197	 This stringent sequence conservation, coupled with a cluster of missense mutations identified in this subdomain (among which two homozygosities, H1085R [Yoshimura et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	198	 1999 ] and R1066C [Casals et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	199	 1997 ], cause a severe CF phenotype), undoubtedly underlies its functional significance within CFTR.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	200	 While a large fraction of the analyzed ICL4 missense mutations disrupted the biosynthetic processing of CFTR, this was not universally the case.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Most importantly, those processed mutants had no discernible effect on the channel's pore properties, but they did alter gating behavior, the response to increasing concentrations of ATP, and stimulation in response to pyrophosphate (Cotten et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Thus, ICL4, and probably the other three ICLs, may actively participate in interdomain interactions; for example, they may link the NBDs to MSDs, thereby coupling the activity of NBDs to the gating of the channel.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	203	Possible Motifs Implicated in the Interdomain Interaction Between the NH2-Terminal Tail (N-tail; M1 to R80) and the R Domain An eliciting finding is that the N-tail controls CFTR channel gating through a physical interaction with the R domain.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Not surprisingly, this positive regulatory activity was mapped to a cluster of acidic residues, D47, E51, E54, and D58, within the highly charged and conserved motif D44 to E60 (fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Since no effects of any of the N-tail mutations on steady-state phosphorylation in vitro or in vivo were detected, the N-tail most likely modulates channel activity by controlling access of the phosphorylated R domain to inhibitory or stimulatory sites within the channel (Naren et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	206	The fact that a cluster of stringently conserved acidic residues in the N-tail appears to bind to part of the R domain (most probably the region involving amino acids 708 to 740 and the nearby surrounding sequences; Naren et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	207	 As illustrated in figure 2 , there are three highly conserved, positively charged motifs (K696-R697-K698, R709-K710, and R764-R765-R766) in this region.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Although the conservation of these motifs may be explained by the fact that they potentially participate in phosphorylation of the R domain, the possibility that all, or at least some, of them serve as counterparts to the acidic residues in the N-tail cannot be excluded, particularly if the fact that none of them appear to be phosphyorylated by PKA in vivo is taken into account (Cheng et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	209	 More recently, a relatively small portion of the R domain (residues 760 to 783) that encompasses the stringently conserved motif (R765-R766-Q767-S768-V769-L760) was found to be critical for the prevention of constitutive activity of the CFTR (Baldursson et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	210	 This further highlights the functional importance of these motifs when it is considered that they are conserved even within the most evolutionarily divergent R domain sequences.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Future studies focusing on these motifs may result in the revelation of further novel molecular mechanisms.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	212	How Many Missense Mutations Are Functional? Unlike splicing and truncating mutations, it is always difficult to assign a definitive role to missense mutations, especially when they are detected in single cases.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Functional analysis provides important data, but extrapolation to clinical effects may not be straightforward.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	214	 This can be seen in the conflicting results that often occur in some aspects of CF research, exemplified by the two different models for salt and water transport across epithelia (reviewed by Wine 1999 ), as well as the disparity among results on the intracellular localization of F508del-CFTR (reviewed by Drumm 1999 ).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	215	 There is ongoing effort to tackle this issue (e.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	216	, the CF European Network: the Second Consensus Meeting Towards Validation of CFTR Gene Expression and Functional Assays, Estoril, March 30 to  April 1, 2001).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	217	We believe that a combined analysis of the currently available data can complement this effort and enhance our understanding of the identified mutations, particularly those that are missense.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Taking advantage of the previously redefined R domain, a systemic evaluation of the missense mutations occurring in this region was produced, and as a result, some of these mutations, such as F693L, V754M, and T760M, were identified as being likely to represent neutral polymorphisms (Chen, Scotet, and Ferec 2000) .
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Similarly, the missense mutations occurring in evolutionarily divergent regions, for example, N418S, G424S, Q890R, and K1177R, may also represent neutral polymorphisms.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	220	 At the other extreme, for example, the mutations I506M and F508C, which occur in stringently conserved residues in the functionally important NBD1, have also been confirmed to be nonfunctional variants (Kobayashi et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	221	 1990 ; Kalin, Dork, and Tummler 1992 ; Will et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	222	 The assignment of mutations as in these two extreme cases would raise a serious concern that a certain fraction of the identified missense mutations in classic and atypical CF patients may in fact merely represent polymorphisms rather than mutations associated with the disease.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	223	 If this assumption is correct, it is not unreasonable to infer that the truly causal mutation event may remain unidentified in a certain fraction of patients in whom the disease has been incorrectly assumed to be caused by identified "missense mutations.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	224	The above assumption is further supported by the following considerations.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The large size of the CFTR gene makes it difficult to analyze the entire coding sequence, not to mention the intronic sequence.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Consequently, initial identification of one DNA variant may discourage further screening efforts, thereby ignoring a second variant in cis in the gene.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Even if the whole CFTR gene were analyzed, certain variants, such as large deletions within the gene (which are being detected at an increasing rate; http://www.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	228	ca/cftr), are still not readily detected by common mutational screening techniques (Girodon-Boulandet, Cazeneuve, and Goossens 2000) .
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	229	 In addition, the promoter sequence (Romey et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	230	 1999 ) and the upstream regulatory region (Nuthall et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	231	 1999 ) of the CFTR gene may be targets for extended mutational screening.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Moreover, mutations in other genes in certain CF-like disease subjects should be considered (Mekus et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	233	Taken together, it is likely that a certain fraction of the missense mutations identified in the CFTR gene may be ultimately confirmed to be nonpathological polymorphisms.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	234	 It is even possible that some of them may turn out to be modifiers of another variant in the CFTR gene or even in another gene.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	235	 An answer to this question will significantly improve our understanding of the disease, as well as that of the protein itself.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Nevertheless, this vast number of missense mutations represents an invaluable resource for exploring the subtlety of the CFTR structure-function relationship, and figure 2 could serve as an important complement to ongoing mutation detection and functional analysis efforts in the CF field.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	237	A Comprehensive Phylogenetic Analysis: Implications for Animal Models of CF An additional dividend of the availability of a large number of CFTR sequences is their benefit concerning the use of animal models in CF studies.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	238	 We had previously suggested that the rabbit could be a better CF model than the current murine model, mainly based on (1) anatomical and developmental data, (2) comparison of CFTR promotor sequences and partial coding sequences, and (3) phylogenetic analysis of those sequences (Vuillaumier et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Although sequence comparisons clearly showed a higher similarity between rabbit and primate sequences than between murine and primate sequences or even between rabbit and murine sequences, the phylogenetic implications were ambiguous.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	240	A long-branch attraction artifact (Felsenstein 1978 ) of the murine lineage toward the outgroup was suspected (Vuillaumier et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	241	 This classical artifact of phylogenetics concerns all tree reconstruction methods.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	242	 It occurs when rates of character change vary among lineages, provoking in trees the grouping of lineages sharing close rates, whatever the evolutionary relationships.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	243	 To solve this ambiguity, additional sequence data (particularly from further species) were required for a successful analysis.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	244	 When all of the full-length CFTR amino acid sequences were analyzed in this study (fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	245	 1 ), the murine lineage was the most basal of the placental mammals, a strange result possibly due to a long-branch attraction.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Moreover, the position of the rabbit was ambiguous.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	247	 In the most parsimonious tree (fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	248	 1 ) and in the neighbor-joining tree from corrected distances (data not shown), the rabbit is a sister group to the bovids + primates clade.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	249	 In the neighbor-joining tree based on uncorrected distances, the rabbit is the sister group to the primates as in our previous report (Vuillaumier et al.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	250	 When an extended set of exon 13 to coding sequences including a nonplacental mammal (the kangaroo) and another nonmurid rodent (guinea pig) were analyzed (fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	251	 3 ), the guinea pig represented a sister group to the rabbit corresponding to the Glires (node E), while the murids were still the most basal of the placental mammals.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Assuming that rodents are a monophyletic group (Novacek and Wyss 1986 ; Luckett and Hartenberger 1993 ; Philippe 1997 ), it appears that the murids are artifactually basal in the placental tree, as they should be a sister group to the guinea pig within clade E.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Thus, the high level of divergence of the mouse sequence not only makes the mouse an inappropriate model for CF studies, but also provokes a phylogenetic artifact.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Unfortunately, the addition of the kangaroo sequence did not correct this artifact, as it was added as a taxon closer to placental mammals than the frog is, in order to break a long branch that could have reduced the possibility of the murid long-branch attraction.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Nevertheless, the conclusions from the phylogenetic analysis do not challenge the proposition of the rabbit as a better CF model whose sequence is more closely related to humans (than murine species are).
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Additionally, the guinea pig appears to be an equally good model candidate.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	257	View larger version (16K):    Fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	258	 The most parsimonious tree from the nucleotide sequences encoding CFTR exon 13 using the branch-and-bound search of PAUP* 4.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	259	 The sequence length is 618 positions, from which 75 positions have been removed because they corresponded to two independent insertions in the teleost sequences, yielding 543 positions, of which 397 were variable and 343 were informative for parsimony.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Taking the above inserted/deleted regions into account produces an identical tree.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	261	 The tree length is 1,134, with a consistency index of 0.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Branch lengths are given using ACCTRAN optimization.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Numbers above the nodes are bootstrap proportions obtained from 1,000 replicates.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	264	 The same tree was recovered with the neighbor-joining method (Saitou and Nei 1987 ) except for the position of the puffer fish, which is a sister group of the killifish in the neighbor-joining tree.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	265	 When the exon 13 to encoding amino acids were analyzed (data not shown), sequence variability and phylogenetic information was lost.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Consequently, nodes C, D, and E collapsed, preventing any conclusion about the interrelationships of placental mammals from the amino acid data set.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The EMBL accession number for the sequence alignment is ALIGN_000079.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	268	View larger version (111K):    Fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	269	  View larger version (113K):    Fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	270	  View larger version (126K):    Fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	271	  View larger version (80K):    Fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	272	  View larger version (69K):    Fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	273	  View larger version (78K):    Fig.
0.41600177.11504857.html.plaintext.txt	274	   Footnotes   William Jeffery, Reviewing Editor.
