0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	661	 Hum Mol Genet 2: 1253-1261, 1993[Abstract].
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	662	Am J Physiol Lung Cell Mol Physiol 282(1):L12-L25 1040-0605/02 $5.
0.4228028.11741811.html.plaintext.txt	663	00 Copyright   2002 the American Physiological Society.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	0	A domain mimic increases F508 CFTR trafficking and restores cAMP-stimulated anion secretion in cystic fibrosis epithelia Lane L.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Gawenis,1 Tzyh-Chang Hwang,2 Nancy M.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	2	Departments of 1Biomedical Sciences and 2Medical Physiology and Pharmacology and Dalton Cardiovascular Research Center, University of Missouri, Columbia, Missouri 65211.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	3	Submitted 5 August 2003 ; accepted in final form 10 March 2004.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	4	protein processing; mouse; retrovirus; gene therapy.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	5	THE MAJOR DISEASE-CAUSING mutation of the cystic fibrosis (CF) transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein is a deletion of phenylalanine at position 508 (F508) in the predicted cytoplasmic domain known as the first nucleotide binding fold (NBF1).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Approximately 70% of CF patients are homozygous for the F508 cftr, and  > 90% carry at least one F508 cftr allele (compound heterozygotes) (11).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Nascent wild-type human (h)CFTR is translated and core-glycosylated at the endoplasmic reticulum (ER).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	8	 A fraction of the core-glycosylated hCFTR protein (25 to 40%; Refs.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	9	 36 and 48) is transported to the Golgi apparatus, where glycosylation is further modified to form mature hCFTR that is targeted to the plasma membrane (5).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	10	 There, the wild-type hCFTR functions as a cyclic nucleotide-regulated anion channel and serves a number of transport functions, including regulation of other ion transport proteins and membrane recycling phenomena (2, 8).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	11	 In contrast to wild-type hCFTR, nearly all of F508 hCFTR is retained in the ER in its core-glycosylated form and sorted to the ubiquitin-proteasome protein degradation pathway instead of the Golgi apparatus (5, 25).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	12	 It is believed that improper folding of the mutant protein is recognized by proteins comprising a cellular "quality control" mechanism that retains misfolded proteins for degradation (44).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Chaperone proteins are also involved in the processing of hCFTR and at least two proteins, HSP70 and calnexin, bind F508 hCFTR with greater avidity than wild-type hCFTR (39).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The process of recognition by the quality control machinery and the conformation of the misfolded F508 hCFTR have not been elucidated.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	15	 In epithelia homozygous for the F508 mutation, retention and degradation of the mutant hCFTR essentially eliminates the capacity for cyclic nucleotide-regulated anion secretion, and it is believed that this deficit is fundamental to the pathogenesis of the disease (38).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	16	Defective processing of F508 hCFTR is at least partially reversible.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Studies in cells expressing recombinant F508 hCFTR and tissues cultured from transgenic F508 murine (m)CFTR mice have shown that a fraction of the mutant protein undergoes biosynthetic maturation when cells are grown at subphysiological temperatures (26 degrees C) (13).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Studies in which F508 hCFTR-expressing cells were treated with "chemical chaperones" such as glycerol and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) or organic cellular osmolytes such as myo-inositol and betaine have also found increased maturation of F508 hCFTR, a result that was attributed to stabilization of the mutant protein (1, 3, 22, 52).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Overexpression of the mutant protein either by transfection or by treatment with butyrate results in trafficking of F508 hCFTR to the plasma membrane (4, 40).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The above observations have important therapeutic implications because F508 hCFTR in the plasma membrane retains its capacity as a cyclic nucleotide-regulated anion channel (13).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Studies in cell-free systems indicate that stimulated F508 hCFTR may have channel kinetics similar to wild-type hCFTR (23, 31, 42), whereas on-cell patch studies measure reduced channel kinetic activity compared with wild-type hCFTR (12, 20, 24).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Even if F508 CFTR has reduced function and shorter membrane residence (32), previous studies suggest that only a small amount (10 to 15%) of F508 CFTR activity in the membrane is required to restore epithelial function and moderate disease (15, 26).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Combined with recent pharmacological studies showing that F508 hCFTR channel activity can be significantly enhanced by treatment with compounds such as 8-cyclopentyl-1,3-dipropylxanthine (CPX), genistein, or class III phosphodiesterase inhibitors (28), it is clear that correcting F508 hCFTR trafficking is a viable strategy for treating CF.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	24	Recent studies have shown that expression of polypeptides representing the structural domain of a protein (i.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	25	, "domain mimics") can predictably alter posttranslational processing of the protein.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Expression of a minigene encoding the carboxy terminus of human ether-a-go-go-related gene was shown to rescue a carboxy-terminal truncation mutant from misprocessing (29).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In another study, a 6-mer peptide mimic of the reactive center loop of 1-antitrypsin was used to block pathological polymerization of the Z variant mutation of the protein (35).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	28	 With regard to CFTR, expression of a polypeptide representing the NBF1 plus the regulatory "R" domain of hCFTR was shown to inhibit activity of ENaC, the epithelial Na+ channel reputedly regulated by CFTR (45).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Because the NBF1 domain of hCFTR is the location of F508 as well as several other processing mutants (46), the NBF1 domain itself may serve as a "checkpoint" for recognition by the cellular quality control machinery or, alternatively, may function in a critical intramolecular interaction that stabilizes hCFTR structure within the ER.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Therefore, we hypothesized that expression of the NBF1 domain may be sufficient to increase F508 CFTR activity in epithelial cells.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The NBF1 domain of CFTR is well conserved among mammalian species (17), and in the mouse, deletion of F508 results in a mCFTR processing defect that recapitulates the fundamental cellular defect of F508 homozygous CF patients (16, 50).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	32	 In the present study, both heterologous cell systems expressing recombinant F508 hCFTR and epithelial monolayers from a F508 CFTR homozygous mouse were used to test the hypothesis that expression of a NBF1 domain mimic increases trafficking F508 CFTR and restores cAMP-stimulated anion secretion.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	33	Stable expression of NBF domain mimics.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	34	 NotI restriction endonuclease site-flanked cDNA constructs of wild-type NBF1 and F508 NBF1 (coding for amino acids 429 to 591 of full-length hCFTR) with a flag epitope (DYKDDDDK) inserted at the carboxy terminus were prepared as previously described (6).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The constructs were subcloned into the Zeocin-selectable vectors pZEOSV or pCDNA3.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	36	 C127 cell lines were transfected with the NBF1 construct plasmids by electroporation and selected in medium containing 200  microg/ml Zeocin.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Clones were isolated 2 wk after electroporation.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	38	 For stable expression of the NBF1 construct in the polarized MGEF and MGEN epithelial cell lines (passages 3 to 16), the NotI-flanked construct was subcloned into the retroviral vector pLXSNz [i.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	39	 John Olsen, University of North Carolina) that was engineered with Zeocin resistance] to form the proviral component NBF1-LXSNz.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	40	 As a positive control, hCFTR cDNA was introduced into the plasmid to produce the proviral component hCFTR-LXSNz.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Transfection by Ca/PO4 precipitation of NBF1-LXSNz, hCFTR-LXSNz, and pLXSNz (empty vector control) into the virus-packaging cell line PA317 led to the production of replication-defective virus.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Virus stock supernatant was used to infect the MGEF and MGEN cells, which were subsequently selected in medium containing 200  microg/ml Zeocin.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Transfected cell lines were screened for expression of the NBF1 constructs by RT-PCR essentially as described previously (19) utilizing a gene-specific primer (5'-GGATCCACTGGAGCAGGCAAG-3') in combination with a primer specific for the flag epitope of the NBF1 domain mimic (5'-ATCATCGTCGTCTTTGTAGTC-3').
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	44	 C127 cells were grown on glass coverslips for whole cell patch-clamp recordings as described previously (47).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Briefly, a Cl to  gradient was established with the following solutions: pipette (in mM): 85 aspartic acid, 5 pyruvic acid, 10 EGTA, 10 HEPES, 20 tetraethylammonium-Cl, 5 Tris, 10 MgATP, 2 MgCl2, and 5.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	46	4 with CsOH); bath (in mM): 145 NaCl, 5 glucose, 5 HEPES, 2 MgCl2, 1 CaCl2, 5 KCl, and 20 sucrose (pH 7.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	47	 An outward current generated by Cl to  influx was observed at a holding potential of 0 mV on activation of CFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The holding current at 0 mV was normalized with the membrane capacitance to yield current density.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Current traces in response to voltage pulses ( plus or minus 100 mV at 20-mV increments) were filtered at 1 kHz with a built-in four-pole Bessel filter and digitized (at 2 kHz) through an ITC-16 interface (Instrutech, Great Neck, NY).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	50	 MGEN and MGEF cells were cultured on a rat tail collagen membrane covering a 4.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	51	5-mm-diameter aperture in polycarbonate cups as previously described (10).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Bioelectric measurements were made under voltage-clamp conditions with intermittent voltage spikes to calculate transepithelial resistance (with Ohm's law).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The preparations were bathed on the luminal and basolateral surfaces with warmed (37 degrees C), oxygenated Krebs bicarbonate Ringer (KBR) solution containing (in mM) 115 NaCl, 4 K2HPO4, 0.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	54	2 CaCl2, and 10 glucose at pH 7.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	55	 In ion substitution studies, gluconate and sulfate replaced Cl to , N-tris(hydroxymethyl)methyl-2-aminoethanesulfonic acid (TES) replaced HCO3 to , and tetramethylammonium (TMA+) replaced Na+ on an equimolar basis.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	56	Detection of hCFTR and F508 hCFTR glycosylation status by immunoprecipitation-32P labeling.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Detection of hCFTR and its glycosylation status was performed as described by Gregory et al.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Cultured cells (1 confluent T-25 flask) were homogenized in 1 ml of lysis buffer [50 mM Tris pH 7.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	59	4, 150 mM NaCl, 10 mM MgCl2, 1% (vol/vol) Triton X-100, 1% (wt/vol) 3-[(3-cholamidopropyl)dimethylammonio]-1-propanesulfonate (CHAPS), 1 mM Pefabloc, 10  microg/ml aprotinin].
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	60	 After low-speed centrifugation to remove insoluble material (14,000 g), CFTR was immunoprecipitated with 1.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	61	5  microg of the monoclonal antibody M3A7 (27), which recognizes an epitope within the NBF2 domain (Genzyme), and the addition of protein A agarose beads.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	62	 After tumbling (2 h, 4 degrees C), the beads were washed three times in lysis buffer and incubated for in vitro phosphorylation in buffer containing 25 mU protein kinase A, 0.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	63	2 mM rATP, and 50  microCi of [-32P]ATP for 10 min at 30 degrees C.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	64	 After washing to remove unincorporated [-32P]ATP, bound phosphorylated protein was eluted from the beads into SDS-PAGE sample buffer at room temperature for 1 h.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Total protein was separated by SDS-PAGE on 4 to 20% gels, dried, and autoradiographed (1 to 7 days).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Densitometric measurements were performed on a Kodak Image Station 2000R (Rochester, NY) with 1D Image Analysis software.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Forskolin, genistein, and 5-nitro-2-(3-phenylpropylamino)benzoate (NPPB) were diluted in DMSO to stock concentrations of 10, 10, and 100 mM, respectively.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Amiloride was diluted to a stock concentration of 10 mM in distilled water.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	69	 All reagents were obtained from either Sigma (St.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Louis, MO) or Fisher Scientific (Springfield, NJ).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Data are expressed as means  plus or minus  SE.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Data between two treatment groups were compared with a two-tailed Student's t-test assuming equal variances.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Data from more than two treatment groups were compared with a one-way ANOVA with a post-hoc Student-Newman-Keuls test.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	74	 A probability value of P  <  0.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	75	05 was considered statistically significant.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	76	View larger version (29K):    Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Immunoblot analysis and whole cell Cl to  current densities of phenylalanine 508-deleted (F508) human (h) cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR)-transfected C127 cells coexpressing first nucleotide-binding fold (NBF1) domain mimics.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	78	 A: lane 1, cells expressing wild-type (WT) hCFTR; lanes 2 to 5, F508 hCFTR cell lines coexpressing F508 (F) NBF1; lanes 6 to 8, F508 hCFTR cell lines coexpressing wild-type NBF1.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	79	 B: relative contribution of band C to pixel intensity profile/lane for WT hCFTR, F508 hCFTR cell lines coexpressing F508 NBF1 (n = 4) and F508 hCFTR cell lines coexpressing wild-type NBF1 (n = 3) from data in A.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Relative intensity was calculated as the pixel intensity of band C/combined pixel intensity for bands B + C (after correction for background in each lane).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	81	 *Significantly different from F NBF1.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	82	 C: whole cell patch-clamp measurements of Cl to  current density (in pA/pF to normalize for differences in cell size) of C127 epithelial cell transfectants.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Data were collected after cell treatment with a cocktail containing 2  microM forskolin and 100  microM genistein.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	84	 WT and F508 C127 cell lines expressing full-length WT and F508 hCFTR, respectively; F508/27 degrees C, C127 cells expressing F508 hCFTR that were maintained at 27 degrees C for 48 h before experimentation; NBF1, wild-type NBF1 domain mimic.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Bars labeled with different letters are significantly different.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	86	  Whole cell patch-clamp analysis was used to investigate Cl to  current density in the cell clones showing a maximal increase in F508 hCFTR maturation after coexpression of the wild-type NBF1 domain mimic.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Because the open probabilities of wild-type hCFTR and F508 hCFTR are greatly enhanced in the presence of forskolin plus genistein (23), the whole cell Cl to  current density was used to estimate the activity of functional channels in the plasma membrane.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	88	 As positive controls, cells expressing wild-type hCFTR and cells expressing F508 hCFTR but exposed to processing-permissive temperature conditions (27 degrees C) for 48 h were also assayed for comparison.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Earlier studies using cells expressing recombinant F508 hCFTR showed that temperature-induced band C expression correlates positively with whole cell Cl to  current and I to  efflux (13, 21).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	90	 1C, C127 cells expressing wild-type hCFTR demonstrate a whole cell Cl to  current density that is severalfold greater than that in cells expressing F508 hCFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Cells expressing F508 hCFTR grown at a temperature permissive for F508 hCFTR trafficking to the plasma membrane had a Cl to  current density that was 50% of wild-type hCFTR-expressing cells.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Most importantly, clonal F508 hCFTR cell lines expressing wild-type NBF1 showed an increased Cl to  current density that was similar in magnitude to that in the temperature-corrected F508 hCFTR cells.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	93	Expression of a NBF1 domain mimic in F508/F508 CFTR murine epithelial monolayers reconstitutes cAMP-stimulated anion secretion.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	94	 The studies described above demonstrate that coexpression of the NBF1 domain mimic can increase plasma membrane activity of F508 hCFTR in an epithelial cell line expressing recombinant protein driven by a nonnative promoter.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Because the level of F508 hCFTR expression can affect trafficking in the cell (4), we asked whether expression of the NBF1 domain mimic would also improve plasma membrane trafficking of endogenously expressed F508 CFTR in a polarized epithelium.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	96	 After an extensive search, we were unable to identify a human F508/F508 CFTR epithelial cell line that retained the ability to both form polarized epithelial monolayers and express significant levels of the endogenous F508 hCFTR protein for the retroviral transfection studies.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Because previous studies demonstrated that defects in processing and plasma membrane expression of the F508 mCFTR homolog in murine epithelia recapitulate the defects of F508 hCFTR (16), an epithelial cell line (MGEF) developed by transformation of gallbladder epithelia from a F508/F508 CFTR mutant mouse model was transfected with the NBF1 domain mimic (50).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	98	As shown by the short-circuit current (Isc) trace from an Ussing chamber experiment (Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	99	 2A), expression of the NBF1 domain mimic in the MGEF epithelial monolayer not only increased the basal Isc [means for n = 9 monolayers: NBF1 =  to 18.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	100	 zeomycin-resistance gene (Zeo) =  to 6.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	101	05] but, more importantly, yielded a distinct Isc response to forskolin stimulation compared with MGEF cells transduced with only the empty vector control (pLXSNz).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Subsequent treatment of the monolayer with the CFTR channel blocker NPPB inhibited both the cAMP-stimulated Isc and a large fraction of the basal Isc.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Although the ionic basis of the residual Isc was not investigated, previous studies indicate the presence of a Ca2+-activated anion channel in the apical membrane of the MGE epithelial cells (9).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	104	 As a negative control, the mCFTR-null cell line MGEN, developed by transformation of gallbladder epithelium from a CFTR knockout mouse, was also transfected with the NBF1 construct for comparison with the NBF1-expressing MGEF cells.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Expression of the NBF1 domain mimic in the MGEN cells slightly increased the basal Isc (means for n = 5 monolayers: NBF1 =  to 4.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	106	 However, in contrast to cAMP-induced Isc responses in the NBF1-expressing MGEF cells, expression of the NBF1 domain mimic in the MGEN cells did not restore the Isc response to cAMP stimulation (see cumulative data in Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	107	 As a positive control for the transfection and selection procedure, hCFTR was expressed in the CFTR( to / to ) MGEN cell line by the same transduction process used for the NBF1-expressing cell lines.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Expression of hCFTR in the MGEN cell monolayers resulted in a significantly greater basal Isc (mean for n = 7 monolayers: hCFTR =  to 6.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	109	 1C, a greater stimulation of Isc after forskolin treatment than MGEN cells transduced with only pLXSNz.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	110	View larger version (26K):    Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Short-circuit current (Isc) measurements of F508/F508 MGEF or murine (m)CFTR-null MGEN epithelial monolayers.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	112	 A: Isc recording of MGEF cells expressing either the selectable zeomycin-resistance gene (Zeo) or NBF1 + Zeo (NBF1).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Repetitive upward current deflections result from applied voltage (2 mV) used to measure transepithelial resistance.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Treatments (arrows) were sequential additions to the luminal bath of 10  microM forskolin (Forsk) and 100  microM 5-nitro-2-(3-phenylpropylamino)benzoate (NPPB).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	115	 B: comparison of the maximal Isc change (Isc) after 10  microM forskolin treatment for MGEF or MGEN cell lines transfected with Zeo, NBF1 + Zeo (NBF1), or wild-type hCFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	116	 *Significantly different from MGEN + Zeo and MGEF + Zeo (n = 5 to 9).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	117	 C: ion substitution studies of the Isc induced by treatment with 10  microM forskolin of MGEF cells expressing NBF1 + Zeo (NBF1).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	118	 KBR, Krebs bicarbonate Ringer solution.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	119	 *Significantly different from KBR (n = 4 to 9).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	120	  Because the cAMP-stimulated Isc in the NBF1-expressing F508 homozygous MGEF monolayers could result from either electrogenic cation (Na+) absorption or electrogenic anion (Cl to  + HCO3 to ) secretion, ion substitution studies were used to investigate the ionic basis of the cAMP-stimulated Isc in the NBF1-expressing MGEF cell line.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	121	 2C, substitution of Na+ with the impermeant cation TMA+ in the mucosal bath did not significantly affect the cAMP-stimulated Isc response compared with the response in standard KBR solution.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Subsequent addition of 10  microM amiloride to the mucosal solution of NBF1-expressing MGEF cells bathed in the standard KBR solution also did not affect the magnitude of the cAMP-stimulated Isc [change in ()Isc =  to 0.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	123	 These findings indicated that the cAMP-induced Isc response in the transduced cell line was not due to electrogenic Na+ absorption.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	124	 In contrast, when both Cl to  and HCO3 to  were substituted with impermeant anions in the mucosal and serosal bathing solutions, the cAMP-stimulated Isc of the NBF1-expressing MGEF cell monolayers was nearly eliminated.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Together with the evidence that the cAMP-stimulated Isc response in the NBF1-expressing MGEF cells is sensitive to NPPB (see Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	126	 2A), the findings are consistent with the conclusion that the stimulated Isc represents F508 CFTR-mediated anion secretion.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	127	cAMP-stimulated Isc is maintained in successive passages of the NBF1-expressing MGEF epithelial cell line.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Previous studies showed that expression of recombinant CFTR can induce downregulation of the cftr gene and adversely affect cell proliferation (41).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Therefore, we compared the stability of the Isc response in the NBF1-expressing MGEF cell line with that in the hCFTR-expressing MGEN cell line by measuring the cAMP-stimulated Isc response of monolayers from successive passages of the two cell lines.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	130	 3, the NBF1-expressing MGEF cell monolayers maintained an almost identical magnitude of cAMP-stimulated Isc response for over 30 passages (passaged every 4 to 7 days).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	131	 In contrast, the magnitude of the cAMP-stimulated Isc progressively decreased in hCFTR-transfected MGEN cells with successive passages and was essentially absent after passage 9.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	132	View larger version (13K):    Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Comparison of the maximal Isc resulting from treatment with 10  microM forskolin for the MGEN cell line expressing hCFTR and the MGEF cell line expressing NBF1 for successive passages.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Cell lines were passaged approximately once per week.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Each data point represents an average of experiments from 2 to 5 monolayers.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	136	Restoration of cAMP-stimulated anion secretion in the F508 CFTR-expressing epithelial cells yielded bioelectrical responses with characteristics consistent with activation of a F508 CFTR conductance.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	137	 In studies of F508 hCFTR cells expressing NBF1, genistein-forskolin treatment increased whole cell Cl to  currents to 50% of those exhibited by C127 cells stably expressing wild-type CFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	138	 This difference, whether due to reduced open probability or to numbers of membrane channels, is similar to that observed when F508 hCFTR cells are exposed to reduced ambient temperature or after increased expression of the mutant CFTR (4, 13, 16, 40).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	139	 In studies of the polarized MGEF monolayers expressing NBF1, the macroscopic Isc response to forskolin treatment activated at a slower rate compared with MGEN cells expressing wild-type hCFTR (data not shown), which might reflect a characteristic of the F508 CFTR protein that attenuates its protein kinase A phosphorylation-dependent activation (47).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	140	 However, in contrast to the C127 cells, the absolute magnitude of the cAMP-induced Isc in the NBF1-expressing MGEF monolayers was approximately the same as in the MGEN monolayers expressing recombinant hCFTR.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	141	 This variance may reflect differences in the activities of the recombinant vs.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	142	 the endogenous CFTR channel or result from inherent differences in F508 CFTR properties between the two species (30).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Interestingly, the basal Isc of the NBF1-expressing MGEF and MGEN cells was elevated compared with the Zeocin-expressing control monolayers.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	144	 This change is consistent with previous demonstrations that expression of NBF1 yields a transmembrane configuration of the peptide and an increase in the basal halide permeability in mammalian cell lines (7, 19).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	145	 However, similar to our findings with the NBF1-expressing MGEN cells, expression of only the NBF1 domain did not result in cAMP-regulated anion permeability.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	146	 In the present study, restoration of cAMP-regulated anion secretion required NBF1 coexpression in F508 CFTR-expressing epithelial cells.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	147	Expression of cytosolic domain mimics has previously been used to alter specific intra- and intermolecular interactions within cells.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Pioneering work by Lefkowitz and coworkers (33) used domain mimics to disrupt interactions between plasma membrane receptors and G proteins coupled to phospholipase C activation.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	149	 More recently, a domain mimic expressed via a minigene was used to rescue misprocessing of a carboxy-terminal truncation mutant of human ether-a-go-go-related protein (29) and a domain peptide was used to selectively mask portions of mutant 1-antitrypsin to prevent posttranslational polymerization within hepatocytes (35).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	150	 With regard to CFTR, exogenous copies of the R domain have been shown to interact with full-length CFTR and modify gating behavior of its channel activity (34).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Domain mimics of CFTR and the integral membrane protein syntaxin 1A were used to modify channel activity and demonstrate a direct protein-protein interaction (37).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Furthermore, peptide mimics have been used to demonstrate binding interactions between NBF1 and the R domain of CFTR, which could be partially disrupted by introduction of the F508 mutation (6).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	153	Given the findings of the present study and previous observations with expression of recombinant F508 CFTR (4, 40), at least two mechanisms can be postulated that would result in increased processing of F508 CFTR beyond the ER.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	154	 First, expression of recombinant NBF1 may overwhelm the quality control system that is involved in retention and degradation of the mutant protein.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	155	 A similar process could be postulated for the plasma membrane appearance of F508 hCFTR when the mutant protein is overexpressed in heterologous cell systems (4, 40).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	156	 This mechanism would predict competitive binding for, perhaps specific, chaperone proteins or proteases, thereby allowing escape of mutant protein from the ER.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	157	 However, some evidence weakens the case for this proposed mechanism.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Our measures of protein expression in the C127 cells indicated that clones expressing wild-type NBF1 were more likely to have greater expression of the fully processed F508 CFTR compared with clones expressing the F508 NBF1 peptide (Fig.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	159	 This seems contrary to the prediction that F508 NBF1 would be more efficacious in competing for quality control proteins.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Furthermore, although it is possible that the concentration of the recombinant NBF1 at the quality control binding site(s) far exceeds that needed to discern differences between the two domain mimics, our estimates of NBF1 peptide concentration ( < 5 ng/ microl in cell pellets, as based on detection of the flag epitope with M2 monoclonal antibody) are well below the millimolar concentrations that are typically necessary to inhibit proteases with chemical inhibitors (25, 49).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The second potential mechanism by which NBF1 expression may lead to increased processing of F508 CFTR is that coexpression of additional NBF1 peptides may bind immature F508 CFTR and stabilize its structure in the ER.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	162	 For example, peptide interaction with the R domain of F508 CFTR may mask a site on the misfolded protein that is recognized by the quality control machinery, or additional copies of NBF1 may temporarily interact with F508 CFTR to catalyze a folding reaction that results in properly folded protein.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Given recent evidence that mature CFTR protein may dimerize in the plasma membrane (51), it seems plausible that cooperation between different CFTR monomers may be necessary for correct folding and that this interaction may be mimicked by the NBF1 domain peptides.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	164	Although the precise mechanism resulting in increased expression of F508 CFTR at the plasma membrane using coexpression of NBF1 peptides remains speculative, the significant aspect of the present study is that it suggests a refinement for therapeutic approaches to correcting F508 CFTR processing.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	165	 One major drawback to the use of viral vectors such as adeno-associated virus 2 for gene therapy is that the packaging capacity of the virus is limited, which, with a large gene like CFTR, leaves little capacity for promoter sequences (14).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Thus modification of the strategy to instead transfect only the NBF1 domain is attractive because the small size of the construct (0.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	167	5 kb) would improve packaging efficiency.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Furthermore, two biological advantages of using NBF1 domain transduction as therapy can be envisioned.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	169	 First, the expression of F508 CFTR is driven by its endogenous promoter, which may avoid the consequences of CFTR overexpression on the epithelium, e.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	170	, reduced cell proliferation potential (41).
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	171	 A second advantage is that the NBF1 peptide is less likely to be toxic than the full-length channel protein when inadvertently expressed in nontarget tissues.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The NBF1 construct fused to a protein transduction domain (43) may also be useful for peptide therapy, especially if the smallest effective subunit of NBF1 can be defined.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Thus, on the basis of the observations in the present study, the therapeutic approach to correcting the basic protein-processing defect of F508 CFTR should be refined to focus on NBF1 domain mimics that alter trafficking of the mutant protein.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	174	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We acknowledge the technical assistance of Julie Schultz and Shenghui Hu.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Gruis: Pioneer Hi-Bred International, Inc.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	176	, Suite 800, PO Box 14453, Des Moines, IA 50306-3453.

0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Clarke, 324D Dalton Cardiovascular Research Center, Research Park Drive, Univ.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	179	 of Missouri-Columbia, Columbia, MO 65211 (E-mail: clarkel{at}missouri.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	180	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	183	1 An abstract presented at the 16th Annual North American Cystic Fibrosis Conference reported that coexpression of F508 CFTR with an amino-terminal fragment of CFTR (amino acids 1 to 633) induced the maturation of F508 CFTR in Cos7 cells (Cormet-Boyaka EA and Kirk KL.

0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	320	2003v1 Alert me when this article is cited Alert me if a correction is posted Citation Map Services Email this article to a friend Similar articles in this journal Similar articles in ISI Web of Science Similar articles in PubMed Alert me to new issues of the journal Download to citation manager Search for citing articles in: ISI Web of Science (1) Google Scholar Articles by Clarke, L.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Articles citing this Article PubMed PubMed Citation Articles by Clarke, L.
0.42343527.15028554.html.plaintext.txt	322	HOME HELP FEEDBACK SUBSCRIPTIONS ARCHIVE SEARCH TABLE OF CONTENTS Visit Other APS Journals Online Copyright   2004 by the American Physiological Society.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	0	A Principal Role for the Proteasome in Endoplasmic Reticulum-associated Degradation of Misfolded Intracellular Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator* Marina S.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Department of Biological Sciences, Stanford University, Stanford, California 94305-5020.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, December 14, 2001, and in revised form, January 16, 2002.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	3	The endoplasmic reticulum (ER)1 is the site of synthesis of membrane and secretory proteins and the site of their conformational maturation and assembly into correctly folded functional molecules.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	4	 "Quality control" refers to the system that monitors the folding and assembly of proteins in the ER, ensuring that only correctly folded proteins can mature to later compartments of the secretory pathway (1, 2).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Nascent proteins that fail to fold or assemble in the ER are degraded by a process known as ER-associated degradation (ERAD) (3).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Studies in mammalian cells and in yeast have led to the formulation of a general model for ERAD in which substrates are degraded by cytoplasmic proteasomes following retrotranslocation (i.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	7	 "dislocation") across the ER membrane by a process that requires the Sec61 translocon and functional ubiquitylation machinery at the cytosolic face of the ER membrane (4-6).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Dislocation of ERAD substrates across the ER membrane is kinetically coupled to their degradation by proteasomes, and in many cases, cytosolic intermediates of degradation are hard to detect (7, 8).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Although a central role for proteasomes in ERAD is widely accepted, a number of studies have suggested that other, nonproteasomal, proteolytic systems may also contribute to the elimination of misfolded proteins from the ER (9-12).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	10	The polytopic membrane protein cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) is a chloride channel expressed at the apical surface of polarized epithelial cells and one of the first integral membrane proteins demonstrated to be a substrate of the ubiquitin-proteasome system (9, 13).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Mutations in the CFTR gene cause the recessively inherited fatal disease cystic fibrosis.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Although nearly 1000 mutations have been linked to cystic fibrosis, the majority of Caucasian cystic fibrosis patients have at least one copy of the F508 mutation, a temperature-sensitive allele that is unable to fold correctly at physiological temperature.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	13	 As a consequence, F508 CFTR (F508) is not deployed to the plasma membrane and is instead rapidly degraded without being processed in the Golgi apparatus (14, 15).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	14	Several lines of evidence support a role for the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway in F508 turnover.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	15	 First, CFTR undergoes both co-translational and posttranslational ubiquitylation when expressed in a cell-free system (16, 17).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Second, inhibition of proteasome function with chemical inhibitors or with a dominant negative form of ubiquitin leads to accumulation of multiubiquitylated, undegraded forms of CFTR and F508 (13).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Third, degradation of F508 in a cell-free system is sensitive to inhibitors of both the 19 S and 20 S subunits of the proteasome (17, 18).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Curiously, despite this compelling evidence in support of a role for proteasomes in the degradation of misfolded CFTR, the effect of proteasome inhibition on the disappearance of F508 from pulse-chase studies is minimal (9, 13).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	19	 This observation has led some investigators to conclude that other proteolytic systems are primarily responsible for the ERAD of misfolded CFTR molecules (9).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	20	 However, no other proteases or proteolytic systems have been convincingly demonstrated to contribute to the degradation of CFTR or other ERAD substrates.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Therefore, the intracellular fate of F508 and the identity of the proteases that participate in its degradation remain unresolved.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	22	Reagents-- Most chemicals (with the exception of some proteasome inhibitors) were obtained from Sigma Chemical Co.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Epoxomicin and carbobenzoxy-L-leucyl-leucyl-L-leucinal (MG132) were obtained from Calbiochem.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	24	 YU102 was generously provided by Dr.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Graig Crews (Yale University, New Haven, CT).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Polyclonal anti-GFP antibody was a kind gift from Dr.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Michael Rexach (Stanford University).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	28	Constructs and Cell Lines-- pGFP-CFTR in a pEGFP-C1 vector (CLONTECH) was obtained from Dr.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Stanton (Dartmouth Medical School, Hanover, NH) and subsequently subcloned into pcDNA3.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	30	1 vector (Invitrogen) using NheI and EcoRV.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	31	 F508 mutation was introduced by replacing the [Pml1-Blp1] cassette within the CFTR sequence.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	32	 For selection of stable CHO cell lines, GFP-F508/pcDNA3 plasmid was linearized and transfected into CHO cells by calcium phosphate precipitation.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The cells were subjected to selection in G418-containing medium.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Stable transfectants were expanded in culture and enriched for GFP-F508-expressing cells by fluorescence-activated cell sorting of highly fluorescent cells after overnight incubation of these cells with the proteasome inhibitor N-acetyl-L-leucinyl-L-leucinyl-L-norleucinal.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Cells were then cloned into 96-well dishes at a density of 1 cell/well.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Clonal cell lines were expanded and analyzed for full-length GFP-F508 expression by immunoblotting, and a single clone (clone 2) was selected for this study.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Generation of human embryonic kidney HEK293 cells stably expressing GFPu was described elsewhere (20).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	38	35S Labeling and Immunoprecipitation-- CHO clone 2 cells were plated on 10  x  10-cm dishes and treated with 5 mM butyrate overnight to increase GFP-F508 expression.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	39	 The next day, cells were starved in cysteine/methionine-free media for 30 min and then labeled with [35S]cysteine/methionine (specific activity, 1 mCi/ml) for 30 min in the presence of 5 mM butyrate.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Two 10-cm dishes were harvested immediately after the pulse (t = 0 h), whereas the remaining dishes were chased in the presence of the protein synthesis inhibitor emetine (75  microM) or emetine and MG132 (25  microM) together.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	41	 At specified time intervals, cells were solubilized in buffer A (10 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	42	5, 5 mM EDTA, 150 mM NaCl, 1% NP-40, 0.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	43	05% deoxycholate) containing a CompleteTM protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Diagnostics GmbH) for 30 min.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Cell lysates were precleared with protein A-Sepharose beads and incubated with anti-GFP antibody and protein A-Sepharose.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The immunoprecipitates were washed extensively with buffer A and fractionated by 4-15% gradient SDS-PAGE (Bio-Rad).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Quantitation of radioactive bands was done using PhosphorImager SI and ImageQuant software (Molecular Dynamics).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	47	Fluorescence-activated Cell-sorting Assay-- Analysis of GFP-F508 CFTR fluorescence by flow cytometry was performed using Coulter  Epics  XL-MCL Flow Cytometer and EXPO v.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Cells were typically incubated with 5 mM butyrate overnight to increase GFP-F508 CFTR expression or with 10  microg/ml N-acetyl-L-leucinyl-L-leucinyl-L-norleucinal for 3 h to increase GFPu steady-state level.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	49	 After the addition of emetine with or without protease inhibitors, cultures were incubated for different time intervals before analysis.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Data from 10,000 cells were collected, and the mean fluorescence of the cell population was used as a measure of GFP-F508 levels after each treatment.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	51	Effect of Proteasome Inhibitors on GFP-F508 Degradation in Metabolic Pulse-chase Analysis-- To validate the use of GFP-F508 as a model of F508 degradation, we performed pulse-chase analysis in a clonal CHO cell line (cl.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	52	2) stably expressing this fusion protein.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	53	2 cells were selected for low basal expression levels to avoid accumulation of GFP-F508 in detergent-insoluble aggresomes, which are highly refractory to degradation (23).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Before use, the cells were treated with the transcriptional activator sodium butyrate to increase GFP-F508 expression.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Under these conditions, aggregation of GFP-F508 was undetectable by either immunoblot or fluorescence microscopy (data not shown).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Immunoprecipitation of metabolically labeled cell lysates with anti-GFP antibody revealed a major Mr ~170,000 band corresponding to core-glycosylated GFP-F508 and high molecular weight (HMW) species migrating near the top of the gel (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	57	 During the chase, the Mr 170,000 band disappeared with first-order kinetics (t1/2 = 50 min), consistent with previous determinations of F508 (9, 24, 25) and GFP-F508 half-life (23).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	58	 In the presence of MG132, a specific proteasome inhibitor (26), the half-life of this species was only modestly extended (t1/2 = 1.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	59	 A minor band migrating at Mr ~50,000 probably corresponds to an amino-terminal fragment of the GFP-508 fusion protein comprising Mr ~20,000 of CFTR in addition to the GFP moiety because it reacted with antibody to GFP, but not with an antibody raised against the carboxyl terminus of CFTR (data not shown).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Disappearance of the Mr 50,000 fragment paralleled that of the Mr 170,000 band (t1/2 = 1.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	61	1 h) and was also only modestly inhibited by MG132 (t1/2 = 1.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	62	 HMW forms of GFP-F508 were detected immediately after the pulse (top band in Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	63	 These complexes disappeared rapidly when the chase was conducted in the absence of proteasome inhibitor (t1/2 = 0.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	64	9 h), but in contrast to the core-glycosylated protein and the Mr 50,000 fragment, they were strongly stabilized by the presence of MG132 (t1/2 = 6.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	65	View larger version (59K):    Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	66	   Pulse-chase analysis of GFP-F508 CFTR degradation.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	67	 A, butyrate-treated CHO cells were labeled with [35S]cysteine/methionine and chased for the indicated time intervals in the presence or absence of MG132 (25  microM).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Cells were then solubilized, and lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-GFP antibody as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	69	" B, quantitation of individual bands and total radioactivity in each lane was performed using ImageQuant software.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Filled symbols represent cells that were chased without MG132, and open symbols represent cells chased in the presence of 25  microM MG132.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The insets show semilog plots of these data.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	72	 In the insets, solid and broken lines represent cells chased without or with MG132, respectively.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	73	The HMW complexes could represent either polyubiquitylated forms of monomeric GFP-F508 (16, 17) or detergent-insoluble aggregates of CFTR (23).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	74	 To distinguish between these possibilities, we sought to determine whether the HMW material that accumulated during the chase in the presence of MG132 could be degraded after washout of the inhibitor.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Our results (data not shown) indicate that the HMW material was soluble in nonionic detergent and competent for degradation, strongly suggesting that the increase in molecular weight was due to covalent modification with Ub, as observed previously for CFTR in cell-free extracts (17).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	76	Quantification of the pulse-chase data indicates that MG132 was only marginally effective at stabilizing the Mr 170,000 F508 band.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Even when the total amount of GFP-immunoreactive material is considered (the sum of all electrophoretic species, Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	78	 1B, bottom right panel), only 40% of the initial amount of GFP-F508 was stable at the end of a 4-h chase, despite proteasome inhibition.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	79	 This observation suggests several plausible explanations.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	80	 First, as suggested by Jensen et al.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	81	 (9), in addition to proteasomes, other proteolytic systems could also contribute to F508 ERAD.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Alternatively, it is possible that some proteolytic activities within the proteasome remain uninhibited in the presence of MG132 and continue to degrade the substrate.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Finally, immunoprecipitation of radiolabeled material from detergent extracts of pulse-labeled cells may underestimate the amount of stable F508 if some of the protein becomes insoluble, if the epitope used for immunoprecipitation becomes inaccessible, or if the increased molecular weight (due to polyubiquitylation and/or aggregation) of the protein prevents it from being well resolved by SDS-PAGE.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	84	 We reasoned that a noninvasive method of monitoring the fluorescence of GFP-F508 in intact cells using fluorescence-activated cell-sorting analysis may be a more accurate way to measure protein stability because it does not rely upon efficient recovery of radiolabeled protein from cells or upon the detection of a resolvable electrophoretic species.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	85	 This would in turn allow us to better evaluate the effect of protease inhibitors on prevention of CFTR degradation.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	86	Fluorescence-based Determination of GFP-F508 Degradation-- To circumvent the limitations of the pulse-chase approach, we developed a fluorescence-based assay to measure degradation of GFP-F508.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Inhibition of GFP-F508 synthesis in butyrate-treated cells with emetine, an inhibitor of translational elongation, caused a rapid decrease in mean fluorescence, as measured by flow cytometry (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Similar results were obtained with other translation inhibitors including cycloheximide and puromycin (data not shown).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Emetine does not affect the degradation kinetics of CFTR or F508 (13).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The decrease in GFP-F508 fluorescence fitted a first-order exponential with a t1/2 = 60 min, in good agreement with the GFP-F508 half-life measured in pulse-chase experiments (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	91	 In a control experiment, CHO cells expressing GFP alone were incubated with emetine for up to 10 h without any loss of total fluorescence (data not shown), consistent with GFP being a stable protein (20) and indicating that emetine treatment does not cause detectable cell lysis during the course of the experiment.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Together, these results suggest that the decline in the fluorescence of cl.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	93	2 cells upon exposure to protein synthesis inhibitor faithfully reflects the degradation of F508 and constitutes a valid and convenient method for characterization of this degradation process.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	94	View larger version (17K):    Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	95	   Fluorescence-based measurement of F508 CFTR degradation rate.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Butyrate-treated cells were incubated with 75  microM emetine for the indicated time intervals, and cellular fluorescence was measured by flow cytometry.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The mean fluorescence of 10,000 cells was determined at each time point and represented as a percentage of initial fluorescence.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The inset shows a semilog plot of fluorescence decline versus time in emetine, from which the half-time of fluorescence decline was calculated.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	99	Inhibition of GFP-F508 Degradation by Proteasome Inhibitors-- To assess the effect of inhibition of different proteolytic systems on the degradation of mutant CFTR using the fluorescence assay, we evaluated the effect of a panel of protease inhibitors on the decline in GFP-F508 fluorescence in butyrate-treated cl.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	100	2 cells in the presence of emetine (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Among the inhibitors tested, only those that are known to inhibit the proteasome (N-acetyl-L-leucinyl-L-leucinyl-L-norleucinal, clasto-lactacystin -lactone, and MG132) significantly slowed the degradation of GFP-F508.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	102	 In contrast, inhibitors of serine and cysteine proteases (TPCK, N-tosyl-Lys-chloromethyl ketone, and phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride), calpains (EDTA), lysosomal cathepsins ((2S,3S)-trans-epoxysuccinyl-L-leucylamido-3-methylbutane ethyl ester, chloroquine, and NH4Cl), and autophagy (3-methyladenine and wortmannin) had no measurable effect on the degradation process, either alone (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	103	 3A) or in combination with MG132 (25  microM) (data not shown).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	104	 These data confirm a central role for proteasomes in the degradation of F508 and suggest that other major proteolytic systems do not contribute significantly to this process.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	105	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	106	   Effect of protease inhibitors on GFP-F508 fluorescence.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	107	2 cells were treated with 5 mM butyrate overnight and incubated for 4 h with emetine alone (75  microM) or with emetine and one of the following protease inhibitors: N-acetyl-L-leucinyl-L-leucinyl-L-norleucinal (ALLN; 10  microg/ml), (2S,3S)-trans-epoxysuccinyl-L-leucylamido-3-methylbutane ethyl ester (EST; 10  microM), -lactone (25  microM); EDTA (2 mM), chloroquine (150  microM), NH4Cl (10 mM), MG132 (25  microM), N-tosyl-Lys-chloromethyl ketone (TLCK; 2  microg/ml), 3-methyladenine (3-MA; 10 mM), TPCK (2  microg/ml), and wortmannin (100 nM).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Fluorescence at the end of 4 h was expressed as a percentage of initial fluorescence at t = 0, after subtraction of background fluorescence (CHO cell autofluorescence).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	109	 B, CHO clone 2 cells expressing GFP-F508 (solid line) or HEK293 cells expressing GFPu (broken line) were incubated with 75  microM emetine ( or , respectively) or with 75  microM emetine and 25  microM MG132 ( or , respectively) for the indicated time intervals.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Mean cellular fluorescence was expressed as a percentage of initial fluorescence at t = 0 h, after subtraction of background fluorescence.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	111	In the presence of MG132 (25  microM), the fluorescence of GFP-F508 first increased, reaching almost 120% of the initial fluorescence after 1 h of emetine chase (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	112	 This increase probably reflects slow fluorogenesis of the GFP moiety (t1/2 = 30-90 min; 27, 28) in the absence of CFTR degradation.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Indeed, this transient increase in fluorescence is also observed with GFPu, a GFP molecule that is targeted to the ubiquitin-proteasome system for degradation via a short carboxyl-terminal degron (20) (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	114	 However, in contrast to GFPu, which was completely stabilized by 25  microM MG132, the fluorescence of GFP-F508 started to decline after the first hour and dropped to about 70% of initial fluorescence after 4 h of emetine chase.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The half-time of the decline of GFP-F508 fluorescence in the presence of MG132 (25  microM) was 6.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	116	8 h, indicating that proteasome inhibition results in substantial stabilization of GFP-F508.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	117	To determine whether the continued decline in GFP-F508 fluorescence in the presence of MG132 was due to degradation by the proteasome, we examined the effect of increased inhibitor concentration on the fluorescence remaining at the 4 h chase point (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	118	 These data suggest that GFP-F508 degradation is inhibited by MG132 biphasically with a high-affinity component (IC50  10  microM) and a low-affinity component that we were not able to saturate, even at concentrations as high as 300  microM.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	119	View larger version (17K):    Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	120	   Dose dependence of proteasome inhibitors in the fluorescence assay.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	121	 A, fluorescence of butyrate-treated CHO cl.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	122	2 cells was measured at 4 h after the addition of emetine and the indicated concentrations of MG132 and expressed as a percentage of the initial fluorescence at t = 0 h.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Values represent the average of three experiments.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	124	2 cells were incubated with emetine alone () or emetine plus the following concentrations of epoxomicin: 1  microM (), 5  microM (), 10  microM (), 20  microM (), and 50  microM ().
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Inset, rate constants of GFP-F508 degradation were calculated and plotted as a function of epoxomicin concentration.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	126	2 cells were incubated with increasing concentrations of epoxomicin in the absence () or presence () of 500  microM YU102.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Values represent the average of three separate experiments + S.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	128	To further investigate the role of proteasomes in GFP-F508 degradation, we performed a titration of epoxomicin, a highly specific and potent proteasome inhibitor (29).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Like MG132, epoxomicin inhibited GFP-F508 fluorescence decay biphasically with a high-affinity component (IC50  <  1  microM) and a low-affinity component (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Although epoxomicin can inhibit all three of the characterized activities of the proteasomes, it is 66- and 500- fold more effective at inhibiting the chymotrypsin-like (CT-L) activity than the trypsin-like or peptidyl-glutamyl hydrolyzing activities, respectively (30).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	131	 To investigate whether the low-affinity component of the MG132 and epoxomicin titrations was due to non-CT-L activities, we performed a titration of epoxomicin in the presence of 500  microM YU102, an ','-epoxyketone inhibitor that is selective for the peptidyl-glutamyl hydrolyzing activity of the proteasome (30).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	132	 This treatment resulted in a small (10-15%) but significant increase in the degree of inhibition of GFP-F508 fluorescence decay at all epoxomicin concentrations (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	133	 These results suggest that the CT-L and peptidyl-glutamyl hydrolyzing activities of the proteasome may contribute independently to the degradation of GFP-F508.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	134	A hallmark of proteolysis by the Ub-proteasome system is its dependence on ATP hydrolysis.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	135	 ATP is required for at least two steps in Ub-dependent degradation: activation of Ub, and substrate unfolding (31, 32).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	136	 However, previous studies suggested that the fraction of CFTR degradation that is insensitive to proteasome inhibitors is independent of ATP (9).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	137	 To assess the dependence of GFP-F508 degradation on ATP, we assayed GFP-F508 fluorescence in ATP-depleted cl.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	138	 These data demonstrate that GFP-F508 degradation is absolutely dependent on the presence of cellular ATP.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The degradation of GFPu was similarly dependent upon ATP (Fig.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	140	ER-associated degradation is a central element of the quality control pathways that ensure that only correctly folded and assembled proteins are deployed in the secretory pathway of eukaryotic cells.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Although many studies have confirmed a primary role of the Ub-proteasome system in ERAD, the apparently minimal effect of highly potent proteasome inhibitors on the degradation of CFTR has remained an enigma and has suggested that other ATP-independent proteolytic systems also contribute to ERAD.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	142	 In this study, we have used a fluorescent substrate to re-evaluate the role of the UPS in ERAD.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Our data establish the primacy of the UPS in the degradation of ER-associated misfolded CFTR and suggest that the different proteolytic functionalities of the proteasome, associated with the three active -subunits, may operate independently in the degradation of an ERAD substrate (GFP-F508), but apparently not in the degradation of a cytoplasmic substrate (GFPu).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Three lines of evidence support our conclusion that the UPS is the principal pathway for degradation of misfolded CFTR.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	145	 First, proteasome inhibitors, but not inhibitors of serine or cysteine proteases or inhibitors of lysosomal or autophagic pathways, strongly stabilize GFP-F508 fluorescence.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Second, GFP-F508 degradation was inhibited by MG132 and epoxomicin in a dose-dependent fashion, with biphasic apparent IC50 values in the expected range for CT-L and non-CT-L activities (30).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Third, GFP-F508 degradation was strictly dependent on ATP, a hallmark of UPS-mediated proteolysis (31, 32).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The possibility that other proteases initiate the clipping of the CFTR molecule while it is situated in the ER membrane, followed by proteasome-mediated proteolysis, is also unlikely because simultaneous addition of protease and proteasome inhibitors did not protect CFTR from degradation.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Although our results do not rule out participation in CFTR degradation of protease classes for which cell-permeable inhibitors are not available (i.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	150	 aspartic proteases, aminopeptidases, and so forth) or of substrate-specific proteases (e.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	151	 colligin is a specific inhibitor of procollagen degradation (33)), these data establish that inhibition of proteolytic activities of the proteasome alone is sufficient to prevent the degradation of the majority of F508 molecules in living cells.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	152	In previous studies using metabolic pulse-chase labeling and immunoprecipitation, proteasome inhibitors including MG132 and lactacystin had a very modest effect at inhibiting the decay of the electrophoretic species corresponding to core-glycosylated F508 degradation (9, 13).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	153	 In the present work, we show that at least part of radiolabel lost from core-glycosylated GFP-F508 could be recovered as high molecular weight material.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Because this HMW material remains competent for degradation, our data suggest that in the absence of proteasome function, a significant fraction of radiolabeled GFP-F508 molecules are converted to multiubiquitylated forms.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Accumulation of HMW forms in the presence of proteasome inhibition is not observed for most other ERAD substrates such as the -subunit of the T-cell receptor (7, 34) and soluble proteins such as IgG light chains (8), which tend to accumulate as core-glycosylated detergent-soluble monomers in the ER after proteasome inhibition.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	156	 It is likely that this difference is a consequence of the topology of CFTR, in which most of the mass of the protein is accessible to the cytoplasmic face of the ER and hence to components of the ubiquitin conjugation system.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	157	 A recent study reported that inhibition of proteasome function leads to accumulation of a substantial fraction of CFTR in reconstituted cell-free extracts as high molecular weight multiubiquitylated protein (17).
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	158	We thank Neil Bence for providing HEK293 cells expressing GFPu and Karim Helmy for help with epoxomicin and ATP depletion experiments.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Craig Crews for a kind gift of YU102.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	160	 We also thank members of the Kopito laboratory for helpful comments.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	161	* This work was supported in part by National Institutes of Health Grant R01 DK43994 (to R.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	162	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	165	Supported in part by a postdoctoral training grant from the National Institutes of Health.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	166	  To whom correspondence should be addressed: Dept.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	167	 of Biological Sciences, Stanford University, 371 Serra Mall, Stanford, CA 94305-5020.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	168	: 650-723-7581; Fax: 650-723-8475; E-mail: kopito@stanford.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	169	Published, JBC Papers in Press, January 25, 2002, DOI 10.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	170	The abbreviations used are: ER, endoplasmic reticulum; ERAD, endoplasmic reticulum-associated degradation; UPS, ubiquitin-proteasome system; TPCK, tosylphenylalanyl chloromethyl ketone; CHO, Chinese hamster ovary, CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; GFP, green fluorescent protein; cl.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	171	2, clone 2; HMW, high molecular weight; Ub, ubiquitin; CT-L, chymotrypsin-like.
0.42448953.11812794.html.plaintext.txt	172	Copyright   2002 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	0	EDITORIAL FOCUS Focus on "Exocytosis is not involved in activation of Cl secretion via CFTR in Calu-3 airway epithelial cells" William B.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Physiology and Pediatrics, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, Maryland 21205.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	2	RAPID CHANGES IN salt and water movement occur in many epithelial tissues that respond quickly to alterations in overall salt and water balance.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	3	 For example, the amount of Cl secreted by the shark rectal gland can vary greatly in response to changes in the external environment (4).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	4	 To rapidly change the rate of transport, epithelial cells regulate the transport rates of specific ion channels, pumps, and carriers.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	5	 This regulation commonly occurs by either affecting the activity of an individual transport process and/or the number of transport entities in the plasma membrane.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The activity of many ion channels is regulated by voltage, by extracellular ligands, or by intracellular signal transduction mechanisms (6).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Thus many ion channels can be easily switched on and off to match the needs of a rapidly changing physiological process.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	8	 CFTR is an excellent example of a highly regulated Cl channel (2).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The activity of CFTR is controlled by the coordination of two processes, phosphorylation of several sites primarily within the regulatory domain followed by ATP binding and hydrolysis by the nucleotide binding domains.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	10	 These two processes act together to both switch on and regulate channel opening (3).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	11	In contrast, in some clear-cut cases, once inserted into the plasma membrane the activity of a variety of transporters is difficult to regulate.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	12	 In those cases, the most effective way to modulate transepithelial transport is to alter the number of transporters in the plasma membrane.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	13	 For example, it is well known that mature aquaporin water channels move water in an unregulated fashion (1).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	14	 To modulate overall transepithelial water transport such as in the renal collecting duct, vesicles containing aquaporin 2 water channels are rapidly inserted into the plasma membrane following activation by antidiuretic hormone (8).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The specific question addressed by this article in focus is whether exocytosis is involved in the activation of Cl secretion via CFTR in the human airway serous cell line, Calu-3.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Serous cells are located primarily in the submucosal glands of human airway and are known to express CFTR.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	17	The overall question of how much of the function of CFTR is dependent on its insertion into the plasma membrane can be answered by the phrase "it depends.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	18	" CFTR is expressed in a variety of tissues, including airway, pancreas, gastrointestinal tract, heart, and kidney, where it participates in ion transport (5).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Thus how much of CFTR-mediated transport is controlled by exocytosis may depend critically on which organ is being considered.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Moreover, when cultured cells are being studied, it may also depend on the degree of differentiation of the cells.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	21	For example, in the current article in focus (Ref.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	22	 C913 in this issue), Loffing and colleagues demonstrate that exocytosis of CFTR-containing vesicles is not involved in the activation of Cl secretion in Calu-3 cells.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Similarly, exocytic delivery of CFTR does not occur in gallbladder epithelium (14).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Presumably in these tissues, activation of resident CFTR is sufficient to regulate transport.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	25	 In other tissues such as the shark rectal gland, bronchial epithelial cells, and in transporting cell lines such as Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) II and A6, cAMP increases the amount of CFTR in the apical cell membrane (7, 9, 11, 13).
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	26	 In T84 cells (a colonic epithelial cell line), the results are conflicting, suggesting either that culture conditions may affect the machinery for cAMP-dependent exocytosis of CFTR (12, 15) or that methodological difficulties in localizing CFTR in the plasma membrane make it difficult to detect exocytosis of CFTR.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Thus the question of how much of a role exocytosis plays in regulating the transport of CFTR in T84 cells is still unresolved.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	28	Loffing and colleagues (10) speculate that serous cells in the airway have high basal rates of Cl and antibiotic secretion.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	29	 This may require that high levels of CFTR be present at all times to support such a high level of transport.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Given that CFTR is highly regulated both by phosphorylation and ATP binding and hydrolysis, then why do some tissues need to control its function further by rapidly moving CFTR to the plasma membrane via exocytosis? One may speculate that stimulation of transport via CFTR, by increasing the number of channels though exocytosis, may occur only in tissues such as the shark rectal gland, where very large and rapid changes in transport occur.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	31	This report was funded by grants from the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute, the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, and the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Aquaporin CHIP: the archetypal molecular water channel.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	33	 265 (Renal Fluid Electrolyte Physiol.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	34	 34): F463-F476, 1993[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Demonstration that CFTR is a chloride channel by alteration of its anion selectivity.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Science 253: 202-205, 1991[Medline].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator and ATP.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Mechanism and control of hyperosmotic NaCl-rich secretion by the rectal gland of Squalus acanthias.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	39	 32): C267-C286, 1992[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Regulation of tubular transport via ion channels.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	41	 cAMP-regulated trafficking of epitope-tagged CFTR.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Vasoactive intestinal peptide, forskolin, and genistein increase apical CFTR trafficking in the rectal gland of the spiny dogfish, Squalus acanthias.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Acute regulation of CFTR trafficking in an intact epithelium.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	44	 101: 737-745, 1998[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Exocytosis is not involved in activation of Cl secretion via CFTR in Calu-3 airway epithelial cells.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	46	 44): C913-C920, 1998[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Vesicle targeting and ion secretion in epithelial cells: implications for cystic fibrosis.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Cell surface labeling of CFTR in T84 cells.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	49	 33): C491-C498, 1993[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Rapid endocytosis of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator chloride channel.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	51	 USA 91: 5192-5196, 1994[Abstract].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Polarized expression of cAMP-activated chloride channels in isolated epithelial cells.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	53	 40): C1574-C1582, 1996[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Apical recruitment of CFTR in T-84 cells is dependent on cAMP and microtubules but not Ca2+ or microfilaments.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	55	 109: 1325-1334, 1996[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	56	Am J Physiol Cell Physiol 275(4):C911-C912 0002-9513/98 $5.
0.4255241.9755043.html.plaintext.txt	57	00 Copyright   1998 the American Physiological Society.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	0	Activation of F508 CFTR in an epithelial monolayer Zsuzsa Bebok1, Charles J.
