0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Venglarik1,2, Zita Panczel3, Tamas Jilling4, Kevin L.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	2	1 Gregory Fleming James Cystic Fibrosis Research Center, Departments of 2 Physiology and Biophysics and 5 Medicine, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama 35294; 3 University Medical School of Pecs, Pecs H-7624, Hungary; and 4 Department of Pediatrics, Northwestern University Medical School, Evanston, Illinois 60201.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	3	The F508 mutation leads to retention of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) in the endoplasmic reticulum and rapid degradation by the proteasome and other proteolytic systems.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	4	 In stably transfected LLC-PK1 (porcine kidney) epithelial cells, F508 CFTR conforms to this paradigm and is not present at the plasma membrane.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	5	 When LLC-PK1 cells or human nasal polyp cells derived from a F508 homozygous patient are grown on plastic dishes and treated with an epithelial differentiating agent (DMSO, 2% for 4 days) or when LLC-PK1 cells are grown as polarized monolayers on permeable supports, plasma membrane F508 CFTR is significantly increased.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Moreover, when confluent LLC-PK1 cells expressing F508 CFTR were treated with DMSO and mounted in an Ussing chamber, a further increase in cAMP-activated short-circuit current (i.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	7	00025 compared with untreated controls) was observed.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	8	 No plasma membrane CFTR was detected after DMSO treatment in nonepithelial cells (mouse L cells) expressing F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The experiments describe a way to augment F508 CFTR maturation in epithelial cells that appears to act through a novel mechanism and allows insertion of functional F508 CFTR in the plasma membranes of transporting cell monolayers.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The results raise the possibility that increased epithelial differentiation might increase the delivery of F508 CFTR from the endoplasmic reticulum to the Golgi, where the F508 protein is shielded from degradative pathways such as the proteasome and allowed to mature.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	11	short-circuit current; dimethyl sulfoxide; cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; cell differentiation.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	12	APPROXIMATELY 90% of cystic fibrosis (CF) patients possess at least one cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) allele that lacks a phenylalanine residue at CFTR position 508 (F508).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	13	 (4) indicated that the F508 mutation causes retention of CFTR in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and a failure to insert the protein in the plasma membrane.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Butyrate, an epithelial differentiating agent, has been shown to augment F508 maturation in nonpolarized cells grown on plastic (3).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Another report suggested the possibility that butyrate increases ion transport in CF nasal epithelia, although augmentation of F508 maturation was not directly shown (36).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Improvements in F508 CFTR due to butyrate have not been attributed to differentiating effects per se but to increased CFTR mRNA and protein levels.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The F508 folding defect is also temperature sensitive and influenced by high concentrations of glycerol (7, 37).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	18	 CFTR normally functions as a Cl channel in the context of polarized epithelial monolayers.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	19	 However, interventions that activate maturation and Cl secretion through F508 CFTR in physiologically important systems such as polarized epithelial cell monolayers have been difficult to establish.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	20	An effort in many laboratories has been directed toward development of channel openers for the F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	21	 This strategy depends on at least some (e.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	22	, small amounts of) F508 protein in the plasma membrane (19).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Because studies of F508 processing have focused on undifferentiated cells, less information is available concerning CFTR maturation in polarized epithelia.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Previous observations in other laboratories suggest that measurable amounts of F508 protein might be present in highly differentiated F508 human nasal epithelial cells (9), CF sweat ducts in situ (35), or in the nasal airways of F508 CFTR mice (22).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	25	 In the present experiments, we adapted LLC-PK1 renal epithelial cells transfected with CFTR cDNAs for measurement of transepithelial Cl transport.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	26	 This cell line readily forms polarized cell monolayers (30, 34, 39) and may have advantages over primary CF airway epithelial cells (i.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	27	, since lung or nasal tissue from F508 patients is limited or less frequently available) for use in screening drugs for effects on CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Although the kidney-derived LLC-PK1 cell line does not endogenously express wild-type or F508 CFTR, the processing of wild-type and mutant CFTR in this cell type has been carefully studied and found to closely resemble the behavior of other epithelial cells that do endogenously express CFTR (28).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Moreover, kidney-derived epithelia have been a useful model system for characterizing effects due to epithelial differentiation.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	30	 For example, Madin-Darby canine kidney cells grown on filters have been used to study the distribution of membrane proteins in polarized cells (1) and the mechanisms underlying this distribution (12, 29).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	31	 LLC-PK1 cells have been used to explore specific markers of differentiation (27), ion conductance and membrane voltage (24), chemical induction of differentiation (26), and the differentiation-dependent expression of the Na+-glucose cotransporter (8).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	32	 We also studied the effect of DMSO on human nasal epithelial cells derived from F508 homozygous patients and on mouse L cells expressing F508 or wild-type CFTR (46).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	33	 In our studies, we found that growth of epithelial cells under conditions designed to induce a more differentiated phenotype (treatment with an epithelial differentiating agent, DMSO, or growth of the cells as monolayers on permeable supports) led to improvements in F508 CFTR processing.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Butyrate (5 mM for 24 h), glycerol (10% for 48 h), or growth at 27 degrees C (for 48 h) had no detectable effect on F508 maturation in these epithelial cell monolayers.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Parental LLC-PK1 cells were cultured in M199 media supplemented with 5% fetal bovine serum (FBS).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	36	 LLC-PK1 cells with stable expression of the wild-type or F508 CFTR (generous gift of S.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	37	 28) were cultured in DMEM medium supplemented with 10% FBS and 500  microg/ml G418 (Sigma).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	38	 DMSO (Sigma) was diluted in medium.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Cells were treated with DMSO (2% vol/vol) for 4 days after confluency.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Cd2+ was added to induce CFTR expression from the metallothionein promoter at 5  microM in experiments and controls.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Mouse fibroblast cells expressing F508 or wild-type CFTR (46) were cultured in DMEM medium supplemented with 10% FBS.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	42	Human nasal polyp cells were isolated and cultured according to an earlier described protocol (47).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	43	 LLC-PK1 cells grown on plastic were washed three times with PBS (pH 7.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	44	1 mM CaCl2) on ice and then lysed in a buffer containing 150 mM NaCl, 20 mM HEPES, 1 mM EDTA, 1% NP-40, 100  microg/ml aprotinin, 100  microg/ml leupeptin, and 2 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Lysate supernatant (300  microg protein) was immunoprecipitated at 4 degrees C for 2 h using an anti-CFTR COOH-terminal monoclonal antibody (Genzyme) and protein G agarose beads (Boehringer Mannheim).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Immunoprecipitated proteins were phosphorylated in vitro as described previously (4, 33) and separated on a 7% polyacrylamide gel.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Gels were placed on PhosphoScreen and analyzed with PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Images were further characterized with IPLab spectrum (Signal Analytics).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	49	 RT-PCR was carried out using Promega PolyATtract series 9600 mRNA isolation and cDNA synthesis system, according to the manufacturer's protocol.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Briefly, mRNA was extracted from control and DMSO-treated samples (1  x  105 cells) and 50% of each mRNA sample was used to synthesize cDNA.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	51	 The remainder of the sample was identically treated, but without RT, as a control to exclude DNA contamination.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Samples were homogenized and diluted in 40  microl of prewarmed (70 degrees C) manufacturer's hybridization buffer, and mRNA was purified on oligo(dT) matrix.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	53	 After samples were washed, 10- microl samples were processed to cDNA by adding 5  microl of reverse transcriptase.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	54	 To ensure that PCR yield in these experiments was roughly dependent on the amount of mRNA starting material, pBluescript containing CFTR (gift of J.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Rommens) was transcribed in vitro with T7 polymerase and mRNA added to cell lysates from parental LLC-PK1 cells at known concentrations.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	56	 First-strand CFTR cDNA was then synthesized exactly as above and studied in parallel with cDNA from cells expressing wild-type or F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	57	 In all studies, cDNA synthesis was stopped after 30 min by incubating the samples at 95 degrees C for 5 min.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Control experiments in which RT was omitted from the cDNA synthesis step led to no detectable PCR product under any conditions.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Quantitation was by densitometry using IPLab spectrum (Signal Analytics).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	60	CFTR detection by confocal immunofluorescence microscopy using anti-first nucleotide binding domain (NBD1) (rabbit) polyclonal antibody.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Coverslips were washed three times in PBS containing 1 mM Ca2+ and 0.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	62	5 mM Mg2+, fixed in 20 degrees C methanol for 20 min, and air dried at room temperature.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The cells were rehydrated in PBS for 5 min.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Nonspecific protein binding sites were blocked by incubating with 1% (wt /vol) porcine -globulin in PBS for 30 min at room temperature.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Primary antibody [a polyclonal (rabbit) antibody raised against the CFTR NBD1] (17, 33) was applied and incubated at room temperature for 40 min.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	66	 After subsequent washing (5  x  3-min washes in PBS), the cells were incubated with tetramethylrhodamine isothiocyanate (TRITC)-labeled anti-rabbit IgG antibody for 40 min and then washed, mounted, and visualized as described above.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Controls in which the first antibody was replaced by nonimmune rabbit serum were negative in all cases.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Cells were viewed with an Olympus IX70 inverted epifluorescence microscope at 623-nm light excitation using UPlanApo  x 100 or UApo/340  x 40 objectives.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Digital confocal images were captured using a Photometrics SenSys digital camera and IPLab spectrum software with Power Microtome (Signal Analytics).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	70	Detection of tight junction formation by confocal immunofluorescence microscopy using anti-zonula occludens-1 (rabbit) polyclonal antibody.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Coverslips were washed three times in PBS supplemented with 1 mM Ca2+ and 0.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	72	5 mM Mg2+ and fixed in 4% formaldehyde in PBS for 30 min at room temperature.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Nonspecific protein binding sites were blocked by incubating with 1% (wt /vol) porcine -globulin (Sigma) in PBS for 30 min at room temperature.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	74	 A rabbit polyclonal antibody, anti-zonula occludens-1 (ZO-1) IgG (Zymed Laboratories) (15), was applied and incubated at room temperature for 60 min.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	75	 After subsequent washing (5  x  3 min washes in PBS), the cells were incubated with TRITC-labeled anti-rabbit IgG antibody (DAKOPATTS) for 40 min at room temperature, washed in PBS, and mounted using Vectashield (Vector Labs) mounting medium.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Controls in which the first antibody was replaced by nonimmune rabbit serum were negative in all cases.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	77	 DMSO treatment (2%) was for 4 days.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	78	Identification of F508 CFTR single-channel activity in the plasma membranes of LLC-PK1 cells following DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	79	 DMSO-treated cells grown on plastic were studied in the cell-attached configuration by the patch-clamp technique.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The bath and pipette solutions, electronics, pipette fabrication, and further details regarding the patch-clamp technique have been described previously (43).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The pipette solution contained an impermeant cation (i.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	82	, N-methyl-D-glutamine) so that inward current could only be due to Cl flow into the pipette.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	83	 CFTR channels were activated after excision by 250 U/ml protein kinase A (PKA) plus 200  microM ATP in the bath.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	84	Transepithelial transport through F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	85	 LLC-PK1 cell monolayers were grown to confluency on permeable supports (Millipore, Anotec) for at least 5 days and then treated with 2% DMSO for 3-6 additional days.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Filters were mounted in an Ussing chamber, and short-circuit current (Isc) measurement was carried out as described in Ref.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Bumetanide was added at 100  microM to both the mucosal and serosal surfaces.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	88	 NaCl Ringer solution contained (in mM) 145 Na+, 5 K+, 124.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	89	8 mM of Cl was replaced by the impermeant anion gluconate.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	90	DMSO treatment of LLC-PK1 cells expressing F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	91	 DMSO, like butyrate, displays potent activity as an epithelial differentiating agent (14, 23, 31, 40).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Both drugs cause changes in the display of plasma membrane glycoproteins in epithelial cells, although the two compounds are believed to act by independent mechanisms (14, 23, 31, 40).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Dose and time dependencies of DMSO treatment (0, 2, 5, and 10% DMSO for 1, 6, or 12 h and 1, 3, 4, and 5 days) were evaluated systematically in LLC-PK1 cells that express recombinant F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	94	 We found that treatment for 4 days with 2% DMSO led to maximal effects on F508 maturation and transepithelial Cl transport in these cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	95	 This 2% DMSO schedule had no visible effect on cell viability, and, in a quantitative assay of cell growth (CellTiter 96, Promega), the well-known differentiating effects of DMSO (which slow cell proliferation) decreased cell proliferation in the LLC-PK1 cells by only ~15%.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	96	 We therefore settled on this schedule for future studies.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	97	 We studied LLC-PK1 cells expressing wild-type or F508 CFTR and the parental (non-CFTR expressing) LLC-PK1 cell line (28).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	98	DMSO treatment leads to a mature, band C form of F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Incomplete processing of CFTR can be identified by the absence of a mature, fully glycosylated (band C) form of the protein (4).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Lower-molecular-weight forms of CFTR (e.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	101	, band B) represent the high-mannose, endoglycosidase H-sensitive forms of the protein that are established cotranslationally in the ER.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The maturation of CFTR from core to complex glycosylation reflects the transition of the protein from the ER to the Golgi, where attachment of carbohydrates and trimming are accomplished as CFTR proceeds to the trans-Golgi network.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Immunoprecipitation of CFTR after a 4-day pretreatment with DMSO is shown in Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The result shows the appearance of mature, fully glycosylated CFTR after DMSO treatment in F508 cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	105	 This result supports the notion that F508 maturation is augmented by DMSO.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Figure 1 also indicates a small increase in total CFTR protein in LLC-PK1 cells after DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	107	 To determine whether this increase was due to effects on steady-state levels of mRNA, we performed a semiquantitative RT-PCR from total cellular mRNA.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	108	 DMSO did not appear to cause increases in CFTR mRNA levels as judged by this RT-PCR assay (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Unlike previous reports concerning butyrate treatment (3), the experiment suggests that increased F508 CFTR mRNA does not account for the modest increase in total F508 protein after DMSO treatment or the increase in band C.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	110	 These results also suggest that DMSO promotes F508 maturation through a mechanism that is different from that observed with butyrate.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	111	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	112	   A: immunoprecipitation and in vitro phosphorylation of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Location of 170-kDa band C, the fully processed form of CFTR, is shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	114	 A lower-molecular-weight form (band B) is also shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Band B represents the endoglycosidase H-sensitive, endoplasmic reticulum-localized form of the protein, whereas band C is the complex glycosylated form taken by CFTR at and beyond entry into the Golgi.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Total CFTR obtained from ~106 cells (~300  microg total cell lysate protein) is shown in each lane.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	117	 B: densitometric measurement of CFTR after in vitro phosphorylation.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Percentage of fully processed band C CFTR compared with total CFTR is shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Approximately 10% of total F508 CFTR became fully glycosylated after DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Cells in these experiments were grown in plastic dishes.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Quantitation was by phosphor imaging.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	122	View larger version (25K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	123	   CFTR mRNA levels after DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	124	 A: poly(A) mRNA isolated from ~5  x  105 cells was used to synthesize first-strand cDNA and amplify a segment of the human CFTR first nucleotide binding domain (NBD1; Ref.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	125	 16; size ~500 bp, indicated by arrow).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	126	 PCR products of the predicted size were obtained in all cases.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Lane M displays a molecular size standard.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	128	 B: no evidence of increased CFTR mRNA was observed under the same DMSO treatment conditions shown in Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Known amounts of in vitro-transcribed CFTR mRNA in the reaction mixture (5, 2, 1, or 0 pg/ml) led to a roughly linear PCR yield under conditions shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Quantitation was by densitometry using IPLab spectrum (Signal Analytics).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	131	F508 CFTR localization in the plasma membrane.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	132	 We used digital confocal fluorescent microscopy for CFTR localization that was detected by a polyclonal (rabbit) antibody raised against CFTR NBD1.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The antibody used in these experiments has been validated previously by its ability to immunoprecipitate either truncated CFTR or full-length CFTR, immunolocalize CFTR to cells overexpressing the protein, and correctly identify the presence or absence of CFTR in vivo from salivary gland sections of CFTR wild-type or knockout mice of the same strain (5, 16, 17, 33).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	134	 In LLC-PK1 cells expressing the wild-type CFTR, the protein localized mainly to the perinuclear ER compartment and to the region of the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	135	 DMSO treatment only slightly increased the membrane staining of wild-type CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	136	 In contrast, F508 CFTR was detected in the perinuclear (ER) compartment in LLC-PK1 cells with no significant membrane staining.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	137	 After DMSO treatment, staining in the region of the cell membrane (similar to that observed in wild-type CFTR-expressing cells) could be detected.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	138	 F508 CFTR localizes to the perinuclear ER region of F508 homozygous human nasal epithelial cells (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Treatment of these cells with DMSO (2% for 4 days) resulted in a more diffuse cytoplasmic staining that included staining of cells in the plasma membranes.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	140	 In contrast, DMSO treatment had no significant effect on F508 CFTR staining in mouse fibroblast cells (mouse L cells, Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	141	 These studies suggest that the specificity of effects of DMSO on F508 CFTR processing occurs in epithelial cells but not in fibroblast cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	142	View larger version (57K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	143	   A: immunofluorescent detection of wild-type or F508 CFTR in recombinant LLC-PK1 cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	144	 B: CFTR staining in F508 homozygous human nasal epithelial cells in primary culture.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	145	 C: CFTR immunostaining in mouse L cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	146	 A polyclonal (rabbit) antibody directed against NBD1 was used to detect CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	147	 In A-C, confocal images are shown of cells under each condition.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	148	 DMSO treatment (2%) was for 4 days.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Controls in which 1) first antibody was replaced by nonimmune rabbit serum and 2) parental (non-CFTR expressing) LLC-PK1 or L cells were studied were negative in all cases.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	150	Identification of F508 channels in the plasma membranes of LLC-PK1 cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	151	 We also examined F508 CFTR activity in the plasma membranes of LLC-PK1 cells following DMSO treatment (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	152	 4) using patch-clamp techniques.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Cells grown on plastic were studied in the cell-attached and excised inside-out configurations.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The pipette solution contained an impermeant cation (i.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	155	, N-methyl-D-glucamine) so that inward current could only be due to Cl flow.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The holding potential was approximately 60 mV.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	157	 A current-voltage relationship and typical tracing are shown in Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	158	 4, both consistent with the channel activity previously described for F508 CFTR (6, 21, 32).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	159	 The conductance of the channel is ~8-10 pS, and the channel is activated after excision by 250 U/ml PKA plus 200  microM ATP in the bath, as expected for a functional CFTR protein.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	160	 We observed CFTR channels in 2 of 27 seals in F508 LLC-PK1 cells and in 12 of 48 seals in the same cells treated with DMSO.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The wild-type CFTR was observed in 8 of 25 seals.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The open probability of the F508 channels was studied after stimulation by PKA and ATP.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	163	 In the representative tracing shown in Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	164	 4, open probability before activation was 2% (98% closed); open probability after activation was 97% (3% closed).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The wild-type CFTR also exhibited strong activation when cells attached (open probability up to 98% following PKA stimulation).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	166	View larger version (18K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	167	   Single F508 CFTR channels in the plasma membrane of LLC-PK1 cells after DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Cells were studied in the cell-attached and excised inside-out (I/O) configuration.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Single channels with properties similar to those described previously for F508 CFTR were observed (see text).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	170	 B: current-voltage relationship.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	171	Transepithelial Cl transport mediated by F508 CFTR following DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	172	 To extend our findings concerning F508 CFTR in LLC-PK1 cells grown in plastic dishes, we also grew cells on permeable supports to form epithelial monolayers.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	173	 LLC-PK1 cells exhibit a more differentiated phenotype under these conditions, as indicated by tight junction formation, epithelial resistance measurements, and the capability to perform vectoral ion transport (11, 30, 38, 39).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Under these conditions, F508 LLC-PK1 cells had low, but detectable, Cl transport that was absent in parental (non-CFTR expressing) cells (P  <  0.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Resistance in the cell monolayers was ~100    cm2.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	176	 A 3-day DMSO treatment of F508 CFTR-expressing cells led to forskolin-activated currents in the direction of Cl secretion that were greatly increased compared with untreated F508 LLC-PK1 cells (P  <  0.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Transport was absent in parental LLC-PK1 cells with or without DMSO treatment, indicating specificity for F508 CFTR expression.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	178	 When Cl was omitted from solutions bathing the monolayers, Isc was not detectable either in wild-type or F508 CFTR-expressing cells under any treatment conditions, indicating that the Isc observed in the presence of Cl was due to vectoral Cl transport.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Studies of wild-type CFTR-expressing cells are shown for comparison.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Modest increases in monolayer resistance (e.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	181	, by 15-20%) were noted in most paired experiments as a result of DMSO treatment, a finding that suggests enhancement of tight junction formation in cells grown on permeable supports in the presence of DMSO.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	182	 A summary of these studies is shown in Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	183	View larger version (45K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	184	   Short-circuit current (Isc) measurements in LLC-PK1 cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Representative tracings are shown with and without DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	186	 F508 LLC-PK1 cell monolayers bathed in NaCl Ringer solution exhibited a rapid, forskolin-activated Isc in the direction of Cl secretion specifically following DMSO treatment (F508 + DMSO).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Isc disappeared when either Cl (F508 + DMSO, 6 mM Cl Ringer bath bilaterally) or F508 CFTR (parental + DMSO) was omitted.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	188	 For comparison, cells expressing the wild-type (wt) CFTR are shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Effects of bumetanide, a blocker that inhibits transepithelial Cl transport by inhibiting the basolateral Na+-K+-2Cl cotransporter, are also shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Resistance was ~100    cm2 in each experiment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Mock-treated cells (F508, top right) represent vehicle treatment without DMSO.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Aperture area in these studies was 0.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	193	View larger version (14K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	194	   Summary of Isc activation through F508 CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Maximal Isc stimulation by forskolin in F508 CFTR and parental LLC-PK1 cells under conditions of symmetrical (NaCl) Ringer solution is shown.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Statistics were by Student's t-test (compared with parental LLC-PK1 without DMSO, third bar from left); n = 12 paired experiments for each condition.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	197	Isc studies of alternative activators of F508 CFTR maturation in LLC-PK1 cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	198	 We performed the same sorts of experiments shown above on F508 LLC-PK1 cells following incubation with 10% glycerol (for 48 h), 5 mM butyrate (for 24 h; longer incubations led to substantial toxicity), or growth at 27 degrees C (for 48 h).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Each of these interventions has been shown to augment F508 processing in certain cell types grown on plastic (3, 7, 37).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	200	 We saw no evidence with any of these approaches of either Isc activation or band C CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	201	 These results are significant because they suggest that DMSO acts to potentiate F508 CFTR maturation through a mechanism that 1) is different from that observed with glycerol or butyrate, 2) is more potent than can be obtained with glycerol or butyrate, at least in the LLC-PK1 model, and 3) allows insertion of the F508 CFTR in the plasma membrane of a transporting cellular monolayer in vitro.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	202	DMSO treatment leads to a more differentiated phenotype in recombinant LLC-PK1 cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	203	 To determine whether DMSO altered the phenotype of LLC-PK1 cells, we probed cells grown on plastic with an antibody to ZO-1, a constituent of epithelial tight junctions (15, 41).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Organization and assembly of tight junctions is an additional, useful measurement of polarity and differentiation in epithelial cell monolayers.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Well-organized tight junctions occurring in an ordered distribution indicate a higher level of polarity and differentiation, whereas tight junction antigens that are absent, poorly developed, or distributed throughout the cytoplasm or plasma membrane may be indicative of a less differentiated phenotype.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	206	 7, a 4-day treatment with 2% DMSO led to qualitative increases in tight junction organization in LLC-PK1 cells, as detected by ZO-1 staining in the regions of cell-to-cell contact.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	207	View larger version (48K):    Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	208	   Tight junction formation in LLC-PK1 cells after DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Confocal immunofluorescence microscopy of cells without and with DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Increases in the organization of tight junction antigen zonula occludens-1 (ZO-1) were observed as a result of DMSO treatment.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	211	In LLC-PK1 cells grown on plastic, F508 CFTR is absent from the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	212	 3) but can be detected at the cell surface when cells are grown as a monolayer on a permeable support (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	213	 The maturation of F508 CFTR can be augmented further by treatment with nontoxic concentrations of a differentiation agent known to increase epithelial cell polarity, DMSO (14, 23, 31, 40).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	214	 The in vitro model described here for cell monolayers (as opposed to previous studies of nonpolarized cells grown on plastic) might be useful in the development of procedures to augment F508 CFTR maturation or to study openers of F508 CFTR Cl channels present in the plasma membrane.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	215	We tested the possibility that DMSO, like butyrate, increases F508 CFTR mRNA levels (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	216	 We saw no evidence of increased CFTR mRNA in either wild-type or F508 LLC-PK1 cells under the same DMSO treatment conditions that partially corrected F508 protein processing.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Moreover, butyrate treatment of F508 cells at 5 mM caused no improvement in Cl transport in an Ussing chamber protocol.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	218	 These results suggest that DMSO augments the maturation of F508 CFTR by a mechanism that is different from the known effects of butyrate.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	219	 DMSO has also recently been suggested to act as a "chemical chaperone" and to correct the folding and biogenesis of the pathogenic prion protein in vitro (W.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Welch, personal communication).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Although it is possible that DMSO has effects on CFTR folding, there is no direct evidence in our experiments that DMSO can reach cytoplasmic levels that alter the kinetics, efficiency, or other aspects of CFTR folding in living cells to augment F508 CFTR processing.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Therefore, although an effect on CFTR folding remains an important consideration in our experiments, further studies will be necessary to test a direct role for DMSO as a chemical chaperone for CFTR.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	223	In our experiments, interventions that increase epithelial cell polarity and differentiation also conferred increases in F508 CFTR maturation.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Growth of epithelial cells on permeable supports is a well-established method of augmenting epithelial cell differentiation and has been described previously as leading to dome formation and a more differentiated phenotype in many cell types (13, 18, 25).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	225	 LLC-PK1 cells have previously been reported to switch from an undifferentiated to a more differentiated phenotype when grown on filters (48).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	226	 This method was therefore selected as one way to increase cell polarity in our experiments.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	227	 We showed that growth on permeable supports also led to functionally detectable F508 CFTR in the plasma membrane by Isc measurements (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	228	 DMSO treatment is another well-described method for augmenting cell differentiation in epithelial cells derived from different tissues (14, 23, 31, 40).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Accordingly, we tested the influence of DMSO on F508 CFTR maturational processing.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	230	 DMSO treatment caused increased resistance in LLC-PK1 monolayers (presumably on the basis of greater organization of tight junctions), and the same treatment led to further increases in F508 CFTR activity at the cell surface (Figs.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Moreover, we observed that organization of tight junctions in LLC-PK1 cells increased under the same conditions that led to F508 maturation (Figs.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Finally, vectoral chloride transport (Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	233	 5) should only be detectable in a polarized epithelial monolayer and was observed in our studies of anion transport.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Together, these experiments indicate that a more differentiated phenotype also confers an increase in F508 CFTR maturation.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The effect of DMSO on F508 CFTR processing was also observed in primary human nasal polyp cells but not in nonepithelial cells (mouse fibroblast, L cells; Fig.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Experiments in these other cell types suggest the usefulness of the approach for activating F508 processing in human epithelial cells.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	237	Transmembrane proteins are often distributed throughout the plasma membrane when cells are undifferentiated.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	238	 With the onset of differentiation and the development of adherens junctions, tight junctions, and cell matrix interactions, structural polarity is established.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The process by which proteins target to the apical membrane appears to occur by a default mechanism (10).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Our results may indicate that cellular polarity helps establish part of this default pathway.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The possibility that F508 CFTR enters the apical targeting pathway specifically after an increase in cellular differentiation is suggested by results in Figs.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Other contributors to F508 maturation, including stabilization of the folded structure of F508 protein, a change in F508 CFTR interactions with cellular chaperones, or a decrease in the rate of degradation of F508 CFTR in the ER (so as to allow more time to reach the Golgi), are among the alternative explanations for the findings shown here.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	243	In summary, the ER in epithelial cells is a hostile environment, insofar as the CFTR is concerned.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Wild-type and F508 molecules, even when folded into functional Cl channels, are polyubiquitinated and degraded in short order (half time of ~30 min) by the proteasome and possibly other proteolytic pathways (20, 44).
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	245	 CFTR that escapes the ER and enters the Golgi may reach a "safe haven," where half time increases to  > 12 h for the post-ER form.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Our data suggest, after DMSO treatment in LLC-PK1 cells, an increased amount of the post-ER complex-glycosylated and membrane-localized F508 CFTR is observed.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Because neither block of ubiquitination nor proteasome inhibition has been reported to enhance F508 maturation, it is less likely that the effects observed here are caused by blockade of the proteasome or of ubiquitination.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Our results raise the possibility that induction of polarity in LLC-PK1 cells might increase a transition of F508 CFTR from the ER to the trans-Golgi network (Figs.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	249	 If the F508 CFTR quality control mechanism becomes "leaky" in differentiated cells compared with the undifferentiated state, the findings could have important implications concerning the in vivo processing of F508 CFTR, which occurs in well-organized cells within tissues characterized by tight junctions and polarity.
0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Further experiments are needed to test this possibility, as well as to test the effects of DMSO treatment in F508 CF mice.

0.42564055.9688615.html.plaintext.txt	337	00 Copyright   1998 the American Physiological Society.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	0	Tissue-specific in vivo transcription start sites of the human and murine cystic fibrosis genes.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	1	Nuffield Department of Clinical Biochemistry and Imperial Cancer Research Fund Laboratories, Institute of Molecular Medicine, University of Oxford, John Radcliffe Hospital, Oxford OX3 9DS, UK.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received June 20, 1997; Revised and Accepted December 15, 1997.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	3	The in vivo transcription start sites of the human cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR) and its murine homologue (Cftr) have been mapped in a range of tissues using the technique of 5[prime] rapid amplification of cDNA ends (5[prime] RACE).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	4	 These are the first in vivo transcription start sites for CFTR or Cftr to be reported.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Distinct, tissue-specific patterns of CFTR start site usage were identified in both mouse and human.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In particular, striking variation in the position of the murine Cftr transcription start site was seen along the length of the intestinal tract; different start sites being utilized in ileum and in duodenum.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In humans, distinct transcription start sites are utilized in adult and foetal lungs.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In addition, a novel 5[prime]-untranslated exon of murine Cftr, denoted exon -1, was identified and shown to be expressed exclusively in mouse testis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Expression of exon -1-containing Cftr transcripts was shown by mRNA in situ hybridization to be confined to the germ cells and to be regulated during spermatogenesis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	10	Cystic fibrosis is a common, autosomal recessive disease characterized by intestinal blockages, exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, male infertility and progressive, degenerative lung disease (1).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	11	 These diverse symptoms result from mutation of a single gene, the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator or CFTR (2,3), the product of which functions as a cAMP-regulated, low conductance chloride channel (4).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	12	CFTR exhibits complex patterns of tissue-specific expression being expressed at low levels in specialized epithelial cells of the intestinal crypts, airway submucosal glands, pancreatic ducts, sweat gland ducts and the male reproductive tract (5-8).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	13	 In addition, the observed patterns of expression indicate that CFTR expression is regulated by hormones (9) and during development and differentiation (8,10,11).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Although the patterns of regulated CFTR gene expression are well known, surprisingly little is known of the genetic elements and transcription factors that regulate the tissue-specific expression of CFTR.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Both the mouse and human CFTR genes have promoters which resemble those of `housekeeping' genes (12-14), an observation that is inconsistent with the tissue and cell type specificity of CFTR expression.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	16	Knowledge of the position of the CFTR transcription start site utilized in CFTR-expressing cells in vivo is a prerequisite to understanding the regulation of the CFTR promoter.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	17	 CFTR transcription start sites previously have only been mapped in a number of immortalized cell lines (12,13,15), and it cannot be concluded that identical sites are used in vivo.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In the present study, we used a 5[prime] rapid amplification of cDNA ends (5[prime] RACE) approach to map accurately transcription start sites of human CFTR, and its murine homologue Cftr, in a range of primary tissues.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Distinct tissue-specific patterns of transcription start site usage were observed.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The implications of these findings with regard to the regulation of CFTR expression are discussed.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	21	 RESULTS Identification of murine Cftr transcription start sites by 5[prime] RACE.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	22	In order to identify the major in vivo Cftr transcription start sites utilized in mouse primary tissues, we performed 5[prime] RACE on total RNA isolated from adult mouse lungs, ileum, duodenum, testis, uterus, kidney, and also 16-day-old foetal mouse lungs.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	23	 First strand cDNA synthesis was performed using a Cftr-specific primer (MC6R; Table 1).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	24	 cDNAs were then homopolymer tailed and subjected to two successive rounds of hemi-nested PCR amplification with anchor primer complementary to the homopolymer tail and Cftr-specific nested primers (MC5R and MC2.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Discrete 5[prime] RACE products were amplified from each mouse tissue (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	26	 1 shows representative experiments).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	27	 These 5[prime] RACE products were excised and either sequenced directly or cloned into the vector pT7 blue (Novagen) and then sequenced.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The positions of the observed transcription initiation sites, numbered relative to the A of the initiating methionine codon of the Cftr open reading frame (ORF) at position +1, are shown schematically in Figure 2 and summarized in Table 2.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Single, major transcription start sites were observed for mouse adult lung (-82), kidney (-75), uterus (-72) and 16-day-old mouse foetal lung (-72).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Variation in Cftr transcription start site usage was seen along the length of the mouse intestinal tract; two start sites were observed in mouse duodenum (-60 and -19), whereas two different major start sites were mapped in mouse ileum (-72 and -75) corresponding to the most abundant 5[prime] RACE products amplified from this tissue (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	31	 In addition to the major start sites, a number of minor transcription start sites were observed in the ileum, kidney and uterus.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The minor 5[prime] RACE products from the ileum were isolated and found to correspond to transcription start sites at positions +27, -216 and -255.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Representative 5[prime] RACE PCR experiments performed on mouse tissue cDNA samples.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	34	 For each tissue, dC-tailed cDNA samples (TdT) and paired negative control cDNA samples that had not been homopolymer tailed (-) were subjected to identical PCR amplification.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	35	 (a) T-testis; (b) L, adult lung; FL, foetal lung; I, ileum; D, duodenum; U, uterus; K, kidney.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Lane M contains a 100 bp ladder (Promega), the most intense band corresponding to 500 bp.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The 700 bp of murine Cftr 5[prime]-flanking genomic sequence, spanning exons 1 and -1 and the intervening intron.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The nucleotide sequence is numbered relative to the first base of the initiation codon of the Cftr ORF.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Exons are shown in the upper case, with the first 17 amino acids of Cftr and the predicted amino acid sequence of a short upstream ORF shown in single letter code.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Bent arrows indicate the relative positions of the Cftr transcription start sites utilized in mouse tissues.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	41	 L, adult lung; FL, foetal lung; T, testis; I, ileum; D, duodenum; U, uterus; K, kidney.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Oligonucleotide primers used in reverse transcription and PCR Primer Exon Sequence HC6R 6 5[prime]-CCAGCTCTCTGATCTCTGTACTTCATCATC HC5R 5 5[prime]-TTATCTAGAACACGGCTTGACAGC HC2R 2 5[prime]-TTTGGTATATGTCTGACAATTCCAGGCGCT HC3R 3 5[prime]-ACATCGCCGAAGGGCATTAATGAGTTTAGG MC6R 6 5[prime]-GCAGCTCTTTGATCTCTGTACTTCACCATG MC5R 5 5[prime]-GTTCAGGTTGTTGGAAAGAAGACTAACAA MC2.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	43	1R 2 5[prime]-ACAAGTGGTCAGCTGAATCAGCAGAAGGGG.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	44	As the Cftr transcription start sites were mapped by a PCR-based technique, where more than one start site was observed, no absolute values can be assigned to the percentage of transcript initiating at each of the sites.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	45	 However, we can conclude that the most abundant products correspond to the major transcription start sites for Cftr and that, collectively, the minor 5[prime] RACE products constitute at most 10% of Cftr transcripts in any tissue.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Importantly, the two major start sites mapped in the ileum (-72 and -75) are used with approximately equal frequency while the two start sites mapped in the duodenum (-60 and -19) are used in an ~4:1 ratio, respectively.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Finally, the relative intensities of 5[prime] RACE products from foetal and adult lung correspond well with the known down-regulation of Cftr expression in adult mouse lung tissue (unpublished data).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Positions of the major murine Cftr transcription start sites utilized in mouse tissues, numbered relative to A of the initiation codon of the Cftr open reading frame at +1 Tissue Major start site(s) Minor start site(s) Testis -549   Lung -82   Foetal lung -72   Duodenum -19, -60   Ileum -75, -72 +27, -216, -255 Kidney -75   Uterus -72  .
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Positions of human CFTR transcription start sites, numbered relative to A of the CFTR translation initiation codon at +1 Tissue Position of start site Adult lung -69 Foetal lung -132 Intestine -69 Intestine -114 Pancreas -68 Identification of human CFTR transcription start sites by 5[prime] RACE.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	50	A significant amount of tissue-specific variation in the pattern of Cftr transcription start site usage was observed in the mouse.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	51	 In order to investigate whether similar variation in CFTR transcription start site usage also occurs in human tissues, we performed 5[prime] RACE on RNA isolated from human whole small intestine, whole pancreas, whole adult lung and whole foetal lung (pooled from 29 specimens in the age range 18-28 weeks): these tissues represent the major sites of CFTR expression relevant to CF disease pathology.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	52	 First strand cDNA synthesis was performed using a CFTR-specific primer (HC6R; Table 1).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	53	 cDNAs were then homopolymer tailed and subjected to two successive rounds of hemi-nested PCR amplification with an anchor primer complementary to the homopolymer tail and CFTR-specific nested primers (HC5R and either HC2R or HC3R; Table 1).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Discrete 5[prime] RACE PCR products were amplified from each human tissue (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	55	 3 shows representative experiments).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	56	 These 5[prime] RACE products were excised from a gel, purified and sequenced directly.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	57	 The positions of the transcription initiation sites, numbered relative to the A of the initiating methionine codon of the CFTR ORF at position +1, are shown schematically in Figure 4 and summarized in Table 3.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Mapping of transcription start sites for the CFTR gene in samples of human tissue total RNA.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	59	 For each tissue analysed, paired samples of dC-tailed cDNA (TdT) and negative control `No TdT' cDNA (-) were subjected to identical hemi-nested PCR amplification.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	60	 A first round of PCR amplification was performed with an anchor primer and the CFTR-specific primer HC5R, and a second round of PCR amplification was performed with anchor primer and HC2R (except * which was performed with anchor primer and HC3R).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	61	 L, lung; I, whole small intestine; P, pancreas; FL, foetal lung; M, 100 bp DNA ladder.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Sequence of the 5[prime]-flanking region of the human CFTR gene.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The nucleotide sequence is numbered relative to A of the translation codon at +1, and the initiation codon is double underlined.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Bent arrows indicate the positions of CFTR transcription start sites; the position of each site and the tissue in which it was mapped is shown.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	65	 FL, foetal lungs; L, adult lungs; I, whole small intestine; P, pancreas.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	66	The 5[prime] RACE products amplified from adult lung, foetal lung and pancreas corresponded to single transcription initiation sites at positions -69, -132 and -68 respectively, whilst the two 5[prime] RACE products amplified from small intestine corresponded to start sites at positions -69 and -114.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Because of limited availability of human tissues, it has not been possible to determine whether these two alternative start sites represent variation in start site usage along the length of the human intestinal tract, as is the case with murine Cftr, or whether these alternative start sites are used in different CFTR-expressing cell types all along the length of the intestine [e.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	68	 the epithelial cells lining the intestinal crypt versus the poorly characterized CFTR-expressing cells of the intestinal villus (16,17)].
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The results of this in vivo transcription mapping study are broadly consistent with previously published data from immortalized cell lines in that the single transcription start sites utilized in adult lung (-69) and pancreas (-68) and one of the start sites identified in intestine (-69) are close to the major CFTR start site(s) mapped in the colonic epithelial adenocarcinoma cell lines T84, HT-29 and Caco-2 (12,13,15).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	70	 However, none of the multiple minor start sites observed in T84, HT-29 and Caco-2 cells appear to be used in CFTR-expressing cells in vivo.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	71	The observation that distinct CFTR transcription start sites are utilized in adult (-69) and foetal lungs (-132) is intriguing given the previously reported developmental regulation of CFTR expression in the lung (10,11,18).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	72	 CFTR mRNA levels are substantially higher in foetal lungs than in adult lungs, with CFTR expression declining dramatically after birth, although the precise age at which this down-regulation occurs is not known.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	73	 It is possible that a switch in transcription initiation from the -132 site to the -69 site correlates with a particular stage in lung development.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	74	 A correlation between the pattern of CFTR transcription start site usage and the level of CFTR mRNA expression previously has been reported in CFTR-expressing cell lines, suggesting that a mechanism of CFTR regulation operates at the level of start site selection (15).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	75	 These data suggest that a similar mechanism might operate during human lung development.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Identification of a novel exon of murine Cftr.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	77	Figure 1 shows that a major 5[prime] RACE product of 420 bp was amplified from mouse testis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	78	 DNA sequencing revealed that this PCR product extended from Cftr exon 2 up to the splice junction with exon 1 and contained 161 bp of Cftr exon 1 and 154 bp of unknown sequence, which was named exon -1.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Comparison of the sequence of the major 5[prime] RACE product from testis with the upstream genomic sequence of murine Cftr (19) confirmed the existence of exon -1 as a distinct, untranslated exon and indicated that the major transcription start site for Cftr in mouse testis is at position -549 relative to the initiating methionine codon of the Cftr ORF (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	80	 An intron of 285 bp separates exon -1 and exon 1, with the sequences for both splice donor and splice acceptor sites obeying the invariant GT-AG rule (20) at the exon -1/exon 1 splice junction.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The position of the exon -1/exon 1 boundary in polyadenylated RNA from mouse testis was confirmed by performing an independent RT-PCR amplification on mouse testis first-strand cDNA primed with oligo(dT) (not shown).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Exon -1 expression is testis specific.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	83	The tissue specificity of exon -1 expression was investigated using a dual probe RNase protection assay which simultaneously detected Cftr exon -1 and an internal Cftr sequence (Cftr exons 10-12; base pairs 1580-1865) in samples of mouse tissue total RNA.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Cftr exon 10-12 expression was detected in all tissues examined with the exception of pancreas (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	85	 5), in agreement with previous observations that Cftr is expressed at extremely low levels in rodent pancreas (5,21).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Significant levels of exon -1 expression were observed only in the testis (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	87	 The amounts of each protected fragment were quantitated using a Molecular Dynamics phosphoimaging cassette and Imagequant software, by comparison with the relevant standard curve of known amounts of RNA sense strands (not shown).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Approximately 95% of the Cftr transcripts expressed in murine testis contain exon -1, whilst in the other mouse tissues examined  < 5% of Cftr transcripts contained exon -1.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Simultaneous detection of CFTR exons 10-12 and CFTR exon -1 in single samples of mouse tissue total RNA by dual probe RNase protection analysis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Lane 1, ileum; lane 2, duodenum; lane 3, ovary/oviduct; lane 4, uterus; lane 5, testis; lane 6, pancreas; lane 7, adult lung; lane 8, 16 day foetal lung; lane 9, salivary gland.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Lane 10 represents the yeast RNA negative control.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	92	 The expected positions of the two protected fragments are indicated.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	93	Germ cell-specific expression of Cftr exon -1.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	94	Cftr exhibits a cell type-specific pattern of expression in murine testis, with levels of expression varying during the different stages of spermatogenesis (22).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Cftr is expressed first in pachytene spermatocytes, with expression being maintained as these cells undergo meiotic division, to produce round spermatids, and then declining as the round spermatids elongate (22).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	96	 In order to determine whether Cftr exon -1 shows the same cell type-specific pattern of expression, we examined the in vivo expression of Cftr exon -1 in mouse testis by mRNA in situ hybridization.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	97	 A series of consecutive sections of adult mouse testis were hybridized with probes specific for exon -1 (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	98	 6) and for an internal region of Cftr (data not shown).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Identical patterns of cell type-specific expression were observed with both probes, demonstrating that expression of the exon -1-containing Cftr transcript is regulated during stages of spermatogenesis, in agreement with our previous observations of Cftr expression in mouse testis (22).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Cell type-specific expression of Cftr mRNA in adult mouse testis examined by in situ hydridization.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	101	 A series of consecutive sections of adult mouse testis were hybridized with 35S-labelled CFTR -1 antisense and sense probes.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	102	 (A) Brightfield view of haemotoxylin and eosin-stained section of mouse testis hybridized with a 35S-labelled CFTR -1 antisense probe.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	103	 (B) Darkfield view of the same section.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	104	 (C) Hybridized with a 35S-labelled CFTR -1 sense probe.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	105	CFTR expression in human testis has been reported to be extremely low and not associated with any particular cell type or with any particular stage of spermatogenesis-strikingly different from the rodent expression pattern (23).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Nevertheless, the existence of a human equivalent of the testis-specific murine Cftr exon -1 was investigated by performing 5[prime] RACE PCR in order to identify the CFTR transcription start site utilized in adult human testis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The 5[prime] RACE procedure was repeated a total of three times, but no CFTR-specific product bands could be amplified.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	108	 As a positive control, CFTR expression in human testis was confirmed by RT-PCR using an internal CFTR primer set (not shown).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	109	 It was concluded, therefore, that the level of CFTR expression in human testis is extremely low but detectable by RT-PCR, but that this low level expression is below the limit of detection by 5[prime] RACE due to the latter method's inherently lower sensitivity.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Thus, the position of the CFTR start site utilized in adult human testis remains unknown, and no conclusions can be drawn regarding the expression of a human equivalent of murine Cftr exon -1 in human testis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	111	In this study, we have mapped the in vivo transcription start sites for human CFTR and its murine homologue Cftr.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Using a sensitive 5[prime] RACE technique, we were able to map CFTR start sites in a number of different mouse and human tissues.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	113	 These are the first in vivo CFTR transcription start sites to be mapped for any species.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	114	In the case of murine Cftr, the use of distinct, tissue-specific transcription start sites leads to the production of Cftr transcripts which differ in the length of their 5[prime]-untranslated regions (5[prime] UTRs).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The observation that distinct transcription start sites are used in different tissues suggests that the tissue-specific regulation of Cftr expression may, in part, operate at the level of transcription start site selection.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Analysis of the primary sequence of the 5[prime]-flanking region of murine Cftr provides some clues as to how tissue-specific start site selection might be achieved.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	117	 No sequence likely to correspond to a TATA box element could be found upstream of any of the in vivo transcription start sites identified for murine Cftr (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	118	 However, Table 4 illustrates that sequences surrounding three of the Cftr transcription start sites, the -82 site utilized in lung and the -60 and -19 sites utilized in duodenum, are similar to the consensus sequence for the mammalian initiator (Inr) element, PyPyA(+1)N(T/A)PyPy, that has been suggested to maintain the fidelity of transcription initiation in promoters devoid of TATA boxes (24).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	119	 It is likely, therefore, that an Inr-dependent mechanism is responsible for directing the formation of a transcription pre-initiation complex in these tissues.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Sequence context of murine Cftr transcription start sites.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	121	 In each case, the transcription start site (+1) is underlined Position of start site Sequence context Inr consensus PyPyA(+1)N(T/A)PyPy -549 AGAAGGA -82 GCATTGA -75 CCTGGTC -72 GGTCCTG -60 CCAGATG -19 TCATTGC.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	122	Tissue-specific variation in the position of the CFTR start site was also observed in human tissues.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Most notably, distinct start sites appear to be used in adult and in foetal lungs.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	124	 However, the exact position of the CFTR transcription start site relative to the translation initiation codon does not appear to be conserved between equivalent tissues of mice and humans, suggesting that the precise mechanisms responsible for correct start site selection are not conserved cross-species.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	125	 This is perhaps not surprising given the apparent lack of primary nucleic acid sequence homology between the mouse and human proximal promoter regions (19,25).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	126	The identification of a testis-specific, untranslated exon of murine Cftr (exon -1) implies that Cftr expression in this tissue is under the control of a testis-specific alternative promoter.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Murine Cftr falls into a group of genes demonstrating cell type-specific expression in the testis, with expression being regulated during spermatogenesis (22).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Other genes in this group include many whose protein products are thought to play a particular role in the complex process of spermatogenesis (reviewed in 26), and a potential role for the Cftr chloride channel during spermatogenesis has been suggested (22).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Genes such as Cftr that are expressed both post-meiotically in the testis and in other tissues often produce testis-specific transcripts, generated by the use of testis-specific promoters, altered polyadenylation and/or tissue-specific alternative exon splicing (26).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	130	 We have shown that the testis-specific Cftr transcript is generated through the use of an alternative promoter and alternative splicing in the 5[prime] UTR, to include exon -1 at the extreme 5[prime] end of the transcript.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The vast majority (95%) of Cftr transcripts in mouse testis contain this additional untranslated exon, implying an important role for exon -1 with regard to either the function of Cftr in testis or the regulation of Cftr expression in this tissue.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The latter alternative would appear to be more plausible as a number of genes expressed post-meiotically in rodent testis exhibit negative translational regulation mediated by the binding of regulatory proteins to specific 5[prime] UTR sequences (reviewed in 27).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	133	 One of the families of germ cell-specific proteins proposed to mediate translational regulation in the testis are the Y-box proteins (28).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Y-box proteins may function both as DNA-binding transcription factors, which bind to specific, cis-acting Y-box promoter elements, and as RNA-binding proteins, which mediate translational regulation via mRNA masking in vertebrate gametes (29).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	135	 In this context, it is interesting to note that a Y-box consensus sequence, previously suggested to act as a positive regulator of transcription in the murine Cftr promoter (14), is contained within exon -1 and thus will be present exclusively in the 5[prime] UTR of testis-specific Cftr transcripts.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	136	Another feature of the murine Cftr 5[prime]-flanking region suggests that translational regulation may be a more general mechanism controlling Cftr expression.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	137	 An additional AUG codon is present at position -58, upstream of the Cftr ORF (Fig.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	138	 This upstream AUG precedes a short upstream ORF (uORF) that, if recognized by the translation machinery, would produce a small peptide of five amino acids in length.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	139	 This uORF will be present in the 5[prime] UTR of Cftr transcripts initiating upstream of position -58, including the major Cftr transcripts expressed in lung, foetal lung, ileum, kidney, uterus and testis.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The upstream AUG occurs in a weak Kozak context, with neither the critical purine at position -3 nor the G at position +4 being present (30), whereas the AUG of the Cftr ORF occurs in a much stronger Kozak context (31).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The scanning model predicts that translation will usually initiate at the first AUG in a favourable Kozak context (30).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Nevertheless, interaction between the translation machinery and the upstream AUG may have the effect of reducing the translation efficiency of the Cftr ORF.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The presence of the short uORF would therefore be predicted to reduce the translation efficiency of the major Cftr transcripts expressed in lungs, ileum and testis but not those expressed in duodenum, as the uORF is absent from the 5[prime] UTR of the duodenum transcript initiating at position -19 and is too close to the m7G cap site to exert an effect in the transcript initiating at position -60 (31).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Thus, by the use of distinct transcription start sites, the expression of Cftr might also be modulated at the translational level.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	145	The identification of the major Cftr transcription start sites utilized in vivo is an essential prerequisite to understanding the function of the Cftr promoter.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	146	 It will now be possible to define the promoter elements, transcription factors and mechanisms directing the complex patterns of in vivo Cftr expression.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	147	 MATERIALS AND METHODS Sources of mouse tissues for total RNA preparation.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	148	All human RNA samples were purchased from Clontech.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Mouse tissues were pooled from six male and six female adult mice, all of strain MF1.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Foetal lung tissue was pooled from three 16-day-old foetuses removed from a single timed pregnant female.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Total RNA was isolated using a guanidinium thiocyanate/acid phenol-chloroform extraction method (32).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	152	5[prime] RACE was performed using an adaptation of the method of Frohman (33).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	153	 First-strand cDNA synthesis was performed on 2  microg of total RNA using 10 pmol of primer MC6R (Table 1) and 200 U of superscript II reverse transcriptase (BRL).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	154	 RNA template strands were digested with 2 U of RNase H (BRL), and first-strand cDNAs were purified using QIAquik PCR purification columns (QIAGEN) and homopolymer tailed using 0.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	155	2 mM dCTP and 20 U of terminal transferase (Promega).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	156	 cDNAs were again purified using QIAquik columns and then subjected to two rounds of hemi-nested PCR amplifications using primers MC5R and MC2.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	157	1R and a 5[prime] RACE anchor primer specific for the homopolymer tail (purchased from BRL), with 10 pmol of each primer and 2.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	158	5 U of AmpliTaq Gold polymerase (Perkin Elmer) per PCR reaction.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	159	 5[prime] RACE products were either sequenced directly or ligated into the vector pT7 blue and the recombinant plasmids sequenced.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Sequencing reactions were performed using an AmpliTaq Dye Terminator Cycle Sequencing Kit (Applied Biosystems) and analysed on an ABI prism 377 automated sequencer.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	161	Dual probe RNase protection assays were performed using the RPA II system from Ambion.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Two probes were used to detect different regions of a single Cftr mRNA: the first, CFTR 10-12, corresponded to an internal region of Cftr spanning exons 10-12 [base pairs 1580-1865 of the Cftr cDNA (19)] in the vector Bluescript KS (Stratagene); the second, CFTR -1, contained 150 bp of mouse Cftr exon -1 and 50 bp of RACE anchor primer sequence, amplified from the mouse testis major 5[prime] RACE product by PCR using anchor primer (Gibco-BRL) and the primer MC -1R (5[prime]-ACCGTGGCCAATCTGCGGGACTTAGAACCC), and cloned into Bluescript SK (Stratagene).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The Bluescript vectors contain opposing T3 and T7 promoters to allow the synthesis of both 32P-labelled antisense RNA probes and control unlabelled sense strand RNAs by in vitro transcription.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Samples (20  microg) of mouse tissue total RNA were hybridized overnight with equal, excess amounts (0.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	165	) of 32P-labelled, antisense CFTR -1 and CFTR 10-12 probes.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Following RNase digestion and precipitation, protected products were resolved on 6% denaturing polyacrylamide gels and visualized by exposure to Kodak X-omat AR film.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	167	In situ hybridization was performed essentially as described previously (17).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Probes specific for two regions of mouse Cftr were used for in situ localization of Cftr mRNA: the first, CFTR 10-13, corresponded to a fragment of Cftr exons 10-13 [bases 1580-2108 of the Cftr cDNA (19)] in the vector Bluescript KS; the second, CFTR -1 was the same as that used for RNase protection (above).
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Both probes were cloned in Bluescript vectors containing opposing T3 and T7 promoters for the generation of [35S]UTP-labelled sense and antisense strand RNA probes by in vitro transcription.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Cryostat tissue sections (10  microm) were hybridized overnight with 35S-labelled single-stranded RNA probes in 50% formamide at 55-60 degrees C.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Sections were then digested with RNase A to remove excess probe and other single-stranded RNA, and washed at a stringency of 0.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Slides were dipped in Kodak NTB-2 emulsion, exposed for 2 weeks at 4 degrees C, developed and counterstained with haematoxylin and eosin.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Sections were photographed under brightfield and darkfield illumination using a Nikon Optiphot-2 microscope equipped with a Nikon UFX-DX automatic camera.
0.4301281.9466991.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Multiple tissue sections were hybridized with either sense or antisense probes for each of the two regions of Cftr and, in all cases, results were seen to be consistent for each probe.
