0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	0	Electrodiffusional ATP movement through the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator Horacio F.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Borkan4, Yihan Wang4, Ignacio L.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	2	1 Renal Unit, Massachusetts General Hospital East, Charlestown 02129; 2 Department of Medicine, Harvard Medical School, Boston 02115; 4 Renal Section, Boston Medical Center, Boston 02118; 5 Genzyme Corporation, Framingham, Massachusetts 01701; and 3 Departamento de Quimica General e Inorganica, Facultad de Farmacia y Bioquimica, Universidad de Buenos Aires, 1113 Buenos Aires, Argentina.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	3	Expression of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), and of at least one other member of the ATP-binding cassette family of transport proteins, P-glycoprotein, is associated with the electrodiffusional movement of the nucleotide ATP.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Evidence directly implicating CFTR expression with ATP channel activity, however, is still missing.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Here it is reported that reconstitution into a lipid bilayer of highly purified CFTR of human epithelial origin enables the permeation of both Cl and ATP.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Similar to previously reported data for in vivo ATP currents of CFTR-expressing cells, the reconstituted channels displayed competition between Cl and ATP and had multiple conductance states in the presence of Cl and ATP.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Purified CFTR-mediated ATP currents were activated by protein kinase A and ATP (1 mM) from the "intracellular" side of the molecule and were inhibited by diphenylamine-2-carboxylate, glibenclamide, and anti-CFTR antibodies.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	8	 The absence of CFTR-mediated electrodiffusional ATP movement may thus be a relevant component of the pleiotropic cystic fibrosis phenotype.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	9	adenosine 5'-triphosphate channels; adenosine 5'-triphosphate-binding cassette transporters; nucleotide transport.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	10	THE CYSTIC FIBROSIS transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) supports ATP-dependent Cl channel activity (3, 14).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	11	 However, controversy still exists as to whether this functional feature of CFTR is sufficient to explain the complete pathophysiology of this disease (7).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The cellular epithelial cystic fibrosis (CF) phenotype, for example, is associated both with a dysfunctional phospholipase A2 activity and a deranged arachidonic acid metabolism (10, 24) and with an abnormally increased apical epithelial Na+ permeability (6), which is regulated by CFTR (26).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Expression of CFTR is also associated with the recovery of outwardly rectifying Cl channel activity of CF cells (12) by an autocoid mechanism entailing the release of cellular ATP, which, in turn, helps modulate other cell responses (23).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	14	 These disparate observations are unlikely to stem from an altered Cl conductance.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Alternate paradigms to explain the various features of the CF phenotype are currently being sought.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	16	CFTR has been implicated in the release of cellular ATP (18, 23) and electrodiffusional ATP movement (17, 22, 23); however, other studies have failed to detect electrodiffusional ATP movement in preparations containing a functional CFTR (13, 21).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	17	 In this report, we have revisited the question of whether CFTR is capable of permeating ATP.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Highly purified and functional human epithelial recombinant CFTR (14) was reconstituted into a lipid bilayer in which addition of protein kinase A (PKA) and ATP elicited diphenylamine-2-carboxylate (DPC)-inhibitable Cl- and ATP-permeable ion channel activity, in agreement with our previous findings in intact cells (9, 22, 23).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The present data indicate that ATP transfer by CFTR may not require an "adjacent" transmembrane structure to allow permeation of the nucleotide.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Recombinant human epithelial CFTR was obtained from baculovirus-infected Sf9 (insect) cell membranes according to O'Riordan et al.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Briefly, CFTR was purified with a small (2.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	22	6  x  6 cm, 30 ml) ceramic hydroxyapatite column and an equilibration buffer containing 10 mM sodium phosphate buffer, pH 6.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	23	15% sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), and 5 mM dithiothreitol (DTT) and was eluted with a linear gradient of 100-600 mM sodium phosphate, 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	24	15% SDS, and 5 mM DTT as originally described (3).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	25	 A Superdex column and chromatography in 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	26	25% lithium dodecyl sulfate, were also used to facilitate purification of larger quantities (mg) of insect CFTR (14).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In cases in which purified CFTR was obtained from CFTR-expressing Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells, cells grown on microcarriers were harvested, washed with sodium phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), and lysed in buffer containing protease inhibitors (for more details, see Ref.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The supernatant was processed to obtain a membrane suspension, which was pelleted at 100,000 g for 60 min.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	29	 The supernatant containing the solubilized CFTR was further purified by immunoaffinity resins prepared with monoclonal antibody (MAb) 13-1 and MAb 24-1 (Genzyme, Framingham, MA), activated with sodium periodate, and coupled to Hydrazide Avidgel (Unisyn Technologies) in 50 mM sodium acetate, pH 5.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Immunoaffinity chromatography was performed by incubation of CFTR-containing membranes (25 ml) with 15 ml of resin for at least 3 h at 4 degrees C.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	31	 After collection of the flow-through, the resin was rinsed with 100 ml of wash buffer containing 150 mM NaCl, 50 mM tris(hydroxymethyl)aminomethane (Tris)   HCl, pH 8.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	32	0, 1 mM EDTA, and 1% sodium cholate to remove nonspecifically bound proteins.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	33	 CFTR was further eluted from the resin using elution buffer (150 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris   HCl, pH 7.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	34	4, 1 mM EDTA, 10% glycerol, and 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	35	5% sodium cholate) containing 5 mg/ml of the appropriate peptide antigen, synthesized by QCB (Hopkinton, MA).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Fractions containing CFTR were pooled and concentrated using a Centricell 20 to a final concentration of 1 mg/ml (500  microl).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	37	 CFTR was further purified using either gel filtration or ion exchange chromatography (14).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Gel filtration chromatography was performed on a Superdex 200 HR 10/30 column preequilibrated with 150 mM NaCl, 50 mM Tris   HCl, 1 mM EDTA, 10% glycerol, and 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Immunoaffinity-purified CFTR (200  microl) was applied to the column, fractions were collected, and CFTR was detected by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis followed by silver staining.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	40	 These fractions were pooled and concentrated, and CFTR was quantitated by an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (for details, see Ref.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	41	 In cases in which ion exchange chromatography was used, a 50-ml column of DEAE-Sepharose was equilibrated with 10 mM K2HPO4, 10% glycerol, and 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	42	05% -lysophosphatidylcholine, pH 7.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Stripped membranes (100 mg) were solubilized in the above buffer, and the resulting 100,000-g supernatant was applied to the column.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	44	 CFTR bound to DEAE-Sepharose under these conditions.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	45	 After extensive washing of the resin with equilibration buffer, a linear gradient of 10-150 mM K2HPO4 was applied.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	46	 CFTR eluted from the column at ~60-85 mM K2HPO4 (14).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Purified CFTR obtained from insect Sf9 cells was subjected to 4-20% SDS gradient gel electrophoresis to identify potential protein contaminants ranging in size from  < 1 to 300 kDa.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Electrophoresis was stopped before the bromophenol blue dye front reached the bottom of the gel.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The gel was then overstained with silver to enhance sensitivity.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Molecular size was estimated using markers obtained from GIBCO BRL (Grand Island, NY).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	51	Detection of CFTR by immunoblot analysis.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Mouse mammary carcinoma (C127I) cells transfected with human epithelial CFTR (WT1 cells) were harvested by washing with ice-cold Ca2+-free PBS (5 ml), scraped with a rubber policeman, centrifuged, and resuspended in ice-cold lysis buffer [containing 1% Triton X-100, 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	53	5% NP-40, 150 mM NaCl, 10 mM Tris   HCl, pH 7.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	54	5, 1 mM ethylene glycol-bis(-aminoethyl ether)-N,N,N',N'-tetraacetic acid (EGTA), 1 mM EDTA, 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	55	25 mM sodium vanadate, 10  microg/ml phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 10  microg/ml aprotinin] and then sonicated.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Purified CFTR from Sf9 cells was prepared as indicated above.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Protein determination was performed using the Bio-Rad assay (Bio-Rad, Richmond, CA).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Briefly, each sample was mixed with dilution buffer (final concentrations 62.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	59	5, 2% SDS, 10% glycerol, and 50 mM DTT) and heated for 5 min at 60 degrees C.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Proteins were separated on a 7.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	61	5% SDS-polyacrylamide gel and then transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membranes prewetted with methanol and soaked in transfer buffer for 15 min.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Membranes were blocked with 5% dried milk and 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	63	5% nonimmune goat serum in TBST (50 mM Tris   HCl, pH 7.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Blots were probed with one of two CFTR MAb (0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	65	5-1  microg/ml; MAb 13-1 or MAb 24-1, Genzyme) in TBST containing 1% bovine serum albumin for 36-48 h at 4 degrees C.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	66	 After three washings with TBST, membranes were incubated with peroxidase-labeled goat anti-mouse antibody (Sigma) for 1 h at 25 degrees C.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Immunoreactive bands were detected by enzyme-linked chemiluminescence (Kirkegaard and Perry, Gaithersburg, MD).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	68	Reconstitution of CFTR into phospholipid vesicles.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Immunoaffinity-purified CFTR was concentrated as described above and reconstituted using a modification of the procedure described by Bear et al.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	70	 An aliquot containing a known amount of CFTR (15-20  microg/ml) was added to 100  microl of a solution containing 15 mM N-2-hydroxyethylpiperazine-N'-2-ethanesulfonic acid (HEPES; pH 7.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	71	5 mM EGTA and also containing 1 mg of a sonicated phospholipid mixture of phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylserine, phosphatidylcholine, and ergosterol (5:2:1:2 molar ratio) and 1% sodium cholate.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	72	 After a 40-min incubation on ice, the mixture was dialyzed at 4 degrees C for 24 h against 15 mM HEPES, 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Dialysis continued with daily changes of buffer for an additional 3 days against the same buffer without sodium cholate.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	74	 The sample was further dialyzed against 15 mM HEPES, 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	75	5 mM EGTA, and 150 mM sodium isethionate, pH 7.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The resulting proteoliposomes were quickly frozen at 80 degrees C, thawed, and sonicated for 5 s in a bath sonicator (Lab Supplies, Hicksville, NY).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	77	 In some cases, reconstitution of CFTR-containing proteoliposomes was conducted without freezing and thawing to avoid the potential denaturing of the protein.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Purified CFTR from either transfected Sf9 or CHO cells was reconstituted into a lipid bilayer reconstitution system that has been previously used to assess CFTR-mediated Cl channel activity (3, 14).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The reconstituted protein was either fused into the lipid bilayer by reconstitution of proteoliposomes with techniques previously described (3, 14) or applied directly to the lipid bilayer after elution through a Sephadex G-50 (fine) column to remove denaturing SDS.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Reconstitution of CFTR under these conditions was conducted as follows.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The glass rod used for painting the lipid bilayer was "dipped" consecutively in the CFTR-containing eluent and then into the lipid mixture used for forming the bilayer.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	82	 This CFTR-containing mixture was used to break and repaint the lipid bilayer.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	83	 To test the lack of detergent contamination as a potential source of "spurious" ion channel activity, equivalent samples of SDS were also eluted through a Sephadex G-50 column and/or incorporated into the bilayer as indicated above.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	84	 None of the eluate SDS fractions tested showed a "nonspecific" leak conductance, either in the absence or presence of PKA.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Thus reconstituted CFTR channel activity was only correlated with the presence of the protein and not with either contaminant SDS or protein degradation products that eluted before the protein.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Experiments were also conducted with membrane preparations of CFTR-expressing WT1 cells (22) (data not shown).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Either proteoliposomes containing purified CFTR or CFTR mixed with lipid components was fused to planar lipid bilayers by painting onto a 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	88	1-mm hole in a 13-mm polystyrene cuvette (Warner Instrument, Hamden, CT), as described by Alvarez (2).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The phospholipid composition of the lipid bilayers was 1-palmitoyl-2-oleyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphoethanolamine, 1-palmitoyl-2-oleyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine, and oleyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphatidylserine (7:2:1, vol/vol/vol; Avanti Polar Lipids, Alabaster, AL) in n-decane (Aldrich Chemical, Milwaukee, WI) to a final concentration of 14, 6, and 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	90	 CFTR eluted through Sephadex G-50 (fine) was collected at a final concentration of 1.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The initial cis and trans solutions usually contained, respectively, 10 mM 3-(N-morpholino)propanesulfonic acid (MOPS)-20  microM CaCl2 (pH 7.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	92	 However, the solutions varied for the different experiments as indicated below.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	93	Single-channel recordings of purified CFTR.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Input signals were acquired with a PC-501A patch/whole cell clamp amplifier via a 10-G head stage for lipid bilayers (Warner Instrument).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	95	 The output currents were low-pass filtered at 500 Hz with an eight-pole Bessel filter (Frequency Devices, Haverhill, MA), digitized at 37 kHz and 14 bits with a VR-10B digital data recorder (Instrutech, Great Neck, NY), and stored on a videocassette recorder (JVC, Fairfield, NJ) until further analysis with pCLAMP 6.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	96	3 (Axon Instruments, Foster City, CA).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Single-channel tracings were Gaussian-filtered at 100-200 Hz for display purposes, and analyzed as per patch-clamp protocols.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Unless otherwise stated, values of n given in the text are the numbers of individual current measurements and do not necessarily reflect the numbers of experiments analyzed.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	99	Calculation of the perm-selectivity ratio under asymmetrical ATP/Cl conditions.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	100	 To calculate the ATP-to-Cl perm-selectivity ratio (PATP/PCl) under asymmetrical conditions (ATP/Cl), single-channel conductances  [ = current (I) divided by holding potential (Vh)] were best fitted to the Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz (GHK) equation, such that where i (species in trans compartment) and j (species in cis compartment) represent Cl or ATP, depending on their locations on either side of the membrane, Vh is in mV, zi and zj are the charges for species i and j, respectively, and Ci and Cj are the concentrations of i and j, respectively.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Pi and Pj represent the permeability coefficients for the species i or j, respectively, and  = ziFVh/RT and  = zjFVh/RT, where F, R, and T are Faraday's constant, the gas constant, and absolute temperature, respectively.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	102	 All cases in which MgATP was used were fitted with z = 2, and those in which Tris ATP was used instead were fitted with z = 4.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	103	 ATP salts (MgATP and Tris ATP; Sigma) were added from stock solutions (100 mM) in distilled water.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The catalytic subunit of the adenosine 3',5'-cyclic monophosphate (cAMP)-dependent protein kinase (PKA; Sigma) was used at final concentrations ranging from 75 to 252 nM.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The Cl channel blocker DPC (Fluka Chemical, Ronkonkoma, NY) was kept in a 100-fold stock solution (20 mM) in 50% water-ethanol.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	106	 4,4'-Diisothiocyanostilbene-2,2'-disulfonic acid (Sigma) and glibenclamide (RBI, Natick, MA) were kept in 10 mM stock solutions in 100% dimethyl sulfoxide.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The MAb raised against amino acids 729-736 of the regulatory domain (R-domain) of CFTR (MAb 13-1, Genzyme) was directly diluted 1:100 in the intracellular or bathing solution from a stock solution (292  microg/ml).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	108	 An inactive antibody was obtained by preheating the CFTR antibody for 30 min at 100 degrees C.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	109	Cl and ATP currents of highly purified human epithelial CFTR.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	110	 To assess the role of CFTR in electrodiffusional ATP transfer, human epithelial CFTR was expressed and purified from either Sf9 insect or mammalian CHO cells (14) and functionally reconstituted into a lipid bilayer system to measure ion channel activity as reported previously (3, 14).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The summarized data of the various experimental conditions and preparations used are shown in Table 1.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Purified material from either CHO (data not shown) or Sf9 cells (Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	113	 1) (14) was reconstituted in a chamber containing either 50 mM KCl and 100 mM MgATP (data not shown) or 75 mM MgCl2 and 100 mM Tris ATP (Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	114	 2A) in the cis and trans compartments, respectively.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Both compartments contained 10 mM MOPS, pH 7.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	116	4, and the cis compartment also contained 200 nM PKA.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Eight of nine experiments in KCl/MgATP and seven of nine experiments in MgCl2/Tris   ATP displayed anion-selective channel activity after PKA addition from the cis side of the chamber.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Under the latter conditions, currents were observed in both directions (Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	119	 2A), with at least two distinct (discernible) single-channel conductances of 8.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	120	32 pS (n = 7), respectively (Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	121	 The reversal potentials (Er ) were 2.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	122	29 mV (n = 7) and were thus consistent with a PATP/P Cl of 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	123	2, for the smaller and larger conductances, respectively.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	124	 These values are in close agreement with the PATP/PCl values previously obtained from whole cell and single-channel currents of CFTR-expressing cells and calculated from the respective conductances with symmetrical concentrations of the two ions, in the range of 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	125	 A further indication that the CFTR molecule itself may be implicated in ATP transport is suggested by the observation that addition of the active, but not the heat-inactivated, anti-CFTR R-domain antibody 13-1 (Genzyme) inhibited simultaneously and almost completely both Cl and ATP currents of highly purified CFTR (Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	126	 2C) in five of five experiments tested.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	127	 These data further suggest that CFTR incorporation into the lipid reconstitution chamber was indeed functional and oriented as expected, with the PKA activation sites on the cis side of the membrane.

0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	159	Single-channel currents seemed to correspond to the simultaneous gating of smaller conductance states of the channel (in this case, four; Fig.

0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Data are representative of 3 experiments.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	174	Effect of low ATP on the Cl conductance of purified CFTR.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	175	 To further determine the role of Cl in the single-channel permeability to ATP, experiments were also conducted in the presence of low cis (5-10 mM) MgATP and high N-methyl-D-glucamine chloride (300 mM) in the trans compartment (Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Both compartments also contained 10 mM MOPS, pH 7.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	177	4, and the cis compartment contained 200 nM PKA.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Ion channel activity was observed with unitary conductances of 22.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Interestingly, ion channel activity was also observed at positive potentials, indicating a sizable permeability to 10 mM MgATP (identical results were obtained either in the absence of cis MOPS or by its replacement with HEPES).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The Er values of these two channel conductances were highly similar, 15.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	181	3), indicating a PATP/PCl on the order of 9.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	182	9, as obtained when fitting the data with the GHK equation (Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Under similar conditions, a higher conductance state of CFTR, 511  plus or minus  58.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	184	1 pS (n = 7), was also observed, albeit rarely, with similar Er and PATP/PCl of 15.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	185	 In the presence of 300 mM cis Cl and only 6 mM trans MgATP, with the ionic gradients thus reversed, the single-channel conductance of purified CFTR was 26.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	186	50 pS (n = 16), with an Er of 16.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	187	98 mV (n = 16) and a PATP/PCl of 17.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The data suggest that CFTR may be highly sensitive to external ATP, a phenomenon that will require further examination.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	189	View larger version (22K):    Fig.

0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Single ATP channel activity of CFTR was also determined in the complete absence of Cl (Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	200	 With cis 10 mM MgATP and trans 100 mM MgATP (and similar buffer conditions as before), ATP channel currents were observed (Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	201	 5, A and B), with single-channel conductance of 32.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Addition of cis Cl, however, reduced the conductance of the ATP channel currents (Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Occasionally, a channel conductance of 235  plus or minus  40.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	204	4 mV (n = 5), which was statistically different from the theoretical Er for MgATP2, (RT/zF)   ln([ATP]cis/[ATP]trans) = 29.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	205	1 mV (where [ATP]cis and [ATP]trans are the cis and trans concentrations of ATP, respectively; see Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Thus it is possible either that ATP4 (theoretical Er = 14 mV) makes a contribution to the ionic conductance of CFTR in the presence of MgATP or that CFTR is also permeable to Mg2+.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	207	 In either case, the CFTR preparation was permeable to ATP, which was further determined by replacing ATP salts.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	208	 In the presence of trans 100 mM Tris ATP (cis 10 mM MgATP), the single ATP channel conductance was 38.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	209	1 pS (n = 13), similar to that seen in the presence of MgATP.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The Er shifted, however, to 52.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	211	0 mV (n = 13), consistent with a strong difference in the permeabilities of both free and Mg2+-complexed ATP.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	212	 These findings indicate that, although CFTR is capable of Cl permeation, its ability to preferentially move Cl or ATP may depend not only on the driving force for the intracellular nucleotide ATP but also on the ATP species, the PATP/PCl, and the intracellular Cl concentration.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Under physiological intracellular conditions (5 mM ATP and 30 mM Cl), ATP transport may be favored, however, as the electrochemical gradient for the multivalent ATP will be 1,000-fold higher than that for Cl (18, 22).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	214	View larger version (28K):    Fig.

0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	229	 C, top right: replacement of trans MgATP with an equimolar concentration of Tris ATP shifted Er but not value of single-channel conductance, indicating that both free and Mg2+-complexed ATP may have different permeabilities (7 of 7 experiments).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	230	 C, bottom: I-V relationship is an expansion of C, top left, to more clearly indicate predicted Er for z = 2 (right), z = 3 (middle), and z = 4 (left) obtained from fitting with GHK equation of experimental data using asymmetrical MgATP (10 vs.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	231	 100 mM) for larger (235 pS) and smaller (32.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	232	 D: in presence of 10 mM cis MgATP and 100 mM trans MgATP, further addition of cis NMGCl (50 mM) reduced single-channel currents.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Change is shown for 2 channels (top and middle) whose main conductance state was defined as current amplitude at which channel closed (bottom).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Single-channel opening (bottom left, a) decreased its main conductance state from 25 pS to 11.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	235	7 pS (bottom right, b) after addition of cis Cl.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Data are representative of 2 experiments.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	237	The expression of CFTR has been recently associated with the otherwise unapparent permeation of ATP.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	238	 This phenomenon has been observed by the cAMP-induced release of ATP from CFTR-expressing cells under physiological conditions (18), as well as by electrophysiological studies under highly nonphysiological conditions (22), which determined, nevertheless, the channellike nature of the PKA-induced ATP movement at the single-molecule level (17, 22, 23).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	239	 This is in agreement with our observation that cAMP activation is associated with extrusion of ATP in wild-type (18) but not in 508 CFTR-expressing cells (8).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	240	 The molecular steps associated with ATP movement in CFTR-expressing cells, however, have not been unequivocally determined.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Although the simplest possible explanation for these findings is to implicate CFTR itself as the channel responsible for the ATP-permeable pathway, direct evidence to support this claim is still lacking.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	242	ATP-permeable channels in CFTR-expressing cells may be a reflection of endogenous functional channel proteins that are regulated by, but are distinct from, CFTR.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	243	 For example, expression of both mammalian (1) and Drosophila melanogaster (5) P-glycoproteins, CFTR congeners of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family of transport proteins, has been associated with the expression of ATP channel activity, thus raising the possibility that transport proteins other than CFTR are present in certain preparations.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	244	 At least one recent report demonstrated an osmotically stimulated electrodiffusional ATP movement in human hepatoma cells seemingly devoid of CFTR (28).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	245	 A direct role of CFTR in ATP movement has also been questioned by recent reports that failed to detect ATP-permeable channel activity in cells or preparations containing CFTR (13, 21).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	246	 However, these studies also failed to detect "any" other ATP channel activity, which is inconsistent with the ATP release associated with CFTR expression (18, 23).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	247	 This raises the possibility that the presence of putative ATP-permeable pathways in CFTR-expressing preparations may largely depend on the cellular (tissue) model under study and/or the nature of the ATP complexes driven.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Alternate possibilities, however, may also entail more critical experimental conditions for determining ATP movement than previously expected.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	249	 A previous study that failed to detect ATP release from CFTR-expressing cells (27), for example, may have simply failed to meet the technological parameters suitable for detecting the expected amounts of ATP released to the extracellular milieu (18).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Furthermore, the possibility that under certain conditions, electroneutral ATP complexes are driven through channel structures cannot yet be ruled out.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	251	                              View this table:    Table 2.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	252	   Most frequent single-channel conductances.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	253	In the present report, addition of cis Cl (N-methyl-D-glucamine chloride, 50 mM) in the presence of 10 mM MgATP reduced the CFTR single-channel conductance from 25 to 11.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	254	 5D), a condition similar to previously reported values for CFTR-associated Cl movement (13).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	255	 This finding further suggests that both Cl and ATP may compete with each other for the conductance pore of the channel, as was originally reported in intact cells (22).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	256	Reconstituted CFTR ATP channel activity was readily inhibited by the anti R-domain CFTR antibody MAb 13-1 (Genzyme), in agreement with previous reports in intact cells (19).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The possibility that a functional CFTR is required to regulate ATP channels other than CFTR, however, cannot be easily ruled out, since, as indicated above, recent studies failed to detect any ATP-permeable channel activity in preparations containing CFTR (13, 21).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	258	 At least one such study was conducted with a purified CFTR preparation similar to the one presented in this report (13).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Thus a likely possibility is that activated CFTR, which is indeed permeable to Cl, may behave as an ATP-selective ion channel only under certain circumstances (see below).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	260	 It should also be noted that these reports did not exactly mimic our present or previous studies.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	261	 We have found that PKA activation of CFTR, for example, was readily observed (15 of 18 experiments) in experiments tested with daily fresh batches of PKA.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	262	 However, under certain experimental conditions, namely the use of "older" PKA (prepared  > 24 h before the experiments), CFTR activation under Cl-free conditions also required the presence of sustained holding potentials (between +100 and +150 mV; 41 of 82 experiments).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	263	 This finding may actually explain previous failed attempts to obtain single ATP channel currents from reconstituted CFTR in which PKA was absent (21) and further suggests the possibility that adjacent structures other than CFTR may also be required for proper channel activation in vivo (19).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	264	Although the reason for the required voltage activation of CFTR in the presence of PKA is as yet unknown, it is not unprecedented for ATP transport by other ABC transporters.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Concerning the electrodiffusional ATP movement by the murine mdr1 gene product, P-glycoprotein (1), for example, it was observed that a double mutation of this channel protein in either nucleotide-binding domain rendered the mutated P-glycoprotein completely unable to spontaneously release cellular ATP.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	266	 However, voltage activation reestablished ATP transport and, interestingly, Cl channel activity associated with this protein as well (1).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Similar findings have also been recently observed with the D.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	268	 melanogaster mdr gene products Mdr65 and Mdr49 P-glycoprotein homologues, which were also voltage activated (5).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Although it is unlikely that this activation process has any physiological significance, it raises the interesting possibility that other relevant intracellular factors that are absent in the purified CFTR preparation may be required for a proper PKA activation of CFTR.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Under no circumstances, however, did voltage stimulation induce any ATP-permeable channel activity in the absence of PKA.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	271	The present data also dispel a common misconception about the size of ATP as it is transported through this channel molecule.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	272	 In solution, ATP takes various conformations by interacting with counterions other than Mg2+ (11).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	273	 However, only one conformation has been observed for the MgATP2 complex, the relevant moiety associated with molecules that bind and/or hydrolyze ATP (4, 11).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	274	 The average planar diameter of the MgATP complex under these conditions is  < 5 A (see Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	275	 6), at least similar to, if not smaller than, the expected diameter of I, a CFTR-permeable anion (for details, see Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Thus ATP "size" is not a constraint to movement through CFTR, provided that it is either free or complexed to Mg2+.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Counterion-ATP complexes of larger sizes, however, may reflect different interactions with CFTR.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	278	 A recent paper (13), reporting that purified CFTR was tested and failed to detect ATP transport, suggested that the K2ATP salt used in that study actually blocked Cl movement through CFTR.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Because K+ is almost nine times larger than Mg2+, the larger K2ATP moiety is likely to be a blocking agent of CFTR channel activity.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	280	 This is in agreement with an expected, undetectable, 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	281	14-pS K2ATP single-channel conductance (assuming a monovalent salt as the minimum size) calculated by extrapolating the single-channel conductance of 26.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	282	2 pS obtained in the present study, as a function of the counterionic radius of the MgATP complex.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	283	View larger version (35K):    Fig.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	284	   Models of free and Mg2+-complexed ATP.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Scaled color models of Mg2+-complexed ATP (MgATP2; B and D) and free ATP (A and C) were created with Chem3DPro molecular modeling system (version 3.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	286	0, 1990, Cambridge Scientific Computing, Cambridge, MA).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	287	 C atoms, solid purple; O atoms, solid red; P atoms, striped red; H atoms, light blue.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Mg atom is indicated as a green striped ball at bottom left center of B, and extreme left of D.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	289	 A and B show phosphate groups covered by their respective oxygen atoms to left of molecule.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	290	 C and D are 3-dimensional perspectives indicating pyridine ring toward front of molecule.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Molecule (of either model) is largely oblong.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Shorter diameter is drawn from steric distance between N1 and N3 of pyridine ring (2.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	293	46 A), and longer diameter is drawn from C2 and P17 (5.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Thus phosphates "encircle" adenine moiety (using ribose as the hinge), such that their position is coordinated not only by nucleoside but also by their surrounding oxygens.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	295	 In comparison, N1-N3 distance in MgATP2 was found to be identical to that of free ATP.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	296	 However, arrangement of phosphates surrounding adenine moiety was completely different, as distance between C4 and O25, which is 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	297	 In addition, distance between C2 and P17, 5.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	298	18 A (C2-P18) in MgATP2, thus suggesting that, although both models have similar diameters, MgATP seems to be "longer" than free ATP.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Both structures were "minimized" for structural errors but not by their minimal energy conformations.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Furthermore, it is also important to realize that ether bonds for either model were computed as 1.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	301	0, despite the fact that bond orders for high-energy phosphates are significantly shorter (on the order of 0.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	302	41), thus suggesting much smaller 3-dimensional structures (20).
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Model of free ATP, however, is almost identical (although without structural minimization) to that of Stryer's Biochemistry (Ref.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	304	 329), although other possible conformations for MgATP2 (Ref.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	305	 352) were not explored in above molecules.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	306	Reconstituted CFTR mediated the electrodiffusional movement of both Cl and ATP and displayed several conductance states, which may be related to "clustering" of CFTR in complexes that have the same perm-selectivity properties.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Each ion seems to modify the permeability properties of the other, which may be due to either competition for one another at the conductance pore of the channel or the possibility that both ions have distinct, but mutually interactive, permeable pathways.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	308	 This is a phenomenon that will require further investigation.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Interestingly, however, both the cis concentration of Cl and the trans concentration of ATP modified the single-channel conductance of CFTR.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	310	In conclusion, the present data are consistent with the most likely, but not exclusive, possibility that CFTR permeates ATP.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	311	 This is in close agreement with previous reports indicating that wild-type CFTR (9, 17, 22, 23), but not 508 CFTR (8), may be involved in ATP movement in vivo.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	312	 "Contaminant" channels that are permeable to ATP but are distinct from CFTR cannot be ruled out, although the finding that preparations with different degrees of purification of CFTR, including the purified protein, show functional characteristics similar if not identical to those observed in vivo strongly suggest a direct role of this channel protein in ATP movement.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Additional studies, including mutational analysis of this channel protein, will be required, however, to further assess the relevance of the CFTR-mediated ATP transport in the context of Cl vs.
0.43087202.9530112.html.plaintext.txt	314	 ATP transport and, most importantly, in the onset and reversal of the CF phenotype.
