0.43596935.7499295.html.plaintext.txt	292	 (1992) Nature 358, 761-764 [CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Lukacs, G.
0.43596935.7499295.html.plaintext.txt	293	 268, 21592-21598 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Dalemans, W.
0.43596935.7499295.html.plaintext.txt	294	 (1991) Nature 354, 526-528 [CrossRef][Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Pasyk, E.
0.43596935.7499295.html.plaintext.txt	295	 270, 12347-12350 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Li, C.
0.43596935.7499295.html.plaintext.txt	296	 (1993) Nature Genetics 3, 311-316 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Horowitz, B.
0.43596935.7499295.html.plaintext.txt	297	 (1993) Nature Genetics 4, 426-431 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve]  1995 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	0	The  Subunit of the Sec61 Complex Facilitates Cotranslational Protein Transport and Interacts with the Signal Peptidase during Translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	1	* Abteilung Biochemie II, Zentrum Biochemie und Molekulare Zellbiologie, Georg-August-Universitat, 37073 Gottingen, Germany; and  Harvard Medical School, Department of Cell Biology, Boston, Massachusetts 02115.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	2	The Sec61 complex is the central component of the protein translocation apparatus of the ER membrane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	3	 We have addressed the role of the  subunit (Sec61) during cotranslational protein translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	4	 With a reconstituted system, we show that a Sec61 complex lacking Sec61 is essentially inactive when elongation and membrane targeting of a nascent chain occur at the same time.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The translocation process is perturbed at a step where the nascent chain would be inserted into the translocation channel.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	6	 However, if sufficient time is given for the interaction of the nascent polypeptide with the mutant Sec61 complex, translocation is almost normal.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Thus Sec61 kinetically facilitates cotranslational translocation, but is not essential for it.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	8	Using chemical cross-linking we show that Sec61 not only interacts with subunits of the Sec61 complex but also with the 25-kD subunit of the signal peptidase complex (SPC25), thus demonstrating for the first time a tight interaction between the SPC and the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Interestingly, the cross-links between Sec61 and SPC25 and between Sec61 and Sec61 depend on the presence of membrane-bound ribosomes, suggesting that these interactions are induced when translocation is initiated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	10	 We propose that the SPC is transiently recruited to the translocation site, thus enhancing its activity.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	11	IN higher eukaryotes, most proteins are transported across the ER membrane in a cotranslational manner.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The translating ribosome binds tightly to the ER membrane (Connolly et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	13	, 1994), and the growing nascent polypeptide chain is transferred directly from the channel in the ribosome into a channel in the membrane (Blobel and Dobberstein, 1975; Connolly et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	14	, 1989; Simon and Blobel, 1991; Gorlich et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	15	, 1992b; Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	16	The cotranslational translocation pathway in mammals can be reproduced with reconstituted proteoliposomes containing only three membrane protein components: the SRP receptor complex, the translocating chain-associating membrane (TRAM)1 protein, and the Sec61 complex (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The signal recognition particle (SRP) receptor is required to target a ribosome- nascent chain complex to the ER membrane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The function of the TRAM protein is still unclear; it is only required for the translocation of a subset of proteins (Gorlich et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The Sec61 complex represents the essential core of the translocation machinery in the ER membrane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	20	 It consists of three subunits, an  subunit (Sec61) that spans the membrane 10 times, and  and  subunits (Sec61 and Sec61, respectively) that each span the membrane a single time.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	21	The Sec61 complex is evolutionarily highly conserved and is proposed to carry out at least three different functions.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	22	 First, it is the major constituent of the protein conducting membrane channel.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Cross-linking experiments have shown that its  subunit is in continuous proximity of nascent polypeptide chains passing through the membrane (Mothes et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Recent electron microscopic data demonstrate that the Sec61 complex can form cylindrical oligomers that presumably represent the channels (Hanein et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Second, the Sec61 complex is tightly associated with membrane-bound ribosomes and is likely to be the ribosome receptor (Gorlich et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	26	, 1994; Jungnickel and Rapoport, 1995).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Third, the Sec61 complex is involved in a signal sequence recognition event that takes place inside the membrane (Jungnickel and Rapoport, 1995).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	28	The role of the Sec61 complex subunits for its different functions is not yet clear.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Whereas the presence of a multi-spanning  subunit in a channel-forming protein complex may not be surprising, the role of the two small single-spanning polypeptide chains remains mysterious.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	30	 A particular enigma is the  subunit.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	31	 In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the simultaneous deletion of the  subunits of the two homologous Sec61 complexes (Sec61p and the Ssh1p complex) is not lethal; the cells only show a growth defect at elevated temperatures (Finke et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Thus, despite the fact that the protein is evolutionarily highly conserved, it does not appear to be absolutely required in vivo.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Posttranslational protein transport across yeast ER membranes in vitro is reduced, but not completely prevented, when the  subunits are lacking.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	34	 At which point the transport process is inhibited, and whether the  subunits play any role in the cotranslational mode of protein transport has not yet been investigated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	35	The function of the  subunit of the Sec61 complex may not necessarily be restricted to the actual translocation process.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The transport of proteins across the ER membrane must be intimately coupled to their modification and folding, and it seems possible that the  subunit could be involved in interactions between the translocation channel and modifying enzymes or chaperones.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	37	 A physical association of these proteins with the channel may enhance the efficiency of their function.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	38	 A good example is the signal peptidase, an abundant enzyme whose active site is in the lumen of the ER.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Although it can cleave the signal peptide of even completed polypeptide chains, its efficiency is probably much higher when it can act on polypeptide chains that are just emerging from the translocation channel into the lumen of the ER.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	40	 One may therefore predict its physical association with channel constituents.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The signal peptidase complex is composed of five membrane protein subunits (Evans et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	42	, 1986), two with an active site for enzymatic activity, one with a lumenal domain of unknown function, and two (12 and 25 kD) with cytosolic domains.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The function of the latter is particularly unclear because they cannot contribute to the enzymatic activity on the lumenal side of the membrane, and are not essential for the viability of yeast cells (Lively and Walsh, 1983; Fang et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	44	, 1996; Kalies and Hartmann, 1996; Mullins et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	45	 They would be especially good candidates to serve as linkers to the translocation channel.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	46	In the present paper, we have analyzed the role of the  subunit of the Sec61 complex in the cotranslational translocation pathway in mammals.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Using a reconstituted system, we demonstrate that the  subunit kinetically facilitates, but is not essential for, cotranslational translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The protein does not play a role in the interaction of the ribosome with the Sec61 complex, but rather in the insertion of the nascent chain into the translocation site.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Using a bifunctional cross-linker, we also provide evidence that it interacts specifically with the 25-kD subunit of the signal peptidase complex (SPC25), thus demonstrating for the first time a tight interactions between the SPC and the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Cross-linking is only observed in the presence of membrane-bound ribosomes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	51	 These data thus suggest that, upon ribosome binding to the Sec61 complex, an interaction between the cytosolic domains of the Sec61 and SPC25 serves to recruit the signal peptidase complex to the translocation site.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Together with the observation that cross-linking between the  and  subunits of the Sec61 complex is also dependent on translocation, these data provide first evidence for structural changes in the translocation apparatus upon initiation of cotranslational translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	53	Microsomes treated with puromycin and high salt (PK-RM) (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993) were solubilized at a concentration of 2 eq/ microl in SB (50 mM Hepes/KOH, pH 7.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	54	6, 15% glycerin, 400 mM potassium acetate, 10 mM magnesium acetate, and 10  microg/ml leupeptin, 2  microg/ml pepstatin, and 5  microg/ml chymostatin as protease inhibitors) containing 1.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	55	5% decylsucrose for 30 min on ice.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	56	 After centrifugation for 10 min at 14,000 rpm in a microfuge, 0.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	57	7% deoxyBigChap was added to the supernatant.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	58	 500  microl detergent extract was mixed with 100  microl of an immunoaffinity resin that contained 0.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	59	2 mg/ml affinity-purified antibodies directed against the NH2 terminus of Sec61, covalently coupled to protein A-Sepharose (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The column was previously equilibrated with SB containing 1.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The incubation was done for 18 h in an overhead shaker in a cold room.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Every 6 h the resin was replaced with a new one.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The non-bound material was collected and proteoliposomes were produced by incubation with SM2-biobeads at 4 degrees C (Bio Rad Laboratories, Hercules, CA) (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Proteoliposomes containing the purified Sec61 complex were prepared as described previously (Kalies et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	65	The signal peptidase complex (SPC) was purified as reported (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Proteoliposomes were produced by mixing 20  microl of the SPC preparation (200 eq) with 20  microl of a phospholipid mixture (phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylserine, and phosphatidylinositol in a ratio of 100:25:3:12.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	67	5; total concentration 5 mg/ml).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	68	 40  microg SM2 biobeads equilibrated in SB were added and vesicles were prepared as described (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	69	Binding of Ribosomes to Proteoliposomes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	70	The purification, radioactive labeling, and binding of ribosomes to reconstituted proteoliposomes were done as described (Kalies et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The ribosome binding was carried out at 26 degrees C.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	72	Cross-linking with Bis-maleimidohexane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	73	A 25 mM stock solution of bis-maleimidohexane (BMH) in dimethylformamid was prepared.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Microsomes or proteoliposomes were incubated with increasing amounts of BMH for 30 min at 0 degrees C in a cross-link buffer containing 50 mM Hepes/KOH, pH 7.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	75	6, 100 mM KCl, 5 mM MgCl2, 250 mM sucrose, and protease inhibitors.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The reaction was quenched by addition of 100 mM -mercaptoethanol and the samples were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting, using various antibodies.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	77	Transcription, Translation, and Translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	78	Transcripts coding for preprolactin were produced by in vitro transcription with T7 RNA polymerase of the plasmid pGEMBP1.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	79	 For full-length transcripts, the plasmid was cut with PstI and in the case of the transcripts coding for the 86-mer with PvuII.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	80	Translation of the full-length protein was carried out in the wheat germ system in the presence of 40 nM SRP, [35S]methionine, and membranes at 26 degrees C for 30 min.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	81	 After 15 min, 4  microM edeine was added to prevent further initiation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	82	 In a parallel experiment translation was started in the absence of membranes for 15 min at 26 degrees C.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	83	 4  microM edeine and membranes were then added.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The samples were incubated on ice for 10 min followed by an incubation at 26 degrees C for additional 15 min.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Half of the sample was precipitated with 15% TCA.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The other half was treated with 0.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	87	5 mg/ml proteinase K for 30 min on ice, before precipitation with TCA.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	88	 The pellets were washed with acetone and dissolved in SDS sample buffer.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	89	 After SDS-PAGE, the gels were dried and analyzed in a quantitative manner with a PhosphorImager (Bas 1000; Fuji, Tokyo, Japan).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	90	Translation of the 86-mer of preprolactin was done in the reticulocyte lysate system in the presence of [35S]methionine at 24 degrees C for 20 min.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	91	 For the mock translation, the mRNA was omitted.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	92	 2 mM cycloheximide and 5 eq membranes were added to 300  microl translation mix and the incubation was continued at 0 degrees C for 10 min and at 25 degrees C for 5 min.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	93	 After centrifugation in a microfuge at 14,000 rpm for 5 min the samples were layered on top of a sucrose cushion (400  microl of 50 mM Hepes/KOH, pH 7.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	94	6, 100 mM KCl, 5 mM MgCl2, and 500 mM sucrose) and were centrifuged at 75,000 rpm for 20 min (rotor TLA 100.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Finally the pellets were resuspended in 65  microl cross-link buffer.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	96	Immunoblotting, Immunoprecipitation, and Antibodies.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	97	Immunoblotting was carried out as described (Gorlich et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Before immunoprecipitation, the samples were denatured in SDS sample buffer omitting reducing reagents.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The samples were then mixed with 10 vol of SB containing 1% Triton X-100, and incubated for 20 min on ice.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Affinity-purified antibodies against Sec61 coupled to protein A-Sepharose were added.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	101	 After shaking in a cold room for 3 h, the antibody resin was washed with 1% Triton X-100 in SB.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Finally, the material bound to the column was analyzed by SDS-PAGE and Western blotting.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	103	Polyclonal antibodies directed against the following synthetic peptides were used: against the NH2 terminus of Sec61 (Gorlich et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	104	, 1992b); against the COOH terminus of Sec61 (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993); against the position 137 to 150 of the SRP-receptor  (docking protein ); against the COOH terminus of the TRAM protein (Gorlich et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	105	, 1992a); against the NH2 terminus of Sec61 (DQVMQFVEPSRQC); and against the COOH terminus of SPC25 (Kalies and Hartmann, 1996).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	106	We used reconstituted proteoliposomes, immunodepleted of the  subunit of the Sec61 complex, to investigate the role of the protein in cotranslational protein translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Mammalian PK-RM, were solubilized in a detergent mixture that leads to the dissociation of the Sec61 complex into its subunits.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The detergent extract was incubated either with antibodies directed against Sec61 that had been immobilized on protein A-Sepharose or, to generate a mock-depleted extract, with protein A-Sepharose alone.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The efficiency of immunodepletion was tested by Western blotting, using a radioactively labeled secondary antibody and a PhosphorImager.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	110	 In a typical experiment, the depleted proteoliposomes contained  < 0.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	111	5% of the original amount of Sec61, whereas all other proteins tested remained almost unaffected (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The only exception was Sec61, the concentration of which was reduced to 50- 70% in the worst case.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Apparently, under the conditions used, the  and the  subunits are not totally dissociated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	114	View larger version (38K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	115	   Sec61 facilitates cotranslational protein translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	116	 (A) To produce proteoliposomes lacking Sec61 ribosome-free membranes (PK-RM) were solubilized under conditions where the Sec61 complex dissociates into its subunits.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	117	 The detergent extract was immunodepleted with an antibody column directed against Sec61 or was incubated with protein A-Sepharose to generate a mock-depleted extract.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	118	 After reconstitution the proteoliposomes and PK-RM were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and Western blotting using a radioactively labeled secondary antibody and a PhosphorImager system for quantitation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	119	 (B) The membranes and proteoliposomes analyzed in A were tested for their competence to translocate polypeptides.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Preprolactin mRNA was translated in the wheat germ system in the presence of SRP and microsomes or proteoliposomes, respectively, at 26 degrees C (lanes 2-8).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	121	 In a parallel experiment translation was started in the absence of microsomes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	122	 After addition of membranes or proteoliposomes, respectively, the targeting reaction was carried out at 0 degrees C followed by an elongation at 26 degrees C (lanes 10-16).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Half of the sample was treated with proteinase K to assay for material that is translocated into the vesicles and is therefore protected against the added protease.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	124	 DP,  subunit of the SRP receptor; pPL, preprolactin; PL, prolactin.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	125	We then tested the reconstituted proteoliposomes for their ability to translocate proteins synthesized in a wheat germ translation system.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Microsomes (PK-RM) served as a control.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Transcripts coding for full-length preprolactin were translated at 26 degrees C in the presence of microsomes or proteoliposomes, the concentration of which was normalized for their Sec61 content (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	128	 PK-RM and mock-depleted proteoliposomes had the same translocation activity (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	129	 1 B, lanes 6 and 7), whereas the depleted proteoliposomes were totally inactive (lane 8).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	130	 In the absence of Sec61, processed prolactin was produced (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	131	 1 B, lane 4) that, however, was accessible to the action of proteinase K; it therefore presumably represents material generated by signal peptidase that was incorporated into the reconstituted membrane in the inverse orientation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	132	Since Sec61 is not essential in yeast, we wondered if the mammalian Sec61 complex lacking this component may show in vitro translocation activity under less stringent conditions than used before.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	133	 We therefore performed the translocation reaction such that more time would be allowed for the membrane binding of the ribosome- nascent chain complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Translation of the full-length transcript coding for preprolactin was initially carried out in the presence of SRP but absence of membranes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	135	 This leads to a translational arrest when the polypeptide chain reaches a length of ~70 residues.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The membranes were then added at 0 degrees C, conditions that allow efficient membrane binding of the ribosome-nascent chain complexes but no chain elongation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The samples were then warmed up to 26 degrees C to continue translation and concomitant translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	138	 With this protocol, proteoliposomes lacking Sec61 were active in translocation, although their activity was lower by a factor of three compared with the wild-type complex (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Thus, the depleted proteoliposomes are capable to translocate polypeptides if given enough time in the membrane targeting reaction.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The results also indicate that the Sec61 complex lacking its  subunit has not been irreversibly denatured during the prolonged immunodepletion procedure.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	141	 These data suggest that the ribosome-nascent chain complex was targeted to the membrane and thus brought in contact with the signal peptidase, but that a subsequent translocation step was perturbed.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	142	 We also found that a fragment of preprolactin of 86 amino acids could be efficiently targeted to reconstituted proteoliposomes and reached a protease-protected state even if Sec61 was lacking (data not shown), supporting the conclusion that insertion of the nascent chain into the Sec61-depleted translocation site can occur if no chain elongation is going on.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	143	It should be noted that in the absence of membranes, almost no full-length preprolactin could be observed (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	144	 1 B, lanes 1 and 9), indicating that under the conditions used, SRP produced a tight translational arrest.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Both the microsomes and the two types of proteoliposomes were able to release the translational arrest (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	146	 1 B, lanes 2-4 and 10-12), indicating that this reaction is not dependent on the presence of Sec61.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	147	Sec61 Is Not Required for Ribosome Binding.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	148	Our data suggested that in the absence of Sec61, the binding of the ribosome-nascent chain complex to the ER membrane is less efficient.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	149	 This could be due to either a defect in the interaction of the mutated Sec61 complex with the ribosome, or to a perturbed insertion of the nascent chain into the translocation site.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	150	 We therefore analyzed whether the  subunit plays a role in ribosome binding.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Depleted and mock-depleted proteoliposomes were incubated at physiological salt concentrations with radioactively labeled ribosomes and increasing amounts of unlabeled ribosomes, both lacking nascent polypeptide chains.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Under these conditions, the ribosomes interact mainly with the Sec61 complex (Kalies et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	153	 To separate the unbound from the bound fraction, the membranes were floated in a sucrose gradient.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Scatchard plot analysis was used to estimate the number of binding sites and the apparent dissociation constants (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Both the depleted and mock-depleted proteoliposomes were found to bind ribosomes with approximately the same binding constant.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Also, the number of binding sites was about the same.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The measured parameters are in good agreement with published data for the binding of ribosomes to PK-RM and proteoliposomes (Kalies et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	158	, 1994), although the dissociation constants seem to be somewhat higher at 26 degrees  than at 0 degrees C.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Thus, steps other than the interaction between SRP and its membrane receptor or the binding of ribosomes to the Sec61 complex must be responsible for the less efficient insertion of the nascent polypeptide chains into proteoliposomes lacking Sec61.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	160	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	161	   Binding of ribosomes to reconstituted proteoliposomes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Sec61- and mock-depleted proteoliposomes were incubated with radioactively labeled ribosomes and increasing amounts of unlabeled ribosomes at physiological salt concentrations and 26 degrees C.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	163	 To separate the bound from the unbound fraction the samples were submitted to flotation in a sucrose gradient.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The number of binding sites and the apparent dissociation constants were estimated by Scatchard plot analysis.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Kd, dissociation constant; eq, membrane equivalant (Walter and Blobel, 1983).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	166	Sec61 Interacts with the 25-kD Subunit of the Signal Peptidase Complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	167	To further analyze the function of Sec61, we investigated its molecular environment in the membrane by chemical cross-linking.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Rough microsomes (RM) were treated with increasing amounts of BMH, a bifunctional cross-linking reagent that reacts with sulfhydryl (SH) groups.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The proteins were subsequently separated by SDS-PAGE and analyzed by immunoblotting with antibodies against Sec61 (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Three cross-linked products were detected with the antibodies (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The apparent molecular weights of the cross-linked proteins were estimated to be 12, 23, and 38 kD, assuming an apparent molecular weight for Sec61 of 13 kD.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	172	View larger version (36K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	173	   Analysis of the environment of Sec61 by chemical cross-linking.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	174	 RM were treated with increasing amounts of bis-maleimidohexane (BMH) and were subsequently analyzed by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting using antibodies directed against the  subunit of the Sec61 complex (lanes 1-6).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	175	 To identify the cross-linked polypeptides, RM were treated with BMH as indicated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The samples were subsequently immunoprecipitated under denaturing conditions with an anti-Sec61 column.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	177	 The precipitated material was analyzed by Western blotting using antibodies directed against Sec61 (lanes 7-10), Sec61 (lanes 11-14) or the 25-kD subunit of the signal peptidase complex (SPC25) (lanes 15-18), respectively.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Lanes 1, 7, 11, and 15 show the results for untreated RM.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	179	To identify the cross-linked proteins, microsomes were treated with two different concentrations of BMH and dissolved in SDS-containing buffer to dissociate noncovalent chemical bonds.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The extract was subjected to immunoprecipitation with Sec61 antibodies and the precipitated material was analyzed by Western blotting using different antibodies.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	181	 3 shows the immunoblots with antibodies directed against Sec61 (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	182	 3, lanes 11-14) and SPC25 (lanes 15-18).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The product containing the 38-kD protein could be immunoprecipitated with Sec61 antibodies (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	184	 3, lane 10) and was recognized by the Sec61 antibody (lane 14), indicating that it is generated by cross-linking between the  and  subunits of the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The product containing a protein of ~23 kD could be immunoprecipitated with Sec61 antibodies (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	186	 3, lane 9) and reacted with antibodies against SPC25 (lane 17) and is thus generated by cross-linking between these two proteins.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Neither Sec61 nor SPC25 were coprecipitated with Sec61 if BMH was omitted (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	188	 3, lanes 12 and 16), and both antibodies recognized single bands in untreated RM (lanes 11 and 15).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	189	The product containing the protein of ~12 kD did not react with any of the antibodies tested.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Considering its size, we suspected that it may represent a product generated by cross-linking of two  subunits of the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	191	 To test this assumption, purified Sec61 complex was reconstituted into proteoliposomes and subjected to cross-linking with BMH.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	192	 When analyzed by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting with Sec61 antibodies, a cross-linked product containing a 12-kD protein was again observed (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	193	 4 A, lanes 10-12), indicating that the cross-linking partner is indeed a constituent of the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	194	 The smaller cross-linked product in Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	195	 4 A, lanes 11 and 12 (marked with an asterisk) is probably generated by cross-linking between Sec61 and Sec61, the smallest subunit of the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	196	 The appearance of this cross-linked product in native microsomes was variable among different experiments.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	197	View larger version (50K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	198	   Sec61 is involved in ribosome-dependent structural changes of the translocation site.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Rough microsomes (RM), ribosome-free membranes (PK-RM), proteoliposomes produced from an unfractionated detergent extract of PK-RM (total), and proteoliposomes containing the purified Sec61 complex (Sec61p) or the purified signal peptidase complex (SPC), respectively, were treated with BMH as indicated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	200	 After SDS-PAGE the samples were analyzed by immunoblotting with antibodies against Sec61 (A) or SPC25 (B).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The position of a probable cross-link between Sec61 and Sec61 is marked by an asterisk.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	202	Ribosome-dependent Structural Changes of the Translocation Site.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	203	We were concerned that the membrane-bound ribosomes may prevent full access of the bifunctional cross-linker to Sec61 so that only a subset of its interacting partners could be detected.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	204	 However, to our surprise, when PK-RM were used in cross-linking experiments, not only were no additional cross-links observed, but those between Sec61 and Sec61 and between Sec61 and SPC25 could no longer be seen (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Treatment of RM with high salt or puromycin alone did not change these cross-links (data not shown), suggesting that their disappearance requires the dissociation of the ribosomes into subunits.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	206	 In agreement with this assumption, proteoliposomes reconstituted from a crude detergent extract of microsomes or proteoliposomes containing only the purified Sec61 complex, which both lack membrane-bound ribosomes, also did not give these cross-links (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	207	A similar conclusion could be drawn when the cross-linking reaction was analyzed with SPC25 antibodies (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	208	 With RM two cross-linked products were seen, one of ~36 kD between SPC25 and Sec61, and another of ~46 kD (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	209	 With PK-RM or with proteoliposomes reconstituted from a crude detergent extract, the adduct of SPC25 and Sec61 was no longer observed (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	210	 4 B, lanes 4-6 and lanes 7-9, respectively), whereas the 46-kD cross-linked product remained unchanged.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The latter was also observed with proteoliposomes containing only the purified signal peptidase complex (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Two SPC subunits, the nonglycosylated SPC25 and the glycoprotein SPC22/23 carry SH groups and have an appropriate molecular weight to produce this 46-kD cross-link with SPC25.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	213	 As the molecular weight of the cross-linked product did not change after treatment with N-glycosidase F (data not shown), we conclude that it consists of two SPC25.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	214	To exclude that the high salt treatment during the preparation of PK-RM was responsible for the structural alterations identified, ribosomes were detached from the membrane by an independent method.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	215	 When the reaction with BMH was performed in the presence of 10 mM EDTA under low salt conditions, the cross-link between Sec61 and Sec61 and that between Sec61 and SPC25 could not be seen anymore (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	216	 However, the homotypic cross-link between two Sec61 remained unchanged, indicating that the EDTA did not interfere with the reactivity of the BMH.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	217	 It should be noted that the extent to which the cross-linking intensity was reduced varied in different experiments.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	218	View larger version (60K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	219	   Structural changes of the translocation site in EDTA-treated microsomes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	220	 RM were incubated with 10 mM EDTA before BMH was added as indicated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	221	 The samples were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting with anti-Sec61 antibodies.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	222	If the ribosome-dependent alteration of the cross-link pattern has a real physiological significance it should be possible to reproduce the cross-link between Sec61 and Sec61 and that between Sec61 and SPC25 by a retargeting of ribosomes carrying nascent polypeptide chains at ribosome free membranes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Ribosome-nascent chain complexes were produced by an in vitro translation of truncated mRNA coding for the first 86 amino acids of preprolactin (86-mer).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Ribosome-free membranes (PK-RM) were then added to the translation mix (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	225	 As controls PK-RM and RM were incubated with a translation mix that did not contain any preprolactin mRNA (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	226	 After isolation of the membranes aliquots of each sample were treated with different amounts of BMH.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	227	 The samples were analyzed by Western blotting with Sec61 antibodies using enhanced chemiluminescence as a detection system (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	228	 6 A) or by quantitative immunoblotting using radioactively labeled secondary antibodies and a PhosphorImager (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	229	 6 B) shows that the incubation of PK-RM with ribosome-nascent chain complexes led to a clear restimulation of the cross-link intensity between Sec61 and Sec61 and between Sec61 and SPC25.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Similar results were obtained if EDTA-treated membranes were analyzed (data not shown).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	231	View larger version (47K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	232	   Structural changes of the translocation site are induced by the targeting of ribosomes carrying the preprolactin 86-mer (pPl 86mer).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	233	 (A) Translation was carried out in the reticulocyte lysate system in the presence (lanes 4-6) or absence (lanes 1-3 and 7-9) of mRNA coding for the pPl 86-mer.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	234	 After addition of PK-RM (lanes 1-6) or rough microsomes (lanes 7-9), respectively, the targeting reaction was carried out at 0 degrees C followed by an incubation at 26 degrees C.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	235	 The membranes were collected by a centrifugation through a sucrose cushion, separated into three aliquots and treated with bis-maleimidohexane (BMH) as indicated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	236	 The samples were analyzed by immunoblotting with antibodies against Sec61 using as a detection system enhanced chemiluminescence (A) or radioactively labeled secondary antibodies (B), respectively.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	237	 The unknown cross-link marked with an asterisk was not observed in other experiments.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	238	 (B) A PhosphorImager system was used for quantitation of the cross-linking intensities.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The cross-linking intensities obtained for RM were defined as 100%.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	240	Taken together, these data provide evidence that the  subunit of the Sec61 complex is involved in ribosome- dependent conformational changes of the translocation channel and that it specifically interacts with the signal peptidase during cotranslational translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	241	In this paper, we have studied the role of the  subunit of the Sec61 complex during cotranslational protein translocation into the mammalian ER.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	242	 We have found that the translocation competence of reconstituted proteoliposomes immunodepleted of Sec61 is greatly reduced when tested under conditions in which membrane targeting and translation occur at the same time.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	243	 However, if ribosomes carrying short nascent chains are first targeted to the membrane before translation is continued, i.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	244	, if enough time is given for their membrane insertion, the depleted proteoliposomes are only marginally reduced in their activity.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	245	 These results can be explained by the assumption that elongation of a nascent chain and its insertion into the translocation channel are kinetically competing processes: if the membrane insertion is too slow, elongation of the nascent chain would continue in the cytosol and its folding would prevent a later interaction of the signal sequence with the translocation apparatus.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	246	 We therefore infer that the  subunit is required for a rapid insertion of the ribosome-bound nascent chain into the translocation sites in the ER membrane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The observation that the  subunit is not essential is in agreement with the fact that the deletion of the two  subunits in yeast cells is not lethal and leads to a growth phenotype only at elevated temperatures.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Since microsomes isolated from the mutant had a reduced activity for posttranslational protein transport, these and the present results indicate that the  subunit plays a role in both pathways, but is not absolutely required in either one.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	249	As the cotranslational translocation process is known in much detail, we have been able to analyze the effect of Sec61 depletion on the various steps.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	250	 One of the first steps is the interaction of the ribosome-nascent chain- SRP complex with the SRP receptor in the membrane that leads to the release of the translational arrest exerted by SRP.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	251	 This reaction was not perturbed by the depletion of Sec61, although previous data showed that, for optimal release, both the SRP receptor and the Sec61 complex are required (Gorlich and Rapoport, 1993).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	252	 We therefore conclude that the  subunit is not essential for this activity of the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	253	 The binding of ribosomes to the ER membrane was also not affected by the absence of Sec61.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Both the number of binding sites and the dissociation constant remained unchanged and were almost identical to the values determined for the reconstituted, purified wild-type Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	255	 These results are consistent with the observation that proteolytic degradation of the cytosolic domain of Sec61 in microsomes does not prevent the binding of ribosomes (Kalies et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Taken together, our results indicate that even in the absence of Sec61, efficient release of the SRP arrest and binding of the ribosome-nascent chain complex to the Sec61 complex can occur.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	257	 This conclusion is further supported by the observation that the membrane targeted nascent chains undergo signal peptide cleavage by signal peptidase located in the wrong orientation in the reconstituted membrane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	258	 It therefore appears that a step subsequent to membrane targeting, most likely the step in which the nascent chain is inserted into the Sec61 channel, is perturbed in the absence of the  subunit.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Structural changes in the Sec61 channel, which may be required for its opening (Crowley et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	260	, 1994; Jungnickel and Rapoport, 1995), may occur with a reduced rate.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	261	To further analyze the function of Sec61, we have probed its molecular environment in ER membranes by cross-linking.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	262	 A bifunctional cross-linker was used that reacts specifically with SH groups and therefore can be expected to give a relative simple cross-linking pattern.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	263	 As predicted, in rough microsomes Sec61 was found in close proximity to the  subunit of the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	264	 We also found a cross-linked product consisting of two Sec61 molecules, perhaps explained by the occurrence of oligomers of the trimeric Sec61 complex in microsomes (Hanein et al.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Most interestingly, however, a specific cross-linked product containing SPC25 was observed.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	266	 Conversely, when the cross-linking partners of SPC25 were analyzed, the only partner outside the signal peptidase complex was found to be Sec61.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	267	 Remarkably, 70% of SPC25 could be cross-linked to Sec61.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	268	 We therefore believe that the cross-link between the two proteins indicates their specific interaction.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	269	 These data provide the first evidence that the signal peptidase physically contacts the protein conducting channel in the membrane.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	270	 The cross-linking between Sec61 and SPC25 has likely occurred between their cytosolic domains since the only cysteine in Sec61 is in its NH2 terminus and two appropriately located cysteines exist in the NH2-terminal domain of SPC25 (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	271	 7), previously shown to be cytosolic (Kalies and Hartmann, 1996).
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	272	 SPC25 has almost no amino acid residues in the lumen of the ER where the active site of the signal peptidase resides (Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	273	 7) and its function was therefore obscure.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	274	 On the basis of our data, we propose that it is involved in an interaction with the Sec61 complex to bring the enzyme close to the translocating polypeptide substrate.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	275	 However, sequestration in the translocation site may not be absolutely essential for its function because the signal peptidase complex is very abundant and can probably reach its substrates by mere diffusion in the plane of the membrane, explaining why neither SPC25 nor Sec61 are essential for the viability of yeast cells.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	276	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	277	   Membrane topology of the signal peptidase complex and the Sec61 complex.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	278	 The topologies of all subunits are schematically illustrated.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	279	 The dark boxes indicate hydrophobic segments or membrane spanning segments, respectively.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	280	 SPC22/23 is drawn in the glycosylated form.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	281	 The position of SH-groups is marked by white circles.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	282	Further evidence for our conjecture that Sec61 may be involved in recruiting the signal peptidase complex to the translocation site comes from cross-linking experiments in which ribosome-stripped membranes were used.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	283	 These membranes gave many cross-link-reduced cross-links between Sec61 and SPC25.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	284	 After retargeting of ribosome-nascent chain complexes at almost ribosome-free membranes, the cross-linking between both proteins was increased, suggesting that their interaction is induced when translocation is initiated by ribosome binding.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	285	 The cross-linking between Sec61 and Sec61 was also dependent on the presence of membrane-bound ribosomes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Both effects required the dissociation of the ribosome, and not merely the release of the nascent chain from the ribosome, since they occurred with puromycin at high but not at low salt concentrations.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	287	 The changes in cross-linking pattern upon ribosome removal or retargeting of ribosome-nascent chain complexes could be caused by conformational alterations in an assembled complex or by dissociation of an assembly into subcomplexes.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	288	 In any case, they provide first evidence for structural changes among known components of the translocation apparatus induced by the onset of cotranslational translocation.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	289	Received for publication 11 April 1997 and in revised form 10 February 1998.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	290	   The work was supported by a grant from the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	291	    Address all correspondence to Dr.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Hartmann, Abteilung Biochemie II, Zentrum Biochemie und Molekulare Zellbiologie, Georg-August-Universitat, Gossler Strasse 12 d, 37073 Gottingen, Germany.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	293	    Abbreviations used in this paper.
0.43853024.9585408.html.plaintext.txt	294	BMH, bis-maleimidohexane; PK-RM, puromycin and high salt-treated rough microsomes; RM, rough microsomes; SPC, signal peptidase complex; SPC25, the 25-kD subunit of the signal peptidase complex; SRP, signal recognition particle; TRAM, translocating chain-associating membrane.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	0	Diffusional Mobility of the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator Mutant, F508-CFTR, in the Endoplasmic Reticulum Measured by Photobleaching of GFP-CFTR Chimeras* Peter M.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the  Departments of Medicine and Physiology, Cardiovascular Research Institute, University of California, San Francisco, California 94143-0521 and   Dartmouth Medical School, Hanover, New Hampshire 03755-3835.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, December 25, 2001, and in revised form, February 26, 2002.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	3	The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator protein (CFTR)1 mediates transepithelial chloride transport across epithelial cells in the airways, intestine, pancreas, and sweat gland.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Some mutations in CFTR cause the lethal genetic disease cystic fibrosis, which produces chronic lung infection, progressively impaired pulmonary function, and pancreatic insufficiency.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The most common CFTR mutant, F508-CFTR, is retained at the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and consequently is unable to function as a plasma membrane chloride channel (1).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Electrophysiological studies indicate that the ER-retained F508-CFTR is at least partially functional in excised ER membranes (2).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Further, growth of F508-CFTR-expressing cells under non-physiological conditions (low temperature, Ref.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	8	 3 or with chemical chaperones, Ref.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	9	 4) indicates that under certain conditions F508-CFTR can be transported to the plasma membrane and restore cell chloride permeability.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	10	CFTR biosynthesis is an inefficient process.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Newly synthesized wild type (wt)-CFTR and F508-CFTR are folded into the ER membrane where they become core-glycosylated (5, 6).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Only 20-30% of newly synthesized wt-CFTR is transported to the Golgi where complex glycosylation occurs, with the remaining protein ubiquinated and degraded by the proteasome (7, 8).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Wild type CFTR exists initially in a protease-susceptible form (t1/2 ~30 min) that becomes more stable upon transport from ER to Golgi (t1/2 ~24 h), whereas F508-CFTR is rapidly degraded (t1/2 ~30 min) (5, 6).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Inhibition of proteasome function results in the formation of aggresomes, which are detergent-insoluble, perinuclear protein aggregates common to many degenerative diseases (9-11).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	15	CFTR folding in the ER appears to be facilitated by interactions with the cellular quality control machinery.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Wild type CFTR and F508-CFTR have been shown to interact with the molecular chaperones Hsc70, Hdj2, Hsp70, Hsp90, and calnexin but not with BiP or Grp94 (12-15).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Recent data suggest that the Hsc70 co-chaperone CHIP (C-terminus of Hsc70-interacting protein) targets immature CFTR for proteasome-mediated degradation (16).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Biochemical data indicate that calnexin and Hsp70 bind F508-CFTR more avidly than wt-CFTR (12, 13).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	19	 The differential processing of F508-CFTR and wt-CFTR, however, is probably not accounted for by gross structural differences.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Proteolytic cleavage experiments have suggested that the conformation of F508-CFTR is similar to that of the early, relatively unstable form of wt-CFTR (17).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	21	 In vitro folding studies of the isolated nucleotide binding domain 1 (containing the phenylalanine 508 residue) support the view that the F508 mutation does not affect structure (18, 19) but may affect folding kinetics.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	22	Cell Culture, Plasmids, Transfection, and Treatments-- COS7 (ATCC CRL-1651) and CHO-K1 (ATCC CCL-61) cells (obtained from the University of California, San Francisco Cell Culture Facility) were cultured in DMEH-21 and Ham's F12 media, respectively, supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 100 units/ml penicillin and 100  microg/ml streptomycin at 37  degrees C in a 5% CO2/95% air atmosphere.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Cells were grown on 18-mm diameter glass coverslips in 12-well plates.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Cells were transiently transfected with plasmid DNA using 6  microl of lipofectamine (Invitrogen) and 1  microg of plasmid DNA according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	25	cDNA encoding wt-CFTR was fused downstream of the enhanced GFP (CLONTECH) as described previously, and the F508 mutation was introduced by site-directed mutagenesis (20, 22).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	26	 A glycosylation-null mutant of GFP-wt-CFTR, in which asparagine residues were replaced by glutamines at positions 894 and 900, was also generated by site-directed mutagenesis.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	27	 For GFP expression in the ER lumen, the GFP sequence was flanked by an N-terminal preprolactin leader sequence and a C-terminal KDEL motif (25).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	28	 For GFP expression in the cytoplasm, the coding region of pEGFP (CLONTECH) was ligated into pcDNA3.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	29	Photobleaching experiments were performed 2-3 days after transfection for CFTR-transfected cells and 1-2 days after transfection for cytoplasmic or ER-targeted unconjugated GFP.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	30	 For most experiments GFP-CFTR-transfected cells were treated with brefeldin A (BFA) by 16-24 h of incubation at 5  microg/ml at 37  degrees C in the CO2 incubator.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	31	 For ATP depletion, cells were incubated in phosphate-buffered saline containing 6 mM 2-deoxyglucose and 0.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	32	02% sodium azide at 37  degrees C for 30 min or 1 h.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Geldanamycin (Calbiochem) was used at 0.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	34	1  microg/ml for 90 min (14) and tunicamycin (Calbiochem) at 5  microg/ml for 20 h.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Clasto-lactacystin -lactone (the active form of lactacystin, Sigma) was used at 6  microM for 1.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	36	 In heat shock experiments, cells were incubated at 42  degrees C for 1 h followed by 16-20 h recovery at 37  degrees C.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Paraformaldehyde (for GFP-CFTR immobilization) was used at 4% for 30 min in phosphate-buffered saline at 23  degrees C.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	38	 ER membranes in untransfected cells (subjected to various treatments above) were fluorescently labeled with 3,3'-dibutyloxacarbocyanine iodide (diOC4(3), Molecular Probes) by incubation for 10 min with 10  microM dye in phosphate-buffered saline at 37  degrees C.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	39	 In some experiments transfected cells were identified by their green fluorescence prior to diOC4(3) labeling, and those cells were photobleached.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The relatively small amount of GFP had little effect on the recovery of the much brighter and more rapidly diffusing diOC4(3).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	41	Fluorescence Recovery after Photobleaching-- For spot photobleaching, an argon ion laser beam (488 nm, Innova 70-4, Coherent) was modulated by an acousto-optic modulator and the first-order beam was directed onto cells through an oil immersion (Nikon fluor) objective lens ( x 40, numerical aperture (N.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	42	4) using an inverted epifluorescence microscope.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	43	 To visualize cells and to select cellular regions to be bleached, full-field epi-illumination was accomplished using the expanded zero-order laser beam directed onto the objective lens by a fiber optic.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The beam was reflected onto the objective by a dichroic mirror (510 nm), and emitted fluorescence was filtered by serial 530  plus or minus  15 nm bandpass and 515 nm longpass filters.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Emitted fluorescence was detected by a photomultiplier and digitized by a 14-bit analog-to-digital converter.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The photomultiplier was transiently gated off during the bleach pulse.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Fluorescence was sampled over 200 ms before the bleach pulse, then at rates of up to 1 MHz.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	48	 For measurement of slow recoveries, an electronic shutter was used to collect fluorescence at 1 Hz, averaging 10,000 acquisitions during the shutter open time of 20 ms.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	49	For photobleaching experiments with image detection, a Leitz upright microscope with a cooled CCD camera detector (Photometrics) was used to record full-field epifluorescence images.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	50	 An electronically shuttered bleach beam from the argon laser (488 nm) was directed onto the sample (from below) using a Nikon  x 25 long working-distance air objective.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Cells were viewed (from above) using an oil immersion  x 60 objective (N.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	52	4) and GFP filter set (HQ filters, Chroma).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Software was written (in LabVIEW, National Instruments) to coordinate the bleach pulse, illumination and camera shutters, and image acquisition.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Fluorescence loss in photobleaching (FLIP) experiments were performed using the same apparatus in which repeated laser photobleaching was performed with specified delays between bleach pulses.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	55	All photobleaching experiments were done at 37  degrees C.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Cultured cells were mounted in custom built perfusion chambers designed to fit a PDMI-2 microincubator (Harvard Apparatus) controlled by a TC-201A temperature regulator (Harvard Apparatus).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Objective lens temperature was also maintained at 37  degrees C using a lens thermoregulator (Bioptechs Inc.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	58	 For maneuvers on GFP-CFTR-expressing cells, single recovery curves from 5-12 different cells were averaged to generate a single averaged recovery curve, and this was repeated 4-10 times using different coverslips.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	59	 For cytoplasmic GFP and ER-targeted GFP-expressing cells, each averaged recovery curve was generated from 10 individual recoveries, each from a different cell.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	60	 For diOC4(3) measurements, averaged recovery curves were generated from the average of 5-8 cells.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Results are reported as means  plus or minus  S.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	62	 for the number of different coverslips, and representative averaged recovery curves from single coverslips are shown in figures for the reader to evaluate curve shape and signal-to-noise ratio.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Statistical analysis was performed by analysis of variance against control conditions, and values of p  <  0.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	64	The diffusion of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR in the ER of living cells was determined using GFP as a fluorescent reporter (Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Transfection of COS7 and CHO cells with the GFP-wt-CFTR chimera showed GFP localization to the plasma membrane and intracellular membranes (including Golgi and ER) but exclusively to the ER after BFA treatment (Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The GFP-F508-CFTR chimera was seen in an ER-like pattern without or after BFA treatment (Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Similar patterns of ER staining were observed in COS7 and CHO cells transfected with ER-localized (aqueous phase) GFP or stained with the fluorescent ER lipid probe diOC4(3) (not shown).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	68	View larger version (36K):    Fig.

0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	73	Photobleaching experiments with image detection were done to evaluate the gross mobility of GFP-CFTR chimeras in BFA-treated COS7 (Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	74	 A large region of the cell, ~5  microm in diameter (marked by cross-hairs), was bleached by the laser pulse, and fluorescence recovery was recorded by serial imaging.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	75	 In each case a darkened region is seen immediately postbleach (t = 0 s).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Recovery into this bleached region is diffusive in nature from the edges of the bleach spot inward and appears to be nearly complete.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The kinetics of fluorescence recovery were qualitatively similar for cells expressing wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR and in both cell types.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	78	 In each case the fluorescence recovery was  >  80% complete as determined from the ratio of fluorescence intensity in the bleach spot to the whole cell immediately after versus 4 min after the bleach.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Quantitative spot photobleaching was done in the brighter COS7 cells.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	80	View larger version (78K):    Fig.

0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	84	 All experiments were done at 37  degrees C.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Each image series is one set of experiments representative of 4-8.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	86	 3A shows spot photobleaching of GFP-labeled wt-CFTR (top) and F508-CFTR (bottom) using a  x 60 oil immersion objective to produce a small spot (~1.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	87	2- microm diameter) in which GFP fluorescence was bleached to ~50% of its initial value.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	88	 To distinguish between processes that produce irreversible photobleaching (authentic GFP diffusion) from those that produce reversible photobleaching (from triplet-state relaxation or other photophysical phenomena), fluorescence recovery was measured in fixed cells (Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	89	 3B) and using different spot sizes (Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	90	 As found in prior photobleaching studies (26, 27), the fluorescence recovery remaining after fixation represents reversible (diffusion-independent) photobleaching because fixation abolishes diffusion.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	91	 3B (top curve) shows a small component (5-10%) of reversible photobleaching with ~1-s exponential time constant.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Similar recoveries were found under the same photobleaching conditions for unconjugated GFP in cytoplasm (middle curve) and aqueous phase (unconjugated) GFP in the ER lumen (bottom curve).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	93	 As expected for reversible fluorescence recovery, the recovery rates did not depend on spot size (not shown).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	94	 3C shows that (in unfixed cells) the fluorescence recovery was spot size-dependent as expected for diffusive processes, because the recovery time for a larger spot increases approximately with the square of the spot diameter.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Using a regression procedure to determine (t1/2) for irreversible fluorescence recovery (see "Experimental Procedures"), t1/2 values for GFP-wt-CFTR were 1040  plus or minus  60 ms (100 x ), 3.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	96	2 s (40 x ) (n = 4-10 sets of measurements).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The t1/2 values for GFP-F508-CFTR (in BFA-treated cells) were 1170  plus or minus  120 ms (100 x ), 3.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The relative t1/2 are as expected for a diffusive process.

0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	116	 3D (top) shows the substantially faster fluorescence recovery of soluble GFP in the ER lumen of COS7 cells (t1/2, 60  plus or minus  4 ms; n = 12).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	117	 This value was similar to that measured in CHO-K1 cells under identical conditions (t1/2, 65  plus or minus  4 ms; n = 6, not shown).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	118	 The absolute diffusion coefficient for luminal GFP in COS7 cells was computed using a simple model to correct for ER geometric effects (28) as (6.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	119	5)  x  108 cm2/s, similar to that previously measured in CHO cells (25) and LLC-PK1 cells (27).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	120	 3D (middle) summarizes diffusion coefficients for the GFP-chimeras.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	121	 There was no significant effect of the F508 mutation on CFTR diffusion and/or of BFA treatment on F508-CFTR mobility.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	122	 3D (bottom) summarizes the percentage of mobile GFP, determined from the completeness of the fluorescence recovery at long times.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	123	 GFP-wt-CFTR fluorescence recovered almost completely (92  plus or minus  2%, n = 10), whereas GFP-F508-CFTR recovery in BFA-treated and untreated cells was slightly though significantly smaller (85  plus or minus  2% and 82  plus or minus  1%).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	124	To investigate interactions of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR with elements of the ER quality control machinery, we used a series of maneuvers to modulate molecular chaperone interactions.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	125	 4A shows wt-CFTR mobility after ATP depletion (a maneuver that increases interactions between CFTR and chaperones in the ER), which was produced by 30 min of incubation with 6 mM 2-deoxyglucose and 0.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The diffusion coefficient of GFP-wt-CFTR was similar to control conditions, (10.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	127	9)  x  1010 cm2/s (n = 7), and the percentage recovery was reduced significantly to 80  plus or minus  2%.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The diffusion coefficient of GFP-F508-CFTR was reduced significantly after a 30-min ATP depletion to (6.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	129	 4A, bottom curve), and substantially more GFP-F508-CFTR became immobilized (mobile percentage, 55  plus or minus  5%).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	130	 ATP depletion for 60 min had no further effect.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Table I summarizes averaged diffusion coefficients and percentages of mobile GFP.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	132	 To investigate whether the reduced F508-CFTR mobility in ATP-depleted cells was related to restructuring or fragmentation of the ER, the mobility of the fluorescent ER membrane marker diOC4(3) was measured.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	133	 4B shows that diffusion of diOC4(3) was essentially complete with a diffusion coefficient of (2.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	134	 diOC4(3) diffusion was unaffected by BFA treatment ((2.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	135	1)  x  108 cm2/s, n = 5, middle curve) or ATP depletion ((2.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	136	3)  x  108 cm2/s, n = 4, bottom curve).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Further, photobleaching of transfected cells expressing GFP-labeled wild type CFTR or F508-CFTR and subsequently labeled with diOC4(3) in situ showed that the expression of GFP-CFTR chimeras did not affect ER structure or fluidity (not shown).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Image photobleaching experiments similar to those shown in Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	139	 2 were also performed on diOC4(3)-labeled cells (not shown), and it was demonstrated that ATP depletion did not alter ER continuity or gross structure.

0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	147	                              View this table:    Table I Diffusion coefficients (D) and mobilities of wt- and F508-CFTR Data as mean  plus or minus  S.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	148	 (n = 4-10 sets of measurements, each measurement the average of 5-12 recovery curves from different cells) for indicated maneuvers (see "Experimental Procedures").
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	149	To identify the cellular location of the immobilized GFP-F508-CFTR in ATP-depleted cells, fluorescence loss in photobleaching (FLIP) experiments were performed (Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	150	 A fixed spot in the cell was repetitively bleached with delays between each bleach pulse to permit diffusion of unbleached GFP-labeled CFTR into the location of the bleach spot.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Under these conditions GFP-wt-CFTR freely diffused throughout the ER with ~10% of cell fluorescence remaining after 35 bleach pulses (top).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	152	 In contrast, a substantial amount of fluorescence remained after bleaching of GFP-F508-CFTR in ATP-depleted cells (bottom) with the remaining fluorescence having an ER pattern.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	153	 These findings suggest that ATP depletion does not alter ER continuity or gross structure and that the immobilization of F508-CFTR in ATP-depleted cells results from interactions with ER proteins.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	154	Additional maneuvers were carried out to modulate putative CFTR interactions with molecular chaperones and elements of protein processing and degradation (Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Heat shock, which nonspecifically up-regulates the expression of molecular chaperones, produced small reductions in the diffusion coefficients and percentage mobilities of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR (Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Proteasome inhibition by lactacystin resulted in mild slowing and immobilization of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR after 6 h of incubation (second curves), with complete immobilization after 14 h (third curves).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	157	 GFP was seen in an ER pattern at 6 h but was concentrated in aggresomes at 14 h (not shown).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The ansamysin compound geldanamycin, which disrupts associations with Hsp90, caused comparable slowing of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR with somewhat greater immobilization of F508-CFTR (fourth curves).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Last, the role of glycosylation was investigated by incubation with tunicamycin (to inhibit addition of oligosaccharide chains), using a glycosylation-null mutant of wt-CFTR (asparagines 894 and 900 replaced by glutamines).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Somewhat more immobilization of F508-CFTR than wt-CFTR was found with tunicamycin (fifth curves).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Although the glycosylation-null mutant of wt-CFTR expressed poorly and a substantial proportion of fluorescence was associated with aggresomes, the mobility of ER-associated CFTR could be measured in some cells and was found to be similar to that produced by tunicamycin (sixth curve).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	162	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	163	   Effect of putative modulators of molecular chaperone interactions on the ER mobility of GFP-wt-CFTR and GFP-F508-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Photobleaching experiments were done on cells expressing wt-CFTR (A) and F508-CFTR (B) using a  x 60 objective as in Fig.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Recovery curves are the average of 5-12 individual measurements, each from a single cell.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Maneuvers are described under "Experimental Procedures" and include: heat shock, 1 h of incubation at 42  degrees C followed by 16-20 h of recovery at 37  degrees C; lactacystin, 6  microM for 6 and 14 h; geldanamycin, 0.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	167	1  microg/ml for 90 min; tunicamycin, 5  microg/ml for 20 h; and glycosylation-null mutant of GFP-wt-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	168	 For curves shown, the fitted absolute diffusion coefficient (in cm2/s  x  1010) and percentage recoveries were the following: 9.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	169	2, 83% (heat shock, F508-CFTR); 6.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	170	2, 81% (lactacystin 6 h, wt); 5.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	171	7% (lactacystin 6 h, F508-CFTR); 7.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	172	0, 63% (geldanamycin, F508-CFTR); 6.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	173	2, 61% (tunicamycin, F508-CFTR); 6.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	174	 See Table I for summary of fitted mobilities and diffusion coefficients.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	175	This study has shown that although F508-CFTR is retained in the ER, it diffuses at a comparable rate to wt-CFTR in BFA-treated cells.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Similar observations were made for the T126M mutant of AQP2 (a water channel that is partially misfolded and similarly retained in the ER, Ref.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	177	 27) and for a temperature-sensitive folding mutant of the vesicular stomatitis virus G protein (29).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Therefore, slowed or restricted F508-CFTR mobility in the ER cannot account for its failure to be exported.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Efficient recycling from the Golgi or failure to be recognized by the ER export machinery remain possible explanations for the ER localization of F508-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The observation of small amounts of F508-CFTR in post-ER membranes suggests that efficient recycling may be responsible for the retention of F508-CFTR in the ER (30).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	181	The small immobile pool of F508-CFTR and the substantial immobilization after ATP depletion suggest that a greater fraction of F508-CFTR interacts with molecular chaperones than does wt-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Approximately 50% of F508-CFTR was immobile after ATP depletion, with only minor effects on the mobility of wt-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The simplest interpretation of this finding is that ATP depletion, which stabilizes protein interactions with molecular chaperones, is able to reveal F508-CFTR interactions that are not observable under normal conditions.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	184	 As discussed in the Introduction, F508-CFTR structure is thought to be similar to that of an early intermediate of wt-CFTR, and biochemical evidence supports F508-CFTR associations with molecular chaperones.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	185	Additional maneuvers were performed to investigate specific interactions between wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR and the cellular protein processing machinery.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Inhibition of N-linked glycosylation by tunicamycin resulted in significant slowing and immobilization of both wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR, similar to findings for the VSVG glycoprotein (29).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Similar results were found with a glycosylation-null wt-CFTR mutant, which was poorly expressed in the plasma membrane as determined by biotinylation studies (not shown).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Protein glycosylation can facilitate folding, sorting, and quality control (31).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Our data are thus consistent with a role for glycosylation in CFTR folding.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Proteasome inhibition causes the accumulation of deglycosylated wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR in detergent-insoluble, high molecular weight aggregates (9, 32).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Consistent with the observations here, Bebok et al.
