0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	192	 (32) demonstrated an association between the Sec61 translocation system and CFTR that was enhanced by proteasome inhibition.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	193	 After prolonged (14 h) incubation with lactacystin, wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR were found in aggresomes (9, 10).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Aggresomes are vimentin-enclosed, pericentriolar, electron-dense structures that contain aggregates of misfolded, often ubiquinated proteins associated with molecular chaperones and proteasomes.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	195	 As expected, the GFP-CFTR chimeras were completely immobile in aggresomes.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	196	Inhibition of interaction between Hsp90 and CFTR by geldanamycin also slowed the diffusion of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR, with greater immobilization of F508-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Geldanamycin has been shown to disrupt interactions of Hsp90 and CFTR, increasing the degradation rates of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR (14).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Hsp90 has thus been proposed to have a potential role in protecting CFTR from rapid degradation.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The relative immobilization of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR after geldanamycin treatment supports a role of Hsp90 for CFTR processing.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	200	 As suggested for VSVG by Nehls et al.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	201	 (29), we believe that the physical state of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR after perturbation of CFTR processing by tunicamycin or geldanamycin may be different from that produced by ATP depletion.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The slowing and immobilization of CFTR by ATP depletion may represent CFTR interactions with molecular chaperones existing in large complexes (33), whereas the immobilization after tunicamycin and geldanamycin, or molecular deglycosylation, may represent CFTR self-aggregation.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Because of the logarithmic relationship between molecular radius and diffusion rate for a protein in a bilayer, substantial aggregates (10-100 units) must be formed to significantly slow diffusion.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	204	 The similar responses of wt-CFTR and F508-CFTR to some of the pharmacological maneuvers are consistent with the intrinsically inefficient folding of wt-CFTR, which when compared with P-glycoprotein (another member of the ABC cassette family) is poorly folded.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	205	The diffusion coefficient for CFTR diffusional mobility in the ER, ~10  x  1010 cm2/s, is within the range of other ER membrane proteins that have been studied.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The membrane water channel AQP2 (retained in the ER with BFA) and the ER-retained mutant AQP2-T126M have diffusion coefficients of 2.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Cytochrome P450 2C2, an intrinsic ER protein, has a diffusion coefficient of 5.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	208	 VSVG in its native and misfolded states and two ER resident transmembrane proteins (lamin B receptor and the -subunit of the signal recognition particle receptor) have diffusion coefficients of 26-50  x  1010 cm2/s, depending upon temperature (29).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Two Golgi resident transmembrane proteins (galactosyltransferase and the KDEL receptor) retained in the ER with BFA have diffusion coefficients of 21-48  x  1010 cm2/s, depending upon cell type and temperature (29, 35).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	210	 The diffusion coefficient of the ER-retained MHC class 1 molecule H2Ld is 20-46  x  1010 cm2/s and that of TAP1 (transporter associated with antigen presentation 1) is 12  x  1010 cm2/s (36).
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	211	 The variation in these diffusion coefficients probably reflects different protein sizes, interactions with ER and cytoplasmic proteins, and ER composition in different cells.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	212	We thank Katherin Karlson for assistance with the generation of the glycosylation-null mutant of EGFP-CFTR.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	213	* This study was supported by National Institutes of Health Grants EB00415, DK43840, HL59198, DK35124, EY13574, and HL60288, Research Development Program Grant R613 from the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (to A.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	214	 V), and National Institutes of Health Grants DK45881 and DK34533 and a Research Development Program grant from the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (to B.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	215	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	218	  To whom correspondence should be addressed: 1246 Health Sciences East Tower, Cardiovascular Research Inst.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	219	, University of California, San Francisco, San Francisco, CA 94143-0521.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	220	: 415-476-8530; Fax: 415-665-3847; E-mail: verkman@itsa.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	221	Published, JBC Papers in Press, February 27, 2002, DOI10.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	222	The abbreviations used are: CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; ER, endoplasmic reticulum; GFP, green fluorescent protein; wt, wild type; CHO, Chinese hamster ovary; BFA, brefeldin A; N.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	223	, numerical aperture; VSVG, vesicular stomatitis virus G protein; AQP, aquaporin; diOC4(3), 3,3'-dibutyloxacarbocyanine iodide; FLIP, fluorescence loss in photobleaching.
0.44094175.11877404.html.plaintext.txt	224	Copyright   2002 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	0	Binding of serum response factor to cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator CArG-like elements, as a new potential CFTR transcriptional regulation pathway Celine Rene, Magali Taulan, Florence Iral, Julien Doudement, Aurore L'Honore1,2, Catherine Gerbon, Jacques Demaille3, Mireille Claustres and Marie-Catherine Romey*.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	1	Laboratoire de Genetique Moleculaire et Chromosomique, Institut Universitaire de Recherche Clinique Montpellier, France 1Laboratoire de Proliferation et Differentiation Cellulaire, Institut de Genetique Humaine Montpellier, France 2Laboratoire de Genetique Moleculaire, Institut de Recherches Cliniques de Montreal Quebec, Canada 3Centre de Sequencage Genomique, Institut de Genetique Humaine Montpellier, France.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	2	*To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Tel: +33 4 67 41 53 60; Fax: +33 4 67 41 53 65; Email: Marie-Catherine.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	4	Despite the absence of a TATA element, the transcription of the CFTR gene may be initiated through several discrete start sites (6,7), including those that are tissue-specific (8).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	5	 An intact CCAAT consensus is also required for accurate transcript initiation (9).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Both basal and cAMP-mediated regulation of CFTR transcription involve a weak cAMP response element (CRE) nucleotide consensus (10,11) in tandem with a consensus inverted CCAAT element or Y box (9).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In addition, CFTR transcription may be modulated by additional overlapping cis-acting elements, including a polymorphic YY1 site, located in the human minimal CFTR promoter (12).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	8	 CFTR promoter activity may be enhanced by exogenous transfected NF-B via its binding to the  to 1103 B element (13).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	9	 CFTR expression is also regulated through interactions with factors involved in remodeling of chromatin structure, such as CDP/cut and hGCN5 (14).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	10	Because none of these cis-acting elements confers tissue-specific control of CFTR expression, several studies focused on identifying potential regulatory elements that lie mainly outside the coding region.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Extensive analyses of the chromatin structure identified multiple clusters of DNase I-hypersensitive sites (DHSs) (15,16), some of which contain tissue-specific enhancer elements (17,18).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Multiple binding sites for a tissue-specific transcription factor, called HNF1, recently identified in various DHS core, modulate likewise CFTR expression (19).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Despite extensive studies, the transcriptional regulatory networks of CFTR expression remain to be unraveled.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	14	Our current model for the regulation of human CFTR expression proposes that multiple transcription factors interact with previously reported polymorphic and composite cis-acting elements encompassing a CArG-like motif (12,20).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The CArG box (CC(A/T)6GG), originally defined as the core component of the serum response element (SRE), is found in the 5' region of immediate early response genes, such as c-fos (21), and in many muscle-specific gene promoters (22).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	16	 This DNA element binds serum response factor (SRF), highly regulated and interactive transcription factor, which is phylogenetically conserved and belongs to the MADS box family of proteins, with MCM1, Agamous, Deficiens and SRF (23).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Although SRF is particularly enriched in skeletal, cardiac and smooth muscle lineages (24,25), it is also expressed in a variety of human cell lines from distinct tissue origins (26), and, to a lesser extent, in ectoderm-derived tissue such as gastric epithelium (27).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Interestingly, it has been shown that Drosophila SRF homolog is expressed in a subset of tracheal cells and regulates cytoplasmic outgrowth during terminal branching of the tracheal system (28).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Hence, it has been suggested that SRF plays an essential role in the formation of the respiratory system.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Moreover, it has been recently shown that SRF is involved in myofibroblast differentiation during lung damage (29).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Therefore, we hypothesized that trans-acting factors interacting with CArG-like motif, such as SRF, could be important in CFTR expression regulation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	22	 We provided evidence that SRF is expressed in bronchial epithelial cell expressing endogenous CFTR protein.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Through the use of combined gel mobility shift to chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assays, we first demonstrated that SRF protein binds, both in vitro and in vivo, the CFTR minimal promoter region spanning the CArG-like motif.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Mutagenic studies and transient co-transfections experiments showed that SRF alone is not sufficient to transactivate the CFTR gene.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Upon some mutations of the CFTR-CArG-like element, promoter activity is severely decreased, potentially implying YY1 as a co-repressor.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Given the YY1 well-defined role in the transcriptional regulation of some SRE-dependent promoters (30 to 33), we explored the putative role of YY1 on the CFTR promoter activity and demonstrated functional interplay between this factor and SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Finally, by stringent in silico structural analysis, we identified additional multiple near consensus CArG sites within the highly conserved promoter and intronic regions of the CFTR gene.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	28	 We also documented the existence of SRF-containing protein complexes on numerous predicted CFTR CArG-like elements.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Taken together, the data obtained classify CFTR as a novel SRF target gene, subject to modest but significant SRF activation, and open the gate to further investigate how SRF may be involved in the regulation of CFTR gene expression.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	30	Plasmids constructs The original luciferase expression vector pGL3-Basic containing the wild-type human CFTR minimal promoter was described previously (12).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	31	 To further study the putative composite cis-acting element located at  to 108 from the major transcription initiation site of the human CFTR promoter (38), the CFTR-CArG-like motif was either mutated in a consensus CArG box or in a degenerated motif.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Mutations were introduced into the WT-pGL3 plasmid using an oligonucleotide-directed mutagenesis system (QuickChangeTMSite-Directed Mutagenesis Kit, Stratagene) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Mutagenesis primers are depicted in Table 1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The presence of mutations and sequence fidelity were verified by dideoxynucleotide sequencing.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	35	 For each introduced mutation the loss or the improvement of transcription factor binding activity was checked by in vitro assays.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The 3xSRE-fos TATA-luciferase reporter construct was kindly provided by R.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Hipskind, Institut de Genetique Moleculaire, Montpellier, France.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Expression vectors encoding either human wild-type SRF, the pHiv-SRF or SRF dominant-negative form deleted of an essential part of DNA-binding domain (DBD), the pHiv-DN, were generously given by D.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Trouche, Laboratoire de Biologie Moleculaire Eucaryote, Toulouse, France.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Another dominant-negative SRF mutant, pHiv-DBD, was constructed by PCR amplification of SRF fragment spanning the DBD flanked by HindIII and HincII sites to facilitate cloning into expression vector.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The PCR was performed using pHiv-DBD-SRF primers (listed in Table 1), 10 ng of SRF expression vector, 200  microM of each dNTP, 0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	42	5 U Taq DNA polymerase (Perkin Elmer, Inc.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	43	) in a 1x reaction buffer provided by the manufacturer.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	44	 TranSilent human control siRNA vector and TranSilentTM human SRF siRNA vector (catalog no.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	45	 SR1038) were purchased from Panomics.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Expression vectors encoding either pCMV-YY1 or pcDNA3-YY1 were generously provided by E.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	47	View this table:    Table 1 Sequences of oligonucleotides.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	48	  Transient transfections Cells were seeded at a density of 200 000 cells/2 ml of medium and plated in 6-well dishes (NUNClone , Merck-Eurolab, Inc.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	49	 After a culturing period of 24 h, cells were transfected with PolyFect  transfection reagent (Qiagen Corporation, France) according to the manufacturer's recommendations.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	50	 For transient transfection, we used 1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	51	8  microg of plasmid reporter and 0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	52	2  microg of internal control pRL-SV40 containing Renilla luciferase (Promega Corporation).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The pGL3-Basic vector lacking both eukaryotic promoter and enhancer sequences was used as a negative control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	54	 After 48 h, the luciferase activity was evaluated with the Dual Luciferase Reporter Assay System (Promega Corporation), as described previously (12).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Luminescence measurements were performed on a Luminoskan Ascent luminometer (ThermoLabsystem Corporation, France).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Firefly luciferase activity was normalized to Renilla luciferase activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	57	 All luciferase activities represent at least three independent experiments with each construct tested in triplicate per experiment.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Luciferase activity data are expressed as the means  plus or minus  SD computed from the results obtained from each set of transfection experiments.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	59	 To minimize the possibility of errors in DNA amplification, at least two independently constructed clones were tested.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	60	 For co-transfection assays, unless otherwise indicated, 1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	61	8  microgof luciferase reporter and 1 to 2  microg of each expression vector were used.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Transfection with siRNA was performed using Lipofectamine 2000 (Invitrogen) with 2.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The cells were transfected with CFTR promoter plasmid reporter, and luciferase activity was determined as described above.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Aliquots of cell lysates were used for western blotting to confirm the specificity and level of SRF protein knockdown.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	65	Preparation of whole cell proteins, nuclear extracts and recombinant protein production For the CFTR immunodetection analyses, Beas2B, A549, C2C12, COS-7 and Caco-2 cells were treated with 5 mM sodium phenylbutyrate, which has been previously reported to increase CFTR (39) and scraped into lysis buffer (50 mM Tris to HCl, 1% NP-40, 40 mM beta-glycerophosphate and 120 mM NaCl) supplemented with protease inhibitors [1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride (PMSF), 1 mM DTT, and 1  microg/ microl aprotinin, leupeptin and pepstatin].
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Nuclear extracts were prepared using the Nuclear extraction kit according to the procedure recommended by the supplier (Panomics, Ozyme, France).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Protein concentrations were determined using the Bio-Rad Protein Assay kit with BSA as a standard, based on the classical Bradford method.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The pGEX-SRF plasmid, a generous gift from D.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Trouche (Laboratoire de Biologie Moleculaire Eucaryote), was used for protein expression.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	70	 GST to SRF fusion protein was purified from Escherichia coli as described previously (40).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The purity and concentration of protein samples were estimated by SDS to PAGE.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	72	Electrophoretic mobility shift assay (EMSA) and supershifts Oligonucleotides probes were synthesized corresponding to CFTR CArG-like element and mutant versions in which the CArG motif was either mutated in a consensus box or disrupted.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The oligonucleotide sequences were listed in Table 2.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Single-stranded complementary oligonucleotides containing the studied sequences were annealed, end-labeled with [-32P]ATP (5000 Ci/mmol) and purified as described previously (12).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Mobility assay conditions were specifically optimized for binding of SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The binding reaction was carried out in a total volume of 20  microl containing 2 ng (30 000 c.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	77	) of the labeled probe, 10  microl of binding buffer (2x), 0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	78	25  microg poly(dI to dC) (Amersham Pharmacia) used as a non-specific competitor, 5 to 12  microg of nuclear extracts and 100 to 1000 ng of GST to SRF fusion chimera protein.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	79	 For EMSA competition and antibody interference assays, proteins were incubated with either cold specific competitors (WT and SRE oligonucleotides, see Table 2), unspecific competitor (GATA oligonucleotide, see Table 2) or purified antibodies (anti-SRF: sc-335X; anti-YY1: sc-1703X or anti-HA, Santa Cruz, Biotechnology Inc.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	80	, TEBU, France) for 20 min before addition of labeled probes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	81	 After incubation of 30 min at room temperature, complexes were resolved on 5% acrylamide:bisacrylamide (29:1) native gel containing 0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	82	View this table:    Table 2 Ologonuc leotides used in EMSA analysis.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	83	  Formaldehyde cross-linking and chromatin immunoprecipitation Beas2B and A549 cells proteins were cross-linked to DNA by adding formaldehyde to a final concentration of 1% for 10 min at 37 degrees C.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The fixed cells were prepared for immunoprecipitation using the protocol of ChIP assay kit (Upstate Biotechnology Inc.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	85	, Euromedex, France) with minor modifications.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Cells were resuspended in 1 ml cold phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), pelleted by centrifugation and lysed in 800  microl of SDS lysis buffer (1% SDS, 10 mM EDTA, 50 mM Tris to HCl, pH 8.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	87	1) containing protease inhibitors (1 mM PMSF, 1  microg/mlaprotinin and 1  microg/ml pepstatinA).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	88	 After incubation on ice for 10 min, the cross-linked chromatin was sheared by sonication at the following conditions eight times for 10 s at 40% of maximum power and diluted 10-fold in ChIP dilution buffer (0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	89	1 and 167 mM NaCl) with protease inhibitors.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Aliquots containing 20  microl of each aliquot were used as a control to show total input DNA.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The chromatin solution was precleared with 80  microl of salmon sperm DNA/protein A agarose-50% slurry (Upstate Biotechnology Inc.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	92	) for 1 h at 4 degrees C under agitation, and subsequently incubated at 4 degrees C on a rotating stand overnight with either 3  microl of anti-SRF antibody (sc-335X, Santa Cruz, Biotechnology Inc.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	93	) or an irrelevant antibody (anti-HA).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Immune complexes were precipitated by the addition of 60  microl of salmon sperm DNA/protein A agarose and incubated at 4 degrees C for 1 h and low speed spinning.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Precipitates were washed once with 1 ml of low salt buffer, once with high salt buffer, once with LiCl buffer and twice with 1x TE, according to the manufacturer's recommendations (Upstate Biotechnology Inc.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The cross-links were reversed by the addition of 20  microl of 5 M NaCl and incubation at 65 degrees C overnight.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The samples were treated with proteinase K, phenol to chloroform extracted, ethanol precipitated and resuspended in 30  microl of sterile water.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	98	 PCR analysis was carried out using primers from different regions of the human CFTR promoter and as additional controls from promoter regions of a number of genes that are either silent (ss-globin) or having at least one functional CArG element (ss-actin).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The sequences of PCR primers are listed in Table 1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	100	 After 45 cycles of amplification, PCR products were separated on 1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	101	8% agarose gels and visualized by ethidium bromide staining and UV transillumination.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	102	Reverse transcriptase to PCR Total RNA from epithelial cells (Beas2B and A549), myoblasts (C2C12) and fibroblasts (COS-7) was isolated using the SV Total RNA Isolation System  (Promega, France).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Reverse transcription was performed with 3  microg of total RNA, 300 ng of random hexamers (Invitrogen Corporation), 10 mM dNTPs, 1  microl of RNasin RNase inhibitor (Promega), 2  microl of DTT at 0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	104	1 M, 4  microl of first strand buffer (Invitrogen), 200 U of M-MLV RT (Invitrogen) and nuclease-free water (Promega) in a final reaction volume of 20  microl.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	105	 For each RNA template, a control reaction without RT was included.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	106	 For each RT reaction condition, an H2O no-template reaction was included as an additional negative control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The reaction mixture was incubated first for 10 min at 25 degrees C, then 40 min at 42 degrees C; this was followed by a heat inactivation step of 72 degrees C for 3 min.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Aliquots containing 1  microl of the cDNA synthesis reaction mixture were used for PCR analyses.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The expression level of SRF mRNA was analyzed by PCR amplification of the endogenous Hypoxanthine PhosphoRybosyl-Transferase (HPRT) gene used as internal control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Amplification mixture included either 10 pmol of each SRF-specific primer or 10 pmol of each HPRT-specific primer, 1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	111	5 U of AmpliTaq polymerase (Applied Biosystem Corporation) and nuclease-free water (Promega) in a 25  microl volume.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Amplification was performed with an initial denaturation step at 95 degrees C for 5 min, followed by 35 cycles of 30 s of 95 degrees C denaturation, 60 s of 52 degrees C annealing and 2 min extension at 72 degrees C.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Amplification of CFTR was performed as described previously (41).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The RT to PCR products were separated on an 8% non-denaturing polyacrylamide gel, stained with ethidium bromide.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	115	 To ensure that the sequence of cDNA products derived from both SRF and CFTR RT to PCR analyses correspond to respective published sequences, the cDNA bands were purified and prepared for dideoxy DNA sequencing.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Controls included RNA preparations from monkey kidney fibroblasts (COS-7), which are negative for CFTR expression (36,37).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	117	Western blot analysis Twenty-five microgram protein extracts (except where otherwise indicated) were resolved on a 10% (except where otherwise indicated) SDS to polyacrylamide gel and transferred onto a nitrocellulose membrane (except where otherwise indicated).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	118	 All membranes were Ponceau S stained to ensure sample integrity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Briefly, the membranes were blocked with 5% skim milk in PBS supplemented with 0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	120	01% Tween-20 and incubated with diluted primary antibodies in 5% skim milk (1:5000 diluted anti-SRF Abs: sc-335X and sc-25290X purchased from Santa Cruz; 1:1000 diluted anti-CFTR Ab: 24.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	121	1 from R and D System; 1:2500 diluted anti-ss-actin antibody: AC-15 from Sigma, 1:2500 diluted anti-ss-tubulin antibody: T6074 from Sigma) overnight.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The membranes were then washed and incubated with an appropriate horseradish peroxidase (HRP) conjugated secondary antibody at 1:15 000 in PBS-5% milk.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The membranes were reacted with chemiluminescence reagent ECL (Roche Diagnostic) as described by the manufacturer and subsequently exposed to Biomax photographic film (Kodak Corporation).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	124	 The protein levels of the actin housekeeping gene (except where otherwise stated) were assayed for internal control of protein loading.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	125	Indirect immunofluorescence A549, Beas2B, C2C12 and COS-7 cells were plated on Lab-TekTMII CC2TM Chamber SlideTM systems (Nalge Nunc) 1 day before immunohistochemical analysis.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	126	 The cells were fixed and permeabilized in 4% paraformaldehyde and 0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	127	1% Triton X-100, respectively, for 20 min durations at room temperature.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Non-specific binding sites were blocked with 1% BSA in PBS for 1 h.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	129	 The cells were subsequently incubated with primary antibodies diluted in 1:100 in PBS to BSA.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Antibodies used included, the clone L12B4 (Upstate biotechnology), an anti-CFTR antibody known to recognize human, rat, mouse and bovine CFTRs (42) and the H-300 or the A11 anti-SRF antibody (sc-13029 and sc-25290, Santa Cruz).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The specificity of the anti-CFTR antibody has been described previously (43,44) and was also verified by using a CFTR-positive human Caco-2 cell line (34,35).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	132	 For nuclear counterstaining, DAPI (sc-3598, Santa Cruz) was applied at a concentration of 1:5000.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Cells were then washed with PBS to BSA and incubated with either donkey anti-rabbit fluorescein isothiocyanate-conjugated (FITC) or donkey anti-mouse Cy3TM conjugated secondary antibody (Jackson ImmunoResearch Laboratory Inc.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	134	) diluted 1:200 for 1 h at room temperature.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Cells were washed twice with PBS to BSA, once with PBS, and mounted with Dakocytomation fluorescent mounting medium (Dakocytomation).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Indirect immunofluorescence was examined with an inverted Leica DMR microscope (Leica Microsystemes SAS).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Final images were further processed using Adobe Photoshop 7.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	138	Statistical analyses Transfection data are expressed as the mean  plus or minus  SE.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Paired comparisons were made using student's t-test.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Data were considered statistically significant at P  <  0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	141	 All graphical data and statistical analyses were generated with GraphPAD Prism software (Version 3.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Densitometric analysis was performed using computerized densitometry and ImageQuantTL v.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	143	0 software (Amersham Biosciences).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Densitometric values for both transcript and protein bands were determined in areas of equal size and are reported in normalized arbitrary units relatives to the expression of either HPRT gene or actin protein set to 1 (except where otherwise indicated).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	145	Computational analyses The computer program ConSite (http://www.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	146	org/), particularly suited to the analysis of large genomic sequences, was used to identify putative CArG binding sites within the promoter and intronic regions of the human CFTR gene.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	147	com/) was then used to verify these predictions and minimize false negatives or positives.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	148	 To prevent a possible bias introduced by palindromic or internally repetitive cis-regulatory elements, overlapping matches, including on opposite DNA strands, were defined as a single match.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	149	To assess the importance of the putative CArG elements identified in the non-coding regions of the human CFTR gene, we performed multiple sequence alignments.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	150	 The human, cynomolgus, gibbon, squirrel monkey, rabbit, pig, sheep and cow sequences were aligned using the ClustalW global alignment tool (http://clustalw.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	151	 The gap open and extension penalties were set at 15 and 6.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	152	66, respectively, and sequence delay divergence of 30% with a DNA transition weight of 0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	153	View larger version (29K):    Figure 1 Cross-species comparison of the CFTR-CArG-like element.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	154	 (A) Visualization of consensus CArG binding site: pop-up window containing information about SRF transcription factor obtained from in silico analysis performed with the ConSite tool.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	155	 (B) Detailed alignment view of the CArG-like element-including region of human CFTR minimal promoter with seven orthologous sequences: Cynomolgus, Gibbon, Squirrel Monkey, Rabbit, Pig, Sheep and Cow.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Dashes indicate gaps that were introduced to maximize alignment.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Each sequence is represented by a classical text representation with each nucleotide assigned its own color (A is colored in red, C in blue, G in green and T in black).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	158	 The numberings above the Cynomolgus sequence are indicated according to the major human transcription initiation site.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	159	 In the left panel, the phylogenetic relationships between the different species are illustrated in a rooted tree, directly derived from ClustalW program.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	160	 In the right panel, human/species homologies are indicated.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	161	 The accession number of each CFTR genomic sequence is indicated below each species name, in brackets and bold characters.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	162	 The human CFTR-CArG-like motif is noted above the Cynomolgus sequence.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	163	  To assess the putative functional importance of CFTR-CArG-like binding site, we used an orthogonal approach of deducing regulatory elements by considering orthologous CFTR minimal promoter regions from several mammalian species representing the Primates, Artiodactylia and Lagomorpha orders.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Comparison of human/species homologies was carried out using ClustalW multiple CFTR sequence alignments according to the numerous alignment parameters described previously (49).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Consistent with previous studies (50,51), we showed that the human minimal CFTR promoter is remarkably conserved across the orders studied (Figure 1B, right panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	166	 We found that the CFTR-CArG-like element is conserved within all the Primates species studied and also within the pig while, within the sheep, cow and rabbit species, some substitutions occur in the middle of the CArG-like motif (Figure 1B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	167	 These data are consistent with previous CFTR promoter phylogenetic work that identified two types of regulatory elements: some are conserved between species, such as a non-consensus CRE at positions  to 0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	168	1 kb relative to ATG and some are species-specific elements, such as a 300 bp purine.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	169	Py) stretch that is present only in rodents (50).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	170	Bronchial epithelial expression of SRF Because we could not previously identify SRF binding to the CFTR CArG-like element, even though an anti-SRF antibody had been used (12), we asked whether SRF, mainly described as highly expressed in muscle cells, was also present in epithelial cell lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	171	 To measure the expression levels of SRF mRNAs, we used a RT to PCR-based procedure previously described by Davis et al.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	172	 As reverse-transcribed control, the Hypoxanthine PhosphoRybosyl-Transferase (HPRT) housekeeping gene was amplified.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Amplification of SRF from bronchial epithelial cells and myoblasts yielded a fragment of the same size, 651 bp (Figure 2A), as that of the full-length SRF transcript produced by RT to PCR from human hearts (52).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	174	 The 453 bp band corresponding to SRF lacking exon 5 (SRF5) was only detected in the C2C12 myoblast line (Figure 2A).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	175	 To ensure that these bands were not the result of a PCR artifact or genomic contamination of samples, negative controls such as exclusion of RT or RNA during cDNA synthesis were included in each assay.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	176	 As expected, no PCR product appeared when either RT or the template was omitted (Figure 2A).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Densitometric analysis revealed that bronchial epithelial cells contained an appreciable amount of SRF mRNA.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Nuclear extracts from A549, Beas2B and C2C12 cells were electrophoresed and then assayed by western blotting with anti-SRF antibody reported to recognize all four isoforms of the protein (52).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	179	 As shown in Figure 2B, we found that robust expression of a 67 kDa band, that based on molecular mass, corresponds to full-length SRF (SRF-FL) in all of the cell lines examined.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Consistent wit RT to PCR analysis, a 57 kDa band corresponding to SRF5 was only detected in the C2C12 myoblast line.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	181	 As a control, we checked the ss-actin levels (Figure 2B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Densitometric analysis of western blot revealed no apparent difference in the expression level of SRF proteins between the myoblasts and epithelial cells (Figure 2B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	183	 In subsequent western blot analyses in which parallel blots were probed with only the secondary antibody, no band was detected (data not shown), thus confirming that these bands are indeed specific for SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	184	 As further evidence, A549, Beas2B and C2C12 cells express relatively large amounts of SRF, the cell lines were assessed by indirect immunofluorescence labeling.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	185	 A similar staining pattern was noted in the bronchial epithelial cells and myoblasts (Figure 2C, rows A to C).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	186	 The nuclei have been stained blue with DAPI.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	187	 As negative control, no staining was detected when the primary antibody was omitted (Figure 2C, row D).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Consistent with other studies reporting that SRF is ubiquitously expressed in a variety of cell types (26,27,53), our SRF expression studies demonstrated that human SRF gene is expressed in bronchial epithelial cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	189	View larger version (25K):    Figure 2 Bronchial epithelial expression of SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	190	 (A) Detection of SRF and HPRT transcripts from both bronchial epithelial and myoblast cell lines by RT to PCR analysis.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Total RNAs isolated from A549, Beas2B and C2C12 cells, as indicated, were reverse transcribed with random hexamers and PCR amplified with SRF or HPRT primers.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Amplified products were directly stained with bromide ethidium on non-denaturing polyacrylamide gel.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Expected size of PCR products is given at left of each transcript.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Negative controls are noted as follow: No RT for the absence of reverse transcriptase and No RNA for an H2O no-template reaction.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Densitometric analysis of SRF bands intensity was performed with relative HPRT mRNA expression in C2C12 myoblasts.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	196	 (B) Western blot analysis of nuclear extracts prepared from both epithelial and myoblast lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Each extract (25  microg) was separated by SDS/PAGE (10%) and western blotted using an anti-SRF Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Relative mass, in kilodaltons, is indicated alongside.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	199	 As a control for proteins loading in SDS to PAGE, an anti ss-actin Ab was used in western blot.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Numbers below the ss-actin panel indicate densitometric values of the total SRF bands normalized over the corresponding ss-actin bands and expressed relative to the C2C12 controls bands, which are set to 1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	201	 (C) The A549, Beas2B and C2C12 cells (rows A, B and C, respectively) were grown on coverslips, fixed and subjected to indirect immunofluorescence with anti-SRF Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Left panel, cells were stained with FITC-conjugated secondary antibody (green).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Middle panel, cells were counterstained with DAPI (blue) for nuclear staining.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Right panel, shown is merge of SRF immunostaining and DAPI.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Row D, background immunofluorescence obtained in the absence of the primary antibody.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	206	  SRF binds the CFTR-CArG-like element Because the CArG box is not only found in the regulatory regions of many muscle-specific genes but also located at the center of other SREs (54) and forms the core binding site for SRF (55), we have attempted to determine whether or not SRF binds to the CFTR-CArG-like element sequence.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	207	 We performed two series of bandshift experiments.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	208	 First, we incubated the 32P-labelLed WT oligonucleotide corresponding to CFTR-CArG-like element sequence (as indicated in Table 2) with bacterially expressed SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	209	 As shown in Figure 3A (lane 3), EMSA revealed a recombinant SRF to WT duplex.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	210	 As shown in Figure 3A (lane 5), bands defined as the CFTR-CArG-like-SRF complex disappeared when 100-fold molar excess of specific competitor containing the consensus SRE motif, derived from human c-fos promoter (56), was added.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	211	 In contrast, competition by an irrelevant oligonucleotide (noted UC) did not appear to significantly alter the complex suggesting specificity of binding (lane 6).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	212	 To confirm precisely the identity of protein binding in the minimal CFTR promoter (from  to 121 to  to 83 bp), bacterially expressed SRF was preincubated with anti-SRF antibody before incubation with 32P-labelled probe.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	213	 As shown in Figure 3A (lane 4), bands corresponding to CFTR-CArG-like-SRF complex disappeared, and more slowly migrating bands appeared when anti-SRF antibody was added.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	214	 To verify the antibody specificity, control experiments were performed either in the absence of the SRF protein (Figure 3A, lane 7) or in the presence of an irrelevant antibody (Figure 3A, lane 8).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	215	 These results demonstrate that the CFTR-CArG-like element is a bona fide SRF-binding site.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Second, we performed additional EMSA with the WT oligonucleotide, as main binding target, and nuclear extracts from both epithelial and muscle cells (Figure 3B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	217	 While three nucleoprotein complexes were formed from nuclear extracts of Beas2B and C2C12 cells on the WT probe, five complexes were detected from A549 cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Each nuclear protein complex was designated by an upper case relative to nuclear lysate followed by a Roman numeral indicating its position into the gels.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	219	 The binding specificity of the different complexes was examined by competition analyses with both specific and non-specific unlabeled oligonucleotides (Figure 3B, lanes 2 to 4).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Although a few non-specific binding activities were observed, complexes BII, BIII, AIII, AV, CI, CII and CIII were efficiently competed with an excess of both WT and c-fos SRE unlabeled specific competitors indicating binding specificity (Figure 3B, lanes 2 and 3, respectively).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Control experiments including an irrelevant oligonucleotide did not reveal any change in electrophoretic profiles (Figure 3B, lanes 4).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	222	 To evaluate whether the SRF protein contributes to the formation of nucleoprotein complexes interacting with the CFTR-derived SRF site, we used a specific antibody against the SRF protein.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Although the incubation with the anti-SRF antibody apparently failed to give any discrete supershift from various sources of nuclear proteins, a significant decrease of specific complexes was observed (Figure 3B, lanes 6).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	224	 This effect seemed to be specific because none of these nuclear protein complexes was supershifted or abolished when a non-specific antibody was used (Figure 3B, lanes 7).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Control experiments containing only the anti-SRF antiserum and the radiolabeled WT oligonucleotide did not reveal any binding activities (Figure 3B, lanes 8).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	226	 In addition, supershift assays performed with the radiolabeled c-fos SRE oligonucleotide instead of the WT probe showed that bands corresponding to SRE to SRF complex disappeared and more slowly migrating bands appeared (Figure 3B, lane 10).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	227	 The absence of supershift for specific WT binding complexes (Figure 3D, lanes 6) may be explained if the epitope recognized by the anti-SRF antibody is part of (or located near) the CFTR-CArG-like DNA-binding site.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Antibody binding would compete DNA binding, resulting in a significant decrease or total disappearance of CArG-like complexes rather than in supershifted complexes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Alternatively, if the interaction between the CFTR-CArG-like DNA-binding site and the SRF protein is insufficiently strong, it could be not as stable as the one observed with the SRE probe (Figure 3B, lane 10) to be detected as a supershift in gel retardation assays.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	230	 On the one hand, other DNA-binding proteins that are potentially part of this complex could interfere with the antibody's access to SRF protein.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	231	 Taken together, these EMSA studies establish SRF-binding CArG-like box within the minimal promoter of the human CFTR gene.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	232	View larger version (36K):    Figure 3 SRF is a component of CFTR-CArG-like binding complexes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	233	 (A) EMSAs were performed with a radiolabeled oligonucleotide encompassing the studied CFTR-CArG-like motif (noted WT, see Table 2) and bacterially expressed SRF (lane 3).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Competition assays were carried out using a 100-fold molar excess of two specific competitors, noted WT and SRE (lanes 2 and 5, respectively).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	235	 UC (lane 6) indicates unspecific competitor that is used as negative control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Supershift assays were carried out using either a specific antibody (lane 4) or an irrelevant antibody (lane 8).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	237	 The arrow SS indicates the Ab-supershifted complex.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	238	 Neither the retarded nor the supershifted complexes were found when the 32P-labeled WT double-stranded oligonucleotide was incubated either only with the binding buffer (lane 1) or with specific anti-SRF antibody in the absence of purified SRF protein (lane 7).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	239	 (B) EMSAs were performed with WT 32P-labeled probe in the absence of proteins (lanes 1) or with nuclear extracts (lanes 5) isolated from Beas2B (upper panel), A549 (middle panel) and C2C12 cells (lower panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Three or five nuclear protein complexes were detected and designated by a cell type-dependent upper-case to the left of autoradiograms.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Some binding reaction mixtures included a 100-fold molar excess of the indicated cold probes (lanes 2 to 4).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Immunologic assays were performed with either anti-SRF Ab (lanes 6), or anti-HA as irrelevant antiserum (lanes 7).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	243	 As a control, the 32P-labeled WT probe was incubated with anti-SRF Ab without nuclear extracts (lanes 8).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	244	 In additional control experiments, radiolabeled SRE double-stranded oligonucleotide corresponding to the SRE binding site of the c-fos promoter was subjected to EMSAs with nuclear extracts from Beas2B cells (upper panel) in the absence (lane 9) or presence of anti-SRF antiserum (lane 10).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Nuclear protein complexes that were significantly decreased or supershifted with anti-SRF Ab are indicated.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	246	  SRF binds the CArG-like motif of the CFTR minimal promoter within intact chromatin under physiological conditions Although there is extensive evidence that SRF can bind to CArG-like elements in in vitro assays and that it is involved in transcriptional regulation through CArG elements in reporter assays in cultured cells with a typical epithelioid morphology (53), there is a lack of direct evidence for involvement of SRF in transcription of the endogenous CFTR gene within the context of intact chromatin.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	247	 To directly address whether SRF also binds in vivo, ChIP was carried out in bronchial epithelial cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	248	 For this purpose, DNA-binding proteins of Beas2B epithelial cells were covalently linked to genomic DNA by treatment of the cells with formaldehyde.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Cross-linked chromatin was immunoprecipitated with either specific or irrelevant antibodies, anti-SRF and anti-HA, respectively.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	250	 The precipitated chromatin DNA was then purified and amplified by PCR with specific primers of the target sequences (Table 1).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	251	 The promoter of ss-globin gene, which lacks CArG elements, was used as negative control (Figure 4, row A).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	252	 The skeletal ss-actin promoter sequence, which contains at least a consensus SRF-binding site, was used as positive control (Figure 4, row B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	253	 As expected, PCR signals were obtained when the DNA/protein adducts were immunoprecipitated with an anti-SRF antibody from both Beas2B (Figure 4, rows B and C, lane 1) and A549 (data not shown) epithelial cell lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	254	 In contrast, the negative controls, in which immunoprecipitation was performed with an irrelevant antibody (Figure 4, rows A to C, lane 3) or without antibody (Figure 4, rows A to C, lane 2), did not show any PCR signal.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	255	 These results were reproduced in several independently isolated ChIP populations.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	256	 These data show that the CFTR-CArG-like binding site identified within the CFTR minimal promoter binds SRF in vivo, in bronchial cell lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	257	View larger version (14K):    Figure 4 ChIP analysis of SRF binding to the endogenous CFTR minimal promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Chromatin immunoprecipitation was carried out as described in Materials and Methods.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Sheared DNA/protein complexes were immunoprecipitated by using either an anti-SRF Ab or an irrelevant anti-HA Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	260	 Then, PCR was carried out to detect the endogenous CArG regions in immunoprecipitated chromatin fragments.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Target promoter sequences are indicated as follow: row A, ss-globin; row B, ss-actin; row C, CFTR.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Lane 1 shows amplification of target sequences in immunoprecipitated chromatin fragments with anti-SRF Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Lanes 2 and 3: PCR amplification of control samples, without Ab or with an irrelevant Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Lane 4 shows amplification of 1:100 dilution samples of total input DNA for immunoprecipitation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	265	  The human minimal CFTR promoter shows activity in both epithelial and muscular cells As the SRF transcription factor is thought to mainly mediate the tissue-specific transcription in muscular cells, we first assessed the activity of the minimal CFTR promoter in both epithelial and muscular cell types.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	266	 We therefore addressed the ability of the WT-pGL3 construct, previously described (12) to drive the expression in Beas2B, A549 and C2C12 cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	267	 As shown in Figure 5A, an efficient transcription of the CFTR promoter could be readily observed in all three cell lines compared with monkey kidney fibroblasts (COS-7), which are negative for CFTR expression (36,37).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	268	 Surprisingly, the activity of the minimal CFTR promoter in C2C12 cells was 4 to 5.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	269	5 times higher than that observed in Beas2B and A549 cells, respectively.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	270	 Although the expression of the CFTR protein was previously evidenced in some muscle cells (57 to 59), it has never been investigated in mouse C2C12 myoblasts.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Therefore, we investigated the CFTR expression at both mRNA and protein levels.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	272	 To examine CFTR mRNA expression in mouse myoblasts (C2C12), total RNA isolated from epithelial and non-epithelial cells was analyzed via RT to PCR with CFTR-specific primers (Table 1).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	273	 As shown in Figure 5B, while no PCR product for CFTR was seen with COS-7 cells, the expected CFTR amplified product was obtained for both epithelial (A549 and Beas2B) and muscular (C2C12) cell lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	274	 No product was detected in the absence of reverse transcriptase or RNA (noted No RT or No RNA, respectively).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Although the HPRT PCR control showed non-equivalent amounts of cDNA used in the different PCRs, densitometric analysis revealed that C2C12 cells contained an appreciable amount of CFTR mRNA.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Further determination of CFTR expression in C2C12 myoblasts was conducted by western blot analysis (Figure 5C).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Caco-2 cells were used as positive control and COS-7 as negative control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	278	 As shown in Figure 5C, while mature fully glycosylated band C CFTR was observed in A549, Beas2B and C2C12 cells, the core glycosylated band B CFTR occurred at the same molecular mass only in a subset of cell lines, indicative of potential variations in glycosylation process.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	279	 To rule out the possibility of antibodies cross-reactivity or non-specific labeling, indirect immunofluorescence analysis was performed with another anti-CFTR antibody, L12B4 (Figure 5D).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	280	 As expected, the Caco-2 cell line used as a positive control showed strong immunoreactivity for CFTR protein (Figure 5D, row D).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	281	 In contrast, and as expected, COS-7 cells used as negative control did not stain with this anti-CFTR antibody (Figure 5D, row E).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	282	 No staining was detected when the primary antibody was omitted (Figure 5D, row F).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	283	 The comparison of immunofluorescence images between epithelial (Figure 5D, row A, B and D) and muscular (Figure 5D, row C) cells provides evidence that CFTR is significantly expressed in C2C12 myoblasts.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	284	 However, because the indirect immunofluorescence experiments were performed in permeabilized cells, they do not distinguish between CFTR that is located in the apical membrane and CFTR that is located in a vesicular pool just beneath the apical membrane.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	285	 These findings, together with the transcriptional activities presented above, suggest that the minimal CFTR promoter might contain tissue-specific enhancer(s) as well as repressive cis-regulatory elements that have the ability to mitigate the activity of the CFTR promoter between epithelial and non-epithelial lineages.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Because CF affects mainly epithelial tissues and Beas2B consistently yielded higher enhancer activity than A549, we restricted subsequent studies to this bronchial epithelial cell line.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	287	View larger version (25K):    Figure 5 Analysis of CFTR minimal promoter activity and CFTR expression.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	288	 (A) CFTR minimal promoter activities in Beas2B, A549, C2C12 and COS-7 cell lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	289	8  microg of WT-pGL3 construct was co-transfected together with 0.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	290	2  microg of internal control pRL-SV40 containing Renilla luciferase.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	291	 The empty pGL3-Basic vector was transfected as a negative control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	292	 Normalized luciferase values are illustrated as relative light units.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	293	 The mean of two independent plasmids preps and each experiment with standard errors is shown.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	294	 The experimental value for luciferase activity represented the mean  plus or minus  SD of four separate experiments in triplicates.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	295	 (B) RT to PCR analysis of CFTR mRNA expression.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Total RNA was harvested from the indicated cell lines and subjected to PCR as described in  Materials and Methods .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	297	 cDNA derived from COS-7 was used as a negative control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Samples without reverse transcriptase (noted No RT) or with an H2O no-template reaction (noted No RNA) were used as additional negative controls.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Samples were also amplified for HPRT to control for RNA degradation during DNase treatment and reverse transcription.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	300	 Densitometric analysis of CFTR bands intensity was performed with relative HPRT mRNA expression in Beas2B bronchial epithelial cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Whole cell proteins extracts prepared from indicated cells were subjected to electrophoresis with 7% SDS to PAGE gel and transferred to supported PVDF membrane.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	302	 CFTR immunoreactivity was detected using 24.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	303	1 anti-CFTR Ab as the primary antibody.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Positions for the core glycosylated (band B) and mature fully glycosylated CFTR (band C) are indicated by the arrows at the right.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Numbers below the ss-actin panel indicate intensity values of integrated optical densities of the mature and immature CFTR bands normalized over the corresponding ss-actin bands and expressed relative to the Beas2B controls bands, which are set to 1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	306	 (D) Indirect immunofluorescence analysis.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	307	 The A549, Beas2B, C2C12, Caco-2 and COS-7 cells (rows A to E, respectively) were fixed, permeabilized, and then stained with the L12B4 anti-CFTR Ab, followed by the appropriate secondary antibody as described in  Materials and Methods .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Left panel, cells were stained with Cy3-conjugated secondary antibody (red).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	309	 Middle panel, cells were counterstained with DAPI (blue) for nuclear staining.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Right panel, shown is merge of CFTR immunostaining and DAPI.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	311	 Row F, Background immunofluorescence obtained in the absence of the primary antibody.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	312	  Effects of SRF on the proximal CFTR promoter To assess whether SRF protein might affect CFTR transcriptional regulation, we took two related approaches.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	313	 First, we co-transfected either exogenous full-length SRF or truncated SRF mutants with the wild-type CFTR minimal promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Second, we utilized a siRNA approach to ask whether a reduction in endogenous SRF levels could affect basal CFTR activation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	315	 Luciferase assays were carried out in Beas2B cells using the indicated SRF expression vectors and the WT-pGL3luciferase reporter construct (Figure 6B, left panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	316	 The 3XSRE-fos TATA-Luciferase reporter gene was used as positive control because its transcriptional activity is highly dependent on SRF binding (Figure 6B, right panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	317	 As expected, while this synthetic promoter containing several consensus SREs was markedly and significantly activated ( > 2-fold) by forced expression of full-length SRF protein (pHiv-SRF) (Figure 6B, right panel), truncated SRF mutants either containing only the amino acids 133 to 264 corresponding to DNA-binding domain of SRF (pHiv-DBD-SRF), or deleted of amino acids 153 to 165, an essential part for the DNA binding (pHiv-DN-SRF) induced modest but significant decrease of SRE activity (10% and 30%, respectively).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	318	 When these SRF expression vectors were transiently co-transfected with the WT-pGL3 luciferase reporter construct, the trans-activator effect of SRF was notably reduced.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Indeed, overexpression of full-length and dominant-negative (pHiv-DN-SRF) SRF proteins resulted in 50% increased and 30% decreased of luciferase activity, respectively (Figure 6B, left panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Unexpectedly and inconsistent with previous study (60), the pHiv-DBD-SRF construct induced 40% increase of the WT-pGL3 luciferase activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	321	 This results disparity may be explained by the fact that the c-fos promoter study (60) assessed the DBD to SRF domain activity via microinjection of corresponding truncated SRF polypeptide.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Perhaps, the best explanation for this increased activity is that the DNA-binding domain of SRF, also called MADS box, is sufficient for transcriptional activation of some SRF-dependent genes because it mediates interactions with accessory co-activators (61).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	323	 These results suggest that neither of the regions outside the MADS box, N- or C-terminal, appear essential for transactivation of the CFTR promoter by SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	324	View larger version (24K):    Figure 6 Effect of SRF on the activity of CArG-containing CFTR minimal promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	325	 (A) Schematic representation of different SRF constructs analyzed.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	326	 The SRF fragments shown were cloned into the pHiv expression vector as indicated in  Materials and Methods .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	327	 The position of the MADS box containing the DNA-binding domain and dimerization domain of SRF is depicted by black rectangle.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	328	 WT SRF construct encodes a human full-length SRF open reading frame.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	329	 DBD SRF construct encodes only the DNA-binding domain of SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	330	 DN SRF deletion construct encodes full-length SRF deleted of an essential part for the DNA binding.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	331	 (B) Expression of exogenous SRF in Beas2B cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	332	 Cells were co-transfected with the WT-pGL3 luciferase reporter plasmid (left panel) together with the empty pHiv vector, pHiv-SRF, pHiv-DBD-SRF or pHiv-DN-SRF constructs, as indicated below the bar diagram.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	333	 As a positive control, 3XSRE luciferase reporter plasmid was used.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	334	 In each experiment, a Renilla luciferase expression plasmid was included to normalize for transfection efficiency.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	335	 For each reporter plasmid, luciferase activity (mean  plus or minus  SE) is derived from 4 to 7 different transfection experiments performed in triplicate.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	336	 The errors bars indicate the standard deviations.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	337	 The luciferase activity value 100 was assigned to the samples co-transfected with the indicated reporter plasmid and the empty pHiv expression vector.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	338	 Statistical significance is referred to differences with the activity obtained with empty expression vector.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	339	 (C) Effects of SRF siRNA on CFTR promoter activity and expression in Beas2B epithelial cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	340	 Left panel: Beas2B cells were co-transfected with either human control siRNA vector or plasmid encoding SRF siRNA as indicated.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Forty-eight hours following transfection, total proteins were harvested and analyzed by western blotting.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	342	 Densitometric analysis showed a substantial decrease of endogenous SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	343	 Right panel: the luciferase activity value 100 was assigned to the samples co-transfected with the control siRNA.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	344	  To further establish the role of SRF in mediating the increase in CFTR gene transcription, we performed siRNA experiments (Figure 6C).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	345	 To demonstrate the efficacy of specific SRF siRNA construct, Beas2B cells were co-transfected with either control or SRF siRNA plasmids and western blots were performed to analyze levels of SRF in these cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	346	 Densitometric analysis of western blot showed that endogenous SRF levels were strongly reduced in the presence of the SRF siRNA plasmid (Figure 6C, left panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	347	 Then, control and SRF siRNA plasmids were co-transfected into Beas2B cells with either the WT-pGL3 or the 3XSRE luciferase reporter construct.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	348	 As shown in Figure 6C (right panel), reduction of endogenous SRF protein level decreased the activity of both wild-type CFTR promoter and 3XSRE-fos TATA-Luciferase reporter constructs by 25%.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	349	Taken together, these findings indicate that endogenous SRF into bronchial epithelial cells normally function as transcriptional coactivator for the CArG-mediated transactivation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	350	 However, we found that SRF activated the CFTR promoter less well than the SRE-containing synthetic promoter, suggesting that the CArG-like element mediated CFTR transcriptional activation probably required other bridging or co-activating factors.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	351	The CArG-like element contained in the human minimal CFTR promoter is important but not sufficient for basal transcriptional activity in Beas2B cells To assess the transcriptional relevance of the CArG-like binding sequence of CFTR minimal promoter, mutants were performed to create either more consensus CArG element or degenerated motif (Table 1).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	352	 We used the D upper-case and the C upper-case to designate the Degenerated CArG motifs and the Consensus CArG elements, respectively.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	353	 To ensure the efficacy of mutations in abrogating transcription factor binding, we first performed a series of EMSA experiments with each CArG mutant and the WT probe (Table 2).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	354	 As expected, based on the sequence analysis, the mutations resulting in more degenerated CArG motifs (D1, D2, D3 and D4 mutants) completely abolished SRF-binding activity (Figure 7A, lanes 1 to 4), when we compared with SRF-WT complexes (Figure 7A, lane 5).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	355	 In addition, the probes containing more consensus CArG boxes (C1, C2, C3, C4 and C5 mutants) bound SRF more strongly in nuclear extracts prepared from Beas2B (Figure 7A, lanes 6 to 10).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	356	 Inclusion of an anti-SRF antibody partially abolished SRF-binding activity and resulted in a slower mobility band, confirming the identity of the binding protein (Figure 7A, lane 11).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	357	 Then, minimal CFTR promoter constructs bearing the same consensus and disrupted CArG boxes were tested in a transient transfection assays in Beas2B cells (Figure 7B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	358	 Compared with luciferase activity resulting from the WT-pGL3 construct, variable increases in reporter activity are observed when D1, D2, D3 and D4 mutant constructs, with disrupted CArG motif, were transiently transfected.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	359	 On the other hand, mutations that create more consensus CArG element result in either reducing or increasing in the transcriptional activity (Figure 7B).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	360	 Consistent with the preceding gel-shift results revealing an uncharacterized protein/DNA complex with slightly slower mobility and variable intensity compared with the SRF to DNA complex, these finer mutagenesis studies suggest that both co-activators and co-repressors might interact with the studied promoter sequences.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	361	 Taken together, these data demonstrated that the CFTR-CArG-like element alone is not sufficient to confer basal transcriptional activation of the CFTR gene.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	362	View larger version (51K):    Figure 7 The CFTR-CArG-like element is not sufficient for basal transcriptional activity in Beas2B cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	363	 (A) EMSA analysis with nuclear extracts from SRF protein-enriched Beas2B cells using mutated labeled oligonucleotide probes (sequences listed in Table 2).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	364	 Ab against SRF was included as indicated (lane 10).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	365	 The arrow SS indicates the supershifted complexes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	366	 (B) Basal transcriptional activity of CArG variants of the CFTR promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Luciferase activity obtained with the WT-pGL3 luciferase construct was defined as 100%, and relative luciferase activities from mutant constructs are expressed as a percentage of this value.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	368	 Firefly luciferase activity was normalized with respect to Renilla luciferase activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	369	 The errors bars indicate the standard deviations.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	370	  Functional antagonism between SRF and YY1 through competition for the CFTR-CArG-like binding As a further means of establishing the role for SRF-binding CArG boxes in mediating either the CFTR-enhancer or silencer activity observed with the different minimal CFTR promoter mutants, we performed additional computational analyses.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	371	 Sequence analysis of CArG boxes and their immediate flanking sequences showed that C1, C3 and C4 constructs contain consensus binding sites for a number of transcription factors, in addition to SRF, including the transcription factor YY1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	372	 These findings with previous work (12) have particularly evoked our interest to examine the role of YY1 in SRF-mediated CFTR transcriptional activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	373	In a first set of experiments, we evaluated whether the YY1 factor contributes to the formation of nucleoprotein complexes interacting with the WT, C1, C3 and C4 radiolabeled probes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	374	 As shown in Figure 8A, incubation with specific anti-YY1 antibody resulted in either a significant decrease or total disappearance of some complexes normally formed between the CArG boxes and a component of Beas2B nuclear extracts, establishing DNA binding between YY1 and the sequences tested.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	375	 As expected, control experiment performed with radiolabeled probe, D2, devoid of any YY1 binding site and the anti-YY1 antiserum did not reveal any change in electrophoretic profiles indicating specificity of the YY1 binding.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	376	 Thus, these EMSAs demonstrated that the CFTR-CArG-like (WT probe) and more consensus CArG elements (C1  <  C3  <  C4) served as binding site for at least two distinct nuclear factors, namely SRF and YY1 from bronchial epithelial cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	377	View larger version (43K):    Figure 8 Functional interplay between SRF and YY1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	378	 (A) YY1 binding to CFTR-CArG elements.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	379	 Nuclear extracts from Beas2B cells were incubated with 32P-labelled oligonucleotide probe containing either CArG-like (noted WT), consensus CArG box (noted C1, C3 and C4) in the presence or absence of specific antibody raised against YY1 as indicated.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	380	 D2, which contain neither CArG element nor YY1 site, is included as negative control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	381	 Arrows indicate the position of YY1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	382	 (B) Mutually exclusive DNA-binding activity of YY1 versus SRF to the CFTR-CArG site.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	383	 The same labeled CArG oligonucleotides that those used in panel A were incubated with YY1-transfected Beas2B nuclear extracts (5  microg) in the presence of increasing amounts of bacterial purified SRF (100 to 1000 ng).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	384	 Arrows indicate the position of SRF and YY1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	385	 (C) Functional antagonism between SRF and YY1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	386	 Beas2B were transfected with constructs containing either the CFTR-CArG-like element (noted WT) or consensus CFTR-CArG-boxes (noted C1, C3 and C4), in the presence of SRF and/or YY1 expression vectors.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	387	 Luciferase activities were normalized for transfection efficiency to the Renilla luciferase used as internal control.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	388	 The luciferase activity value 100 was assigned to samples co-transfected with the indicated reporter plasmid and the empty expression vector.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	389	 The mean  plus or minus  SD from at least three independent experiments is represented.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	390	  Then, to determine whether the interaction of these two factors with their target DNA (CFTR-CArG-like or more consensus CArG sequence) was either mutually inclusive or exclusive, EMSAs were conducted using bacterially expressed SRF and nuclear extracts prepared from Beas2B cells transfected with a YY1 expression vector as a source of YY1 DNA-binding activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	391	 As shown in Figure 8B, the YY1-binding complex was significantly reduced by increasing SRF binding activity, suggesting their mutually exclusive binding to CArG sites.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	392	Consistent with other studies (32,62), these EMSAs results suggested as a working hypothesis that both SRF and YY1 likely act as functional competitors in the CFTR promoter activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	393	 Since the minimal CFTR promoter is activated by SRF and knowing from previous studies (30 to 33) that YY1 negatively regulates some promoter containing CArG elements, it seemed logical to first assess whether YY1 could also repress the CFTR promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	394	 We asked whether CArG-like-binding site in the CFTR promoter acted as negative regulatory elements.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	395	 Several CFTR promoter reporter constructs containing either CArG-like (namely, WT) or consensus CArG element (C1, C3 and C4) were co-transfected with SRF and/or YY1 expression vectors into Beas2B cells.
