0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	396	 As shown in Figure 8C, while co-transfections with SRF alone resulted in 1.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	397	5- to 2-fold luciferase activation, forced expression of YY1 protein caused a strong decrease in reporter activities (50 to 75% of the control luciferase value).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	398	 Therefore, we wanted to determine the functional relationship of both factors in the CFTR activity regulation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	399	 Transient co-transfections analysis of combination of protein expression vectors showed that over-expression of SRF either did not restore (Figure 8C, panel with the WT and C4 reporter constructs) or only very slightly raised the YY1-repressed reporter activities (Figure 8C, panel with the C1 and C3 reporter constructs).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	400	 These findings are consistent with results obtained from co-transfections performed with the YY1 expression vector alone and previous alpha-actin promoter studies (30 to 33), in which YY1 acted as a strong repressor.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	401	 Taken together, these data suggested functional antagonism between SRF and YY1 through DNA-binding competition.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	402	Identification of multiple CArG binding sites in the non-coding regions of the human CFTR gene and assessment of their putative functional importance To assess the putative importance of CArG motifs in the human CFTR expression regulation, we performed an in silico inspection of additional sequences upstream of the minimal promoter and in the intronic regions.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	403	 Four CArG binding sites were found in the CFTR promoter regions, and seven in the intronic regions.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	404	 The distribution and the positions of these putative binding sites for SRF are shown in Figure 9A.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	405	 Then, to confirm the computational predictions, we used several approaches.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	406	 First, the nucleotide regions harboring these predicted cis-acting elements were analyzed for conservation in the cow, as physiologically relevant transcription factor binding sites are frequently conserved in the non-coding regions of orthologous genes (49,63).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	407	 Second, the SRF-binding sites were tested by EMSAs and also for one of them by ChIP.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	408	View larger version (61K):    Figure 9 The CFTR gene untranslated regions contain multiple SRF-binding sites (CArG-boxes).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	409	 (A) Schematic drawing of CFTR gene shows the exons (circles) and the location of the putative CArG boxes in the non-coding regions, including that identified in the minimal CFTR promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	410	 (B) The CFTR gene non-coding regions encompassing the putative CArG elements were analyzed for conservation in the cow.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	411	 Species homology and positions of the conserved sequence within BAC clones are indicated, as reported in a recent work (49).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	412	 (C) Comparative binding of SRF to CFTR CArG boxes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	413	 Each promoter and intronic CArG box-containing oligonucleotide (see Table 2) was radiolabeled and purified as described in  Materials and Methods .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	414	 Upper panel, binding reaction was performed with bacterially expressed SRF.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	415	 Ab against SRF was included as indicated.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	416	 Arrow indicates specific DNA to SRF complexes and SS indicates the Ab-supershifted complexes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	417	 Lower panel, EMSA analysis with nuclear extracts from Beas2B cells using mutated labeled oligonucleotide probes.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	418	 (D) ChIP analysis of SRF binding to the endogenous CArG regions.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	419	 Lane 1 shows amplification of target sequence in immunoprecipitated chromatin fragments with anti-SRF Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	420	 The target sequence encompasses a CArG element, located to  to 2373 bp in the minimal CFTR promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	421	 Lane 2 shows PCR amplification of a control sample, without Ab.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	422	 Lane 3 shows amplification of 1:100 dilution samples of total input DNA for immunoprecipitation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	423	  We showed that all the predicted CArG elements occur in highly conserved CFTR non-coding regions (Figure 9B), which may contain tissue-specific transcription factors (5).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	424	 We provided evidence that the majority of in silico predicted CArG motifs form specific DNA to protein complexes with bacterially expressed SRF protein (Figure 9C, left panel).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	425	 We also demonstrated by using Beas2B nuclear extracts and supershift assays that some of these CArG elements bound in vitro SRF protein (Figure 9C, right panel, lanes 1, 3, 7 and 9).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	426	 Finally, additional ChIP experiments indicated that the only tested CArG element, located at  to 2373 bp in the CFTR promoter, bound SRF in chromatin from intact cultured Beas2B cells (Figure 9D, lane 1).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	427	 Collectively, these findings support the concept that SRF may play a key role in the CFTR expression regulation via binding to multiple CFTR CArG elements.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	428	Comparisons of nucleotide sequences of this CFTR promoter region in eight mammalian species representing three different orders (Primates, Artiodactyla and Lagomorpha) revealed high levels of conservation of the minimal promoter region, as described previously (64).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	429	 However, the CArG-like element (GC(T/A)6GG), which does not conform to the authentic CArG box (CC(T/A)6GG), is absent from three species (sheep, cow and rabbit).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	430	 Even though this motif occurs in only a subset of the input sequences, it does not necessarily mean that it is of no functional importance.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	431	 Instances of cis-regulatory elements being species-specific have been already reported for the CFTR gene (50).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	432	 More generally, it is well known that some transcription factors can tolerate more than one type of nucleotide at a given position of the binding site.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	433	 Instances of substitutions in both the central core of the CArG element and the highly conserved contact points for SRF, at the terminal ends, not impairing SRF binding have been previously reported (48,65 to 68).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	434	 Taken together, these data support the notion that the CFTR-CArG-like element has possible important implication in the CFTR transcriptional regulation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	435	Interestingly, analysis of SRF expression has revealed relatively high expression levels of SRF protein in the bronchial epithelial cells (Figure 2), as shown in other differentiated epithelial cells (27).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	436	 Accumulating evidence supports the concept that SRF could contribute to the CFTR expression regulation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	437	 In addition to regulating growth-responsive genes and numerous muscle-specific genes (22,69), SRF is also described as a key trans-binding factor in various important physiological events.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	438	 For example, SRF has been shown to regulate pulmonary development in Drosophila (28), to promote both re-epithelialization and muscular structure restoration during gastric ulcer healing (70) and more recently to be involved in the regulation of endoplasmic reticulum-targeted gene (67).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	439	 Therefore, it was relevant to examine the potential role of SRF on the CFTR transcriptional activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	440	In the present study, we demonstrated that CFTR-CArG-like element forms specific DNA to protein complexes that include SRF protein as part of the complex, in vitro and in vivo (Figures 3 and 4).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	441	 We have investigated the expression driven by the proximal human CFTR promoter in a pGL3 construct in both epithelial and myoblasts lines.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	442	 Results of our transient transfections of 3XSRE-fos TATA and WT-pGL3 luciferase reporter genes showed that the human minimal CFTR promoter encompassing a CArG-like motif was sufficient to drive the expression in both cell types (Figure 5).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	443	 Consistent with other studies showing CFTR expression in smooth muscle tissue (71,72), our results demonstrated that the human CFTR minimal promoter had the ability to drive the expression in muscle lineages.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	444	 Our transient co-transfections analyses performed with full-length and dominant-negative SRF forms expression vectors, and also specific SRF siRNA constructs (Figure 6, panels B and C) provide the first evidence for a positive role of the SRF protein in the regulation of the human CFTR promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	445	 However, the SRF-induced CFTR transactivation, though significant, is relatively modest.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	446	 These data with the results of finer mutagenesis studies presented in Figure 7 support the concept that SRF alone is not sufficient to drive the basal expression of the CFTR gene.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	447	 As suggested by other previous studies (73 to 75), it is likely that additional factors might be required to optimally drive the CFTR promoter, as well as to specify the cell-type-restricted expression.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	448	 Since YY1 was previously shown to bind the CFTR promoter (12) and a subset of SREs serve as binding sites for YY1 (30 to 33), we first evaluated this candidate in the SRF-mediated CFTR transcriptional activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	449	 The data analysis suggests a functional antagonism between SRF and YY1 through binding competition for the CFTR-CArG-like box.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	450	 However, the analysis of combinatorial co-transfection studies, presented in Figure 8C, suggests that the functional interplay between SRF and YY1, alone, is not sufficient to account for basal CFTR transcriptional activation.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	451	 Further studies will be necessary to determine whether another player might be involved in this functional interplay and accounted for the basal transcriptional CFTR activity observed in the Beas2B bronchial epithelial cells.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	452	Interestingly, we showed that, in addition to the CArG-like element defined in the minimal promoter of the CFTR gene, there are three CArG motifs located at the 5' end of the gene and seven are present in the intronic regions (Figure 9).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	453	 We also evidenced SRF binding to CArG elements of the endogenous CFTR gene in the context of intact chromatin (Figures 4 and 9D).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	454	 Although the role of these more distal CArG boxes has yet to be assessed, these findings are of major importance, since it has been shown that optimal activity of the SRF-dependent target genes may require a number of CArG boxes, including those that are defined in the intronic region (66,67,76).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	455	 Moreover, as already suggested for the -actin promoters (32,74), perhaps the presence multiple CArG elements in the CFTR gene with cooperative binding events might be essential for SRF to prevent YY1 from binding to the CFTR promoter.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	456	 Clearly, further studies are needed to directly investigate the role of these multiple CArG elements in transcriptional regulation of the CFTR gene.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	457	Taken together, our results demonstrated for the first time that the human CFTR promoter is a novel SRF target gene, subject to modest but significant SRF activation partially due to functional antagonism between YY1 and SRF through mutually exclusive DNA-binding activities of YY1 versus SRF to the CFTR-CArG-like site.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	458	A critical question is, thus, how might SRF contribute to orchestrating cell-restricted and context-dependent programs of CFTR gene expression? Our findings and investigations to date clearly indicate the presence of several different underlying mechanisms of SRF-dependent transcriptional activation, as represented in Figure 10.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	459	 These might include association of SRF with a variety of cell-restricted co-factors (noted in gray bubbles, Figure 10), such as MRTF-A highly expressed in epithelial cells of the lung, kidney, colon and testis, and MRTF-B also expressed in smooth muscle cells (77), ternary complex factors, such as p62 and SAP-1 (25,78) and remodeling chromatin co-factors in an HAT-dependent manner, such as the CREB-binding protein (79).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	460	 In addition, it is well known that binding of SRF to the CArG box induces an acute bend in the DNA and that this bending may vary with changing base compositions across the CArG box (80).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	461	 Such bending can probably facilitate interactions with other proteins already involved in the CFTR expression regulation, such as NF-B (13) and C/EBP (9) and described as interacting with SRF (81).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	462	 Finally, the Ras-related GTPases family (rac, RhoA and cdc42) might have a critical role in the activation of SRF (82).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	463	 Indeed, it is reported that RhoA-induced SRF activation occurs through a phenomenon of  actin treadmilling  restricted to CArG-dependent genes that do not have adjacent ETS-binding sites (e.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	464	 smooth muscle cell restricted CArG genes) (83,84).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	465	 Moreover, it has been shown that the activation of SRF may be mediated by the NF-B and C/EBP transcription factors (81).
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	466	View larger version (33K):    Figure 10 Schematic model depicting potential mechanism that might contribute to epithelial-specific regulation of the CFTR gene.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	467	 In this model, arrows and bubbles marked in gray indicate multiple potential SRF-mediated regulation pathways, such as protein to protein interaction and potential induction by the Ras-related GTPases cascades.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	468	 Blue and pink bubbles indicate trans-factors identified in this study that contribute to the basal CFTR transcriptional activity.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	469	 Black and double arrow shows the functional antagonism between YY1 and SRF identified in this study through the CFTR-CArG-like element characterization.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	470	  These data provide the foundation for further studies on the regulation of CFTR and will unable the rational design of further functional studies, including various strategies aiming to further dissect the different regulation pathways.

0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	538	 (2002) Ablation of internalization signals in the carboxyl-terminal tail of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator enhances cell surface expression J.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	539	, 277, 49952 to 49957[Abstract/Free Full Text] .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	540	 (1991) Characterization of the promoter region of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene J.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	541	, 266, 24471 to 24476[Abstract/Free Full Text] .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	542	 (1995) Functional activation of the cystic fibrosis trafficking mutant delta F508-CFTR by overexpression Am.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	543	 Physiol, 268, L615 to L624[ISI][Medline] .
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	544	 (1994) The transcription factors Elk-1 and serum response factor interact by direct protein-protein contacts mediated by a short region of Elk-1 Mol.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	545	 (1996) Transcript analysis of CFTR frameshift mutations in lymphocytes using the reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction technique and the protein truncation test Hum.
