0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	626	 PubMed PubMed Citation Articles by Rene, C.
0.44163495.16170155.html.plaintext.txt	627	 Online ISSN 1362-4962 - Print ISSN 0305-1048 Copyright   2006 Oxford University Press Oxford Journals Oxford University Press Site Map Terms  and  Conditions --> Privacy Policy Frequently Asked Questions Other Oxford University Press sites: Oxford University Press American National Biography Booksellers' Information Service Children's Fiction and Poetry Children's Reference Corporate  and  Special Sales Dictionaries Dictionary of National Biography Digital Reference English Language Teaching Higher Education Textbooks Humanities International Education Unit Law Medicine Music Online Products Oxford English Dictionary Reference Rights and Permissions Science School Books Social Sciences Very Short Introductions World's Classics.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	0	Transcriptional Adaptation to Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator Deficiency* Yan Xu , Jean C.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Divisions of  Pulmonary Biology,   Developmental Biology,   Pediatric Informatics, and  Pulmonary Medicine, Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center, Cincinnati, Ohio 45229-3039.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, October 8, 2002, and in revised form, November 13, 2002.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	3	Cystic fibrosis (CF)1 is the most common lethal, inherited pulmonary disorder and is caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) (1).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	4	 More than 800 distinct mutations in the CFTR gene have been associated with clinical diseases characteristic of cystic fibrosis (2).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Whereas many organs are affected in CF, morbidity and mortality in the disease is primarily related to mucus accumulation, recurrent infections, and excessive inflammation in the lung.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Whereas the pathogenesis of CF is not fully understood, abnormalities in cyclic AMP-dependent chloride secretion and excessive sodium reuptake by epithelial cells related to CFTR deficiency are thought to alter fluid homeostasis at the airway surface liquid leading to its dehydration, impaired mucociliary clearance, and infection (see Ref.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Because the elucidation of the primary structure of CFTR, a myriad of functions and numerous interactions with other cellular proteins have been ascribed to CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Thus, in addition to the role of CFTR in the regulation of cAMP-dependent chloride transport, this protein may play pleotropic roles in many cellular processes by interacting with the cytoskeleton, membrane transport proteins, as well as receptors, protein routing and degradation machinery (2).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	9	 A number of studies support the concept that the excessive inflammatory responses occur in the CF lung, but the mechanisms underlying these abnormalities have not been clarified.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Changes in levels of IL-8 and other proteins mediating inflammatory signaling including NFB and iNOS have been associated with CF, in the presence or absence of infection, raising the possibility that abnormalities in CFTR may constitutively alter pathways mediating inflammation (4-6).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	11	In the lung, CFTR is distributed primarily in apical regions of airway and submucosal gland epithelial cells (7).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Abundance and cellular sites of expression of CFTR are strongly influenced by developmental, spatial, and humoral factors, supporting the concept that the expression and function of CFTR are regulated at both transcriptional and post-transcriptional levels.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Despite extensive study, the precise role of CFTR in the pathogenesis of CF disease remains poorly understood.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	14	 At the clinical level, severity of CF disease is highly variable even among individuals bearing identical mutations, supporting the concept that environmental and hereditary factors may influence the severity of the disorder (2).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	15	 These clinical observations, and observations demonstrating strain differences in the severity of CF phenotype after CFTR gene targeting or mutation in mice (8), support the concept that the expression of CFTR and its function in cellular processes may be influenced by many genes or pathways intensifying or mollifying CF disease in various organs.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Morbidity and mortality in patients with CF is strongly associated with pulmonary disease caused by mucous accumulation, inflammation, and infection; however, deletion of CFTR mice does not cause significant pulmonary disease suggesting that expression of alternative channels or other complementary genes maintains pulmonary homeostasis in the mouse.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Whereas numerous in vitro and in vivo models have been developed for study of CFTR, analysis of genomic responses to the presence or absence of CFTR are complicated by heterogeneity of cell models, and culture conditions that may influence cell function and gene expression independently of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Direct RNA analysis of pulmonary tissue from humans with CF is complicated by the nearly ubiquitous, severe pulmonary infections that may secondarily modify cellular responses and gene expression, complicating identification of responses to CFTR in vivo.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	19	Transgenic mice bearing a null mutation in CFTR (CFTR()), generally succumb to intestinal disease in the weanling period (9).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	20	 To generate healthy mice deficient in CFTR, the human CFTR cDNA was expressed in the intestinal epithelium under control of the intestinal fatty acid-binding protein gene promoter (iFABP), fully correcting small intestinal pathology and supporting normal postnatal survival of CFTR() mice (10).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The iFABP-hCFTR, mCFTR() mice have been maintained in a mixed FVB/N, C57BL/6 background without evidence of gastrointestinal or pulmonary disease for nearly a decade in our laboratory.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Histological andbiochemical studies identified no overt pathology in lung tissue from these mice compared with CFTR expressing littermate controls (10, 11).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Mice were maintained in filtered microisolator cages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Sentinal mice were free of mouse pathogens.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Lungs of adult iFABP-hCFTR, mCFTR(), and control mice were free of bacterial pathogens or colonization as assessed by quantitative culture of lung homogenates on blood agar plates.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	26	RNA Preparation-- Matings of FABP-hCFTR(+/+)/mCFTR(/) mice to wild type FVB/N-mCFTR(+/+) mice were used to produce F1 FABP-hCFTR(+/)/mCFTR(/+) mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	27	 These mice were crossed to generate F2 offspring littermates that were then genotyped, choosing FABP-hCFTR(+)/mCFTR() and hCFTR(+)/mCFTR(+) mice for use in RNA comparisons.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	28	 To minimize the potential influence of strain differences in this colony, lung RNA was isolated from sex-matched littermates at 3, 6, and 11 weeks of age.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	29	 RNA was also isolated from lungs of surviving CFTR()/hCFTR() and CFTR(+) littermates at 3 weeks of age for comparison with those bearing the iFABP-hCFTR transgene.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	30	 All CFTR(+) mice were heterozygous for the targeted mCFTR gene.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Lungs from sex-matched littermates were carefully dissected and the conducting airways and mediastinal structures removed.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	32	 RNA, cDNA synthesis, and microarray analysis were performed in pairs to minimize technical variability related to RNA and isolation and hybridization conditions.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Lungs were homogenized in TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen) using methods recommended by the manufacturer.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Genotyping was performed using the following primers: primers for mCFTR PCR: forward primer (intron 9), 5'-AGGGGCTCGCTCTTCTTTGTGAAC-3', and reverse primer (intron 10), 5'-TGGCTGTCTGCTTCCTGACTATGG-3'; neomycin resistance gene PCR: forward primer, 5'-CACAACAGACAATCGGCTGCT-3', and reverse primer, 5'-ACAGTTCGGCTGGCGCGAG-3'; and hCFTR PCR: forward primer (exon 9), 5'-AAACTTCTAATGGTGATGACAG-3', and reverse primer (exon 11), 5'-AGAAATTCTTGCTCGTTGAC-3'.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	35	Validation of RNAs by RT-PCR-- Changes in selected RNA levels identified in the microarray analysis were validated by RT-PCR using a Light CyclerTM or a regular thermocycler followed by gel electrophoresis.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	36	 For these studies, lung RNAs were isolated as described above.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	37	 cDNAs were generated by reverse transcription and PCR analysis was performed using the following primers for: Kir 4.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	38	2 forward, 5'-CTTTGAGTTTGTGCCTGTGGTTTC-3', and reverse, 5'-GCTGTGTGATTTGGTAGTGCGG-3'; human CFTR, same as above; and mouse CFTR forward, 5'-TGCTTCCCTACAGAGTCATCAACGG-3', and reverse, 5'-CACAGGATTTCCCACAACGCAGAG-3'; -actin for normalization, forward, 5'-TGGAATCCTGCGGCATCCATGAAC; reverse, 5'-TAAAACGCAGCTCAGTAACAGTCCG-3'; glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, forward, 5'-CTTCACCACCATGGAGAAGGC-3', and reverse, 5'-GGCATGGACTGTGGTCATGAG-3'; CCAAT enhancer-binding protein (CEBP) , forward, 5'-CGCAACAACATCGCTGTG-3', and reverse, 5'-GGGCTGGGCAGTTTTTTG-3'; TNF-AIP-3, forward, 5'-GCACGAATACAAGAAATGGCAGG-3', and reverse, 5'-GGCATAAAGGCTGAGTGTTCACG-3'; and Grin 2d, forward, 5'-CCTTCTTTGCCGTCATCTTTCTTGC-3', and reverse, 5'-AAACTTCAGGGGTGGGTATTGCTCC-3'.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	39	RNA Microarray and Data Analysis-- Total RNA was subjected to reverse transcription using oligo(dT) with T7 promoter sequences attached, followed by second strand cDNA synthesis.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Antisera cRNA was then amplified and biotinylated using T7 RNA polymerase, prior to hybridization to the Affymetrix genechip mouse U74aV2 using the Affymetrix recommended protocol (12, 13).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Affymetrix MicroArray Suite version 5.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	42	0 was used to scan and quantitate the genechips using default scan settings.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Intensity data were collected from each chip, scaled to a target intensity of 1500, and the results were analyzed using both MicroArray Suite and GeneSpring 5.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	44	cDNAs were hybridized to U74aV2 chips (Affymetrix Inc.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Hybridization data were normalized in a CCAAT enhancer-binding protein two-step process to remove or minimize systemic sources of variation at both chip and gene level.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Specifically, each chip was normalized to the distribution of all genes on the chip to control for variation between samples.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Each RNA from mCFTR() mice was normalized to its specific control (i.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	48	 sex and age-matched mCFTR(+) littermates).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Data were further transformed into log ratio for analysis and symmetry of distribution.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Changes in mRNAs were identified by the combination of a distribution analysis (JMP4, SAS Institute, Inc.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	51	), and the Welch analysis of variance.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Outlier box and quartile box plots were used to identify outliers with the definition of up-outlier  >  upper quartile + 1.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	53	5 (interquartile range), and the down-outlier  <  lower quartile  1.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Significant changes were calculated by the Welch t test at p  <  0.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Adjusted p values were calculated by Westfall and Young permutation for correction of false positives (GeneSpring 4.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Comparisons between genotype and age groups were performed using one-way analysis of variance.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	57	 To identify genes that were differentially expressed because of CFTR genotype regardless of age, hierarchical, and k-means clustering were used to identify consistent changes in gene expression in response to the lack of CFTR at all three time points.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Candidate RNAs were further filtered on the basis of reproducibility and absolute intensity.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Mean, standard deviation, and coefficient variation were calculated for each replicate.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Replicates with coefficient variations  >  50% were deleted from analysis.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Genes whose expression was below the level of detection were eliminated as experimental noise.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	62	Pathway and Literature Analysis-- Selected genes were subjected to intensive search to identify biological function and associated regulatory pathways.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	63	 A U74Av2 annotation data base with system identifiers was constructed for all the array elements and their associated GenBankTM accession numbers.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Gene description, functional categories, biological processes, molecular functions, cellular components, protein domain, and literature information were identified.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Information resources included NetAffy (www.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	66	com), Source Search genome-www5.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	67	edu/cgi-bin/SMD/source/), BLAST NCBI, Locus Link, mouse-human homolog search (www.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	68	gov), and Gene Ontology data base (www.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Differentially expressed genes were classified into functional categories based on the gene ontology definition.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	70	 To determine which functional category is overrepresented in the selected gene list, the binomial probability was calculated for each category using the entire U74Av2 (contains 12488 mice genes) as a reference data set.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The binomial probability is defined by the following.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	72	 1) It returns the probability of getting k successes of n trials if the probability is p in the given population (U74Av2).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Potential protein/protein or protein/DNA interactions were identified using the published literature information.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	74	Histology and Immunohistochemistry-- Lung histology in adult iFABP-hCFTR, CFTR(); iFABP-hCFTR, CFTR(+), and CFTR(+) control mice was not different (Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	75	 There was no evidence of pulmonary inflammation, infection, or remodeling.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Mac-3 staining was used to identify alveolar macrophages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Numbers and histology of alveolar macrophages were not altered by mCFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	78	View larger version (133K):    Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	79	   Normal lung histology in CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Lung tissue was obtained after inflation fixation from iFABP-hCFTR, mCFTR() mice (B and D) and iFABP-hCFTR, mCFTR(+) littermates (A and C) at 3 months of age.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Lung histology after staining with hematoxylin-eosin (A and B) or Mac-3 antibody (C and D), a marker of alveolar macrophages, were not altered in the CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	82	Identification of Gene Responses to the Lung CFTR Deletion-- To identify genes responsive to CFTR, lung RNAs from iFABP-hCFTR, mCFTR(), iFABP-hCFTR, mCFTR(+), mCFTR() and mCFTR(+) littermates at the age of 3, 6, or 11 weeks of age were compared.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Microarray analyses were performed in duplicate from RNA isolated at 3 and 6 weeks of age.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Data from 10 Affymetrix Murine Genome U74Av2 chips were normalized and statistical differences between CFTR-deficient (CFTR()) and control (CFTR(+)) mice were identified.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Differences related to age were identified by outlier analysis and/or unpaired t test.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	86	 After normalization, normal distributions were observed in the intensity data from lung tissue obtained at all ages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Lung RNA data from 3-week-old mCFTR(+) and mCFTR() mice (lacking the iFABP-hCFTR transgene) were similarly distributed to those bearing the FABP-hCFTR gene and were, therefore, included in the analysis.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	88	To identify RNAs that were differentially expressed in response to CFTR regardless of age, mCFTR() and mCFTR(+) data were separated into two groups.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The log-ratio distribution and outlier plot of the combined data set are represented by Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	90	 A total of 1977 outliers were identified from 12442 genes/expressed sequence tags analyzed.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	91	 The abundance of 848 RNAs was increased; 1129 were decreased.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Welch t test together with the Westfall and Young step-down permutation further narrowed the number of differentially expressed RNAs to 315.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Hierarchical clustering was used to visualize and classify the data set (Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Data are shown in a two-dimensional matrix to identify groups of genes with similar expression patterns and show remarkably ordered gene expression profiles of 315 selected genes.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	95	 On the chip level (top dendrogram) RNAs influenced by CFTR formed two distinct groups.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Within each group, the samples collected from age-matched pairs were more closely related than those from different ages, suggesting that age also influenced gene expression.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	97	 At the RNA level (the dendrogram at the left side), genes were clearly separated into two major groups: those mRNAs increased or decreased in mCFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Genes were further filtered for the consistency of differences in expression levels across all time points (coefficient variation  <  50%) and for their absolute intensity above 243 (90% of genes called absent by Affymetrix software,  < 243 for this data set).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Additional filters reduced the number of RNAs to 54, of which 29 were consistently increased and 25 were decreased in mCFTR() compared with their mCFTR(+) littermates (Tables I and II).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	100	 The expression profiles of these 54 genes are shown in Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	101	 4, demonstrating consistent patterns of expression of the CFTR-responsive RNAs regardless of age.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	102	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	103	   Distribution of lung RNAs from mCFTR() and mCFTR(+) mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The left panel is a histogram of log ratio and gene frequency.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The right panel is the outlier box plot.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The ends of the dashed lines, denoted by an x and y markers, are the outliers identified from their respective quartiles.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	107	View larger version (47K):    Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	108	   Two-dimensional hierarchial clustering of 315 genes/expressed sequence tag that were significantly altered in response to the presence or absence of mCFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Intensity in the red and green color range indicates up-regulated and down-regulated RNAs, respectively.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Each row represents a single gene.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Each column represents a particular experimental condition.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Each box represents the normalized RNA intensity value.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Clustering was performed by UPGMA.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Similarity measures were assessed utilizing Euclidean distance.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	115	                              View this table:    Table I Genes up regulated in mCFTR() versus mCFTR(+) mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	116	                              View this table:    Table II Genes down-regulated in mCFTR () mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	117	View larger version (31K):    Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	118	   Expression profile chart (A) and hierarchical clustering (B) of 54 selected RNAs that were consistently altered in response to the lack of CFTR regardless of age.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Hierarchical clustering was performed by UPGMA.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Data were normalized using Trimmed Mean and Z-score calculations.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	121	 In the profile chart, data were normalized by pairwise control.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The y axis is normalized intensity (log scale) and the x axis represents experimental ages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Red lines represent the profiles of lung RNAs increased in CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Green lines represent the profiles of down-regulated RNAs.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	125	Differentially expressed genes were further classified according to their known or predicted functions.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Each gene was annotated and assigned to a functional category.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	127	 To simplify the calculation, we assumed that genes in each category could be fit to a binomial distribution.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The binomial probability was calculated for each category using the entire U74Av2 as reference data set.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	129	 "Inflammatory Response" was the most represented category of those RNAs increased in mCFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Among RNAs whose abundance was increased by the lack of CFTR, those influencing inflammation, transcription, and transport were most highly represented and consisted of a group of functional categories quite distinct from those whose expression was decreased in mCFTR() mice (Tables I-III).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	131	                              View this table:    Table III Functional Categories of the gene list.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	132	The potential influence of the FABP-hCFTR transgene on RNA expression was also assessed using the Welch t test at the three ages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Differentially regulated RNAs identified in analysis of gastrointestinal-corrected mice were similarly affected in mCFTR() mice, demonstrating a lack of effect of iFABP-hCFTR on this subset of genes.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Genes whose expression was independently altered by the iFABP-hCFTR transgene included 7 RNAs decreased and 11 increased.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Differences in their levels of expression were modest (less than 1.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	136	                              View this table:    Table IV The effect of fabp-hCFTR(+) on lung gene expression Lung RNA samples from iFABP-hCFTR,CFTR() (i.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	137	 gut corrected, GC) were compared with those from CFTR(+) (lacking the iFARP-hCFTR transgene, i.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Ratio is defined as: R = GC/NGC, if (GC  >  NGC); R = NGC/GC if (GC  <  NGC).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	139	Validation of Selected mRNAs-- To validate the responsive RNAs identified by microarray analyses, real time RT-PCR was performed.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	140	 mRNA levels were normalized using -actin or glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	141	2 (Kcnj15), CEBP, TNF-AIP-3, and Grin 2d mRNA were significantly increased in CFTR() mice compared with control littermates (Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	142	 As expected, murine CFTR was not detectable by RT-PCR in mCFTR() mice, nor was hCFTR mRNA detected in lung from the iFABP-hCFTR bearing mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	143	The absence of CFTR caused stereotypic changes in gene expression in the lungs of CFTR() mice in the absence of detectable infection or inflammation.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Cellular responses to CFTR included enhanced expression of transcription factors and signaling pathways known to influence CFTR gene expression (IL-1 and CEBP).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Likewise, expression of RNAs modulating inflammation, ion transport, protein trafficking, and degradation were altered, indicating that a number of cellular pathways may compensate for or mediate CFTR-dependent functions that, in turn, may maintain normal pulmonary homeostasis in the CFTR() mice or alternatively, influence CF phenotype following response to pathogens.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	146	 The absence of CFTR initiates reproducible changes in lung gene expression that may modify inflammation, host defense, and other cellular functions, that likely contribute to or mollify the pathogenesis of pulmonary disease in CF.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	147	Because strain is known to influence pulmonary findings in CF mice (8), and the transgenic mice presently studied were generated in a mixed FVB/N, C57 Bl/6 background, lung RNA was compared from sex-matched littermates at various ages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	148	 An extensive data set was utilized to identify CFTR-dependent changes in gene expression that were present throughout development and in the absence of inflammation, seeking to identify pathways influenced primarily by CFTR, rather than sex, strain, age, or other secondary phenomena.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	149	 As expected, expression of mCFTR was not detected in the gastrointestinal-corrected mCFTR() mice, consistent with previous findings (10).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Histologic analyses, performed presently and previously, demonstrated no structural abnormalities, infection or inflammation in the lungs of these mice as maintained in our vivarium (10, 11), supporting the concept that changes in gene expression were related to CFTR and not to age or lung disease.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Analysis of arrays prepared from pairs of mCFTR() mice and mCFTR(+) littermates (those lacking the iFABP-hCFTR transgene), confirmed the microarray findings, demonstrating both the lack of mCFTR mRNA in lungs of the mCFTR() and that RNA changes were independent of the iFABP-hCFTR transgene.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	152	Expression of Genes Modulating CFTR-- Expression of a number of genes known to influence CFTR expression was enhanced in the lungs of CFTR() mice, including CEBP and IL-1 suggesting that CFTR cells responded by enhancing levels of RNAs encoding transcription factors or pathways that may compensate for the lack of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	153	 IL-1 increased CFTR gene transcription in epithelial cells in vitro (15) and cis-acting elements binding CEBP (to CCAAT enhancer sites) and c-Fos (to AP-1 elements) are present in the promoter-enhancer regions of the mouse CFTR gene (16, 17).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Previous studies demonstrated that CEBP directly enhanced CFTR gene transcription in vitro (18), thus, the increased CEBP expression may represent a potential compensatory response to CFTR deficiency that, in turn, may influence expression of genes unrelated to CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Expression of c-fos was also increased in the mCFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Whereas AP-1 sites have been identified in the hCFTR promoter, the precise role of c-fos in regulation of CFTR has not been clarified; although treatment of various cell types with phorbol esters decreased CFTR gene transcription in vitro (18).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Because CEBP and c-fos activate or inhibit the expression of numerous genes that share cis-active elements with the CFTR gene, changes in their activity may broadly influence gene expression, perhaps inadvertently linking CFTR deficiency to the expression of genes whose activities are not directly related to CFTR protein function.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	158	 RNA encoding TNF-AIP-3, a zinc finger transcription factor, was also increased in the CFTR() mice, further linking transcription responses to the lack of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Of considerable interest, TNF-AIP-3 RNA was induced by either IL-1 or TNF.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	160	 TNF-AIP-3 inhibited NFB translocation in vitro, and may represent a compensatory response to the increased expression of IL-1 seen in the CFTR() mice (19).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	161	 JAK-3, nuclear receptor subfamily 2, and interferon regulatory factor-1 RNAs were decreased in CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	162	 These RNAs encode transcription factors that regulate various pathways involved in inflammation and may, therefore, represent responses to the proinflammatory proteins induced in the CFTR() mice, in essence, being secondarily responsive to initial compensatory changes.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	163	Enhanced Expression of Genes Modulating Inflammation-- Genes involved in inflammation were overly represented among the RNAs induced and were distinct from those that were decreased in the lungs from CFTR() mice (Table III).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Most prominent among genes whose expression was increased were a family of calcium-binding proteins termed the calgranulins (S100A8, S100A9, and calbindin D9K).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	165	 S100A8 is expressed primarily by macrophages and monocytes and its expression is enhanced by various cytokines including TNF-, IL-1, and interferon  (20, 21).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	166	 This family of peptides is expressed by various cell types and share potent chemoattractant activities, stimulating inflammatory cell trafficking.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Increased expression of S100A8 (calgranulin A) was previously demonstrated in alveolar macrophages from CFTR mutant mice, the authors suggesting that increased S100A8 may contribute to the enhanced inflammatory responses seen in the absence of CFTR (22).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Expression of S100A8 by alveolar macrophages was induced by TNF-, interferon  and IL-1, mediated at least in part by AP-1-dependent pathways (20).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Chitinase A mRNA was also consistently increased in the lungs of CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	170	 The acidic chitinase A is a small peptide containing a mammalian lectin domain that binds complex carbohydrates on surfaces of microbial pathogens including fungi.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Like the S100 family of proteins, chitinase family members are also expressed by alveolar macrophages in the lung (23).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Thus, decreased mCFTR initiated changes in expression of gene expressed primarily in alveolar macrophages.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	173	 It remains unclear whether these responses are mediated by direct effects of CFTR in alveolar macrophages or by altered cellular signaling initiated by the lack of CFTR in epithelial or other pulmonary cells that secondarily alters macrophage activity.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	174	Intense neutrophilic infiltration and an increased IL-8 production are strongly associated with CF lung disease in humans (2).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Increased IL-8 and neutrophilic infiltrates were observed in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid from CF patients in the absence of documented pulmonary infection (4).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Although it remains possible that antecedent, but resolved, infections may have contributed to the increased inflammation observed in the CF, these observations support the concept that CF is associated with increased susceptibility to pulmonary inflammation.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	177	 In the present study, IL-1, IL-4, and CSF-1 receptor RNAs were increased and each may contribute to the proinflammatory milieu.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	178	 IL-1 enhances CFTR gene transcription, induces inflammation, and is known to stimulate production of the S100-calgranulins, perhaps indicating a network of genes influenced by CFTR through IL-1.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	179	 IL-4 is a potent inflammatory mediator that enhances inflammation and mucous production in airway epithelia.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Transgenic animals expressing IL-4 or animal models in which IL-4 is induced developed severe goblet cell hyperplasia, increased mucous production, and inflammatory cell infiltrates (24), findings typically found in patients with cystic fibrosis.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	181	 CSF-3r RNA encoding a receptor that mediates monocytic cell migration, proliferation, and activity in response to CSF-3 (G-CSF) was increased 3-4-fold in the CFTR() mice (25).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Thus, taken together, expression of a number of genes; many influenced by IL-1 and mediating inflammation, were induced in the lungs of CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	183	Despite the increased expression of proinflammatory molecules, there is no evidence of inflammation in the lung of the CFTR() mice perhaps indicating that normal homeostasis is maintained by the complex responses of the lung to the lack of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The presence of stereotypic changes in expression of many genes suggests that the presence of a single ameliorating gene, for example, an alternative chloride channel, does not fully explain the physiologic adjustment of the lung the CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	185	 At present, it is unclear whether these proinflammatory responses are secondary to changes in the expression and function of CFTR in the epithelial cells that, in turn, modulate cell signaling and cytokine production in the lung.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Alternatively, the absence of CFTR in the alveolar macrophages may alter expression of genes mediating inflammation in those cells.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	187	 It is of considerable interest that changes in RNAs modifying inflammation were altered in the lungs of mCFTR() mice in the absence of detectable bacterial infection or inflammation, supporting the concept that the transcriptional adjustment to CFTR deficiency suffices to maintain normal pulmonary homeostasis in the mouse in vivo.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Alternatively, the levels of expression of the proinflammatory molecules may not be adequate to cause histologically detectable inflammation.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	189	 It remains unclear whether these adjustments in gene expression may, in turn, render the CFTR() mice susceptible to inflammation following infection or injury.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	190	Changes in NFB- and TNF--dependent Pathways-- RNAs encoding a number of proteins involved in TNF signaling and NFB activation were also induced in the CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	191	 The abundance of TNF-AIP-3 mRNA, a zinc finger transcription protein, a protein whose expression is induced by both TNF- and IL-1, was increased in the CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	192	 TNF-AIP-3 inhibits NFB activity at target genes (19) and may represent a response to the proinflammatory milieu established in the CFTR() lung.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	193	 PEG-3, a protein that regulates the induction of NFB following TNF stimulation, was also increased, providing for the support for transcriptional relationships between CFTR deficiency and activity of NFB (26).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Recent studies of Schroeder et al.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	195	 (27) support the concept that the CFTR is required for regulation of NFB, serving as a pattern-associated molecular recognition molecule, following pulmonary exposure to Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	196	 In that study, NFB activation and its nuclear trafficking were deficient in CF cells.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Taken together with the observation that IL-1-mediated transcription of CFTR gene transcription is dependent upon NFB, this important pathway mediating inflammation appears to be influenced by CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	198	In the present microarray analysis, CFTR deficiency was associated with increased claudin 8 and decreased gap junction connexin 37.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Decreased expression of gap junction proteins (Cx43, 40, -37, and -32) and decreased gap junction communication were observed in various in vitro cell systems after exposure to proinflammatory cytokines (28).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	200	 The observed changes in RNAs mediating cell adhesion and increased expression of IL-1 seen in the CFTR() mice are consistent with findings that in the absence of CFTR, IL-1 and TNF- failed to inhibit cell communication via gap junctions.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Previous studies demonstrated that CFTR is required for the uncoupling of gap functions between epithelial cells during inflammation, a process that may restrict the spread of pathogens or signaling among adjacent cells.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	202	 It will be of interest to test whether cell adhesion mediated by the claudins is also linked to the pathogenesis of CF.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	203	Changes in Protein Degradation Pathways-- Several genes involved in protein degradation were altered in the absence of CFTR compared with normal.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Proteosome 26 S subunit (PSMC3) is the major proteolytic component of the ubiquitin-dependent proteosome.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Proteosome 26 S regulates degradation of proteins influencing cell cycle, oncogenesis, transcription, and immunity, including CFTR itself (29, 30).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	206	 The proteosome is composed of two subcomplexes, the 20 S proteosome and PA700.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	207	 PSMC3 expression was modestly, but significantly increased (1.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	208	 In contrast, PA28 (PSME3), an activator of the 20 S proteosome, was decreased 1.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	209	 These observations are consistent with previous findings that proinflammatory cytokines, including TNF- or interferon- increased expression of the 26 S proteosome and its activators PA28  and  (31), whereas expression of PA28  was decreased by interferon- (32).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	210	 RNA encoding adaptor protein complex AP-2, 1 subunit (Ap2a1), a protein involved in the formation of intracellular transport vesicles was also decreased in the absence of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	211	 CFTR co-precipitates with -adaptin (33).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Recent studies demonstrated that a C-terminal domain of CFTR binds to the AP-2 adaptor complex to form clathrin-coated vesicles that mediates CFTR internalization (34).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	213	 ADP-ribosylation factor 5 belongs to a family of GTP-binding proteins that play important roles in the control of membrane trafficking, including formation of secretory vesicles at the trans-Golgi network, endosomal and vesicle-plasma membrane fusion (35).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Recent studies support the concept that CFTR regulates endosomal fusion and vesicular trafficking (36, 37) indicating potential relationships between CFTR and the actions of ADP-ribosylation factor 5.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Another gene in this functional category is represented by kinesin3, an mRNA that was decreased in the lungs of CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	216	Transport Proteins Influenced by CFTR-- RNAs encoding several transmembrane transport proteins and receptors were also altered in the lungs of CFTR() mice, including solute carrier 38 (member 4), the potassium inwardly rectifying channel (Kir 4.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	217	2 or Kcnj 15), the glutamate receptor (Grin 2d), the naturietic peptide receptor 3 (Npr-3), and the 3-adrenergic receptor (ADRB-3).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Thus, expression of a number of membrane transport proteins was influenced by CFTR, perhaps representing compensatory responses to defects in CFTR-mediated transport activity.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	219	2 and Grin 2d RNAs were increased 2-3-fold in CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	220	2 is expressed in respiratory epithelial cells at sites similar to that of CFTR (38).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	221	2 regulates cation transport upon which chloride transport via CFTR or other chloride channels may be influenced.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Surprisingly, there is evidence for interactions between CFTR and Kir family members because they are both known to bind via PDZ binding domains through interactions with channel interacting PDZ domain protein (39).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Likewise, there is precedence for PDZ-dependent interactions among glutamate receptors, CFTR, and Kir family members (40).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Thus, the lack of CFTR enhanced the expression of a number of membrane proteins that may interact with CFTR via PDZ domains, perhaps indicating that CFTR-protein complexes may initiate changes in gene expression.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	225	 These findings support the concept that CFTR interacts with numerous membrane transport proteins and do not support a model in which activity of an alternative Cl transporter alone suffices to compensate for the lack of CFTR in pulmonary cells in the CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	226	Regulation of Cell Receptors by CFTR-- Natriuretic peptide receptor C (Npr-3 or NprC) was increased more than 2-fold in CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Natriuretic peptides comprise a family of 3 structurally related molecules: atrial (ANP), brain (BNP), and C-type (CNP) whose functions are cGMP-dependent (41, 42).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Among them, CNP increased ciliary beat, mucociliary clearance in airway epithelial cells, and activated CFTR-dependent chloride transport (42).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Natriuretic peptides regulate cytokine-stimulated NO production via the binding of Npr-3 (43).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	230	 Because deficient NO production was observed in respiratory epithelial cells of the iFABP-hCFTR, CFTR() mice, the increased expression of Npr-3 in CFTR() mice may represent a compensatory response influencing airway clearance and nitric oxide production via cGMP (44).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	231	 In contrast to the transport/receptors that were induced, ADRB3, a G protein-coupled transmembrane protein mediating cAMP production was decreased in CFTR() mice.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	232	 ADRB3 is co-expressed with CFTR in airway epithelium (45) and may be functionally coupled to CFTR via cAMP-independent pathways (46).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	233	 2-Adrenergic receptors directly interact with CFTR via the Na(+)/H(+) exchanger regulatory factor to form a signal transduction complex (47).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Co-regulation of ADRB3 and CFTR may indicate that these proteins interact closely at both structural and functional levels, a finding that may be linked to the important role of -adrenergic stimulation and cAMP in the activation of chloride transport mediated by CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	235	Altered Expression of RNAs Encoding CFTR Interacting Proteins-- Surprisingly, analysis of the RNA influenced by CFTR identified a number of proteins that directly or indirectly interact with CFTR via protein-protein interactions.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	236	 This list included proteins involved in protein trafficking and degradation (proteosome 26 S and PA28 subunits and -adaptin), ion transport (Kcnj15 and Grin 2d), and receptors (Npr-3 and ADRB3).
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Interaction of CFTR with many proteins occurs via PDZ binding domains that mediate protein-protein complex formation.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The finding that expression of CFTR interacting proteins is altered in the lungs of CFTR() mice, suggests that CFTR influences networks of signaling and transport activities in the cell and that cells respond to CFTR deficiency via transcriptional responses to CFTR-protein complexes, rather than to CFTR per se.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	239	Are Changes in Gene Expression Bystander Effects?-- Whereas genomic responses may compensate for the lack of CFTR mRNA and represent compensation for CFTR function, some responses may be secondary and mediated by pathways not directly related to the action of CFTR per se.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Alterations in cytokine production or changes in transcription factor activity caused by the absence of CFTR may secondarily change the behavior of numerous cell types, that may, in turn, contribute to the pathogenesis of CF lung disease by processes that are not direct functions of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Because CFTR is known to form a membrane-associated cyclic nucleotide-activated Cl channel and interacts with numerous other cellular proteins, changes in gene expression may indicate that cells sense the CFTR protein, CFTR-dependent activity, or CFTR-protein complexes that initiate transcriptional responses related to or unrelated to CFTR function.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	242	 At present, it is unclear whether the "sensor" is chloride ion, the presence of CFTR, or CFTR-protein complexes in intracellular and membrane compartments or to other functions of CFTR.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	243	 Likewise, the hierarchy and interrelatedness of the networks of RNA responses to CFTR deficiency remain to be unraveled.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	244	Maintenance of pulmonary homeostasis in the mCFTR() mouse was associated with complex adaptive responses in gene expression.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	245	 CFTR influenced RNAs encoding transcription factors, ion channels, membrane receptors, cytokines, and intracellular trafficking proteins.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Finally, CFTR altered the expression of a number of proteins that interact with CFTR via protein-protein interactions perhaps representing transcriptional responses to functions mediated by CFTR() protein complexes (Fig.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The diversity of genes whose expression was altered by CFTR support the concept that, in addition to regulation of Cl transport, CFTR plays diverse roles in multiple cellular functions.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	248	 The present findings support the hypothesis that pulmonary homeostasis in the CFTR() mouse is maintained by complex genomic responses to the lack of CFTR rather than by the action of a single alternative Cl channel.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Finally, the genes and pathways identified in this study provide new links between CFTR and cellular processes that may influence the pathogenesis of CF lung disease.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	250	We thank Theresa Richardson for technical support.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	251	* This work was supported by the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation and National Institutes of Health Grant HL56387.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	252	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	253	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	255	** To whom correspondence should be addressed: Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center, Divisions of Neonatology and Pulmonary Biology, 3333 Burnet Ave.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	256	: 513-636-4830; Fax: 513-636-7868; E-mail: jeff.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	257	Published, JBC Papers in Press, December 12, 2002, DOI 10.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	258	The abbreviations used are: CF, cystic fibrosis; CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; IL, interleukin; iFABP, intestinal fatty acid-binding protein gene promoter; RT, reverse transcriptase; CEBP, CCAAT enhancer-binding protein; TNF, tumor necrosis factor; CSF, colony stimulating factor; Npr-3, naturietic peptide receptor 3; ADRB, 3-adrenergic receptor.
0.44193757.12482874.html.plaintext.txt	259	Copyright   2003 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	0	A Golgi-associated PDZ Domain Protein Modulates Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Regulator Plasma Membrane Expression* Jie Cheng, Bryan D.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Moyer  , Michal Milewski, Johannes Loffing**, Masahiro Ikeda, John E.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	2	From the  Department of Physiology and  Institute of Genetic Medicine, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, Maryland 21205, the   Department of Physiology, Dartmouth Medical School, Dartmouth College, Hanover, New Hampshire 03755, and the ** Institute of Anatomy, University of Zurich, CH-8057 Zurich, Switzerland.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received for publication, October 23, 2001, and in revised form, November 12, 2001.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	4	Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR)1 (1-3).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	5	 CFTR is a cAMP-regulated chloride channel and channel regulator (4) that mediates salt and water balance in a number of tissues, including the airways, intestines, pancreatic and sweat ducts, and kidney tubules (5).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In many polarized epithelial tissues, CFTR functions in the apical cell membrane but in the sweat duct CFTR is localized to both the apical and basolateral cell membranes.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Because a common mutation in CFTR, F508, is degraded through the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-associated processes, many studies have focused on the trafficking of CFTR through this compartment (6).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Much less attention has been devoted to how CFTR is processed through the post-ER pathways.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	9	We reported previously that the polarization of CFTR in the apical membrane of human airway and kidney epithelial cells is altered in CFTR mutants lacking the C-terminal domain (7, 8).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	10	 These data suggested that the C-terminal domain plays a role either in the trafficking to and/or stability within the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The last three amino acids of CFTR (Thr-Arg-Leu) comprise a consensus sequence known to bind to PDZ domain proteins, a family of proteins containing a 80- to 90-amino acid motif that binds to the C terminus of a variety of ion channels and receptors (9-11).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	12	At least two PDZ domain-containing proteins, Na+/H+ exchanger regulatory factor, NHE-RF (also called EBP50), and the CFTR-associated protein CAP70 are known to bind to the terminal amino acids of CFTR (12, 13).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	13	 NHE-RF is a submembranous phosphoprotein that regulates the apical membrane Na+/H+ exchanger NHE3 (14).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Because NHE-RF associates with ezrin, which itself binds to the regulatory subunit of PKA (15), it was hypothesized that NHE-RF anchors CFTR to the cytoskeleton at a subapical compartment targeting protein kinase A near CFTR (12).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	15	 E3KARP, an NHE-RF-related protein, was also shown to interact with CFTR (16, 17).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	16	 CAP70, a subapical protein with four PDZ domains, binds to at least two CFTR molecules simultaneously via PDZ3 and PDZ4 (18).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	17	 CAP70 and NHE-RF enhance CFTR Cl channel activity in excised patches probably by cross-linking CFTR dimers (18, 19).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	18	 NHE-RF, E3KARP, and CAP70 are localized to subplasma membrane regions reflecting their proposed roles in anchoring and/or regulating CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	19	Although there is growing evidence of a functional interaction between CFTR and PDZ domain proteins at the plasma membrane, little is known about whether PDZ domain proteins play a role in intracellular trafficking of CFTR along the ER, the Golgi, and the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The post-ER secretory pathway involved in the trafficking of wild type and mutant CFTR to the plasma membrane is poorly characterized.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	21	 A recent study has demonstrated that CFTR has an unusually low distribution in cis-Golgi compartments compared with most membrane proteins (20), raising the possibility that CFTR may utilize novel modes of anterograde and retrograde trafficking mechanisms.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	22	Two-hybrid Screening and Cloning of CAL-- Yeast two-hybrid screening was used to identify proteins that interact with the C terminus of CFTR (21).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The bait consisted of the C-terminal 51 amino acids of rat CFTR (aa 1428-1478 of rCFTR), amplified by PCR from a rat lung MATCHMAKER cDNA library (CLONTECH, Palo Alto, CA).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The PCR products were subcloned into the BamHI/PstI sites of a pAS2-1 vector, in-frame with the Gal4 DNA-binding domain.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Approximately 1  x  107 recombinants of a rat lung MATCHMAKER cDNA library fused to the Gal4 activation domain (CLONTECH) were screened for interaction with the bait protein in Y190 yeast cells on triple-minus plates supplemented with 35 mM 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole (3-AT) (Leu, Trp, His, 3-AT).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	26	 A rat CAL (rCAL) fragment identified in yeast two-hybrid screening was used to screen a human lung cDNA library (CLONTECH) to obtain the full-length human CAL (hCAL).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Cloned inserts were sequenced in both directions by automated fluorescent sequencing (Johns Hopkins University Biosynthesis  and  Sequencing Facility).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	28	 A partial rat CAL truncated at the extreme N terminus was also obtained by hybridization screening of a rat hippocampus library (gift from Drs.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	29	Yeast Two-hybrid Assay-- rCFTRC4 (aa 1428-1474) and rCFTRC7 (aa 1428-1471) were subcloned into the BamHI/PstI sites of the pAS2-1 vector, in-frame with the Gal4 DNA-binding domain (CLONTECH).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	30	 rCFTRC4, rCFTRC7, or the empty pAS2-1 vector were co-transformed with rCAL (in pGAD10 vector) into Y190 cells.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Interactions were monitored by the LacZ expression on filter lifted from the transformed cells and by counting viable colonies on triple-minus plates (Leu, Trp, His, 35 mM 3-AT).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	32	Cell Culture and Transfection-- Human embryonic kidney cell line HEK 293 and colorectal carcinoma T84 cells (obtained from American Type Tissue Culture, Manassas, VA) were maintained in DMEM:F-12 (1:1), L-glutamine, penicillin, streptomycin, and 10% FCS.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	33	 African green monkey kidney cell (COS-7) and Madin-Darby Canine Kidney II cells (MDCK) (obtained from American Type Tissue Culture) were maintained in DMEM, L-glutamine, penicillin, streptomycin, 10% FCS.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Human bronchial epithelial cells (16HBE14o, gift of Dr.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Dieter Gruenert) were maintained in minimal essential medium, L-glutamine, penicillin, streptomycin, and 10% FCS.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Cystic fibrosis bronchial epithelial cells (IB3-1) (22) were maintained in LHC-8 basal medium, L-glutamine, penicillin, streptomycin, and 5% FCS.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	37	 LHC-8 basal medium was purchased from Biofluids.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	38	 All other media and components were purchased from Invitrogen (Carlsbad, CA).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	39	 L-Glutamine (2 mM), penicillin (100 units/ml), and streptomycin (100  microg/ml) were used.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	40	 COS-7, IB3-1, MDCK, and 16HBE14o cells were transfected using LipofectAMINE or LipofectAMINE 2000 (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	41	Antibody Production-- Glutathione S-transferase (GST) fusion protein of C-terminal polypeptide (aa 216-454) from human CAL was prepared using the GST gene fusion system (Amersham Biosciences, Inc.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	42	 The Precision protease-cleaved CAL C-terminal polypeptide was sent to a commercial producer (Covance, Princeton, NJ) to prepare rabbit polyclonal antibodies.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	43	Plasmid Construction-- The HA and myc-tagged constructs were made by PCR amplification and subcloning into SalI/NotI sites of the HA-tagged pRK5 vector (pRK5-HA) and myc-tagged pRK5 vector (pRK5-myc), respectively (gifts from Drs.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Huganir, Johns Hopkins University).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The resulting constructs contain HA or myc tag at the N terminus of the fusion proteins (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The GFP-tagged constructs were made by PCR amplification and subcloning into the SalI/NotI sites of the pEGFP-N1 vector (CLONTECH).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The resulting constructs contain EGFP tag at the C terminus of the fusion proteins (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	48	 All constructs were sequence-verified.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	49	Other plasmid constructs used were HA-NHE-RF (13), GFP-CFTR and GFP-CFTRTRL (7), and full-length vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein (VSVG) protein cloned into pcDNA3.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	50	Northern Blotting-- Multiple human tissue poly(A) RNA blots (MTB1 and MTB2, CLONTECH) containing 16 human tissue poly(A) RNAs were hybridized with full-length hCAL probes under stringent conditions according to the manufacturer's directions.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	51	Immunoprecipitation and Immunoblotting-- Cells were harvested and processed as described previously (23).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Briefly, cells were solubilized and lysates were spun at 14,000  x  g for 15 min to pellet insoluble material.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The supernatants were immunoprecipitated with 1  microg of monoclonal Myc antibody, HA antibody (Roche Molecular Biochemicals, Indianapolis, IL), R domain CFTR antibody (Genzyme, Cambridge, MA) or polyclonal GFP antibody (CLONTECH), and CAL antibody followed by Protein G-agarose beads for R domain CFTR antibody or Protein A-agarose beads for all other antibodies.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The eluted proteins were then subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blot followed by enhanced chemiluminescence (ECL, Amersham Biosciences, Inc.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	55	 GFP-CFTR was detected with monoclonal GFP antibody (1:1000; Roche Molecular Biochemicals).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	56	 HA-CAL, HA-NHE-RF, and other HA-tagged molecules were detected with monoclonal HA antibody (1:2000; Roche Molecular Biochemicals).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Endogenous CAL was detected by CAL antibodies.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Endogenous CFTR was detected by immunoprecipitation with R domain CFTR antibody (Genzyme) followed by protein kinase A phosphorylation as described previously (24).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	59	Pull-down Assay-- Biotinylated peptides were first incubated with immobilized NeutrAvidin beads (Pierce, catalog number 53151) in Nonidet P-40 lysis buffer at 4  degrees C for 2 h.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The beads were washed three times in Nonidet P-40 lysis buffer.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	61	 500  microg of cell lysate in a total volume of 500  microl was added to 25  microg of immobilized NeutrAvidin beads and tumbled at 4  degrees C for 2 h.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Samples were washed three times in Nonidet P-40 lysis buffer.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The bound proteins were eluted with 2 x  Laemmli sample buffer supplemented with 100  microM DTT at 42  degrees C for 30 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Eluted proteins were subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blot.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Biotinylated peptides used were CFTRCT, Biotin-SGSGSKPQIAALLEETEEEVQDTRL; CFTRCT2, Biotin-TEEEVQDTRL; and JN33, Biotin-MNRVIEEDGTSA (C terminus of human frizzled-3).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	66	Surface Biotinylation-- Biotinylated CFTR at the plasma membrane was precipitated as described in detail previously with some modifications (23).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Lysates were incubated with immobilized NeutrAvidin beads (Pierce, catalog number 53151), and bound proteins were eluted with 2 x  Laemmli sample buffer supplemented with 100  microM DTT at 42  degrees C for 30 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The eluted proteins were subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blot.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	69	 GFP-CFTR was detected with monoclonal GFP antibody (1:1000; Roche Molecular Biochemicals).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	70	 For VSVG surface biotinylation, COS-7 cells were transfected with full-length VSVG.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	71	 VSVG was detected with rabbit anti-VSVG polyclonal antibody (25).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	72	Pulse-chase and Cell Surface Biotinylation-- Two days after transfection, COS-7 cells were washed twice in methionine/cysteine free DMEM and then incubated for 60 min in methionine/cysteine free DMEM.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Cells were incubated in methionine/cysteine free DMEM containing Tran35S-label (250  microCi/ml) for 30 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Subsequently, cells were washed extensively with DMEM containing 10 mM of non-labeled methionine and 10 mM of unlabeled cysteine and chased in this solution for 0, 30, 60, 90, or 120 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Biotinylated CFTR at the plasma membrane was immunoprecipitated as described previously (23).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Radiolabeled CFTR was analyzed using a PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics, Sunnyvale, CA).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	77	 To examine the effect of CAL overexpression on the half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane, cells were incubated in methionine/cysteine free DMEM containing Tran35S-label (250  microCi/ml) for 3 h.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Cells were washed extensively with DMEM containing 10 mM non-labeled methionine and 10 mM unlabeled cysteine (containing penicillin/streptomycin and 10% FBS) and chased in this solution for 0, 12, 24, or 32 h.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Plasma membrane proteins were biotinylated at 0, 12, 24, or 32 h, and biotinylated CFTR was immunoprecipitated using a GFP monoclonal antibody.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Radiolabeled CFTR was analyzed using a PhosphorImager.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	81	Subcellular Fractionation-- For subcellular fractionation experiments, cells were trypsinized and collected by centrifugation.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The pellet were resuspended and incubated in ice-cold swelling buffer (1 mM DTT, 1 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EGTA, and Complete protease inhibitor mixture (Roche Molecular Biochemicals)) for 5 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Cells were collected by centrifugation and resuspended in buffer containing 0.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	84	25 M sucrose, 3 mM imidazole, pH 7.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	85	4, and Complete protease inhibitor mixture.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Lysate was obtained by homogenizing 10 strokes with a Dounce homogenizer.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	87	 After a pre-clarification centrifugation (100  x  g, 4  degrees C, 5 min), the lysate was spun in an Ultracentrifuge at 100,000  x  g for 45 min at 4  degrees C in a centrifuge (TL-100) using a TLA-100.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	88	2 rotor (both from Beckman Coulter).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	89	 -Tubulin monoclonal antibody was obtained from Amersham Biosciences, Inc.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	90	Confocal Microscopy-- Cultured cells were plated on glass coverslips 1-day post-transfection and examined 2-days post-transfection.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Cells were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde and permeabilized in 0.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Nonspecific binding sites were blocked with 5% normal goat serum (NGS).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Cells were stained with anti-HA monoclonal antibody (1:2000, Roche Molecular Biochemicals) or -adaptin (1:10, Sigma Chemical Co.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Louis, MO) in 5% NGS, washed with 1% bovine serum albumin, and incubated with goat anti-mouse Cy3 secondary antibodies in 1% NGS.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	95	 In some cases, cells were counter-stained with 4',6-diamidino-2-phenyl-indole (200  microg/ml, Sigma) to visualize nuclei.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Specimens were mounted and viewed on an LSM 410 confocal microscope (Zeiss).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	97	The immunofluorescence of rat tracheae was performed exactly as described (26).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Sections of frozen tracheae 6  microM thick were incubated with the following antibodies: rabbit-anti-CAL (1:500), mouse-anti--COP (1:50, Sigma), mouse-anti-58K (1:50, Sigma), and mouse-anti-TGN38 (1:50, Oncogene, Cambridge, MA).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	99	Identification and Tissue Distribution of CAL-- To identify PDZ domain proteins that interact with CFTR, we performed a yeast two-hybrid screen using the last 51 amino acids of the C terminus of rat CFTR (21).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Approximately 1  x  107 recombinants of a lung cDNA library fused to the Gal4 DNA activation domain were screened.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	101	 A novel protein designated as CAL (CFTR-Associated Ligand) was identified in this screening.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Fifty-six clones were isolated that encoded overlapping, partial sequences of CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Each contained the consensus sequence for a complete PDZ domain.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The interaction between CFTR and CAL was confirmed by re-transforming the cloned cDNA into yeast.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The interaction was bait-dependent, because it did not occur with the vector alone.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The interaction was also dependent upon the terminal amino acids of CFTR, because it did not occur with CFTR C-terminal constructs missing the terminal 4 or 7 amino acids (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	107	To obtain the full-length CAL, we screened a human lung cDNA library (CLONTECH) with rat CAL cDNA.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Seven independent and overlapping clones were identified.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The largest fragment contained a 1362-bp open reading frame, preceded 132 bp upstream by an in-frame stop codon.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	110	 A start codon consistent with a Kozak consensus sequence (27) was identified.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Translation in this reading frame predicts a 454-amino acid polypeptide with an estimated molecular mass of 50 kDa (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Hydropathy analysis did not detect any putative membrane-spanning regions (28).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	113	 No targeting signal sequence was detected.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The carboxyl half of CAL is identical to the amino half of an aberrant clone Homo sapiens RNA for ros1 oncogene (29).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	115	 This aberrant clone very likely results from the rearrangement of CAL to the human ros1 oncogene.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	116	 CAL mapped to chromosome 6q21A by aligning to a finished human genomic sequence (PAC 94G16) in GenBankTM (30).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	117	 A rat CAL cDNA that is highly homologous to the human CAL (91% identity, 94% conserved) was obtained in a hybridization screen (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Human CAL is also highly homologous (56% identity, 71% homology) to a protein identified in the Caenorhabditis elegans genome project (ZK849.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	119	2) suggesting an evolutionarily conserved function (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	120	 1A), as well as to a recently described protein (31).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	121	 In addition to a PDZ domain, CAL is predicted to have two coiled-coil domains.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Coiled-coil domains are also involved in protein-protein interactions (32).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The co-existence of coiled-coil domains and a PDZ domain suggests that CAL can potentially interact with multiple proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	124	View larger version (90K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	125	   Protein sequences, protein domains, and the tissue distribution of CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	126	 A, conceptual translation of human CAL cDNA (hCAL: accession number AF450008), a partial rat CAL cDNA (rCAL), and a putative C.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	127	2: GenBankTM accession number T28036).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The box depicts the PDZ domain (aa 280-363).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Underlined are the coiled-coil domains (aa 77-132 and 143-198).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	130	 B, tissue distribution of CAL mRNA.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Multiple human tissue poly(A) RNA blots were probed with CAL under stringent conditions.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	132	 A major transcript (~5 kb) was detected in all tissues.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	133	5, and 2 kb) were detected in a number of tissues.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	134	 a, full-length CAL consists of the N-terminal domain (N), the coiled-coil domain (CC, in green), the PDZ domain (PDZ, in red), and the C-terminal domain (C).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	135	 b, HA-tagged PDZ domain of CAL (aa 216-404).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	136	 c, myc-tagged N-terminal half of CAL, including N-terminal and coiled-coil domains (aa 1-279).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	137	 d, myc-tagged C-terminal half of CAL, including the C-terminal and PDZ domains (aa 216-454).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	138	 e, GFP-tagged N-terminal domain of CAL (aa 1-76).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	139	 f, GFP-tagged the N-terminal and coiled-coil domains of CAL (aa 1-279).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	140	 g, GFP-tagged PDZ domain and C-terminal of CAL (aa 216-454).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Blue filled circles indicate the positions of epitope tags.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	142	Northern blot analysis detected CAL in all human tissues examined, including CFTR-expressing tissues such as lung and pancreas (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The major transcript is 5 kb; in addition, some tissues have less abundant transcripts of different sizes (e.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The ubiquitous expression pattern and evolutionarily conserved protein sequence of CAL suggest an essential housekeeping role for its interaction with CFTR and other membrane proteins with similar PDZ binding motifs.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	145	Native Properties of CAL-- To study CAL in vivo, we generated a rabbit polyclonal antibody raised against the C-terminal domain of human CAL (see "Experimental Procedures").
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Consistent with the wide pattern of expression of CAL mRNA, CAL protein is endogenously expressed in several cell lines, including human bronchial epithelial cells, 16HBE14o (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	147	 2A), the colonic carcinoma T84 cell line (see related data in Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	148	 3D) and in the cystic fibrosis bronchial epithelial cell line, IB3-1 (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	149	 In Western blots, 16HBE14o cells display native CAL at two molecular masses, ~50-kDa and ~100-kDa bands (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	150	 2A, Lysate), when analyzed under non-reducing conditions, but only a single ~50-kDa band (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	151	 2A, +ME and +DTT) when analyzed under reducing conditions.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	152	 This raises the possibility that CAL can form a homo-multimer.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	153	 To test this further, we cotransfected HEK293 cells with HA-tagged full-length CAL (HA-CAL) and with each one of the following myc-tagged CAL constructs: full-length (myc-CAL), a construct containing only the C-terminal portion, including the PDZ domain (myc-CAL-PDZ-C), or a construct containing only the N-terminal amino acids, including the coiled-coil domains but minus the PDZ domain (myc-CAL-N-CC).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	154	 Only in cells containing the myc-tagged full-length CAL (first lane) and the N-terminal portion of CAL (third lane) was it possible to immunoprecipitate HA-tagged full-length CAL with anti-Myc antibodies (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The myc-labeled C-terminal portion is not capable of precipitating HA-tagged full-length CAL (second lane).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	156	 These data demonstrate that CAL forms a homo-multimer and the self-association domain lies in the N-terminal half of CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	157	View larger version (31K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	158	   The native properties of CAL.

0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Total lysates of 16HBE14o cells were incubated with two biotinylated C-terminal CFTR peptides (SGSGSKPQIAALLEETEEEVQDTRL) (lane 1) and (TEEEVQDTRL) (lane 2) or a control biotinylated peptide JN33 (lane 3).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	186	 JN33 peptide comprises the biotinylated C terminus of human frizzled-3 (Biotin-MNRVIEEDGTSA).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	187	 JN33 was used as a control for nonspecific binding.
