0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Total lysates of T84 cells were immunoprecipitated with CFTR antisera (Genzyme R domain monoclonal antibodies, CFTR ~ 160 kDa) (lane 1), protein A beads (lane 2), or CAL antisera (lane 3).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Top panel, Western blot using CAL antibody.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	192	 Bottom panel, autoradiography of radiolabeled CFTR (see "Experimental Procedures").
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	193	To determine if CAL is a membrane-associated or cytosolic protein, 16HBE14o cells were fractionated by centrifugation into pellet and soluble fractions.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	194	 CAL was found both in the pellet and soluble fractions (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	195	 2B) suggesting that CAL could associate with a membrane fraction.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	196	 To isolate further the sequences responsible for membrane association, we transfected various truncation constructs of GFP-tagged CAL into HEK293 cells and assayed again after subcellular fractionation.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	197	 GFP did not change the CAL membrane association (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	198	 CAL containing only the N-terminal domain and lacking both the coiled-coil and PDZ domains (CAL-N) was mostly within the soluble fraction and with some in the pellet (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	199	 CAL containing both the N-terminal and the coiled-coil domains but lacking a PDZ domain (CAL-N-CC) was found in the pelleted fraction (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	200	 CAL containing the PDZ and the C-terminal domains (CAL-PDZ-C) was soluble (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Although CAL has no predicted transmembrane sequences, the coiled-coil domains conferred membrane association, presumably by binding to resident Golgi coiled-coil proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	202	CAL Binds to CFTR-- To test whether full-length CAL and CFTR interact in animal cells, COS-7 cells were transiently transfected with an N-terminal-tagged, full-length HA-CAL and GFP-CFTR (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	203	 GFP-CFTR has single-channel and whole-cell current properties indistinguishable from wild type CFTR (23).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	204	 3, HA-CAL and GFP-CFTR were co-immunoprecipitated by a GFP polyclonal antibody (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Removal of the last 3 amino acid residues of the full-length CFTR (GFP-CFTRTRL) substantially reduced the ability of the truncated CFTR to interact with CAL (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	206	 3A, lane 3), suggesting the importance of the extreme C-terminal PDZ binding motif.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The faint band in lane 3 suggests that other weak binding sites for CAL may exist in CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	208	To test further whether the PDZ-interacting domain of CFTR is important for the CAL CFTR interaction, we conducted studies using the C terminus of CFTR and the PDZ domain of CAL (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	209	 COS-7 cells were transfected with the HA-tagged PDZ domain of CAL (HA-CAL-PDZ, aa 216-404) and the myc-tagged C terminus of CFTR (myc-CFTR-C, aa 1387-1480).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	210	 HA-CAL-PDZ was co-immunoprecipitated with myc-CFTR-C using an anti-Myc antibody (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	211	 As a control, HA-CAL-PDZ was not immunoprecipitated by the Myc antibody in the absence of myc-CFTR-C (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Because truncation of C-terminal CFTR residues (TRL) abolishes the binding (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	213	 3A), and binding can occur between portions containing only the PDZ domain of CAL and the C terminus of CFTR (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	214	 3B), the PDZ domain-mediated interaction is both necessary and sufficient for the CAL CFTR interaction.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	215	To confirm that the C terminus of CFTR was involved in the interaction, we immobilized biotinylated peptides corresponding to the C-terminal 8 and 24 residues of CFTR on NeutrAvidin beads and incubated the peptides with whole cell lysates prepared from 16HBE14o cells.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	216	 The bound fractions were examined by Western blot using CAL antisera.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Endogenous CAL bound to the immobilized CFTR peptides (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	218	 3C, lanes 1 and 2) but not to a control peptide (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Because the last 8 residues of CFTR bind to CAL, the interaction is likely to be direct and not mediated through other proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	220	To test whether CAL is present in a complex with CFTR in vivo, CFTR was immunoprecipitated from T84 cell lysates using an R-domain antibody from Genzyme and the precipitated fraction was analyzed by Western blotting using CAL antibody.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	221	 CAL was found in the CFTR immunoprecipitated fraction (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	222	 3D, lane 1) but not in the control fraction (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	223	 In a reciprocal experiment, CAL antisera also precipitated CFTR (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Taken together, these data suggest that CFTR and CAL associate in vivo.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	225	Golgi Localization of CAL-- Next, we examined the expression of native CAL by indirect immunofluorescence staining with rabbit anti-CAL antibodies.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	226	 In rat trachea, CAL immunostaining was seen in surface epithelium and submucosal glands (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	227	 The staining was bright in both acini (A) and the ducts (D) of submucosal glands (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	228	 CAL is predominantly localized in intracellular compartments of acinar cells and is weakly expressed in cytoplasm (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Under the same conditions, the pre-immune serum shows no significant staining (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	230	 To examine the subcellular localization of CAL, acinar cells were double-labeled with CAL antibodies and Golgi markers.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	231	 4 (d-f), CAL colocalized with trans-Golgi network marker TGN38.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	232	 CAL partially colocalizes with COP, a medial and cis-Golgi marker (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	233	 4, g-i) and 58K, a marker for ER-Golgi Intermediate Compartment (ERGIC; Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	234	 A similar staining pattern was observed in rat kidney cells (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	235	View larger version (33K):    Fig.

0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	238	 CAL immunostaining is bright in acini (A) and in ducts (D) of submucosal glands.

0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	245	To investigate the subcellular localization of CAL further, we examined the transiently transfected HA-tagged CAL using monoclonal HA.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	246	 In IB3 and MDCK cells, CAL, detected by a monoclonal antibody to the HA epitope tag, appeared predominantly in the juxtanuclear region as a single spot and overlapped with the expression of the trans-Golgi network (TGN) marker, -adaptin (Figs.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Some weak expression was observed in the cytoplasm.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Treatment with BFA is known to redistribute Golgi coat proteins to the cytosol (33).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	249	 In IB3 cells, BFA treatments (15 min) caused a redistribution of -adaptin and CAL to the cytoplasm (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	250	 BFA also caused a redistribution of CAL to the cytoplasm in 16HBE14o (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Endogenous CAL was found in the same subcellular localization when detected by anti-CAL antibody (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	252	View larger version (24K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	253	   Subcellular localization of CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	254	 A, IB3-1 cells were transfected with HA-CAL and grown on collagen-coated glass coverslips.

0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	264	CAL Reduces CFTR Cl Current-- To elucidate the functional consequence of CAL CFTR interaction, we examined how co-expression of CAL affects CFTR-mediated Cl conductance in COS-7 cells.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	265	 6 shows whole cell recordings and summary data measured using the whole cell patch clamp technique.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	266	 CFTR expressing cells were identified using GFP fluorescence.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	267	 6, A and B) produced cAMP-activated Cl currents typical of those we have shown previously for CFTR (23).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	268	 CFTR Cl currents were not observed in non-transfected or mock-transfected cells (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	269	 Co-transfection of CFTR and CAL resulted in greatly reduced currents despite the expression of CFTR (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	270	 In parallel experiments, the presence of both GFP-CFTR and HA-CAL was verified to prove that green-fluorescing cells were co-transfected with both CFTR and CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	271	 To test this outcome further, CFTR and CAL mRNA were injected into Xenopus oocytes.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	272	 In the absence of CAL, expression of CFTR mRNA resulted in cAMP-activated currents typical of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	273	 No such currents were present in non-injected oocytes.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Co-expression of CAL clearly inhibited CFTR-mediated cAMP-activated Cl currents (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	275	 These data show that CAL inhibits CFTR currents in both mammalian and Xenopus oocyte expression systems.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	276	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	277	   CAL affects CFTR Cl currents.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	278	 COS-7 cells were transfected with 1  microg of GFP-CFTR (A and B); 1  microg of GFP-CFTR and 3  microg of HA-CAL (C and D); 1  microg of GFP-CFTR, 3  microg of HA-CAL, and 1  microg of HA-NHE-RF (E and F).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	279	 Currents were measured by the whole cell patch clamp.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Typical recordings in which application of cpt-cAMP (250  microM) evoked chloride currents (A, C, and E) and the relationships of the steady-state current to the membrane voltage are shown (B, D, and F).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	281	 The cell was held at 0 mV, and 100-ms voltage steps were applied (100 through 100 mV, increments of 20 mV).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Open and solid circles indicate the basal and cpt-cAMP-stimulated current, respectively.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	283	 No cpt-cAMP-induced current responses were observed in mock transfected cells (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	284	 The bar graph (G) shows the maximum deviations of the current from each basal level during stimulation with 250  microM cpt-cAMP for 1 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	285	 Values are presented as mean  plus or minus  S.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	286	01 versus CFTR + CAL (Dunnett's method).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	287	 The numbers of experiments are given in parentheses.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	288	CAL Alters the Surface Expression of CFTR-- Because the inhibition of whole cell currents by CAL could be caused either by a direct inhibition of Cl channel activity or by a reduction in CFTR channel number at the cell surface, we investigated the effect of CAL on CFTR protein expression at the cell surface.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	289	 First, we co-expressed HA-CAL and GFP-CFTR in COS-7 cells and examined how CAL affects plasma membrane expression of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	290	 HA-CAL alone was detected primarily at the Golgi apparatus with some expression in the cytosol and near the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Wild type GFP-CFTR alone was found at both the plasma membrane and the ER (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	292	 In cells co-expressing HA-CAL and GFP-CFTR, CFTR disappeared from the cell membrane and clustered in an intracellular location (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	293	 Moreover, CAL colocalized with CFTR in the same intracellular location (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	294	View larger version (14K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	295	   Immunochemical characterization of CFTR and CAL interaction.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	296	 COS-7 cells were transfected with HA-CAL alone (a), GFP-CFTR alone (b), or co-transfected with CAL and GFP-CFTR (c, d, e), CAL was detected by monoclonal antibody to HA epitope (red).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	297	 CFTR was detected by GFP fluorescence (green).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	298	 Co-localization was visualized by image overlay (yellow).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Co-expression of CAL and CFTR results in the redistribution and complete colocalization of each protein into clusters.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	300	Next, we tested whether cell surface expression of GFP-CFTR in COS-7, as assessed by surface biotinylation, was altered by co-expression with HA-CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Approximately 10% of CFTR was expressed at the cell surface 40-48 h post-transfection.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Overexpression of HA-CAL reduced the expression of GFP-CFTR at the cell surface (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	303	 The reduction becomes more pronounced with increasing amounts of HA-CAL (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	304	 In contrast, overexpression of HA-CAL had no effect on plasma membrane expression of GFP-CFTRTRL (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	305	 To test whether overexpression of CAL causes a generalized suppression of membrane protein trafficking, we co-transfected COS-7 cells with HA-CAL and the vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein (VSVG), known to traffic to the plasma membrane through the cis-, medial, and trans-Golgi (34).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	306	 8C) had no effect in VSVG surface expression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Likewise, CAL has no effect on P-glycoprotein surface expression, which like CFTR is an apical membrane protein (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	308	 Taken together, these data show that inhibition of surface expression of CFTR by CAL is not cause by a nonspecific effect of protein overexpression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	309	 These data demonstrate that CAL selectively inhibits the cell surface expression of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	310	View larger version (52K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	311	   CAL affects cell surface CFTR expression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	312	 A, COS-7 cells were co-transfected with 3  microg of GFP-CFTR and various amounts of HA-CAL, HA-NHE-RF, and empty vector pRK5.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Cell surface membrane proteins were biotinylated and analyzed by Western blot using GFP monoclonal antibody (top panel).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Total lysates were analyzed using HA monoclonal antibody (middle panel) or GFP monoclonal antibody (bottom panel).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	315	 B, luminescent image analysis of cell surface GFP-CFTR expression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	316	 Values are the percentage of the cell surface CFTR in the total cell lysate.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Data are averages of three independent experiments.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	318	 C, cell surface VSVG expression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	319	 COS-7 cells were co-transfected with 3  microg of VSVG and various amounts of HA-CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Cell surface proteins were analyzed using a VSVG monoclonal antibody (top panel).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	321	 Total lysates were analyzed by Western blot using an HA monoclonal antibody (middle panel) or a VSVG monoclonal antibody (bottom panel).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	322	 D, co-immunoprecipitation of CFTR, CAL, and NHE-RF.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	323	 COS-7 cells were transfected with GFP-CFTR (3  microg), HA-CAL (6  microg), and HA-NHE-RF (3  microg) as indicated.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	324	 Lysates were immunoprecipitated with GFP polyclonal antibodies and analyzed using HA monoclonal antibody (top panel).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	325	 The cell lysates were analyzed using HA monoclonal antibody (bottom panel).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	326	 IP, immunoprecipitation; WB, Western blot.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	327	CAL Alters the Insertion of CFTR and the Half-life of CFTR in the Plasma Membrane-- To characterize the mechanism by which CAL suppresses the surface expression of CFTR, we conducted two sets of experiments.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	328	 First, we measured the rate of appearance of CFTR in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	329	 COS-7 cells were transfected with GFP-CFTR and HA-CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Two days later cells were labeled with 35S-Cys/Met (30 min) and chased for 0-120 min, and plasma membrane CFTR was detected by cell surface biotinylation.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	331	 CAL inhibits the expression of CFTR at the plasma membrane at least in part by decreasing the rate of appearance of CFTR in the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	332	 Second, we examined the effect of CAL on the half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	333	 COS-7 cells were transfected with GFP-CFTR and HA-CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	334	 Two days later, cells were labeled with 35S-Cys/Met (3 h) and chased for 0-32 h, and plasma membrane CFTR was then detected by cell surface biotinylation.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	335	 CAL also decreased the half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	336	 These data suggest that CAL may interact with components near the cell surface in determining the expression of CFTR at the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	337	View larger version (33K):    Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	338	   CAL affects insertion of CFTR to the plasma membrane as well as its half-life in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	339	 A, rate of CFTR appearance in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	340	 COS-7 cells were transfected with GFP-CFTR (3  microg) or GFP-CFTR (3  microg) and HA-CAL (3  microg).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Two days later cells were labeled with 35S-Cys/Met (30 min) and chased for 0-120 min.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	342	 The figure presents the rate of appearance of 35S-labeled CFTR in plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	343	 All data are relative to the amount of CFTR in the plasma membrane at t = 0 (CFTR cells) and are the averages of two independent experiments.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	344	 B, half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	345	 COS-7 cells were transfected with GFP-CFTR (3  microg) or GFP-CFTR (3  microg) and HA-CAL (3  microg).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	346	 Two days later plasma membrane proteins were biotinylated at t = 0, and cells were placed back into the incubator for 12, 24, or 32 h.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	347	 Proteins were analyzed by Western blot using GFP monoclonal antibody.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	348	The Roles of CAL and Other PDZ Domain Proteins in Determining Cell Surface CFTR Expression-- NHE-RF is a subplasma membrane PDZ domain protein that may anchor CFTR to the cytoskeleton.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	349	 To understand how PDZ domain proteins may work together in regulating CFTR trafficking and membrane organization, we examined the effect of overexpressing NHE-RF alone and co-expressing NHE-RF and CAL on CFTR cell surface expression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	350	 Overexpression of HA-NHE-RF did not change the plasma membrane expression of GFP-CFTR (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	351	 Co-expression of HA-NHE-RF with HA-CAL, however, restored cell surface GFP-CFTR expression (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	352	 Whereas CAL overexpression inhibited CFTR currents (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	353	 6, C, D, and G), these too were restored when NHE-RF was expressed along with CAL and CFTR (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	354	 Addition of NHE-RF alone with CFTR did not affect CFTR currents (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	355	 It has been shown that NHE-RF under certain conditions can enhance the open probability of CFTR in excised patches, but this stimulation was diminished when expression of NHE-RF was high (19).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	356	 6, GFP-tagged CFTR and HA-tagged NHE-RF were cotransfected at a ratio of 1:1 (by weight).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	357	 We also co-transfected GFP-CFTR and NHE-RF at a ratio of 1:3 (by weight) and observed the same results (data not shown).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	358	 Clearly, the effect of NHE-RF on restoring CFTR currents in cells overexpressing CAL parallels the restoration of CFTR in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	359	We identified a Golgi CFTR-interacting protein, CAL, that plays a role in regulating the plasma membrane expression of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	360	 CAL is the first PDZ domain protein identified that regulates the trafficking of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	361	 Biochemical evidence suggests that CAL can exist as a multimer that is mediated by domains in the N-terminal region.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	362	 CAL can form clusters of CFTR within the cell when overexpressed, suggesting that multimers of CAL may tether more than one CFTR within the cell as a mechanism to regulate export to the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	363	 This is consistent with data that overexpression of CAL suppresses CFTR expression at the cell surface.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	364	 In contrast to its effect on CFTR, CAL does not affect VSVG surface expression (see Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	365	 8C) or of P-glycoprotein expression, proteins that sort to the plasma membrane but do not have C-terminal PDZ interacting domains.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	366	 CAL also does not affect surface expression of CFTRTRL, eliminating the possibility that the inhibition of surface expression is due simply to the nonspecific effect of protein overexpression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Thus, the role of CAL is restricted to proteins such as CFTR with C-terminal, PDZ domains capable of binding CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	368	 Given the wide distribution of CAL in many tissues, it is likely that CAL can regulate the surface expression of molecules other than CFTR as long as they have a C-terminal domain capable of binding to CAL.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	369	 Although CAL is located primarily located within the Golgi, it is also found at the plasma membrane where it may also function (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	370	CAL contains two putative coiled-coil domains that play a role in membrane association.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	371	 Coiled-coil domains are found in SNARE proteins and a large number of Golgi resident proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	372	 Recently, it has been shown that CAL can bind to the Q-SNARE protein syntaxin 6, a protein whose primary function is unknown (31).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	373	 It is likely that the coiled-coil domains of CAL may mediate interactions with multiple Golgi proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	374	CAL overexpression also reduces the rate of appearance of CFTR in the plasma membrane suggesting that CAL may reduce the anterograde trafficking of CFTR to the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	375	 CAL also reduces the half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	376	 There are at least two possible scenarios to explain how CAL may interact with CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	377	 First, CAL may be part of an anterograde trafficking complex that controls CFTR movement from ER to Golgi and to the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	378	 CAL with two coiled-coil domains may tether CFTR to the Golgi as a requisite step in moving CFTR to the cell surface.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	379	 The overexpression of CAL may disrupt the stoichiometry of such an anterograde trafficking complex and favor retention of the CAL CFTR complex in the Golgi.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	380	 Second, CAL may also regulate the retrograde trafficking of CFTR from the Golgi to ER and perhaps promote the recycling of CFTR to the ER for degradation.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	381	 Thus CAL, like the PDZ protein GRASP 55/65, may play a role in vesicle budding and cargo selection in ER to Golgi and Golgi to membrane transport (35, 36).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	382	 8a, overexpression of CAL enhances the ER-localized, immature, and core-glycosylated form of CFTR (band B), which is localized to the ER.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	383	If the role of CAL is to tether CFTR to the Golgi, then what promotes CFTR trafficking to the plasma membrane? Clearly, the majority of CAL is located within the Golgi, yet some is also found near the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	384	 Also, membrane-biotinylated CFTR can be co-immunoprecipitated with CAL (data not shown) indicating that some CAL CFTR complexes do travel to the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	385	 Unlike CAL, other PDZ domain proteins such as NHE-RF and E3KARP are associated with the plasma membrane (12), suggesting that they play a key role in the function of CFTR at the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	386	 Our data show that, when CAL is overexpressed, CFTR trafficking to the plasma membrane is reduced but that suppression can be reversed by NHE-RF.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	387	 We hypothesize that, because CAL is more abundant in the Golgi, binding of CFTR to CAL may be favored.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	388	 As a CAL CFTR complex traffics to the plasma membrane where NHE-RF is abundant, CFTR may then bind to NHE-RF, which tethers CFTR to the actin-based cytoskeleton.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	389	 This tethering of CFTR to the plasma membrane increases the half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane resulting in the apical polarization of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	390	2 Overexpression of CAL increases its expression both in the Golgi and at the plasma membrane (data not shown), shifting the stoichiometry of the interaction of the CFTR with NHE-RF toward CAL and decreasing the half-life of CFTR in the plasma membrane.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	391	 Our data answer a critical question as to why more than one PDZ domain protein interacts with CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	392	 At least for CAL and NHE-RF, we show that both are concentrated in different locations within the cell and only transiently interact, most likely within the plasma membrane, to regulate the surface expression of CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	393	 Thus, this regulation by two or more PDZ domain proteins may allow for the precise regulation of CFTR surface expression.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	394	Other membrane proteins are found to bind to multiple PDZ domain proteins.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	395	 For example, the C termini of the GluR2/3 subunits of AMPA receptors bind to both GRIP/ABP, which contains 7 PDZ domains (37), and to PICK1, which contains a single PDZ domain as well as a domain that interacts with protein kinase C (38).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	396	 Phosphorylation of the C terminus of GluR2 by protein kinase C prevents its binding to GRIP but not to PICK1, which may contribute to the protein kinase C-induced rapid internalization of surface GluR2 subunits (39).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	397	 Likewise, the C terminus of the 1-adrenergic receptor binds to a pair of PDZ proteins, PSD-95 and MAGI-2 (40, 41).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	398	 Although the agonist-induced internalization of the 1-adrenergic receptor is attenuated by PSD-95 co-expression, it is markedly increased by co-expression with MAGI-2 (41).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	399	 These reports, as well as our present findings, support the notion that multiple PDZ domain proteins interact with the same short C terminus of a membrane protein to regulate its function.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	400	The precise mechanism of how CAL may hand off CFTR to NHE-RF remains unknown.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	401	 It is not clear whether it is driven strictly by mass balance, by affinity, or by a combination of these two.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	402	 In our co-expression system, NHE-RF expression is ~4.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	403	 Under these conditions, NHE-RF may sufficiently compete with CAL for CFTR binding strictly by mass action.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	404	 Immunofluorescence localization studies suggested that CFTR is present in both the apical membrane and in the subapical vesicles (42).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	405	 These findings were confirmed by cryoimmunogold electron microscopy (43).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	406	 The translocation of CFTR from the intracellular pool to the plasma membrane may be regulated by protein kinase A as observed by some investigators (44, 45) but not by others (23, 46).
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	407	 It is possible that CAL may pass CFTR off to NHE-RF in the subapical vesicles.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	408	 If so, it is important to determine the endogenous levels of CAL, NHE-RF and other CFTR binding proteins in these locations, as well as their relative affinity to CFTR in native tissues that express CFTR.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	409	 It is likely that these data, together with their regulation by protein kinase A and/or other physiological and pathophysiological stimuli, will provide a more comprehensive understanding of CFTR trafficking and its regulation in different native tissues.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	410	 Hubbard, and Peying Fong for critical reading of this manuscript.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	411	* This work was supported by Cystic Fibrosis Foundation Research Development Programs (to W.

0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	415	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	416	The nucleotide sequence(s) reported in this paper has been submitted to the GenBankTM/EBI Data Bank with accession number(s) AF450008.

0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	418	 of Physiology, Johns Hopkins University, School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD 21205.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	419	: 410-955-7166; Fax: 410-955-0461; E-mail: wguggino@bs.

0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	422	The abbreviations used are: CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; CAL, CFTR-associated ligand; NHE-RF, Na+/H+ exchanger regulatory factor; VSVG, vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein; PDZ, PSD-95/DLG/ZO-1; GFP, green fluorescence protein; HA, hemagglutinin; GST, glutathione S-transferase; BFA, Brefeldin A; cpt-cAMP, 8-chlorophenyl-thio-cAMP; DTT, dithiothreitol; ME, -mercaptoethanol; EZ-Link Sulfo-NHS-SS-Biotin, sulfosuccinimidyl-2-(biotin-amido)ethyl-1,3-dithiopropionate; TBS, Tris-buffered saline; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; ER, endoplasmic reticulum; aa, amino acid(s); 3-AT, 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole; DMEM, Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium; FCS, fetal calf serum; MDCK, Madin-Darby canine kidney cells; NGS, normal goat serum; PS, pipette solution; TGN, trans-Golgi network; ERGIC, ER-Golgi intermediate compartment; DIDS, 4,4'-diisothiocyanatostilbene-2,2'-disulfonic acid.
0.44482413.11707463.html.plaintext.txt	423	Copyright   2002 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	0	Voltage-dependent Gating of the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator Cl- Channel Zhiwei Cai, Toby S.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Physiology, University of Bristol, School of Medical Sciences, University Walk, Bristol BS8 1TD, UK.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Sheppard, Department of Physiology, School of Medical Sciences, University Walk, University of Bristol, Bristol BS8 1TD, UK.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Fax: (44) 117 928 8923; email: D.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	4	Key Words: ATP-binding cassette transporter   cystic fibrosis   chloride ion channel   channel gating   voltage dependence.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	5	In cell-attached membrane patch recordings, the single-channel current-voltage (I-V) relationship of CFTR outwardly rectifies (Berger et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	6	 (1991) attributed this outward rectification to Goldman-type rectification caused by the Cl- concentration gradient.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	7	 However, subsequent studies have offered alternative explanations.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	8	 (1993) proposed that rectification is a function of the concentration and permeability of anions within the cell.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Second, Fischer and Machen (1994) attributed rectification to high frequency gating of the CFTR Cl- channel at negative voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Third, studies by a number of investigators have demonstrated that large anions cause a voltage-dependent block of the CFTR Cl- channel when they are present in the intracellular solution (McDonough et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	11	, 1994; Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1996; Sheppard and Robinson, 1997; Zhou et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	12	 These anions bind within a deep wide vestibule at the intracellular end of the CFTR pore to prevent Cl- permeation (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1996; Sheppard and Robinson, 1997; Hwang and Sheppard, 1999; Zhou et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	13	 This block of the CFTR Cl- channel by large intracellular anions is reminiscent of the effect of intracellular cations on inward-rectifier K+ channels (Kir channels; Hille, 2001).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Inward rectification of these K+ channels is caused by voltage-dependent block by Mg2+ and polyamines found in the cytoplasm of the cell (Vandenberg, 1987; Lopatin et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Thus, as first proposed by Tabcharani et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	16	 (1991), the outward rectification of CFTR Cl- channels observed in cell-attached membrane patches is likely caused by voltage-dependent block by large anions found in the cytoplasm of the cell (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1998a, 1999).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	17	When inside-out membrane patches excised from cells expressing wild-type human CFTR are bathed in symmetrical Cl--rich solutions, the single-channel I-V relationship of CFTR is linear (e.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	18	 However, we previously observed inward rectification of wild-type CFTR Cl- currents in excised membrane patches from C127 cells expressing wild-type human CFTR (Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	19	, 2000; Cai and Sheppard, 2002).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	20	 At negative voltages, the I-V relationship was linear, whereas at positive voltages, the I-V relationship exhibited inward rectification that was most marked at voltages above +50 mV (Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	21	, 2000; Cai and Sheppard, 2002).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Using excised membrane patches from baby hamster kidney (BHK) cells expressing wild-type human CFTR, Linsdell and colleagues observed similar results in some studies (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1999; Linsdell and Gong, 2002), but not in others (e.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	23	, 1998; Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1998b).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	24	 (1996) reported inward rectification of CFTR Cl- channels reconstituted into planar lipid bilayers.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	25	 In this study, we investigate the mechanism of inward rectification of the CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	26	 We employ voltage-ramp and -step protocols to study macroscopic and single-channel currents in excised inside-out membrane patches from cells expressing wild-type human and murine CFTR and kinetic modeling to analyze channel gating.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	27	Electrophysiology CFTR Cl- channels were recorded in excised inside-out membrane patches using an Axopatch 200A patch-clamp amplifier (Axon Instruments, Inc.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	28	) and pCLAMP data acquisition and analysis software (version 6.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	29	) as described previously (Hamill et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	30	, 1981; Sheppard and Robinson, 1997).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The established sign convention was used throughout; currents produced by positive charge moving from intra- to extracellular solutions (anions moving in the opposite direction) are shown as positive currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	32	Both the pipette (extracellular) and bath (intracellular) solutions contained (mM): 140 NMDG, 3 MgCl2, 1 CsEGTA, and 10 TES, adjusted to pH 7.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	33	3 with HCl, ([Cl-], 147 mM; free [Ca2+],  < 10-8 M).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Patch pipettes had resistances of 10 to 30 M when filled with this solution.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The intracellular solution was maintained at 37 degrees C using a temperature-controlled microscope stage (Brook Industries).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	36	After excision of inside-out membrane patches, we added the catalytic subunit of PKA (75 nM) and ATP (1 mM) to the intracellular solution within 5 min of patch excision to activate CFTR Cl- channels.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	37	 To prevent the rundown of CFTR Cl- channels in excised membrane patches, we added PKA to all intracellular solutions.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Unless otherwise indicated, membrane patches were voltage-clamped at -50 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	39	To investigate the voltage dependence of CFTR, we used either membrane patches containing large numbers of active channels or membrane patches containing five or less active channels.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The number of channels in a membrane patch was determined from the maximum number of simultaneous channel openings observed during the course of an experiment, as previously described (Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Using multichannel patches, we generated macroscopic I-V relationships by averaging currents generated by 15 to 30 ramps of voltage each of 2-s duration; holding voltage was -50 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Basal currents with no active CFTR Cl- channels recorded in the absence of PKA (75 nM) and ATP (1 mM) were subtracted from those recorded in the presence of PKA and ATP to generate the I-V relationship of CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	43	 To generate ensemble currents, we applied the same voltage protocol used with multichannel patches to membrane patches containing five or less active channels 50 to 100 times.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	44	 We subtracted basal currents recorded in the absence of PKA (75 nM) and ATP (1 mM) from currents recorded in the presence of PKA and ATP before averaging subtracted currents to generate the ensemble current.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	45	 For single-channel studies of the voltage dependence of CFTR, voltage was stepped from -100 to +100 mV in 20-mV increments of 30 to 60 s duration.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Alternatively, voltage was clamped at a single voltage for 2 to 4-min periods to acquire sufficient data for analyses of gating kinetics.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	47	CFTR Cl- currents were initially recorded on digital audiotape using a digital tape recorder (model DTR-1204, Biologic Scientific Instruments; Intracel Ltd.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	48	 On playback, records were filtered with an eight-pole Bessel filter (model 902LPF2, Frequency DevicesTM; SCENSYS Ltd.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	49	) at a corner frequency of 500 Hz and acquired using a Digidata 1200 interface (Axon Instruments, Inc.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	50	) and pCLAMP software at sampling rates of either 1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	51	0 kHz (voltage-ramp protocols) or 5 kHz (single-channel studies).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	52	 To determine whether a sampling rate of 1 kHz was suitable for the construction of I-V relationships, we compared the effects of acquiring voltage-ramp protocols at sampling rates of 1 and 5 kHz.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	53	 1 B demonstrates that identical I-V relationships were obtained using the two different sampling rates.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	54	To measure single-channel current amplitude (i), Gaussian distributions were fit to current amplitude histograms.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Chord conductance was calculated by dividing unitary current by the difference between the applied voltage and the reversal potential.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	56	 For open probability (Po) and kinetic analyses, lists of open open and closed times were created using a half-amplitude crossing criterion for event detection.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Transitions  < 1 ms in duration were excluded from the analyses.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Single-channel open and closed time histograms were created using logarithmic x-axes with 10 bins decade-1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Histograms were fit with one or more component exponential functions using the maximum likelihood method.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	60	 To determine which component function fitted best, the log-likelihood ratio test was used and considered statistically significant at a value of 2.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Burst analysis was performed as described by Carson et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	62	 (1995a), using a burst delimiter (tc; the time that separates interburst closures from intraburst closures) determined by analyses of closed time histograms (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Closures longer than tc were considered to define interburst closures, whereas closures shorter than this time were considered gaps within bursts.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The mean interburst interval (TIBI) was calculated using the equation:.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	65	(1)where Tb = (mean burst duration) x (open probability within a burst).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Mean burst duration (TMBD) and open probability within a burst (Po(burst)) were determined directly from experimental data using pCLAMP software.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	67	 TMBD was determined from histograms of burst duration data plotted with logarithmic x-axes with 10 bins decade-1, Po(burst) was calculated using burst duration and closed times within bursts data, and Po was calculated as described previously (Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Only membrane patches that contained a single active channel were used for single-channel kinetic analyses.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	69	Modeling of Single-channel Kinetics To perform maximum likelihood analysis and develop kinetic models of CFTR channel gating, we used the QuB software suite (www.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	70	, 1997) to analyze data from membrane patches that contained only a single active channel as described previously (Cai and Sheppard, 2002).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	71	 In brief, digitized current records generated by pCLAMP software were imported with no further filtering and baseline corrected (program PRE).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Using a recursive Viterbi algorithm (program SKM), idealized currents were produced.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Finally, rate constants for kinetic models were calculated from the idealized current dwell time sequence using a maximum likelihood approach (program MIL).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	74	 For consistency with analyses using pCLAMP software, transitions  < 1 ms were excluded.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	75	To investigate the voltage dependence of rate constants, we first calculated rate constants at equivalent positive and negative voltages from individual membrane patches.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	76	 If rate constants are voltage dependent, the relationship between rate constant and voltage is described by the single exponential function:.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	77	(2)where k is the unknown rate constant, k0 is the rate constant at unitary ligand concentration and zero voltage, P is the ligand concentration, and V is voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	78	(3)where zg is the equivalent gating charge (defined as the product of the unit charge moved (z) times the fraction of the electric field ()), qe is the elementary charge, kB is the Boltzmann's constant, and T is the absolute temperature.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The parameters k1 and k0 are intrinsic properties of the channel that do not vary with experimental conditions (Qin et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	80	 To determine k0 and k1, we simultaneously fitted combined sets of data obtained at equivalent positive and negative voltages (e.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	81	,  plus or minus 75 mV) from the same membrane patch.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Because the ligand concentration (P) is constant under the experimental conditions employed ([ATP]i = 1 mM), the value of P is assumed to be 1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Finally, using values of k0 and k1, we simulated the effects of voltage on rate constants over a wide range of voltages (program SIM; Qin et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	84	Reagents The catalytic subunit of PKA was purchased from Promega UK.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	85	 ADP (disodium salt), ATP (disodium salt), pyrophosphate (tetrasodium salt), and TES were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	86	 All other chemicals were of reagent grade.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	87	Statistics Results are expressed as means  plus or minus  SEM of n observations.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	88	 To compare sets of data, we used either a one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) or Student's paired t test.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Differences were considered statistically significant when P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	90	 All tests were performed using SigmaStatTM (version 2.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	91	Online Supplemental Material To investigate the possibility that inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents is caused by a component of the recording solutions, we examined the effect on CFTR of a number of factors in the bath and pipette solutions.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	92	 These included the nature of the biological buffer (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	93	 S1) and the monovalent cation used in our recording solutions (Figs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Supplemental figures and text is available at http://www.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	95	View larger version (17K):    FIGURE 1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	96	 I-V relationship of CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	97	 (A) Current traces from an excised inside-out membrane patch from a C127 cell expressing wild-type human CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The recordings were made in the absence (middle) and presence (bottom) of PKA (75 nM) and ATP (1 mM) in the intracellular solution.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The basal recording is the current in response to a single ramp of voltage with no active CFTR Cl- channels, whereas the recording in the presence of PKA + ATP is the average current of 30 ramps of voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Holding voltage was -50 mV and the membrane patch was bathed in symmetrical 147 mM NMDGCl solutions.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	101	 The voltage ramp protocol used is shown and currents were acquired at a sampling rate of 1 kHz as described in the MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	102	 (B) I-V relationship constructed by subtracting the basal trace from the PKA + ATP trace shown in A.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The inset shows the I-V relationship of the same data acquired at a sampling rate of 5 kHz (abscissa: -100 to +100 mV; ordinate: -30 to +30 pA).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	104	 (C) I-V relationship of CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Data are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 10) at each voltage calculated by expressing individual current values measured from -100 to +100 mV in 10-mV increments as a percentage of the current value at -100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Error bars are smaller than symbol size.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The continuous line is the fit of a second order regression to the data.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	108	 The dotted line shows the predicted ohmic I-V relationship.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	109	  To further investigate the inward rectification of CFTR, we studied single Cl- channels.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	110	 We reasoned that if the I-V relationship of individual CFTR Cl- channels exhibits inward rectification, summation of single-channel currents should reproduce the rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	111	 To test this hypothesis, we applied the same voltage protocol used to study macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents to membrane patches containing five or less active channels.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	112	 2 A shows the activity of a single CFTR Cl- channel evoked by five ramps of voltage from -100 to +100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Visual inspection of these single-channel records suggests that current amplitude at negative voltages is larger than that at positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Consistent with this idea, the ensemble current generated by averaging the single-channel currents elicited by 70 voltage ramps inwardly rectifies (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Importantly, the extent of the inward rectification observed for the ensemble current agrees closely with that of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents (Figs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	116	 For example, at +100 mV the magnitude of the macroscopic CFTR Cl- current was 74  plus or minus  2% (n = 10) of that at -100 mV while that of the ensemble current was 79  plus or minus  3% (n = 5) of that at -100 mV (P > 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	117	 These data indicate that voltage-dependent changes in the single-channel activity of CFTR account for the inward rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	118	View larger version (27K):    FIGURE 2.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Summation of single-channel currents reproduces the rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	120	 (A) Representative recordings of a single CFTR Cl- channel in an excised inside-out membrane patch elicited by a depolarizing voltage ramp from -100 to +100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	121	 ATP (1 mM) and PKA (75 nM) were continuously present in the intracellular solution.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The dotted line indicates the zero current level.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	123	 For the purpose of illustration, single-channel records were digitally refiltered at 100 Hz.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	124	 (B) Ensemble current obtained by averaging 70 ramps of voltage from the same experiment as that shown in A.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	125	 The continuous line is the fit of a second-order regression to the data.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	126	 (C) I-V relationship expressed as a percentage of the current value at -100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Data are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 5) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	128	  Effect of Voltage on the Single-channel Activity of CFTR In principal, the inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents might be caused by a voltage-dependent change in first, the number of active channels; second, current flow through open channels; third, channel gating and hence, Po.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	129	 To discriminate between these different possibilities, we investigated the effect of voltage on the single-channel activity of CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	130	 3 compares the activity of a single CFTR Cl- channel phosphorylated by PKA and ATP at -75 and +75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	131	 These single-channel records suggest that inward rectification was not caused by a decrease in the number of active channels present at positive voltages (n = 6; Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	132	 On the contrary, the single-channel data suggest that inward rectification is caused by both a reduction in i and changes in gating behavior at positive voltages (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	133	View larger version (55K):    FIGURE 3.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Effect of voltage on the single-channel activity of CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Representative recordings of a single CFTR Cl- channel at -75 mV (top) and +75 mV (bottom).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	136	 ATP (1 mM) and PKA (75 nM) were continuously present in the intracellular solution.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Dotted lines indicate the closed channel state.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Downward and upward deflections correspond to channel openings at -75 mV and +75 mV, respectively.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	139	 For the purpose of illustration, single-channel records were filtered at 500 Hz and digitized at 1 kHz.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	140	  The decrease in i at positive voltages is not readily apparent by visual inspection of single-channel records (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	141	 However, it is evident from single-channel current amplitude histograms and the I-V relationship of CFTR (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	142	 4 A shows histograms of the distribution of current values at  plus or minus 50 and  plus or minus 75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	143	 When compared with i values at negative voltages, the reduction in i at +50 mV was very slight and that at +75 mV was small (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Nevertheless, like that of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents, the single-channel I-V relationship of CFTR weakly inwardly rectified at positive voltages (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Consistent with these data, the chord conductance of CFTR decreased from 11.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	146	3 pS at +100 mV (n = 10; P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	147	View larger version (31K):    FIGURE 4.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Single-channel conductance of CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	149	 (A) Single-channel current amplitude histograms of a single CFTR Cl- channel at the indicated voltages recorded using the conditions described in Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	150	 At negative voltages (top), the closed-channel amplitude is shown on the right, whereas at positive voltages (bottom), the closed channel amplitude is shown on the left.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Linear x-axes with 20 bins decade-1 were used for the histograms and the continuous lines represent the fit of Gaussian distributions to the data.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	152	 The vertical dashed lines indicate the position of the open and closed channel levels at negative voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	153	 (B) Single-channel I-V relationship of CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	154	 (C) Relationship between chord conductance and voltage for the data shown in B.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Chord conductance was calculated as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	156	  Comparison of the macroscopic and single-channel I-V relationships of CFTR (Figs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	157	 1 C and 4 B) suggests that the decrease in i at positive voltages is insufficient to account for the rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	158	 For example, at +100 mV single-channel current amplitude (i) = 88  plus or minus  2% of that at -100 mV (n = 10), whereas at +100 mV macroscopic current (I) = 74  plus or minus  2% of that at -100 mV (n = 10; P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	159	 In agreement with these data, Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	160	 3 demonstrates that the pattern of channel gating at +75 mV differs strikingly from that observed at -75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	161	 At negative voltages the gating behavior of CFTR was characterized by bursts of channel activity, interrupted by brief flickery closures, separated by longer closures between bursts (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	162	 In contrast, at positive voltages both the duration of bursts as well as the long closed periods separating bursts were decreased in length (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	163	To quantify the changes in gating behavior at positive voltages, we used membrane patches that contained only a single active channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	164	 We analyzed histograms of open and closed times at  plus or minus 75 mV to determine how voltage alters the distribution of open and closed times.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	165	 At both -75 and +75 mV, open and closed time histograms of CFTR were best fitted with one- and two-component functions, respectively (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	166	 However, at positive voltages the distribution of open and closed times was altered in several ways.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	167	 First, the open time constant (O1) was decreased by 52% (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Second, the fast closed time constant (C1) that describes the flickery closures which interrupt channel openings was increased by 79%, while its share of the closed time distribution expanded slightly from 61 to 66% (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Third, the slow closed time constant (C2) that describes the long closures which separate channel openings was decreased by 27%, while its share of the closed time distribution contracted slightly from 39% to 34% (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	170	 As a consequence of these changes in channel gating, the number of events per minute at +75 mV was double that at -75 mV (Table I).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	171	View larger version (34K):    FIGURE 5.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Analysis of the dwell time histograms of a single CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	173	 (A and B) Representative open and closed time histograms for a single CFTR Cl- channel recorded at -75 and +75 mV, respectively, using the conditions described in Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	174	 For open time histograms, the continuous line is the fit of a one-component exponential function.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	175	 For closed time histograms, the continuous line is the fit of a two-component exponential function.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The dotted lines show the individual components of the exponential functions.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Logarithmic x-axes with 10 bins decade-1 were used for both open and closed time histograms.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	178	 (C) Burst duration (top), interburst interval (middle), and Po (bottom) of CFTR at the indicated voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Columns and error bars indicate means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 10) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	180	 For the Po data, filled circles connected by lines represent individual experiments and the open circles are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 10).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	181	 The asterisks indicate values that are significantly different from the -75 mV data (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Burst duration and interburst interval were calculated as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	183	  View this table:    TABLE I Effect of Voltage on the Open and Closed Time Constants of Wild-type CFTR Cl- Channels.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	184	  To further investigate the changes in gating behavior at positive voltages, we performed an analysis of bursts using a burst delimiter (tc) determined as the nadir between the two populations of channel closures (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	185	 5, A and B, and Table I; Carson et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	186	32 ms (n = 10), whereas at +75 mV, tc = 18.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The large difference between the fast and slow time constants at both negative and positive voltages, suggests that errors caused by misclassification of bursts should be rare.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	188	 5 C demonstrates that both burst duration and interburst interval were significantly decreased at +75 mV (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	189	 As a result, the Po of CFTR at +75 mV was only slightly decreased compared with the value at -75 mV, although the difference was statistically significant (P = 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	190	 These data suggest that voltage alters the gating behavior of the CFTR Cl- channel without noticeably changing Po.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	191	Thus, our data suggest that the single-channel behavior of CFTR accounts for the rectification of CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	192	 CFTR Cl- current is determined by the product of the number of CFTR Cl- channels in the membrane patch (N), the single-channel current amplitude (i), and the probability (Po) that a single channel is open: ICFTR = N x i x Po.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	193	 If we set each of these variables to 100% for the -100 mV data, we can compare the CFTR Cl- current generated at -100 and +100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Table II presents values of each variable, the predicted CFTR Cl- current determined by calculating N x i x Po and the observed value of CFTR Cl- current.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Differences between the observed and predicted values are likely accounted for by using data at  plus or minus 75 mV and not  plus or minus 100 mV to calculate Po and the subtraction of basal currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	196	1 Nevertheless, the predicted and observed values agree closely.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	197	View this table:    TABLE II Comparison of Predicted CFTR Cl- Current, N x i x Po, and Measured CFTR Cl- Current at -100 and +100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	198	  Voltage Changes the Gating Kinetics of CFTR To understand better how voltage changes the pattern of channel gating, we used maximum likelihood analysis and kinetic modeling.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Using this approach, Winter et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	200	 (1994) demonstrated that the gating kinetics of single phosphorylated wild-type CFTR Cl- channels are described equally well by the linear three-state schemes shown in Figs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	201	 In these schemes, C1 represents the long duration closed state separating channel openings, C2 the brief flickery closures that interrupt channel openings, and O the open state.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Transitions between the three states are described by the rate constants ss1, ss2, 1 and 2.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Using the C1C2O kinetic scheme, intracellular ATP regulates CFTR at the transition between C1 and C2: as the ATP concentration is raised, ss1 increases (Winter et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	204	 In contrast, none of the other transition rates were altered significantly by ATP (Winter et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	205	 Similar analyses of our own data support this model of ATP-dependent regulation of CFTR channel gating (Cai and Sheppard, 2002).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	206	 They also suggest that using the C1OC2 kinetic scheme, intracellular ATP regulates CFTR at the transition between C1 and O with ss1 increasing at elevated ATP concentrations while the other rate constants remain unchanged (unpublished data).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	207	 As the gating behavior of CFTR is equally well described by the kinetic schemes C1C2O and C1OC2, we used both schemes to determine how voltage regulates CFTR channel gating.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	208	View larger version (24K):    FIGURE 6.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Effect of voltage on the rate constants of the C1C2O kinetic scheme.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	210	 (A) The C1C2O kinetic scheme that describes CFTR channel gating (Winter et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	211	 States C1, C2, and O represent two closed states and one open state, respectively, while ss1, ss2, 1, and 2 represent the rate constants describing transitions between these states.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	212	 States enclosed within the dashed box represent the bursting state.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	213	 (B) Rate constants at the indicated voltages determined by the maximum likelihood fit to the model shown in A.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Data are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 6) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	215	 The asterisks indicate values that are significantly different from the -75 mV data (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	216	 (C) The relationship between the rate constants ss1 (filled circles), ss2 (filled diamonds), 1 (open circles) and 2 (open diamonds) and voltage for the C1C2O model.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Values are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 5 to 6) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	218	 The continuous lines represent fits of the single exponential function k=k0Pexp (Eq.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	219	 2) as described in the MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	220	 6 B shows the rate constants for the C1C2O kinetic scheme (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	221	, 1994) at -75 and +75 mV calculated using the QuB software suite (www.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	222	 When compared with the -75 mV data, 1 was decreased by 53% at +75 mV, 2 was increased by 88%, ss2 was decreased by 24%, but ss1 was unchanged.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The duration of bursts is influenced first by 1, the rate constant that determines the velocity with which the channel leaves the bursting state, and second by 2 and ss2, the rate constants that control opening and closing transitions within the bursting state (see Eq.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The decrease in 1 delays the exit from the bursting state and hence, increases the duration of bursts at +75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	225	 In contrast, the decrease in ss2 and particularly the increase in 2 both act to decrease the duration of bursts at +75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Thus, the data suggest that depolarized voltages produce reciprocal changes in 1 and the rate constants within the bursting state (i.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	227	, 2 and ss2) that tend to offset each other.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	228	 7 B shows the rate constants for the C1OC2 kinetic scheme (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	229	 When compared with the -75 mV data, 1 was increased by 27% at +75 mV, ss1 was increased by 29%, ss2 was increased by 118% and 2 was decreased by 34%.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	230	 As with the C1C2O kinetic scheme, the duration of bursts in the C1OC2 model is influenced by 1, 2, and ss2 (see Eq.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	231	 However, unlike the C1C2O kinetic scheme, the changes in 2 and ss2 have little effect on burst duration at +75 mV while the increase in 1 accelerates the rate of exit from the bursting state and hence, decreases the duration of bursts at +75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Similarly, the increase in ss1, the rate constant that determines the velocity with which the channel enters the bursting state, causes a reduction in the interburst interval at +75 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	233	View larger version (24K):    FIGURE 7.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Effect of voltage on the rate constants of the C1OC2 kinetic scheme.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	235	 (A) The C1OC2 kinetic scheme that describes CFTR channel gating (Winter et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	236	 (B) Rate constants at the indicated voltages determined by the maximum likelihood fit to the model shown in A.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	237	 (C) The relationship between the rate constants ss1 (filled circles), ss2 (filled diamonds), and 1 (open circles) and voltage for the C1OC2 scheme.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The inset shows the relationship between the rate constant 2 and voltage for the same scheme.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	239	  To investigate whether the changes in rate constants counteract each other, we used the rate constants for the C1C2O and C1OC2 kinetic schemes to calculate values of (i) burst duration, (ii) mean duration of gaps within bursts, (iii) interburst interval, and (iv) Po and compared these values with those derived using pClamp software.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	240	 First, using the kinetic scheme C1C2O, mean burst duration is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	241	 4, mean burst duration decreased from 158  plus or minus  17 ms (n = 6) at -75 mV to 130  plus or minus  18 ms (n = 6) at +75 mV, a decrease of 18% (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Using the kinetic scheme C1OC2, mean burst duration is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	243	 5, mean burst duration decreased from 145  plus or minus  18 ms (n = 6) at -75 mV to 120  plus or minus  16 ms (n = 6) at +75 mV, a reduction of 17% (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	244	 These data are in close agreement with the mean burst duration values determined using rate constant data for the C1C2O kinetic scheme and pClamp software (19% decrease; Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	245	 They indicate that burst duration decreases at positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	246	Second, using the kinetic scheme C1C2O, mean duration of gaps within bursts is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	247	 6, mean duration of gaps within bursts increased from 1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	248	17 ms (n = 6) at +75 mV, an increase of 57% (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	249	 Using the kinetic scheme C1OC2, mean duration of gaps within bursts is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	250	 7, mean duration of gaps within bursts increased from 1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	251	15 ms (n = 6) at +75 mV, an increase of 52% (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	252	 These data are in reasonable agreement with the values of mean duration of gaps within bursts calculated using rate constant data for the C1C2O kinetic scheme and excellent agreement with values determined using pClamp software (-75 mV, 2.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	253	25 ms (n = 10); 52% increase; P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	254	 They indicate that bursts become interrupted by longer brief closures at positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	255	Third, using the kinetic scheme C1C2O, an approximate value of interburst interval can be determined using the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	256	 8, interburst interval decreased from 113  plus or minus  18 ms (n = 6) at -75 mV to 84  plus or minus  11 ms (n = 6) at +75 mV, a decrease of 26% (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Using the kinetic scheme C1OC2, interburst interval is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	258	 9, interburst interval decreased from 106  plus or minus  18 ms (n = 6) at -75 mV to 80  plus or minus  11 ms (n = 6) at +75 mV, a reduction of 25% (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	259	 These data are in very good agreement with the values of interburst interval calculated using rate constant data for the C1C2O kinetic scheme, but only reasonable agreement with those values determined using pClamp software (16% decrease; Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	260	 They indicate that interburst interval decreases at positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	261	Fourth, using the kinetic scheme C1C2O, Po is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	262	 10, Po decreased slightly from 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	263	04 (n = 6) at +75 mV, a decrease of 2% (P > 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	264	 Using the kinetic scheme C1OC2, Po is given by the equation (Sakmann and Trube, 1984):.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	265	 11, Po decreased marginally from 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	266	04 (n = 6) at +75 mV, a reduction of 2% (P > 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	267	 These data are in very good agreement with the values of Po calculated using rate constant data for the C1C2O kinetic scheme and good agreement with values determined using pClamp software (5% decrease; Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	268	 However, the decrease in Po calculated using rate constant data was not statistically significant, unlike that calculated using pClamp software.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	269	 We attribute this subtle effect of voltage on Po to the changes in mean burst duration and interburst interval counterbalancing each other.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	270	To understand better the voltage dependence of CFTR channel gating, we calculated rate constants for both kinetic schemes at -50, -20, +20, and +50 mV and fitted the data using the single exponential function k=k0Pexp (Eq.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	271	 To determine whether rate constants changed with voltage, we performed one-way ANOVAs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Considering first the C1C2O kinetic scheme, this test indicated that ss1 and ss2 did not change significantly with voltage (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	273	2 In contrast, a significant difference was found between voltage and 2 and 1 (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	274	2 Considering next the C1OC2 kinetic scheme, one-way ANOVAs indicated that 1 and ss2 did not change significantly with voltage (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	275	 In contrast, a significant difference was found between voltage and ss1 and 2 (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Thus, in both kinetic schemes voltage has profound effects on the gating behavior of the CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	277	 However, because in both kinetic schemes the effects of voltage on the rate constants tend to oppose one another, CFTR Cl- currents exhibit only weak voltage-dependence.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	278	Finally, using the data in Figs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	279	 6 C and 7 C, we derived values of equivalent gating charge for each of the rate constants in the two kinetic schemes (Tables III and IV).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	280	 For the C1C2O kinetic scheme, the total equivalent gating charge for CFTR is 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	281	32e (Table III) while for the C1OC2 kinetic scheme it is 0.
