0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	282	 These values of gating charge are threefold lower than that of ClC-0, the voltage-dependent Cl- channel of Torpedo electric organ (Hanke and Miller, 1983; Pusch et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	283	, 1995; Chen and Miller, 1996) and about fortyfold lower than those of voltage-gated Na+, K+ and Ca2+ channels (Hille, 2001).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	284	View this table:    TABLE III Summary of the Fits to the Rate Constants for the C1C2O Kinetic Scheme.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	285	  View this table:    TABLE IV Summary of the Fits to the Rate Constants for the C1OC2 Kinetic Scheme.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	286	  Effect of Voltage on the Regulation of Channel Gating by the NBDs Following cAMP-dependent phosphorylation, the gating behavior of CFTR is controlled by cycles of ATP binding and hydrolysis at the NBDs (Gadsby and Nairn, 1999; Sheppard and Welsh, 1999).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	287	 Previous work indicates that ADP inhibits the activity of CFTR by antagonizing ATP-dependent channel opening to prolong greatly the duration of long closures separating channel openings (Winter et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Conversely, the inorganic phosphate analogue, pyrophosphate (PPi) stimulates the activity of CFTR by increasing the frequency and prolonging dramatically the duration of channel openings (Carson et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	289	 We were especially interested in the effects of PPi on the voltage dependence of CFTR channel gating, because PPi abolished the asymmetric permeability of CFTR to large organic anions (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1998b).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	290	 We speculated that PPi might convert CFTR from an inwardly rectifying channel to a linear channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	291	 To test this hypothesis, we examined the effect of PPi on the inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents using voltage ramp protocols.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	292	 As a control, we tested the effect of ADP, which is without effect on the asymmetric permeability of CFTR to large organic anions (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1998b).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	293	 8 A shows I-V relationships of CFTR Cl- currents recorded in the absence and presence of PPi (5 mM).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	294	 PPi (5 mM) increased CFTR Cl- currents by similar amounts at both negative and positive voltages (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	295	 8 B), indicating that PPi-stimulation of CFTR is voltage-independent.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	296	 9, A and B, demonstrates that CFTR inhibition by ADP (1 mM) was voltage independent.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Consistent with these data, neither PPi (5 mM) nor ADP (1 mM) altered the inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents (Figs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	298	View larger version (14K):    FIGURE 8.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Pyrophosphate stimulation of CFTR Cl- currents is voltage independent.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	300	 (A) I-V relationships of CFTR Cl- currents recorded in the absence and presence of pyrophosphate (PPi; 5 mM) in the intracellular solution.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	301	 (B) Effect of voltage on the fraction of CFTR Cl- current stimulated by PPi (5 mM).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	302	 Values are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 4) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	303	 The continuous line is the fit of a first order regression to the data.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	304	 (C) I-V relationships of CFTR Cl- currents recorded in the absence (open circles) and presence (filled circles) of PPi (5 mM) expressed as a percentage of the current value at -100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	305	 Data are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 4) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	306	  View larger version (13K):    FIGURE 9.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	307	 ADP inhibition of CFTR Cl- currents is voltage independent.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	308	 (A) I-V relationships of CFTR Cl- currents recorded in the absence and presence of ADP (1 mM) in the intracellular solution.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	309	 (B) Effect of voltage on the fraction of CFTR Cl- current inhibited by ADP (1 mM).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	310	 (C) I-V relationships of CFTR Cl- currents recorded in the absence (open circles) and presence (filled circles) of ADP (1 mM) expressed as a percentage of the current value at -100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	311	  Voltage Dependence of the Murine CFTR Cl- Channel In previous work, we demonstrated that wild-type murine CFTR Cl- channels have a reduced single-channel conductance, a dramatically decreased Po and an altered pattern of channel gating compared with those of wild-type human CFTR (Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	312	 To explore further the voltage dependence of CFTR, we investigated the effect of voltage on the activity of wild-type murine CFTR Cl- channels in excised inside-out membrane patches.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	313	 10 A demonstrates that at -80 mV the pattern of gating of murine CFTR is characterized by transitions between a closed state and two open states: sustained openings to a subconductance state and brief openings to a full open state (Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	314	 At +80 mV, the gating behavior of CFTR was also characterized by prolonged openings to a subconductance state and brief openings to a full open state (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	315	 However, the frequency and duration of openings to the full open state appeared to be reduced compared with those at -80 mV (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	316	View larger version (36K):    FIGURE 10.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	317	 Effect of voltage on the murine CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	318	 (A) Recordings of a single murine CFTR Cl- channel at -80 mV (top) and +80 mV (bottom) made using the conditions described in Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	319	 (B) Single-channel I-V relationships of human (open circles) and murine (filled circles) CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Data are means  plus or minus  SEM (n = 8 to 10) at each voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	321	 (C) Relationship between chord conductance and voltage for the data shown in B.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	322	 (D) Effect of voltage on the Po of human (left ordinate) and murine (right ordinate) CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	323	 Columns and error bars indicate means  plus or minus  SEM (human, n = 6; murine, n = 10).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	324	 For human CFTR, voltage was -75 and +75 mV, whereas for murine voltage was -80 and +80 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	325	 The asterisks indicate values that are significantly different from the data at negative voltages (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	326	  To quantify the voltage dependence of the murine CFTR Cl- channel, we measured i and Po of the full open state.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	327	 (We did not investigate the voltage dependence of the subconductance state because of its tiny single-channel current amplitude.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	328	 10 B compares the single-channel I-V relationship of murine CFTR with that of human CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	329	 For murine CFTR, at +100 mV i = 73  plus or minus  4% (n = 7) of that at -100 mV while for human CFTR at +100 mV i = 88  plus or minus  2% (n = 10) of that at -100 mV (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	330	 Consistent with these data, the chord conductance of murine CFTR decreased by 25% over the voltage range -100 to +100 mV, whereas that of human CFTR decreased by only 12% (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Moreover, at each voltage tested, the chord conductance of murine CFTR was reduced compared with that of human CFTR (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	332	 10 D compares the Po of human and murine CFTR at negative and positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	333	 These data demonstrate two important differences between human and murine CFTR: first, the Po of the full open state of murine CFTR is much reduced compared with that of human CFTR (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	334	 Second, the Po of murine CFTR is greatly decreased at positive voltages, whereas that of human CFTR is little changed (Fig.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	335	 For murine CFTR, the Po value at +80 mV decreased by 49  plus or minus  10% (n = 10) when compared with that at -80 mV (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	336	 In contrast, for human CFTR, the Po value at +75 mV was decreased by only 5  plus or minus  1% (n = 6) when compared with that at -75 mV (P  <  0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	337	 Thus, these single-channel data suggest that inward rectification of murine CFTR is stronger than that of the human CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	338	In principal, inward rectification of the CFTR Cl- channel might either result from channel block by a soluble factor or be an intrinsic property of the CFTR channel protein.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Studies of other ion channels provide strong support for both hypotheses.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	340	 For example, the inward rectification of Kir channels, NMDA receptors, and cyclic nucleotide to gated channels is caused by voltage-dependent block of outward current flow by extrinsic cations.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	341	 In the case of Kir channels the blocking cations are intracellular Mg2+ and polyamines (Vandenberg, 1987; Lopatin et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	342	, 1994), whereas for NMDA receptors and cyclic nucleotide to gated channels the blocking cations are extracellular Ca2+ and Mg2+ (Nowak et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	343	, 1984; Zimmerman and Baylor, 1986).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	344	 In contrast, inward rectification of KAT1, an inward-rectifier K+ channel from the plant Arabidopsis thaliana, results from an intrinsic gating mechanism (Zei and Aldrich, 1998).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	345	 Like voltage-gated K+ channels (Hille, 2001), KAT1 possesses a voltage-sensor, the S4 segment that uses the energy of voltage to control channel gating (Zei and Aldrich, 1998).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	346	Several lines of evidence suggest that channel block is not likely to account for inward rectification of the CFTR Cl- channel in excised inside-out membrane patches.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	347	 First, changes in the composition of the intra- and extracellular solutions did not abolish inward rectification (for data and discussion, see the online supplemental material, available at http://www.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	348	 Second, inward rectification has been observed using cells expressing either native or recombinant wild-type human CFTR (e.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	349	, Quinton and Reddy, 2000; Lansdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	350	, 2000; Linsdell and Gong, 2002; this study), indicating that inward rectification is independent of the expression system used to investigate CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	351	 Third, inward rectification of CFTR Cl- channels reconstituted into planar lipid bilayers was unaffected by changes in the composition of the lipid bilayer (Zhao et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	352	, 1996), suggesting that the surface charge of the membrane lipid does not affect inward rectification.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Fourth, the effects of voltage on the function of the murine CFTR Cl- channel (present study) indicate that inward rectification is a common characteristic of human and murine CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	354	 Fifth, mutation of several residues within the MSDs alters the shape of the I-V relationship of CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	355	 Inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents is accentuated by mutation of R334, T338, T339, and S341 (sixth transmembrane segment (M6); Gong and Linsdell, 2003; Linsdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	356	, 2002), S1118 (M11; Zhang et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	357	, 2000), and T1134 and N1138 (M12; Gupta et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	358	 In contrast, mutation of V317 (M5; Zhang et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	359	, 2002) causes outward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	360	 Based on these data, we speculate that inward rectification is an intrinsic property of the CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	361	 Because ADP and PPi, two agents that interact with the NBDs, are without effect on inward rectification and because site-directed mutations in the MSDs enhance inward rectification, we propose that the CFTR pore determines this property of the CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	362	For the CFTR pore, itself, to be responsible for inward rectification, the architecture of the pore should facilitate the flow of Cl- from the intra- to the extracellular side of the membrane, but hinder Cl- flow in the opposite direction.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	363	 To transport ions at maximal translocation rates, ion channels have evolved charged lined vestibules that concentrate and funnel ions toward the selectivity filter (Green and Andersen, 1991; Dutzler et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	364	 Based on these considerations, inward rectification of current flow through the CFTR pore might be achieved by asymmetries in the geometry of the intra- and extracellular vestibules, differences in the distribution of Cl--binding sites between the two vestibules or a combination of these factors.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	365	Evidence for asymmetries in the topology of the intra- and extracellular vestibules is provided by studies of anion permeation and channel block.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	366	 Anion permeation studies indicate that the narrowest part of the CFTR pore is 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	367	60 nm in diameter (Cheung and Akabas, 1996; Linsdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	368	, 1997), widening under certain circumstances to a diameter of 1.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	369	3 nm (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1998b).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	370	 This constriction, which likely represents the selectivity filter, occurs in the region of F337 and T338 in M6 because mutation of these residues altered dramatically the anion permeability sequence of CFTR, whereas mutation of other residues in M6 had less marked effects on anion permeation (Linsdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	371	, 1998, 2000; McCarty and Zhang, 2001; Gong et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	372	, 2002; Gupta and Linsdell, 2003).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	373	 On the intra- and extracellular sides of this constriction, the pore enlarges.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	374	 The voltage dependence of channel block by large organic anions suggests that the CFTR pore contains a wide intracellular vestibule that funnels blocking anions deep into the pore where they bind, occlude the pore, and block Cl- permeation (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1996; Sheppard and Robinson, 1997; Hwang and Sheppard, 1999; Zhou et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	375	 Less is known about the topology of the extracellular end of the CFTR pore.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	376	 Based on the ability of methanethiosulphonate reagents in the extracellular solution to react with M6 residues toward the cytosolic side of the membrane (Cheung and Akabas, 1996), there might also be a wide extracellular vestibule.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	377	 However, the inability of open-channel blockers to reach their binding sites when added to the extracellular solution and the short length of extracellular loops 3 and 6 led McCarty (2000) to propose that CFTR has a small extracellular vestibule.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	378	 Consistent with this idea, Linsdell and Hanrahan (1998a)(b) demonstrated that CFTR exhibits an asymmetric permeability to large organic anions (e.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	379	, galacturonate, glutathione, and lactobionate).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	380	 During the normal gating cycle, flow of large organic anions through the CFTR pore is only permitted in the intra- to extracellular direction (Linsdell and Hanrahan, 1998a,b).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	381	The sixth transmembrane segment plays a crucial role in determining the pore properties of CFTR (Sheppard and Welsh, 1999; McCarty, 2000; Gong et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	382	 Within M6, the residues R334 (Smith et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	383	, 2001; Gong and Linsdell, 2003), K335 (Anderson et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	384	, 2002), and possibly R352 (Guinamard and Akabas, 1999; Gong et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	385	, 2002) contribute to Cl--binding sites.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	386	 Assuming that the narrowest part of the CFTR pore occurs in the region of F337 and T338 (see above and Linsdell et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	387	, 1998, 2000; McCarty and Zhang, 2001; Gong et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	388	, 2002; Gupta and Linsdell, 2003), the data suggest that three Cl--binding sites (S341, I344, and R352) might be located in a spacious intracellular vestibule, whereas two Cl--binding sites (R334 and K335) might be located in a more confined extracellular vestibule.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	389	 This simple model suggests that current flow through the CFTR pore might inwardly rectify.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	390	 However, an important caveat of this model is that present knowledge of the mechanism of anion permeation by the CFTR Cl- channel is incomplete and it is quite likely that residues in other transmembrane segments contribute to Cl--binding sites.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	391	 Nevertheless, asymmetries in the size of the intra- and extracellular vestibules and/or the distribution of Cl--binding sites within the CFTR pore are plausible explanations for the inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	392	Besides the architecture of the CFTR pore, voltage-dependent gating might make some contribution to the observed inward rectification of current flow through the CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	393	 Work by other investigators and ourselves demonstrate that CFTR channel gating exhibits voltage dependence despite the lack of a marked effect of voltage on Po.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	394	 First, using cell-attached membrane patches from NIH 3T3 fibroblasts expressing wild-type human CFTR, Fischer and Machen (1994) demonstrated that slow (ATP dependent) gating is voltage independent, whereas fast (flickery intraburst) gating is voltage dependent, becoming the dominant gating mode at strong negative voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	395	 Second, using excised membrane patches from Xenopus oocytes expressing wild-type human CFTR, Zhang et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	396	 (2002) demonstrated that burst duration increases at negative voltages, whereas interburst interval is unaffected by voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	397	 Third, to investigate the flickery closures that interrupt bursts of channel openings, Zhou et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	398	 (2001) analyzed the gating kinetics of the CFTR variant K1250A whose prolonged openings facilitate the discrimination of fast and slow gating events.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	399	 (2001) found that the rate of transition from the short-lived closed state to the open state exhibits voltage dependence and is sensitive to permeant anions in the extracellular solution, suggesting that brief flickery closures represent the voltage-dependent occupancy of an anion-binding site within the CFTR pore by unknown intracellular anions.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	400	To elucidate the effects of voltage on CFTR channel gating, we adopted a different strategy to other investigators.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	401	 We employed kinetic modeling to analyze the gating behavior of single wild-type human CFTR Cl- channels in excised membrane patches bathed in symmetrical Cl--rich solutions at 37 degrees C and lightly filtered our data.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	402	 Using this approach, we determined the effect of voltage on both fast and slow gating events.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	403	 Our data indicate that voltage has significant effects on CFTR channel gating.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	404	 Membrane depolarization decreased both the duration of bursts and the interburst interval, but increased the duration of gaps within bursts.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	405	 However, because the voltage dependencies of the different rate constants were in opposite directions, Po was largely unaffected by voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	406	 The voltage independence of Po and the lack of effect of ADP and PPi on the inward rectification of CFTR Cl- currents argue that changes in CFTR channel gating do not contribute to the rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	407	 However, other data suggest the contrary.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	408	 First, the predicted CFTR Cl- current (N x i x Po) at +100 mV, which is accounted for by reductions in both i and Po, agrees closely with the measured CFTR Cl- current at this voltage.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	409	 Second, the Po of murine CFTR is decreased markedly at positive voltages.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	410	 Third, comparison of the data of Smith et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	411	 (2001) and Gong and Linsdell (2003) suggests that the strong inward rectification of the CFTR variant R334C is not accounted for by voltage-dependent changes in i.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	412	 Based on these data, we argue that voltage-dependent changes in CFTR channel gating contribute to the inward rectification of macroscopic CFTR Cl- currents.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	413	Our data indicate that the total equivalent gating charge for CFTR is only 0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	414	 The small size of the gating charge of CFTR is consistent with the lack of marked voltage dependence of CFTR channel gating.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	415	 The data suggest that residues with charged and uncharged polar side chains move only a very small distance within the transmembrane electric field.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	416	 These residues might be located either along the full-length of the CFTR pore or restricted to a specific region of the permeation pathway.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	417	 Alternatively, linear three-state kinetic schemes might be too simple to describe the voltage dependence of CFTR channel gating.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	418	 Because the total equivalent gating charge of CFTR is comparable to the amount of charge movement intrinsic to the voltage-dependent Cl- channel ClC-0 (Chen and Miller, 1996), we favor the former idea.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	419	 The amino acid sequence of ClC-0 lacks a motif equivalent to the S4 segment, the voltage sensor of voltage-gated cation channels (Hille, 2001).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	420	 Instead, permeant anions in the extracellular solution act as the source of the gating charge (Pusch et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	421	 The binding of Cl- ions to a Cl--binding site located at the extracellular end of the ClC-0 pore causes a conformational change that precedes channel opening and inward Cl- flow (Chen and Miller, 1996).
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	422	 Because bound Cl- ions traverse the transmembrane electric field, gating is both voltage and Cl- concentration dependent (Pusch et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	423	 Excitingly, the structural basis of this gating mechanism has been elucidated following the determination of high-resolution crystal structures of bacterial CLC proteins (Dutzler et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	424	 In these bacterial CLC channels, the Cl--binding site closest to the extracellular end of the selectivity filter is gated by the carboxyl group of glutamate (E)148 that protrudes into the CLC channel pore: when the carboxyl group of E148 is bound to the Cl--binding site the pore is closed, but when a Cl- ion binds the pore opens to allow Cl- permeation (Dutzler et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	425	The regulation of CLC channel gating by localized motions of an amino acid side chain (Dutzler et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	426	, 2003) raises the question as to whether a similar mechanism might operate in the CFTR Cl- channel.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	427	 However, anion permeation through the CFTR pore is tightly linked to the function of the NBDs that power channel gating.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	428	 (2003) recently demonstrated that glutathione permeation through the CFTR pore is controlled by ATP binding rather than ATP binding and hydrolysis as in the case of Cl- permeation.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	429	 These data suggest that global conformation changes in the structure of the CFTR protein control Cl- permeation, not local changes in the orientation of amino acid side-chains.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	430	 If this idea were correct, it would suggest that CFTR channel gating shares similarities with activation gating in K+ channels that involves the reorientation of transmembrane -helices (Jiang et al.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	431	 Future studies should test this possibility.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	432	   FOOTNOTES   The online version of this paper contains supplemental material.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	433	Abbreviations used in this paper: CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; M, transmembrane segment; MSD, membrane-spanning domain; NBD, nucleotide-binding domain; PPi, pyrophosphate.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	434	1 Although very small, the membrane currents evoked by the voltage ramp protocol under basal conditions outwardly rectified.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	435	 For example, at -100 mV basal current was -0.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	436	20 pA and at +100 mV basal current was 2.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	437	 When basal currents were subtracted from those recorded in the presence of ATP (1 mM) + PKA (75 nM), the outward rectification of basal current accounted for 6  plus or minus  2% (n = 10) of the inward rectification of CFTR Cl- current at +100 mV.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	438	2 In contrast to analyses of rate constant values at  plus or minus 75 mV using Student's paired t test, some analyses of rate constant data over the range -75 to +75 mV using one-way ANOVAs failed to achieve statistical significance.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	439	 We attribute this difference to the fact that paired data were used for analyses using Student's paired t test, but pooled data were used for one-way ANOVAs.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	440	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Professor M.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	441	 Winter, and our departmental colleagues, especially Dr.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	442	 Meech, for valuable discussions, and Dr.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	443	 O'Riordan (Genzyme, Framingham, MA) for the gift of C127 cells expressing wild-type human CFTR, Dr.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	444	 Wainwright (University of Queensland, Brisbane, Australia) for the gift of CHO cells expressing wild-type murine CFTR, and Dr.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	445	 Mendes (Universidade de Lisboa, Lisboa, Portugal) for the gift of BHK cells expressing wild-type human CFTR.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	446	This work was supported by the Cystic Fibrosis Trust and the National Kidney Research Fund.
0.44508743.14581585.html.plaintext.txt	447	Submitted: 13 August 2003 Accepted: 2 October 2003.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	0	Syntaxin 8 impairs trafficking of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) and inhibits its channel activity Frederic Bilan1,*, Vincent Thoreau1,*, Magali Nacfer1, Renaud Derand2, Caroline Norez2, Anne Cantereau2, Martine Garcia3, Frederic Becq2 and Alain Kitzis1,.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	1	1 Laboratoire de Genetique Cellulaire et Moleculaire, UPRES EA 2622, CHU de Poitiers, BP 577, 86021 Poitiers CEDEX, France 2 Laboratoire de Biomembranes et Signalisation Cellulaire, CNRS UMR 6558, Universite de Poitiers, France 3 Laboratoire d'Immunologie et Interactions Moleculaires, UPRES EA 2224, Universite de Poitiers, France.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	2	Author for correspondence (e-mail: a.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	3	Key words: CFTR, Syntaxin 8, SNARE, Recycling endosome, Trafficking.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	4	In cystic fibrosis patients, dysfunction in the chloride channel activity of CFTR alone seems insufficient to elicit the deep disorders in the ionic equilibrium observed at the surface of epithelial tissues.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Indeed, CFTR expression has been linked to the regulation of numerous ionic channels and it is now assumed that CFTR is a key member of a complex network of ionic channels (Gabriel et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	6	, 2000) and cytoplasmic proteins in epithelia.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	7	 For example, CFTR interacts with several proteins containing PDZ (PSD-95/Dlg/ZO-1) domains.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Most of these proteins are localized in a subplasma membrane region (Short et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	9	, 2001), and one was found in the Golgi apparatus (Cheng et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Interactions were also detected between CFTR and proteins involved in the intracellular vesicle trafficking.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Notably, the C-terminus of CFTR binds to the endocytic clathrin adaptator complex AP-2 (Weixel and Bradbury, 2000), presumably during the internalization of CFTR from the plasma membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Several studies are now focusing on the relationships between CFTR and proteins of the SNARE (soluble N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive factor attachment protein receptor) family.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	13	 These proteins are involved in the membrane fusion events happening during the different steps of vesicle trafficking in eukaryotic cells (reviewed by Chen and Scheller, 2001).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	14	Syntaxins belong to a subfamily of the t-SNAREs, whose C-terminal half contains the t-SNARE homology domain (Weimbs et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	15	, 1997) followed by a short hydrophobic tail that anchors the protein in its resident membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The region of syntaxins upstream of this transmembrane domain protrudes at the cytoplasmic side of vesicle or plasma membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Remarkably, a direct interaction between the SNARE homology domain of syntaxin 1A and the N-terminal cytoplasmic tail of CFTR is thought to be responsible for inhibiting CFTR chloride channel activity (Naren et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	18	We have previously described the cloning of human syntaxin 8 cDNA (STX8 gene), using the R domain of CFTR as a bait in the two-hybrid screening of a human fetal lung library (Thoreau et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Subsequently, syntaxin 8 has been localized in different endosomal compartments: it has been involved in trafficking from early endosome (EE) to late endosome (LE), or in homotypic fusion events in LE (Prekeris et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In the present study, we establish that syntaxin 8 overexpression inhibits CFTR channel activity and trafficking to the plasma membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	21	 A direct regulation can also be suggested as we show evidence for the existence of a physical interaction between CFTR and syntaxin 8, either directly or within a protein complex.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Thus, we propose that syntaxin 8 is a member of the CFTR interaction network.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Our results strengthen the idea that the SNARE machinery directly regulates CFTR trafficking and activity.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	24	The following antibodies were used in this study: rabbit polyclonal antibody against syntaxin 3, a gift from A.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	25	, 1997), monoclonal antibody against syntaxin 1A clone 78.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	26	3 (Synaptic Systems, Germany), monoclonal antibody against syntaxin 8 clone 48 (Transduction Laboratories); antibodies against CFTR, monoclonal antibody clone M3A7 with epitope at amino acid 1370-1380 (Chemicon International), used for immunoblotting, and monoclonal antibody clone 24-1 with epitope at amino acid 1377-1480 (R and D Systems), used for immunoprecipitation; antibody against GFP, monoclonal antibody clone GEP-20 (Sigma-Aldrich).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	27	 For immunofluorescence experiments, anti-syntaxin 8 antibody was prepared by immunization of a rabbit with bacterially expressed GST-Syn8TM.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Polyclonal antibody was then affinity purified from rabbit antiserum using CNBr-activated sepharose beads (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Monoclonal anti-TfR antibody was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (clone DF1513), monoclonal anti-Lamp 1 was obtained from Pharmingen, rabbit polyclonal anti-Rab11 antibody was a gift from B.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	30	, 2000) and rabbit polyclonal anti-NCX2 was provided by the intermediary of C.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Cognard (LBSC, Poitiers, France).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	32	 All fluorescent secondary antibodies were obtained from Jackson Immunoresearch Laboratories.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Secondary antibody for western blot was obtained from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech: horseradish peroxidase-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	34	Cell culture All cell lines were cultured at 37 degrees C in 5% CO2 in a medium containing 100 IU/ml penicillin (Panpharma SA, France) and 100  microg/ml streptomycin (Solvay Pharma, France).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	35	 CHO cells transfected with CFTR cDNA (CHO-CFTR), established by J.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	36	, 1991), were grown in MEM medium with Glutamax-I (Life Technologies) containing 100  microM methotrexate (Sigma-Aldrich) and supplemented with 7% fetal calf serum (Life Technologies).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	37	 COS-7 and HT29-CL19A cells were cultured in DMEM with Glutamax-I supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	38	Transfection CHO-CFTR cells were transfected with 1  microg of pcDNA3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	39	1/Zeo( to ) plasmids encoding syntaxins, using 3  microl of FuGene6TM transfection reagent (Roche Diagnostics Corp.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	40	), according to the manufacturer's protocol.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	41	 After 24 to 48 hours incubation 40  microg/ml zeocin (Invitrogen) was added to the culture medium.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Resistant cells were cultured with 20  microg/ml zeocin and were tested by western blot and immunofluorescence.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	43	 To isolate clones overexpressing Syn8 or Syn8TM, cells were diluted and cultured in 24-well plates.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	44	For the electroporation of COS-7 cells, 2x106 cells at 90% confluence were trypsinized and resuspended in 800  microl of PBS with 10  microg of each plasmid.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	45	 After 5 minutes incubation on ice, cells were transferred into an electroporation cuvette (4 mm electrode gap, EquiBio Ltd) and electroporated with one shock at 300 V, 450  microF, using an EasyjecT Plus multipurpose electroporation system (EquiBio Ltd).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The cells were then incubated on ice for 10 minutes in 10 ml of culture medium, plated on glass coverslips, grown for 48 hours and treated subsequently for immunofluorescence analysis.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	47	Iodide efflux experiments CFTR chloride channel activity was assayed by measuring the rate of iodide (125I) efflux from transfected CHO cells as previously described (Derand et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	48	 All experiments were performed at 37 degrees C.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	49	 The loss of intracellular 125I was determined by removing the medium with efflux buffer every 1 minute for up to 10 minutes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The fraction of initial intracellular 125I lost during each interval time was determined and time-dependent rates of 125I efflux were calculated from ln(125It1 / 125It2)/(t1  to  t2) where 125It is the intracellular 125I at time t, and t1 and t2 are successive time-points (Venglarik et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	51	Patch-clamp experiments Whole-cell chloride currents were recorded from CHO cells at room temperature with a List EPC-7 patch-clamp amplifier.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	52	 I-V relationships were built by clamping the membrane potential to  to 40 mV and by pulses from  to 100 mV to +100 mV by 20 mV increments.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Mediums generating a chloride gradient of 151 mM external concentration and 28 mM internal concentration were used.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The pipette solution contained: 113 mM L-aspartic acid, 113 mM CsOH, 27 mM CsCl, 1 mM NaCl, 1 mM MgCl2, 1 mM EGTA, 10 mM TES, 285 mOsm (pH 7.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	55	 MgATP (3 mM) was added just before patch-clamp experiments were started.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The external solution consisted of 145 mM NaCl, 4 mM CsCl, 1 mM CaCl2, 5 mM glucose, 10 mM TES, 340 mOsm (pH 7.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Results were analyzed with the pCLAMP6 package software (pCLAMP, Axon Instruments).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Cells were stimulated with forskolin (Sigma-Aldrich) or by the CFTR activator MPB-91 (5-butyl-6-hydroxy-10-chlorobenzo[c]quinolizinium) synthesized as previously described (Derand et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	59	Statistics Results are expressed as means  plus or minus  s.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	60	 To compare sets of data, we used either an analysis of variance (ANOVA) or Student's t test.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Differences were considered statistically significant when P < 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	62	 All statistical tests were performed using GraphPad Prism version 3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	63	0 for Windows (Graphpad Software).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	64	Immunofluorescence Cells grown on glass coverslips were washed with PBS++ (PBS buffer supplemented with 1 mM CaCl2 and 1 mM MgCl2) and fixed for 10 minutes in 3% paraformaldehyde in PBS and permeabilized for 10 minutes in saponin buffer (0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Cells were incubated in PBS++ containing 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	66	5% BSA for 45 minutes at room temperature to block unspecific antigen sites.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Then, coverslips were labeled for 1 hour with primary antibody (1:100 in blocking buffer).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The cells were washed three times in PBS++ containing 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	69	5% BSA and labeled with conjugated antibody (1:100) for 1 hour.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Coverslips were mounted with VectaShield fluorescence medium H1000 (Vector Lab).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	71	Confocal imaging The labeled samples were examined by confocal laser scanning microscopy using a BioRad MRC 1024.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The confocal unit was attached to an inverted microscope (Olympus IX70).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Maximal resolution was obtained with Olympus plan apo x60 water, 1.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	74	3 numerical aperture objective lens.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Fluorescence signal collection, image construction and scaling were performed through the control software (Lasersharp 3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	76	 For colocalization study of CFTR, syntaxin 8 and endosomal markers, bleed-through was avoided during acquisition with red, green and far red fluorescence: images were collected sequentially and then merged as an RGB colored image.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	77	2 software permitted analysis of the degree of colocalization in the same focal plane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	78	 For each pair of color combinations, a two-dimensional fluorogram displayed the intensity and distribution of different colored pixels within a merged image as a scattergram.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	79	 It was possible to select a subset of pixels from the scattergram that have significant intensity in both colors (as shown by colored rectangle) to visualize on the cell image the localization of the selected pixels.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	80	SDS-PAGE and immunoblot Cells were homogenized by several passes through a 23-gauge syringe needle in RIPA buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	81	5), 1 mM EDTA, 100 mM NaCl, 1% Triton X-100) containing protease inhibitors (20  microM leupeptin, 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	82	8  microM aprotinin, 10  microM pepstatin and 1.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	83	25 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Cell lysates were incubated on ice for 30 minutes and clarified by centrifugation at 15,000 g for 5 minutes at 4 degrees C.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Total proteins were quantified using the BCA protein assay reagent (Pierce), and 10-50  microg of proteins were loaded onto an SDS-PAGE apparatus.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	86	 SDS-PAGE was performed according to Laemmli and Favre (Laemmli and Favre, 1973).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Extracts were separated on 15% polyacrylamide gels to study syntaxin 8, and 7% for CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	88	 For western blots, proteins were transferred from gels to a 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	89	20  microm pore nitrocellulose membrane (Sartorius, Germany) using a Miniprotean III electroblotter (BioRad Laboratories).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Immunoblots were washed in PBS containing 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	91	1% Tween-20 (PBS-Tween) and then probed overnight at 4 degrees C with primary antibody in PBS-Tween.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Membranes were washed and incubated for 1 hour at 4 degrees C with the secondary antibody.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Bound antibodies were detected using enhanced luminol and oxidizing reagents as specified by the manufacturer (ECL, Amersham Pharmacia Biotech).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	94	Immunoprecipitation Cell lysates were prepared as described above with 1 ml of lysis buffer per 100 mm culture dish.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	95	 In these experiments, 3 ml of cell lysate supplemented with 9 ml of NET buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	96	05% Nonidet P-40) were incubated overnight at 4 degrees C with 2  microg of CFTR or Syn8 antibodies.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	97	 To precipitate immune complexes, an incubation with 3  microg of protein G-sepharose (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) was conducted for 1 hour at 4 degrees C.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Bead-bound complexes were washed three times with cold NET buffer and denatured in Laemmli buffer for 15 minutes at room temperature.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Samples were separated on SDS-PAGE and analyzed by western blot.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	100	Pull-down assays GST-fusion proteins were produced in E.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Cells transformed with pGEX (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) constructs were grown and lysed according to the manufacturer's protocol.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Recombinant proteins contained in lysates were purified by incubation for 30 minutes at 4 degrees C with 500  microl of glutathione-sepharose beads (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) followed by three washes with PBS, 1% Triton X-100.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	103	 GST-fusion protein yield was controlled by SDS-PAGE followed by Coomassie blue gel staining.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Then, 8x106 COS-7 cells stably transfected with GFP-CFTR were lysed as described above.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Lysates were mixed with 200  microg of recombinant proteins bound to glutathione-sepharose beads.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Incubation was conducted overnight at 4 degrees C.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Bead-bound complexes were washed three times in lysis buffer, denatured in Laemmli buffer for 15 minutes at room temperature, loaded on a 7% SDS-PAGE and analyzed by western blot using GFP antibody.

0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	144	To determine whether the cytosolic domain (90% of the entire protein) of syntaxin 8 could modulate CFTR channel activity, we used a soluble form of this protein (deleted of its transmembrane domain, noted Syn8TM).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	145	 CHO-CFTR cells were transfected with the appropriate vector as described above.

0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Analysis of CFTR channel activity in the presence of different syntaxins.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	158	 (A) Expression profile analysis of different syntaxins before (NT) or after plasmid transfection in CHO-CFTR cells (Syn8TM, Syn1A and Syn3).
