0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Data are expressed as a percentage of CFTR maximal activity.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	162	At this stage, we agreed that CFTR inhibition was not due to overexpression of any SNARE proteins.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Syntaxin 3, unlike syntaxin 1A, is known not to physically interact with CFTR (Naren et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	164	 So, we have assayed CFTR channel modulation under overexpression of each of these syntaxins in the CHO-CFTR model.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Stably transfected cells were characterized by fluorescent immunostaining (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	166	 We noticed that syntaxin 1A as well as syntaxin 3 antibodies were unable to detect endogenous proteins (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	167	 As expected, cells overexpressing syntaxin 1A or syntaxin 3 presented plasma membrane localization (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	168	 3Ad,f) of these proteins with a predominant perinuclear staining observed in the case of syntaxin 1A (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	169	 In each case, more than 40% of cells exhibited high level expression (data not shown).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	170	 We measured CFTR response by iodide efflux experiments under 5  microM forskolin stimulation and we found no significant difference between control and Syn3-transfected CHO-CFTR cells, whereas syntaxin 1A overexpression induced a 40% inhibition of CFTR channel activity (100 plus or minus 3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	171	63 (n=12), respectively, expressed as a percentage of CFTR maximal activity) (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	172	To confirm our iodide efflux results, we performed whole-cell patch-clamp recordings and compared the properties of CFTR chloride currents in the presence or absence of syntaxin 8.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	173	 In control CHO-CFTR cells, the activity of CFTR Cl- current was stimulated by 5  microM forskolin and the current measured at +60 mV was 25.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	174	 The expression of syntaxin 8 in CHO-2T cells resulted in a dramatic reduction in the CFTR chloride current, with a current density, measured at +60 mV, of only 4.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	175	77 pA/pF (n=7 for each concentration, Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	176	 4B-D) with 5  microM and 10  microM forskolin, respectively.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	177	 These observations confirmed the flux study and showed that the chloride channel activity of CFTR is strongly affected by syntaxin 8.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	178	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Analysis by patch-clamp assay of the CFTR chloride channel activity in the presence of syntaxin 8.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Typical whole-cell currents recorded from a CHO-CFTR cell (A) and from a Syn8 and CFTR transfected CHO-2T cell (B) in the absence or presence of 5  microM forskolin in the bath.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Cells capacitances are 30 pS and 27 pS in A and B, respectively.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	182	 (C) Averaged current-voltage relationships from 12 CHO-CFTR cells and seven CHO-2T cells in the presence of 5  microM forskolin.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	183	 (D) Histograms showing current densities measured at +60 mV for the different experimental conditions indicated at the bottom of each column.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The number of experiments is indicated on the graph.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	185	GFP-tagged CFTR trafficking is impaired by syntaxin 8 overexpression in COS-7 cells To understand how syntaxin 8 overexpression induces an inhibition of the CFTR chloride current, we investigated the impact of syntaxin 8 or cytosoluble syntaxin 8 expression on the cellular distribution of a GFP-tagged CFTR in COS-7 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	186	 GFP-CFTR is known to be functional and the GFP tag does not affect its trafficking and localization (Moyer et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Moreover, we have observed, in COS-7 cells, that two cystic fibrosis widespread mutants, GFP-(F508del)CFTR and GFP-(G551D)CFTR, exhibited a pharmacological response and a trafficking consistent with the physiological data (data not shown).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Immunofluorescence study showed that in both cases (endogenous or overexpressed), syntaxin 8 was concentrated in a structure close to nuclear envelope, and a cytoplasm punctuated staining indicated the presence of syntaxin 8 in vesicle-like structures.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	189	For the following experiments, we have chosen a photomultiplier sensitivity allowing us to visualize overexpressed syntaxin 8 without fluorescence saturation.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	190	 At this sensitivity, endogenous syntaxin 8 was not detected.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Most of the cells overexpressing GFP-CFTR exhibited a strong plasma membrane staining with weaker intracellular staining (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	192	 When COS-7 cells were cotransfected with syntaxin 8 and GFP-CFTR, we observed a strong decrease or a disappearance of GFP-CFTR plasma membrane staining (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	193	 GFP-CFTR appeared in cytosolic or punctuated pattern as shown in Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	194	 5B with observation at different Z positions.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Moreover, cotransfection with the empty pcDNA3.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	196	1/Zeo( to ) vector did not affect GFP-CFTR localization at the plasma membrane (data not shown).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	197	View larger version (144K):    Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	198	 The impact of syntaxin 8 overexpression on GFP-CFTR cellular localization in COS-7 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	199	 (A-C) Thick optical sections acquired with 2, 0.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	200	8  microm steps (from top to bottom).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	201	 (D-F) Projections of entire Z series.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Cells were transfected with GFP-CFTR alone (A,D), cotransfected with GFP-CFTR and Syn8 (B,E) and cotransfected with GFP-CFTR and the cytosoluble form of syntaxin 8: Syn8TM (C,F).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Green fluorescence resulting from GFP-CFTR expression shows strong and continuous localization of GFP-CFTR concentrated in plasma membrane of control cells (A,D).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	204	 In doubly transfected cells, overexpression of Syn8 (as revealed by red fluorescence) is associated with a strong reduction of GFP-CFTR plasma membrane localization, while a partial colocalization is visualized in a juxtanuclear region as revealed by yellow fluorescence.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	205	 By contrast, experiments using Syn8TM exhibit a large cytosolic staining of syntaxin 8 soluble form and a plasma membrane staining for GFP-CFTR (C,F).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	206	 (G) Control experiments studying NCX2 localization in wild-type or Syn8-transfected COS-7 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Arrowheads indicate plasma membrane localization of NCX2 in both cases.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Each image is representative of six independent experiments.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	209	Control experiments using Syn8TM exhibited a large cytosolic staining that clearly differed from the wild-type syntaxin 8 immunostaining pattern.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Cells overexpressing Syn8TM presented a plasma membrane staining of GFP-CFTR in focal planes (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	211	 5C) and in the projection of all XY sections (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	212	 5F), with an intensity level comparable to GFP-CFTR overexpressing cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	213	 This result evidenced that double transfection did not affect the expression level of exogenous proteins such Syn8TM or GFP-CFTR as compared with cells transfected with only one of these cDNAs.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Thus, we could discount the possibility that the syntaxin 8 inhibitory effect on CFTR trafficking was simply due to an excess of protein biosynthesis in the cell.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	215	Cells overexpressing wild-type syntaxin 8 exhibited a colocalization with GFP-CFTR only in the juxtanuclear region (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	216	 However, accumulation of GFP-CFTR or syntaxin 8 in this region did not seem to be linked to the coexpression of both proteins, as GFP-CFTR or syntaxin 8 alone also had a strong staining of this organelle near the nucleus.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	217	 In the cytoplasm, syntaxin 8 often appeared as dot-like structures corresponding presumably to endosome/lysosome structures, whereas GFP-CFTR appeared more homogenous in the entire cytosol.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	218	 So, apart from juxtanuclear organelles, wild-type syntaxin 8 and GFP-CFTR did not seem to be colocalized in the distal part of cytosol.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	219	 By contrast, the Syn8TM immunostaining pattern colocalized with GFP-CFTR not only in the juxtanuclear area but also in a large part of the cytosol.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	220	 A colocalization between the two proteins was also observed at the plasma membrane in several focal planes (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	221	View larger version (71K):    Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Syntaxin 8 must be anchored in the membrane to inhibit GFP-CFTR plasma membrane localization.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	223	 We compared the intracellular localization of both proteins in COS-7 cells cotransfected with GFP-CFTR and Syn8 (A) or by GFP-CFTR and Syn8TM (B).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Overexpressed (Aa) syntaxin 8 shows a predominantly perinuclear staining and also appears in a cytoplasm punctuated pattern.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	225	 GFP-CFTR presents no plasma membrane localization (Ab), but is accumulated and colocalizes with syntaxin 8 only in the perinuclear region (arrows).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	226	 (B) Soluble syntaxin 8 (Syn8TM) displays a continuous staining within the cell, but is predominantly accumulated in compartments where GFP-CFTR is present, notably at the plasma membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	227	These results showed that overexpressing wild-type syntaxin 8, which is anchored on the vesicle membrane, disturbed CFTR trafficking, whereas cytosoluble syntaxin 8 had no or little effect on CFTR plasma membrane localization.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	228	 As a control, we analyzed the distribution of a plasma membrane Na+/Ca2+ exchanger isoform (NCX2) (Li et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	229	, 1994), which is not known to interact with SNARE proteins.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	230	 As expected, the surface localization of NCX2 in COS-7 cells was not affected by syntaxin 8 overexpression (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	231	GFP-CFTR and syntaxin 8 colocalize and are accumulated in recycling endosomes (RE) in COS-7 transfected cells To identify the subcellular compartments in which GFP-CFTR and syntaxin 8 colocalize, we performed immunofluorescence studies with three well characterized markers of the endosomal and lysosomal compartments on wild-type and doubly transfected COS-7 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	232	 As expected, cells overexpressing GFP-CFTR and syntaxin 8 exhibited a strong staining for both proteins in a juxtanuclear area, a compartment where the two proteins highly colocalize (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Each fluorogram showed that most syntaxin 8 and CFTR fluorescent plots were placed on the bisector line (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	234	 This indicated a high degree of colocalization of both proteins.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	235	 In each immunostaining experiment, the highest intensity of merged fluorescence corresponded to the juxtanuclear region (data not shown).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Syntaxin 8 immunostaining, whether using the rabbit polyclonal antibody (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	237	 7Aa,Ba) or the mouse monoclonal antibody (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	238	 7Ca), gave a classical tubular/vesicular-like pattern.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	239	 GFP-CFTR, as described above, was not localized on plasma membrane but on punctuated and tubular-like structures in the cytosol, and a strong signal was seen on the juxtanuclear area (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	240	 Lamp-1 (an LE/lysosomal marker) staining was observed as a strong vesicular and perinuclear pattern (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	241	 7Ac), but its distribution did not colocalize with Syn8 and GFP-CFTR cellular staining (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	242	 These data were confirmed by fluorograms showing that Lamp-1 fluorescence distribution was clearly separated from CFTR and Syn8 fluorescences (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	243	 By contrast, TfR immunostaining (endocytosis-recycling pathway) revealed a dot-like vesicular pattern more extensive in the cytosol than Lamp-1 staining (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	244	 Intracellular distribution between TfR and CFTR on the one hand (noted TfR/CFTR) and between TfR and Syn8 on the other hand (noted TfR/Syn8) was mostly in distinct compartments within the cell (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	245	 These results were supported by data from fluorograms, which showed two distinct fluorescences in each case.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Several plots with high intensity of overlapping fluorescence suggested a colocalization between TfR and CFTR on the one hand, and between TfR and Syn8 on the other, in vesicular structures near the nucleus (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	247	 When we compared the TfR/CFTR and TfR/Syn8 vesicular pattern in this region (insert), we observed many similarities suggesting that TfR, CFTR and Syn8 were present in the same vesicles.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	248	 As the juxtanuclear colocalization between CFTR and Syn8 partially matched to TfR localization, we could identify these vesicles as recycling or post-Golgi endosomes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	249	 To test our hypothesis, we have used a rabbit polyclonal antibody against Rab11, a protein that has been found associated with trans-Golgi network (TGN) membranes, post-Golgi vesicles and recycling endosomes (Urbe et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	250	 In COS-7 cells, endogenous Rab11 displayed a punctuated vesicular pattern scattered throughout the cytoplasm and seemed to accumulate in a tubulo-vesicular structure near the nucleus (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	251	 In wild-type cells, a partial colocalization was found between Rab11 and TfR stainings (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	252	 7Db), but no overlap was detected between Rab11 and Lamp-1 stainings (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Finally, in COS-7 cells transfected with GFP-CFTR and Syn8, the Rab11 immunostaining profile matched exactly with CFTR and Syn8 stainings (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	254	 These results were sustained by fluorogram data showing Rab11/Syn8 and Rab11/CFTR fluorescent plots only on bisector line (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	255	 This clearly showed that these proteins had the same localization.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	256	 In conclusion, when syntaxin 8 inhibits CFTR trafficking in COS-7 transfected cells, CFTR appears to be restricted to a compartment including at least the recycling endosomes and possibly other post-Golgi vesicles.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	257	View larger version (63K):    Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	258	 GFP-CFTR and syntaxin 8 colocalize at least in the recycling endosome complexes in doubly transfected COS-7 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	259	 In each experiment (except D), COS-7 cells were cotransfected with GFP-CFTR and Syn8, then costained with anti-syntaxin 8 antibody and anti-Lamp-1 (A), anti-TfR (B) or anti-Rab11 (C) antibodies.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	260	 All cell images present the projection of the entire Z series sections acquired by fluorescent confocal microscopy.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	261	 Fluorograms were obtained as described in Materials and Methods.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	262	 In each experiment, protein colocalizations were analyzed with three fluorograms.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	263	 Syntaxin 8 (a in A-C) and GFP-CFTR (b in A-C) exhibit perinuclear staining as expected.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	264	 These two proteins colocalize in the perinuclear region as shown in the merged images (d in A-C) and fluorograms (e in A-C).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Lamp-1 immunostaining pattern (Ac) exhibits no colocalization with GFP-CFTR and syntaxin 8 both on merged image (Ad) and fluorograms (Af,g), whereas the immunostaining profile obtained with TfR (Bc) presents a partial colocalization on merged picture (Bd) and fluorograms (Bf,g).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	266	 To further analyze colocalization compartments, we selected plots with high fluorescence intensity and placed them on the fluorogram bisector line (square in Bf,g) to generate images showing the colocalization patterns between CFTR and TfR (Bf') or Syn8 and TfR (Bg').
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	267	 The vesicular pattern obtained in each case is very similar and shows a colocalization between the three proteins within these vesicles.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	268	 By contrast, Rab11 immunostaining (Cc) closely matches in the perinuclear region with CFTR and syntaxin 8 stainings (Cd).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	269	 This high degree of colocalization is sustained by fluorogram data (Cf,g) displaying Rab11/CFTR or Rab11/Syn8 fluorescent plots placed on the bisector line.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	270	 As a control, we have studied endogenous localization between Rab11 and Lamp-1 or between Rab11 and TfR in wild type COS-7 cells.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	271	 As expected, no overlap was found between Lamp-1 and Rab11 stainings (Da), whereas a partial colocalization was observed in the perinuclear region between Rab11 and TfR (Db).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Each analysis is representative of three independent experiments.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	273	Syntaxin 8 physically interacts with CFTR To test the physical interaction between syntaxin 8 and CFTR, we performed immunoprecipitation experiments in CHO-2T and HT29-CL19A cell lines expressing both syntaxin 8 and CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	274	 Using lysates from both cell lines, we purified syntaxin 8 or CFTR complexes using monoclonal syntaxin 8 or CFTR antibodies, respectively.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	275	 As expected, syntaxin 8 and CFTR immunoprecipitated with high efficiency (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	276	 In these syntaxin 8 complexes, anti-CFTR western blot revealed the presence of the mature (band C) and immature (band B) forms of CFTR in each cell line (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	277	 Reversibly, in CFTR complexes, anti-syntaxin 8 western blot revealed a significant amount of the protein (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	278	 Notably, the existence of such an interaction in untransfected HT29-CL19A cells suggests the physiological relevance of this result.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	279	View larger version (39K):    Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	280	 CFTR and syntaxin 8 belong to the same protein complex.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	281	 (A) Co-immunoprecipitation of CFTR with Syn8 in CHO-2T and HT29-CL19A cell lysates.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Immunoprecipitated proteins were revealed after western blot with antibodies against CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	283	 Bands B and C represent immature and mature forms of CFTR, respectively.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	284	 CFTR antibody and nonimmune mouse IgG were used as positive and negative immunoprecipitation controls, respectively.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	285	 (B) Co-immunoprecipitation of Syn8 with CFTR in CHO-2T and HT29-CL19A cell lysates.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	286	 Immunoprecipitated proteins were revealed after western blot with antibodies against Syn8.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	287	 CHO-2T and HT29 cells lysates were used as a positive control for western blot.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Syn 8 antibody and nonimmune mouse IgG were used as positive and negative immunoprecipitation controls, respectively.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	289	We also investigated the interaction between CFTR and syntaxin 8 by an in vitro affinity binding assay using four recombinant GST-fusion proteins: as a positive control, the cytosolic domain of syntaxin 1A (Syn1ATM), the cytosolic domain of syntaxin 8 (Syn8TM), and two truncated domains of syntaxin 8 (Syn8[1-99] and Syn8[99-209]).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Recombinant GST protein was used as a negative control.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	291	 Bead-bound recombinant proteins were incubated with COS-7+GFP-CFTR cell lysate, and retained proteins were analyzed by western blot using an anti-GFP antibody (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	292	 A COS-7+GFP-CFTR cell lysate was used as a GFP-CFTR control.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	293	 The N-terminal tagging of CFTR by GFP did not affect the in vitro binding of syntaxin 1A, which has been shown to interact with the N-terminus of CFTR (Naren et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	294	 GFP-CFTR was pulled down with syntaxin 8 either with the full-length cytosolic domain of syntaxin 8 or with each of its truncated domain but predominantly with its N-terminal half upstream of its t-SNARE domain.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	295	 However, this interaction was far weaker compared with GFP-CFTR binding to syntaxin 1A.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	296	 Nevertheless, these results were significant as CFTR was not retained by GST alone.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	297	 Because pull-down experiments revealed a weak physical interaction between syntaxin 8 and CFTR, we hypothesized that intermediary proteins could be involved in CFTR/syntaxin 8 complexes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	298	 The best candidates were the other components of the endosomal SNARE complex: VAMP8, vti1b and syntaxin 7.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	299	 Similarly, we produced these recombinant SNARE proteins to test their interaction with CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	300	 GFP-CFTR was pulled down either with VAMP8 or vti1b but not with syntaxin 7 (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	301	 These data suggested that endosomal SNARE proteins VAMP8 or vti1b bound CFTR in vitro with a comparable efficiency to syntaxin 1A (Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	302	View larger version (48K):    Fig.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	303	 In vitro interactions between CFTR and endosomal SNARE proteins.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	304	 (A) In vitro binding of GFP-CFTR with different recombinant cytosolic domains of syntaxin 8: GST-Syn8TM, GST-Syn8[1-99] and GST-Syn8[99-209].
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	305	 (B) In vitro binding of GFP-CFTR with different recombinant endosomal SNARE proteins: GST-Syn7TM, GST-VAMP8TM and GST-vti1bTM.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	306	 (A,B) Glutathione-sepharose-immobilized GST or GST-fusion proteins were incubated with COS-7+GFP-CFTR cell extracts.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	307	 Bound proteins were studied by anti-GFP immunoblot.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	308	 COS-7+GFP-CFTR lysate was used as a GFP-CFTR control; GST-Syn1ATM and GST alone were used, respectively, as positive and negative pull-down controls.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	309	Regulation of CFTR channel activity by syntaxin 8 We have observed that syntaxin 8 overexpression is responsible for a strong inhibition of CFTR channel, activated either by the cAMP pathway (forskolin stimulation) or by a cAMP-independent pathway through the CFTR activator MPB-91 (Derand et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Such regulation of ionic channels by SNARE proteins has already been described.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	311	 For example, physical interactions have been assessed between syntaxin 1A and P/Q-type calcium channels, N-type calcium channels (Bezprozvanny et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	312	, 2000) and amiloride-sensitive epithelial sodium channels (Saxena et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Interestingly, syntaxin 1A inhibits CFTR chloride current by direct protein-protein interaction between the t-SNARE homology domain of syntaxin 1A and the N-terminal cytoplasmic tail of CFTR (Naren et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	314	 In another study (Peters et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	315	, 1999), cAMP-induced delivery to plasma membrane of CFTR present in peripheral vesicles was inhibited by syntaxin 1A in Xenopus oocytes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	316	 As in the case of syntaxin 1A, our electrophysiological data indeed showed an inhibition of the CFTR activity due to syntaxin 8 overexpression.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	317	 This regulation is protein specific, as when we performed the same experiment with syntaxin 3, a SNARE protein that does not bind CFTR, we obtained a normal CFTR activation.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Moreover, CFTR modulation required syntaxin 8 to be anchored in membrane, as we showed that its soluble form has no effect on CFTR activity.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Thus, CFTR may directly be regulated by a protein-protein interaction, or alternatively, syntaxin 8 overexpression may disturb the vesicular transport machinery.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	320	 This could affect CFTR recycling or cellular targeting towards the plasma membrane and consequently inhibit the chloride channel activity measured at the cell level.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	321	Physical interactions between syntaxin 8 and CFTR We have shown a direct protein-protein interaction, given that CFTR was pulled down using immobilized GST-syntaxin 8 recombinant proteins.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	322	 Moreover, CFTR and syntaxin 8 could be co-immunoprecipitated with each other from CHO-2T or HT29-CL19A cell extracts.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	323	 These data suggest that syntaxin 8 interacts with CFTR either directly, or as a component of a CFTR-containing complex.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	324	 However, this interaction is different from the one observed between syntaxin 1A and CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Recombinant GST-syntaxin 1A binds CFTR with a high affinity (Naren et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	326	, 1997), whereas the interaction between syntaxin 8 and CFTR appears to be weaker.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Moreover, unlike syntaxin 1A in which only the t-SNARE domain interacts with CFTR, each moiety of syntaxin 8 binds CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	328	 Despite the fact that it will be necessary to test the in vitro binding between the different domains of CFTR and syntaxin 8 to ascertain a direct physical interaction, the immunoprecipitation results confirm that syntaxin 8 and CFTR are part of the same complex.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	329	 As we have precipitated both proteins with the same efficiency in CHO transfected cells and in HT29-CL19A cells (endogenously expressing both CFTR and syntaxin 8), we conclude that this interaction was not induced solely by overexpression.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	330	 As the affinity between syntaxin 8 and CFTR is weak, syntaxin 8 may not be the major partner of CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Tierce proteins may be necessary to establish a protein complex containing syntaxin 8 and CFTR.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	332	 This hypothesis is consistent with the pull-down and immunoprecipitation experiments, and could explain the small amount of CFTR retained by GST-syntaxin 8.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Possible candidates partner are the different components of the heterotetrameric endosomal SNARE core complex: vti1b, syntaxin 7 and VAMP8 (Antonin et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	334	 Our pull-down experiments suggest that VAMP8 and vti1b, which strongly and directly interact with CFTR, could be partner proteins involved in a CFTR/syntaxin 8 multimeric protein complex.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	335	 This result strengthens the idea that an entire SNARE complex could regulate ion channel delivery/insertion, retrieval or recycling to the plasma membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	336	Syntaxin 8 is involved in CFTR trafficking Syntaxin 8 physical binding and functional regulation of CFTR prompted us to investigate, at the cellular level, the effect of syntaxin 8 overexpression on CFTR localization.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	337	 GFP fluorescence analysis on COS-7+GFP-CFTR cells showed a strong plasma membrane staining characteristic of mature CFTR cellular localization.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	338	 However, when syntaxin 8 was cotransfected with GFP-CFTR, a dramatic decrease or a disappearance of CFTR plasma membrane staining was observed and both proteins colocalized in a perinuclear region.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	339	 Syntaxin 8 impact on CFTR trafficking does not apply to any channel as, when we overexpressed syntaxin 8, the plasma membrane localization of endogenous Na+/Ca2+ exchanger was not affected.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	340	Moreover, coexpression of GFP-CFTR and Syn8TM, a cytosoluble form of syntaxin 8 (depleted of its transmembrane domain), led to a normal trafficking of GFP-CFTR to the plasma membrane.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Furthermore, a plasma membrane colocalization between Syn8TM and GFP-CFTR was observed and, interestingly, Syn8TM was seen in the plasma membrane only if CFTR was present too.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	342	 More generally, Syn8TM is located mainly in cellular structures where GFP-CFTR is abundant.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	343	 So, when syntaxin 8 is soluble, it may physically bind CFTR and follow its trafficking, but when syntaxin 8 is anchored in vesicle membrane, it binds CFTR too, but only in the cellular compartment where syntaxin 8 assumes its function (i.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	344	 As Syn8TM had no or little effect on CFTR trafficking, inhibition of CFTR trafficking by syntaxin 8 overexpression could not be related to an excess of protein synthesis in endoplasmic reticulum.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	345	 Moreover, syntaxin 8 must be anchored in vesicle membranes to impair CFTR trafficking, which means that the t-SNARE function of syntaxin 8 can be engaged.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	346	 These results reinforce the physiological relevance of a putative regulator role of syntaxin 8 on CFTR channel activity.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	347	Syntaxin 8 is involved in CFTR recycling pathway The precise identification of the colocalization region of CFTR and syntaxin 8 was determined using fluorescent confocal microscopy and three well characterized antibodies against Lamp-1, an LE/lysosomal marker protein, TfR (transferrin receptor), an EE/RE marker protein, and Rab11, which stains RE and TGN membranes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	348	 Our results exhibited no colocalization between Lamp-1 staining and the juxtanuclear compartment where CFTR and syntaxin 8 were accumulated.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	349	 TfR vesicular pattern partially matched with this region, and CFTR, syntaxin 8 and TfR seemed to be located together in thin perinuclear vesicles.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	350	 By contrast, Rab11 staining was highly similar to syntaxin 8 and CFTR juxtanuclear staining and we observed a high degree of colocalization both on fluorograms and on the merged image.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	351	 These results indicate that when syntaxin 8 is overexpressed with GFP-CFTR, both proteins are mainly localized in the same compartment, which could be identified as recycling endosomes and/or TGN membranes.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	352	 Because we have colocalized CFTR and syntaxin 8 with TfR and Rab11 proteins, we favour the recycling endosome hypothesis.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	353	Syntaxin 8 is a t-SNARE protein that belongs at least to the endosomal SNARE complex (Antonin et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	354	, 2000), and is consequently involved in the endosomal pathway like syntaxins 7, 11 and 12/13 (Prekeris et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	355	 Its cellular localization was determined mainly in the early endosome, but syntaxin 8 was also detected in the late endosome and lysosome organelles.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	356	 The early endosome is a dynamic compartment displaying a highly complex and pleiomorphic organization that contains clearly two functionally distinct subcompartments without real physical boundaries: plasma membrane proteins are recycled via the recycling endosomes or degraded via the endosomal carrier vesicles/multivesicular bodies of the degradation pathway (reviewed by Gruenberg, 2001).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	357	 In some cases, syntaxin 8 was also observed at the plasma membrane (Subramaniam et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	358	, 2000; Kasai and Akagawa, 2001), suggesting a vesicular cycling of syntaxin 8.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	359	The mechanism of CFTR recycling is still poorly understood, but CFTR has previously been detected in recycling endosomes using fluorescence microscopy in human bronchial epithelial cells (Poschet et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	360	 Thus, physical binding between CFTR and syntaxin 8 may occur in recycling endosomes, a cellular compartment which is required for CFTR recycling pathway and where syntaxin 8, probably assembled with other SNARE proteins (i.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	361	 endosomal SNARE complex), is implicated in its vesicular trafficking function.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	362	 Syntaxin 8 overexpression is likely to disrupt the vesicular transport step in which it is involved, as it has been previously observed for several SNARE proteins (Dascher and Balch, 1996; Low et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	363	 This could explain CFTR accumulation in recycling endosomes in our experiments.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	364	 So our results show that syntaxin 8 appears as an important regulatory protein directly implicated in CFTR recycling pathway.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	365	In conclusion, SNARE proteins, and particularly syntaxin 8, participate actively in CFTR trafficking, recycling and/or in direct regulation of CFTR activity.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	366	 Here, we describe a relationship between CFTR and syntaxin 8 in the recycling endosome.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	367	 A recent paper showed that in cystic fibrosis cells a dysfunction in the recycling endosome pathway may have many repercussions on endocytic and plasma membrane processes (Poschet et al.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	368	 So elucidating the recycling pathway of CFTR could be important in understanding the physiopathology of cystic fibrosis.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	369	   Acknowledgments   We thank the following people for their gift or reagents: J.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	370	 Stanton (GFP-CFTR construct); A.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	371	 Naren (GST-Syn1ATM construct); W.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	372	 von Mollard (endosomal SNARE constructs); Y.
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	373	 Salamero (Rab11 antibody and helpful discussions).
0.44555384.15039462.html.plaintext.txt	374	 This work was supported by Vaincre la Mucoviscidose and Region Poitou-Charentes.

0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	0	Temporal regulation of CFTR expression during ovine lung development: implications for CF gene therapy Fiona C.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Broackes-Carter, Nathalie Mouchel, Deborah Gill1, Stephen Hyde1, John Bassett2 and Ann Harris+.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	2	Paediatric Molecular Genetics, Institute of Molecular Medicine, Oxford University, John Radcliffe Hospital, Oxford OX3 9DS, UK, 1Nuffield Department of Clinical Laboratory Sciences, Oxford University, John Radcliffe Hospital, Oxford OX3 9DU, UK and 2Growth and Development Unit, Field Laboratory, Oxford University, Oxford OX2 8QJ, UK.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received September 10, 2001; Revised and Accepted November 13, 2001.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	4	Relatively little attention has been given to progression of CF disease in utero though this affects postnatal pathology and may be of relevance to the likely success of gene therapy.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	5	 The initial pathology of CF is exhibited in the pancreas in the early second trimester of gestation, when proteinaceous material starts to obstruct the ductal tree (8,9).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	6	 This is perhaps not surprising since CFTR is expressed in epithelia from before the start of the second trimester of human development and CFTR expression levels are high in the mid-trimester pancreas (10 to 12).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In most tissues the CFTR expression levels show little fluctuation between the second trimester of gestation and postnatal life.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	8	 However, CFTR appears to be developmentally regulated in both human and sheep lung epithelium (11 to 13) where high expression levels during fetal life are in contrast to much lower abundance of CFTR mRNA by birth, and into adulthood.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	9	 The significance of this down-regulation of CFTR expression is the major focus of this work.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	10	Since it is not feasible to investigate human lung development in utero, we have used the sheep to provide a useful model of human lung development (14).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The sheep lung is anatomically more similar to human than that of the mouse, having submucosal glands throughout the cartilagenous airway.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The expression pattern of CFTR in sheep is similar to humans, both temporally and spatially and we have shown that the ovine CFTR gene sequence shows close homology to the human gene (14,15).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Expression of CFTR during human and sheep lung development has so far been assessed primarily by means of in situ hybridization (11,12), northern blotting (10,13) and reverse transcriptase to polymerase chain reaction (RT to PCR) (10,13).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	14	 CFTR expression levels are high in the lung during the second trimester of gestation and low postnatally.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	15	 To date, developmental expression of CFTR has only been examined at a limited number of time points and data have not been accurately quantitative.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Our aim was to evaluate CFTR expression at specific time points throughout gestation using a real-time quantitative RT to PCR assay provided by TaqMan technology.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	17	 We have generated a developmental profile of CFTR mRNA in sheep with particular attention to the down-regulation of CFTR in the respiratory system.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	18	 This profile has identified key gestational ages where CFTR expression is maximal and hence when targeting of potential in utero therapies might be of most benefit.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	19	View larger version (41K):    Figure 1.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Developmental expression of CFTR in ovine airway.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Ovine lung samples from 52, 66, 83, 94, 108, 129 and 143 days gestation (G), 147 days (term) (T) and 2 days post-term (PT).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Semi-quantitative RT to PCR using CFTR primers C2R and C2L yielding a 792 bp fragment and ovine ATP synthase primers F1 and R1 producing a 530 bp fragment.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Fragments were separated on a 1.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	24	5% agarose gel and stained with ethidium bromide.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	25	  Validation of the real-time CFTR RT to PCR assay target The region of the ovine CFTR gene chosen for generating the TaqMan amplifying primers and probe covered the boundary between exons 6a and 6b.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Since the CFTR gene is known to exhibit a range of alternatively spliced forms in a number of species (18) it was necessary to confirm that no aberrant transcripts lacking parts of exons 6a and 6b were produced from the ovine gene.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	27	 Conventional RT to PCR was carried out using primers spanning exons 4 to 7 and no alternative transcripts lacking exons 6a or 6b were detected in RNA from lung at mid-gestation or birth, pancreas, small intestine, salivary gland and colon at 2 days after birth (data not shown).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	28	 These results suggested that the real-time TaqMan RT to PCR assay targeted to the exon 6a/6b boundary, would accurately reflect total CFTR mRNA transcription.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	29	Real-time RT to PCR for CFTR mRNA in ovine fetal tissues The real-time RT to PCR assay for ovine CFTR mRNA was optimized and its reproducibility established.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Values obtained from reactions in which template was omitted, consistently fell below the range of the standard curve and were  < 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Standard curves were highly reproducible for the ovine CFTR and ribosomal RNA assays (R2 = 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	32	99) and genomic contribution to the RT to PCR reactions was  < 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	33	Two series of experiments were performed: the first evaluated CFTR expression in ovine lung tissues throughout the developmental time course; the second evaluated CFTR expression in eight ovine tissues at 83 and 108 days of gestation and at 2 days post-term.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	34	Developmental expression of ovine CFTR in the lung The developmental profile of CFTR expression in the lung showed a gradual fall in mRNA levels though the 147 days of gestation (Fig.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Values at 52 days of gestation, the end of the first trimester, were 75-fold higher than those at birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	36	 By 66 days, CFTR mRNA levels were reduced 4.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	37	5-fold before increasing between 74 and 80 days.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	38	 After levels peaked at 80 days of gestation, there was a gradual decline toward birth with negligible levels of expression by 4 days before term (143 days) and at birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Two days after parturition, levels of CFTR mRNA increased slightly and this expression level was maintained at 2 weeks of age and in adult sheep tissue.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Experiments were performed three times with samples analysed in triplicate.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	41	 To evaluate the variation in CFTR expression levels in individuals at specific time points, samples were analysed from a sib pair at 74 days gestation and a half-sib pair at 2 days after birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	42	 In both cases, CFTR expression levels were not significantly different from each other (74 days, P = 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	43	86; two-tailed Student s t-test).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	44	View larger version (15K):    Figure 2.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Developmental expression of CFTR in ovine airway.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Quantitative RT to PCR using an ABI Prism 7700 sequence detection system.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Ovine lung samples were from 52, 66, 74, 80, 83, 90, 94, 108, 129 and 143 days gestation (G), 147 days (term) (T) and 2 and 14 days post-term (PT) and adult (A).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Mean values of triplicate assays are expressed as a percentage of CFTR mRNA in lung at 83 days.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Data are derived from CT values (threshold cycle at which a statistically significant increase in emission is first detected) produced by the ABI Prism 7700 sequence detection system for a CFTR assay normalized to 18S ribosomal RNA.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Error bars represent SD values.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	51	  Developmental expression of ovine CFTR in other organs The developmental expression of ovine CFTR in pancreas, small intestine, colon, trachea, salivary gland, kidney and muscle was evaluated at three different time points (83 and 108 days of gestation and 2 days post-term) (Fig.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Muscle provided a negative control and as expected had negligible amounts of CFTR mRNA expression for all three time points in these experiments.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Experiments were performed three times with samples analysed in triplicate.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	54	View larger version (25K):    Figure 3.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Developmental expression of CFTR in ovine tissues.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Quantitative RT to PCR using an ABI Prism 7700 sequence detection system.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Ovine tissue samples, pancreas, small intestine, colon, lung, trachea, salivary gland, kidney and muscle were from 83 and 108 days gestation (G) and 2 days post-term (PT).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Mean values of triplicate assays are expressed as a percentage of CFTR mRNA in lung at 83 days.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Data are derived from CT values produced by the ABI Prism 7700 sequence detection system for a CFTR assay normalized to 18S ribosomal RNA.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Error bars represent SD values.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	61	  These are the first quantitative data that enable comparison of CFTR expression levels between tissues of the one species.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	62	 They confirm the observation that the levels of CFTR mRNA in the pancreas and digestive system are significantly higher (at least 5-fold) than in the lung epithelium even at the time of maximal expression in the respiratory system.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The observation of greater levels of CFTR mRNA in the colon than in the small intestine is probably a unique feature of the sheep and its digestive system as there are data to show the opposite distribution in the human intestine (11).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Glandular organs such as pancreas, lung and salivary gland had a similar pattern of expression characterized by higher expression early in gestation followed by a decline towards birth with levels maintained 2 days post-term.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	65	 CFTR mRNA levels were higher in both pancreas and salivary gland than in lung.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	66	 In trachea CFTR mRNA levels were comparable to values in lung during gestation but rose at 2 days post-term.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Small intestine expressed lower levels of CFTR mRNA before birth in comparison to 2 days after birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Colon initially expressed very high amounts of CFTR mRNA, which then decreased slightly at mid-gestation before rising again to a high level after birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	69	 CFTR mRNA expression in the ovine kidney is very low and declines between 83 and 2 days post-term.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	70	Developmental expression of ovine ENaC in the lung The CFTR and ENaC ion channels are thought to interact directly (2), hence it was pertinent to evaluate also the developmental expression of ENaC in the ovine lung.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	71	 These assays were performed using conventional RT to PCR rather than real-time TaqMan RT to PCR due to lack of full sequence information for ovine ENaC and reported alternative splicing of this gene (19).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	72	 In marked contrast to CFTR, expression of the subunit of ENaC is very low in the ovine lung at 52 days of gestation, but gradually rises through 108, 129, 143 and 147 (term) days of gestation to much higher levels in 2 days post-term and adult lung (Fig.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Again, subunit c of the ATP synthase was used as a reference standard (17) for these semi-quantitative RT to PCR reactions.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	74	View larger version (36K):    Figure 4.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Developmental expression of ENaC in ovine airway.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Ovine lung samples from 52, 66, 83, 94, 108, 129 and 143 days gestation (G), 147 days (term) (T), 2 and 14 days post-term (PT) and adult.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Semi-quantitative RT to PCR using ENaC primers ENaF and ENaR yielding a 373 bp fragment and ovine ATP synthase primers F1 and R1 producing a 530 bp fragment.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Fragments were separated on a 1.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	79	5% agarose gel and stained with ethidium bromide.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	80	However, the previous data did not evaluate CFTR expression throughout gestation.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The gradual decline in CFTR that we observed during ovine fetal lung development could be accounted for by at least two explanations.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Either, the percentage of cells that express CFTR within the lung epithelium decrease with time or the levels of expression within the same cell type gradually decreases.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	83	 On the basis of previous data we would expect the former explanation to be correct.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	84	 In postnatal human lung epithelium significant CFTR expression is limited to specific cells within the serous portion of submucosal glands and individual cells in the airway surface epithelium (20,21).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	85	 This is in contrast to the apparent expression of CFTR mRNA in the majority of cells in the fetal lung epithelium (11).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Furthermore, in human trachea, CFTR expression was seen to be intermediate and diffuse during the first trimester by in situ hybridization (11).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	87	 In the second trimester, CFTR mRNA expression was reduced and limited to a subset of cells in the epithelia of the trachea and by the third trimester, only individual cells expressed CFTR but at very high levels (12).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	88	High levels of CFTR mRNA expression have been observed by in situ hybridization in pancreas, small intestine and colon from an early gestational age in humans (11).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	89	 These expression levels remain constant throughout gestation in contrast to lung expression patterns.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The temporal and spatial expression of CFTR mRNA in ovine small intestine, pancreas, colon, salivary gland and kidney and muscle seen in our experiments, closely parallel the human gene (13).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	91	 However, the quantitative assays show that in contrast to the human CFTR gene, which is expressed at a higher level in the crypts of the small intestine than in the colon, ovine CFTR mRNA is most abundant in the colonic epithelium.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	92	 This may reflect functional differences in the ruminant digestive system.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	93	 It is of interest that the decline of CFTR expression observed in ovine fetal lung between 83 days gestation and 2 days after birth is also seen in pancreas and salivary gland.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	94	 CFTR may have a significant role in the development and differentiation of other glandular tissues.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	95	The physiological implications of the gradual decline in lung CFTR expression levels during gestation warrant further discussion.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The fetal lung is filled with a high chloride, low pH fluid that is distinct from amniotic fluid.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Chloride is actively secreted from the lung epithelium into the lung lumen during development and as a chloride ion channel, CFTR protein could contribute to this process.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	98	 However, chloride conductances other than CFTR are likely to be more important in fetal lung fluid secretion since CF is not associated with hypoplastic lungs at birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Furthermore, the profile of CFTR expression during gestation does not correspond to changes in lung liquid secretion (22,23).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	100	Postnatally, the major ion flows across the airway epithelium are uptake of sodium.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Lung liquid begins to be reabsorbed by ovine lung epithelium at 140 days of gestation.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Sodium reabsorption is achieved primarily by sodium channels located on the apical surface of the lung epithelium, the main one being the ENaC (24).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Recent data have shown that ENaC is inhibited by CFTR, which probably interacts directly with it (2,25,26).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	104	 The gradual decline in CFTR mRNA levels and protein would be compatible with enabling ENaC activity.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Furthermore, we have shown that the abundance of ENaC transcripts is inversely proportional to the levels of CFTR mRNA in the developing ovine lung after the second trimester, hence the expression of the genes encoding these two ion channels may be also coordinately regulated.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	106	An additional possibility is that CFTR expression in the fetal lung epithelium has an important, as yet undefined functional role in normal lung development.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Though at birth lung pathology is not usually evident in CF, absence of functional CFTR protein in the developing lung has been reported to produce a pro-inflammatory state (27).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Increased levels of interleukin-8 were observed in the airway surface fluid of human CF fetal tracheal grafts implanted into severe combined immunodeficient (SCID) mice.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Though this apparent pro-inflammatory state of the epithelia did not result directly in histological abnormalities, challenge with Pseudomonas aeruginosa provoked an exaggerated immune response resulting in sloughing of epithelial cells and increased leukocyte activity, thereby increasing likelihood of further bacterial colonization (27).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	110	The high levels of CFTR expression early in gestation may correspond to an important function of CFTR protein unique to this developmental stage.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	111	 The periods of high and low CFTR expression that we have defined, correspond to distinct developmental phases in the sheep lung.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Relatively high levels of CFTR mRNA expression are observed during the pseudoglandular phase (between 40 and 80 days of sheep gestation) when the bronchial tree and acini form.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	113	 During the developmental progression to the canalicular phase (80 to 120 days of gestation) when differentiation into type I and II epithelial cells occurs, CFTR mRNA levels begin to decline, and remain low until birth.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	114	 (28) have shown that overexpression of CFTR in the lungs of wild-type mice, at 15 to 16 days (corresponding to the late pseudoglandular and early canalicular developmental stages), advanced epithelial cell proliferation and differentiation.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Furthermore, the same investigators suggested that transient expression of CFTR in CF mice following intramniotic injection of adeno-CFTR cDNA at 15 to 16 days of mouse gestation, corrected the lethal intestinal disease (29).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	116	 The expression profile of CFTR in the developing sheep lung is consistent with data from the mouse that suggest a crucial role for CFTR in lung epithelial maturation.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	117	 These observations may have important implications for current attempts to treat CF airway disease by postnatal gene therapy.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	118	Extraction of RNA from ovine tissues Tissue was homogenized in glass homogenizers and RNA was prepared by guanidinium thiocyanate extraction (30).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Following ethanol precipitation samples were stored at  to 20 degrees C.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The RNA pellet was resuspended in nuclease-free water and OD260 determined.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	121	 Volumes were adjusted to a concentration of 100 to 250 ng/ microl before aliquoting and storage at  to 20 degrees C.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	122	RT to PCR for ovine CFTR and ENac RT to PCRs were carried out as previously described by Chalkley and Harris (16) across the region encompassing exons 4 (4S3R, 5'-GGAATGCAGATGAGAATAGC-3') to 7 (A1L, 5'-GCTCCAAGAGAGTCATACCA-3') to ascertain whether alternative splicing of exons 6a and or 6b occurred.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	123	 For semi-quantitative RT to PCR, CFTR cDNA synthesis was primed with 3' primer (C2L) 5'-TCTTCACTTATTTCCAAGCC-3'.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	124	 cDNA was generated using Superscript (Life Technologies) at 42 degrees C for 1 h, PCR was then performed with the 5' primer C2R (16) 5'-AGCAGTATACAAAGATGCTG-3' and C2L (94 degrees C for 5 min, then 30 cycles of 94 degrees C for 1 min, 60 degrees C for 1 min, 72 degrees C for 1 min followed by a final cycle of extension at 72 degrees C for 5 min).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Primer concentrations were 10 ng/ microl.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Subunit c of sheep mitochondrial ATP synthase was coamplified as a control for total RNA using primers F1 and R1 at concentrations of 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	127	 For semi-quantitative RT to PCR of ovine ENaC reactions were carried out as described for CFTR but using primers for the subunit of ENaC subunit.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	128	 The 5' primer, 5'-CTGCTACACTTTCAACGACA-3', and the 3' primer, 5'-CTCCTTGATCATGCTCTCCT-3', were both used at 5 ng/ microl, and primers for ovine ATP synthase were used at 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	129	5 ng/ microl (annealing temperature of the PCR was 65 degrees C and extension time was 5 min).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	130	Real-time quantitative RT to PCR (TaqMan) using the ABI Prism 7700 sequence detection system (Applied Biosystems) Primer and probe sequences were designed using the ovine CFTR cDNA sequence (GenBank accession no.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	131	 U20418) and ABI PrimerExpress 1.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The ovine CFTR 5' primer was located in exon 6a, 5'-AAGCCGGGTTAGGGAAAATG-3'.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	133	 The 3' primer was located in exon 6b, 5'-TGCCTTAACTGATTGGATATTTTCAA-3'; the ovine CFTR TaqMan probe was 5'-CATTGATCTTTCCAGCTCTCTGATCTCTGTACTTCAT-3' and contained reporter dye FAM at the 5' end and quencher dye TAMRA at the 3' end.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	134	 18S rRNA primer and probes (5' primer, 5'-CGGCTACCACATCCAAGGAA-3'; 3' primer, 5'-GCTGGAATTACCGCGGCT-3'; and 5' VIC, 3' TAMRA modified probe 5'-TGCTGGCACCAGACTTGCCCTC-3') were supplied by Applied Biosystems.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	135	A one-step RT to PCR approach was adopted for quantitative analysis.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Independent assays were performed on each experimental sample to determine levels of both CFTR mRNA and 18S rRNA.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Variations in RNA loading between samples were controlled by normalizing levels of CFTR mRNA to levels of 18S rRNA.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	138	 CFTR RT to PCR assays (25  microl final volume) were performed using the TaqMan Gold RT to PCR Kit (Applied Biosystems) and contained 1x Buffer A, 7.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	139	3 mM each of dATP, dCTP, dGTP and 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	140	2 U/ microl RNase Inhibitor, 300 nM each of 5' and 3' primers and 100 nM probe, and included 5  microl of experimental total RNA template.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	141	 18S rRNA assays were identical in composition, except that reactions contained 5.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Experimental total RNA samples were diluted to 10 ng/ microl for the CFTR assays and to 0.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	143	01 ng/ microl for the 18S rRNA assays.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	144	 Reactions were carried out in MicroAmp Optical 96-well plates covered with MicroAmp Optical caps (Applied Biosystems).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	145	 The TaqMan RT conditions were 48 degrees C for 30 min followed by AmpliTaq Gold activation at 95 degrees C for 10 min and 40 PCR cycles of 95 degrees C for 15 s and 60 degrees C for 1 min.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	146	Data were analysed using ABI Sequence Detector software version 1.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Relative standard curves for CFTR and 18S rRNA levels were generated from seven, sequential, 5-fold dilutions of a common arbitrary sample of lung RNA at 83 days gestation.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	148	 The determined arbitrary values for CFTR were divided by the appropriate 18S rRNA value to give an expression ratio.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	149	 This ratio was then expressed as a percentage of one chosen sample (the  calibrator ).
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	150	 For all experiments, total RNA at 83 days of gestation was used as the calibrator sample.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Standards and experimental samples were assayed three times with each sample analysed in triplicate in each experiment.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Reaction controls were performed which omitted RT and/or template RNA.
0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Standard curves were fitted by linear regression and goodness of fit was reported as the coefficient of determination (R2).
