0.45434183.11809721.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Biochemistry, 18, 5294 to 5299.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	0	Proliferation, not apoptosis, alters epithelial cell migration in small intestine of CFTR null mice Ann Marie Gallagher and Roberta A.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Molecular and Experimental Medicine, The Scripps Research Institute, La Jolla, California 92037.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	2	Expression of a mutated cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) has been shown to enhance proliferation within CF airways, and cells expressing a mutated CFTR have been shown to be less susceptible to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Because the CFTR is expressed in the epithelial cells lining the gastrointestinal tract and all CF mouse models are characterized by gastrointestinal obstruction, we hypothesized that CFTR null mice would have increased epithelial cell proliferation and reduced apoptosis within the small intestine.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	4	 The rate of intestinal epithelial cell migration from crypt to villus was increased in CFTR null mice relative to mice expressing the wild-type CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	5	 This difference in migration could be explained by an increase in epithelial cell proliferation but not by a difference in apoptosis within the crypts of Lieberkuhn.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	6	 In addition, using two independent sets of CF cell lines, we found that epithelial cell susceptibility to apoptosis was unrelated to the presence of a functional CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Thus increased proliferation but not alterations in apoptosis within epithelial cells might contribute to the pathophysiology of CF.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	8	cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; animal model; pathophysiology.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	9	THE CYSTIC FIBROSIS TRANSMEMBRANE conductance regulator (CFTR) is a chloride channel that is mutated in CF.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Mutation of the CFTR results in a decrease in epithelial cell chloride permeability.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Although the defect affects all exocrine tissues, in humans it manifests itself primarily in the airways and intestine.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	12	 CF is characterized by reduced chloride and fluid secretion, which results in accumulation of mucus within the bronchioles and in meconium ileus in CF newborns and intestinal obstructions in older CF patients.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	13	 In all mouse models of CF in which the CFTR has been deleted by insertional or deletional mutagenesis, intestinal pathophysiology is characterized by mucus accumulation in the crypts of Lieberkuhn, goblet cell hyperplasia, and intestinal obstruction.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	14	 In addition, the CFTR is expressed in the epithelial cells lining the gastrointestinal tract with a reduction in expression along the crypt-to-villus axis (7, 26).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	15	Previously, Gottlieb and Dosanjh (9) showed that cultured C127 mouse mammary epithelial cells stably transfected with the F508-mutated CFTR remained viable and were less susceptible to apoptosis induced by cycloheximide or etoposide than cells expressing the wild-type CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Programmed cell death, or apoptosis, is a physiologically relevant process that occurs in regenerating tissues such as the lung and intestine.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Cell turnover is a balance between proliferation and elimination, and cell proliferation has been shown to be greater in airway epithelia and nasal polyps in CF patients than in tissue from non-CF patients (12, 15).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Although this phenomenon has traditionally been attributed to inflammation, the possibility that the proliferative differences might be due to differential expression of the CFTR has not been addressed.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	19	Because all mouse models of CF (CFTR /) develop intestinal obstructions (10) and the CFTR is expressed in epithelial cells lining the gastrointestinal tract, we hypothesized that the CFTR / mouse intestine would show evidence of altered apoptosis and/or enhanced proliferation relative to mice expressing the wild-type CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The hypothesis was tested in vivo using a knockout mouse model of CF.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Mice expressing a mutant CFTR were found to have a greater rate of migration of epithelial cells up the crypt-villus axis within the small intestine.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	22	 This increased rate could be attributed to an increase in the proliferative capacity of cells within the crypts of Lieberkuhn but not to differences in apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Because these current results contradict the previous findings (9) of differences in apoptosis between cells transfected with the F508 CFTR and the wild-type CFTR, studies were extended to further examine apoptosis in two independent cell culture models of CF.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	24	A mouse model of CF generated by Dr.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Beverly Koller (University of North Carolina) was used for all studies (3).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	26	 In this model (cftrtm1Unc), the CFTR gene has been disrupted by gene targeting, and as with all mouse models of CF, the animals develop intestinal obstructions and typically die within weeks of birth.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	27	 However, by replacing the drinking water with Colyte (Schwarz Pharma, Milwaukee, WI), a commercially available electrolyte solution containing 6% polyethylene glycol, the mice remain alive past 18 mo of age (10).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Animals were maintained within the custom breeding colony at The Scripps Research Institute with all animals receiving Colyte in place of drinking water.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	29	 At the time of weaning, the genotypes of all mice were determined by isolation of tail DNA and PCR amplification of the CFTR alleles as described previously by Koller et al.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	30	 All animal studies adhered to approved institutional animal protocols and American Association for Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care guidelines.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	31	Bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU; Sigma Chemical, St.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Louis, MO) was suspended in PBS at 20 mg/ml and administered via intraperitoneal injection at 150  microg/g body wt.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The mice were killed by halothane overdose 2-48 h after BrdU injection.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	34	 The small intestine was isolated and excised, rinsed in PBS, splayed open along its length, and rinsed twice to remove contents.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	35	 The splayed intestine was fixed in Z-Fix (10% buffered formalin containing zinc; Anatech, Battle Creek, MI), coiled from proximal to distal end to form a "Swiss roll," dehydrated, and embedded in paraffin for tissue sectioning.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Tissue sections of Swiss rolls allow for examination of the entire length of the intestine in a single section.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	37	 BrdU incorporation on Swiss rolls was analyzed by immunohistochemistry.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Briefly, 3- microm-thick tissue sections were cleared of paraffin and rehydrated through graded alcohols.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Endogenous peroxidase activity was blocked by 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	40	3% hydrogen peroxide in methanol for 15 min at room temperature.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	41	1 N HCl, 15 min at 37 degrees C), tissue was treated with 2 N HCl for 30 min at 37 degrees C and rinsed in 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Tissue sections were incubated with anti-BrdU (Sigma Chemical) at 1:500 in 20% normal goat serum (90 min at 37 degrees C).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Incubation with biotinylated goat anti-mouse IgG (1:2,000 in PBS containing 1 mg/ml IgG-free BSA; Caltag, Burlingame, CA) for 60 min at room temperature was followed by enzymatic labeling with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated streptavidin (1:1,000 in PBS/BSA, 30 min at room temperature; Caltag).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	44	01% H2O2 were used for color development.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Tissues were counterstained with Gill's hematoxylin (Fisher Scientific, Pittsburgh, PA), dehydrated through graded alcohols, and placed on a coverslip with Permount (Fisher Scientific).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	46	Epithelial cell migration was evaluated in CFTR +/ and CFTR / mice by measuring the distance between the base of the intestinal crypts at the most distal Paneth cell along the epithelial cells to each BrdU-positive nuclei within the crypt-villus structure.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The investigator was blinded to animal identification and time after BrdU injection.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Through the use of a  x 20 objective on a Nikon TE300 microscope and a Spot Diagnostics Instruments digital camera (Sterling Heights, MI), 5 to 24 crypt-villus structures were captured for each animal and analyzed using MetaMorph imaging software (Universal Imaging, West Chester, PA).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Three individual time courses for BrdU migration were performed for a total of 20 animals (3 animals/genotype at 2 and 24 h, 4 mice/genotype at 48 h).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	50	 ANOVA was used to assess whether there was a genotypic difference in migration rate, and a two-tailed t-test was utilized to determine if there was a difference in distance of migration at 48 h after BrdU injection.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	51	Spontaneous and Induced Epithelial Cell Apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	52	In situ terminal deoxynucleotidyltransferase dUTP nick-end labeling (TUNEL) has been found to be unreliable as a method of detecting apoptosis in the gastrointestinal tract (21).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Therefore, a method previously described by Potten (21) in which apoptosis is quantified by calculating the percentage of cells with condensed and/or fragmented nuclei within the first 10 cells following the Paneth cells in the crypts of Lieberkuhn was used to quantify apoptosis in the small intestine of CFTR mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Crypts were scored by an investigator blinded to the identity of animals that met the following criteria: 1) Paneth cells could be viewed, 2) the crypt lumen could be seen, and 3) a minimum of 10 nonoverlapping epithelial cells in the crypt column could be distinguished.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Levels of spontaneous apoptosis were evaluated in control animals.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Whole body cesium gamma irradiation was used to induce apoptosis in the small intestine of CFTR mice in an attempt to uncover genotypic differences in susceptibility to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	57	 An initial dose-response curve using CFTR +/ mice revealed that significant epithelial cell apoptosis could be seen 3 h after whole body cesium gamma irradiation with 100 rads.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Higher doses of gamma irradiation did not result in detection of more apoptotic cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Therefore, subsequent experiments were performed with a dose of 100 rads, and the animals were killed 3 h after gamma irradiation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Following fixation and sectioning as described above, intestinal tissue was deparaffinized, stained with hematoxylin, and placed on a coverslip with Permount.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The average number of apoptotic nuclei was determined in a minimum of 50 crypts/animal in 18 CFTR / mice (8 control, 10 irradiated) and 14 each of +/ and +/+ mice (5 control, 9 irradiated) and expressed as a percentage of the first 10 crypt cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	62	 ANOVA was used to test whether irradiation increased intestinal cell apoptosis, and two-tailed t-tests were used to determine the statistical significance of irradiation within each genotype.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	63	Intestinal Epithelial Cell Proliferation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	64	Immunohistochemical detection of proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) was evaluated within the crypts of control (nonirradiated, no BrdU) CFTR mice by an investigator blinded to animal identity.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Tissues were acquired and processed as described above, and paraffin-embedded Swiss rolls were dewaxed and rehydrated through graded alcohols.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Tissues were incubated with Target retrieval solution (DAKO, Carpinteria, CA) at 95 degrees C for 20 min and at room temperature for an additional 20 min.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Endogenous peroxidase activity was blocked by 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	68	3% hydrogen peroxide in methanol before incubation with anti-PCNA (clone PC10, DAKO) for 90 min at 37 degrees C in 20% normal goat serum.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	69	 After rinsing with PBS, tissue was incubated with biotinylated goat anti-mouse IgG (Caltag) suspended 1:2,000 in PBS containing 1 mg/ml IgG-free BSA.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	70	 After 30 min incubation with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated streptavidin (Caltag), color was developed with SigmaFast diaminobenzidine (0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	71	2 mg/ml urea-H2O2), counterstained with hematoxylin, dehydrated through alcohols, and placed on a coverslip with Permount.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Proliferation was evaluated by determining the average number of PCNA-positive cells present within the first 10 cells following the Paneth cells in a minimum of 25 crypts/animal.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Twelve animals (17) were used to determine if there was a genotypic difference in epithelial cell proliferation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	74	 A two-tailed t-test was used to determine statistical significance.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	75	 C127 mouse mammary epithelial cells stably transfected with the wild-type CFTR or the CFTR with the deletion of phenylalanine at position 508 (C127 F508) were obtained from Dr.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Denning (Howard Hughes Medical Institute, University of Iowa College of Medicine) (4).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	77	 These cells were grown in DMEM (GIBCO BRL, Rockville, MD) supplemented with 10% FBS (HyClone, Logan, UT), penicillin, streptomycin, and Fungizone (Sigma Chemical) and passaged 1:5 two times per week.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The cell lines were grown in the presence of Geneticin (500  microg/ml; GIBCO BRL).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	79	 CFT1 cell lines, which were derived from tracheal epithelial cells isolated from a 24-year-old CF patient homozygous for the F508 mutation, were obtained from J.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Yankaskas (University of North Carolina).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	81	 The parental cell line (CFT1-C2) was used to establish the other three cell lines and has been immortalized with human papilloma virus.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	82	 CFT1-LCFSN cells overexpress the wild-type CFTR introduced by retroviral vector (20).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	83	 CFT1-F508 cells express an additional copy of the CFTR with the F508 mutation, and the CFT1-LC3 is a retroviral vector control cell line overexpressing the -galactosidase gene.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	84	 These cells were grown in Ham's F-12 (Fisher Scientific) supplemented with insulin (10  microg/ml), hydrocortisone (1  microM), endothelial cell growth supplement (ECGS; 3.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	85	75  microg/ml), epidermal growth factor (25 ng/ml), T3 (30 nM), transferrin (5  microg/ml), and cholera toxin (10 ng/ml) (all hormones were obtained from Sigma Chemical).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	86	 All cells, except the CFT1-C2 cells, were grown in the presence of Geneticin (500  microg/ml) and were passaged 1:3 two times per week.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	87	Membrane destabilization detected by YOPRO-1 uptake.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Cells were plated at 10,000 cells/well into 96-well tissue culture plates.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	89	 After 24 h, the medium was aspirated and replaced with 100  microl sterile PBS.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Cells were ultraviolet (UV) irradiated at 0-8,000 J/m2 using a Fisher Scientific UV crosslinker, the PBS was replaced with fresh medium, and the cells were incubated at 37 degrees C with 5% CO2.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	91	 After 16 h, 25  microM YOPRO-1 (10  microl) was added to each well and incubated at 37 degrees C for 10 min.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	92	 YOPRO-1 is taken up by cells with an unstable membrane and binds to double-strand DNA; therefore, apoptotic or necrotic cells will be labeled with YOPRO-1 (13).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	93	 With the use of a fluorescence plate reader (Bio-Tek Instruments, Winooski, VT), YOPRO-1 was found to be excited at 530 nm and emissions were detected at 480 nm.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Cells were lysed with 10  microl of lysis buffer (125 mM EDTA and 2.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	95	5% Nonidet P-40) and incubated at 37 degrees C with 5% CO2 for 30 min after which fluorescence was evaluated to determine the total number of cells per well.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The ratio of the first fluorescence (apoptotic and necrotic cells) to the second fluorescence (total cells) was taken to evaluate percent death and plotted against UV dose.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	97	Nuclear condensation and fragmentation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	98	 Cells were plated at 30,000 cells/chamber into four-well chamber slides.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	99	 One cell type was plated per chamber slide with cells plated in the first and fourth chambers only.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	100	 After allowing the cells to adhere and reach ~80% confluence, the medium was aspirated and replaced with 500  microl sterile PBS.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	101	 One chamber (containing control cells) was covered with an opaque material to prevent irradiation while the chamber slide was irradiated at 2,000 J/m2.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The position of the control and irradiated cells was randomized to ensure that the analysis was done under blinded conditions.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The PBS was aspirated and replaced with fresh medium.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Cells were incubated at 37 degrees C with 5% CO2 for 6 h after which 37% formaldehyde was added to each chamber (final concentration: 3.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	105	 During fixation, the slides were centrifuged at 1,200 rpm for 15 min to ensure minimal loss of cells during the fixation procedure.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The cells were fixed for an additional 15 min, rinsed with PBS, and allowed to air dry.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	107	 At the time of analysis, 30  microM Hoechst no.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	108	 33342 in PBS were added to each chamber, slides were coverslipped, and a minimum of 300 cells/chamber were analyzed for nuclear condensation and fragmentation by fluorescence microscopy.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The percentage of fragmented and condensed nuclei from three separate experiments was obtained with the experimenter blinded to cell type and irradiation dose.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	110	To confirm that the mutated CFTR was responsible for the resistance to apoptosis, C127 F508 cells were infected with a CFTR adenovirus in an attempt to restore susceptibility to death in these cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	111	 C127 F508 cells were plated at 5,000 cells/well in a 96-well tissue culture plate and allowed to adhere overnight.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Preliminary studies with the -galactosidase adenovirus (Ad2/CMVgal-4, gift from Genzyme, Framingham, MA) showed that these cells were fairly resistant to infection by this adenovirus and required 20,000 infective units/cell for 95% infectivity.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Cells were infected with the 20,000 infective units of CFTR adenovirus (Ad2/CFTR-16, gift from Genzyme) suspended in DMEM containing 2% heat-inactivated FBS for 60 min at room temperature, followed by 48 h at 37 degrees C with 5% CO2.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	114	 After this infection, cells were UV irradiated and evaluated with YOPRO-1 as described above to determine susceptibility to death.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	115	 -Galactosidase adenovirus-infected and uninfected cells were used as negative controls.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	116	Mouse models of CF are consistent in their susceptibility to gastrointestinal obstruction; therefore, studies were designed to determine whether a nonfunctional CFTR alters the kinetics of epithelial cell migration within the gastrointestinal tract and ultimately might underlie the pathophysiology within the intestine.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	117	The rate of migration of BrdU-labeled cells up the crypt-villus axis is faster in CFTR / mice than in their CFTR +/ littermates (P = 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	118	 By 48 h, the distance that the epithelial cells from the CFTR / mice have migrated is significantly greater than the distance of migration in the CFTR +/ mouse intestine (P = 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Because epithelial cell migration from the crypts of Lieberkuhn up the intestinal villi is the net result of proliferation and apoptosis within the crypts, both components were evaluated separately to see if either or both are altered as a result of the expression of the mutant CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	120	 An increase in epithelial cell migration might occur if apoptosis is reduced and/or proliferation within the crypts of Lieberkuhn is increased.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	121	View larger version (12K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	122	   Intestinal epithelial cell migration in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) / and CFTR +/ mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	123	 CFTR mice given an intraperitoneal injection of bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU) were killed 2-48 h after BrdU injection.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Cells that incorporated BrdU were localized immunohistochemically, and the distance from the base of the crypt of Lieberkuhn to each BrdU-positive cell was determined in 20 animals (3 animals/genotype were evaluated at 2 and 24 h and 4 animals/genotype were examined at 48 h).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	125	 BrdU-labeled epithelial cells from CFTR / mice migrate up the intestinal villi at a faster rate than do cells from CFTR +/ mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Each point represents the mean  plus or minus  SE of the most distal BrdU-positive cell for the animals in the group.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	127	 At 48 h after BrdU migration, the distance in migration is significantly different between the 2 genotypes (P = 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	128	Levels of spontaneous apoptosis are not different between CFTR genotypes, with CFTR / mice exhibiting 5.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	129	6% apoptosis within the crypts and CFTR +/ and CFTR +/+ mice presenting 6  plus or minus  2.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	130	1% apoptosis, respectively (Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	131	 To determine whether the low levels of spontaneous apoptosis seen within the crypts masks a difference in susceptibility to apoptosis, intestinal apoptosis was induced with whole body cesium gamma irradiation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Irradiation significantly increased apoptosis in all genotypes (P  <  0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	133	001) but did not uncover any differences in susceptibility to apoptosis between genotypes (Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Epithelial cells at the villus tips do not show nuclear fragmentation and condensation and, additionally, detection of apoptosis in the gastrointestinal tract by TUNEL is highly variable (19).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Therefore, apoptosis at the villus tips could not be examined in this study.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	136	View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	137	   Irradiation induced crypt cell apoptosis in CFTR mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	138	 CFTR mice were subjected to whole body cesium gamma irradiation and killed 3 h after irradiation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Apoptosis was evaluated in the first 10 cells following the Paneth cells in 50 crypts of Lieberkuhn per animal.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	140	 of animals per group is noted above each bar.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Values are means  plus or minus  SD.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Gamma irradiation (100 rad) induced 10-fold increases in apoptosis within the epithelial cells in the crypts of Lieberkuhn in CFTR /, CFTR +/, and CFTR +/+ mice (P  <  0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	143	 There were no genotypic differences in susceptibility to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	144	To determine whether the difference in epithelial cell migration is the result of differences in crypt cell proliferation, epithelial cells within the crypts of Lieberkuhn were evaluated for expression of PCNA.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	145	 A significantly greater percentage of epithelial cells from CFTR / mice (49.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	146	6%) express PCNA than those from animals expressing at least one copy of the functional gene (CFTR +/, 36.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	147	View larger version (11K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	148	   Intestinal epithelial cell proliferation in CFTR mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) was detected by immunohistochemistry in the first 10 cells following the Paneth cells in 25 crypts of Lieberkuhn in 7 CFTR / mice and 5 CFTR +/ mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	150	 The %PCNA-positive cells per crypt revealed significantly more proliferative capacity in the crypts of Lieberkuhn of CFTR / mice (49.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	151	 *Significant difference (P = 0.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	152	The results of the animal studies contradict the previous cell culture findings presented by Gottlieb and Dosanjh (9), in which cells expressing the mutated CFTR were more resistant to apoptosis than cells expressing the wild-type CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Therefore experiments were designed to determine whether the cell culture results were misleading.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	154	Mouse mammary epithelial cells expressing a mutated CFTR (C127 F508) are more resistant to death induced by 1,000 or 2,000 J/m2 UV irradiation than cells expressing the wild-type CFTR (Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	155	 With UV irradiation doses at or above 4,000 J/m2, a similar percentage of cell death was seen in both cell types.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	156	 This is consistent with the previous findings (9) that C127 F508 cells are more resistant than C127 wild-type cells to induction of apoptosis by etoposide and cycloheximide.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	157	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	158	   Dose-response curve for ultraviolet (UV)-induced cell death in C127 cells expressing the wild-type CFTR (C127 wt) and C127 F508 cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	159	 C127 cells UV irradiated at doses of 0-8,000 J/m2 were evaluated for cell death 16 h after irradiation by uptake of the DNA binding fluorochrome YOPRO-1.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Only cells with an unstable plasma membrane will take up YOPRO-1; therefore, the ratio of fluorescence emissions before and after cell lysis allows for the determination of %cell death.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	161	 C127 wt are more susceptible to UV irradiation-induced death than are cells expressing the F508-mutated CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	162	001) produces significant genotypic differences in death.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Irradiation with doses at or above 4,000 J/m2 results in similar %cell death in the two cell lines.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Values are means  plus or minus  SD of 2-6 experiments/dose with a minimum of triplicates for each dose in each experiment.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	165	To determine whether the difference in susceptibility to UV irradiation seen in the C127 cell lines is a result of differences in expression of a functional CFTR, C127 F508 cells were infected by an adenovirus expressing the wild-type CFTR before induction of apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Although cells overexpressing the mutant CFTR may have a low level of CFTR activity (2), expression of the wild-type CFTR in the C127 F508 cells did not increase the susceptibility of these cells to death relative to cells infected with the -galactosidase adenovirus or uninfected cells (Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	167	 These data suggest that expression of the functional CFTR does not make C127 cells more susceptible to apoptosis than cells expressing a mutated CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Instead, the data suggest that the observed difference in apoptosis is unrelated to the CFTR but instead may have been a property acquired during the clonal selection process.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	169	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	170	   Dose effect of UV irradiation on cell death in adenovirus-infected C127 F508 cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	171	 C127 F508 cells were infected with an adenovirus construct containing the wild-type CFTR (wt CFTR) or the -galactosidase gene (b-gal) or were uninfected.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	172	 After 48 h of infection, apoptosis was induced by 2,000 J/m2 UV irradiation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Sixteen hours after irradiation, cells were evaluated for cell death by uptake of YOPRO-1.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Expression of the wild-type CFTR did not alter susceptibility to death by UV irradiation relative to the uninfected control cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	175	 -galactosidase expression made the cells more sensitive to UV irradiation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The data reflect 2 experiments performed in quadruplicate with the range of data reflected by the error bars.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	177	To further assess whether the original data were misleading, a second set of cell lines was tested to determine susceptibility to apoptosis based on expression of a functional or mutated CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	178	 In the CFT1 cell lines, at 16 h after UV irradiation, cell death increased in a dose-dependent manner to a similar extent across cell lines (Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Similar data were obtained 6 h after UV irradiation using nuclear condensation and fragmentation as markers of apoptosis (Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	180	 In addition, UV irradiation of CFT1 cell lines resulted in a similar time course of DNA degradation (data not shown) with DNA laddering present at 3 h after UV irradiation in all four cell lines.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Furthermore, cleavage of caspase 3 (PharMingen, La Jolla, CA) and caspase 9 (New England Biolabs, Beverly, MA) after UV irradiation was not different across cell lines (data not shown).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Thus the current data from the C127 and CFT1 cell lines suggest that the CFTR does not play a role in apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	183	View larger version (36K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	184	   Dose-response curve for UV-induced cell death in CFT1 cell lines.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	185	 CFT1 cells were UV irradiated at doses of 0-8,000 J/m2 and evaluated for cell death as described in the Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	186	 No differences were seen across cell lines.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Cells expressing the wild-type CFTR (LCFSN) were equally susceptible to death by UV irradiation as were cells from the parental cell line (C2), cells expressing additional copies of the F508 mutation (dF508), or cells expressing the -galactosidase vector control (LC3).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The data reflect 2 experiments performed in quadruplicate with error bars reflecting the range of the data.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	189	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	190	   Effect of UV irradiation on nuclear condensation and fragmentation in CFT1 cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	191	 CFT1 cells were UV irradiated at 0 and 2,000 J/m2, fixed after 6 h, and evaluated for nuclear condensation and fragmentation by fluorescence microscopy after staining the nuclei with 30  microM Hoechst no.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	192	 A: examples of typical nuclear condensation and fragmentation for each cell line.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	193	 B: means  plus or minus  SD of %apoptosis seen in 3 separate experiments in which a minimum of 300 cells was counted per cell type per experiment.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	194	 The amount of apoptosis seen for each cell line was similar and independent of the expression of the wild-type or mutated CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	195	Many CF patients and all mouse models of CF have a common pathology in their susceptibility to gastrointestinal obstruction.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	196	 In the normal intestine, epithelial cells line the villi of the absorptive surfaces.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	197	 These cells are continuously regenerated by proliferation in the crypts of Lieberkuhn, differentiation, and migration up the villi.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	198	 At the tips of the villi, the cells undergo apoptosis and are shed into the lumen (11, 24).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	199	 (18) have shown that both proliferation and apoptosis occur in the stem cells within the crypts and that apoptosis within the crypts is likely to be an important part of the homeostatic process for tissue maintenance.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Under normal conditions, stem cell proliferation and epithelial sloughing are in equilibrium.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	201	 As we have shown in the current study, epithelial cells in CFTR / mice migrate up the crypt-villus axis at a greater rate than in animals expressing a functional CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The epithelial cells from CFTR / mice migrated 27% farther in 48 h than those from the CFTR +/ mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	203	 This difference in rate is due to differences in proliferation and not apoptosis within the crypts of Lieberkuhn with ~12% more cells with proliferative capacity in the CFTR / mice than the CFTR +/ mice.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	204	 Because villus length is not different between the genotypes (data not shown), the increased number of cells proliferating within the crypt and migrating up the villi would lead to an increase in the mass of cells that are sloughed into the gastrointestinal tract.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	205	The increased proliferative capacity within the CFTR-null mice may be attributed to a cellular defect within the cells as a result of a nonfunctional CFTR, although the mechanism by which this might happen is unknown.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Potentially, differences in intracellular pH might account for the enhanced proliferation in CFTR / cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	207	 Cytosolic pH is thought to be one of the factors that control the rate of proliferation (8) with cytoplasmic alkalinization constituting a signal for mitogenesis (1, 22, 27).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	208	 In addition, cells with higher intracellular pH are more likely to be in the S, G2, or M phases of the cell cycle, whereas cells with lower pH are more likely to be in G1 (19).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Cells expressing a mutated CFTR have been reported (5, 6) to have an elevated cytosolic pH, and overexpression of the wild-type CFTR but not a mutant CFTR results in growth arrest (23).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Thus a mutation in the CFTR may result in an elevated intracellular pH, which stimulates the cell to undergo proliferation more readily and thus increase the rate at which epithelial cells of the crypts of Lieberkuhn proliferate and migrate up the intestinal villi.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	211	All the mouse models of CF show evidence of inflammation and intestinal obstructions (10); thus the possibility that the stimulus to enhanced proliferation within the intestine of the CFTR / mice might be due to differences in inflammation cannot be ruled out.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Proliferation in nasal polyps (12, 16) and epithelium of bronchial airways (15) has been shown to be increased in CF patients and has been attributed to airway inflammation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	213	 Chronic inflammation has been shown to be present in the CF intestine with increased luminal content of immune cell constituents, secretory immunoglobulins, and cytokines (25).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Therefore, inflammation within the gastrointestinal tract potentially can be a stimulus to enhanced proliferation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	215	Initial studies by Gottlieb and Dosanjh (9) showed decreased susceptibility to apoptosis in cells expressing the mutated CFTR relative to cells expressing the wild-type CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	216	 In this initial study, cycloheximide and etoposide were used to induce apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	217	 The CFTR is an anion channel that when mutated does not allow for chloride to be transported across the plasma membrane.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Because this is a transport problem, one concern with the use of any drug or chemical to induce apoptosis is a difference in the ability of the cells to transport the drug or chemical across the cell membrane.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	219	 To avoid this potential problem in the current studies, UV irradiation was utilized as the apoptotic stimulus.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Cells expressing the mutated CFTR were more resistant to apoptosis induced by UV irradiation than cells expressing the wild-type CFTR, which is in accordance with the findings of Gottlieb and Dosanjh (9).
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	221	 However, one control that was lacking from the original set of experiments was the introduction of the wild-type CFTR into these resistant cell lines to restore susceptibility to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	222	 In the current study, infection of C127 F08 cells with an adenovirus expressing the wild-type CFTR failed to restore susceptibility to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	223	 -galactosidase adenovirus-infected cells were found to be more susceptible to death than both the uninfected and infected CFTR cells.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	224	 The reason behind this increased propensity toward death is not known.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	225	 The -galactosidase construct used in these experiments was the nuclear-targeted protein, which, because of its location of expression, may make the cells more susceptible to the DNA-damaging effect of UV irradiation.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	226	 To confirm the findings from the C127 cells, an independent set of cell lines was used to determine whether expression of a mutated or wild-type CFTR results in differences in susceptibility to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Cells with a mutated CFTR were found to be no different in their sensitivity to UV irradiation than cells expressing the wild-type CFTR when evaluated for membrane destabilization detected by the uptake of YOPRO-1, nuclear condensation and fragmentation, DNA degradation, or caspase cleavage.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Thus taken together the data suggest that the CFTR does not play a role in a cell's susceptibility to apoptosis.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	229	In the CFTR-null mice, epithelial cell kinetics within the gastrointestinal tract differ from mice expressing at least one copy of the functional CFTR.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	230	 The altered proliferation within the crypts of Lieberkuhn is not accompanied by changes in apoptosis but results in an increased rate of cell migration up the villus.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	231	 The increased number of cells reaching the intestinal lumen might contribute to the viscosity of the luminal contents and increase the likelihood of intestinal blockage, one of the pathophysiological hallmarks of CF.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	232	 If epithelial cell proliferation and turnover is increased in parallel in the CF lung and pancreas, this might contribute to the viscosity of the bronchial and pancreatic secretions and exacerbate the symptoms of CF.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	233	This research was supported by a postdoctoral fellowship from the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (A.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Gallagher), a grant from the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (R.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Gottlieb), and an award from the Pew Foundation Scholars Program in Biomedical Sciences (R.

0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	240	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.

0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Science 257: 1125-1128, 1992[ISI][Medline].
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	251	   Denning, GM, Anderson MP, Amara JF, Marshall J, Smith AE, and Welsh MJ.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Processing of mutant cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator is temperature sensitive.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	253	 Nature 358: 761-764, 1992[ISI][Medline].
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	254	 High intracellular pH is lowered by retrovirus-mediated CFTR gene transfer.

0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Altered sulfate transport via anion exchange in CFPAC is corrected by retrovirus-mediated CFTR gene transfer.

0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Inositol phosphates turnover, cytosolic Ca2+ and pH: putative signals for the control of cell growth.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	314	 Life Sci 38: 2269-2276, 1986[ISI][Medline].
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	315	Am J Physiol Gastrointest Liver Physiol 281(3):G681-G687 0193-1857/01 $5.
0.4581272.11518680.html.plaintext.txt	316	00 Copyright   2001 the American Physiological Society.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	0	RAPID COMMUNICATION Glutathione permeability of CFTR Paul Linsdell and John W.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Physiology, McGill University, Montreal, Quebec, Canada H3G 1Y6.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	2	The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) forms an ion channel that is permeable both to Cl and to larger organic anions.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	3	 Here we show, using macroscopic current recording from excised membrane patches, that the anionic antioxidant tripeptide glutathione is permeant in the CFTR channel.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	4	 This permeability may account for the high concentrations of glutathione that have been measured in the surface fluid that coats airway epithelial cells.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Furthermore, loss of this pathway for glutathione transport may contribute to the reduced levels of glutathione observed in airway surface fluid of cystic fibrosis patients, which has been suggested to contribute to the oxidative stress observed in the lung in cystic fibrosis.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	6	 We suggest that release of glutathione into airway surface fluid may be a novel function of CFTR.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	7	cystic fibrosis; chloride channel; lung defense; airway surface fluid; multidrug resistance protein ; cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	8	CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF) is caused by mutations in a single gene: the one that encodes the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	9	 CFTR, which is a member of the "ATP-binding cassette" (ABC) family of membrane transport proteins, forms a phosphorylation- and ATP-dependent Cl channel (3, 4).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	10	 It remains unclear how the reduced epithelial Cl permeability caused by the functional absence of CFTR leads to the complexity of symptoms seen in CF lung disease.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	11	 This, coupled with the structural similarity between CFTR and other ABC proteins, has long hinted that CFTR may also perform some other function.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	12	The anionic tripeptide glutathione (-glutamyl-cysteinyl-glycine; GSH) is the most important extracellular antioxidant in the lung (1, 20).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Airway surface fluid (ASF) contains ~400  microM GSH, ~50 times the concentration found in plasma and 100 times that found in the extracellular fluid of many other tissues (1, 5, 17, 20).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The source of the high concentration of GSH found in ASF is unknown (20).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Interestingly, the concentration of GSH in ASF is greatly reduced in CF (16), which may exacerbate the severe oxidative stress that results from chronic inflammation of the CF lung (19).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	16	    Indeed, antioxidant therapy for CF has previously been suggested (2, 16, 19).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	17	Recently we demonstrated that a broad range of large organic anions were able to permeate through the CFTR Cl channel from the cytoplasmic side of the membrane, and we suggested that release of such anions into ASF might be a novel physiological function of CFTR (11).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Here we show that both GSH and oxidized glutathione (GSSG) can permeate through CFTR from the intracellular solution.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	19	 These results suggest that CFTR, in addition to its role as a Cl channel, may function as a permeation pathway by which GSH is released into ASF.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Such a function would suggest a previously unidentified link between CFTR and lung antioxidant defense.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Loss of this GSH permeation pathway may contribute to the pathogenesis of CF.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	22	Macroscopic CFTR current recordings were carried out on inside-out membrane patches excised from baby hamster kidney cells stably expressing CFTR, as described in detail elsewhere (9, 11).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Briefly, channels were activated by exposure of the cytoplasmic face of excised patches to 40-60 nM protein kinase A catalytic subunit (PKA) plus 1 mM MgATP.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	24	 All current traces shown have had the background leak current, recorded before addition of PKA, digitally subtracted, as described previously (9, 11).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Current traces were filtered at 100 Hz using an eight-pole Bessel filter, digitized at 250 Hz and analyzed using pCLAMP6 computer software (Axon Instruments, Foster City, CA).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	26	Recording solutions contained (in mM) 150 NaCl, 2 MgCl2, 10 TES, or 154 NaGSH or Na2GSSG plus 2 Mg(OH)2 and 10 TES.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	27	 All solutions were adjusted to pH 7.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Where the pipette solution did not contain Cl, the pipette Ag-AgCl wire was protected by an NaCl-containing agar bridge inside the pipette.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Voltages were corrected for measured liquid junction potentials of up to 12 mV existing between dissimilar pipette and bath solutions.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	30	 All chemicals were obtained from Sigma (St.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Louis, MO) except 4,4'-dinitrostilbene-2,2'-disulfonic acid (DNDS; Pfaltz  and  Bauer, Waterbury, CT) and glibenclamide (glyburide; Calbiochem, La Jolla, CA).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	32	Macroscopic current-voltage (I-V) relationships were constructed using depolarizing voltage ramp protocols as described previously (9, 11).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	33	 The current reversal potential, Erev, was estimated by fitting a polynomial function to the I-V relationship and was used to estimate permeability (P) ratios according to the equations (1) (2) where F is the Faraday constant, R is the gas constant, and T is temperature.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	34	Block of CFTR Cl current by GSH and GSSG was analyzed using the Woodhull model of voltage-dependent block (21) (3) where i is the amplitude of the current remaining in the presence of blocker, i0 is the control, unblocked current amplitude, [B] is the blocker concentration, V is the membrane potential, and Kd(V) is the voltage-dependent dissociation constant, the voltage dependence of which is given by (4) where z' is the apparent valence of the blocking ion.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	35	Experiments were carried out at room temperature (21-23 degrees C).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Values are presented as means  plus or minus  SE.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	37	A broad range of large organic anions are able to carry current through CFTR when present in the intracellular solution (11).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	38	 PKA-stimulated I-V relationships obtained with GSH (Fig.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	39	 1B) in the intracellular solution and Cl in the extracellular solution (bi-ionic conditions) indicated that both of these large anions were permeant in CFTR, with mean permeabilities (according to Eqs.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	40	 1D) were measurably permeant when present in the extracellular solution under bi-ionic conditions.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	41	 This asymmetric permeability is similar to that which we previously observed with a number of other large organic anions (11).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	42	 This asymmetry is abolished by substances that "lock" CFTR channels in the open state, such as pyrophosphate (PPi) (11).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	43	 1, C and D, addition of 10 mM PPi to the intracellular solution stimulated the influx of GSH and GSSG from the extracellular solution.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	44	 All of these properties of GSH and GSSG permeation are similar to those we described previously for a number of different large organic anions (11).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	45	 As discussed in more detail elsewhere (11), the reasons for the disruption of asymmetric permeability caused by PPi are not currently known but may involve inhibition of ATP hydrolysis-dependent transitions between different channel open states.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The mean relative permeability of GSH and GSSG under different conditions, calculated according to Eqs.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	47	 1 and 2 (see METHODS), are summarized in Fig.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Note that the permeability of the divalent anion GSSG is very low compared with GSH and other large monovalent anions (Fig.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	49	View larger version (23K):    Fig.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	50	   Asymmetric glutathione (GSH) and oxidized glutathione (GSSG) permeation in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	51	 A-D: example current-voltage (I-V) relationships recorded with either GSH or GSSG present in intracellular or extracellular solution under bi-ionic conditions, as stated on each individual panel.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	52	 CFTR currents were consistently much smaller with intracellular GSSG than under any of the other ionic conditions studied; reasons for this are unknown.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	53	 I-V relationships such as those shown in A-D were used to calculate mean permeabilities for GSH (E) and GSSG (F), when present in intracellular solution (In) or extracellular solution (Out) under bi-ionic conditions.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Numbers in parentheses are number of patches examined.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Permeability ratios shown for GSH and GSSG in extracellular solution in absence of pyrophosphate (PPi) are maximum values, since no reversal potential was observed under these conditions over voltage range studied.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Actual permeabilities under these conditions are likely to be considerably lower; they may be zero (see Ref.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	57	The suggestion that intracellular large organic anions were permeant in CFTR and not simply transported by some CFTR-regulated transport process was supported by the finding that currents carried by such large anions were inhibited by the CFTR open-channel blockers DNDS and glibenclamide (11).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Both DNDS and glibenclamide also blocked the current carried by intracellular GSH under bi-ionic conditions (Fig.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	59	 This suggests that GSH and Cl share a common permeation pathway through CFTR, as previously suggested for other large anions (11).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	60	View larger version (14K):    Fig.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	61	   Blocker sensitivity of GSH efflux.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Typical examples of I-V relationships recorded under bi-ionic conditions (intracellular GSH, extracellular Cl) before (control) and immediately after addition of 200  microM 4,4'-dinitrostilbene-2,2'-disulfonate (DNDS; n = 4 patches) or 60  microM glibenclamide (Glib; n = 3 patches) to intracellular solution.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	63	If GSH and GSSG are able to permeate through the CFTR Cl channel pore, then they might also be expected to act as open channel blockers of CFTR Cl current.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Indeed, the large organic anions gluconate and glutamate, both of which are permeant in CFTR when present in the intracellular solution (11), are also low-affinity blockers of Cl permeation through the channel (10).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	65	 3, addition of GSH (5 mM) or GSSG (10 mM) to the intracellular solution reduced the macroscopic CFTR Cl current recorded with 150 mM NaCl present on both sides of the membrane.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Block by intracellular GSH and GSSG was immediate and readily reversible, consistent with an open channel block mechanism.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Analysis of the blocking effects of GSH and GSSG using the Woodhull model (21; see METHODS) suggested Kd(0) = 15.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	68	02 (n = 5) for GSH and Kd(0) = 23.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Thus, although the affinity of channel block by these two anions is relatively low, it is at least 20 times higher than that estimated for intracellular gluconate or glutamate ions at a membrane potential of 0 mV (~600 and 1,100 mM, respectively; Ref.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The ability of intracellular GSH and GSSG to act as blockers of CFTR Cl current is consistent with their being able to enter the pore from the intracellular end.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	71	View larger version (12K):    Fig.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	72	   Block of CFTR Cl currents by GSH and GSSG.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Example I-V relationships recorded with symmetrical Cl-containing solutions, before (control) and immediately after addition of 5 mM GSH or 10 mM GSSG to the intracellular solution.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	74	Despite early skepticism due to its structure, CFTR has been conclusively proven to be a Cl channel.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Reduced transepithelial Cl transport is thought to be the primary defect in CF (15); however, the link between this reduced Cl permeability and the pathogenesis of CF lung disease remains unclear.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Previously, we suggested that CFTR may fulfill another direct transport role, allowing efflux of a broad range of large organic anions from the cytoplasm (11).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Based on our present results, we propose that a potential physiological substrate for this transport pathway is the important antioxidant molecule GSH.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The ability of GSH to permeate through CFTR suggests a direct link between CFTR and antioxidant defense in the lung.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	79	GSH is synthesized in the cytoplasm, where levels of 1-10 mM are typical (17).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	80	 High concentrations of GSH (~400  microM) are also found in ASF of healthy individuals (1).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	81	 We propose that GSH may be released into ASF via CFTR, further emphasizing the role of CFTR in determining ASF composition (18).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Because cytoplasmic concentrations of GSH are so high, a passive permeation pathway would presumably be sufficient to mediate release of such amounts of GSH into ASF.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Loss of this GSH transport pathway may contribute to CF lung disease.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	84	 The levels of GSH are greatly reduced in ASF of CF patients (16), potentially exacerbating the oxidant stress that results from neutrophil-dominated inflammation of the CF lung (16, 19).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	85	 GSH levels in ASF are also reduced in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and adult respiratory distress syndrome and are increased in cigarette smokers with no clinical evidence of lung disease (16).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	86	GSH and GSSG transport by CFTR suggests a functional similarity between CFTR and the structurally related ABC proteins, multidrug resistance protein (MRP) and canalicular multispecific organic anion transporter (cMOAT; also known as MRP2).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Both MRP and cMOAT mediate ATP-dependent export of large intracellular organic anions, in particular glutathione-S-conjugates (6, 14).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	88	 GSSG is a substrate for both MRP- and cMOAT-mediated transport (8, 14).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Unconjugated GSH may be transported by cMOAT (14) but is thought not to be transported by MRP (8); however it may act as a cosubstrate for MRP-mediated transport of unconjugated compounds (12, 13).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Potential functional overlap between CFTR and other ABC proteins is of particular interest, since it has been suggested that MRP may be able to functionally substitute for CFTR in the lung and alleviate CF symptoms (7).
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Our results suggest that such functional substitution may be due to restoration of GSH or GSH-conjugate transport.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	92	We thank Jie Liao for maintaining the cell cultures and Drs.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Elizabeth Cowley and David Eidelman for their comments on the manuscript.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	94	This work was supported by the Canadian Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (CCFF), Canadian Medical Research Council (MRC), and National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Linsdell is a CCFF postdoctoral fellow.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	96	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	97	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	98	  1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	99	Address for reprint requests: P.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	100	, Montreal, Quebec, Canada H3G 1Y6.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	101	Received 6 March 1998; accepted in final form 14 April 1998.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Normal alveolar epithelial lining fluid contains high levels of glutathione.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	103	 63: 152-157, 1987[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Oxidants and respiratory tract epithelial injury: pathogenesis and strategies for therapeutic intervention.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	105	 The CFTR chloride channel of mammalian heart.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Function and dysfunction of the CFTR chloride channel.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	107	 In: Ion Channels and Genetic Diseases, edited by D.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Glutathione concentrations in rat lung bronchoalveolar lavage fluid: effects of hyperoxia.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Transport of glutathione conjugates and glucuronides by the multidrug resistance proteins MRP1 and MRP2.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Induction by antitumoral drugs of proteins that functionally complement CFTR: a novel therapy for cystic fibrosis? Lancet 350: 711-712, 1997[Medline].
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	111	 ATP-dependent glutathi-one disulfide transport mediated by the MRP gene-encoded conjugate export pump.
0.46872106.9688865.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Disulphonic stilbene block of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator Cl channels expressed in a mammalian cell line and its regulation by a critical pore residue.
