0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	0	Cysteine String Protein Interacts with and Modulates the Maturation of the Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator* Hui Zhang, Kathryn W.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Peters, Fei Sun, Christopher R.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	2	 Marino, Jochen Lang , Robert D.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	3	From the Department of Cell Biology and Physiology, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261, the  Department of Medicine, University of Tennessee, Memphis, Tennessee 38163, the   Institut Europeen de Chimie et Biologie, Pessac F-33607, France, and the   Physiological Laboratory, University of Liverpool, Liverpool L69 3BX, United Kingdom.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	4	Received for publication, December 7, 2001, and in revised form, May 1, 2002.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	5	The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR)1 is responsible for the cAMP-activated chloride conductance of epithelial cell apical membranes (1).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Mutations in the CFTR gene cause cystic fibrosis, whereas hyperactivity of this transport pathway produces secretory diarrhea.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The folding of CFTR is energetically complex; misfolding and degradation of the protein are features of the most common CFTR mutation (F508) (2, 3).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In addition, F508 CFTR is unable to undergo ATP-dependent conformational changes in the ER that are required for its proper folding.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	9	 When CFTR folding is retarded in the ER, the protein becomes a target for proteolysis by ER-associated degradation mechanisms that police the protein secretory pathway for misfolded or incompletely complexed proteins (4).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	10	 This degradation involves ubiquitination of the aberrant protein and its delivery to the proteasome (5, 6).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Nearly all of the F508 CFTR produced by the cell is destroyed in this manner; and because of its complex folding pattern, much of the wild-type protein is also degraded.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	12	 The mechanisms that govern CFTR folding/degradation processes are facilitated by chaperone and co-chaperone protein interactions (discussed further below).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	13	The primary step in CFTR activation involves cAMP/protein kinase A-mediated phosphorylation of its central regulatory (R) domain, which not only permits the channel to gate, but also alters pathways for CFTR trafficking at the plasma membrane (7).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	14	 In recent years, protein interactions at several CFTR domains have been implicated in channel function and trafficking.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The N-terminal cytosolic tail of CFTR is a site of syntaxin 1A binding (8), and syntaxin 1A overexpression is thought to inhibit CFTR currents by reducing channel gating (9) and by interfering with regulated CFTR trafficking to the plasma membrane (10).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	16	 A motif promoting CFTR endocytosis has been identified at the C terminus, and this region interacts physically with the plasma membrane endocytic adapter (AP-2) complex (11, 12).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	17	 The C terminus of CFTR corresponds to a PDZ (PSD-95/Disc-large/ZO-1) binding motif, which interacts with ezrin radixin moesin-binding phosphoprotein 50 or E3KARP to bring ezrin into proximity with CFTR (13, 14).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Ezrin can anchor protein kinase A at a position physiologically appropriate for CFTR phosphorylation (15, 16), and ezrin interactions with the cytoskeleton permit retention of CFTR at the apical membrane as a mechanism to establish its polarity in epithelial cells (17).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Here, we report the interaction of CFTR with another multidomain protein, the cysteine string protein (Csp).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	20	The Csps were first discovered in Drosophila and Torpedo (18, 19), and their expression has now been documented in a variety of tissues from several mammalian species (20, 21).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Csp null mutants in Drosophila produce a temperature-sensitive block of synaptic transmission followed by paralysis and premature death.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	22	 These findings demonstrate a crucial role for Csp in neurosecretion (22).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In neurons, Csp is associated predominantly with synaptic vesicles (19), and in secretory cells it is found in large dense core or secretory granules (23, 24).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Studies of membrane dye labeling (25) and neurotransmitter release (26, 27) indicated that Csp knockouts exhibit defective neurotransmitter exocytosis; presynaptic endocytosis and vesicle recycling appear to be intact.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Studies in neuroendocrine (28) and endocrine cells (24) have confirmed that altered Csp expression elicits an impaired secretory phenotype.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	26	Csps contain an N-terminal "J-domain," a central cysteine-rich "string" region, and a phylogenetically more variable C-terminal domain.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The J-domains of Csps are structurally conserved among different species, and this region provides a fingerprint of Csp as a member of the DnaJ/Hsp40 (heat shock protein) chaperone family.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	28	 As observed for other chaperone proteins (29), the HPD motif of the Csp J-domain mediates its binding to and activation of the Hsc70 chaperone ATPases, which influence protein conformation/binding.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Structural predictions indicate that the C terminus of Csp1 may form a coiled-coil region, and this structure may be important in view of the emerging evidence that Csp can interact with proteins involved in exocytosis, such as vesicle-associated membrane protein and syntaxins 1A and 4 (21, 30, 31).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Thus, prior results suggest that Csp could link functions of the SNARE complex with those of Hsc70.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The concept that assembly of the core fusion complex requires chaperone activity has been raised previously (21); however, the explicit roles of Csp and Hsc70 in the assembly or disassembly of SNARE components are not yet known.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	32	 The C terminus of Csp contains the only primary structural difference that exists between the mammalian isoforms: full-length Csp1, and its C-terminal truncated variant, Csp2 (32, 33).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	33	Materials and Reagents-- Protein A/G-agarose beads and Taq polymerase were purchased from Invitrogen.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Glutathione-Sepharose 4B was purchased from Amersham Biosciences.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	35	 DNA restriction endonucleases were from New England BioLabs.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	36	 DNA purification kits were obtained from Qiagen.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Csp1 and Csp2 cDNAs were subcloned into pcDNA3 with an N-terminal Myc tag (34).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Mouse hippocampus neuronal cell (SY5S) lysate, employed as a Csp protein positive control, was kindly provided by Dr.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Chaohua Yan (Children's Hospital, Pittsburgh).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Protein kinase A and other reagent grade chemicals were purchased from Sigma.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	41	Antibodies-- Anti-Csp serum was raised in rabbits against recombinant bovine Csp1 (32).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Monoclonal anti-GST and anti-Golgi 58K antibodies were purchased from Sigma.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Anti-CFTR polyclonal antibodies (R3195) were generated and affinity purified as described (35).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Anti-CFTR (mAb3484 and mAb3482) and anti-Csp monoclonal antibodies were obtained from Chemicon.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Horseradish peroxidase-conjugated anti-rabbit IgG and anti-mouse IgG were obtained from Sigma.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Monoclonal anti-calnexin antibodies were obtained from Affinity Bioreagents.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	47	Cell Culture-- Calu-3 and T84 cells were cultured as described by Sun et al.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	48	 CFPAC-1 cells were grown in Iscove's essential medium (Biofluids) containing 5% fetal bovine serum, 4 mM L-glutamine, and penicillin-streptomycin (Invitrogen).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Madin-Darby canine kidney and HEK293 cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Sigma) with 10% fetal bovine serum, 4 mM L-glutamine, and penicillin-streptomycin.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Xenopus kidney-derived A6 epithelial cells were cultured as described previously (36).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	51	Reverse Transcription-PCR-- Total RNAs were prepared from the indicated cell lines by use of Trizol buffer (Invitrogen), and cDNAs were synthesized using reverse transcriptase and a dT15 primer.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	52	 PCRs were performed as described (24).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The following primers were used: 5'-ATTAGGATCCatggcagaccagagacagc (sense for human Csp; BamHI restriction site underlined), 5'-ACGAATTCTTAGTTGAACCCGTCAGTGTG (antisense for human Csp; EcoRI restriction site underlined), 5'-ATTAGGATCCATGGCAGATCAGCGGCAGC (sense for Xenopus Csp), and 5'-ACGAATTCTCAGTTGAATCCATCGGTGTG (antisense for Xenopus Csp).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	54	 PCR products from Calu-3 and A6 cells were cloned into the pCRII vector using the TOPO cloning reaction and transformation kit (Invitrogen) for sequencing.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	55	Western Blotting-- Crude membranes from various epithelial cell lines or oocytes were prepared as described by Lang et al.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	56	 To prepare crude membrane extracts, epithelial cells were detached by incubation for 5 min at 37  degrees C with 1 x  trypsin, and after two washes in ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline, cells were resuspended in ice-cold homogenization buffer (5 mM HEPES, pH 7.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	57	4, 250 mM sucrose, 1 mM EGTA, 10  microg/ml leupeptin, 2  microg/ml aprotinin), sonicated, and centrifuged at 100,000  x  g for 60 min.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Crude membranes were recovered and incubated with 0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	59	5% Triton X-100 at 4  degrees C for 1 h and then centrifuged at 16,000  x  g for 1 h.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	60	 The supernatant was collected and stored for analysis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	61	 50  microg of membrane extract was separated on 12% SDS-PAGE minigels and transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membranes.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Blots were probed with a 1:2,000 dilution of Csp or CFTR antiserum.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	63	 For vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein (VSV-G) detection, blots were probed with a polyclonal antibody at 1:5000 dilution.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	64	Immunofluorescence-- Calu-3 cell labeling was performed as described previously (14).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Cells were seeded on filters (Costar Transwell) 2-3 weeks before use.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	66	 After washing away apical secretions, cells were fixed (4% paraformaldehyde) and permeabilized (0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Filters were mounted on glass coverslips, and images were obtained using a Leica TCS-NT confocal microscope as described (14).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	68	Plasmid Constructs and GST Fusion Protein Expression-- Wild-type Csp1 and Csp2 were subcloned into pGEX-6p-1.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	69	 cDNAs encoding GST-CFTR R-domain (GST-R), GST-CFTR N terminus (GST-N) and GST-CFTR C terminus (GST-C) were described previously (15).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	70	 GST-CFTR-N random was constructed as GST-N, except for a one-nucleotide shift in the reading frame, which yields a different amino acid composition; its net charge and size are comparable with CFTR-N.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Purification and dialysis of GST fusion proteins were performed as described by Sun et al.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	72	Pull-down Assays and Coimmunoprecipitation-- 10  microg of GST fusion protein was incubated with 20  microl of preequilibrated glutathione-Sepharose 4B beads in 200  microl of DIGNAM-D buffer containing 0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	73	1% bovine serum albumin at 4  degrees C for 1 h (38).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Calu-3 membrane fractions were added, and the incubation continued for an additional 2 h at 4  degrees C.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	75	 After five washes with DIGNAM-D buffer, samples were resuspended in 30  microl of 2 x  SDS sample buffer, boiled for 2 min, resolved on 12% SDS-PAGE, and probed with anti-Csp antibodies (1:2,000).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Coimmunoprecipitation was performed as described by Sun et al.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	77	 10% of the protein extract employed in the immunoprecipitation was loaded for subsequent immunoblot.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	78	In Vitro Binding and Competition Assays-- In vitro binding assays were performed as described by Sun et al.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	79	 (15), and in vitro competition assays were performed as described by Sun et al.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	80	 Briefly, 10  microg of GST-CFTR-R or GST-CFTR-N fusion protein was immobilized on glutathione beads and incubated with 106 cpm of 35S-labeled Csp1 or Csp2 in the presence of the indicated concentrations of unlabeled Csp1 or Csp2.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	81	 After five washes, samples were resuspended in SDS sample buffer and signals visualized by autoradiography.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	82	Transient Transfections-- HEK293 cells grown in 60-mm dishes were transiently transfected using LipofectAMINE (Invitrogen) with the indicated pcDNA3 or pcDNA3.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	83	1 expression plasmids, 4  microg of cDNA/dish.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	84	 After 24 h, the cells were rinsed with phosphate-buffered saline and either prepared for pulse-chase assays or lysed in RIPA buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	85	4, 150 mM NaCl, 1% Triton X-100, 1% sodium deoxycholate, 0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	86	1% SDS) or Nonidet P-40 lysis buffer (0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	87	09% Nonidet 40, 50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	88	4, 150 mM NaCl and 10 mM NaMoO4).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Samples were incubated for 2 h in the appropriate lysis buffer and centrifuged at 16,000  x  g for 30 min at 4  degrees C.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Cell extracts were utilized for immunoblot analysis (see figure legends).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	91	Pulse-Chase Assays-- Metabolic labeling and immunoprecipitation of CFTR were performed using methods described previously (39, 40), with modifications.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Transfected HEK293 cells were starved in methionine- and cysteine-free Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium for 30 min, and then metabolically labeled with Redivue Pro-mix L-35S (140  microCi/ml; Amersham Biosciences) for 30 min at 37  degrees C.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Cells were washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline and lysed immediately or incubated in complete Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium for the indicated chase periods.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Cell lysates were precleared with protein A-agarose, and immunoprecipitation was performed as described (40) using M3A7 anti-CFTR, kindly supplied by Dr.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Immunoprecipitates were analyzed using 7% SDS-PAGE and autoradiography.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	96	Csp Is Expressed in Epithelial Cells-- Immunoblotting was performed to determine whether Csp is expressed in several epithelial cell lines.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Crude membrane extracts from the mammalian cells HEK293, Madin-Darby canine kidney (type 2), CFPAC-1, Calu-3, and T84, and from the Xenopus A6 cell line were resolved on 12% SDS-PAGE and probed with an anti-Csp antiserum that does not distinguish between Csp isoforms (32).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	98	 As a positive control, membranes from the SY5Y human neuronal (hippocampal) cell line were applied to the gel.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	99	 1A, all of the mammalian epithelial cells examined expressed two Csp isoforms.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	100	 1A are appropriate in size for Csp1 (33-35 kDa), whereas the lower bands in mammalian cells correspond to the size expected for Csp2 (26-28 kDa); this isoform was uniformly less abundant.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	101	 In contrast, A6 cells expressed only one Csp isoform.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	102	 It is more closely related to Csp1 than Csp2 (33), although its molecular size is slightly smaller than the Csp1 in mammalian cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The Csp antiserum also recognized in vitro synthesized Csp1 and Csp2 (data not shown).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	104	View larger version (46K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	105	   Csps are expressed in various epithelial cell lines.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Panel A, homogenates (15  microg of protein) from the indicated cell lines were probed with Csp antiserum.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Panel B, reverse transcription-PCR was performed as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	108	" No cDNA was added in the PCR designated Control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	109	To confirm the expression of Csp isoforms in these cells, reverse transcription-PCR was employed, and the results are shown in Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	110	 The sizes of the PCR products were as expected for the cDNAs encoding Csp1 and Csp2.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	111	 These products are not derived from contaminating DNA because the primers employed span Csp exons.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Csp2 protein is truncated relative to Csp1 because of the insertion of a stop codon-containing RNA splice fragment (32); this accounts for the smaller size of the Csp2 protein but its larger cDNA and PCR product (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Although the PCR results are not quantitative, the Csp amplicon ratios from different cell lines generally agreed with the pattern of isoform expression observed by immunoblot.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	114	 As with the protein analysis, Csp isoforms were expressed at lower levels in T84 cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Only one isoform of Csp was detected in A6 cells, in accord with the protein data (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	116	 1A) and information in the data base.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Sequencing of these PCR products confirmed the expression of Csp1 and 2 in Calu-3 cells, and of the single isoform (33) reported in Xenopus A6 epithelia (data not shown).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	118	Csps Are Partially Colocalized with CFTR at the ER and Apical Membranes-- In non-epithelial cells, Csps are membrane-associated and are localized predominantly on large dense core vesicles or synaptic-like microvesicles (22-24, 42, 43).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	119	 A small fraction of Csp is located on the plasma membranes of neurons, neuroendocrine or endocrine cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Large dense core vesicles are present in epithelial cells having defined secretory products (e.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	121	 pancreatic acinar cells), but Csp distribution in epithelial cells has not been defined previously.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	122	To examine the subcellular distribution of Csps in airway epithelial cells, immunofluorescent staining was performed in polarized Calu-3 cells and visualized using confocal microscopy.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Sections taken at various cell depths (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	124	 2, A-D) showed a predominantly punctate and vesicular distribution pattern for Csp (green fluorescence).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Csp and CFTR (red fluorescence) colocalized in the most apical sections, as indicated by the yellow staining pattern of Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	126	 2E), a fraction of Csp colocalized with CFTR at the apical region of some cells, but the apex of other cells showed little apparent colocalization.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Although Csp colocalized with CFTR in apical membrane compartments, significant fractions of both proteins showed no apparent overlap by immunofluorescence in their steady-state cellular distributions (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	128	 This is partly because of the presence of Csp in what appear to be large secretory granules that lack CFTR (44).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	129	 These granules are likely to contain the secretory products characteristic of airway submucosal gland serous cells, which Calu-3 cells express (e.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	130	 mucins, microbial defense substances and protease inhibitors) (45).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	131	 CFTR was not detected in their membranes (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	132	 2), in contrast to the localization of CFTR found in the mucin granules of canine gallbladder cells (46).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	133	 This observation suggests that Csp may play a CFTR-independent role in secretory granule exocytosis from Calu-3 cells, and this possibility will require further study.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	134	View larger version (70K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	135	   Colocalization of Csp with CFTR or with calnexin in Calu-3 cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Calu-3 cells were labeled with polyclonal Csp antiserum and monoclonal CFTR R-domain or calnexin antibodies.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Labeling was detected by Alexa488 (green indicating Csp) or Alexa568 (red indicating CFTR in panels A-E or calnexin in panel F).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Serial images in the xy plane were collected every 0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	139	5  microm through the specimen depth; xy images (panels A-D), taken from cell apex to base, are separated by 2.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	140	 Panel E shows the xz scan of the region indicated in panel A.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Images were collected by confocal microscopy and analyzed using Metamorph (Universal Imaging) software.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	142	 2F, taken at the nuclear level, shows that Csp (green) was partially colocalized with calnexin (red), an ER marker.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Preliminary analysis of Calu-3 cells by sucrose density gradient centrifugation was consistent also with the colocalization of these proteins because Csp was found in fractions containing the ER marker calnexin.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	144	2 The results suggest that a fraction of Csp is colocalized with CFTR at both the ER and the apical membrane domain of Calu-3 epithelia.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	145	Interaction of CFTR with Csp-- To determine whether a physical interaction between Csp and CFTR could be detected in vivo, we performed coimmunoprecipitation experiments (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	146	 In these studies, the initial precipitation was performed with either Csp antiserum or with antibodies against the first nucleotide binding domain (NBD1) of CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	147	 3A (lane 3), Csp antibody coimmunoprecipitated the mature, glycosylated CFTR (band C, upper) as well as the immature, core-glycosylated CFTR (band B, lower) from Calu-3 cell extracts.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	148	 As a negative control, no CFTR was precipitated by a nonimmune IgG (lane 2).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	149	 As a control for the coimmunoprecipitation, we performed direct CFTR immunoblotting on the same Calu-3 membrane preparations (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Both CFTR bands were present, but the ratio of the B and C bands found in the Csp immunoprecipitation differs from that constitutively expressed.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Together with the results from the cellular localization experiments, the immunoprecipitation results suggest that in the steady state, Csp interacts with both the immature, core-glycosylated form of CFTR in the ER and with mature, fully glycosylated CFTR at the apical membrane domain.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	152	 3B, a CFTR NBD1 antibody coprecipitated Csp from Calu-3 membranes (see positive control, Calu-3 cell lysate, lane 1).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	153	 An N-terminal CFTR antibody did not precipitate significant Csp (data not shown).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The lower band denoted Csp in panel B likely represents deacylated Csp, produced by the coimmunoprecipitation conditions, which include overnight incubation with detergent, as noted by others (47).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	155	 This lower band is not observed under the conditions used for immunoblotting (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	156	 As a negative control, Csp did not coprecipitate with a GST antibody (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The absence of Csp coprecipitation by anti-CFTR-N could represent a problem of antibody affinity, or it may reflect impaired antibody access to its epitope at the N terminus of CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	158	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	159	   Coimmunoprecipitation of Csp and CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Calu-3 membrane extract was mixed with Csp or CFTR antibody and precipitated as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	161	" Immunoblots were probed with anti-CFTR (1:2,000, panel A) or anti-Csp antibodies (1:2,000, panel B).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Calu-3 cell membrane extract was loaded as a positive control (panels A and B, lanes 1).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Antibodies used for immunoprecipitation were nonimmune IgG and anti-Csp (panel A, lanes 2 and 3) and anti-GST and anti-CFTR-NBD1 (panel B, lanes 2 and 3).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	164	 The lower band denoted Csp in panel B likely represents deacylated Csp, produced by the coimmunoprecipitation conditions, which include overnight incubation with detergent.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	165	 This outcome was noted by others (43, 47).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Hc indicates antibody heavy chain.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	167	Csp Interacts with the R-domain and N Terminus of CFTR-- The results from coimmunoprecipitation experiments indicate that CFTR and Csp interact in vivo.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	168	 To evaluate CFTR domain interactions with Csp, we performed pull-down experiments in which GST or GST-CFTR fusion proteins were bound to glutathione-Sepharose beads and incubated with Calu-3 or CFTR-expressing HEK293 membrane extracts.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Protein complexes were washed, resolved on SDS-PAGE, and immunoblotting was performed using Csp antibodies.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	170	 To verify that comparable amounts of GST or GST fusion proteins were applied in these assays, the Western blots were subsequently stained with Coomassie Blue.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The similar amounts of fusion proteins present are illustrated in Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	172	 4B, both the CFTR R-domain and the N terminus showed significant interactions with Csp.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	173	 A weak interaction between CFTR-C and Csp was detected here, but this was not observed consistently.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	174	 No binding was detected between Csp and GST, GST-CFTR-N random, or GST-syntaxin 1A in these pull-down assays.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	175	 The interaction of Csp with CFTR-N is consistent with the finding from the above coimmunoprecipitation studies and suggests that the interaction with CFTR-N could be masked by Csp binding.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	176	View larger version (18K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	177	   Csp interacts with the R-domain and N terminus of CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Bead-immobilized GST-CFTR fusion proteins were incubated with Calu-3 membrane extracts.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	179	 After washing, samples were resolved on 12% SDS-PAGE.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Coomassie Blue staining was used to determine protein loading (panel A); membranes were blotted with Csp antiserum (panel B).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	181	 GST-CFTR fusion proteins: lane 1, GST; lane 2, GST-R; lane 3, GST-C; lane 4, GST-N; lane 5, GST-N random; lane 6, GST-syntaxin 1A.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	182	As indicated above, two Csp isoforms have been identified in various mammalian species (21); Csp2 is truncated by 31 amino acids at the C terminus relative to Csp1.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The Csp isoform(s) that interact with CFTR or CFTR domains in Calu-3 cells (Figs.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	184	 3 and 4) cannot be determined because of the lack of isoform specific Csp antibodies.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Csp1 may be the more physiologically significant isoform because of its predominant expression and the presence of only Csp1 in some species (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	186	 In further characterizing CFTR-Csp interactions, we evaluated the influence of both Csp1 and Csp2; however, in the discussion following we refer to CFTR interactions with Csp, without attempting to discriminate whether they are mediated by a specific Csp isoform.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	187	Relative Affinities of Csp for CFTR Domains-- To determine the relative binding properties of Csp1 and 2 for CFTR, we performed binding assays with in vitro synthesized 35S-labeled Csp1 and Csp2.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Csp interactions were documented using autoradiography (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	189	 5A) and liquid scintillation counting (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	190	 As indicated by the data from both assays, the interaction of Csp1 with the CFTR R-domain (lane 2) was stronger than that with CFTR-N (lane 4), consistent with the Calu-3 cell pull-down experiments of Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	191	 In the present experiments, a weak interaction between CFTR-NBD1 and Csp1 (lane 5) was also detected relative to the GST negative control (lane 1).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The data for CFTR-C (lane 3) were not different from the GST control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Unlike Csp1, Csp2 showed similar levels of binding to CFTR-R and CFTR-N.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Like Csp1, Csp2 showed significant but low level binding to CFTR-NBD1 relative to the GST control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	195	 The lower panel provides pooled data from three independent experiments.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	196	View larger version (37K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	197	   Quantitative Csp interactions with the CFTR R-domain and N terminus.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Immobilized GST-CFTR fusion proteins were incubated with 35S-Csp1 or 35S-Csp2, washed, and samples were resolved by 15% SDS-PAGE.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Csp binding was detected by autoradiography (panel A) and liquid scintillation counting (panel B).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Mean data from three independent experiments are shown.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	201	 Asterisks indicate a significant difference from the GST control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Lane 1, GST; lane 2, GST-R; lane 3, GST-C; lane 4, GST-N; lane 5, GST-NBD1; S1 or S2, 1  microl of 35S-Csp1 or 35S-Csp2 loaded as a positive control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The higher molecular mass bands are thought to represent Csp dimers and have been observed previously (47).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	204	To determine the relative binding affinities of Csps with the CFTR R-domain and N terminus, we performed in vitro competitive binding assays as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	205	" In these pull-down experiments, 35S-labeled Csp1 or 2 was mixed with various amounts of unlabeled Csp before mixing with immobilized CFTR domains.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	206	 6A, unlabeled Csp1 competed with labeled Csp1 for binding to CFTR-R, such that 1  microM unlabeled Csp1 eliminated 51% of 35S-Csp1 binding.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The results imply that the affinity for Csp1 binding to CFTR-R is ~1  microM.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Qualitatively similar results were obtained for Csp1 binding to the CFTR N terminus, but in this case the apparent binding affinity was ~10 nM.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	209	 6A, the association of labeled Csp2 with either the CFTR N terminus or R-domain was essentially eliminated in the presence of 1  microM cold Csp2 (data not shown).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	210	 These results indicate that both Csp1 and Csp2 show saturable binding to the R-domain and N terminus of CFTR and that the affinities of these interactions are in the submicromolar range.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Whether the differences in apparent binding affinity detected in these experiments (e.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	212	 Csp1 interactions with R and N) have physiological significance will require detailed knowledge of their functional consequences.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	213	View larger version (24K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	214	   Affinity of Csp binding to CFTR-R and CFTR-N.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Panels A and B, immobilized GST-CFTR fusion proteins were incubated with 35S-Csp1 in the presence and absence of five concentrations of unlabeled Csp1 and binding detected by autoradiography (upper panels) or densitometric quantification after autoradiography (lower panels).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Lane B, 35S-Csp1 omitted as a negative control; lane C, equivalent amount of 35S-Csp1 added as a positive control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	217	Csp Coexpression Inhibits CFTR Chloride Currents-- The multiple domain interactions observed for Csp binding to CFTR, as well as the colocalization of these proteins in the ER and apical membrane domain, suggest that the functional interactions between these proteins could be extensive.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	218	 To initiate such studies, we coexpressed CFTR with either Csp1 or Csp2 in Xenopus oocytes and determined the CFTR-dependent current and capacitance changes evoked during cAMP stimulation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Prior studies of CFTR-expressing oocytes indicate that the cAMP-induced membrane current (Im) is caused by the chloride flow through the CFTR and that the corresponding increase in membrane capacitance (Cm) monitors changes in cell surface area which are associated with regulated insertion of CFTR into the plasma membrane (10, 41).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	220	 In relation to the initial rationale for these studies, we monitored Cm because Csp is known to function in regulated exocytosis in other systems (21).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Control oocytes not injected with CFTR cRNA showed no changes in Im or Cm in response to cAMP stimulation, as observed previously (41).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	222	 Expression of Csp without CFTR also yielded no Im or Cm responses to cAMP (data not shown).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	223	 The steady-state data from eight experiments in CFTR expressing oocytes are provided in Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Coexpression of Csp1 or Csp2 with CFTR decreased the Im and Cm responses that result from CFTR stimulation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Although either Csp isoform reduced the functional expression of CFTR, Csp2 was the more potent inhibitor of Im and Cm (~90% inhibition) relative to Csp1 (~50% inhibition).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	226	 7 documents the expression of Myc-tagged Csp isoforms at the time of recording.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	227	 The band in lane 1, observed in oocytes expressing CFTR alone, corresponds to the single known endogenous Xenopus Csp, consistent with the A6 cell line data shown in Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	228	 The exogenous expression of Myc-tagged Csp1 and 2 are shown in lanes 2 and 3 of the upper panel.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	229	 We do not know whether the endogenous Xenopus Csp, which most closely resembles mammalian Csp1 (42), contributes to differences in the extent of inhibition by these isoforms or whether the different potencies relate to their structural features.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	230	View larger version (27K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	231	   Csp coexpression inhibits CFTR Im and Cm.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	232	 Lower panel, Im (solid bars) and basal and stimulated Cm values (horizontal and vertical lined bars, respectively) in oocytes expressing CFTR or CFTR plus the indicated Csp isoform.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	233	 Stimulation was elicited by bath addition of 10  microM forskolin and 1 mM isobutylmethylxanthine.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Steady-state data are from three independent experiments are shown.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Numbers of observations: CFTR, 36; CFTR + Csp1, 14; CFTR + Csp2, 28.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Im and Cm inhibition with Csp coexpression was significant (p  <  0.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	237	 Upper panel, oocyte expression of endogenous Xenopus Csp (all lanes), Myc-Csp1 (lane 2), and Myc-Csp2 (lane 3) in parallel experiments.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	238	 cRNA injected/oocyte: CFTR, 1 ng; Csp isoforms, 5 ng.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	239	Csp Inhibits Functional CFTR Responses by Decreasing Steady-state CFTR Expression-- To determine whether the observed inhibition of CFTR current and capacitance changes was the result of a Csp-induced change in CFTR expression levels, we immunoprecipitated CFTR from oocytes expressing CFTR alone or CFTR plus Csp1, Csp2 or the Csp2 double mutant, H43Q/E93V.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	240	 CFTR was precipitated from oocyte membrane extracts, resolved on SDS-PAGE, and immunoblotted (see "Experimental Procedures").
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	241	 CFTR currents recorded from these populations of oocytes at the time of harvest are also provided.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	242	 8 (upper panel), the coexpression of Csp1 or Csp2 produced significant decreases in the level of CFTR expression (to 52 and 36% of the control level by densitometry, lanes 3 and 4, respectively).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	243	 As a negative control, CFTR was not detected in noninjected oocytes (lane 1).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	244	 As a positive control, we blotted CFTR expressed transiently in HEK293 cells (lane 6).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	245	 The apparent molecular masses of CFTR B and C bands expressed in oocytes was similar to those observed in HEK cells (a longer exposure demonstrated migration of HEK cell band B at the same location as observed in oocytes).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	246	 An increase in CFTR expression was observed with the Csp2 double mutant, but this did not result in currents greater than those of the CFTR control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	247	 This degree of CFTR expression increase was not observed in all experiments, and it was not present in mammalian cells (see below).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	248	 The basis of this stimulatory effect of Csp2 double mutant has not been pursued.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	249	 As to the double mutant mutation sites, His-43 is a conserved site in the J-domain of Csp which is essential for Hsc70 binding and ATP hydrolysis (48), and Glu-93 is located in the Csp linker region and has been shown previously to abrogate the inhibitory effect of Csp overexpression on insulin release from pancreatic cells (24).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	250	 These results indicate that the effects of exogenously expressed Csp on CFTR activity are specific for known Csp functional domains, and they suggest that the inhibition of CFTR functional response is due primarily to a Csp-induced reduction in CFTR protein expression.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	251	View larger version (48K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	252	   Csp coexpression reduces oocyte CFTR protein levels.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	253	 cRNAs encoding CFTR (1 ng) and Csp isoforms (5 ng) were injected into Xenopus oocytes as indicated.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	254	 Upper panel, results from CFTR immunoprecipitation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Immunoprecipitation was performed with anti-CFTR monoclonal M3A7, and the immunoblot was probed with anti-CFTR polyclonal R3195 antibodies.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Lane 1, uninjected control; lane 2, CFTR alone; lane 3, CFTR plus Csp1; lane 4, CFTR plus Csp2; lane 5, CFTR plus Csp2 double mutant; lane 6, HEK293 cells transiently expressing CFTR used as a positive control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	257	 Lower panel, cAMP-stimulated chloride currents recorded from the oocyte populations used for the immunoprecipitations.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Data are from five pooled oocytes for immunoprecipitation (50  microg of protein/lane) and four or five oocytes for ICl under each condition.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Recordings/immunoprecipitations were performed 4 days after injection.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	260	Csp Coexpression Inhibits CFTR Biogenesis-- The influence of Csp coexpression on the steady-state levels of CFTR expressed in mammalian cells was determined by cotransfecting HEK293 cells with plasmids encoding Csp and CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	261	 CFTR levels were determined by immunoblot after 24 h.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	262	 The Csp cDNAs used for transfection included an N-terminal Myc-tag, permitting exogenous Csp expression to be detected using an anti-Myc antibody (lower panel, Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	263	 As shown in the top panel of Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	264	 9A, the coexpression of either Csp1 or Csp2 with CFTR (lanes 3 and 4) eliminated the expression of mature, glycosylated CFTR (band C) and produced an accumulation of immature CFTR (band B).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	265	 This finding suggests that Csp overexpression interferes with the processing of CFTR to its mature form and that it stabilizes the immature form of CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	266	 The effect of exogenous Csp on CFTR biogenesis is specific because the Csp2 double mutant (H43V/E93Q) eliminated its inhibitory effect on CFTR maturation (lane 5).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	267	 In other experiments, a similar result was obtained with the Csp2 single mutant, H43Q, implying that a functional J-domain is critical for the inhibitory effect of Csp overexpression.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	268	 The enhancement of CFTR protein level by the Csp2 double mutant found in oocytes was not observed in mammalian cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	269	View larger version (34K):    Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	270	   Effect of Csp on CFTR biogenesis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Panel A, HEK293 cells were transfected with CFTR (lane 2), CFTR plus Myc-Csp1 (lane 3), CFTR plus Myc-Csp2 (lane 4), and CFTR plus Myc-Csp2 double mutant (lane 5).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Lane 1, nontransfected control.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	273	 After 24 h, 50  microg of cell extract was resolved by 7% or by 15% mini-SDS-PAGE, and blots were probed with polyclonal anti-CFTR (R3195, 1:2,000), monoclonal anti-Hsc70 (1:2,000), or monoclonal anti-c-Myc (9E10, 1:2,000, Sigma) antibodies.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	274	 B and C indicate the positions of immature and mature CFTR, respectively.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Panel B, HEK293 cells were transfected with VSV-G (lane 1) or VSV-G plus Csp1 (lane 2); blots were probed with anti-VSV-G polyclonal (1:5,000).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	276	 Experiments were otherwise performed as in panel A.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	277	Because Csp is an Hsc70-binding protein, we examined the levels of Hsc70 by immunoblot under these conditions.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	278	 As shown in the middle panel of Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	279	 9A, the effect of Csp1 or 2 on CFTR expression was not associated with a change in Hsc70 expression levels when this Hsc70-binding protein was expressed.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Thus, the failure of cells to express mature CFTR is not caused by a change in the expression of this important CFTR chaperone.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	281	 In addition, the specificity of the Csp effect for CFTR biogenesis was determined by coexpressing Csp with the VSV-G.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Csp coexpression did not affect the production of the mature VSV-G, in experiments performed in a manner similar to those with CFTR (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	283	 This result suggests that the effect of expressed Csp is specific for maturation of CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	284	The effect of Csp on the steady-state expression of mature CFTR was supported by the results of pulse-chase assays.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	285	 10, Csp1 coexpression in HEK293 cells blocked the conversion of immature CFTR to mature CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	286	 As in prior studies (5), ~30% of wild-type CFTR matures to the fully glycosylated band C protein (lower panels); however, no band C was detected in Csp-coexpressing cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	287	 In addition, the half-life of immature CFTR was prolonged, consistent with the accumulation of band B observed in the steady-state data (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Similar effects on the biogenesis of mature CFTR resulted from the coexpression of Csp2 (data not shown).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	289	 With Csp coexpression, the rise in band B production at chase periods of 30 and 60 min is probably attributed to the lack of cold methionine and cysteine in the chase media; nevertheless, the experiments with CFTR alone were performed identically.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	290	 The results indicate that Csp interferes with CFTR biogenesis when Csp is overexpressed.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	291	 The implications of these findings for a physiological role of Csp in the production of CFTR will be discussed below.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	292	The results of this study show that Csp is expressed in a variety of epithelial cell lines, several of which are models for CFTR-mediated chloride secretion.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	293	 These cells expressed predominantly Csp1, as observed previously in neurons and secretory cells (21) (e.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Immunofluorescent labeling showed a membrane-limited distribution of Csp in ER and apical membrane compartments.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	295	 Significant amounts of CFTR coprecipitated with Csp from Calu-3 cell lysates; in protein binding assays, Csp associated with both the CFTR R-domain and the N terminus.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	296	 The overexpression of Csp decreased CFTR biogenesis, and it correspondingly reduced the functional response of CFTR to cAMP stimulation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	297	 These results indicate that Csp interacts physically and functionally with CFTR in epithelial cells.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	298	 This is the first report of an action of Csp on protein maturation, as discussed below.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	299	Role of Csp in Regulated Exocytosis-- Csp is expected to influence CFTR directly by virtue of its localization at the cytosolic surfaces of intracellular membranes that contain CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	300	 A defining feature of the Csps is their central cysteine-rich (string) domain, where palmitoylation at multiple sites permits Csp to associate with membrane lipid (49).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	301	 Immunofluorescence demonstrated that Csp is distributed in membrane-limited compartments, including the apical membrane domain, in Calu-3 cells (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	302	 The Csps were discovered in Drosophila, and from their cellular distribution and knockout studies, a role for these proteins in neurotransmitter secretion became apparent (18).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	303	 Studies in neuroendocrine (28) and endocrine cells (24) have confirmed the role of Csp in regulated exocytosis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	304	 Several studies have implicated a regulated exocytic event in the control of plasma membrane CFTR channel density (50).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	305	 In Xenopus oocytes expressing CFTR, cAMP stimulation enhances the chloride current and elicits increases in membrane capacitance and cell surface CFTR labeling, consistent with cAMP-regulated insertion of CFTR into the plasma membrane (10, 41, 51).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	306	 In adenovirus-transduced Madin-Darby canine kidney cells, CFTR was distributed in both intracellular and plasma membrane compartments under basal conditions and was recruited to the plasma membrane during cAMP stimulation (52).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	307	 The partial colocalization of Csp with CFTR at the apical membrane domain of Calu-3 cells (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	308	 2E) and its interaction with mature (band C) CFTR (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	309	 3A) is consistent with the concept that this protein may participate in post-Golgi CFTR trafficking events.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	310	 It will be interesting to determine whether Csp interacts with CFTR in a regulated trafficking compartment because this location would be consonant with the documented role of Csp in regulated exocytosis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	311	 To perform such studies, however, it will be necessary to obviate the influence of Csp on CFTR maturation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	312	A Role for Csp in CFTR Biogenesis-- We found Csp to be localized in airway epithelial cells in a compartment marked by the ER resident protein, calnexin.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	313	 Coimmunoprecipitation experiments showed that more of the core glycosylated, immature CFTR was associated with Csp than was the mature, fully glycosylated protein, particularly in proportion to the steady-state expression levels of the mature and immature forms of CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	314	 In addition, Csp coexpression reduced the production of mature CFTR, and this effect of Csp appears to require a functional J-domain.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	315	 These results imply that Csp and CFTR interact during CFTR biogenesis in the ER.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	316	 As a member of the DnaJ family of proteins, Csp could play a role in CFTR processing via its association with Hsc70.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	317	 The DnaJ proteins can serve as co-chaperones that recruit Hsc70 ATPases to specific substrates, where they activate the ATPase activity of the chaperone to modulate protein conformation (folding) or protein-protein interactions (4, 29).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	318	 Hsc70 has long been recognized as a CFTR chaperone, which coprecipitates with CFTR in the presence of ATP (39).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	319	 Hsc70 has been shown to assist in preventing the aggregation of NBD1, the domain in which the common CFTR folding mutant, F508, is located (4, 53, 54).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	320	 Normally, wild-type CFTR will be released from chaperones as it achieves its native conformation, but Hsc70 is thought to remain attached to misfolded CFTR where it can recruit the ubiquitin ligase, CHIP, to facilitate proteosome-mediated CFTR degradation (40, 55).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	321	Csp is a J-domain protein that interacts with Hsc70 and enhances its ATPase activity (56).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	322	 The interaction of Csp with Hsc70 and CFTR is likely to affect CFTR processing in one of two ways.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	323	 First, Csp may be a CFTR co-chaperone that stabilizes intermediate forms of CFTR to promote their folding and maturation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	324	 This model suggests that Csp contributes positively to CFTR maturation, similar to the Hsc70 co-chaperone, Hdj-2 (53).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	325	 Second, Csp interactions with nonfolded CFTR intermediates may contribute to the degradation of nascent CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	326	 This model suggests that Csp may contribute to CFTR degradation, similar to the Hsc70-interacting protein, CHIP (see below).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	327	 Either model could explain how Csp overexpression reduces the steady-state expression levels of mature CFTR in mammalian cells or oocytes and therefore, the cAMP-stimulated CFTR currents (Figs.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	328	 In the first model, Csp overexpression causes a prolonged association of Hsc70 with CFTR, which can target CFTR for degradation (55).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	329	 Hsc70 has been shown to promote the ubiquitination and degradation of several cellular proteins (57).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	330	 For example, overexpression of Hsc70 leads to ubiquitination and degradation of apolipoprotein B (58).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	331	 Thus, a prolonged Csp-mediated association of CFTR with Hsc70, because of Csp overexpression, could lead to CFTR degradation, despite the possibility that the physiological role of Csp is to facilitate CFTR biogenesis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	332	The second model is trivial, in that augmenting the level of a protein involved in CFTR degradation would reduce CFTR expression.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	333	 Illustrative of this model is the Hsc70-binding protein CHIP, a ubiquitin ligase whose overexpression promotes proteasome-mediated CFTR degradation (40).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	334	 CHIP appears to recognize slowly folding or misfolded forms of CFTR and promotes their destruction by binding to CFTR-associated Hsc70.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	335	 CHIP then targets CFTR to ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	336	 The finding that proteosome inhibitors fail to promote trafficking of class II CFTR mutants suggests that mechanisms exist for irreversible targeting of protein to intracellular degradation processes before their cellular destruction.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	337	 CHIP appears to be a component of this pathway; in principle, Csp could function in this manner as well.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	338	Several findings favor the co-chaperone model.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	339	 First, the predominant interaction of Csp with CFTR band B in Calu-3 cells (Fig.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	340	 3) suggests a physiological role for Csp in the maturation of CFTR because the majority of the CFTR expressed in these cells is the fully glycosylated mature form.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	341	 Second, the direct interaction of Csp with CFTR subdomains in the absence of Hsc70 (Figs.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	342	 4 and 5) suggests that Csp may localize Hsc70 at specific sites to facilitate CFTR folding.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	343	 In contrast to CHIP (40), Csp does not require Hsc70 for its interaction with CFTR.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	344	 Third, Csp overexpression stabilized CFTR band B, which is contrary to the result expected for a protein that promotes degradation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	345	 Finally, previous data indicate a positive role for Csp in protein folding processes, also favoring the first model of Csp interaction.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	346	 As is true of other DnaJ proteins, Csp can bind to unfolded proteins and prevent their aggregation (49).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	347	 This activity is synergistic with the similar action of Hsc70.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	348	 Together, these findings suggest that Csp may serve as a co-chaperone during CFTR biogenesis.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	349	Csp Interactions with the N terminus and R-domain-- With regard to protein interactions that could regulate CFTR biogenesis, it is interesting that Csp has the capacity to bind to both the R-domain and the CFTR N terminus.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	350	 Previous studies implicate the N terminus as a site important for the normal processing of CFTR and suggest that interactions of the R-domain with other CFTR subdomains may facilitate its biogenesis (3).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	351	 N-terminal truncations of CFTR are poorly processed, and little of the truncated protein is able to traffic to the plasma membrane.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	352	 In addition, several N-terminal disease mutations are processing mutants.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	353	 Several studies indicate that a pivotal point in CFTR synthesis is the generation of the R-domain.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	354	 Before synthesis of the R-domain, CFTR is unstable and is associated with chaperones to prevent NBD aggregation (53, 54).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	355	 Once the R-domain is formed, chaperone protein associations with CFTR decrease, and the nascent protein becomes more stable.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	356	 Other studies indicate that mutations near the N terminus of CFTR which lead ultimately to protein degradation are not recognized by the ER-associated degradation machinery until the R-domain is synthesized (3).
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	357	 This implies that degradation processes recognize structural interfaces between CFTR subdomains.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	358	 These interdomain effects may be mediated by specific co-chaperones that can interact with several CFTR subdomains to facilitate access of Hsc70 to intermediates in the folding pathway; Csp is a candidate for such interactions.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	359	Finally, the discussion has focused primarily on CFTR biogenesis in the ER; however, it is possible also that the physiological action of Csp involves the trafficking of immature CFTR to post-ER compartments.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	360	 For example, Csp and CFTR could interact in the transition of CFTR to the ER-Golgi intermediate compartment or to proximal Golgi regions prior to CFTR glycosylation.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	361	 The mechanistic involvement of Csp in such trafficking processes may parallel its action in regulated exocytic events (see discussion above), presumably exploiting its interaction with Hsc70 to facilitate trafficking protein interactions.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	362	 In addition, a nonconventional pathway for CFTR trafficking has been proposed recently (59, 60) involving direct transit from the ER to the trans-Golgi network, perhaps via an endosomal compartment.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	363	 Csp could be involved in these trafficking steps; however, the significance of their role in CFTR maturation was cell type-dependent, and the presence of this pathway in epithelial cells has not yet been demonstrated.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	364	 Further studies will be necessary to evaluate these possibilities.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	365	 Wrigley for excellent technical assistance; John R.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	366	 Riordan for antibody; Mark Silvis, Neil A.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Bradbury, and Meir Aridor for help with the pulse-chase studies; Simon C.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	368	 Watkins for assistance with image analysis; and Jeffrey L.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	369	 Brodsky and Meir Aridor for comments on the manuscript.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	370	* This work was supported by National Institutes of Health Grant DK56490, Cystic Fibrosis Foundation Grants FRIZZE97RO and 99GO, and a grant from the Wellcome Trust.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	371	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	372	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	373	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	374	To whom correspondence should be addressed: Dept.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	375	 of Cell Biology and Physiology, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, S362 BST, 3500 Terrace St.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	376	: 412-648-9498; E-mail: frizzell@pitt.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	377	Published, JBC Papers in Press, May 30, 2002, DOI 10.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	378	The abbreviations used are: CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; Cm, capacitance current; Csp, cysteine string protein; ER, endoplasmic reticulum; GST, glutathione S-transferase; GST-C, GST-CFTR C terminus; GST-N, GST-CFTR N terminus; GST-R, GST-CFTR R-domain; HEK, human embryonic kidney; Hsc, heat shock cognate; Im, cAMP-induced membrane current; NBD, nucleotide binding domain; R-domain, regulatory domain; SNARE, soluble NSF attachment protein receptor; VSV-G, vesicular stomatitis virus glycoprotein; CHIP, C terminus of Hsc70-interacting protein.
0.4726967.12039948.html.plaintext.txt	379	Copyright   2002 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	0	Functional human CFTR produced by stable Chinese hamster ovary cell lines derived using yeast artificial chromosomes Functional human CFTR produced by stable Chinese hamster ovary cell lines derived using yeast artificial chromosomes Peter J.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Guggino4, Yuan Jiang2 and Melissa A.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	2	1Laboratories of Gene Transfer and 2Cancer Genetics, National Center for Human Genome Research, National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, Maryland 20892, USA and Departments of 3Pediatrics, Anesthesia and Critical Care Medicine and 4Physiology, Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions, Baltimore, Maryland 21287, USA.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	3	Received July 29, 1996; Revised and Accepted November 5, 1996.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	4	The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR) encodes a transmembrane protein (CFTR) which functions in part as a cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-regulated chloride channel.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	5	 CFTR expression is controlled temporally and cell specifically by mechanisms that are poorly understood.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Insight into CFTR regulation could be facilitated by the successful introduction of the entire 230 kb human CFTR and adjacent sequences into mammalian cells.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	7	 To this end, we have introduced two different CFTR-containing yeast artificial chromosomes (YACs) (320 and 620 kb) into Chinese hamster ovary-K1 (CHO) cells.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Clonal cell lines containing human CFTR were identified by PCR, and the genetic and functional analyses of one clone containing each YAC are described.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Integration of the human CFTR-containing YACs into the CHO genome at a unique site in each cell line was demonstrated by fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Southern blot analysis suggested that on the order of one copy of human CFTR was integrated per CHO cell genome.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Fiber-FISH and restriction analysis suggested that CFTR remained grossly intact.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Northern analysis showed full-length, human CFTR mRNA.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Immunoprecipitation followed by phosphorylation with protein kinase demonstrated mature, glycosylated CFTR.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Finally, chloride secretion in response to cAMP indicated the functional nature of the human CFTR.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	15	 This study provides several novel results including: (i) functional human CFTRcan be expressed from these YACs; (ii) CHO cells are a permissive environment for expression of human CFTR; (iii) the level of human CFTR expression in CHO cells is unexpectedly high given the lack of endogenous CFTR production; and (iv) the suggestion by Fiber-FISH of CFTR integrity correlates with functional gene expression.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	16	 These YACs and the cell lines derived from them should be useful tools for the study of CFTR expression.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	17	Cystic fibrosis (CF) is the most common fatal autosomal recessive disorder in the Caucasian population (1 ).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	18	 It is caused by mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR) leading to the loss of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-stimulated chloride efflux from epithelial cells (2 -4 ).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	19	 CFTR is a 230 kb gene encoding a 1480 amino acid transmembrane protein which functions as a chloride channel with several other regulatory properties (5 ,6 ).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	20	 More than 600 mutations in CFTR have been identified in individuals with CF (7 ).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The most common mutation, a deletion of 3 bp leading to the loss of a phenylalanine residue at position 508, is found in nearly 70% of CF alleles (8 ).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	22	CFTR is expressed primarily in exocrine epithelia from the lung, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas and sweat glands (9 -11 ).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	23	 The expression is generally low in these tissues, although a few specific epithelial cell types, such as the serous cells in the submucosal glands of the lung, have relatively high level expression (12 ).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	24	 The mechanisms that govern the level and the cell specific regulation of CFTR expression have been explored but remain poorly understood.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	25	 The putative promoter region lies within 3800 bp of the start site of CFTR transcription and supports low level expression of reporter genes in vitro (13 -16 ).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	26	 CFTR expression can be induced by cAMP (17 ) and suppressed by phorbol ester (18 ,19 ).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	27	 (20 ) demonstrated that the induction of CFTR expression by protein kinase A is mediated by an 8 bp cAMP responsive element upstream from CFTR.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	28	 (21 ) analyzed the function of an inverted CCAAT element at -132 to -119 upstream from CFTR in detail.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	29	 They showed that transcription factor binding to this element confers both basal and cAMP-induced CFTR expression.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The level of CFTR expression also appears to be related to the state of cellular differentiation (22 ).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Additional regulatory elements have been shown to lie within this 5'-flanking region as well as within the first CFTR intron (23 ).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	32	 DNase I hypersensitivity sites have been demonstrated within the 120 kb upstream of CFTR, but no correlation with cell type specific CFTR expression was observed (24 ).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Taken together, these studies provide little insight into the exact mechanisms that determine the level and specificity of CFTR expression.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	34	One novel approach to study CFTR expression is to introduce the entire 230 kb gene and flanking sequences into mammalian cells.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Obstacles to this approach include: (i) obtaining an appropriate vector containing a full-length, human CFTR without deletions, mutations or rearrangements; (ii) maintaining the integrity of CFTR during vector propagation; and (iii) transferring CFTR intact into appropriate mammalian cells.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Yeast artificial chromosomes (YACs) provide potential vectors for such a study.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	37	 YACs containing human CFTR were generated soon after the gene was identified (25 ,26 ).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Although the genetic structure of these YACs has been studied, the functionality of CFTR contained within them has not been established.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	39	The goal of the present study was to determine if two different YACs containing full-length, human CFTR and ~45 or 335 kb of adjacent upstream sequence can produce functional human cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator protein (CFTR) in mammalian cells.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The analyses that follow demonstrate the functionality of the human CFTR contained within each YAC.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	41	 RESULTS Human CFTR-containing YACs are used to generate stable Chinese hamster ovary cell lines.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	42	Each YAC used in this study contains full-length, human CFTR (Fig.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The neomycin resistance gene (neor) was introduced into the right arm of each YAC and the extent of human sequence surrounding CFTR was determined by restriction analysis.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	44	 The smaller YAC, yCFTR325-Neo, is ~320 kb and contains 45 kb of flanking sequence upstream from the CFTR transcriptional unit and 30 kb of 3'-flanking DNA.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The larger YAC, yCFTR8-Neo, is ~620 kb and contains 335 kb of 5'-flanking and 40 kb of 3'-flanking DNA.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Map of the two YACs used in this study.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	47	 yCFTR325-Neo is ~320 kb and contains 45 kb of 5'-flanking and 30 kb of 3'-flanking DNA.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	48	 yCFTR8-Neo is ~620 kb and contains 335 kb of 5'-flanking and 40 kb of 3'-flanking DNA.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	49	 CFTR transcription start site is indicated by the arrow.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	50	 The NruI sites in the human DNA as well as the two sites in the right YAC arm are indicated by `N'.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	51	In separate experiments, Chinese hamster ovary-K1 (CHO) cells were fused with yeast spheroplasts containing one of the two YACs.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	52	 CHO cells that incorporated neor were identified by their clonal growth in the presence of G418.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Approximately 50 colonies of CHO cells from each YAC transfer were present after 2 weeks of G418 selection.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Twenty clones derived using the smaller YAC and 27 clones derived using the larger YAC were randomly selected and sub-cultured.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Fourteen clones containing the smaller YAC and seven containing the larger YAC were randomly selected and analyzed to determine if they contained human CFTR, as described below.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	56	Screening of CHO cell clones for human CFTR was performed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis of genomic DNA using two sets of intron primers, one spanning exon 2 and the other, exon 6a.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	57	 These primers were chosen toward the 5'-end of the gene since neor was located beyond the 3'-end of CFTR.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Seven out of 14 clones derived using the smaller YAC and the six out of seven clones derived from the larger YAC were positive for CFTR exons 2 and 6a.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Control CHO cell DNA was negative under identical reaction conditions.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Clones positive for both exons were analyzed for CFTR mRNA by reverse transcription (RT)-PCR using primers spanning exon 7 to exon 9.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Three out of seven clones derived using the smaller YAC and four out of six clones derived using the larger YAC were positive.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Control CHO cell RNA was negative under identical reaction conditions (data not shown).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Based on this screening, candidates were chosen for further study.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	64	 The detailed genetic and functional analyses of the two clones with the highest level of CFTR mRNA are described below.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	65	 The cell line designated CS2/C5 was derived using yCFTR325-Neo, and CS1/F2 was derived using yCFTR8-Neo.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	66	 A single site of integration is identified in each cell line.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	67	Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) was performed on metaphase nuclei from CS2/C5 and CS1/F2 to determine the site of CFTR integration (Fig.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Using a YAC derived from y37AB12 (25 ) containing the entire CFTR as a probe, the human CFTR was localized to a single locus in each clone.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The human CFTR was integrated at CHO chromosome band 4p21-23 in the CS2/C5 cell line and at CHO chromosome band 5q27 in the CS1/F2 cell line.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	70	 FISH of metaphase nuclei hybridized with a CFTR-containing YAC probe derived from y37AB12 and labeled with SpectrumOrange.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The chromosomes were counter-stained with DAPI.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	72	 (A) yCFTR325-Neo integrated into CHO chromosome band 4p21-23 in the cell line CS2/C5.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	73	 (B) yCFTR8-Neo integrated into CHO chromosome band 5q27 in the cell line CS1/F2.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	74	 No hybridization was seen in control CHO cells (data not shown).
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	75	Southern analysis was performed to determine the copy number of human CFTR incorporated into each CHO cell clone (Fig.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Genomic DNA from CS2/C5, CS1/F2, control CHO cells and HT-1080 (a pseudodiploid human fibrosarcoma cell line; ATCC CCL 121) was digested with EcoRI and hybridized to a cDNA fragment containing part of the CFTR 3'-untranslated region within exon 24.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	77	2 kb single band was seen in CS2/C5, CS1/F2 and HT-1080, but not in control CHO.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	78	 CFTR copy number was assessed by comparing the clones with HT-1080.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The intensity of the bands from 10 [mu]g of CS2/C5 and CS1/F2 DNA was similar to that obtained from 5 [mu]g of HT-1080 DNA.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	80	 These data suggest that on the order of one copy of CFTR was integrated into the CHO genome in each cell line.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Similar results are shown for CS2/C5 and CS1/F2 compared with CFPAC-1 cells [a hyperdiploid human pancreatic adenocarcinoma cell line (ATCC CRL 1918)].
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Southern analysis of genomic DNA from human genomic DNA, CS2/C5, CS1/F2 and CHO cells digested with EcoRI and hybridized to a cDNA probe containing the CFTR 3'-untranslated region within exon 24.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Lane 1: 10 [mu]g of DNA from CS2/C5.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Lane 2: 10 [mu]g of DNA from CS1/F2.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	85	 Lane 3: 10 [mu]g of DNA from control CHO cells.
