0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	365	This page is maintained by OUP admin.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	366	 Last updated Sun Jan 12 13:36:16 GMT 1997.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	367	 Part of the OUP Journals World Wide Web service.
0.4739439.9002671.html.plaintext.txt	368	Copyright Oxford University Press, 1996.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	0	 1995 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Interaction between Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator and Outwardly Rectified Chloride Channels (*).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	2	(Received for publication, July 24, 1995; and in revised form, September 29, 1995).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	3	Biljana Jovov (1), ( ),  Iskander I.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	4	We have previously described a protocol for the simultaneous isolation and reconstitution of a protein kinase A (PKA)-sensitive outwardly rectified chloride channel (ORCC) and the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) from bovine tracheal epithelium.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Immunoprecipitation of CFTR from this preparation prevented PKA activation of the ORCC, suggesting that CFTR regulated the ORCC and that this regulatory relationship was preserved throughout the purification procedure.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	6	 We now report the purification of CFTR from bovine tracheal epithelia and the purification of a CFTR conduction mutant (G551D CFTR) from retrovirally transduced mouse L cells using a combination of alkali stripping, Triton-X extraction, and immunoaffinity chromatography.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Immunopurified CFTR proteins were reconstituted in the absence and presence of ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	8	 To test the hypothesis that only functional CFTR can support activation of ORCC by PKA and ATP, we used an inhibitory anti-CFTR peptide antibody or G551D CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	9	 When anti-CFTR peptide antibodies were present prior to the addition of PKA and ATP, activation of both the ORCC and CFTR was prevented.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	10	 If the antibody was added after activation of the ORCC and CFTR Cl channels by PKA and ATP, only the CFTR Cl channel was inhibited.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	11	 When ORCC and G551D CFTR were co-incorporated into planar bilayers, only the ORCC was recorded and this channel could not be further activated by the addition of PKA and ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Thus, functional CFTR is required for activation of the ORCC by PKA and ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	13	 We also tested the hypothesis that PKA activation of ORCC was dependent on the extracellular presence of ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	14	 We added ATP on the presumed extracellular side of the lipid bilayer under conditions where it was not possible to activate the ORCC, i.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	15	 in the presence of inhibitory anti-CFTR antibody or G551D CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	16	 In both cases the ORCC regained PKA sensitivity.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Moreover, the addition of hexokinase + glucose to the extracellular side prevented activation of the ORCCs by PKA and ATP in the presence of CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	18	 These experiments confirm that both the presence of CFTR as well as the presence of ATP on the extracellular side is required for activation of the ORCC by PKA and ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	19	The cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) ()and outwardly rectified chloride channels (ORCC) both contribute to cAMP-activated chloride conductance in normal, but not in cystic fibrosis (CF), airway cells (1, 2) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	20	 ORCCs are present in the apical membranes of CF airway epithelia, but they cannot be activated by protein kinase A (PKA) and ATP(3, 4, 5) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	21	 CFTR channels are regulated by PKA and ATP and are inhibited by the channel blocker diphenylamine-2-carboxylate (DPC) but not by 4,4`-diisothiocyanostilbene-2,2`-disulfonic acid (DIDS)(6, 7) , whereas ORCCs are DIDS-sensitive.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Although CFTR and ORCC channels are distinct proteins, they are linked through unknown regulatory pathways.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Different mechanisms by which CFTR might regulate the ORCC can be envisioned.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	24	 For example, CFTR could interact directly with the ORCC protein in the apical membrane, regulation could be a consequence of the channel function of CFTR, or both.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	25	 It has been shown that CFTR can act as both an ATP and a Cl channel(6) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Recently Guggino's group (7) demonstrated that ATP transported through CFTR acts as an autocrine stimulator of the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The proposed mechanism of regulation is via a P receptor that, either through a direct coupling to the ORCC or through a G protein-coupled signaling pathway, stimulates the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	28	Increasing evidence suggests heterogeneity in the molecular pathogenesis of CF.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Some mutations, such as the deletion of a phenylalanine at position 508 (Phe-508) of CFTR, cause CFTR to be processed improperly within epithelial cells, and disease may result because the mutant protein fails to traffic to the apical cell membrane.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Other mutations, such as the relatively common glycine aspartic acid replacement at CFTR position 551 (G551D, 3% of all mutations), appear to be processed and targeted normally to the plasma membrane, but lack responsiveness to stimulation by cAMP(8) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	31	 It is not known how different mutational forms of CFTR affect regulation of the ORCC by PKA.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	32	Amino acid sequence analysis suggests that CFTR is composed of two motifs, each containing a membrane-spanning domain (MSD) and a nucleotide-binding domain (NBD) linked by a regulatory R domain(9) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Recently, Welsh and colleagues (10) demonstrated that the amino-terminal portion of CFTR, which includes MSD1, NBD1, and the R domain, forms a regulated Cl channel.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	34	 It has been shown previously that an even smaller part of CFTR, namely NBD1 (amino acids 426-588), can form an anion channel when reconstituted in planar lipid bilayers(11) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	35	 It is not known if these portions of the CFTR molecule can also transport ATP or if they are sufficient to replace intact CFTR in the regulation of the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	36	We recently reported the simultaneous isolation and functional reconstitution of an ORCC and CFTR from bovine tracheal epithelia(12) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	37	 The regulatory relationship between these channel proteins was preserved throughout the purification procedure, as demonstrated by the activation of the ORCC by PKA and ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Immunoprecipitation of CFTR from this preparation prevented the activation of the ORCC by PKA and ATP, suggesting that the presence of CFTR is required for PKA-dependent activation of the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	39	 However, these experiments did not distinguish if functional CFTR was essential for conferring PKA sensitivity to the ORCC, if only the physical interaction of CFTR was required, or both.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	40	We thus tested the hypothesis that the functional form of CFTR is required for PKA activation of the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	41	 In order to achieve this goal, we used an inhibitory anti-CFTR peptide antibody (13, 14, 15) to block CFTR transport function or replaced functional CFTR with a nonfunctional mutant form of CFTR, namely G551D CFTR(8) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Our results indicate that only when CFTR is functional can the ORCC be activated by PKA and ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Our results also are consistent with the hypothesis of Schwiebert et al.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	44	 (7) that the transport of ATP by CFTR to the extracellular side of the cells is necessary for PKA activation of the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	45	Materials[-P]ATP was obtained from DuPont NEN.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	46	 A hydrazide-derivatized Acti-Disk was obtained from FMC Corp.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Peroxide-free Triton X-100 and Bio-Beads SM2 were purchased from Bio-Rad.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Phospholipids were obtained from Avanti Polar Lipids (Birmingham AL).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	49	 All other reagents were of analytical grade and were purchased from Sigma, Bio-Rad, or Fisher.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	50	Tracheal Apical Membrane PreparationBovine tracheal apical membrane vesicles were prepared by differential centrifugation using a procedure first described by Langridge-Smith et al.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	51	(16) , modified as described previously(14) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Aliquots of prepared vesicles (average protein concentration = 5 mg/ml) were stored in liquid nitrogen until use.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Extraction of peripheral proteins from native membrane vesicles was achieved by incubation of vesicles for 30 min in KCl buffer (100 mM KCl, 5 mM Tris/Hepes, and 0.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Alkaline stripped vesicles were recovered by centrifugation at 35,000 g for 35 min and then solubilized with Triton X-100 (0.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	55	8%) in the presence of KCl buffer (at pH 7.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Quantitation of solubilized protein was performed using the BCA method.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	57	Immunopurification of ORCC and CFTR ClChannel Proteins with p38 AntibodiesImmunopurification of ORCC and CFTR was performed as described previously(12) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	58	 A polyclonal rabbit antibody (p38) generated against the 38-kDa component of an anion channel protein was covalently linked to a hydrazide activated disk.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	59	 An equivalent amount of non-immune rabbit IgG was linked to another hydrazide-activated disk.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Solubilized prewashed apical membrane vesicles were diluted in 40 ml of the above buffer and recirculated first over a non-immune disk and after that over the immune disk for 1 h (each disk) to allow unspecific and specific binding of the proteins.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	61	 The disks were then extensively washed with NaCl/phosphate buffer before elution with 100 mM glycine, pH 3.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Successive 2-ml fractions were collected and immediately neutralized with 40  microl of 1 M Tris.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The first 15 fractions were pooled and concentrated to 500  microl and used for reconstitution in liposomes or for further biochemical characterization.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	64	Immunopurification and in Vitro Phosphorylation of Normal and Mutant Form (G551D) of CFTRImmunopurification of CFTR from bovine tracheal apical vesicles (wild type CFTR) or L cell lysate (G551D CFTR) was performed using polyclonal anti-CFTR antibodies raised against a purified fusion protein corresponding to the first NBD1 (amino acids 426-588) of CFTR(18) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	65	 L cell lysates were prepared as described previously(16) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Essentially the same immunopurification procedure as described above with p38 antibodies was followed, except that solubilized proteins were precleared with non-immune IgG prior to recirculation over the disks and that the pH of the elution buffer was 2.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Subsequent labeling and analysis of eluted proteins with [-P]ATP was done as described previously (12) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Complete solubilized material (30-40  microg of proteins) or immunopurified proteins (approximately 100-200 ng) were washed with reaction buffer (50 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	69	5, 10 mM MgCl) and concentrated to 40  microl.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	70	 PKA (300 ng) and 2 nmol of [-P]ATP (3000 Ci/mmol) were added and the mixture incubated for 60 min at 30  degrees C.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The reaction was stopped by adding SDS sample buffer containing 10 mM dithiothreitol.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	72	 The samples were run on 6% acrylamide gels, and the dried gels were analyzed by autoradiography.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	73	Immunoprecipitation of CFTR from p38-immunopurified Bovine Tracheal ProteinsImmunoprecipitation of CFTR from p38-immunopurified bovine tracheal proteins was performed as described previously (19) using the polyclonal anti-CFTR antibodies.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Precipitation was performed in radioimmune precipitation buffer that contained 50 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	75	5, 550 mM NaCl, 1% Triton -X 100, 1% sodium deoxycholate, and 0.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	76	1% SDS to ensure dissociation of CFTR from other proteins.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	77	Tissue CultureRetrovirus transduced L cells containing G551D CFTR ((8) ; kind gift from Dr.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Raymond Frizzell, University of Alabama at Birmingham), a murine fibroblast cell line, were grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Life Technologies, Inc.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	79	), supplemented with 10% heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum, 100 units/ml penicillin, and 100  microg/ml streptomycin.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	80	Production of Anti-CFTRAntibodyNew Zealand White rabbits were immunized with purified NBD1 (amino acids 426-588) fusion protein emulsified in Freund's adjuvant (complete for initial immunization and incomplete thereafter) in a ratio of 1:1.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Each animal received 400-500  microg of purified protein.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	82	 The animals were bled from the marginal ear vein at 2-week intervals for the initial four bleeds.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The serum antibody titer was monitor by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay as described previously(17) , using the purified fusion protein as the antigen.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Subsequently, the animals were bled and boosted as required.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	85	Production of Anti-CFTRAntibodyAnti-CFTR antibody was produced as described in(13) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	86	 New Zealand white rabbits were immunized with a synthetic peptide corresponding to amino acids 505-511 of CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Site-directed antibody was affinity-purified from immune serum using synthetic 505-511 peptide coupled to CNBr-activated Sepharose.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Whole cell patch clamp studies have shown that this antibody neutralizes CFTR function(13) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	89	Polyacrylamide GelsProtein separation on polyacrylamide gels was performed using the method of Laemmli(20) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	90	 The apparent M of the unknown proteins was determined from appropriately constructed log Mversus relative mobility (R) curves.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	91	Planar Lipid Bilayer ExperimentsImmunopurified Cl channel proteins were reconstituted into liposomes as described previously(21) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Briefly, concentrated protein samples (100-200 ng) were mixed with a phospholipid mixture (phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylserine, phosphatidylcholine at a ratio of 50:30:20, w/w/w) in the presence of 400 mM KCl, 0.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	93	5 mM MgCl, and 5 mM Tris/HCl, pH 7.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	94	4, at a final volume of 600  microl.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Residual Triton X-100 was removed by incubating samples with 150 mg of Bio-Beads SM-2, first at room temperature for 45 min and then overnight at 4  degrees C.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Proteoliposomes were separated from the beads using a 1-ml syringe fitted with a 27-gauge needle.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Liposomes that contained co-reconstituted ORCC and G551D CFTR were produced by mixing an equal amount (100-200 ng) of immunopurified ORCC protein with immunopurified G551D CFTR protein and following the same procedure as for reconstitution of single immunopurified material.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	98	Planar lipid bilayers, composed of a mixture of diphytanoyl-phosphatidylethanolamine, diphytanoyl-phosphatidylserine, and oxidized cholesterol in a 2:1:2 (w/w/w) ratio (final concentration = 25 mg/ml in n-octane), were painted with a fire-polished glass capillary over a 200- microm hole drilled in a polystyrene chamber, as described previously(22) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Bilayer formation was monitored by the increase in membrane capacitance to a final value of 300-400 picofarads.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Liposomes containing anion channel proteins were incorporated into bilayers bathed with symmetrical solutions of 100 mM KCl and 10 mM MOPS adjusted to pH 7.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Channel incorporation was indicated by the appearance of quantal step increases in current with applied voltage.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Current measurements were performed with a high gain amplifier circuit based on a design described previously(23) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Single channel records were analyzed with pCLAMP, version 5.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Steady-state single channel current-voltage (I/V) curves were measured after channel incorporation by applying a known voltage and measuring individual channel current (i).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Single channel open probability (P) was calculated from P = I /ni, where i is the unitary current, I is the mean current, and n is the total number of active channels.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Both n and i were estimated from an all points current amplitude histograms produced by pCLAMP software.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The dashed line in the figures represents the zero current level (or close state).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	108	 All bilayer experiments were repeated a minimum of four times under a specified set of experimental conditions.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	109	Immunopurification of Bovine CFTR from Tracheal Epithelia and Recombinant G551D CFTR from L Cell LysatePreviously we reported an immunopurification procedure for the simultaneous isolation of both an ORCC and CFTR from bovine tracheal epithelia.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Incorporation of isolated proteins demonstrated that both the channel proteins, as well as the regulatory relationship between them, were very well preserved (12) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	111	 To further delineate the mechanism of interaction between the ORCC and CFTR, we immunopurified and reconstituted two different forms of CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	112	 The immunopurification procedure was essentially the same as that previously described for the simultaneous isolation of the ORCC and CFTR, except that anti-CFTR antibody was used.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Mild conditions of immunopurification helped to preserve functional protein for reconstitution.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	114	 The cell lysate of L cells expressing G551D served as a source for a nonfunctional, mutated form of CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	115	 In vitro phosphorylation of immunopurified material revealed a dominant 170-kDa phosphoprotein isolated from either bovine tracheal epithelia (Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	116	 1A, lane 2; n = 3) or L cell lysate (Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	117	 It was shown previously that the G551D form of CFTR is not different from wild type CFTR with respect to glycosylation(8) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	118	 Our results indicate that anti-CFTR antibodies are suitable for immunopurification of G551D CFTR from L cell lysates and that G551D CFTR can be in vitro phosphorylated.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	119	Figure 1: Autoradiograph of in vitro phosphorylated, immunopurified bovine CFTR and G551D CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	120	 The phosphorylation reaction mixture consisted of the protein sample dissolved in 40  microl of buffer (50 mM Tris, pH 7.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	121	5, and 10 mM MgCl), 300 ng of the catalytic subunit of protein kinase A, and 2 nmol of [-P]ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	122	 The reaction was carried out at 30  degrees C for 60 min.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Lane 1, total in vitro phosphorylated proteins from solubilized tracheal apical membrane vesicles.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Lane 2, phosphoprotein eluted from immune Acti-Disk (polyclonal anti-CFTR antibody).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	125	 A 170-kDa phosphoprotein is present.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Lane 3, phosphoproteins eluted from a non-immune IgG bound Acti-Disk.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	127	 B, G551D CFTR from mouse L cells.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Lane 1, total in vitro phosphorylated proteins from L cell lysate.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Lane 2, phosphoprotein eluted from immune IgG-bound Acti-Disk (polyclonal anti-CFTR antibody).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	130	 A 170-kDa phosphoprotein is present.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Lane 3, phosphoproteins eluted from non-immune IgG-bound Acti-Disk.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	132	Reconstitution of Bovine Tracheal CFTR and G551D CFTREqual amounts of immunopurified tracheal CFTR or G551D CFTR were each reconstituted into proteoliposomes and incorporated into planar lipid bilayers.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	133	 2A shows typical current traces of channel activity of bovine tracheal CFTR after incorporation and activation by PKA and ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	134	 No channel activity was observed whatsoever when incorporation was performed in the absence of PKA and ATP in the bathing solution.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Incorporations were random; therefore, PKA + ATP was present in both compartments of the bilayer chamber prior to incorporation.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	136	 When wild type CFTR-containing vesicles were used, a small (16 picosiemens) linear anion-selective channel was recorded.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	137	 The identity of the incorporated channel was confirmed by its insensitivity to 100  microM DIDS, its sensitivity to DPC, and its block by anti-CFTR antibodies (Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Moreover, this channel had a Cl  >  I permselectivity (4:1).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Anti-CFTR antibodies added to the one side of the bilayer containing incorporated CFTR, to a final concentration of 25-50 ng/ml, inhibited bovine CFTR channel activity in the presence of PKA and ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	140	 However, due to the random orientation of the channel in the bilayer, in some of the experiments (11/28) these antibodies did not inhibit CFTR when added to one side of the system only.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	141	 In these same experiments, addition of antibodies to the opposite side successfully inhibited channel activity.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Addition of the anti-CFTR antibody (the antibody used in the purification of CFTR) to either or both sides of the bilayer did not have any effect on the activity of incorporated bovine CFTR (Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Incorporation of G551D CFTR and treatment with PKA and ATP did not result in the appearance of any channel activity (n = 15).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	144	Figure 2: Single channel activity of immunopurified bovine CFTR reconstituted into planar lipid bilayer.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Control single channel recordings were performed at holding potentials of +80 mV in the presence of 100  microM ATP and the catalytic subunit of PKA (1.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Anti-CFTR antibodies 200  microg/ml were added to both sides of the bilayer, followed by addition of 100  microM DIDS to both compartments of the bilayer chamber.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Addition of 100  microM DIDS in a separate experiment (n = 13) to either side (or both) of the channel-containing bilayer prior to addition of anti-CFTR antibodies had no effect on channel activity.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	148	 In the experiment shown (representative of 18 out of a total 33), 300  microM DPC completely blocked channel activity when added to one side of the bilayer (usually trans).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	149	 In the other 15 experiments, DPC was ineffective when added to this one side of the bilayer.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Thus, addition of 300  microM DPC was made to the opposite side; this resulted in abolished channel activity.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	151	 In the experiment shown, anti-CFTR antibodies (50 ng/ml) were added to one side of the bilayer (usually cis).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	152	 Likewise in the DPC inhibition experiments, if channel activity remained unaffected (11 experiments from total 28), antibodies were added to the opposite side with subsequent inhibition.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	153	Effect of Inhibitory Anti-CFTRAntibodies on Activation of the ORCC by PKA and ATPWe next examined whether inhibitory anti-CFTR antibodies could prevent the activation of ORCC by PKA + ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	154	 For these experiments we used immunopurified material obtained using p38 antibodies that contained CFTR co-purified with the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Current rectification of the ORCC allowed us to determine the sidedness of the incorporated channels.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	156	 Moreover, the incorporation of proteins into negatively charged bilayers held at -80 mV permitted us to perform oriented reconstitutions.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	157	 The cytoplasmic (PKA-sensitive) portion of both channels faced the cis compartment, while the extracellular portion faced the trans compartment in more than 90% of successful incorporations of ORCC + CFTR, as assessed by PKA activation.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Another observation allowed us to determine whether CFTR was co-reconstituted into the bilayer membrane prior to PKA activation.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Current-voltage (I/V) curves of ORCC in the presence of nonphosphorylated CFTR were slightly less rectified in the negative voltage quadrant compared with when CFTR was absent (Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	160	 This distinction was important because in a few experiments when PKA + ATP failed to activate ORCC incorporated into the bilayer membrane (3 out of 72), using the criterion described above, we concluded that CFTR was not present in the bilayer.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Furthermore, in these same three experiments, CFTR channel activity also was not observed subsequent to addition of PKA + ATP to either side of the bilayer.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	162	Figure 5: Single channel current-voltage relationships of immunopurified and reconstituted ORCC in the presence or absence of wild type CFTR or G551D CFTR before and after activation by PKA and ATP in planar lipid bilayer.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	163	 Conditions are defined in the symbol legends on the graph.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Symbols indicate mean values, and error bars indicate  plus or minus  S.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	165	 for at least four separate experiments for each condition.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	166	We found that anti-CFTR antibodies had no effect on base-line ORCC activity, confirming their specificity toward CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	167	 If inhibitory anti-CFTR antibodies were added to the presumptive cytoplasmic bathing solutions after PKA and ATP activation of the incorporated channels, only CFTR Cl channel activity was inhibited, while ORCC remained activated with a P 0.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Amplitude histograms of channel recordings made in the presence of PKA and ATP (Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	169	 3B) showed that at least three CFTR Cl channels accompanied one ORCC channel (only one ORCC was active in the bilayer after inhibition of CFTR using anti-CFTR antibodies).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	170	 However, it would be premature to draw any conclusions about the exact molar ratio of ORCC and CFTR necessary for interaction from these bilayer experiments, because in other comparable experiments two to five CFTR channels per single ORCC have been observed.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	171	 In contrast to these results obtained with anti-CFTR antibodies added after PKA + ATP activation of incorporated channels, addition of inhibitory anti-CFTR antibodies prior to addition of PKA and ATP prevented activation of both CFTR and ORCC by PKA + ATP (n = 11; Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	172	Figure 3: Effect of anti-CFTR antibody on PKA- and ATP-activated ORCC and CFTR in planar lipid bilayer.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	173	 A, traces shown are representative of 21 experiments.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Holding potential and doses of PKA and ATP and anti-CFTR antibodies were as described for Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Control refers to channel activity in symmetrical bathing solutions containing 100 mM KCl, 10 mM MOPS, pH 7.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Additions were made sequentially as shown in the figure.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	177	 B, all point amplitude histograms of traces shown in A.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	178	 Histograms were generated by pCLAMP software from record of 5 min in length.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	179	Figure 4: Effect of anti-CFTR antibody on activation of ORCC and CFTR by PKA and ATP in planar lipid bilayer.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	180	 A, traces shown are representative of 11 experiments.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Holding potential, doses of PKA + ATP, and anti-CFTR antibodies were as described for Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Control refers to channel activity in symmetrical bathing solutions containing 100 mM KCl, 10 mM MOPS, pH 7.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Additions were made sequentially as shown in the figure.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	184	 B, all point amplitude histogram of traces shown in A.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Histograms were generated by pCLAMP software from recordings of 5 min in length.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	186	Anti-CFTR antibodies did not affect the rectification properties of ORCC, although by using these antibodies to block CFTR channel activity we were able to determine more precisely the I/V curves of phosphorylated ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	187	 Notably, rectification of ORCC upon PKA-induced phosphorylation did not change.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The slope conductance of ORCC at positive voltages was not altered under any conditions.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	189	 These results support the hypothesis that the active form of CFTR is required for activation of ORCC by PKA and ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	190	Effect of Replacement of Functional CFTR with Nonfunctional G551D CFTR on Activation of ORCC by PKA and ATPTo test further the hypothesis that the functional form of CFTR is required for activation of the ORCC by PKA and ATP, we co-reconstituted immunopurified ORCC and nonfunctional G551D CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Separation of ORCC from co-purified ORCC and CFTR was achieved by immunodepletion of CFTR from the preparation.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	192	 The removal of CFTR was confirmed by the absence of a 170-kDa phosphoprotein and lack of activation by PKA + ATP of reconstituted ORCC incorporated into planar lipid bilayers, as described earlier (12) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	193	 G551D CFTR was immunopurified as described under ``Methods'' and co-reconstituted with the preparation containing ORCC but devoid of CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	194	 For replacement of normal CFTR with G551D CFTR we used autoradiography/densitometry to estimate the intensity of the in vitro phosphorylated CFTR (170 kDa) band and replaced normal CFTR with a similar amount of G551D CFTR, as G551D CFTR can also be in vitro phosphorylated.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Under these conditions following incorporation into the bilayer, only the ORCC was recorded with no change in open probability upon addition of PKA and ATP to one (either cis or trans) side of the bilayer (P = 0.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	196	05; n = 9 in presence of PKA + ATP).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Detailed analysis of the electrical properties of ORCC revealed a change in its rectification properties in the presence of G551D CFTR in the negative potential quadrant, similar to what was described for ORCC in the presence of normal CFTR (see Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	198	 In three separate experiments, liposomes containing only G551D CFTR were fused with a bilayer already containing ORCC but not CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The presence of G551D CFTR, like incorporation of wild type CFTR, produced a change in the rectification properties of ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	200	 In only 2 experiments from a total 26 performed, ORCC incorporated from liposomes presumably containing both ORCC and G551D CFTR displayed properties identical to ORCC incorporated from CFTR-immunodepleted preparations.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	201	 These observations allowed us to conclude that the change of rectification was indicative of the presence of G551D CFTR in a bilayer containing ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Nonetheless, the ORCC was not activated by PKA + ATP in these experiments (n = 9), thus supporting the hypothesis that the conductive form of CFTR was required for the activation of the ORCC by PKA and ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	203	 However, in three experiments in which PKA and ATP were added to both sides of a bilayer containing ORCC and G551D CFTR, the activity of ORCC was increased 2-fold (from 0.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	204	Effect of Extracellular ATP on Activation of ORCC by PKA and ATPIt has been shown that CFTR is both a Cl and an ATP channel(6) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	205	 To test if the transport of ATP by CFTR is required for activation of the ORCC, we added an ATP scavenging system, hexokinase (0.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	206	5 unit/ml) + glucose(5 mM), to the presumptive extracellular side of the bilayer containing incorporated ORCC and CFTR Cl channels.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	207	 The presence of hexokinase + glucose on the presumptive extracellular side did not influence activation of the CFTR channel by PKA + ATP added to the opposite side of the bilayer, but it did prevent the PKA-mediated activation of ORCC (n = 12).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	208	 These results are in contrast to the PKA-mediated activation of ORCC and CFTR seen in the absence of hexokinase and glucose (cf.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	209	The aforementioned results suggested that ATP secretion through CFTR may be required for the PKA-induced activation of the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Addition of ATP by itself from the presumptive extracellular side did not have any effect on the channel activity of the incorporated ORCC + CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	211	 If transport of ATP through CFTR was the only requirement for PKA-mediated activation of the ORCC, it should be possible to activate ORCC by the addition of ATP to the extracellular solution and PKA + ATP to the cytoplasmic side of the system.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	212	 However, when ORCC alone was incorporated into a bilayer, this channel could not be activated by addition of 100  microM ATP to the ``outside'' and PKA + ATP to the ``inside'' or by PKA + ATP to both bathing solutions (see Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	213	 These results suggest that transport of ATP through CFTR is not the only role that CFTR plays in the regulation of the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	214	Figure 7: Channel activity of ORCC and G551D CFTR in planar lipid bilayers and the effects of extracellular ATP and intracellular PKA + ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Traces shown are representative of 11 experiments.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	216	 Holding potential, doses of PKA + ATP, and anti-CFTR antibodies were as described for Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Control refers to channel activity in symmetrical bathing solutions containing 100 mM KCl, 10 mM MOPS, pH 7.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	218	 Additions were made sequentially as shown in the figure.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	219	We therefore examined if the presence of ATP on the presumptive extracellular side of a bilayer containing ORCC and nonfunctional CFTR (i.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	220	 either blocked with the inhibitory antibody or nonfunctional G551D CFTR) could restore PKA sensitivity to the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	221	 Under both conditions, namely, in the presence of inhibitory antibodies (Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	222	 7), the ORCC regained PKA sensitivity when 100  microM ATP was added to the extracellular bathing medium.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	223	 These findings also confirmed the hypothesis that transport of ATP is not the only role that CFTR plays in the regulation of ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	224	 These results also indicate that G551D CFTR, like wild-type CFTR, incorporated into the membrane with a specific orientation in the presence of ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	225	Figure 6: Channel activity of ORCC and CFTR in planar lipid bilayers in the presence of anti-CFTR antibody and the effects of extracellular ATP and intracellular PKA + ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Traces shown are representative of 14 experiments.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Holding potential, doses of PKA + ATP, and anti-CFTR antibodies were as described for Fig.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Control refers to channel activity in symmetrical bathing solutions containing 100 mM KCl, 10 mM MOPS, pH (7.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	229	 Additions were made sequentially as shown in the figure.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	230	We also tested whether a portion of CFTR, namely the NBD1 domain, could interact with the ORCC in the presence of extracellular ATP and be sufficient for PKA-mediated activation of ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	231	 However, in four separate experiments, we found that NBD1 could not substitute for full-sized CFTR in the regulation of ORCC by PKA and ATP added from either or both sides of the membrane.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	232	Our results demonstrate that we have immunopurified and functionally reconstituted into planar lipid bilayers bovine CFTR and nonconductive G551D CFTR from transduced L cells.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	233	 A similar immunopurification procedure for the isolation and reconstitution of recombinant, and functionally competent, CFTR from Chinese hamster ovary and Sf9 cells was reported recently(24) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	234	 Our reconstituted proteins were used with purified and functionally reconstituted ORCC (as described previously) for further delineation of the mechanism of interaction between CFTR and the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	235	Immunopurified and reconstituted bovine CFTR Cl channel had the same ion selectivity, inhibitor specificity, and inhibition by anti-CFTR antibodies as reported previously in patch clamp studies or for reconstituted recombinant CFTR(7, 13, 25) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	236	 The main difference between the previously reported characteristics of the CFTR Cl channel and the bovine CFTR Cl channel was the single channel conductance.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	237	 In our experiments the conductance of bovine CFTR was 16 picosiemens, somewhat larger than that previously reported (8-13 picosiemens).
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The conductance of the CFTR channel in our hands was the same regardless of the antibody that was used for purification or the presence or absence of the ORCC in the reconstituted material.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	239	 The reason for this discrepancy is not apparent.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	240	Our study demonstrated that only when the transport function of CFTR was intact could the activation of the ORCC by PKA and ATP occur.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Our results also support Guggino's (7) hypothesis that one function of CFTR in the activation of the ORCC is to transport ATP to the extracellular side of the cell membrane.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	242	 This hypothesis is consistent with the findings of Reisin et al.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	243	(6) who have demonstrated directly that ATP can traverse the CFTR channel.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	244	 We cannot at present exclude the co-purification of a purinergic receptor by our procedures.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	245	 However, it is unlikely that a receptor-coupled mechanism would be active in the bilayer system because of the absence of necessary signaling molecules.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	246	 However, the failure of ORCC to be activated by PKA + ATP in the presence of external ATP supports the idea that a purinergic receptor mediated pathway does not co-purify in our preparation.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	247	 The second finding revealed by our study is that a nonconductive form of CFTR (G551D) was able to support activation of the ORCC by PKA when ATP was present on the extracellular side of the incorporated channels.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	248	It has been shown previously that the portion of CFTR that includes MSD1, NBD1, and the R domain, or even smaller parts of CFTR (NBD1 amino acids 426-588), can form Cl channels(10, 11) .
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	249	 We tested whether NBD1 could substitute for CFTR in the regulation of the ORCC by PKA by ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Under the conditions used in these studies, NBD1 did not form a channel in the bilayer and therefore was not able to substitute for CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Furthermore, a recombinant NBD1 purified from prokaryotic cells was unable to support activation by PKA of the ORCC in the presence of exogenously added extracellular ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Taken together these results suggest that there is a minimal size requirement of CFTR necessary to subserve its regulatory role in the PKA-related activation of the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	253	In summary, we have immunopurified and functionally reconstituted CFTR from bovine trachea and nonconductive G551D CFTR from transduced L cells.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	254	 In combination with previously co-purified ORCC and CFTR from bovine tracheal epithelia, and inhibitory anti-CFTR antibodies, we were able to explore the regulatory relationship between the ORCC and CFTR.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	255	 We have shown that functional CFTR is required for activation of the ORCC by PKA and ATP.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	256	 CFTR is apparently required to transport ATP from the cytoplasm to the extracellular bathing solution, where it can then interact with some external domain of the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	257	 The observation that the ORCC cannot be activated by extracellular ATP and PKA + ATP added to the cytoplasmic side in the absence of the CFTR molecule also suggests that, in addition to the transport (ATP) function of CFTR, a direct interaction between CFTR and ORCC is essential to confer PKA sensitivity to the ORCC.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	258	*This work was supported in part by National Institutes of Health Grant DK48764.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	259	 The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.

0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	276	 81, 1063-1073 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Yang, Y.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	277	 2, 1253-1261 [Abstract] Fuller, C.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	278	 (1994) Cell 76, 1091-1098 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve] Arisipe, N.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	279	 89, 1539-1543 [Abstract] Jovov, B.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	280	 270, 1521-1528 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Chan, H.
