0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	286	 267, 20630-20637 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Ismailov, I.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	287	 269, 10235-10247 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Alvarez, O.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	288	 270, 17033-17043 [Abstract/Free Full Text] Bear, C.
0.4846223.7493947.html.plaintext.txt	289	 (1992) Cell 68, 809-818 [Medline] [Order article via Infotrieve]  1995 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	0	EDITORIAL FOCUS Activation of NF-B in airway epithelial cells is dependent on CFTR trafficking and Cl channel function Adam J.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Weber, Grace Soong, Ruth Bryan, Shahryar Saba, and Alice Prince.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	2	College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, New York, New York 10032.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	3	Polymorphonuclear leukocyte-dominated airway inflammation is a major component of cystic fibrosis (CF) lung disease and may be associated with CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) dysfunction as well as infection.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Mutant F508 CFTR is mistrafficked, accumulates in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), and may cause "cell stress" and activation of nuclear factor (NF)-B.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	5	 G551D mutants also lack Cl channel function, but CFTR is trafficked normally.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	6	 We compared the effects of CFTR mutations on the endogenous activation of an NF-B reporter construct.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In transfected Chinese hamster ovary cells, the mistrafficked F508 allele caused a sevenfold activation of NF-B compared with wild-type CFTR or the G551D mutant (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	8	 NF-B was also activated in 9/HTEo/pCep-R cells and in 16HBE/pcftr antisense cell lines, which lack CFTR Cl channel function but do not accumulate mutant protein in the ER.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	9	 This endogenous activation of NF-B was associated with elevated interleukin-8 expression.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Impaired CFTR Cl channel activity as well as cell stress due to accumulation of mistrafficked CFTR in the ER contributes to the endogenous activation of NF-B in cells with the CFTR mutation.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	11	nuclear factor-B; cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; chloride channel; inflammatory response; intracellular calcium; mitogen-activated protein kinase.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	12	CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF) transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) mutations have many effects on the physiology of respiratory epithelial cells in addition to the expected effects on Cl transport.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	13	 One of the major clinical manifestations of CFTR mutations is excessive airway inflammation (14-17), implying that CFTR affects the immune function of airway epithelial cells, particularly the expression of nuclear factor (NF)-B-dependent proinflammatory chemokines and cytokines.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Several lines of experimental evidence suggest that CFTR dysfunction influences the exogenous activation of epithelial immune function (8, 30).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Bacteria persist in the respiratory tract of CF patients due to decreased antimicrobial activity in CF airway surface fluid and impair bacterial clearance due to mucus plugging (25).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	16	 Cells with CFTR mutations have increased numbers of asialoglycolipid receptors for common bacterial pathogens (24).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Ligation of these receptors activates NF-B-dependent epithelial interleukin (IL)-8 production to recruit polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) from the circulation into the airways (8).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Epithelial expression of IL-8 after bacterial stimulation is increased in cells with CFTR dysfunction, a finding demonstrated in both matched CF and corrected cell lines (5, 9, 27, 30) and in cftr-deficient [cftr(/)] mice compared with normal control mice (29).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	19	 How CFTR dysfunction might affect the endogenous expression of NF-B-dependent genes is less well documented.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	20	NF-B is a transcription factor required for the expression of many genes important in inflammation.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	21	 It is complexed in the cell cytoplasm with IB- and -, which are selectively phosphorylated, ubiquitinated, and degraded in the proteasome in response to stimuli (2).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	22	 There is both signal-dependent and signal-independent IB- phosphorylation (20), a distinction that may be relevant to the endogenous activity of NF-B as opposed to the activation in response to a superficial stimulus such as bacterial attachment to surface receptors.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Ligation of superficial asialo-GM1 receptors on epithelial surfaces by bacterial adhesins stimulates Ca2+-dependent kinase activity through mitogen-activated protein kinase phosphorylation and NF-B activation (23a).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	24	 NF-B translocation may be regulated by other intracellular factors that lead to a different pattern of IB- phosphorylation than that elicited by extracellular stimuli (4).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	25	 It has been proposed that the abnormal trafficking of F508 CFTR and its accumulation in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) provides sufficient intracellular stress to cause NF-B activation (2).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	26	The most common CFTR mutation responsible for CF in ~70% of patients is the deletion of a phenylalanine residue (F508) in the nucleotide binding domain.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	27	 The F508 mutant CFTR not only fails to transport Cl in response to cAMP but accumulates in the ER due to abnormal maturation and folding (1, 7, 32).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	28	 From experimental data generated with adenovirus mutants targeted for retention in the ER, Pahl and colleagues (18, 19) proposed that homozygous F508 mutations in CFTR would similarly cause Ca2+ release, activation of NF-B, and resultant transcription of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Comparison of the endogenous activation of NF-B in IB3 cells (W1282X/F508), a trafficking mutant similar to the homozygous F508 mutation, with that in corrected C-38 cells, which express a functional but truncated form of CFTR, was consistent with this hypothesis.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	30	 The transcriptionally active p65 component of NF-B was found in the nuclei of unstimulated CF cells but not of the corrected cells by immunofluorescence labeling and was confirmed by gel shift assays (8).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Manipulations to increase CFTR trafficking to the apical surface of the cell, such as growth at low temperature or the addition of glycerol, decreased the amount of p65 found in the IB3 cell nuclei.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Although these observations were consistent with the hypothesis that abnormal CFTR proteins cause endogenous activation of NF-B, they did not differentiate between two possible mechanisms: that "cell stress" associated with CFTR mistrafficking leads to changes in intracellular Ca2+ concentration ([Ca2+]i) and stimulation of NF-B translocation or that CFTR Cl channel dysfunction by itself is associated with endogenous activation of NF-B.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	33	Other types of CFTR mutations cause "CF-like" physiology, i.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	34	, lack of Cl secretion in response to cAMP, without causing trafficking abnormalities or resulting in the accumulation of mutant proteins in the ER (7).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Analysis of the activation of NF-B in such cell lines would provide the opportunity to determine whether Cl channel dysfunction alone is associated with the regulation of NF-B.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	36	 The G551D CFTR mutant, in which a conserved glycine in the ATP binding cassette is mutated, lacks Cl channel function, but the protein is properly folded and trafficked (12).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Patients with the G551D mutation have a clinical disease that is indistinguishable from that caused by the more common F508 mutation (10).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	38	 The 9/HTEo human tracheal epithelial cell line transfected with a plasmid directing constitutive expression of the CFTR regulatory (R) domain also fails to transport Cl in response to cAMP while expressing low levels of wild-type CFTR message detected by RT-PCR (21).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	39	 These 9/HTEo/pCep-R cells are readily activated by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and express significantly more IL-8 than control cells containing the empty vector (5).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The impact of impaired CFTR Cl channel activity on the normal interaction of IBs and NF-B is not known.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Recently constructed 16HBE cell lines expressing plasmid-encoded cftr in the sense or antisense orientation also provide the opportunity to test the impact of CFTR Cl channel function on the activation of NF-B in airway cells without the confounding issues of mistrafficked CFTR protein (23).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	42	In the experiments detailed in this report, several matched cell lines with CFTR dysfunction due to lack of Cl channel function, CFTR misfolding, mistrafficking, or both were tested for endogenous activation of NF-B and basal IL-8 expression.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Although CFTR mistrafficking typical of the common F508 mutation and associated cell stress may be responsible for the increased expression of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines associated with CF cells, we sought to establish whether CFTR Cl channel function as well as the effects of CFTR mistrafficking contributes to endogenous activation of NF-B and the excessive inflammation that characterizes CF airway pathology.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	44	9/HTEo cells, a human tracheal epithelial cell line (11), were grown in DMEM supplemented with 10% FCS and were stably transfected with either pCep, a vector control, or pCep-R, providing constitutive expression of the R-domain of CFTR resulting in typical CF-like physiology, i.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	45	, failure of Cl secretion in response to cAMP (21) and altered superficial sialylation (5).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	46	 IB3 cells (F508/W1282X), a human bronchial epithelial cell line, and C-38 cells, "corrected" cells with normal physiology that express an episomal truncated form of CFTR (33), were obtained from P.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Zeitlin (Johns Hopkins University, Baltimore, MD) and grown in LHC-8 medium (Biofluids, Rockville, MD) plus 10% FCS.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The IB3 cells used in these studies contain the empty vector.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	49	 16HBE cells transfected with plasmids expressing the first 131 nucleotides of cftr in either the sense or antisense orientation were grown in MEM plus 10% FCS plus L-glutamine and have been previously described (23).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Cells expressing the antisense plasmid failed to respond to cAMP agonists with Cl secretion.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Stably transfected Chinese hamster ovary (CHO)-K1 cells that express F508 CFTR or G551D CFTR were obtained from J.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Riordan (Mayo Clinic Scottsdale, Scottsdale, AZ) and grown in MEM plus 200  microM methotrexate plus 8% FCS.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	53	 CHO-K1 cells were obtained from the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC) and lipofected with pCep plasmid constructs expressing either wild-type CFTR, G551D CFTR, F508 CFTR, or the vector alone, provided by M.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Drumm (Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland OH).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	55	 CHO cells were grown in MEM plus 10% FCS.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	56	 CFTR expression in the cells was verified by immunodetection with COOH terminus-specific mouse monoclonal anti-CFTR antibody (Genzyme, Minneapolis, MN).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Total RNA was isolated from confluent monolayers of IB3 and C-38 cells grown in 10-cm plates with RNeasy Mini Kit, and RT was performed with Omniscript RT (both from QIAGEN, Valencia, CA).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	58	 PCR primers for human IL-8 were 5'-TACTCCAAACCTTTCCAACCC-3' and 5'-AACTTCTCCACAACCCTCTG-3'.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The cells were stimulated by the addition of 0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	60	 aeruginosa PAO1 (5  x  109 colony-stimulating units/ml) scraped from an agar plate and resuspended in cell culture medium.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	61	 IL-8 in epithelial cell culture supernatants was measured with ELISA (R and D Systems, Minneapolis, MN).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	62	 The cells were weaned from serum for 18 h, and the supernatants were harvested 18 h later for IL-8 ELISA.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Duplicate wells were treated with trypan blue to assess epithelial viability during the assay, which was  > 75%.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Each IL-8 data point was determined in quintuplicate, and means  plus or minus  SD were calculated.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	65	 Significance was evaluated with a one-way ANOVA with Dunnett's posttest (GraphPad Instat version 3.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	66	00, GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA) to test the null hypothesis that there was no difference in the amount of IL-8 produced by the epithelial cells with different CFTR function.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	67	Activation of NF-B Detected by Luciferase Reporter Constructs.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	68	Cells were grown in six-well plates to 80-90% confluence, washed once with PBS, and replated with serum- and antibiotic-free medium.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The cells were transiently transfected with LipofectAMINE 2000 reagent (Life Technologies, Gaithersburg, MD), 1  microg of each plasmid DNA, pNF-B-Luc (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) and a constitutively active pRL-TK (Promega, Madison, WI), to control for transfection efficiency and incubated at 37 degrees C in 5% CO2 for 18 h.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Lipofection of the CHO cells was done with an additional 3  microg of pCep-CFTR vector DNA.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The cells were washed once, lysed, and harvested with passive lysis buffer (Promega).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Luciferase assays were performed with the reagents and protocol for the dual-luciferase reporter assay system (Promega) and analyzed with a luminometer.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	73	 After standardization for transfection efficiency, data were plotted as the means of quadruplicate samples and are representative of at least three independent experiments.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Statistical analysis was performed with an unpaired t-test for the experiments involving epithelial cells and a one-way ANOVA to analyze the results obtained with the CHO cells to accommodate a larger sample size.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	75	Relative levels of [Ca2+]i were estimated in fluo 3-loaded IB3 and C-38 cells by fluorescence imaging.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	76	 Monolayers of C-38 or IB3 cells were grown for 2 days on Lab-TekII chambered slides (Nalge Nunc International, Naperville, IL) in LHC-8 medium (Biofluids) supplemented with 10% FCS.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	77	 The monolayers were washed and dye loaded with fluo 3-AM (Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA) for 0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	78	5 h at room temperature in the dark in modified Ringer solution (145 mM NaCl, 5 mM KCl, 1 mM Na2HPO4, 2 mM CaCl2, 10 mM glucose, 20 mM HEPES, and 1 mM MgSO4, pH 7.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	79	 The cells were rinsed in Ringer solution and incubated for 30 min to allow continued cleavage of the acetoxymethyl ester.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The monolayers were imaged on a Zeiss Axiovert microscope at  x 40 magnification with Inovision software.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Images were taken at 10-s intervals before and after the addition of stimuli, and each image is the average of eight scans.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Final measurements were taken after the addition of the ionophore 4-bromo-A-23187 (Bio-Rad) to allow for correction of differences in dye loading.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Images were analyzed with Scion image software (Scion, Frederick, MD).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Significance was determined with an unpaired t-test to compare the mean relative fluorescence of the two populations of epithelial cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	85	Airway epithelial cells were grown to near confluence on Lab-TekII eight-chambered glass slides (Nalge Nunc International).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	86	 They were washed with PBS, fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde in PBS for 20 min at room temperature, washed three times with PBS, and blocked in 10% goat serum in Ca2+/Mg2+ PBS for 1 h at room temperature.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	87	 After blocking, the cells were washed three times in PBS and incubated with a 1:100 dilution of rabbit polyclonal antibody p65 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Santa Cruz, CA) for 1 h at room temperature, washed, and then incubated with goat anti-rabbit IgG conjugated to tetramethylrhodamine B isothiocyanate (TRITC; 1:50; Zymed, South San Francisco, CA) in PBS plus 0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	88	1% BSA plus an equal volume of bis-benzimide (50  microg/ml) for 1 h at room temperature.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	89	 The cells were imaged on a Zeiss Axiovert S100 microscope with a Hamamatsu Orca II digital camera and Inovision software.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	90	 560D15 and 400DF15 band-pass filters were used for TRITC and bis-benzimide imaging, respectively.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	91	 Emission data were collected with a triple-pass filter at wavelengths of 460 nm for bis-benzimide and 602 nm for TRITC.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	92	Activation of NF-B in Epithelial Cells With CFTR Dysfunction.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	93	To determine whether lack of CFTR-associated Cl channel function affects the basal activation of NF-B in airway epithelial cells, two cell lines with defective CFTR function but without mutations associated with mistrafficking were studied.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	94	 9/HTEo/pCep cells and 9/HTEo/pCep-R cells, which have constitutive overexpression of the CFTR R-domain and fail to transport Cl in response to cAMP, were transfected with an NF-B-luciferase reporter construct.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	95	5-fold greater activation of NF-B than 9/HTEo/pCep cells expressing the vector control (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Similarly, 16HBE cells expressing cftr antisense, previously shown to lack CFTR-dependent Cl channel activity, had fivefold greater activation of the NF-B reporter than the cells expressing cftr in the sense orientation (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	97	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	98	   Nuclear factor (NF)-B activation in airway epithelial cells with defective cystic fibrosis (CF) transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) Cl channel function.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	99	 The relative activation of an NF-B-luciferase reporter construct in 16HBE cells expressing cftr sense or antisense construct, 9/HTEo/pCep, and 9/HTEo/pCep-R cells is shown (n = 12 experiments).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	100	Nuclear p65 (Rel A) in Cells With CFTR Dysfunction Detected by Immunofluorescence.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	101	The presence of the p65 (Rel A) component of NF-B in the cell nucleus is generally indicative of NF-B activation and gene transcription.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	102	 To verify that activation of NF-B as detected by the reporter constructs was indicative of nuclear localization of the p65 component, the cell lines were permeabilized, treated with antibody to p65 that was detected with a goat anti-human IgG conjugated to TRITC with bis-benzimide to stain the nuclei.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	103	 The control cells with normal CFTR function, either 9/HTEo/pCep or 16HBE/cftr sense, had predominantly cytosolic p65 fluorescence (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	104	 In contrast, within the fields of 9/HTEo/Cep-R and 16HBE/cftr antisense cells, there were significantly more cells with nuclear p65 TRITC fluorescence colocalizing with the blue bis-benzimide nuclear stain.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	105	View larger version (127K):    Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	106	   Fluorescence imaging of airway epithelial cells to localize NF-B p65.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	107	 Digital images of permeabilized cells were analyzed with Inovision software to localize anti-p65 NF-B-tetramethylrhodamine isothiocyanate (TRITC) and -bis-benzimide nuclear fluorescence.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	108	Activation of NF-B in CHO Cells Expressing Wild-Type and Mutant CFTR.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	109	CHO cells that were transiently transfected with the pCep empty vector or pCep vector expressing wild-type CFTR had low levels of basal NF-B activation as did the cells transfected with the plasmid expressing the mutant G551D CFTR (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	110	 This was in contrast to the threefold increase in luciferase activity associated with CHO cells expressing mutant F508 CFTR (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	111	001 for F508 compared with the pCep vector control).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Experiments done with stably transfected CHO cells yielded similar results (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	113	 3C); expression of F508 CFTR was associated with a sevenfold increase in reporter activation compared with that in the CHO cells expressing the G551D mutation (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	114	001) or CHO cells transfected with the reporter construct alone (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The relative expression of CFTR in the CHO cells was roughly equivalent (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	116	 In the CHO cells, expression of the F508 CFTR mutation was sufficient to activate NF-B, whereas the presence of comparable amounts of the mutant G551D CFTR was not.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	117	View larger version (21K):    Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	118	   NF-B activation in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells transiently transfected with CFTR.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	119	 A: relative activation of an NF-B-luciferase reporter construct in CHO cells without CFTR () or transiently transfected with the pCep vector; wild-type (wt) CFTR, G551D CFTR, or F508 CFTR cloned in pCep (n = 12 experiments).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	120	 B: immunodetection of CFTR in the transiently transfected CHO cells: Lane A, control CHO cells; lane B, pCep-wild-type CFTR; lane C, pCep-G551D CFTR; lane D, pCep-F508 CFTR.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	121	 C: NF-B activation in stably transfected CHO cells (n = 12 experiments).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	122	 D: immunodetection of CFTR in stably transfected CHO cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Lane A, without CFTR (control); lane B, G551D CFTR; lane C, F508 CFTR.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	124	IL-8 Expression Is Increased in Cell Lines With CFTR Dysfunction.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	125	The nuclear localization of NF-B is associated with the transcription of several genes such as IL-8, a major PMN chemokine, that are important in inflammation.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Increased expression of IL-8 has been frequently reported to be characteristic of CF cells after bacterial stimulation as well as under basal conditions (8).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	127	 To determine whether the activation of NF-B seen in the epithelial cell lines with dysfunctional CFTR is associated with an IL-8 response, IL-8 expression was assessed with RT-PCR (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	128	 (These unstimulated cells did not produce sufficient amounts of IL-8 in serum-free medium to detect with a standard ELISA.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	129	) There was increased IL-8 mRNA expression detected in the IB3 cells compared with the endogenous levels in the C-38 cells, and both cell lines increased IL-8 mRNA expression in response to bacterial stimulation, included as a positive control.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	130	View larger version (32K):    Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	131	   Interleukin (IL)-8 mRNA expression in IB3 and C-38 cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	132	 Expression of IL-8 mRNA was analyzed by PCR after reverse transcription and compared with a -actin control.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Lane A, IB3 cells; lane B, IB3 cells stimulated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa; lane C, C-38 cells; lane D, C-38 cells stimulated with P.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	134	IL-8 production could be reliably measured by ELISA in 9/HTEo and 16HBE cell culture supernatants accumulated over 18 h after being weaned from serum.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	135	 The 9/HTEo/pCep-R cells produced more IL-8 than those expressing the vector control (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	136	001), and lack of CFTR expression in the 16HBE cells expressing cftr antisense was also associated with increased IL-8 expression (P  <  0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Thus cell lines with defective CFTR Cl channel activity, regardless of the nature of the CFTR defect, had increased IL-8 production compared with the corresponding cell line with normal CFTR activity.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	138	View larger version (15K):    Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	139	   IL-8 expression in cells with CFTR Cl channel dysfunction.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	140	 The relative amounts of IL-8 in epithelial cell culture supernatants were detected by ELISA.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	141	 For the purposes of comparison, the amount expressed by each of the control cell lines (16HBE/cftr sense = 21  microg/ microg protein; 9/HTEo/pCep = 3.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	142	75 ng/ microg protein) was considered as 100% (n = 5 experiments).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	143	[Ca2+]i in Cells With ER Overload.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	144	Epithelial cells with mistrafficked CFTR and "ER overload" have been postulated to have increased release of Ca2+ from ER stores as a consequence, a response that could activate Ca2+-dependent kinase activity.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Relative [Ca2+]i was estimated in subconfluent IB3 and C-38 cells loaded with the fluorescent indicator fluo 3-AM (Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	146	 When the populations of the different cell types were compared, there was a consistent trend of increased [Ca2+]i associated with the IB3 cells, with relative basal fluorescence ranging from 0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	147	85 compared with that in the population of C-38 cells, which had basal [Ca2+]i in the range of 0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Comparing the relative fluorescence of 10 individual cells at a single time point (30 s), the IB3 cells had a relative mean fluorescence of 0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Both cell types responded to the addition of P.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	150	 aeruginosa with increased [Ca2+]i.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	151	View larger version (19K):    Fig.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	152	   Relative intracellular Ca2+ concentration ([Ca2+]i) in IB3 and C-38 cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Each tracing represents the relative level of [Ca2+]i in an individual cell normalized to the maximal level obtained after addition of the ionophore.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	154	 The relative response to the addition of 109 colony-forming units/ml of PAO1 is indicated.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	155	 The relative mean [Ca2+]i at 30 s in unstimulated IB3 cells (0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	156	758) was significantly higher than that in C-38 cells (0.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	157	Airway inflammation is a major factor in the pathogenesis of CF pulmonary disease.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Clinical studies have clearly established a direct correlation between infection, IL-8 secretion, and the accumulation of PMNs and their toxic products in the CF lung (14-17).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Bacterial stimulation of cells with CFTR mutations activates significantly greater cytokine expression than matched cells with normal CFTR function (5, 8, 29, 30).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Several reports (8, 28) suggest that cells with CFTR dysfunction have endogenously upregulated expression of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Young infants with CF, even without detectable evidence of prior infection, have PMNs and increased amounts of IL-8 in their airways (14), and proinflammatory cytokine expression is increased in cells cultured directly from uninfected CF tissues (28).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	162	 These findings are consistent with the in vitro studies demonstrating endogenous activation of NF-B in CF but not in corrected cell lines.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	163	 As indicated by the data in this report, lack of CFTR Cl channel function and the physiological consequences of mistrafficked mutant CFTR both appear to contribute to the endogenous activation of NF-B in CF airway cells, which is manifested by the increased expression of IL-8 in these cells, even in the absence of bacterial stimulation.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	164	There is evidence of endogenous activation of NF-B in cells with CFTR dysfunction due to several different mechanisms.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	165	 In previous studies, IB3 cells, which express the W1282X/F508 mutation associated with mistrafficked CFTR that accumulates in the ER, were found to have significant amounts of the p65 component of NF-B in nuclei under basal conditions in which there was no nuclear NF-B in the corrected C-38 cells (8).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Because the translocation of NF-B can be associated with many types of stimuli, additional consequences of accumulated mutant CFTR in the ER were also demonstrated in the mutant cell line.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The IB3 cells were found to have higher basal [Ca2+]i, a predicted consequence of "ER stress" (2, 18).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	168	 The presence of nuclear NF-B in the IB3 cells could be correlated with increased IL-8 expression as estimated by RT-PCR compared with that in the control C-38 cell line.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The concentration of IL-8 in the tissue culture supernatant was minimal in these cells after an 18-h incubation in serum-free medium; however, the relative amount of IL-8 message was consistent with a previous report by DiMango et al.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Not all investigators have found increased endogenous levels of IL-8 associated with CFTR mutations (30).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Cell culture conditions, effects of FCS, and handling of the monolayers all can affect the translocation of NF-B and endogenous expression of IL-8.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Thus it seems relevant to demonstrate that the presence of nuclear p65 appears to be associated with the expected biological response, namely IL-8 expression.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	173	The activation of other NF-B-dependent pathways is not necessarily increased in IB3 compared with C-38 cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Stimulation of NF-B translocation is associated with an antiapoptotic effect in many cell lines including respiratory epithelial cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Rates of apoptosis can be increased by proteasome inhibitors that inhibit IB degradation and block NF-B translocation (31).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	176	 In a study published recently (23), the rates of IB3 and C-38 cell apoptosis were equivalent both under control conditions and after bacterial stimulation despite the observed differences in endogenous nuclear NF-B.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Thus the association between CFTR dysfunction, activation of NF-B, and transcription of NF-B-dependent genes is somewhat selective and is not a global response.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	178	The consequences of CFTR mistrafficking and the activation of NF-B were further demonstrated in CHO cells that do not normally express CFTR.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	179	 The presence of the mistrafficked mutant F508 CFTR was a significant stimulus for NF-B activation in CHO cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	180	 The G551D CFTR, which does not function appropriately as a Cl channel but is trafficked normally to the apical surface of the respiratory epithelial cell (10), did not stimulate NF-B.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Expression of normal CFTR from the same plasmid construct did not cause NF-B activation in CHO cells nor did transfection with the empty vector or the luciferase reporter construct.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Although both the G551D and F508 CFTR mutations are associated with clinical disease and lack of Cl secretion in response to cAMP (10), the major difference between these mutants is the mistrafficking and accumulation of F508 CFTR within the ER.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Thus it appears that the consequences of mistrafficking of F508 are sufficient to activate NF-B in CHO cells.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	184	In epithelial cells, unlike CHO cells, there appears to be a requirement for normal CFTR function in regulating NF-B-dependent gene transcription.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	185	 The homozygous F508 or the compound F508/W1282X mutation could activate NF-B by two independent mechanisms: cell stress associated with mistrafficking or effects directly due to lack of CFTR Cl channel activity.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Cell lines that lack CFTR Cl function due to either the overproduction of the CFTR R-domain or the expression of CFTR antisense had activated NF-B and significant amounts of endogenous IL-8 production compared with the corresponding control cell lines.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The amount of IL-8 endogenously expressed by these cell lines was greater than that of the IB3 or C38 cells and could be quantified by a standard ELISA assay.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The presence of the p65 component of NF-B in nuclei of undisturbed cells grown on coverslips as well as the relative activation of an NF-B reporter construct compared with appropriate controls indicates that their activated state is unlikely to be an artifact of either cell transformation or manipulations occurring during cell culture.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Because neither the 9/HTEo/pCep-R or the 16HBE/cftr antisense cells have excessive CFTR accumulation in the ER, the lack of CFTR Cl channel function in these epithelial cells appears to be responsible for the observed increase in NF-B activation and IL-8 expression.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	190	Exactly how CFTR dysfunction contributes to the activation and nuclear localization of NF-B is unclear.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	191	 There are multiple mechanisms for NF-B activation that can be divided into signal-dependent and signal-independent pathways (20).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	192	 In airway epithelial cells, bacterial attachment to asialo-GM1 activates a Ca2+-dependent signaling pathway that results in NF-B activation and IL-8 transcription through a cascade that includes phosphorylation of both the p38 and extracellular signal-regulated kinase families of mitogen-activated protein kinases (23a).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	193	 A signal-independent pathway, perhaps involving IB or NF-B regulation directly, may be affected by mistrafficked CFTR.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	194	 IB- has been shown to be increased in IB3 cells under basal conditions and is hypophosphorylated, enabling nuclear NF-B with bound IB- complexes to direct transcription (30).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Hypophosphorylated IB- may be involved in either signal-dependent or the persistent activation of NF-B (26).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Diminished levels of cytosolic IB- was associated with CF (F508/F508) bronchial gland cells in primary culture and correlated with the presence of nuclear NF-B Rel A (27).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	197	 It is possible that CFTR function, perhaps by affecting pH in specific intracellular compartments (3), affects relevant kinase or phosphatase activity.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	198	 Abnormalities in signal transducer and activator of transduction-1 phosphorylation in the same 9/HTEo/pCep-R cells have been described recently (13), indicating that CFTR may have a role in multiple signaling pathways.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	199	 These observations reflect the complexities of CFTR involvement in the normal physiology of the epithelial cell.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Strategies such as gene therapy to correct CFTR Cl channel function alone, which do not ameliorate the effects of mutant CFTR mistrafficking in the majority of airway epithelial cells, may not be sufficient to control the inflammatory component of CF lung disease.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	201	These consequences of CFTR dysfunction in activating translocation of NF-B and stimulating the expression of proinflammatory cytokines are important in not only understanding the many roles of CFTR in normal cell physiology but are also clinically relevant.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	202	 The majority of CF patients with the most common F508 CFTR alleles have multiple reasons for increased expression of inflammatory mediators in their airways.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	203	 The effects of CFTR mistrafficking and ER stress, lack of CFTR Cl channel function, and exogenous stimulation due to airway infection all act to increase epithelial NF-B translocation and the expression of proinflammatory genes.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	204	 This epithelial immune activation does provide multiple targets for therapy.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	205	 It may be possible to devise a therapy to modulate the endogenous upregulation of NF-B-dependent gene transcription without compromising the epithelial barrier function or the host inflammatory response to exogenous airway pathogens.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	206	Expert technical assistance was provided by Robert Adamo.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	207	This work was supported by National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute Grants HL-56194 (to A.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Prince) and P50-HL-60293 (to P.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Davis, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH).
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Imaging studies were performed in the Optical Microscopy Facility of the Herbert Irving Cancer Center at Columbia University (New York, NY), supported by National Center for Research Resources Grant 1-S10-RR-10506.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	211	Original submission in response to a special call for papers on "CFTR Trafficking and Signaling in Respiratory Epithelium.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	212	Address for reprint requests and other correspondence: A.
0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	213	, New York, NY 10032 (E-mail: asp7{at}columbia.

0.49234396.11404248.html.plaintext.txt	310	00 Copyright   2001 the American Physiological Society.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	0	SPECIAL TOPIC CFTR trafficking and signaling in respiratory epithelium Bruce R.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Environmental and Occupational Health, Graduate School of Public Health, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15238.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	2	RESEARCH IN CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF) remains at the leading edge of investigations employing human genetics and molecular and cellular biology.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	3	 In the 12 years since the discovery of the gene encoding the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) Cl channel (14), translation of such efforts clinically has been remarkable and includes 1) identification of almost 1,000 different mutations (http://www.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	4	ca/cftr), including 70% with a phenylalanine deletion (F508) that has led to successful clinical detection of individuals with a family history (even before the completion of the human genome project) and 2) ~20 trials of human CF gene therapy involving dosing to the nose or airways (2, 22).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	5	 Such rapid progress, however, belies the complexity of the CFTR gene and the pathophysiology of CF.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	6	CFTR is a unique member of the ATP-binding cassette transporter gene family in that it 1) conducts Cl, 2) transports substrates across membranes in a nonconductive fashion (e.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	7	, facilitates ATP release), 3) regulates other ion channel proteins (e.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	8	, positive regulation of outwardly rectifying Cl channels or negative regulation of Na+ channels), and 4) regulates intracellular compartment acidification and protein processing (18).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	9	 Such complexity has led these authors to categorize defects in CF respiratory epithelium as primary (dehydration associated with dysfunctional Cl transport), secondary (hyperabsorption of Na+), or tertiary (enhanced binding of Pseudomonas aeruginosa; proinflammatory environment).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Fundamental to such diversity is the awareness that very minor mutations (e.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	11	, F508, a single-amino acid deletion within a 1,480-amino acid protein) result in the profound pathological phenotype of CF (23).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	12	 In the case of F508, the missense mutation results in a mutant CFTR that is believed to fold improperly, and such defects in its biosynthesis and trafficking result in little or no surface CFTR.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Other mutations in CFTR lead to genotypic or phenotypic changes that span the range from no CFTR in the membrane to CFTR that reaches the membrane but does not respond to appropriate stimuli or conduct Cl (6).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Adding to this complexity is a recent report describing tissue-specific changes in the impairment of F508 processing (10).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Some mutations overlap with PDZ-interacting domains on the COOH terminus of CFTR that are required for polarization of CFTR to the apical membrane of respiratory epithelium (13) and may underscore CFTR regulation of other ion channels by affecting the relationship between accessory proteins, linker proteins, and regulatory cofactors.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	16	Accordingly, research into the biosynthesis and trafficking of wild-type and mutated CFTR is at the forefront of CF investigations.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Although the defect in Cl conductance is critical to the pathology of CF respiratory epithelia, contributions of alterations in vesicle trafficking, protein processing, and immune function clearly contribute to the pathogenesis and maintenance of CF (18).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	18	 These efforts underlie the disparities between genotype and phenotype in CF and suggest that in addition to nucleotide repair (gene therapy, aminoglycoside-dependent restoration of readthrough of full-length CFTR), pharmacotherapy targeted toward improved biosynthesis of mutated CFTR may be a useful adjunct approach to the treatment of CF (24).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	19	The importance of providing mechanistic support for pharmacologically affecting the maturation of CF is placed in the context of our current molecular physiological understanding of the roles of various chaperones for CFTR by Brodsky (4) in this issue of the American Journal of Physiology-Lung Cellular and Molecular Physiology.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	20	 The steps in proper folding of CFTR, quality control mechanism of endoplasmic reticulum trafficking, and requisite association with various chaperones are outlined by Brodsky and reference is made to three original articles in the Special Topic.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	21	 The mechanisms by which sodium 4-phenylbutyrate may be a modulator of such chaperones are presented by Rubenstein and Lyons (17) and Choo-Kang and Zeitlin (5), and the in vivo efficacy of a chemical chaperone, trimethylamine oxide, in the restoration of defective Cl conductance in the critical target tissue (intestinal epithelium) of CFTR null mutant mice is presented by Fischer et al.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	22	 This collective work strongly supports the concept that small molecules are useful alternative or adjunct therapies for disorders of protein folding (23, 24).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	23	A critical aspect of CF is chronic airway inflammation, and several groups have provided support that dysregulation of the inflammatory response is an intrinsic component of such a phenotype.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	24	 An editorial by Blackwell et al.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	25	 (1) accompanies the manuscript by Weber et al.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	26	 (21) and highlights the central role of unregulated nuclear factor (NF)-B in the proinflammatory cytokine profile of cells expressing mutated CFTR.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In this regard, blocking the production of NF-B may be an alternative rational therapeutic approach in CF therapy.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In addition to enhanced cytokine (interleukin-8, tumor necrosis factor-) production, oxidative stress appears to be a component of CF epithelia.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Previous in vitro work (9, 11) showed that CFTR is associated with the transport of glutathione (GSH).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	30	 In the current Special Topic, Gao et al.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	31	 (8) show that the Cl channel-forming peptide N-K4-M2GlyR increased Cl secretion and GSH efflux in a human CF airway epithelial cell line, suggesting that apical Cl conductance (but not necessarily CFTR function per se) is coupled to GSH efflux.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	32	 (20) report in this issue that GSH was decreased in the epithelial lining fluid of CFTR-deficient mice and that an imbalance in antioxidant defense in CFTR-deficient mice was evident.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	33	 These data extend previous observations that GSH was decreased in the airway fluid of humans with CFTR (16) and that aerosol delivery of GSH may be a useful therapy for CF (15).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	34	 GSH and other cellular defense mechanisms may indeed represent a rational therapeutic strategy in CF.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	35	As noted above, Na+ hyperabsorption is a critical secondary-like phenomenon in CF epithelia.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Although the mechanism coupling such hyperabsorption to CFTR mutations remains unknown, an extracellular serine protease-mediated signaling pathway has been identified (19) that activates an amiloride-sensitive Na+ channel.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	37	 In the Special Topic in this issue, Bridges et al.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	38	 (3) show that human bronchial epithelial cells are sensitive to aprotinin.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Using the Kunitz domain of aprotinin as a pharmacophore, they show that BAY 39-9437, a recombinant Kunitz-type serine protease inhibitor, decreased Na+ absorption in non-CF and CF human bronchial epithelia.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	40	This is the first of a series of special topics that will appear routinely in the American Journal of Physiology-Lung Cellular and Molecular Physiology.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	41	 The purpose of these special calls is to highlight areas of significant interest in respiratory biology by soliciting input from a broad research community, fast tracking the submitted manuscripts through the review process, and publishing them under their own separate heading.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	42	 In this case, a call for papers in "CFTR Trafficking and Signaling in Respiratory Epithelium" initially appeared in July 2000 (12).
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	43	 This led to the seven manuscripts and two accompanying editorials that appear in the current issue.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	44	 This remarkable and timely turnaround in peer review is a testimony to the importance of the topic and the enthusiasm of the authors and reviewers to bring this information to our readership.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	45	This special topic section is a collection of papers accepted under a special call for manuscripts by the Editor.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	46	 See Journal web site for information about the next call.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	47	Address for reprint requests and other correspondence: B.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	48	 of Environmental and Occupational Health, Graduate School Public Health, Univ.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	49	 of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA 15238 (E-mail: brucep+{at}pitt.

0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	84	   Moyer, BD, Denton J, Karlson KH, Reynolds D, Wang S, Mickle JE, Milewski M, Cutting GR, Guggino WB, Li M, and Stanton BA.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	85	 A PDZ-interacting domain in CFTR is an apical membrane polarization signal.
0.49680814.11404239.html.plaintext.txt	86	 J Clin Invest 104: 1353-1361, 1999[Abstract/Free Full Text].
