0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	0	Rme-1 regulates the recycling of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator John A.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Picciano,1 Nadia Ameen,1,2 Barth D.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	2	1Cystic Fibrosis Research Centre, Department of Cell Biology and Physiology, 2Children's Hospital, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261; and 3Department of Molecular Biology and Biochemistry Rutgers, Piscataway, New Jersey 08854.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	3	Submitted 9 April 2003 ; accepted in final form 18 June 2003.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	4	cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; Rme-1; endocytosis; recycling; channel.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	5	CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF), a common lethal genetic disease of Caucasians, results from mutations in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), a member of the ABC superfamily of transport proteins (28).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	6	 CFTR is a cAMP-activated anion channel and channel regulator that functions at the apical membrane of polarized epithelia to regulate secretion in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts (37).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Previous studies have shown that CFTR is not a stable component of the plasma membrane but is rather efficiently endocytosed from the cell surface (18, 27, 35) through clathrin-coated pits (4, 5).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Furthermore, such entry of CFTR into the clathrin-dependent endocytic pathway is mediated by binding of a tyrosine-based endocytic motif in the carboxyl terminus of CFTR (27, 35) to the medium subunit of the AP2 clathrin adaptor complex (36).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	9	 In addition to endocytic motifs, CFTR also interacts with PDZ-domain containing proteins (29, 32) and AMP kinase (10) at its carboxyl terminus and syntax-ins at its amino terminus (24, 25).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	10	 How all these interactions modulate cell surface expression of CFTR is not clear (2, 22), although morphological, biochemical, and functional data indicate that CFTR is present in cell surface and intracellular compartments in both heterologous expression systems and epithelial cells that natively express CFTR (1, 3, 33).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Although much is now known about the mechanisms of CFTR internalization, the fate of internalized CFTR is less well documented.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Previous studies have suggested that internalized CFTR is recycled (31), but the pathway and compartments through which CFTR traverses to undergo recycling are not known.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	13	Endocytosed material is directed initially to a sorting endosomal compartment from which it is directed to one of two destinations.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Some molecules such as the low-density lipoprotein (LDL) are retained in the sorting endosome, which matures into and/or fuses with late endosomes (6).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Molecules that are destined to be recycled back to the cell surface are initially targeted to the endosomal recycling compartment (ERC) (9, 23).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	16	 While the ERC has been extensively characterized on the basis of studies of transferrin receptor recycling (39) and insulin-regulated recycling of GLUT-4 (14), there are no data concerning the entry of ion channels, such as CFTR, into this compartment for recycling back to the cell surface.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Rme-1 is an epsin homology (EH) domain containing protein (8) recently identified as a key element in controlling exit from the ERC (15).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	18	 A dominant negative Rme-1 (Rme-1 G429R), when expressed in mammalian cells, has no effect on the endocytosis of integral membrane proteins such as the transferrin receptor but dramatically inhibits the recycling of the transferrin receptor back to the cell surface, trapping the receptor in the ERC (15).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Endocytosed proteins such as LDL, which are targeted to lysosomes and do not enter the ERC, are unaffected.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	20	 We examined the fate of endocytosed CFTR by using dominant negative Rme-1 as a tool for probing transport of CFTR through the ERC.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Isogenic 293 cells stably expressing wild-type CFTR were generated as previously described (30) and maintained in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS and hygromycin (150  microg/ml).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	22	 Two-hundred ninety-three cells expressing CFTR were transfected transiently by LipofectAMINE (GIBCO BRL) at 60% confluence and analyzed after 48-72 h.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	23	 TRvb1, a Chinese hamster ovarian (CHO) cell line that fails to express transferrin receptors, was generously provided by Dr.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Tim McGraw (Cornell University, Ithaca, NY) (20).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	25	 TRvb1 cells were transiently transfected with a transferrin receptor/CFTR chimera using LipofectAMINE (GIBCO BRL) and 24 h later with G429R green fluorescent protein (GFP)-tagged Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Experiments were performed 48 h later.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	27	 To monitor recycling of CFTR, we used a modified cell surface biotinylation assay (7, 31, 34).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Briefly, plasma membranes were biotinylated at 4 degrees C using a cleavable reagent (Sulpho-NHS-SS-biotin; Pierce, Rockford, IL) and then warmed up to 37 degrees C to load endocytic vesicles with biotinylated proteins (including CFTR).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Remaining cell surface biotin was removed using MESNA as previously described (34).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Subsequently, the cells were either lysed or rewarmed to 37 degrees C to allow internalized biotinylated CFTR to recycle to the cell surface.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	31	 The cells were again cooled to 4 degrees C, the disulphide bonds on recycled cell surface proteins were reduced with MESNA, and the cells were lysed.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Biotinylated proteins were isolated by streptavidin-agarose beads, eluted into SDS sample buffer, and resolved on a 7.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Biotinylated CFTR was detected by Western blot analysis as described above.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	34	Fluorescent labeling and indirect immunofluorescence.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	35	 CFTR-expressing 293 cells were grown on polylysine-coated glass coverslips.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Two to three days posttransfection with or without GFP-tagged dominant negative Rme-1, cells were rinsed in ice-cold PBS supplemented with 2 mM CaCl2 and 1 mM MgCl2 (PBS-CM).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	37	 Cells were fixed in 2% paraformalde-hyde/0.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	38	1% Triton X-100 and exposed to antibodies against CFTR (M3A7 and L12B4; Upstate Waltham).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Antibody binding was visualized by using Cy3-conjugated goat anti-mouse secondary antibodies (Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Antibodies against Rme were a generous gift from Dr.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Robinson (University of Cambridge, Cambridge, UK).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	42	 To label cells with transferrin, cells were incubated with 10  microg/ml Cy3-transferrin.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	43	 DiLDL (LDL labeled with 3,3'-dioctadecyclindocarbocyanine) was from Molecular Probes.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Confocal images were obtained on a Zeiss 510 META confocal scanning microscope.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	45	 Staining for CFTR was performed essentially as described (1).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Briefly, 293 cells were fixed in 2% paraformaldehyde in PBS for 2 h at room temperature, pelleted, and then embedded in 3% liquid gelatin and placed on ice for 10 min.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	47	1 M PBS overnight at 4 degrees C.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	48	 The pellet was frozen onto ultracryotome stubs under liquid nitrogen and stored in liquid nitrogen until use.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Ultra thin sections (70-100 nm) were cut by using a Reichert Ultracut U ultramicrotome with a FC4S cryoattachment.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Sections were picked up onto a drop of 2.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	51	3 M sucrose and mounted on Formvar-coated copper grids.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Briefly, sections were washed with PBS and then with nonspecific binding blocked with PBS containing 0.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	53	5% bovine serum albumin (BSA) and 0.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	54	15% glycine (in PBS containing 0.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	55	5% BSA), followed by a 30-min incubation with 5% normal goat serum.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Sections were incubated in primary antibodies (1:50) for 1 h and labeled with colloidal gold (1:25) at room temperature for 1 h (Amersham, Piscataway, NJ).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	57	 Sections were washed in PBS containing 0.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	58	5% BSA and PBS and fixed with 2.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Sections were post-stained in 4% uranyl acetate and embedded in 1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Labeling was observed on a JEOL JEM 1210 electron microscope (Peabody) at 80 kV.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Cells were washed with ice-cold PBS and lysed in TGH buffer (1% vol/vol Triton X-100, 10% vol/vol glycerol, 25 mM HEPES-Na [pH 7.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	62	4]) containing protease inhibitors (Complete EDTA-free protease inhibitors; Roche) for 20 min on ice.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Nuclei and unbroken cells were removed by centrifugation (at 15,000 g for 5 min at 4 degrees C).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Soluble proteins were resolved on a 7.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	65	5% SDS-PAGE gel and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	66	 After block, membranes were probed with antibodies (CFTR; M3A7 Upstate, transferrin receptor; BD Pharmingen) and visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence (Pico West) as described (36).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	67	Immunomagnetic isolation of CFTR containing vesicles.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	68	 CFTR-expressing 293 cells transfected with G429R Rme-1 were washed in PBS and homogenized by passing the cells 20 times through a 25-gauge needle in buffer (250 mM sucrose containing 50 mM Na-HEPES [pH 7.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Postnuclear supernatants were obtained by centrifugation and incubated overnight at 4 degrees C with 1  microg/ml each of M3A7 and LB12B4 anti-CFTR antibodies.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Washed paramagnetic beads (25  microl) coated with sheep anti-mouse antibodies (Dynal Biotech) were added for a further 90-min incubation at 4 degrees C.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Vesicles were washed and isolated using standard magnetic separation protocols and subjected to immunoblot analysis by using antibodies described in the text.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	72	View larger version (13K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	73	 Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) undergoes constitutive endocytosis and recycling.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Endocytosis (A) and recycling (B) of CFTR were monitored as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Results are expressed as means  plus or minus  SE of at least 3 separate experiments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	76	Rme-1 identifies a recycling compartment in 293 cells.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	77	 To characterize further the endocytic recycling of CFTR, we investigated whether internalized CFTR entered compartments whose turnover was regulated by Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Anti-Rme-1 antibodies labeled three structures within CFTR expressing 293 cells (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	79	 2a)-a compartment within the perinuclear region, intracellular vesicles, and the plasma membrane (see Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	80	 2a, inset), consistent with the localization of Rme-1 in CHO cells (15).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	81	 There was no colocalization of Rme-1 with endoplasmic reticulum markers (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	82	 2, a-c), lysosomal markers (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	83	 2, g-i), early endosome markers (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	84	 A minor component of apparent overlap was observed with Golgi compartments (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	85	 However, the signals were largely separable, and minor overlap probably represents a lack of special resolution of the optical slice.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	86	View larger version (84K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	87	 Distribution of endogenous Rme-1 in 293 cells.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Cells were fixed and stained with polyclonal antibodies against Rme-1 (followed by secondary antibodies conjugated to Alexa 488) and monoclonal antibodies against endoplasmic reticulum (ER) markers (Bip) (a-c), Golgi markers (Golgin 97) (d-f), lysosomal markers (Lamp-1) (g-i), and early endosome markers (EEA1) (j-l) (followed by secondary antibodies conjugated to Cy3).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Mitochondria were initially labeled in live cells using Mito-tracker (Molecular Probes), followed by fixation and staining for Rme-1 (m-o).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	90	Expression of G429R Rme-1 slows transferrin recycling.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	91	 To confirm that G429R Rme-1 inhibited exit from endosomal recycling compartments in 293 cells, we transiently expressed GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 in cells stably expressing wild-type CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Endosomal recycling compartments were identified by incubating cells for 60 min at 37 degrees C in the continued presence of Cy3-labeled transferrin.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	93	 3a), transferrin-positive compartments were seen as discrete perinuclear vesicles throughout the cytoplasm of the cell.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	94	 When experiments were performed using cells transiently transfected with G429R Rme-1, transferrin was observed in large perinuclear compartments (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Such compartments colocalized with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	96	 3, c and d), consistent with the effects of G429R Rme-1 on affecting exit but not entry into the ERC.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Nontransfected cells incubated under similar conditions with DiLDL showed uptake of labeled LDL into large cytoplasmic vesicles (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	98	 3e), presumably late endosomes/lysosomes.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Transient expression of G429R Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	100	 3, g and h) did not affect the localization of DiLDL (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	101	 3, f and h), which showed little or no colocalization with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	102	 These results are consistent with the premise that G429R Rme-1 has no effect on endocytic uptake nor on traffic to late endosomes/lysosomes but only affects exit from recycling compartments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	103	View larger version (39K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Expression of G429R Rme-1 affects the subcellular localization of transferrin but not low-density lipoprotein (LDL).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Cells stably expressing wild-type Rme-1 were incubated for 1 h in the continued presence of Cy3-labeled transferrin (a) or LDL labeled with 3,3'-dioctadecyclindocarbocyanine (DiLDL) (e).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Expression of G429R Rme-1 caused a redistribution of transferrin to large cytosolic vesicles (b) that colocalized with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 (c).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The merge of the transferrin and G429R signal shows almost complete overlap (d).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Expression of G429R Rme-1 did not affect the delivery of DiLDL to late endosomes and lysosomes (f), and no colocalization between GFP-tagged Rme-1 (g) and DiLDL was seen [as shown by lack of colocalization in the merge (h)].
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	109	CFTR is targeted to Rme-1-positive compartments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Having shown that internalized CFTR recycles efficiently back to the plasma membrane, we determined whether such recycling involved trafficking of CFTR through the ERC in a similar fashion to such molecules as transferrin.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	111	 In untransfected cells, CFTR was seen associated with the plasma membrane (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	112	 4a), consistent with previously published data.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	113	 However, upon expression of G429R Rme-1, plasma membrane-associated staining for CFTR was markedly decreased, with a concomitant increase in intracellular CFTR localization (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Moreover, such intracellular CFTR was found to colocalize mostly with the recycling compartment as determined by colocalization with Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Neighboring cells that failed to take up plasmid for G429R Rme-1 retained cell surface staining for CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	116	View larger version (20K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Expression of G429R Rme-1 affects the cellular localization of CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	118	 CFTR/293 cells were transiently transfected with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	119	 Cells were subsequently fixed and stained for CFTR by using Cy3-conjugated secondary antibodies.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	120	 In untransfected cells (a), CFTR was clearly seen at the plasma membrane.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	121	 In transfected cells (b and d), CFTR moved to an intracellular compartment with completely overlapped with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 (c and d).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	122	 Inset in d shows a higher magnification of the colocalized signal.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	123	To confirm that CFTR was indeed trapped in the ERC in the presence of G429R Rme-1, we performed immunogold electron microscopy on cells expressing CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	124	 Such studies revealed the presence of both transferrin receptor [a marker for the ERC (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	125	 5)] and CFTR within the same vesicle.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	126	 CFTR also colocalized with gold-labeled anti-GFP antibodies (data not shown).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	127	View larger version (154K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Immunogold localization of CFTR to the endosomal recycling compartment (ERC).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Cells expressing CFTR and G429R Rme-1 were fixed and processed for immunogold electron microscopy as described in MATERIALS AND METHODS.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	130	 CFTR (arrows) were identified with 5-nm gold particles and transferrin receptor (arrowhead) with 15-nm gold particles.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	131	To confirm the redistribution of CFTR from a cell surface location to an intracellular compartment, cell surface biotinylation experiments were performed.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	132	 The presence of band C CFTR (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	133	 6, A and B) was seen in untransfected cells, cells transfected with wild-type Rme-1, and cells transfected with G429R Rme-1, arguing against a role for Rme-1 in the biosynthetic pathway.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	134	 While there was a slight reduction in the amount of cell surface CFTR in the presence of wild-type Rme-1, the expression of G429R Rme-1 caused a marked reduction in the amount of cell surface CFTR (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	135	 6, A and B), consistent with a redirection of CFTR to intracellular compartments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	136	 The reduction in cell surface CFTR in the presence of G429R Rme-1 was not due to a global reduction in CFTR expression because the amount of total CFTR in cells expressing G429R Rme-1 was not significantly lower than that in untransfected cells (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	137	View larger version (28K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Expression of Rme-1 (G429R) but not wild-type Rme-1 causes loss of cell surface CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Untransfected CFTR/293 cells, cells transfected with wild-type Rme-1, or G429R Rme-1 were subjected to cell surface biotinylation as described in MATERIALS AND METH-ODS.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	140	 After Streptavidin precipitation, subsequent immunoblot analysis revealed the presence of band C CFTR (A) in untransfected cells and in cells transfected with wild-type Rme-1 but markedly reduced in cells transfected with G429R Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	141	 Shown in B are results of densitometric scans of data shown in A.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Analysis of total cell lysate CFTR in the presence or absence of G429R Rme-1 (C and D) revealed little difference in total CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Results are means  plus or minus  SE of 3 separate experiments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	144	Immunomagnetic isolation of CFTR containing vesicles.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Immunofluorescence microscopy revealed the presence of CFTR trapped in the ERC in the presence of G429R Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	146	 As an alternative strategy to show that G429R Rme-1 causes "trapping" of CFTR in the ERC, vesicles from CFTR/293 cells transfected with G429R Rme-1 were subject to immunomagnetic isolation by using anti-CFTR antibodies (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Because CFTR in ERC should be oriented such that the cytosolic domains of CFTR are facing the outside of the vesicle, we immunoprecipitated CFTR-containing vesicles from cells by using antibodies directed against the amino and carboxyl termini of CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	148	 Immunoblot analysis of such isolated vesicles revealed the presence of band C CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Rme-1 and transferrin receptor were also identified within CFTR-containing vesicles.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	150	 In contrast, markers for early endosomes (EEA1) and lysosomes (Lamp1) showed very little signal.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	151	View larger version (35K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	152	 G429R Rme-1 localizes CFTR to ERC but not early endosomes or lysosomes.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	153	 CFTR-containing vesicles were subjected to immunomagnetic isolation.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	154	 For subsequent immunoblot analysis, the following antibodies were employed.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Robinson), transferrin receptor (TfR 85 kDa; Transduction Labs/BD Pharmingen), CFTR (180 kDa; Upstate Biotech), EEA1(180 kDa), and Lamp-1 (Transduction Labs/BD Pharmingen).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	156	The carboxyl terminal domain of CFTR contains ERC-targeting information.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	157	 To show that CFTR enters the ERC from the clathrin-coated endocytic pathway, we monitored the traffic of internalized CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Because the steady-state level of cell surface CFTR in the presence of G429R Rme-1 is extremely low and there are no high-affinity extracellular antibodies or ligands for CFTR, we decided to utilize a CFTR/transferrin receptor chimera transiently coexpressed with G429R Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	159	 TRVb1 cells lacking endogenous transferrin receptors were transiently transfected with a CFTR transferrin receptor (TfR) chimera in which the cytoplasmic domain of the transferrin receptor was replaced with the carboxyl terminal domain of CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Twenty-four hours after such transfection, some cells were also transfected with G429R Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Traffic of the CFTR/TfR chimera was monitored by using Cy3-conjugated transferrin.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	162	 Cells containing CFTR/TfR (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	163	 8, a and b) or CFTR/TfR and G429R Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	164	 8, c-f) were incubated for 1 h in the continued presence of Cy3 transferrin (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Cy3 transferrin was efficiently taken up in both sets of cells.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	166	 After the hour pulse with labeled transferrin, cells were subject to an hour chase in the absence of labeled transferrin and 100-fold excess of unlabeled transferrin.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Cells expressing CFTR/TfR alone (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	168	 8b) showed loss of cell associated signal because the transferrin was efficiently recycled back to the cell surface and released into the medium.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	169	 In contrast, cells expressing CFTR/TfR and G429R Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	170	 8d) failed to recycle internalized transferrin back to the cell surface.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	171	 The structures within which the transferrin remained colocalized with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 (Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	172	View larger version (58K):    Fig.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The carboxyl terminus of CFTR can target to ERC.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	174	 TRVb1 cells expressing CFTR/TfR chimeras in the presence of wild-type Rme-1 were labeled for 1 h in the presence of Cy3 transferrin (a), followed by a 1-h chase in the presence of 100-fold excess unlabeled transferrin (b).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Similar experiments were performed in cells expressing GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1 for cells incubated for 1 h in the presence of Cy3 transferrin (c), followed by a 1-h chase in the presence of 100-fold excess unlabeled transferrin (d).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	176	 For cells expressing GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1, the corresponding GFP signal is shown in green (e and f).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	177	Although the exit of material from the ERC and its reinsertion into the plasma membrane have been thought to be a constitutive pathway, such traffic nonetheless requires cellular machinery.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	178	 The role of Rme-1 in regulating aspects of the endocytic/recycling pathway has been established by using dominant negative mutants in CHO cells and C.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	179	 While Rme-1 has no effect on initial clathrin-mediated endocytic events, Rme-1 function is necessary for proteins to exit the ERC and travel back to the plasma membrane.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	180	 In contrast, Rme-1 plays no role in the traffic of proteins, such as LDL, to the late endosome/lysosome pathway.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Although there is only one Rme family member in C.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	182	 elegans, there are four related genes in humans (8, 21, 26).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	183	 As yet, the tissue distribution and expression overlap of CFTR with the different Rme-1 genes are not known.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	184	We show that internalized CFTR enters the endocytic recycling compartment on its traffic back to the cell surface in an identical fashion to the well-described marker for endosomal recycling, the transferrin receptor.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Expression of dominant negative Rme-1 has no effect on endocytosis, as shown by uptake of LDL, transferrin, and CFTR/transferrin chimeras, consistent with previously published data (8, 15).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	186	 In contrast to traffic of LDL to late endosomes/lysosomes, which is unaffected by dominant negative Rme-1 and shows no colocalization with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1, transferrin (a marker for the recycling compartment) shows almost complete overlap with GFP-tagged G429R Rme-1.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	187	 CFTR localization in dominant negative Rme-1-expressing cells shows overlap with both transferrin and GFP, arguing that internalized CFTR enters the same recycling compartment that transferrin has access to.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The observation that expression of dominant negative Rme-1 caused a marked redistribution of CFTR away from the plasma membrane to being trapped in the ERC argues for a rapid endocytic rate for CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Indeed, several groups have shown that CFTR is efficiently endocytosed from the cell surface (12, 18, 27, 34).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Moreover, the redistribution of CFTR in the presence of G429R Rme-1 argues that maintenance of steady-state cell surface levels of CFTR is primarily due to recycling of internalized CFTR rather than insertion of newly synthesized CFTR.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	191	 The lack of high-affinity antibodies to extracellular domains of CFTR, and the low level of expression of cell surface CFTR in the presence of G429R Rme-1, precluded monitoring of CFTR from the cell surface to the ERC.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	192	 To confirm that entry of CFTR into the ERC was from the endocytic pathway, we monitored access of transferrin receptor/CFTR chimeras to the ERC.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Transferrin receptor constructs that lack a cytoplasmic tail are internalized inefficiently (13, 27).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	194	 Addition of the carboxyl tail of CFTR to tail-less transferrin receptors restores efficient internalization of the receptor and labeled transferrin reporters (27).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Transfection of cells with transferrin receptor/CFTR chimeras and dominant negative Rme-1 shows that labeled transferrin is trapped within the ERC, arguing that entry into the ERC is from the endocytic rather than the biosynthetic pathway.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	196	 Moreover, it argues that the carboxyl tail of CFTR does not contain any signals that direct traffic of CFTR away from recycling pathways to lysosomal degradative compartments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	197	 While many endocytosed membrane proteins are thought to recycle to the cell surface via a juxtanuclear recycling compartment (23), this is not true for all proteins.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	198	 For example, Kir channels, a potassium channel family involved in regulating membrane excitability (38), do not recycle to the cell surface through Rme-1-regulated compartments (19).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	199	 Thus it is clear that different ion channels can traffic and recycle through diverse compartments.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	200	Many laboratories, both commercial and academic, are currently attempting to acquire pharmacological compounds to increase the efficiency with which mutant CFTR molecules fold, exit the endoplasmic reticulum, and get inserted into the plasma membrane.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	201	 The observation that even wild-type CFTR is rapidly removed from the cell surface argues for the necessity to understand recycling processes with the potential to increase the rate at which CFTR exits the recycling compartment and gets reinserted back into the plasma membrane.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	202	 This is particularly true for F508 CFTR, the most common mutation in CFTR, which even when "corrected" by growth of cells at reduced temperatures has a significantly shorter half-life in the plasma membrane the wild-type CFTR (11).
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	203	 Thus a clear understanding of the molecular events governing the recycling of CFTR will provide inside into ways to augment the overall residence time of pharmacologically corrected mutant CFTR molecules at the cell surface.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	204	   DISCLOSURES   This work was supported by the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation and National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases Grants DK-57583 and P50-DK-56490 (component 2) (to N.

0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	310	 Segregation of transferrin to a mildly acidic (pH 6.
0.5180734.12839834.html.plaintext.txt	311	5) para-Golgi compartment in the recycling pathway.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	0	Modulation of Mature Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Regulator Protein by the PDZ Domain Protein CAL* Jie Cheng, Hua Wang, and William B.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Department of Physiology, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, Maryland 21205.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	2	Received for publication, August 5, 2003 , and in revised form, October 6, 2003.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	3	Misfolded proteins are recognized by ER quality control system and are targeted for degradation in ER-associated degradation (8).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Immature, wild type CFTR is folded inefficiently in the ER with a large fraction degraded before reaching the plasma membrane (9).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	5	 That which is folded efficiently traffics to the Golgi and acquires complex glycosylation characteristic of the mature CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	6	 The most common mutation in CF, F508CFTR, is a misfolded protein and is recognized as such by the ER, translocated to the cytosol, and degraded by the 26 S proteasome (9).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	7	 Thus, the predominant majority of the F508 never matures and traffics to the plasma membrane.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	8	The degradation of mature CFTR is less well understood.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	9	 (10) found that both the lysosome and proteasome are involved.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	10	 They found that lysosomal inhibitors increase the half-life of mature wild type CFTR in baby hamster kidney cells transfected with CFTR and in the endogenous CFTR in Caco-2 and T84 cells.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	11	 Interestingly, C-terminal truncation mutants do not traffic to the lysosome.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Instead, they are degraded in the proteasome (10).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Thus, CFTR appears to enter different degradative pathways depending on signals within its C terminus.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	14	CFTR possesses a type I, C-terminal, PDZ (PSD-95/DLG/ZO-1)-binding motif.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Several PDZ domain proteins known to interact with CFTR include NHE-RF/EBP-50, CAP70, and CAL (CFTR-associated ligand) (11 to 15).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The C-terminal tail of CFTR plays a potential regulatory role in modulating its Cl to  channel activity.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Adding recombinant NHE-RF or CAP70 fusion proteins to the cytoplasmic side of CFTR in vitro increases the activity of CFTR (15, 16).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In addition, NHE-RF anchors CFTR to cytoskeleton stabilizing the cell surface CFTR (13, 17).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	19	 Both NHE-RF and its related protein, E3KARP, link cAMP-dependent protein kinase to CFTR (13, 18).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Moreover, NHE-RF was shown to link 2-adrenergic receptor to CFTR (19).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Formation of such macromolecular complexes facilitates the efficiency of activation CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	22	CAL (also known as PIST (PDZ domain protein interacting specifically with TC10), GOPC (Golgi-associated PDZ and coiled-coil motif containing), and FIG (fused in glioblastoma)) (11, 20 to 22) is a CFTR-interacting PDZ domain protein that associates predominantly with the Golgi apparatus.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Overexpression of CAL reduces CFTR chloride currents in mammalian cells by decreasing the expression of CFTR in the plasma membrane (11).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	24	 This effect of CAL can be overcome by NHE-RF, which restores the plasma membrane expression of CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	25	 CAL favors the retention of CFTR within the cell, whereas NHE-RF favors surface expression by competing with CAL for the binding of CFTR (11).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Interestingly, overexpression of CAL also reduces the amount of CFTR (23).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	27	 These findings point to a role for CAL in the intracellular trafficking of CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Consistent with this notion, CAL interacts with proteins involved in membrane vesicle trafficking such as the SNARE protein, syntaxin 6, and the small GTPase, TC10 (20, 22).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Furthermore, CAL also interacts with and potentially regulates the intracellular trafficking of the Wnt receptors, frizzled 5 and 8, neural members of the epidermal growth factor receptor family, CALEB/NGC (21, 24), and the chloride channel, CLC-3B (23).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	30	Recently, PDZ domain interactions were found to be involved in trafficking of other plasma membrane proteins both to and from the plasma membrane.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	31	 For example, synapse-associated protein 102 is involved in the delivery of N-methyl-D-aspartate receptors to the cell surface (25).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	32	 In addition, NHE-RF regulates 2-adrenergic receptor recycling to plasma membrane (26).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	33	In addition to the PDZ domain, the C-tail of CFTR contains motifs for endocytosis.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	34	 A tyrosine motif at the C terminus of CFTR binds directly with the  micro light chain of the AP2 complex involved in sorting CFTR for endocytosis into clathrin-coated pits (27).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Surface CFTR is endocytosed rapidly.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	36	 For example, within 5 min, 50% CFTR at the plasma membrane is endocytosed via AP2 clathrin-coated pits.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	37	 CFTR contained within endosomes can be either recycled back to the plasma membrane or degraded in the lysosome.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Because surface CFTR has a long half-life (24 to 48h), the majority of CFTR must be recycled back to the cell surface instead of targeted to the lysosome for degradation.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	39	 It is not clear how this process is regulated.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	40	 In this study, we examined the role of CAL on the expression of mature CFTR protein.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	41	 We found that CAL regulates the expression of mature CFTR through mechanisms that are both bafilomycin A1- and dynamin 2-sensitive.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	42	Immunoblotting The cells were harvested and processed as described previously (11).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Briefly, the cells were solubilized in lysis buffer (50 mM NaCl, 150 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	44	4, 1% Nonidet P-40, and complete protease inhibitor; Roche Applied Sciences).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	45	 The cell lysates were spun at 14,000 x g for 15 min at 4  degrees C to pellet insoluble material.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The supernatants were subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blotting followed by ECL (Amersham Biosciences).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	47	 The chemiluminescence signal on the polyvinylidene difluoride membrane was directly captured by FujiFilm LAS-1000 plus system with 1,300,000-pixel cooled CCD camera that has 3.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Quantification was carried out within the linear range using the Image Gauge version 3.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	49	 GFP-CFTR and Dyn2-GFP were detected with polyclonal GFP antibody (1:1000; BD Biosciences, Boston, MA).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	50	 HA-CAL was detected with monoclonal HA antibody (1:2000; Roche Applied Sciences).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	51	 Tubulin was detected with monoclonal tubulin antibody (1: 1000; Sigma).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	52	Surface Biotinylation Surface biotinylation of CFTR at the plasma membrane was described previously (11).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Briefly, the cell surface proteins were labeled with cell-impermeable EZ-LinkTM Sulfo-NHS-SS-Biotin (sulfosuccinimidyl-2-(biotinamido)ethyl-1,3-dithiopropionate; Pierce) at 4  degrees C for 15 min.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	54	 The cell surface proteins were isolated by incubating with immobilized NeutrAvidin beads at 4  degrees C for 2 h (Pierce; catalog number 53151).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	55	 The bound proteins were eluted with 2x Laemmli sample buffer supplemented with 100 mM dithiothreitol at 42  degrees C for 30 min.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	56	 The eluted proteins were subjected to SDS-PAGE and Western blotting followed by ECL (Amersham Biosciences).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	57	 GFP-CFTR was detected with polyclonal GFP antibody (1:1000; BD Biosciences).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	58	Pulse-Chase COS-7 cells were washed twice in methionine/cysteine-free DMEM and then incubated for 30 min in methionine/cysteine free-DMEM.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	59	 The cells were incubated in methionine/cysteine free DMEM containing TRAN-35S-label (250  microCi/ml) for 30 min.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Subsequently, the cells were washed extensively with DMEM containing 10 mM of unlabeled methionine and 10 mM of unlabeled cysteine and chased in this solution for the indicated times.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Radiolabeled CFTR was immunoprecipitated with M3A7 and L12B14 monoclonal antibodies (Upstate, Waltham, MA), separated on 7.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	62	5% SDS-PAGE, dried, and visualized by autoradiography.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The radioactive signal on the dried SDS-PAGE was scanned with a FujiFilm BAS-100 system (FujiFilm).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	64	 Quantification was carried out within the linear range using the Image Gauge version 3.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	65	Confocal Microscopy COS-7 cells were plated on glass coverslips 1 day before transfection.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The cells were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde and permeabilized in 0.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	67	2% Nonidet P-40 1 day post-transfection.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Nonspecific binding sites were blocked with 5% normal goat serum.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The cells were stained with anti-HA monoclonal antibody (1:2000; Roche Applied Sciences) in 5% normal goat serum, washed with 1% bovine serum albumin, and incubated with goat anti-mouse Cy3 secondary antibodies in 1% normal goat serum (1:200; Jackson ImmunoResearch, West Grove, PA).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	70	 The GFP signal was detected by its fluorescence.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	71	 The specimens were mounted and viewed on the UltraVIEW spinning disk confocal microscope (PerkinElmer Life Sciences).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	72	Calculation of Degradation The percentage of bafilomycin A1-sensitive CFTR degradation was calculated as follows: [CFTRbafilomycin A1-treated  to  CFTRuntreated]/CFTRbafilomycin A1-treated x 100%.

0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	75	 We assigned significance at p  <  0.

0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	89	05 versus the cells transfected with 6  microg/dish CAL (n = 3).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	90	  To verify these results further, the effect of CAL on CFTR was investigated in cells stably expressing a low level of CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	91	 This cell line was created by transfecting COS-7 cells with GFP-CFTR, followed by selection and expansion of isolated G418-resistant colonies.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	92	 One resultant clone, 4F2, was obtained that expressed one-tenth of the GFP-CFTR cells transiently transfected with 3  microg of GFP-CFTR/100-mm dish (data not shown).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	93	 In these cells, HA-CAL also reduced the steady state levels of CFTR (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	94	View larger version (25K):    FIG.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Bafilomycin A1 reverses CAL-mediated reduction of CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	96	 A, COS-7 Cells were co-transfected with GFP-CFTR and HA-CAL.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Either the lysosome inhibitor bafilomycin A1 (1  microM) or the proteasome inhibitor MG132 (10  microM) was added 24 h post-transfection.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The cells were lysed, and the proteins were detected by Western blotting as described in the legend to Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	99	 B, the percentage of bafilomycin A1-sensitive CFTR degradation was calculated as the portion of CFTR protected by bafilomycin A1 (see "Experimental Procedures").

0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	105	 D, the percentage of bafilomycin A1-sensitive CFTR degradation in 4F2.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	106	 The data are the means of three experiments.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	107	 The error bars are the standard deviations.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	108	  Is the Degradation of CFTR Influenced by CAL? To investigate the role of the lysosome and the proteasome in CAL-mediated down-regulation of CFTR, we examined the effect of their respective inhibitors.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	109	 2A, treatment with bafilomycin A1, a lysosomal proton pump inhibitor (30), increases steady state protein levels of CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Our data combined with previous findings obtained with other lysosome blocking agents (10, 11) suggest that lysosomal degradation is an important process in regulating mature CFTR abundance.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	111	 Important for this study is that bafilomycin A1 reverses CAL-mediated reduction in mature CFTR (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Fig 2A (first and third lanes) shows the typical effect of CAL on mature CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	113	 In the absence of bafilomycin A1, CAL-transfected cells have significantly less mature CFTR than in cells not transfected with CAL (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Importantly, after 24 to 48 h of bafilomycin A1 treatment, the effect of CAL is significantly reduced (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The effect of bafilomycin is likely underestimated.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Some CAL-induced reduction in mature CFTR was expected to take place prior to the addition of bafilomycin midway, at 24 h posttransfection.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Thus, some CAL-induced reduction in mature CFTR was expected to take place prior to the addition of bafilomycin.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	118	 2B depicts the extent of CFTR bafilomycin A1 sensitivity (see "Experimental Procedures").
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	119	 At 24 to 48 h posttransfection, 27.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	120	85% of CFTR is bafilomycin-sensitive.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	121	 In contrast, in cells transfected with 6  microg of HA-CAL/100-mm dish, 49.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	122	62% of CFTR is bafilomycin-sensitive (p  <  0.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	123	 The reversal of CAL-mediated reduction of mature CFTR by bafilomycin A1 is also reproduced in the stable cell line 4F2 (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	124	 More importantly, transfection of HA-CAL leads to an increase in the extent of bafilomycin A1-sensitive degradation of CFTR (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	125	 These results strongly suggested that CAL plays a key role in regulating the bafilomycin A1-sensitive degradation of CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	126	 On the other hand, treating CAL-transfected cells with the proteasome inhibitor MG132 did not rescue mature GFP-CFTR (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	127	 2A) back to the control levels observed in the absence of CAL.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	128	 In contrast to bafilomycin A1 treatment, in the presence of CAL, MG132 actually reduced levels of mature CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	129	 It has been observed by several investigators that proteasome inhibition does not increase the maturation of CFTR (31, 32).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	130	 MG132 did not increase immature CFTR in the Nonidet P-40 lysates probably because blocking of proteosomal degradation leads to the accumulation of CFTR into a detergent-insoluble polyubiquitinated form of immature CFTR (32).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The failure of MG132 to inhibit CAL reduction of mature CFTR is further evidence that CAL can function downstream of the proteosome and influence the degradation of mature CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	132	What Is the Effect of CAL on CFTR Maturation? The steady state level of mature CFTR is determined by new protein synthesis and the trafficking and maturation of CFTR from ER to Golgi as well as post-Golgi degradation.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	133	 To eliminate the possibility that, in addition to enhancing the degradation of mature CFTR in the lysosome, CAL decreases CFTR synthesis and/or maturation, we examined the synthesis and maturation of CFTR by metabolic labeling and pulse-chase experiments.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	134	 3A, COS-7 cells transfected with GFP-CFTR with or without HA-CAL were metabolically pulse-labeled with [35S]methionine and cysteine for 30 min at 16 h post-transfection.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	135	 The cells were then chased in medium supplemented with unlabeled methionine and cysteine for 1 to 4 h to follow the maturation of CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	136	 3A, band B) is the newly synthesized CFTR in ER that appears first.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Not all newly synthesized CFTR is converted to mature CFTR (band C, upper band); because CFTR folds inefficiently, most of band B is degraded by ER-associated degradation (8).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	138	 3 shows that GFP-CFTR matures similarly whether transfected or not transfected with CAL.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	139	 Therefore, CAL exerts its effects on mature CFTR and does not affect the synthesis and trafficking to Golgi.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	140	 To test this hypothesis directly, the effect of CAL on mature CFTR was examined.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	141	 GFP-CFTR becomes fully mature after chasing for 4 h (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	142	 There is no significant difference in the amount of CFTR in CAL transfected and untransfected cells (40,990  plus or minus  1840 versus 39,284  plus or minus  1464 arbitrary unit/dish, p  >  0.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The mature CFTR was then followed when cells were chased for an additional 16 h.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	144	 3C, there was less 35S-labeled mature CFTR after 16 h in cells transfected with HA-CAL than with those not transfected with HA-CAL, confirming the role of CAL in the degradation of mature CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	145	 On the other hand, if bafilomycin A1 was added at 4 h in the absence of CAL, followed by a 16-h chase, more labeled CFTR remains after 16 h compared with that remaining in the absence of both CAL and bafilomycin A1, suggesting that degradation was inhibited.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Of note is that there is more labeled CFTR remaining in CAL-transfected cells in the presence of bafilomycin than in CAL-transfected cells in the absence of bafilomycin.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Importantly, the fraction of mature CFTR sensitive to bafilomycin A1 is statistically larger in the presence of CAL versus the control (50.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	148	01), indicating that CAL is enhancing the degradation of mature CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	149	 Taken together, these data suggest that CAL does not affect early CFTR biosynthesis in the ER or maturation to mature CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	150	 CAL retains CFTR intracellularly and down-regulates mature CFTR most likely by enhancing its degradation in the post-Golgi compartments.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	151	View larger version (20K):    FIG.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	152	 CAL enhances the degradation of mature CFTR blocked by bafilomycin A1.

0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The error bars are the standard deviations.

0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The error bars are the standard deviations.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	170	  CAL Mediates Mature CFTR through Vesicle Formation Involving Dynamin 2 The large GTPase dynamin 2 controls the pinching of the clathrin-coated endocytic vesicles from the plasma membrane and perhaps the budding of vesicles from the Golgi (33).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	171	 A dominant-negative dynamin 2 (aa), Dyn2K44A, blocks the endocytosis of a wide variety of membrane proteins (34) and is also known to affect the integrity of the Golgi in some cell types (35).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	172	 4 shows the effects of GFP-tagged Dyn2K44A and wild type Dyn2 on CFTR cell surface expression assayed by surface biotinylation.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Dyn2K44A-GFP or Dyn2-GFP were co-transfected with GFP-CFTR either with or without HA-CAL.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	174	 Cell surface CFTR was labeled with cell-impermeable EZ-LinkTM Sulfo-NHS-SS-Biotin at 4  degrees C, isolated with Neutravidin beads, and detected by Western blotting with polyclonal GFP antibodies.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Dyn2-GFP had no effect on cell surface CFTR, whereas Dyn2K44A-GFP increased the cell surface expression of GFP-CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	176	 The increased cell surface expression of mature CFTR by the dynamin mutant is consistent with previous reports that clathrin-coated pits mediate the endocytosis of CFTR (36, 37).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Importantly, Dyn2K44A-GFP inhibits the ability of CAL to reduce surface expression of CFTR, thereby restoring surface expression GFP-CFTR in cells expressing HA-CAL (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	178	View larger version (45K):    FIG.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Dynamin and CAL affect CFTR surface expression.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	180	 A, COS-7 cells were transfected with GFP-CFTR, HA-CAL, and Dyn2-GFP or dominant-negative Dyn2K44A-GFP.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Forty-eight hours post-transfection, the cell surface proteins were labeled with membrane-impermeable Sulfo-NHS-SS-Biotin at 4  degrees C.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	182	 The cell surface proteins were isolated by NeutrAvidin beads, fractionated on SDS-PAGE, and detected by Western blotting using a GFP polyclonal antibody.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	183	 B, averages of three experiments described in A.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	184	 The error bars are the standard deviations.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	185	05 versus the cells transfected with CAL alone.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	186	  Next, we examined whether Dyn2K44A-GFP affects CAL-mediated effects on levels of mature CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	187	 The cells were co-transfected with GFP-CFTR and increasing amounts of HA-CAL in the presence or absence of transfected Dyn2K44A-GFP (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	188	 The dynamin mutant does not significantly affect the levels of mature CFTR arguing against a large effect of the mutant on the maturation of CFTR through the Golgi.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Again, HA-CAL reduces mature GFP-CFTR in a dose-dependent manner.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	190	 Importantly, Dyn2K44A-GFP partially reverses the reduction of mature GFP-CFTR (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	191	 It is not clear whether the incomplete reversal is due to incomplete co-transfection of all three plasmids or whether a portion of the CAL-mediated effect on mature CFTR occurs via a dynamin insensitive pathway.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	192	 However, taken together with the lack of effect of CAL on the maturation of CFTR in Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	193	 3, these data do provide further support for the notion that the degradation of CFTR in post-Golgi compartments is enhanced by CAL causing a down-regulation of mature CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	194	View larger version (35K):    FIG.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Dominant-negative dynamin 2 partially blocks CAL-mediated effects on mature CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	196	 A, COS-7 cells were transfected GFP-CFTR, HA-CAL, and dominant-negative Dyn2K44A-GFP.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	197	 Total mature CFTR was isolated and detected by Western blotting using a GFP polyclonal antibody as described in the legend to Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	198	 B, averages of three experiments described for A.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	199	 The error bars are the standard deviations.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Dyn2K44A-transfected cells do not differ significantly from the untransfected cells.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	201	05 versus the cells transfected with 6  microg of CAL.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	202	05 versus the cells transfected with 9  microg of CAL.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	203	  Dominant-negative Dynamin 2 Redistributes the Subcellular Localization of CAL CAL is predominantly expressed in the Golgi apparatus, particularly at the trans-Golgi network (TGN) (11).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	204	 To further study the subcellular localization of CAL, we examined the effect of dominant-negative dynamin 2 on the subcellular distribution of CAL by confocal microscopy.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	205	 COS-7 cells grown on coverslips were transfected with HA-CAL, Dyn2-GFP, or Dyn2K44A-GFP.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	206	 We have reported previously and others have also shown that CAL is located in the perinuclear region of the cell (11, 20, 21).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	207	 6b shows that Dyn2-GFP is expressed uniformly in COS-7 cells.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	208	 Dyn2K44A-GFP, on the other hand, has a distinctly different punctuate expression pattern (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	209	 6c), consistent with previous report that this mutant blocks clathrin coat-mediated endocytosis and is arrested at the clathrin-coated pits at the plasma membrane (38).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Whereas co-expression of wild type Dyn2 has no effect on the distribution of CAL (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	211	 6, d to f), expression of Dyn2K44A redistributes CAL to the sites that co-localized with Dyn2K44A (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	212	 6 (g to i) transfected only with HA-CAL but not Dyn2K44A-GFP retain typical Golgi localization of CAL.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	213	 These results are significant because they show that CAL traffics from Golgi and is arrested at the cell periphery, where further progression is blocked by Dyn2K44A.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	214	View larger version (70K):    FIG.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	215	 Dynamin 2 dominant-negative mutant redistributes CAL.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	216	 COS-7 cells were singly transfected with HA-CAL (a), wild type Dyn2-GFP (b), or dominant-negative Dyn2K44A-GFP (c) (top row) or doubly transfected with HA-CAL and Dyn2-GFP (d to f; middle row) or HA-CAL and Dyn2K44A-GFP (g to i; bottom row).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	217	 CAL was detected by a monoclonal antibody to HA epitope (red) and Dyn2 were visualized by green fluorescence (green) on confocal microscope.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	218	 CAL is typically expressed in the Golgi apparatus.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	219	 Wild type Dyn2 has no effect on its intracellular localization.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Dyn2K44A redistributes and co-localizes with CAL.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	221	Both intracellular retention and degradation of mature CFTR by CAL contributes to the CAL-mediated down-regulation of CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	222	 To date, no enzymatic activity has been identified in CAL.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	223	 Examining the protein domains and motifs suggests that CAL is a scaffolding protein with multiple protein-binding domains.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Like other scaffolding proteins, CAL operates as an adaptor to couple multiple proteins.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	225	 Other than the PDZ domain that binds to CFTR, the second coiled-coil domain binds to the small GTPase TC10 and the SNARE protein syntaxin 6 (20, 22).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Both TC10 and syntaxin 6 are known to be involved in intracellular trafficking.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	227	 TC10 is a member of the Rho-GTPase family.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	228	 In adipose tissues, TC10 is involved in regulating the trafficking of the insulin-stimulated glucose transporter, GLUT4, to the plasma membrane.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	229	 As an adaptor protein, CAL is likely to link CFTR to the intracellular trafficking processes carried out by TC10 or syntaxin 6 in CFTR-expressing epithelial tissues.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	230	At steady state, CAL is localized to the Golgi complex, particularly in the TGN and cytosol.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	231	 TC10 is localized at the plasma membrane and intracellular vesicles; syntaxin 6 is primarily in Golgi and endosomes.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	232	 CFTR spans all of these compartments.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	233	 For these proteins to work in concert on CFTR, they must physically interact.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	234	 One possibility is that they interact at the interface of their respective compartments.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	235	 Alternatively, one or all of these proteins could cycle among different compartments.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	236	 For example, CAL may traffic from TGN/Golgi to the plasma membrane and then to endosomes and to the lysosome, or it may traffic directly from the TGN to the lysosome.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	237	 6 depicts evidence supporting this notion.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	238	 The data show that expression of a dominant-negative dynamin 2 mutant redistributes CAL to the cell periphery into punctuate structures that co-localize with the mutant dynamin 2.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	239	 In this circumstance CAL is arrested at the sites where dynamin regulates vesicle budding (Fig.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	240	 The dynamin 2 mutant Dyn2K44A is well known to inhibit endocytosis and to affect the Golgi (33, 35).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	241	 The observation that the dynamin 2 mutant Dyn2K44A enhances surface expression of mature CFTR and does not have a large effect on the total amount of mature CFTR supports the notion that the primary effect of Dyn2K44A is post-Golgi.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	242	 Thus, it is likely that CAL can traffic with CFTR past the Golgi and target CFTR for degradation either through endocytosis at the plasma membrane or via direct trafficking from a post-Golgi compartment to the lysosome.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	243	 However, it is important to note that our data do not exclude other ways of regulating mature protein and cell surface expression CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	244	The evidence that CAL is involved in trafficking in tissues other than epithelia was suggested by two recent papers.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	245	 Neuronal CAL contributes to the pathology of Lurcher mice (39).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	246	 Lurcher mutant mice are ataxic because of degeneration of the cortex of the cerebella.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Constitutive activation of the GluRd2Lc receptor causes an inward current and the death of Purkinje cells.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	248	 Neuronal CAL has an additional 8 amino acids at the beginning of the second coiled-coil domain.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	249	 CAL binds to GluRd2 and Beclin1 and links receptor activation to autophagy and cell death (39).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Autophagy involves trafficking membrane compartments to the lysosome for degradation.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	251	 Therefore, CAL maybe involved in lysosomal trafficking in autophagy.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	252	More information on the function of CAL came from knockout mouse experiments (40).
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	253	 In CAL knockout mice, the males are infertile.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	254	 The mature sperm of male mice missing CAL lack acrosome, a specialized lysosomal structure derived from the Golgi that is required for oocyte activation.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	255	 In normal mice, CAL is located in the TGN and TGN-derived vesicles of the round spermatids.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	256	 These data suggest that CAL is involved in acrosome biogenesis, perhaps by facilitating protein cargo transport to this organelle.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	257	New therapies are under development to promote F508 CFTR maturation.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	258	 Interfering with the degradation of F508 CFTR in the post-Golgi compartments may be an attractive method to boost levels of mature CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	259	 Our current study suggests a method to accomplish this by inhibiting the degradation of mature CFTR.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	260	 More importantly, a more specific way of blocking the interaction between CAL and CFTR may potentially allow more CFTR to be trafficked to the plasma membrane.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	261	   FOOTNOTES   * This work was supported by Cystic Fibrosis Foundation Research Development Programs (to W.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	262	) and National Institutes of Health Grants DK-48977 (to W.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	263	 The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	264	 This article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	266	To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	267	: 410-955-7166; Fax: 410-955-0461; E-mail: wguggino{at}bs.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	268	1 The abbreviations used are: CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator; NHE-RF, Na+/H+ exchanger regulatory factor; Dyn2, dynamin 2; GFP, green fluorescent protein; HA, hemagglutinin; ER, endoplasmic reticulum; DMEM, Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium; TGN, trans-Golgi network; SNARE, soluble NSF attachment protein receptors.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	269	   ACKNOWLEDGMENTS   We thank Dr.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	270	 McNiven for dynamin 2 (aa) constructs: Dyn2-GFP and Dyn2K44A-GFP.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	271	 Carolyn Machamer and Laura Roman for helpful discussions.
0.5272462.14570915.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Peying Fong for critical reading of this manuscript.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	0	Evidence That Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER)-associated Degradation of Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator Is Linked to Retrograde Translocation from the ER Membrane* Ximing Xiong, Elaine Chong, and William R.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	1	From the Department of Molecular and Cellular Engineering and Department of Medicine, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania 19104.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	2	The rough endoplasmic reticulum (ER)1 facilitates translocation, membrane integration, folding, and oligomeric assembly of most proteins found in the secretory pathway of eukaryotic cells (1-4).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	3	 The ER also functions to recognize misfolded or unassembled proteins and prevent their exit to the Golgi complex (5-7) through a process termed ER-associated degradation (ERAD) (8).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	4	 Substrates for ERAD, like other secretory and transmembrane proteins, are initially targeted to and translocated across the ER membrane via the Sec61 translocon complex (1, 2).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	5	 However, aberrantly folded proteins are selectively translocated back into the cytosol where they undergo ubiquitination and degradation by cytosolic proteases (9-11).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Certain ERAD substrates such as major histocompatibility complex class I heavy chains (10, 12, 13) and unglycosylated prepro- factor undergo complete retrograde translocation into a soluble, cytosolic form prior to degradation (8).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	7	 In contrast, mutant forms of carboxypeptidase Y and unassembled T cell receptor  subunits translocate back to the cytosol but remain associated with cytoplasmic face of the ER membrane (14, 15).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	8	 In both cases the generation of cytosolic intermediates is thought to occur via retrograde transport through the Sec61 translocon complex (9-11).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	9	The ubiquitin-proteasome pathway is also involved in the ER-associated degradation of polytopic proteins.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	10	 Yeast mutants with defective ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes or proteasome subunits show decreased degradation of mutant forms of Sec61p (16, 17), a resident ER protein with 10 predicted transmembrane segments (18).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	11	 ERAD may also play a role in ensuring proper protein levels in the ER as suggested by mevalonate-mediated regulation of 3-hydroxy-3-methylglutaryl-coenzyme A reductase (19-21).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	12	 For the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), a plasma membrane protein, approximately 80% of wild type protein and 100% of common mutant forms are degraded prior to reaching the Golgi complex (22, 23).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Recent studies have demonstrated that ER-associated degradation of CFTR also requires an intact ubiquitin conjugation pathway and likely involves the 26 S proteasome (24, 25).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	14	 While the underlying reasons for CFTR degradation remain unknown, it has been proposed that the majority of wild type CFTR, like mutant CFTR, is recognized by ER quality control machinery, because it fails to fold properly (26-29).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	15	Degradation of polytopic proteins by cytosolic proteases poses a particular problem in that multiple transmembrane (TM) segments must be removed from the membrane.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	16	 It is unclear whether polytopic proteins, like secretory and bitopic transmembrane proteins, proceed through cytosolic intermediates prior to degradation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	17	 One possibility is that the proteasome might degrade only cytosolic peptide loops, leaving lumenal and/or transmembrane segments to be degraded by other proteases (7, 30).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Alternatively, degradation might be coupled to the process of retrograde translocation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	19	 To distinguish among these possibilities, it will be necessary to define the temporal relationship between recognition, retrograde translocation, and degradation events involved in polytopic protein ER degradation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	20	 In this regard, a cell-free system that reconstitutes ERAD is attractive, because it is readily amenable to physical and pharmacological manipulation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Using such a system, Sato et al.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	22	 (31) recently demonstrated that CFTR could be ubiquitinated cotranslationally, indicating that initial recognition events in ER degradation might occur very early in the lifetime of a polytopic protein.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In the current study we use a similar cell free system to demonstrate that CFTR ubiquitination can also occur after protein synthesis, N-linked glycosylation, and membrane integration have been completed.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	24	 We have also been able to separate the process of ubiquitination from that of degradation and now show that ubiquitinated CFTR remains tightly associated with the ER membrane until it is degraded into trichloroacetic acid-soluble peptide fragments.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	25	 CFTR degradation is therefore physically localized to the ER.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Our results are consistent with a model in which cytosolic degradation machinery is recruited to the ER membrane by polyubiquitinated substrates and suggest that degradation occurs coincident with polypeptide removal from the lipid bilayer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	27	Materials-- ALLN, TPCK, TLCK, hemin, bovine ubiquitin, anti-bovine ubiquitin antibody, and 14C-methylated lysozyme were purchased from Sigma.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	28	 The protease inhibitor mixture, (4-(2-aminoethyl)benzenesulfonyl fluoride, aprotinin, E-64, EDTA, and leupeptin), MG132, lactacystin, and clasto-lactacystin -lactone were purchased from Calbiochem.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Nucleotide triphosphates, creatine phosphate, creatine kinase, and dithiothreitol (DTT) were purchased from Boehringer Mannheim.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Anti-CFTR antisera was raised against synthetic peptides corresponding to residues 45-65 (N terminus), 680-700 (R domain), and 1458-1476 (C terminus) (BAbCo, Berkeley, CA).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	31	 Other regents were purchased from Sigma unless otherwise stated.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	32	Rabbit reticulocyte lysate for translation was prepared from fresh rabbit reticulocytes induced by acetylphenylhydrazine treatment as described previously (32) and stored at 80  degrees C.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Prior to freezing, hemin was added to a final concentration of 40  microM.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	34	 For degradation experiments, RRL was either purchased from Green Hectare Farm (Oregon, WI) or prepared as described previously (32) but without addition of hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	35	 Although degradation efficiency varied between different preparations of RRL, no consistent differences were observed between different RRL sources.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	36	 To prepare ATP-depleted RRL, reticulocytes were washed three times with ice-cold phosphate-buffered saline, resuspended in Krebs-Ringer phosphate medium lacking glucose, and incubated in 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	37	2 mM 2,4-dinitrophenol and 20 mM 2-deoxyglucose at 37  degrees C for 90 min (33).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Reticulocytes were then washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline and lysed by adding 1.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Samples were centrifuged at 15,000 rpm for 30 min (Beckman JA17 rotor), and the supernatant (i.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	40	 RRL) was stored at 80  degrees C.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	41	Methylated ubiquitin was prepared by reductive methylation as described previously (34).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	42	 Bovine ubiquitin was incubated at room temperature for 20 h in 12 mM formaldehyde and 20 mM cyanoborohydride followed by an additional hour in fresh reagents.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	43	 The reaction was dialyzed for 48 h in 10 mM HEPES, 5 mM MgCl2, 3 mM DTT and concentrated to 10 mg/ml using a centricon (number 3) filter.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	44	Cell-free Transcription/Translation-- CFTR mRNA was transcribed in vitro at 40  degrees C for 1 h in reactions containing 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	45	4 mg/ml plasmid DNA (plasmid pSPCFTR(35)), 40 mM Tris (pH 7.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	46	5 mM GpppG (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech), 10 mM DTT, 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	47	75 unit/ml RNase inhibitor (Promega, Madison, WI), and 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	48	4 unit/ml SP6 RNA polymerase (New England Biolabs, Beverly, MA).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Transcript was stored frozen at 80  degrees C.
