0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Translation was performed at 24-25  degrees C for 2 h in a reaction containing 20% transcription mixture, 40% nuclease-treated rabbit reticulocyte lysate, 20% Emix, and a final concentration of 400  microg/ml creatine kinase, 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	51	2  microl of RNAse inhibitor (Promega), 10 mM Tris (pH 7.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	52	5), 100 mM KOAc, 2 mM MgCl2, and 2 mM DTT.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	53	 Emix contains 5 mM ATP, 5 mM GTP, 60 mM creatine phosphate, 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	54	2 mM each of 19 essential amino acids, except methionine, and 5  microCi/ microl of Tran35S-label (ICN Pharmaceuticals, Irvine CA).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Canine pancreas microsomal membranes, prepared as described elsewhere (36), were added at the start of translation to a final concentration of A280 8.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	56	 For all experiments except those in Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	57	 1A, aurin tricarboxylic acid (0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	58	1 mM) was added to the translation mixture after 15 min to synchronize translation and reduce synthesis of partial length chains.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	59	 For membrane pelleting and floatation experiments puromycin HCl (final concentration 1 mM) was added at T = 110 min to ensure that nascent chains were released from ribosomes.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	60	Carbonate Extraction-- Translation products were incubated in 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	61	5) for 30 min on ice as described (37).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Samples were centrifuged at 180,000  x  g for 30 min, and membrane pellets were dissolved directly in SDS loading buffer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	63	 Supernatants were precipitated in 20% trichloroacetic acid, pelleted at 16,000  x  g for 15 min, washed with acetone, and dissolved in SDS loading buffer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	64	Immunoprecipitation-- RRL aliquots were diluted directly into 1 ml of ice-cold Buffer A (0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	65	1 M NaCl, 1% Triton X-100, 2 mM EDTA, 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	66	1 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	67	0)) and preincubated with antisera for 10-30 min prior to addition of 5  microl of protein A Affi-Gel (Bio-Rad).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	68	 CFTR antisera and nonimmune antisera were used at 1:1000 dilution.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Ubiquitin antibody was used at 1:200 dilution (similar amounts of Ig were present in all reactions).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	70	 Samples were mixed at 4  degrees C for 6-10 h, washed three times with Buffer A, twice with 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	71	0), and taken up in SDS loading buffer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	72	Degradation Assay-- The translation mixture was layered onto a 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	73	1 M KCl, 5 mM MgCl2, and 1 mM DTT) and centrifuged at 180,000  x  g for 10 min.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	74	 Membranes were resuspended in ice-cold 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	75	1 M KCl, 5 mM MgCl2, and 1 mM DTT) at one-half the original translation volume.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	76	 The degradation reaction, assembled on ice, included 20% resuspended membranes, 72% reticulocyte lysate, and a final concentration of 10 mM Tris (pH 7.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	77	5), 1 mM ATP, 5 mM MgCl2, 12 mM creatine phosphate, 3 mM DTT, and 80  microg/ml of creatine kinase.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	78	 Where indicated, RRL was replaced with water, and proteasome inhibitors were added.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	79	 For ATP-depleted RRL, ATP and creatine phosphate were omitted.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	80	 The degradation mixture was incubated at 37  degrees C, and aliquots were added directly to loading buffer for SDS-PAGE, EnHance (NEN Life Sceince Products) fluorography and autoradiography.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	81	 Autoradiograms were scanned on an AGFA studioscan II transmission scanner using Adobe Photoshop software.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Quantitation of autoradiograms was performed using an Amersham Pharmacia Biotech DTS scanning densitometer precalibrated with a Kodak photographic step tablet (Eastman Kodak Co.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	83	 Trichloroacetic acid-soluble counts were quantitated by precipitating degradation mixture in 20% trichloroacetic acid, incubating on ice for 30 min, pelleting at 16,000  x  g for 15 min, and counting supernatants in 10 volumes of Ready Safe scintillation fluid (Beckman, Fullerton, CA) in a Beckman LS6500 scintillation counter.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	84	Vesicle Pelleting and Floatation-- Microsomal membranes from translation mixture were pelleted, resuspended, and incubated in ATP- containing RRL in the presence of 40  microM hemin as described above.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	85	 For pelleting experiments, aliquots of this RRL/hemin mixture were taken at specified time points; KCl or Triton X-100 was added as indicated; the mixture was incubated on ice for 30 min and pelleted through 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Equivalent fractions of pellet and supernatant (resuspended directly in SDS loading buffer) were analyzed by SDS-PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	87	 For floatation experiments, aliquots of the RRL/hemin mixture were diluted into 10 volumes of 2.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	88	5), 5 mM MgCl2, 1 mM DTT, or into 2.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	89	 100- microl samples were incubated on ice for 30 min and overlaid with 300  microl of 1.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	90	1 M KCl, 4 mM MgCl2, 10 mM Tris (pH 7.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	91	5), and 1 mM DTT and then overlaid with 200  microl of 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Solutions were centrifuged at 350,000  x  g for 2 h in a TLA 100.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	93	 55- microl aliquots were taken from top to bottom, mixed with 180  microl of 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	94	1 M sucrose buffer, and samples were repelleted at 170,000  x  g for 10 min prior to addition of SDS loading buffer and autoradiography.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	95	In Vitro CFTR Biogenesis-- To examine the steps of CFTR degradation in native ER membranes, we first characterized expression of full-length CFTR protein in a cell-free RRL system.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	96	 Translation of plasmid pSPCFTR (35) in the absence of ER-derived microsomal membranes generated a polypeptide migrating at ~160 kDa (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	97	 This translation product shifted 6 kDa in size when rough microsomes were added at the start of translation, consistent with the addition of two N-linked core carbohydrates at the predicted consensus sites in the fourth extracytoplasmic loop.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	98	 The presence of full-length CFTR was confirmed by immunoprecipitation with peptide-specific antisera raised against N terminus, R domain, and C terminus epitopes.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Carbonate extraction of translation products demonstrated that in vitro synthesized CFTR was fully integrated into the ER membrane.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Thus the RRL system is capable of efficiently reconstituting the early events of CFTR biosynthesis and processing, in agreement with results reported by Sato et al.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	101	 To test the stability of newly synthesized CFTR in the ER membrane, cyclohexamide was added after 2 h of translation, and samples were incubated for an additional 4 h (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	102	 At 24  degrees C, CFTR was remarkably stable, whereas at 37  degrees C CFTR was rapidly converted into a high molecular weight (HMW) complex with an estimated size of  > 450 kDa (T1/2  < 30 min).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	103	 For convenience, this large complex will subsequently be referred to as the HMW complex, and the ~170 kDa band will be referred to as full-length CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	104	View larger version (93K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	105	   Expression of CFTR in rabbit reticulocyte lysate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	106	 A, CFTR cDNA (plasmid pSPCFTR(35)) was translated in a transcription-linked RRL translation system at 24  degrees C for 90 min as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	107	" Canine pancreas microsomal membranes were present during translation in all lanes except lane 1.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Lanes 1, 2, and 7 represent total translation products analyzed by SDS-PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Translation products were immunoprecipitated with nonimmune sera (lane 6) or with peptide-specific antisera raised against the N terminus (lane 3), R domain (lane 4) or C terminus (lane 5) of CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	110	 For carbonate extraction, translation products (lane 7) were incubated at pH 7.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	111	5 (Carb), and supernatant (S) and pellet (P) fractions were analyzed directly.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	112	 B, CFTR translation was carried out as in A except that aurin tricarboxylic acid (0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	113	1 mM) and cyclohexamide were added 15 min and 2 h after the start of translation, respectively.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Following addition of cyclohexamide, aliquots were removed at the specified time points and analyzed directly by SDS-PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	115	ATP-dependent Conversion of CFTR into a HMW Complex-- To determine the requirements for conversion of CFTR into the HMW complex, CFTR was translated in RRL, and microsomal membranes were collected by pelleting through a sucrose cushion (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Microsomes were then resuspended and incubated at 37  degrees C in sucrose buffer containing ATP (lanes 1-5), RRL supplemented with an ATP regeneration system (lanes 6-10), ATP-depleted RRL (lanes 11-15), or ATP-depleted RRL supplemented with additional ATP (lanes 15-20).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	117	 At specified time points samples were analyzed directly by SDS-PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	118	 In the presence of buffer alone, or in ATP-depleted RRL,  > 70% of full-length CFTR remained intact after 4 h of incubation (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	119	 However, when microsomal membranes were incubated in fresh RRL containing ATP, or in ATP-depleted RRL supplemented with additional ATP, full-length CFTR was rapidly converted into the HMW complex (T1/2  <  30 min) that subsequently disappeared over the next 4 h.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	120	 These results are consistent with a two-step process in which full-length CFTR is initially converted into a HMW complex via an ATP-dependent mechanism, and the HMW complex is then a substrate for degradation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	121	View larger version (51K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	122	   In vitro degradation of CFTR via a HMW intermediate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	123	 A, CFTR was translated for 2 h in RRL (as in Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	124	 1B), after which microsomal membranes were pelleted through a 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	125	5 M sucrose cushion and resuspended in 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	126	1 M sucrose buffer as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	127	" Membranes were then incubated at 37  degrees C in buffer (lanes 1-5), RRL containing an ATP regeneration system (lanes 6-10), ATP-depleted RRL (lanes 11-15), or ATP-depleted RRL containing an ATP regeneration system (lanes 16-20).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	128	 At specified time points, aliquots were removed from each tube and analyzed directly by SDS-PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	129	 B, autoradiograms were digitized, and band intensities of full-length CFTR and the HMW complex were quantitated, normalized to the amount of full-length CFTR present at T = 0, and plotted for each time point.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Closed and open symbols represent CFTR and the HMW complex, respectively.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	131	The CFTR HMW Complex Is Polyubiquitinated-- We noted that degradation of the CFTR HMW complex in Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	132	 2 contrasted with results in Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	133	 1B where the complex accumulated over time.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	134	 One difference between these two experiments is that CFTR translation is performed in the presence of hemin, a required co-factor for protein expression in RRL (38), and aurin tricarboxylic acid, an inhibitor of protein synthesis initiation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Both of these compounds inhibit ATP-dependent degradation of ubiquitinated substrates in RRL.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	136	 These results, together with the requirement for ATP and cytosol, suggested that the HMW complex might represent polyubiquitinated CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	137	 Microsomal membranes containing newly synthesized CFTR were therefore incubated in fresh RRL supplemented with bovine ubiquitin and 40  microM hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Aliquots were then immunoprecipitated with anti-bovine ubiquitin antisera and analyzed by SDS-PAGE at specified time points.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	139	 3A, the HMW complex, but not full-length CFTR, was reactive against anti-ubiquitin antisera (lanes 11-15).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	140	 No reactivity was observed when immunoprecipitation was performed with nonimmune sera (NIS, lanes 6-10) or when bovine ubiquitin was omitted from the lysate (data not shown).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	141	 To further confirm CFTR ubiquitination, microsomes containing newly synthesized CFTR were incubated in RRL in the presence of methylated ubiquitin, which blocks the sequential addition of ubiquitin molecules by preventing isopeptide bond formation at ubiquitin residue Lys-48.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	142	 Under these conditions we observed a dose-dependent inhibition in the rate of HMW complex formation (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	143	 Taken together, these data demonstrate that the sequential, covalent addition of multiple ubiquitin molecules contributes to the formation of the CFTR HMW complex.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	144	View larger version (91K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	145	   In vitro ubiquitination of CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	146	 Microsomal membranes containing newly synthesized CFTR were resuspended in 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	147	1 M sucrose buffer and incubated at 37  degrees C in RRL containing 40  microM hemin and 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	148	4 mg/ml of bovine ubiquitin (A) or methylated ubiquitin (B).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	149	 At times indicated, samples were immunoprecipitated with nonimmune sera (NIS; A, lanes 6-10), anti-ubiquitin antisera (A, lanes 11-15), or analyzed directly (A, lanes 1-5 and B, all lanes).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	150	Inhibition of CFTR HMW Complex Degradation by Proteasome Inhibitors-- We next examined the ability of protease inhibitors to influence the disappearance of the CFTR HMW complex.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	151	 Inhibitors of serine, cysteine, and metalloproteases had essentially no effect on the rate of disappearance of either full-length CFTR or the HMW complex (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	152	 In contrast, hemin and MG132, both known inhibitors of the proteasome, resulted in significant delay in the disappearance of the HMW complex particularly at early time points (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	153	 Quantitation of autoradiograms revealed that hemin effectively blocked 60% of HMW complex degradation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	154	 In contrast, MG132, ALLN, and TPCK slowed but did not prevent HMW complex disappearance.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Surprisingly, little inhibition was observed for lactacystin or TLCK.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	156	 These results suggested either that certain proteasome inhibitors might be relatively inactive in the RRL system, or alternatively, that degradation of ubiquitinated CFTR might involve additional protease activities.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	157	 To distinguish between these possibilities, we therefore examined the effect of proteasome inhibitors on the degradation of methylated lysozyme, a known substrate of the 26 S proteasome.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	158	 For these and subsequent experiments the rate and extent of protein degradation was quantitated by measuring the conversion of CFTR and/or lysozyme into trichloroacetic acid-soluble peptide fragments.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	159	View larger version (66K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	160	   Effect of protease inhibitors on CFTR degradation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Microsomal membranes containing newly synthesized CFTR were collected and incubated in RRL in the presence of a protease inhibitor mixture consisting of 500  microM 4-(2-aminoethyl)benzenesulfonyl fluoride, 150 nM aprotinin, 1  microM E-64, 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	162	5 mM EDTA and 1  microM leupeptin (A) or in individual proteasome inhibitors at the indicated concentrations (B).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	163	 At each time point, aliquots were mixed directly with SDS loading buffer and analyzed by PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	164	 C, CFTR and the HMW complex were quantitated at each time point by densitometry, normalized to the amount of CFTR present at T = 0, and plotted as a function of time.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Data shown are representative of results from multiple experiments.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	166	 5, 26% of [14C]lysozyme and 65% of newly synthesized CFTR were degraded into trichloroacetic acid-soluble peptide fragments within 3 h in RRL.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	167	 Lysozyme degradation was inhibited by approximately 90% in the presence of 40  microM hemin or 10 mM EDTA consistent with previous studies (39).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Hemin also resulted in formation of a HMW complex containing [14C]lysozyme (data not shown).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	169	 In contrast, the specific proteasome inhibitor lactacystin, as well as its active metabolite clasto-lactacystin -lactone, had little effect on lysozyme degradation ( < 10% inhibition).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Under these same conditions CFTR degradation was inhibited by approximately 80% in the presence of EDTA or the ATP hydrolyzing enzyme, apyrase.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Hemin inhibited CFTR degradation by 56%, while lactacystin and clasto-lactacystin -lactone inhibited CFTR degradation by only 20 and 35%, respectively.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	172	 In these latter experiments, lactacystin-based inhibitors were preincubated with RRL for 30-60 min prior to addition of CFTR-containing microsomal membranes.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	173	 These experiments demonstrate that specific lactacystin-based proteasome inhibitors are relatively inactive at blocking degradation of these ubiquitinated substrates in RRL.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	174	 It should also be noted that a significant amount of CFTR degradation in RRL (35-40%) appears to proceed through a hemin insensitive pathway distinct from that utilized by lysozyme.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	175	View larger version (22K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	176	   Degradation of lysozyme and CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Degradation mixtures were assembled as described in the legend to Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	178	 2 and added to resuspended microsomal membranes containing CFTR or [14C]lysozyme (0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Hemin (40  microM), EDTA (10 mM), or apyrase (0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	180	1 unit/ microl) was added at T = 0 as indicated.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Lactacystin (100  microM) or clasto-lactacystin -lactone (100  microM) were preincubated with RRL for 30-60 min prior to assembling the reaction.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Aliquots were precipitated in 20% trichloroacetic acid, and soluble counts were calculated by the following formula: % counts released = (Cn  C0)/(T  C0), where Cn = soluble counts at each time point, C0 = soluble counts at T = 0, and T = total counts per aliquot.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	183	 Results represent the average ( plus or minus S.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	184	) of two to six separate experiments.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	185	Ubiquitinated CFTR Remains Tightly Associated with the ER Membrane-- Sixty-five percent of in vitro synthesized CFTR protein was degraded to trichloroacetic acid-soluble fragments within 3 h of incubation in RRL (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Degradation could not be restricted solely to large cytosolic peptide loops (i.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	187	 N terminus, nucleotide binding domains, and the R-domain), as these loops contain only 47% of total methionine residues (40).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Rather, our data indicate that proteolytic machinery also gains access to small cytosolic loops and possibly lumenal and/or transmembrane regions of the protein.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Thus prior to or coincident with degradation, some or all of CFTR is likely to be extracted from the membrane.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	190	 We therefore tested whether the ubiquitinated HMW complex, which has already been targeted for degradation by ubiquitin-conjugating enzymes, might undergo retrograde translocation to a cytosolic intermediate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	191	 Ubiquitinated CFTR complexes were generated by incubation in RRL (in the presence of hemin), and vesicles were collected by pelleting through a sucrose cushion.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	192	 6A, both CFTR and the CFTR HMW complex were nearly quantitatively recovered in the microsome pellet in the absence of detergent.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	193	 In addition, preincubation of CFTR-containing microsomes in high salt (up to 1.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	194	1 M KCl) failed to extract full-length CFTR or the HMW complex into the supernatant fraction (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Thus ubiquitinated CFTR does not behave as a cytosolic or peripheral membrane protein.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	196	View larger version (74K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	197	 CFTR-containing microsomes were incubated in RRL in the presence of hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	198	 A, at times specified, aliquots were analyzed directly (lanes 1-4), pelleted through 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	199	5 M sucrose buffer (lanes 5-9), or incubated on ice in 1% Triton X-100 for 30 min prior to pelleting (lanes 10-14).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	200	 Pellets were dissolved directly into SDS loading buffer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	201	 B, aliquots of RRL degradation mixture were taken at specified times and analyzed directly in SDS loading buffer (lanes 1-3) or incubated for 30 min on ice following addition of KCl to the final concentrations indicated (lanes 4-21).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	202	 Samples were then pelleted through 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	203	5 M sucrose buffer, and equal fractions of pellet and supernatant were analyzed by SDS-PAGE.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	204	 6 do not rule out the possibility that HMW ubiquitinated CFTR might also be pelleted as a large, detergent-sensitive protein complex.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	205	 We therefore tested whether the HMW complex was physically associated with the ER by membrane floatation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	206	 Aliquots of RRL containing newly synthesized CFTR and/or polyubiquitinated CFTR were diluted into 2 M sucrose, layered beneath a discontinuous sucrose gradient, and centrifuged for 2 h as described under "Experimental Procedures" (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	207	 For half of the samples, ribosomes were first stripped from membranes by incubation in KCl/EDTA (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	208	 The secretory protein bovine prolactin (41) was used as a standard to determine the location of microsomal membranes in the gradient.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	209	 Both full-length CFTR and the polyubiquitinated complex exhibited the same floatation pattern as the secretory control.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	210	 Thus in the absence of degradation, CFTR remained membrane-associated long after ubiquitination had occurred.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	211	 Following ribosome stripping with EDTA/KCl microsomes more uniformly partitioned into the lighter fractions.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	212	 However ribosome removal had no detectable effect on dislocation of ubiquitinated CFTR from the ER membrane.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	213	View larger version (41K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	214	 Microsomal membranes containing newly synthesized CFTR or bovine prolactin were incubated at 37  degrees C in RRL degradation mixture for 0, 20, or 120 min in the presence of hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	215	 A, samples were mixed to a final concentration of 2 M sucrose, layered beneath a discontinuous sucrose gradient, and centrifuged at 350,000  x  g for 2 h as described under "Experimental Procedures.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	216	6 M) were added prior to centrifugation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	217	 Aliquots were taken from top to bottom of the gradient (lanes 1-10, respectively).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	218	 The HMW complex, CFTR, and prolactin control are indicated.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	219	Degradation of Membrane-bound, Ubiquitinated CFTR-- To test whether membrane-bound CFTR remained a substrate for degradation and not simply a protease resistant aggregate, CFTR-containing microsomes were incubated in RRL in the presence of hemin to allow accumulation of the ubiquitinated intermediate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	220	 Vesicles were isolated at sequential time points, reincubated in the presence or absence of fresh RRL, and degradation of CFTR was monitored by release of trichloroacetic acid-soluble counts.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	221	 8A, 70% of total CFTR was degraded into trichloroacetic acid soluble counts following 3 h incubation in ATP-containing RRL.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	222	 When vesicles were collected after 20 min of preincubation in hemin-containing RRL and resuspended in fresh RRL lacking hemin, 56% of the total CFTR was subsequently degraded.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	223	 This degradation remained sensitive to both hemin and EDTA.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	224	 Incubation of CFTR in hemin-containing RRL for longer periods of time (i.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	225	 1-2 h) resulted in the near complete conversion (~90%) of full-length protein into the HMW complex as in prior experiments (data not shown).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Even after 2 h of preincubation, 57% of total CFTR protein was still able to be degraded upon removal of hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	227	 In each of these experiments, the degradation of polyubiquitinated CFTR was thus 80% as efficient as the degradation of newly synthesized protein.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	228	 Furthermore, with longer preincubation times the reversible component of CFTR degradation became progressively more sensitive to inhibition such that after 2 h of preincubation, hemin and EDTA each blocked degradation of polyubiquitinated CFTR by approximately 90%.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	229	 When microsomes containing pre-ubiquitinated CFTR were similarly resuspended and incubated in the presence of buffer alone (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	230	 8B), no degradation of the HMW polyubiquitinated CFTR was observed.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	231	View larger version (16K):    Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	232	   Degradation of preubiquitinated CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	233	 CFTR-containing microsomal membranes were incubated in RRL in the presence of hemin as indicated.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	234	 A, at each time point, samples were pelleted through 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	235	5 M sucrose buffer and resuspended in fresh RRL in the presence or absence of hemin or EDTA.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	236	 Aliquots were precipitated in 20% trichloroacetic acid at the indicated times, and percent soluble counts released was determined by scintillation counting.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	237	 B, samples were pelleted through 0.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	238	5 M sucrose buffer in the presence or absence of 1 mM ATP and resuspended in 10 mM Tris, 5 mM MgCl2, 3 mM DTT, and 80  microg/ml creatine kinase, with or without 1 mM ATP/12 mM creatine phosphate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	239	 Time scale for each graph is based on T = 0 for the starting RRL degradation mixture.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	240	 For T = 20, 60, and 120 min graphs, the base line soluble counts reflect the percent of counts released from RRL in the presence of hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	241	 Total trichloroacetic acid-soluble counts plotted therefore represent the counts released during initial incubation plus the counts released following resuspension and reincubation of microsomes.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	242	Together these results demonstrate that: (i) the inhibitory effects of hemin on CFTR degradation are reversible, (ii) most, but not all, of the membrane-bound ubiquitinated CFTR remains a substrate for degradation, (iii) CFTR degradation, like ubiquitination, requires the presence of both ATP and cytosolic factors, and (iv) degradation is physically localized to the ER membrane and likely occurs coincident with removal of at least a portion of CFTR from the lipid bilayer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	243	The ER is a primary site of cellular quality control involved in the recognition and disposal of misfolded and unassembled proteins (5).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	244	 While it was initially proposed that ER proteases were responsible for degrading ER substrates, recent evidence indicates that ERAD is mediated largely by cytosolic proteases including the 26 S proteasome (6, 7).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	245	 This topologic disparity between substrate and degradation machinery has resulted in a reevaluation of protein movement into and out of the ER compartment (6).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	246	 It now appears that translocation across the ER membrane is a bidirectional process that is regulated, in part, by the folded state of a given protein substrate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	247	 Whereas, nascent secretory and transmembrane proteins are targeted to, translocated across, and/or integrated into the ER membrane by ER translocation machinery (2, 42), proteins that fail to fold properly may also be recognized by ER quality control machinery and transported out of the ER and back to the cytosol (6, 9, 10, 15).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	248	 These observations have raised important questions regarding the process of retrograde transport across the ER membrane.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	249	 At what stage of biogenesis are protein substrates identified? How do recognition events target proteins back to the translocon and/or facilitate movement into the cytosol? And how is this retrograde transport coupled to the process of degradation? In the current study, we address these issues by developing an in vitro system that reconstitutes de novo synthesis and ER-associated degradation of the polytopic protein CFTR.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	250	 Full-length, glycosylated and membrane-integrated CFTR was a substrate for ATP-dependent ubiquitination.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	251	 In addition, polyubiquitinated CFTR remained tightly associated with the ER membrane until it was degraded into trichloroacetic acid-soluble peptide fragments.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	252	 Thus ubiquitination precedes retrograde translocation, and degradation of polytopic proteins such as CFTR is physically localized to the ER membrane rather than the cytosol as proposed for some secretory and transmembrane substrates (8, 10, 13).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	253	Our results are consistent with a model in which CFTR degradation is tightly coupled to removal of the polypeptide from the lipid bilayer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	254	 At least 65% of [35S]methionine-labeled CFTR was degraded into trichloroacetic acid-soluble fragments, consistent with proteasomal degradation in which the resulting polypeptides are 6-9 residues in length (43).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	255	 Because a small fraction of full-length CFTR (approximately 10-15%) remained intact in nearly all experiments, the extent of degradation for individual CFTR polypeptides actually approached 80%.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	256	 Thus CFTR degradation could not be limited to large cytosolic regions containing the N terminus, nucleotide binding domains, and R domain, which together comprise 61% of the total mass but only 47% of methionine residues (40).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	257	 If all cytosolic loops within 8-15 residues from the membrane were cleaved, then degradation of all full-length CFTR polypeptide chains would liberate only 60% total CFTR methionine into the trichloroacetic acid-soluble fraction (40).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	258	 It therefore seems likely that proteolytic machinery such as the proteasome might participate in removal of CFTR from the lipid bilayer to gain access to transmembrane segments and/or lumenal peptide regions.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	259	 This possibility is supported by the observation that: (i) proteasome-like particles are physically localized to the cytosolic surface of the ER membrane (44) and (ii) our results that CFTR degradation occurs via a membrane-bound, rather than cytosolic, intermediate.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	260	 If retrograde translocation of CFTR occurred through the Sec61 translocon, then extraction from the lipid bilayer could potentially involve the reverse process of membrane integration, namely lateral movement of TM segments from the membrane back into the translocation channel and into the cytosol (45, 46).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	261	While this study provides additional support that the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway is involved in ER-associated degradation of CFTR, it is unclear why different proteasome inhibitors exhibited different effects on CFTR degradation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	262	 Lactacystin and clasto-lactacystin -lactone, which covalently inactivate the active site threonine residue on the 5 subunit of the 20 S proteasome (subunit X of the mammalian proteasome) (47, 48), had relatively minor effects on CFTR degradation as determined either by disappearance of the CFTR HMW complex (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	263	 4) or generation of trichloroacetic acid-soluble fragments (Fig.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	264	 It is interesting that clasto-lactacystin -lactone, the active form of lactacystin, is inactivated by glutathione in cells (49, 50).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	265	 Our observation that neither lactacystin nor its -lactone form inhibited the degradation of lysozyme, a known proteasome substrate, suggests that RRL is capable of rendering these agents inactive, even when preincubated in the absence of exogenous reducing agents.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	266	 We do not know why the results reported here differ from those of Qu et al.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	267	 (51) that demonstrated 20  microM lactacystin inhibited the degradation of both 1-antitrypsin and lysozyme in a similar RRL system.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	268	 However, our results were consistent for two different preparations of lactacystin and at multiple inhibitor concentrations up to 100  microM.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	269	 It is possible that these differences reflect varying amounts of proteasome in different RRL preparations.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	270	The most potent inhibitors of CFTR degradation were EDTA, apyrase, and hemin.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	271	 EDTA and hemin have been shown previously to inhibit the degradation of other proteasome substrates in RRL by stabilizing HMW ubiquitin conjugates (39, 52, 53).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	272	 Hemin, a heme precursor, exerts pleiotropic effects in RRL.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	273	 Its stimulatory effect on protein translation (38) is proposed to be mediated by inactivation of the translation factor eif-2, possibly by inhibiting an endogenous RRL kinase (54, 55).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	274	 In addition, hemin directly inhibits ATPase activities of the purified 19 S proteasome regulatory complex (PA700) as well as the 26 S proteasome itself (56).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	275	 Because the catalytic core of the 20 S proteasome cannot accommodate folded or ubiquitinated polypeptides, it has been proposed that ATPases contained within the 19 S regulatory subunit are required for substrate unfolding as well as deubiquitination (43, 48, 56-59).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	276	 It is therefore likely that hemin inhibits proteasome-mediated CFTR degradation by blocking ATPase activity and thereby preventing CFTR unfolding and/or deubiquitination.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	277	 If CFTR unfolding were required for removal from the bilayer, such a mechanism would explain the accumulation of membrane-bound, polyubiquitinated CFTR observed in the current study.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	278	Our results do not rule out the possibility that additional peptidase activities either in the ER lumen or within the membrane also participate in CFTR degradation as has been suggested previously (25, 60).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	279	 One such candidate is signal peptidase complex, an ER-localized protease that is capable of cleaving transmembrane proteins (61) and free signal peptides (30) at sites located within the plane of the lipid bilayer.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	280	 Interestingly, CFTR contains cryptic signal peptidase cleavage sites within or adjacent to TM segments of the N terminus hydrophobic domain (62, 63).
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	281	 If similar proteases facilitated CFTR degradation, then TM segments and small peptide loops could potentially be released from the membrane.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	282	 Such a mechanism might explain why a significant amount of CFTR degradation was ATP-independent and hemin insensitive.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	283	 It is also possible that the membrane-bound HMW complex might actually consist of polyubiquitinated CFTR cleavage products that are then degraded by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	284	 Marks and members of the Skach laboratory for their helpful comments.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	285	* This work was supported by Grants GM53457 and DK51818 from the National Institutes of Health and by the North American Cystic Fibrosis Foundation.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	286	The costs of publication of this article were defrayed in part by the payment of page charges.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	287	 The article must therefore be hereby marked "advertisement" in accordance with 18 U.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	288	 Section 1734 solely to indicate this fact.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	289	To whom correspondence should be addressed.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	290	 Present address: Division of Molecular Medicine, 3181 SW Sam Jackson Park Rd.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	291	, NRC-3, Oregon Health Sciences University, Portland, OR 97201.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	292	: 503-494-7322; Fax: 503-494-7368; E-mail: skachw{at}ohsu.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	293	The abbreviations used are: ER, endoplasmic reticulum; ERAD, ER associated degradation; CFTR, cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; DTT, dithiothreitol; HMW, high molecular weight; RRL, rabbit reticulocyte lysate; ALLN, N-acetyl-L-leucyl-L-leucinyl-norleucinal; TPCK, N-tosyl-L-phenylalanine chloromethyl ketone; TLCK, N-tosyl lysyl chloromethyl ketone; TM, transmembrane; PAGE, polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	294	 Skach, unpublished observations.
0.54181886.9915789.html.plaintext.txt	295	Copyright   1999 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	0	Cystic fibrosis, gene therapy, and lung inflammation: for better or worse? Lisa M.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Physiology and Biophysics, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, Alabama 35294-0005.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	2	THE STUDY by van Heeckeren and colleagues, one of the current articles in focus (Ref.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	3	 L717 in this issue), addresses the question of whether adenoviral delivery of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) to the cystic fibrosis airways attenuates inflammation and mortality associated with a chronic bacterial infection.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	4	 This is an intriguing question because adenoviral vectors themselves can invoke a substantial immune response that prohibits their repeated administration to the lung (2).
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	5	 In their article, van Heeckeren and coworkers report that, within the infected cystic fibrosis lung, CFTR expression and/or adenoviral vector-induced inflammation yields a significant survival advantage.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	6	 This promising observation may have profound implications for the utility of adenoviral vectors in the gene therapy treatment of cystic fibrosis.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	7	CFTR mutations and cystic fibrosis lung pathophysiology.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Cystic fibrosis is the most common autosomal recessive disorder in the Caucasian population, with a frequency of 1 in 2,500 live births.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	9	 It is caused by defective function of the cftr gene product (14), which encodes a 170- to 180-kDa protein that functions as a cAMP-regulated chloride channel.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	10	 The CFTR protein is expressed normally in those tissues affected in cystic fibrosis, including airway submucosal glands and airway epithelial cells.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The cystic fibrosis respiratory disease phenotype includes thick mucus secretion and bacterial colonization of the lung with a select few bacterial pathogens, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa (13).
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	12	 aeruginosa infections compounded by an inability to clear this organism result in a profound neutrophil migration into the airways and secretion of a variety of inflammatory mediators, including neutrophil elastase, reactive oxygen species, and inflammatory cytokines, which cause irreversible damage to the airways and gas-exchange components.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	13	Cystic fibrosis and adenoviral vector-mediated gene therapy.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	14	 Correction of the defective cftr gene in vivo has long been the holy grail of the cystic fibrosis research community.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	15	 The use of adenoviral vectors in this pursuit has been problematic (reviewed in Ref.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	16	 In early clinical trials, the administration of adenoviral vectors encoding CFTR demonstrated great promise, with transient correction of chloride transport defects.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Subsequent studies, however, failed to repeat this initial finding and, moreover, revealed that adenoviral vector-mediated delivery of CFTR to the cystic fibrosis airways was limited by the local immune response associated with multiple vector administrations.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Similarly, van Heeckeren and colleagues (19) reported previously that P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	19	 aeruginosa-induced bronchopulmonary inflammation also limited the efficacy of adenoviral vector-mediated gene transfer.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Despite this limitation, several studies suggest that the extent of CFTR correction required for a normal lung phenotype may be quite low (2), thereby validating the use of adenoviral vectors in cystic fibrosis gene therapy.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	21	Until the current study by van Heeckeren et al.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	22	 (20), the impact of adenoviral vector-mediated gene therapy had not been examined in the context of a cystic fibrosis lung chronically infected with bacteria (19).
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	23	 In this ambitious study by van Heeckeren and coworkers (20), the authors determined whether CFTR delivery improved the outcome of a cystic fibrosis murine model infected with P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Specifically, the authors reported that gut-corrected cystic fibrosis mice treated with an adenoviral vector encoding CFTR and inoculated with P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	25	 aeruginosa-laden agarose beads exhibited a significantly greater cumulative 10-day survival compared with sucrose controls; survival of empty vector controls, however, was not significantly different.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Importantly, these authors observed that there were no differences between mice receiving the CFTR vector or controls with regard to the extent of lung inflammation.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	27	 From these data, the authors concluded that the observed survival advantage in mice receiving adenoviral delivery of CFTR to the cystic fibrosis lung may be due to CFTR expression and/or proinflammatory effects of the adenoviral vector.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	28	 adenoviral vector-induced inflammation.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	29	 Because cumulative 10-day survival was not significantly different between mice receiving CFTR-encoding vectors vs.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	30	 empty vector controls, it is likely that CFTR expression plays a small role in this response.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	31	 As the authors note (20), it is possible that the administration of an adenoviral vector may have induced a protective immune response that improved cumulative survival.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	32	 In support of this possibility, the authors observed a persistent lung lymphocytosis in response to adenoviral vector administration; this response was further enhanced upon challenge with P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	33	 aeruginosa-laden agarose beads.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Interestingly, the authors did not observe increased bacterial killing in mice treated with either the CFTR-encoding adenoviral vector or the empty vector control.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	35	Early studies by Markham and coworkers (8, 12) suggest that T cell-mediated immune responses are protective against P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	36	 For example, these authors have shown that adoptive transfer of T cells from mice immunized with P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	37	 aeruginosa to granulocytopenic mice resulted in nearly 100% survival upon challenge with P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	38	 Similar findings have been reported by others (3).
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Despite these reports, the exact nature of T cell-mediated immunity in P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	40	 aeruginosa infections remains unclear.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Hoiby and colleagues have reported that, in a rat model of P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	42	 aeruginosa pnuemonia (4) and in cystic fibrosis patients (11), chronic P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	43	 aeruginosa infection induces a T helper type 2 (Th2)-like response.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Th2 responses are characterized by the production of IL-4 and IL-5 and are important in the generation of humoral immunity.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	45	 These results are further supported by their observation that chronic P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	46	 aeruginosa lung infection is more severe in a Th2 responding mouse strain (BALB/c) (10).
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	47	 With regard to protective T cell immunity, Hoiby and coworkers (4, 5, 9) have demonstrated that induction of a Th1-dominated cytokine response improves the outcome of chronic P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	48	 Th1 responses are characterized by the production of IFN- and are instrumental in the generation of cell-mediated immunity.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Interestingly, previous studies have shown that adenoviral vector administration can trigger a Th1 response in the lungs of mice (18, 21) and humans (1).
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	50	 In light of these findings, it is tempting to conclude that the improved cumulative survival observed in the van Heeckeren study (20) is a function of an adenovirus-induced Th1 response; however, this conclusion may be too simplistic.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	51	Several recent studies call into question the beneficial nature of a Th1 response in P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Reports examining the role of the virulence factor alginate (17) and the quorum-sensing molecule N-(3-oxododecanoyl)homoserine lactone (16) in P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	53	 aeruginosa pathogenicity indicate that each of these factors induces a Th1-predominated immune response that may contribute to P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Moreover, Schultz and colleagues (15) have reported recently that, in a rat model of P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	55	 aeruginosa pneumonia, endogenous IFN- impairs bacterial clearance and host defense.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Clearly, differences in the strain of P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	57	 mucoid), type of infection (acute vs.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	58	 chronic), route of administration, and model system of analysis must be taken into account when considering the role of Th1/Th2 responses in P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	59	Despite the ongoing debate of T cell responses in P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	60	 aeruginosa infections, it should be noted that these studies were performed in non-cystic fibrosis model systems.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Because recent evidence indicates that T cell responses may be dysregulated in cystic fibrosis (6, 7), such studies need to be performed in the context of the cystic fibrosis lung.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	62	 This is underscored by the van Heeckeren study (20), which suggests that adenoviral vector-induced inflammation may promote survival of cystic fibrosis mice during a chronic P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	63	 As with all well-conceived studies, this study precipitates a number of unanswered questions.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	64	 For example, in the absence of P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	65	 aeruginosa infection, does the nature of the inflammatory response differ between mice receiving an adenoviral vector encoding CFTR vs.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	66	 empty vector controls? Does CFTR play a role in the T cell immune responses triggered by P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	67	 aeruginosa infection? How does the hyperimmune response of the cystic fibrosis lung contribute to adenoviral vector- or P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	68	 aeruginosa-mediated inflammation? Future studies examining immune responses triggered upon adenoviral vector administration of the P.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	69	 aeruginosa-infected cystic fibrosis airways should provide new and important information regarding the utility of adenoviral vectors in cystic fibrosis-related gene therapy.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	70	This work was supported by a grant from the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (to L.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	71	   FOOTNOTES   Address for reprint requests and other correspondence: L.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	72	 of Physiology and Biophysics, Univ.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	73	 of Alabama at Birmingham, MCLM 966, 1918 Univ.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	74	, Birmingham, AL 35294-0005 (E-mail: lschwieb{at}uab.
0.563135.15003935.html.plaintext.txt	75	HOME HELP FEEDBACK SUBSCRIPTIONS ARCHIVE SEARCH TABLE OF CONTENTS Visit Other APS Journals Online Copyright   2004 by the American Physiological Society.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	0	THEMES Genetic Disorders of Membrane TransportII.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	1	 Regulation of CFTR by small molecules including HCO3* Beate Illek1,2, Horst Fischer1, and Terry E.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	2	1 Children's Hospital Oakland Research Institute, Oakland 94609; and 2 Department of Molecular and Cell Biology, University of California, Berkeley, California 94720.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	3	Cystic fibrosis (CF) affects a number of epithelial tissues, including those in the gastrointestinal tract.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	4	 The goal of this review is to summarize data related to regulation of the protein product of the CF gene, CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR), by a variety of small molecules.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	5	 There has been a surge of interest in discovering small molecules that could be exogenously added to cells and tissues to regulate CFTR and could potentially be used alone or in combination with genetic approaches for therapy in CF.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	6	 We will discuss the apparent mechanisms of action of genistein, milrinone, 8-cyclopentyl-1,3-dipropylxanthine, IBMX, and NS-004; several of which appear to interact directly with one or both nucleotide binding domains of CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	7	 We also discuss how HCO3 interacts with CFTR as both a permeating anion and a potential regulator of Cl permeation through the CFTR ion channel.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	8	 It is likely that there are complicated interactions between Cl and HCO3 in the secretion of both ions through the CFTR and the anion exchanger in intestinal cells, and these may yield a role of CFTR in regulation of intestinal HCO3 secretion as well as of intra- and extracellular pH.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	9	cystic fibrosis; cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; pharmacology; epithelial transport; chloride secretion.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	10	CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF) is the most common fatal genetic disease of the Caucasian population, with an incidence of 1 in 2,500 live births and a carrier frequency of ~1 in 25.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	11	 The disease is caused by mutations in the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) (30), which functions as a cAMP-activated Cl channel.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	12	 At the cellular level, CFTR dysfunction results in defective cAMP-regulated Cl conductance, primarily in cells of epithelial origin (27).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Although lung disease is the primary cause of mortality in CF patients, a significant proportion of the morbidity can be directly attributed to gastrointestinal complications.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	14	 The duodenum, jejunum, ileum, and colon express high levels of CFTR mRNA (30).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	15	 Immunocytochemical analysis also demonstrated high CFTR protein expression at the luminal surfaces along the intestine (7).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	16	 The small intestine of CF patients exhibits decreased Cl and fluid secretion that results in meconium ileus (lower water content and higher viscosity compared with non-CF patients) in ~10% of all CF newborns and accumulation of mucus and intestinal obstructions [primarily in ileocecum and large intestine in  > 20% of adult patients (see Ref.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Intestinal pathophysiology appears to be the hallmark of recently developed transgenic CF mouse models.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	18	 The ileocecum and large intestine appear to be the most common sites of intestinal blockade, whereas jejunal obstructions occur less frequently (13).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	19	Thus CFTR plays an important role in intestinal secretion.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	20	 This secretion is controlled by multiple hormones and nerve cell transmitters, which will couple to the activation of CFTR as well as the other ion channels and transporters that are required to generate transepithelial secretion.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Phosphorylation of CFTR by protein kinases (PK) and dephosphorylation by protein phosphatases (PP) is considered the major way by which CFTR Cl channel activity is physiologically regulated.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	22	 In addition, the normal gating cycle (both opening and closing) of CFTR requires ATP binding and hydrolysis at the two nucleotide binding domains (NBDs) of CFTR (see Ref.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	23	 ATP concentration is likely maintained constant in cells and is therefore not a significant physiological regulator.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	24	In addition to phosphorylation/dephosphorylation and ATP binding and hydrolysis, investigators have searched for exogenous compounds that are potential therapeutic activators of the mutant CFTR protein found in CF patients.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Figure 1 shows the chemical structures of several such small molecules that will be discussed in this review.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Some of these small molecules appear to bind directly to one or both of the NBDs of CFTR and, if CFTR has been prephosphorylated, increase the open probability of the channel.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	27	 In the first portion of this review, PHARMACOLOGICAL REGULATION OF CFTR BY SMALL MOLECULES, we will discuss work showing that genistein, 8-cyclopentyl-1,3-dipropylxanthine (DPCPX), IBMX and other xanthines, and NS-004 all seem to operate this way.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	28	 In addition, we will discuss the phosphodiesterase (PDE) inhibitor milrinone, which also stimulates CFTR but through a mechanism that is less well characterized.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	29	View larger version (14K):    Fig.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	30	   Chemical structures of compounds discussed in text.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	31	 DPCPX, 8-cyclopentyl-1,3-dipropylxanthine.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	32	In the second portion of this review, HCO3 PERMEATION AND POSSIBLE REGULATION OF CFTR-MEDIATED CL CURRENTS, we will discuss the question of HCO3 permeation and potential regulation of CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	33	 This has been a controversial area of research.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Most secretory epithelia secrete both Cl and HCO3, and CFTR seems to be involved in a critical way that is still poorly understood.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	35	 We will discuss data relevant to the question of whether the key role of CFTR is to conduct HCO3 itself or to play some sort of permissive role in HCO3 secretion through an adjacent anion exchanger that requires Cl at the cell's luminal aspect to exchange for cellular HCO3.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	36	 Alternatively, CFTR could also be required to keep cellular Cl concentration low enough that Cl enters the cell on the exchanger and exchanges for cellular HCO3.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	37	 We will also discuss the possibility that HCO3 may regulate the activity of CFTR by altering the permeation of Cl due to the multi-ion pore behavior of CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	38	    PHARMACOLOGICAL REGULATION OF CFTR BY SMALL MOLECULES.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	39	 Genistein is a member of the large class of naturally occurring flavonoids.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Some flavonoids are more potent than genistein in activating CFTR (19), but we will focus on genistein because it has been investigated the most thoroughly.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Genistein is a potent activator of CFTR (e.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	42	 20, 22), but the activating mechanism has been debated.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	43	 Genistein did not seem to operate through activation of protein kinase A (PKA), PKC, or PKG, because there were no increases in intracellular cAMP, Ca2+, or cGMP concentrations (21, 32).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	44	 Genistein is a well-known tyrosine kinase (PTK) inhibitor, and two other PTK inhibitors (tyrphostin 47 and tyrphostin B42) also stimulated CFTR, and genistein-stimulated channel activity was blocked by the tyrosine phosphatase inhibitor vanadate (21, 32).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	45	 However, several other PTK inhibitors (tyrphostin A23, tyrphostin A51, erbstatin analog, and herbimycin) failed to stimulate CFTR (20).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	46	 Genistein also stimulated CFTR equally well when GTP (a poor substrate for tyrosine kinases) was used as a replacement for ATP (10).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	47	 Some results suggested that genistein activated CFTR by blocking a PP: inactivation rates of CFTR currents on cAMP removal were markedly decreased by genistein (20), and CFTR was phosphorylated on the same amino acids by both genistein (which did not raise cAMP concentration) and forskolin (which did) (29).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	48	More recent data have indicated that the most likely explanation for the stimulatory effect of genistein was through direct binding to an NBD of phosphorylated CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	49	 Genistein did not directly open CFTR channels, because genistein did not stimulate CFTR in ATP- or cAMP-depleted monolayers (22).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	50	 Similarly, genistein activation of CFTR in excised patches required both ATP and prior phosphorylation by PKA (10).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	51	 In addition, genistein stimulated phosphatase-resistant, thiophosphorylated CFTR, even in the presence of PKI (to block PKA) or VO4 (to block PP) (10, 39).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	52	 Kinetic analysis indicated that a genistein concentration of  < 35  microM induced prolonged openings of CFTR (similar to the effect of a nonhydrolyzable ATP analog), whereas a genistein concentration of  > 35  microM caused prolonged closed times (38).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	53	An attractive model for stimulatory and inhibitory effects of genistein on CFTR is that of Gadsby et al.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	54	 This model (11) proposes that ATP binding and hydrolysis at NBD1 control channel opening and closing at low phosphorylation levels, and once ATP hydrolysis at NBD1 has opened a highly phosphorylated CFTR channel, ATP binding to NBD2 can stabilize the open state.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Hydrolysis of the nucleotide at NBD2 terminates the stabilization.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Agents that interfere with ATP hydrolysis at NBD2 [e.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	57	, 5'-adenylylimidodiphosphate (AMP-PNP) or pyrophosphate] induce prolonged burst opening.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Genistein is a competitive inhibitor with ATP for binding to PTK (inhibitor constant, 13.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	59	7  microM) and to other ATP-binding proteins, and crystal structure analysis of the Src family tyrosine kinase Hck revealed that the structurally related flavone and CFTR activator quercetin (19) localized to the binding site for the adenine ring of AMP-PNP or ATP (34).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	60	 When considering the sequence homology shared by Walker A-type-binding motifs of PTK and NBDs of CFTR, it therefore seems possible that genistein competes for ATP-binding sites on CFTR, possibly at NBD2 (10), thereby slowing down ATP hydrolysis and preventing CFTR channel closure.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	61	 It is unlikely that genistein activates CFTR by binding to a Src kinase, because this would require activation of a tyrosine kinase and genistein blocks tyrosine kinases.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	62	 It might also be proposed that higher concentrations of genistein inhibit CFTR by competing with ATP at NBD1 (which may have a lower affinity for genistein binding) and prevent CFTR from opening.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	63	 The substituted benzimidazolone NS-004 has effects that are quite similar to those exhibited by genistein.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	64	1 to 1  microM) and F508-CFTR (at  > 10  microM) without raising cAMP concentration and also in the presence of a PKA inhibitor (12), but it was necessary to pretreat cells with forskolin before patch excision to observe CFTR channel activation by NS-004.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	65	 In addition, the drug caused active CFTR channels to increase their activity, but it had no effect when added after channel rundown, indicating that NS-004 required phosphorylated CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	66	 NS-004 did not inhibit in vitro PP activity.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	67	 Thus, although NS-004 was thought to operate by directly opening CFTR (12), the drug may use a mechanism similar to that of genistein to increase open probabilities of phosphorylated, active channels without affecting either PK or PP.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The cardiotonic drug milrinone is an inhibitor of cGMP-inhibited PDE (a class III PDE) and was selected from several drugs inhibiting PDE isozymes (23).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Because PDE inhibitors raise cellular cAMP concentration and CFTR is activated by increases in cAMP concentration, it has been assumed that milrinone (and also IBMX, see below) stimulate CFTR by raising cAMP.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	70	 However, the exact mechanisms have not been determined.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Milrinone activated both normal and F508-CFTR in transformed nasal epithelial cells (24), and a combination of forskolin and milrinone (but not milrinone alone) increased the potential difference across nasal epithelium of F508-CFTR mice in vivo but not in transgenic mice lacking CFTR (24).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Milrinone activated CFTR even when cells had been maximally stimulated with forskolin or some other cAMP agonist, indicating that the drug likely had other effects than to stimulate production of cAMP.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	73	IBMX, DPCPX, and other xanthine derivatives.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	74	 IBMX is an inhibitor of PDE with broad specificity.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Despite its broad use as a PDE inhibitor, it seems unlikely that IBMX works solely via this mechanism.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	76	 IBMX activated CFTR even when cells had been maximally stimulated with forskolin or some other cAMP agonist (23).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Although other substituted xanthine derivatives activated CFTR, there was no correlation between effects on CFTR and cellular cAMP and ATP concentrations (4).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	78	 We have also found, through use of a fluorescence assay for PKA activity (as opposed to measurements of cAMP concentration using RIA), that forskolin caused fibroblasts to raise cAMP concentration to such a high level that PKA activity was saturated (by maximally binding cAMP), and IBMX (which indeed raised cAMP concentration) had no further effect to increase PKA activity (B.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Machen, unpublished observations).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	80	 It therefore seems likely that the stimulatory effects of IBMX on CFTR are due to combined effects to raise cAMP (when PKA has not been saturated) and also to block PP or directly bind to CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	81	The xanthine derivative DPCPX is an adenosine A1 antagonist that may have some selectivity for F508-CFTR compared with effects on wild-type CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	82	 DPCPX stimulates F508-CFTR channels in a variety of epithelial and fibroblast cells (8, 15).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	83	 In some cells, correction of the CF defect by transfection with the CFTR gene rendered the transfected cells insensitive to DPCPX.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	84	 In contrast, DPCPX stimulated recombinant CFTR channels from HEK cell microsomal membranes incorporated into planar lipid layers (2).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	85	 The effects of DPCPX seemed not to be due to an effect on A1 receptors, because Northern analysis showed that a DPCPX-sensitive cell line (CFPAC-1) had no A1 receptor mRNA, and another xanthine analog 1,3-diallyl-8-cyclohexylxanthine (DAX) was a potent CFTR activator but a poor A1 adenosine receptor antagonist.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Using a rapid membrane filtration assay, Cohen et al.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	87	 (6) reported that DPCPX bound to NBD1 of F508-CFTR [dissociation constant (Kd) = 1.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	88	0 nM] with an affinity 17 times higher than that to NBD1 of wild-type CFTR (Kd = 17.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	89	0 nM) with a rank order among different xanthines of DAX  >  DPCPX  >  caffeine  >  DA-DPCPX  >  adenosine  >  >  IBMX  >  2-thio-DPCPX.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	90	 These results were consistent with a unique binding site for DPCPX and related xanthines on NBD1 of CFTR in the vicinity of F508 (2).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	91	 DPCPX was ~25-fold more potent than IBMX in potentiating F508-CFTR by a mechanism other than elevation of intracellular cAMP concentration (15).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Stimulation of CFTR by DPCPX or DAX required prephosphorylated CFTR (2).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Thus DPCPX (and likely all the other xanthines, including IBMX), genistein, and NS-004 all seemed to activate prephosphorylated CFTR by binding directly to CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	94	 DPCPX appeared to bind to NBD1 rather than to NBD2, and it also seemed to be more selective for F508-CFTR than wild-type CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	95	Pharmacological stimulation of mutant CFTR and therapeutic potential.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The most common mutation in CF, F508-CFTR, leads to a trafficking-impaired protein that gets degraded in the cell (40).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	97	 Some mutations lead to trafficking-competent, but misfunctional, proteins (e.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	98	 It appears that mutants with different misfunctions will need selective treatments.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	99	 For example, genistein failed to activate F508-CFTR in CF bronchial epithelial cells (22), but addition of genistein and cAMP agonists to NIH/3T3 cells overexpressing F508-CFTR caused a strong, synergistic activation (18).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	100	 Alternatively, when CF nasal epithelial cells were treated with 4-phenylbutyrate or low temperature to increase expression of F508-CFTR in the membrane (31, 40), genistein was a potent stimulant (9).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	101	 In addition, the trafficking-competent G551D-CFTR mutant expressed in fibroblasts was stimulated by the combination of genistein and forskolin when forskolin alone was ineffective (9).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	102	 These data indicate that genistein targets CFTR mutants present in the plasma membrane.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	103	 Both NS-004 and, especially, DPCPX have also been shown to activate F508-CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	104	 IBMX produced a small, CFTR-related secretory response in jejunum, cecum, and rectum from G551D mice but had no effect in the nasal epithelium (36).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	105	 NS-004 restored near normal channel activity from P574H-CFTR (a mild, trafficking-impaired mutation in NBD1) (3).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	106	 These results suggest that, in addition to their direct effects on CFTR, these drugs may also have other effects that increase the number of channel proteins found in the membrane.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	107	 It is also important to remember that there may be tissue-specific effects of the drugs, because epithelial cells will require concomitant activity of basolateral K+ channels to secrete fluid efficiently.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	108	    HCO3 PERMEATION AND POSSIBLE REGULATION OF CFTR-MEDIATED CL CURRENTS.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	109	Background: Role of CFTR in HCO3 secretion across intestine.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	110	 HCO3 secretion is a key function that occurs in the stomach, pancreas, and small and large intestine.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	111	 HCO3 secretion is particularly important in the duodenum to protect the intestinal mucosa against damage from large amounts of acid from the stomach (1).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Transepithelial secretion of HCO3 likely involves the concerted activities of an apical anion channel, Cl/HCO3 exchange, HCO3 uptake across the basolateral membrane, and/or production of HCO3 by intracellular carbonic anhydrase activity.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	113	 The paracellular pathway may also contribute, since a transepithelial gradient for HCO3 favoring secretion occurs.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	114	 Electrogenic HCO3 secretion is activated by secretagogues that increase intracellular cAMP, cGMP, or Ca2+ concentrations (1), and this HCO3 secretion required the presence of CFTR in all segments of the small intestine in mice (16, 17, 33).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	115	 However, the specific mechanism(s) involved remains a mystery.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	116	 With the use of the pH stat method in combination with inhibitors of anion exchange and CFTR, recent work (5) with duodenum from normal and CFTR knockout mice shows that CFTR may have contributed to HCO3 secretion in two ways: directly by conducting HCO3 into the lumen and also indirectly by conducting Cl into the lumen, which could be recycled back into the cell via anion exchange for HCO3.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Because CFTR is expressed at highest levels in the crypts (7), electrogenic HCO3 secretion is predicted to occur primarily in this region.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	118	 In contrast, CFTR is expressed at lower levels and carbonic anhydrase activity is expressed at higher levels in the villus epithelium, so CFTR-coupled Cl/HCO3 exchange activity may be primarily localized to the villus.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	119	Does CFTR conduct HCO3? Patch-clamp studies showed that HCO3 was conducted through CFTR in NIH/3T3 cells recombinantly expressing wild-type CFTR (26), with a permeability ratio of Cl to HCO3 of 0.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	120	 Similar measurements have also been presented recently by Linsdell et al.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	121	 (25), who found a permeability ratio of Cl to HCO3 of 0.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	122	 We also measured CFTR-mediated permeation of HCO3 across the apical membrane of Calu-3 monolayers, and conductance ratios of cAMP-stimulated HCO3 and Cl currents of 0.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	123	 Thus HCO3-to-Cl permeability or conductance ratios of CFTR ranged from 0.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	124	 A role of CFTR's function as a HCO3 conductor has also been suggested in CF models using a variety of methods comparing wild-type CFTR-expressing cells with F508-CFTR-expressing CF cells (22, 35) or wild-type with CFTR knockout mice (CFTR /) (5, 13, 17, 33).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	125	 These reports suggested the possibility that a defect in HCO3 secretion through CFTR may contribute to the pathophysiology of CF pulmonary disease (22, 35).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	126	 In contrast to these experiments that showed that CFTR conducts HCO3, Quinton and Reddy (28) (P.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	127	 Quinton, personal communication) showed using microelectrode methods that in intact sweat ducts HCO3 was equally impermeant through CFTR as gluconate.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	128	 This contradiction remains unresolved.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	129	Does CFTR contribute to cytosolic and/or extracellular pH regulation? If CFTR is permeant to HCO3, it is expected that it should contribute to movements of HCO3 into and out of the cell and thereby alter pH of the cell or extracellular fluids.
