0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	130	 In NIH/3T3 cells expressing exogenous CFTR, we showed forskolin-stimulated changes of pH that were absent in cells expressing F508-CFTR (26).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	131	 Data have also been presented for biliary epithelial cells showing that CFTR may regulate the activity of the anion exchanger and alter cytosolic pH regulatory ability in these cells (14) In contrast, we have recently compared cytosolic pH regulation in CF and CFTR-corrected nasal cells and found no apparent differences (L.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	132	 A possible explanation was that these cells expressed Na+/H+ and Cl/HCO3 exchange and Na+-HCO3 cotransport, and these mechanisms were much more prominent than CFTR in regulating cytosolic pH.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Thus, in cells that express prominent activity of transporters that regulate cytosolic pH, the conductive pathway for HCO3 across CFTR might be of minor importance for cytosolic pH regulation.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	134	 However, CFTR might still contribute importantly to the accumulation of HCO3 in the poorly buffered apical/luminal fluid.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	135	Do anions regulate Cl permeation through CFTR? It has been well described that thiocyanate (SCN) is highly permeant across CFTR, but when mixtures of Cl and SCN are used, the conductance of CFTR decreases (37).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	136	 This effect has been interpreted in terms of multi-ion pore behavior of CFTR, i.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	137	, interactions of anions within the pore can lead to anomalous effects.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	138	 Also, the halide anion I both permeated and blocked CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	139	 We have similarly shown that both F and HCO3 added to the apical surface reduced Cl conductance of CFTR in Calu-3 cells (Illek and Machen, unpublished observations).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	140	 In vivo both Cl and HCO3 are present in the cytosol at similar concentrations, and both are driven by the membrane potential into the pore of CFTR, suggesting that both ions may compete for common binding sites in the permeation path, and thus affect the permeation of each other.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	141	 This could be particularly important for tissues that secrete large amounts of HCO3.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	142	Summary: Role of CFTR in HCO3 secretion.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The exact role of CFTR in HCO3 permeation under physiological conditions likely depends on the relative expression of CFTR and other HCO3 channels, HCO3 transporters and paracellular permeability of HCO3.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	144	 In addition, the cell-to-lumen electrochemical driving forces for Cl and HCO3 will determine ion movements across the luminal cell membrane and tight junctions.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	145	 CFTR appears to be important both as a HCO3 conductance and also in some way as a direct or indirect regulator of adjacent anion exchange, e.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	146	, as a source of luminal Cl that may exchange for cellular HCO3 and/or as a means of keeping cellular Cl concentration low enough that the anion exchanger operates as an HCO3 secretion mechanism.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Many CFTR-expressing epithelia, including the intestine, pancreas, and liver, exhibit different gradients of Cl and HCO3 along the length of the organ, so these relationships will also be affected by the anatomic structures.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	148	We apologize to those whose work we were unable to quote due to space limitations.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	149	* Second in a series of invited articles on Genetic Disorders of Membrane Transport.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	150	Study in our laboratories has been supported by grants from the National Institutes of Health (R01-DK-51799), Cystic Fibrosis Research, Inc.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	151	, the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (Grant ILLEK96F0), and the Commercial Endowment of Children's Hospital Oakland.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	152	Address for reprint requests: T.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	153	 of Molecular and Cell Biology, Univ.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	154	 of California, Berkeley, CA 94720.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Gastroduodenal mucosal protection.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	156	 73: 823-857, 1993[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Direct activation of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator channels by 8-cyclopentyl-1,3-dipropylxanthine (CPX) and 1,3-diallyl-8-cyclohexylxanthine (DAX).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	158	 273: 5727-5734, 1998[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	159	 A change in gating mode leading to increased intrinsic Cl channel activity compensates for defective processing in a cystic fibrosis mutant corresponding to a mild form of the disease.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Structural basis for specificity and potency of xanthine derivatives as activators of the CFTR chloride channel.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Dual role of CFTR in cAMP-stimulated HCO3 secretion across murine duodenum.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	162	 37): G718-G726, 1998[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	163	 8-cyclopentyl-1,3-dipropylxanthine and other xanthines differentially bind to the wild-type and F508 first nucleotide binding fold (NBF-1) domains of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	164	 Biochemistry 36: 6455-6461, 1997[Medline].
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Immunocytochemical localization of the cystic fibrosis gene product CFTR.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	166	 USA 88: 9262-9266, 1991[Abstract].
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	167	 A1 adenosine-receptor antagonists activate chloride efflux from cystic fibrosis cells.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	168	 USA 89: 5562-5566, 1992[Abstract].
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Effects of genistein on disease-causing mutant CFTRs (Abstract).
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Genistein activates CFTR Cl channels via a tyrosine kinase- and protein phosphatase-independent mechanism.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	171	 42): C747-C753, 1997[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	172	 The CFTR chloride channel of mammalian heart.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	173	 The substituted benzimidazolone NS-004 is an opener of the cystic fibrosis chloride channel.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	174	 269: 10983-10986, 1994[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	175	 Intestinal physiology and pathology in gene-targeted mouse models of cystic fibrosis.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	176	 36): G258-G266, 1997[Abstract/Free Full Text].
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Regulation of chloride/bicarbonate exchange activity by wild-type and mutant CFTR.

0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	226	 Molecular mechanisms of CFTR chloride channel dysfunction in cystic fibrosis.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	227	 Cell 73: 1251-1254, 1993[Medline].
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	228	Am J Physiol Gastroint Liver Physiol 275(6):G1221-G1226 0002-9513/98 $5.
0.56830734.9843756.html.plaintext.txt	229	00 Copyright   1998 the American Physiological Society.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	0	  The Rockefeller University Press, 0021-9525/2003/1/157 $5.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	1	00 The Journal of Cell Biology, Volume 160, Number 2, 157-163 Report.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	2	Traffic-independent function of the Sar1p/COPII machinery in proteasomal sorting of the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator Lianwu Fu and Elizabeth Sztul.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	3	Department of Cell Biology, University of Alabama at Birmingham, Birmingham, AL 35294.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	4	 of Cell Biology, MCLM Room 668, 1530 3rd Ave.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	5	Key Words: ER sorting; proteasomal degradation; CFTR; ERAD; yeast.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	6	The exact pathway for degradation of transmembrane ERAD substrates from the ER is unclear, but there is evidence to suggest that at least some retained proteins are sorted into specialized ER subdomains before degradation (Kamhi-Nesher et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	7	 It is unknown what molecular mechanisms regulate sequestration of ERAD substrates, and whether such sequestration is required for ER retrotranslocation and proteasomal degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	8	 To explore these questions, we used the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae and mutant strains defective in the Sar1p/COPII sorting machinery and a known ERAD substrate, CFTR, as our model system.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	9	Sar1p/COPII-mediated selection of ER proteins for secretory traffic is one of the best understood mechanisms for selective recruitment of proteins in the ER (Antonny and Schekman, 2001).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	10	 COPII sorting is initiated by Sar1p, a small GTPase (Veldhuisen et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	11	, 1997) that is activated by Sec12p-mediated guanine-nucleotide exchange.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Sar1p in its GTP-bound state associates with the ER membrane and recruits the Sec23p/Sec24p to COPII complex and subsequently the Sec13p/Sec31p to COPII complex to the membrane (for review see Barlowe, 2000).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	13	 The assembly of the COPII coat on ER budding structures is coupled to the selection of transmembrane proteins into the nascent budding structures that will eventually bud from the ER as transport vesicles.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	14	 COPII function has been examined to date exclusively in the context of secretory traffic.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	15	CFTR is a chloride channel present on the apical surface of epithelial cells lining the respiratory, intestinal, and exocrine tissues (Kirk, 2000).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	16	 In mammalian cells, only 20% of newly synthesized wild-type CFTR folds correctly and is transported from the ER to the plasma membrane through the secretory pathway, whereas the remaining 80% of CFTR is degraded from the ER through the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway (Jensen et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	17	 In mammalian cells, CFTR is not sequestered into ER subdomains before degradation because inhibition of proteasomal activity by chemical inhibitors or overtaxing the proteolytic capacity by overexpressing CFTR leads to retrotranslocation of CFTR from the ER and its accumulation in cytosolic aggresomes (Johnston et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	18	 In yeast, the majority (if not all) of newly synthesized CFTR is also degraded through the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway, but in contrast to mammalian cells, CFTR in yeast is not delivered to aggresomes, but appears sequestered in ER subdomains before degradation (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	19	Here, we report that the Sar1p/COPII machinery functions in sorting CFTR into ER subdomains before proteasomal degradation, and that such sorting is required for CFTR entry into the degradative pathway.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	20	 This function of Sar1p/COPII does not involve ER-Golgi traffic.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	21	 Our results support a model in which the Sar1p/COPII machinery participates in sorting proteins to both the anterograde secretory pathway and the degradative pathway.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	22	 These findings raise the possibility that all newly synthesized proteins are subjected to a Sar1p/COPII sorting mechanism, irrespective of their ultimate secretory or degradative fate.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	23	View larger version (26K):    Figure 1.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	24	 EGFP-CFTR represents yeast ERAD substrate.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	25	 (A) Yeast transformed with pCU426CUP1 (EGFP-CFTR, - lane) or pCU426CUP1/EGFP-CFTR (EGFP-CFTR, + lanes) were induced, labeled with [35S]methionine for 20 min, and lysed.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	26	 Lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-CFTR, anti-F1ss, or anti-GFP pAbs.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	27	 A band of 175 kD, appropriate for a chimera of EGFP and CFTR, can be immunoprecipitated with anti-CFTR and anti-GFP antibodies from cells expressing EGFP-CFTR.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	28	 (B) Wild-type, pre1 to 1, and ubc6 yeast were transformed with pCU426CUP1/EGFP-CFTR, induced, and pulse-labeled with [35S]methionine for 20 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	29	 An equal amount of culture was taken at each chase time, lysed, and the lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-CFTR antibody.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	30	 Relative intensities of EGFP-CFTR bands were quantitated.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	31	 EGFP-CFTR is stabilized in pre1 to 1 and ubc6 strains.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	32	  To ensure that EGFP-CFTR behaves as an ERAD substrate, we examined its degradation rate in mutant strains lacking either a functional proteasome subunit (pre1 to 1) or an ubiquitin-conjugation enzyme (ubc6).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Both proteins have been previously shown to be required for degradation of CFTR tagged at the COOH terminus with GFP (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	34	 1 B, EGFP-CFTR in wild-type yeast is digested rapidly, with a half-life of 10 to 15 min (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	35	 1 B), slightly more rapidly than previously published (20 min, Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	36	 All CFTR appears to be degraded in yeast (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	37	, 2001), as opposed to mammalian cells where 20% is transported to the plasma membrane.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	38	 It is possible that yeast does not have sufficient machinery to efficiently fold overexpressed CFTR, or that even correctly folded CFTR is "read" by yeast as defective.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	39	 In contrast to rapid degradation in wild-type yeast, EGFP-CFTR remains stable in pre1 to 1 mutant yeast even after 90 min of chase, and the half-life of EGFP-CFTR in the ubc6 strain is extended to 40 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	40	 Because our EGFP-CFTR construct is degraded through the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway in yeast, we use it as an ERAD substrate to test Sar1p/COPII involvement in proteasomal targeting.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	41	EGFP-CFTR is sorted to subcompartments of ER before degradation Previous studies have shown that CFTR tagged at the COOH terminus with GFP (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	42	, 2001) is degraded as an integral membrane protein and colocalizes with the ER chaperone Kar2p in punctate ER structures before degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	43	 To analyze our EGFP-CFTR construct, we first tested its association with membranes.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	44	 2 A, EGFP-CFTR is detected exclusively in the membrane pellet fraction after medium speed centrifugation, indicating that it is degraded as a membrane-associated form.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	45	View larger version (47K):    Figure 2.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	46	 EGFP-CFTR localization depends on functional Sar1p/COPII machinery.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	47	 (A) Yeast expressing EGFP-CFTR was subjected to membrane fractionation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	48	 A sample of each fraction was processed by SDS-PAGE, transferred to nitrocellulose membrane, and immunoblotted with anti-CFTR antibody.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	49	 S; supernatant after high speed centrifugation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	50	 P1, P2, P3; pellets after low speed, medium speed, and high speed centrifugation, respectively.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	51	 EGFP-CFTR is recovered exclusively in the membrane fraction.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	52	 (B) Wild-type yeast expressing EGFP-CFTR was grown to log phase and processed for immunofluorescence using anti-Kar2p or anti-Kex2p antibodies, or was incubated with the fluorescent dye FM 4 to 64 for 45 min at 0 degrees C, followed by 1 h at 24 degrees C to stain the vacuole.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	53	 EGFP-CFTR colocalizes only with the ER marker Kar2p.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	54	 (C) Wild-type yeast transformed with pCU426CUP1 (- EGFP-CFTR) or with pCU426CUP1/EGFP-CFTR (+ EGFP-CFTR) was grown to log phase, induced, and processed for immunofluorescence with anti-Kar2p antibodies (insets) and for electron microscopy.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	55	 Kar2p shows typical ER localization in - EGFP-CFTR cells, but distributes to punctate structures in + EGFP-CFTR cells.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	56	 Cells without EGFP-CFTR contain normal ER (arrows), but cells expressing EGFP-CFTR show accumulation of membranous elements (arrowheads).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	57	 (D) Wild-type, ubc6, sec18 to 1ts, and sec23 to 1ts yeast transformed with pCU426CUP1/EGFP-CFTR was grown to log phase and induced at permissive (24 degrees C) or restrictive (39 degrees C) temperature.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	58	 Live yeast were then imaged by fluorescence microscopy.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	59	 EGFP-CFTR localizes to ER subdomains in wild-type, ubc6, and sec18 to 1ts yeast grown at permissive or restrictive temperatures.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	60	 EGFP-CFTR localizes to ER subdomains in sec23 to 1ts yeast grown at permissive temperature, but is diffusely distributed throughout the ER in sec23 to 1ts yeast grown under restrictive temperature.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	61	  We performed immunofluorescence with known organellar markers to localize EGFP-CFTR.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	62	 2 B, EGFP-CFTR is not detected in small punctate structures containing the late Golgi marker Kex2p (Preuss et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	63	 This result agrees with findings that CFTR expressed in yeast undergoes ER-type N-glycosylation, but does not undergo Golgi-type oligosaccharide modifications (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	64	 EGFP-CFTR is not detected on the plasma membrane, and does not colocalize with the fluorescent dye FM 4 to 64 (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	65	 2 B) shown to be transported to endosomal (unpublished data) or vacuolar compartments of yeast as a function of incubation time and temperature (Vida and Emr, 1995; the minimal colocalization in the vacuole is due to bleed-through from the strong EGFP-CFTR signal and is not visible in cells without EGFP-CFTR).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	66	 The lack of vacuolar localization is consistent with lack of degradation of CFTR via the Pep4p/Prb1p vacuolar proteases (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	67	EGFP-CFTR is detected in relatively large punctate structures that contain Kar2p (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	68	 The punctate Kar2p distribution in EGFP-CFTR to expressing yeast is distinct from its normal cage-like perinuclear localization in control yeast (Paddon et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	69	 The effects of EGFP-CFTR expression on intracellular morphology were analyzed by electron microscopy of yeast transformed with either empty or EGFP-CFTR to containing plasmids.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	70	 2 C, normal nuclear membrane and sub to plasma membrane ER structures are evident in the control cell (arrows), in agreement with published images (Zhang et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	71	 In contrast, EGFP-CFTR cell shows clusters of membranous structures in proximity to the perinuclear ER (arrowheads).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	72	 Higher magnification shows them to be accumulations of tubular and vesicular elements, morphologically analogous to ER extensions observed in yeast expressing CFTR (Zhang et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	73	 The relative size of such clusters (average diameter 0.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	74	5 to 1  microm) corresponds to the approximate size of the fluorescent Kar2p/EGFP-CFTR puncta.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Significantly, membrane amplification induced by CFTR (Zhang et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	76	, 2001) or EGFP-CFTR (this work) is distinct from multi-layered ER "karmellae" induced by expression of HMG-CoA reductase (Koning et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Together, the data suggest that EGFP-CFTR localizes to subdomains of the ER network that represent penultimate stations before degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	78	 The results also imply that sequestration into the ER domains is more efficient than subsequent removal by degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	79	Functional Sar1p/COPII machinery is required for sorting EGFP-CFTR to ER subdomains To determine if the Sar1p/COPII machinery participates in sorting EGFP-CFTR, we examined its localization when COPII function is disrupted.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	80	 First, we tested the localization of EGFP-CFTR in wild-type, ubc6, and sec18 to 1 yeast strains when grown at 24 degrees C (permissive temperature for strains defective in COPII components) and when grown at 39 degrees C (restrictive temperature for strains defective in COPII components).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	81	 2 D, EGFP-CFTR in the wild-type strain remains as punctate spots at both temperatures.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	82	 Similarly, the pattern of EGFP-CFTR in the ubc6 strain defective for proteasomal degradation is analogous to that in the wild-type strain.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	83	 This strongly suggests that EGFP-CFTR is sorted into the punctate structure and maintained there before it is targeted for ubiquitination and degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	84	 Our data, together with the finding that CFTR remains sequestered in Kar2p-containing subdomains in yeast strain (pre1 to 1pre2 to 2) defective for proteasomal degradation (Zhang et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	85	, 2001), suggest that the catalytic activity of ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme Ubc6p is not sufficient to remove EGFP-CFTR from ER subdomains, and that ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation are tightly coupled.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	86	 The same punctate EGFP-CFTR pattern is observed in sec18 to 1 strain grown at either temperature, indicating that block in vesicular fusion during ER-Golgi protein transport does not significantly affect EGFP-CFTR sequestration.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	87	Analysis of EGFP-CFTR localization in the sec23 to 1ts strain (Kuehn et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	88	, 1998) showed significant temperature-dependent changes (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	89	 At the permissive temperature, EGFP-CFTR is sequestered into ER subdomains, but at the restrictive temperature, EGFP-CFTR is diffusely distributed throughout the ER in a pattern characteristic of ER proteins (compare enlargement with Kar2p staining in inset; Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	90	 Similar results were obtained when yeast strains mutant in other components of the Sar1p/COPII machinery (described below) were analyzed (unpublished data).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	91	Functional Sar1p/COPII machinery is required for EGFP-CFTR degradation To uncover whether the Sar1p/COPII machinery is also involved in CFTR degradation, we compared the degradation rate of EGFP-CFTR at permissive (24 degrees C) and restrictive (39 degrees C) temperature in yeast mutant in Sar1p/COPII components.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	92	 In wild-type strain, EGFP-CFTR is degraded rapidly at both temperatures, with a half-life of 10 to 15 min (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	93	 The temperature-sensitive strain, sec12 to 4ts, is defective in catalyzing GDP/GTP exchange on Sar1p at the restrictive temperature due to a P73L mutation (Barlowe and Schekman, 1993).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	94	 EGFP-CFTR is degraded rapidly in the sec12 to 4ts strain at permissive temperature; with a half-life (10 min) analogous to that in wild-type strain (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	95	 In contrast, the degradation rate is delayed significantly when the yeast is shifted to the restrictive temperature, with the half-life extending to 40 to 45 min, a threefold increase compared with the permissive temperature.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	96	 The temperature-sensitive strains sec23 to 1ts and sec13 to 1ts (Salama et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	97	, 1997) are defective at the restrictive temperature due to an S382L mutation (Yoshihisa et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	98	, 1993), and a mutation that has not yet been identified, respectively.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	99	 In both cases, COPII function is compromised.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	100	 EGFP-CFTR is degraded rapidly in both sec23 to 1ts and sec13 to 1ts strains at the permissive temperature, with half-lives of  < 15 min (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	101	 In contrast, the degradation rates are significantly delayed in both strains at the restrictive temperatures, with a half-life of 50 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	102	 The significant inhibition of EGFP-CFTR degradation suggests that functional COPII machinery is required for proteasomal degradation of EGFP-CFTR.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	103	View larger version (50K):    Figure 3.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	104	 EGFP-CFTR degradation depends on functional Sar1p/COPII machinery.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	105	 Wild-type (A), sec12 to 4ts (B), sec23 to 1ts (C), sec13 to 1ts (D), and sec18 to 1ts (E) yeast were transformed with pCU426CUP1/EGFP-CFTR.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	106	 Yeast were grown to log phase and induced at permissive temperature.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	107	 An equal amount of culture was then pulse-labeled with [35S]methionine for 20 min at either 24 degrees C or 39 degrees C.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	108	 An equal amount of culture was taken after indicated chase times and used to prepare cell lysates.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	109	 Lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-CFTR or anti-CPY (for sec18 to 1ts) antibody.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	110	 Relative intensities of EGFP-CFTR bands were quantitated.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	111	 EGFP-CFTR degradation is significantly inhibited by inactivation of Sec12p, Sec23p, and Sec13p.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	112	  It must be stressed that EGFP-CFTR, like other transmembrane ERAD substrates, does not enter the ER-Golgi recycling degradative pathway.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Like the previously characterized CFTR (Kiser et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	114	, 2001), EGFP-CFTR is degraded with normal kinetics at permissive and restrictive temperatures in a sec18 to 1 strain (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	115	 The strain is defective in Sec18p function, as shown by a block in maturation of the vacuolar CPY at the restrictive temperature (Fig.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Together, the results indicate that ER-Golgi transport and recycling are not required for EGFP-CFTR degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	117	 Our findings suggest a novel role for the Sar1p/COPII sorting machinery.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	118	 In addition to selecting correctly folded substrates into the forward secretory pathway (Schekman and Orci, 1996; Bannykh et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	119	, 2000) and selecting misfolded soluble ERAD substrates for the ER-Golgi recycling degradative pathway (Vashist et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	120	, 2001), Sar1p/COPII also sorts misfolded substrates into subdomains of the ER from which they are subsequently degraded.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	121	 How does the same machinery sort proteins into three distinct pathways? A common sorting mechanism for both correctly folded and misfolded membrane proteins presents a spatial problem because these classes must occupy distinct regions of the ER.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	122	 It is likely that additional targeting mechanisms coordinate with Sar1p/COPII to direct the proteins to ER exit or retention.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	123	 It appears that a primary distinction is made at the level of packaging into COPII vesicles; although correctly folded soluble and transmembrane proteins for secretory traffic and misfolded soluble ERAD substrates for ER-Golgi recycling degradative traffic are sorted into COPII vesicles, misfolded transmembrane ERAD substrates are excluded (Vashist et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	124	 There is evidence that transmembrane ERAD substrates are prevented from entry into COPII vesicles and are retained in the ER through the action of luminal ER proteins.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	125	 For example, mutants of the transmembrane ATPase Pma1p appear to be retained and degraded in the ER through the action of a protein disulfide isomerase to related protein, Eps1p (Wang and Chang, 1999).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	126	 Similarly, the retention of a transmembrane H2a precursor in the ER is determined by a pentapeptide sequence present on the luminal side of the ER (Shenkman et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	127	 In addition, ERAD substrates can be retained by binding to calnexin.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	128	 It has been shown that calnexin binds to wild-type and folding compromised F508CFTR in the ER, but the association with F508CFTR is prolonged and might facilitate ER retention (Pind et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	129	 ERAD substrates can be also retained by association with the translocon (Loayza et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	130	 Cytoplasmic chaperones may also participate in ER retention (Brodsky et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	131	 The finding that strains inactivated in the cytosolic Hsp70 Ssa1p do not sort CFTR into ER subdomains supports the view that ER sequestration requires the coordinate action of Sar1p/COPII and accessory factors.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	132	That Sar1p/COPII is likely to participate in the secretory and the degradative pathways is supported by data obtained from whole genome microarray analysis where many genes involved in secretory traffic were found to be UPR targets (Travers et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Initially, the up-regulation was viewed as means to increase traffic in the ER-Golgi recycling degradative pathway for soluble ERAD substrates (Caldwell et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	134	 However, our work suggests that the up-regulation is also a means to increase components required for ER sequestration of transmembrane ERAD substrates.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Specifically relevant to our analysis is the up-regulation of SEC12, SEC13, and SEC24.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	136	 Thus, it may be that the UPR-mediated up-regulation of these genes may not be a cellular strategy to remove protein from the ER by exporting them, but additionally might promote sorting of retained proteins toward degradation.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	137	To generate an inducible construct expressing GFP-tagged CFTR in yeast, pEGFP-CFTR plasmid (Moyer et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	138	, 1998) was first digested with SacII, and then treated with Klenow fragment followed by digestion with NheI.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	139	 The pRSETB/EGFP plasmid (provided by Dr.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	140	 David Bedwell) was first digested with HindIII and then treated with Klenow fragment followed by digestion with NheI.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	141	 The EGFP-containing fragment from pRSETB/EGFP and CFTR-containing fragment from pEGFP-CFTR were gel-purified, ligated, and transformed into Eschericia coli.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	142	 The resulting plasmid was then digested with NheI and EcoRV, and treated with Klenow fragment.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	143	 The EGFP-CFTR to containing fragment was gel-purified and cloned into the SmaI site of pCU426CUP1 (Labbe and Thiele, 1999).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	144	 The final construct was sequenced to ensure the correct open reading frame.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	145	Yeast strains CTY182 (MATa, ura3 to 52, his3 to 200, lys2 to 80), CTY252 (MATa, ura3 to 52, sec12 to 4ts), CTY253 (MATa, ura3 to 52, sec13 to 1ts), and CTY260 (MAT, ura3 to 52, leu2 to 3, 112, sec23 to 1ts) were a gift from Dr.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	146	 YHI29/W (MATa, ura3, leu2 to 3, 112, his3 to 11, 15, cans, GAL1), YHI29/1 (MATa, pre1 to 1, ura3, leu2 to 3, 112, his3 to 11, 15, cans, GAL1), and YWO0346 (MAT, ura3 to 1, leu2 to 3, 112, his3 to 11, 15, ade2 to 1 ocre, trp1 to 1, can1 to 100, ubc6::LEU2) were a gift from Dr.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	147	 Dieter Wolf (Universitat Stuttgart, Stuttgart, Germany).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	148	 SEY6210 (MAT ura3 to 52 leu2 to 3, 112 his3-200 trp1-901 lys2 to 801 suc2-9) and SEY5186 (MAT sec18 to 1 ura3 to 52 leu2 to 3, 112 GAL+) were a gift from Dr.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	149	Yeast media were prepared as described previously (Rose et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Unless specified, in all experiments, cultures were grown for a minimum of 5 to 6 generations to an A600 of no more than 1.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	151	Fractionation, immunofluorescence, and electron microscopy Yeast expressing EGFP-CFTR was fractionated as described previously (Paddon et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	152	 In brief, cells grown to exponential phase were converted to spheroplasts using yeast lytic enzyme (ICN Biomedicals) in the presence of 20 mM potassium phosphate buffer, pH 7.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	153	 The spheroplasts were washed and disrupted using a Dounce homogenizer in 25 mM Hepes-NaOH buffer, pH 7.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	154	4, plus protease inhibitors (Sigma-Aldrich).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	155	 Cell lysates were centrifuged at 4 degrees C at 500 g for 10 min, and the resulting supernatant was spun at 25,000 g for 15 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	156	 The resulting supernatant was centrifuged at 150,000 g for 1 h.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	157	 Pellet from each spin was washed with Hepes buffer and saved as P1, P2, and P3, respectively.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	158	 Protein concentration was measured using a Detergent Compatible Protein Assay kit (Bio-Rad Laboratories).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	159	For immunofluorescent studies, yeast were grown in synthetic complete medium lacking uracil to an OD600 of no more than 1.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	160	 Yeast were fixed by adding formaldehyde to 3% and incubating at either 24 degrees C or 39 degrees C for 30 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	161	 Cells were harvested and washed twice with 0.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	162	5, and once with potassium phosphate buffer containing 1.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	163	 The cell walls were digested by adding ss-mercaptoethanol to 0.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	164	 After incubating at 30 degrees C for 1 h, cells were washed twice with sorbitol buffer, applied to polylysine-coated coverslips, and were allowed to settle at RT for 20 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	165	 The cells were refixed with 3% formaldehyde for 5 min followed by quenching with 50 mM of NH4Cl for 5 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	166	 Cells were permeabilized with 0.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	167	1% Triton X-100 for 10 min and washed twice for 5 min each with blocking buffer (PBS containing 0.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Cells were incubated overnight with primary antibody diluted 1:5,000 for anti-Kar2p antibody and 1:2,000 for anti-Kex2p antibody.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	169	 Coverslips were washed three times with blocking buffer.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Cells were incubated with secondary antibody for 1 h and washed as above.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Coverslips were mounted on slides in 9:1 glycerol/PBS with 0.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	172	 Images were acquired with an inverted microscope (Axiovert 30; Carl Zeiss MicroImaging Inc.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	173	 IpLab Spectrum software (Signal Analytics Corp.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	174	) was used to control image acquisition.

0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	177	 Grids were examined on an electron microscope (model 100CX; JEOL USA, Inc.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	178	Pulse-chase labeling and immunoprecipitation Yeast were grown overnight to log phase at 24 degrees C in synthetic complete medium supplemented with appropriate amino acids.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	179	 EGFP-CFTR expression was induced with 100  microM of CuSO4 for 2 h (Labbe and Thiele, 1999).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	180	 A total of 32 OD600 U of cells was harvested (3 OD600 U for each time point) and resuspended in 4 ml synthetic complete medium plus 100  microM CuSO4.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	181	 Each culture was separated into two parts and was incubated with shaking at 24 degrees C or 39 degrees C for 10 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	182	 Cells were then labeled with 200  microCi of [35S]methionine (Trans35S label from ICN Biomedicals) for 20 min.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	183	 The label was chased with 40  microl of chasing mixture (1 mg/ml methionine, 1 mg/ml cysteine, and 15% yeast extract).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	184	4-ml samples were collected at 0, 15, 30, 60, and 90 min and added to 25  microl of 100% TCA (5% final TCA concentration).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	185	 Samples were mixed, placed on ice for 20 min, and washed twice with ice-cold acetone.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Cells were resuspended in lysis buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	187	5% SDS, and protease inhibitors) and broken down by vortexing with glass beads.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	188	 EGFP-CFTR was immunoprecipitated from total cell lysate using a polyclonal anti-NBD1 CFTR antibody (1:250 dilutions).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	189	 Immunoprecipitates were separated on 6% SDS-PAGE and analyzed by PhosphorImager (Molecular Dynamics, Inc.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	190	 EGFP-CFTR signal was quantified using ImageQuant Software (Molecular Dynamics, Inc.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	191	), and relative amounts were calculated and plotted using Excel software (Microsoft).
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	192	 For CPY analysis, pulse-chase was done as above, and lysates were immunoprecipitated with anti-CPY antibodies.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	193	 Immunoprecipitates were resolved on 10% SDS-PAGE and analyzed as above.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	194	SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting Samples were resolved on 6% SDS-PAGE as described previously (Bebok et al.
0.57130253.12538638.html.plaintext.txt	195	 Some gels were electrotransferred to nitrocellulose membrane and immunoblotted with anti to COOH-terminal CFTR mAb as described previously (Bebok et al.

0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	0	The role of regulated CFTR trafficking in epithelial secretion Carol A.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	1	Department of Cell Biology and Physiology, University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15261.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	2	cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator; membrane traffic; chloride channel; protein secretion.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	3	THE CYSTIC FIBROSIS TRANSMEMBRANE CONDUCTANCE REGULATOR (CFTR) is responsible for the cAMP-activated anion conductance of epithelial cell apical membranes.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	4	 As a principal apical conductance pathway, the CFTR anion channel is involved in cAMP-dependent Cl and bicarbonate secretion in airway and intestinal epithelia and exocrine glands.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	5	 It also influences the activity of other conductive pathways, through either linked regulatory interactions or electrochemical coupling that influences the driving forces for ion transport (49, 93).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	6	 Subsequent to the cloning of the CFTR gene, methods for in situ hybridization and the development of antibodies to CFTR permitted the characterization of its distribution in a variety of tissues (52, 104, 107).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	7	 The results generally correlated with the presence of cAMP/PKA-stimulated anion secretory processes in various epithelial tissues, identified in earlier studies using physiological methods.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	8	 Mutations in the gene encoding CFTR produce cystic fibrosis (CF), whereas hyperactivity of this transport pathway underlies secretory diarrheas.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	9	 CF disease arises from a reduced density and/or activity of CFTR in the apical membranes of secretory epithelial cells, such as those in the airways, exocrine pancreas, salivary glands, reproductive tissues, and intestines.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	10	 A regulated CFTR conductance pathway is also important for the normal functions of several absorptive cells, including epithelia lining the airway surface and sweat gland ducts (for a general review, see Ref.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	11	The subject of this review is CFTR trafficking in the distal portion of the protein secretory pathway, which lies between the trans-Golgi network and the plasma membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	12	 Historically, studies of this pathway were motivated by the question of whether it would be possible to explain all of the manifestations of CF disease on the basis of a missing anion conductance at the apical membranes of epithelial cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	13	 Accordingly, functional roles for CFTR other than its primary role as an apical membrane anion conductance pathway have been proposed to contribute to CF pathology.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	14	 These include disease-associated changes in regulated protein secretion (65), the chemistry of macromolecular secretions (22, 33, 90), and the properties of the airway microenvironment that lead to bacterial colonization of CF airways (89).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	15	Although the attention of numerous investigators has focused on CFTR trafficking through the distal protein secretory pathway as a possible contributor to the complexity of CF disease, a consensus regarding the importance of intracellular CFTR function and the process of regulated CFTR trafficking within this subcellular domain has yet to emerge.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	16	 As an integral membrane protein, CFTR will reside at least transiently in all compartments of the protein secretory pathway as it migrates toward the cell surface.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	17	 Thus one can expect to find CFTR in membranes of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), Golgi, and endosomal and lysosomal compartments of epithelial cells (Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	18	 Although there is no question that CFTR channels function as a regulated conductance pathway when they are resident in the apical membrane, numerous studies (see CFTR LOCALIZATION IN CELLS) have also indicated that a significant quantity of mature (i.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	19	, post-Golgi) CFTR is contained within intracellular compartments, that CFTR within these compartments is functional (9, 78), and that cAMP stimulation can modulate the distribution of CFTR between these compartments and the plasma membrane (see REGULATED CFTR TRAFFIC).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	20	 Therefore, the issue is not whether apical Cl conductance is due to regulation of the gating of membrane-resident CFTR channels or whether it results from the insertion of CFTR channels into the membrane, because both processes occur.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	21	 We want to know to what extent these forms of CFTR regulation are linked mechanistically and how trafficking of CFTR contributes to the overall conductance response.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	22	View larger version (36K):    Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	23	 Intracellular locations of cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) during maturation, plasma membrane insertion, and degradation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	24	 Properly folded, nascent CFTR leaves the rough endoplasmic reticulum and travels through the Golgi, where it undergoes glycosylation to mature (band C) protein.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	25	 Mature CFTR leaves the Golgi in vesicles that can travel directly to the apical plasma membrane or to the recycling endosome.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	26	 CFTR-containing vesicles continually traffic between recycling endosomes and plasma membrane, with rates of trafficking and protein distribution determined by cell type, differentiation, and phosphorylation conditions.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	27	 CFTR eventually follows the late endosome-to-lysosome pathway for degradation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	28	 Misfolded CFTR mutants and significant wild-type nascent CFTRs are degraded by the proteosome.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	29	This area of CFTR cell biology has been among the most contentious and unresolved subjects in CF research, and it continues to be so.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	30	 In a relatively recent review of this subject, Bradbury (10) argued that disparate conclusions regarding the regulation of the distribution of CFTR between plasma membrane and intracellular compartments might be reconciled if regulated CFTR trafficking was a property specific to epithelial cells, i.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	31	, studies showing a lack of CFTR trafficking were generally performed in fibroblasts.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	32	 Nevertheless, four years after the Bradbury review, the literature has not been clarified.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	33	 Accordingly, the task of bringing some synthesis to this conflicting data set is not an easy one.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	34	 Yet, we feel that it is possible to do so and that the attempt should add to our understanding of the control of plasma membrane CFTR density, a critical issue in CF disease.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	35	Location of mature CFTR (band C).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	36	 From a biochemical standpoint, the prevailing view is that core-glycosylated, immature (band B) CFTR is localized in the ER, whereas complex glycosylated, mature (band C) CFTR is present primarily in compartments distal to the Golgi, including the apical membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	37	 In contrast with many heterologous expression systems, relatively little band B is observed by immunoblot in most epithelial cells expressing CFTR endogenously at steady state.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	38	 For example, the ratio of band C to B in Calu-3 airway cells is 10 (100).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	39	 This indicates that most of the CFTR expressed endogenously in epithelial cells is located in distal compartments of the protein secretory pathway.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	40	 The first reported studies of CFTR localization, performed in COS-7 cells transiently expressing CFTR, showed a weak, diffuse plasma membrane staining pattern.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	41	 Most of the signal was intracellular, probably due to protein overexpression (23).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	42	 In polarized epithelial cells that express CFTR endogenously (T84, HT29, Caco-2, and airway epithelia), this signal was located unambiguously at the apical membrane domain (27, 28).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	43	 No staining was detected in the basolateral membrane, and little perinuclear staining of CFTR was observed in epithelial monolayers, implying that little CFTR is present in the ER at steady state (consistent with the low levels of band B).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	44	 (27) highlighted the importance of localizing CFTR within epithelial cells that express the protein endogenously.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	45	 In the same study, a mostly intracellular location of exogenously expressed CFTR was found in non-polar HeLa and 3T3 cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	46	 The central question concerning the issue of regulated CFTR trafficking is whether the protein that contributes to the plasma membrane anion conductance is present strictly in the apical plasma membranes of epithelial cells or whether it is present also in a subapical, post-Golgi compartment from which it is mobilized to the cell surface during stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	47	 A related issue is whether CFTR is stable in the plasma membrane or undergoes recycling to intracellular compartments.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	48	 In this regard, a rapid rate of CFTR endocytosis from the cell surface has been observed in both epithelial and nonepithelial systems (13, 61, 85).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	49	 These studies used biotinylation procedures to monitor the rate of CFTR internalization from the cell surface.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	50	 In T84 cells, it was estimated that 50% of cell surface CFTR is retrieved within a few minutes (85); in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells the internalization rate was 5% per minute (61).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	51	 These rates of endocytosis are not different from those of constitutively recycling receptors, such as those for transferrin or LDL.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	52	 These findings, together with the estimated 24- to 48-h half-life of mature, plasma membrane CFTR (7, 41), indicate that virtually all of the CFTR that is internalized by endocytosis must be returned to the plasma membrane by a recycling/exocytic pathway.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	53	 The presence of this rapid CFTR recycling pathway is a minimal requirement for a regulated insertion-retrieval model that controls cellular CFTR distribution.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	54	 Thus the question should not be whether CFTR undergoes trafficking at the plasma membrane but whether this process contributes to a change in the distribution of CFTR between plasma membrane and intracellular compartments in response to cAMP/PKA regulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	55	In addition to these kinetic considerations, the presence of CFTR in endosomes under steady-state conditions has been established with the use of a combination of biochemical techniques and functional assays that rely on CFTR's anion channel activity.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	56	 (12) resolved CFTR in the early stages of endosomal retrieval within clathrin-coated vesicles from epithelial cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	57	 CFTR was demonstrated to be present in this compartment by immunoblot.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	58	 After removal of the clathrin lattice by uncoatase and fusion of the resulting membranes with planar lipid bilayers, currents with biophysical and regulatory properties characteristic of CFTR were observed.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	59	 Because clathrin removal was a necessary prerequisite for reconstitution, CFTR was definitely a component of this endocytic compartment.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	60	 Additional studies have demonstrated that the rapid endocytosis of CFTR from the cell surface depends on clathrin-mediated pathways and that CFTR is not significantly internalized into caveolae (11, 85).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	61	 Several transport and/or channel proteins have been found to internalize via clathrin-dependent endocytosis, including aquaporin-2 (AQP-2) (101), Na/H exchanger 3 (NHE3) (24), renal outer medulla K channels (ROMK) (114), and epithelial Na channels (ENaC) (96).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	62	 Recent studies of the mechanism of CFTR endocytosis (see Functional studies of endocytosis) indicate a direct physical interaction of CFTR with the plasma membrane adapter complex, making CFTR a specific target of this endocytic machinery.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	63	Other methods for demonstrating the presence of CFTR in endosomes have relied on the ability of CFTR to provide a pathway for anion transport that parallels the vacuolar H-ATPase.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	64	 (60) allowed CHO cells expressing CFTR to take up the pH-sensitive dye FITC-dextran into endosomes, where the rate of dissipation of a pH gradient across endosomal membranes was stimulated by addition of a proton ionophore.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	65	 In these intact cells, pH gradient dissipation was limited by the counterion.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	66	 Activation of cAMP production elicited a twofold increase in the rate of pH change in cells expressing CFTR but not in parental or mock-transfected cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	67	 The results were duplicated in microsomes isolated from these cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	68	 Biwersi and Verkman (9) used a similar method for monitoring endosomal pH in CFTR-transfected 3T3 cells and in T84 cells endogenously expressing CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	69	 Treatment of the cells with forskolin before microsome isolation produced an approximately twofold increase in the rate of subsequently measured pH gradient dissipation but had no effect on microsomes isolated from nontransfected or F508 CFTR-expressing 3T3 cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	70	 These data are also consistent with the presence of functional CFTR in endosomes that, in principle, could contribute to CFTR recycling.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	71	 Using immunofluorescence and confocal microscopy for detection of cellular CFTR, investigators have generated data that arrive at somewhat divergent conclusions with respect to the importance of regulated CFTR trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	72	 On one side of this issue is the study of Lehrich et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	73	 (55) in shark rectal gland, a tissue that expresses CFTR at high levels endogenously.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	74	 These investigators used quantitative confocal microscopy to show that CFTR immunofluorescence extended from the apical membrane into subapical, supernuclear regions of the cell and that during stimulation with secretagogues, the overall depth of this CFTR signal decreased by 50%.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	75	 Similar conclusions were reached when the histogram of CFTR fluorescence intensity as a function of distance from the apical membrane was quantitated.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	76	 These cAMP agonist effects on CFTR distribution, imposed in perfused, intact rectal glands before fixation, were reversible.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	77	 Whether this shift in fluorescence signal represents insertion of vesicles containing CFTR into the apical membrane remains unknown; however, the findings are consistent with the acute hormonal regulation of CFTR trafficking in an intact epithelial tissue.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	78	 (1, 2) used immunofluorescence microscopy to quantify the cellular location of CFTR in rat small intestine and the influence of cAMP-dependent agonists on its distribution.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	79	 Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) elicited a bicarbonate-rich fluid secretory response in isolated perfused intestinal loops and elicited, within the same time frame, a redistribution of CFTR to the apical membrane domain.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	80	 CFTR association with the apical membrane was quantified by colocalization of F-actin as a brush border marker.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	81	 In duodenal villus cells, VIP elicited a reversible, threefold increase in brush border associated CFTR, and it redistributed CFTR within the cell apex to the brush border within 30 min.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	82	 These studies were confirmed by immunoelectron microscopic methods (see Immunoelectron microscopy).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	83	 The results provide support for a physiological role for cAMP-induced CFTR-containing membrane traffic in the regulation of the apical anion conductance in a native, endogenously expressing epithelium.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	84	Other investigators have reached different conclusions with respect to regulated CFTR trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	85	 (70) expressed a GFP-CFTR fusion protein in MDCK type I epithelial cells and used quantitative confocal fluorescence microscopy and cell surface biotinylation to determine the effect of cAMP stimulation on apical membrane CFTR localization.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	86	 Their findings showed that cAMP did not stimulate detectable GFP-CFTR translocation from intracellular compartments to the apical membrane, along an apical-to-basal GFP fluorescence gradient that extended throughout the cell.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	87	 In these cells, cAMP did not regulate GFP-CFTR endocytosis, determined by apical biotinylation and subsequent immunoprecipitation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	88	 Likewise, disruption of microtubules with colchicine did not affect cAMP-stimulation of Cl secretion or the expression of GFP-CFTR in the apical membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	89	 Thus the authors concluded that cAMP stimulates CFTR-mediated Cl secretion in MDCK type I cells by activating only the channels that are resident in the apical membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	90	 A regulated CFTR trafficking event may be lacking in this cell type; however, it is also reasonable to ask whether the exogenous expression of CFTR driven by the CMV promoter leads to saturation of regulated trafficking pathways (see Functional studies of exocytosis).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	91	A related study (58) involving measurements of cellular CFTR immunolocalization in endogenously expressing Calu-3 epithelia by fluorescence confocal microscopy detected no change in apical CFTR staining upon cAMP stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	92	 Surface biotinylation experiments reported in the same study (58) also showed no stimulation-dependent increase in apical membrane CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	93	 Two biotinylated proteins were detected by CFTR antibody precipitation following biotinylation; they were of equal intensity and 200 to 220 kDa in molecular size.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	94	 Yet, others have demonstrated by immunoblot that CFTR in Calu-3 cells shows the typical pattern of a predominant band C of 150 to 180 kDa and relatively little band B; the latter is presumably intracellular (c.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	95	 Thus it is not clear that the biotin-labeled proteins identified in these experiments were CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	96	It is possible that differences in the conclusions drawn from fluorescence measurements in native and cultured epithelial cells stem from variations in the distribution of CFTR in subapical compartments under nonstimulated conditions.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	97	 In the studies of native secretory tissues (shark rectal gland and rat intestine), the apical fluorescence signal extended into the cell sufficiently to detect a clear change in its distribution with stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	98	 In MDCK cells expressing GFP-CFTR (70), there was an even deeper distribution of expressed protein, but this may reflect its deposition in nonphysiological compartments, as described earlier in this article.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	99	 Given quantitative limitations of GFP visualization, 7 molecules/pixel (79), it may be necessary to express CFTR at nonphysiological levels to obtain a CFTR signal.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	100	 In Calu-3 cells (58), the CFTR signal was much more densely localized at the apical membrane domain.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	101	 Nevertheless, it is reasonable to ask whether a band of apical fluorescence detected in epithelial cross sections can resolve apical membrane CFTR from that present in a nearby subapical recycling pool.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	102	 Consideration of the point-spread function of fluorescence intensity variation with distance suggests that structures separated by  > 0.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	103	2  microm will not be resolved using light microscopy.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	104	 Thus immunofluorescence, even coupled with confocal microscopy, may lack the ability to resolve fluorescence signals from membrane vesicles having a diameter of 0.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	105	1  microm or less, which are components of the CFTR recycling pathway.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	106	 This vesicle size expectation is based on neurosecretory and other regulated trafficking vesicles (see APPENDIX).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	107	 For example, intracellular GLUT-4 staining by thin-section immunoelectron microscopy was localized to vesiculotubular structures 50 to 70 nm in diameter (62).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	108	 Thus it is possible that different conclusions at the light microscopic level may emerge from different cellular distributions of intracellular CFTR trafficking compartments and their constituents (see CONSEQUENCES OF REGULATED CFTR TRAFFICKING).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	109	 The results of several studies using immunoelectron microscopic methods are consistent with a subapical population of post-Golgi CFTR (c.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	110	 (86) used immunogold labeling to localize CFTR in vesicles present beneath the plasma membrane of human airway epithelial cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	111	 They also observed vesicles in the process of fusion or retrieval from the plasma membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	112	 Immunogold labeling of CFTR-expressing L cells and Sf9 cells also demonstrated the presence of CFTR beneath the plasma membrane as well as in the rough ER (26).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	113	 Studies of the striated duct of rat submandibular gland cells by Webster et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	114	 (107) showed immunogold labeling of CFTR along the apical membrane as well as in numerous subapical membrane vesicles.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	115	 Their estimates of labeling density suggested that more CFTR is present in subapical intracellular compartments than in the plasma membrane under "resting" conditions.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	116	 Some of the CFTR-labeled vesicles also stained with antibodies against the transferrin receptor and rab4, two endosomal markers, indicating that these vesicles are likely part of an endosomal/recycling pathway for CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	117	The fluorescence measurements of Ameen et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	118	 (1), performed in rat small intestine, were confirmed by immunoelectron microscopy.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	119	 CFTR was identified in subapical vesicles in several intestinal cell types, including cells from the crypt, Brunner glands, and a subpopulation of villar cells where CFTR expression predominated (so-called CFTR high expressors, or CHE cells).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	120	 cAMP stimulation elicited a two- to threefold increase in CFTR labeling of the apical microvilli of CHE cells in response to cholera toxin, providing evidence for regulated insertion of CFTR into the apical membranes of a native epithelium.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	121	 (42) examined apical membrane domain CFTR localization as a function of CFTR expression level.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	122	 In an earlier study (43), these investigators showed that CFTR located in the plasma membrane could be discriminated from intracellular CFTR by using nonpermeabilized MDCK cells expressing an extracellular epitope-tagged CFTR (where the flag, M2 epitope, was added to the 4th extracellular loop of CFTR, after amino acid 901).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	123	 They found that cAMP stimulation increased the cell surface signal of CFTR two-to threefold in the steady state.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	124	 In the more recent studies, they induced CFTR expression by using a recombinant adenovirus that encoded M2-901/CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	125	 Virally expressed, FLAG-tagged CFTR was functional and could be detected on the apical surface of forskolin-stimulated, polarized MDCK (type II) cells by immunofluorescence performed on nonpermeabilized epithelial monolayers.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	126	 At a low multiplicity of infection (MOI) (i.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	127	, lower CFTR expression level), forskolin stimulated the insertion of M2-901/CFTR into the apical membrane, but at higher MOI and M2-901/CFTR expression levels, no agonist-dependent increase in surface expression could be detected.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	128	 Immunoelectron microscopy confirmed the redistribution of CFTR to the apical membrane upon forskolin stimulation at the lower CFTR expression levels and demonstrated that the apically inserted CFTR originated from a population of subapical vesicles.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	129	 Results similar to these have been obtained with the use of immunoelectron microscopy in Calu-3 cells endogenously expressing CFTR, where a two- to threefold increase in apical CFTR was observed in response to acute forskolin stimulation (Hug MJ and Frizzell RA, unpublished observation).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	130	The observations of Howard et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	131	 (42) may reconcile at least some of the prior conflicting reports regarding the effect of cAMP stimulation on CFTR trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	132	 They show that a high level of CFTR expression, obtained by using strong promoters, for example (70), can saturate pathways for regulated CFTR trafficking, even in epithelial systems.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	133	 Also in oocytes, the CFTR trafficking signal (cAMP-induced increase in membrane capacitance) saturated as the CFTR expression level was elevated by injection of more RNA (102).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	134	 Inappropriate trafficking of AQP-2, in relation to the actions of dominant-negative AQP-2 mutants, has also been observed at high protein expression levels (51).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	135	 Later in this article, we discuss candidate protein interactions that may mediate regulated CFTR trafficking at the apical membrane.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	136	 If cells express different levels of the relevant traffic regulatory proteins, then it is likely that the contribution of regulated CFTR trafficking to the total anion conductance (as opposed to regulated gating of membrane resident CFTR) will vary in different epithelial or nonepithelial systems.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	137	The first studies that implicated CFTR function in regulated endocytosis were performed in colonic and pancreatic epithelial cell lines, with the latter transduced to express CFTR using retrovirus vectors.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	138	 (13, 14) measured detergent-sensitive horseradish peroxidase and FITC-dextran uptake to monitor fluid phase endocytosis in T84 and CFPAC-1 cells.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	139	 They found that cAMP significantly inhibited fluid-phase endocytosis, and in pancreatic cells, this depended on the expression of wild-type (wt) CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	140	 No cAMP inhibition of endocytic activity was observed in parental CFPAC-1 cells or those transduced by empty vector.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	141	 A similar 60% inhibition of endocytosis was observed during cAMP stimulation of endogenous CFTR-expressing T84 (13) and 9HTEo-cells (94).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	142	 In T84 cells, PKC stimulation did not affect either basal endocytosis or the inhibitory effect elicited by cAMP stimulation.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	143	Methods employing biotinylation of the cell surface have also demonstrated that CFTR internalization is inhibited by cAMP/PKA.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	144	 (85) biotinylated carbohydrate residues on the extracellular surface of T84 cells using NHS-biotin.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	145	 Subsequent immunoprecipitation and radioisotope labeling of CFTR with the use of [32P]ATP and PKA was performed to distinguish between CFTR at the cell surface and in intracellular compartments.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	146	 These workers found that apical membrane CFTR was rapidly internalized by T84 cells (half-time of 3 min), and they showed that cAMP decreased this internalization rate to an extent similar to that found in prior studies of fluid-phase endocytosis (60% inhibition).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	147	 They also showed that the internalization rate of G551D CFTR was similar to that of the wild-type protein but that, interestingly, its endocytosis was not affected by cAMP.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	148	 This finding suggested that either the channel activity of CFTR is related to its ability to be retrieved from the cell surface or the altered structure of the G551D mutant precludes regulation of both gating and trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	149	 It was difficult to detect a change in the total amount of CFTR at the cell surface using the method of Prince et al.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	150	 Even at short times (1 min), only a 12% increase in apical membrane CFTR was detected.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	151	 However, the use of in vitro phosphorylation to detect CFTR after its biotinylation and immunoprecipitation may be influenced by the existing phosphorylation status of the protein, thus compromising surface CFTR detection.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	152	 That is, if CFTR is already phosphorylated by agonist, the subsequent CFTR signal would be reduced because phosphorylation sites are already occupied.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	153	 A method that avoids this complication employs a second CFTR antibody to detect biotinylated CFTR, which avoids the potential for back-phosphorylation to reduce the signal.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	154	 This approach also demonstrates a forskolin-induced inhibition of CFTR endocytosis, a depletion of the protein from intracellular compartments, and a consequent increase in plasma membrane CFTR (61).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	155	Studies documenting the presence of functional CFTR in endosomes have been extended to show a role for CFTR in postendocytic membrane trafficking.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	156	 (8) implicated a role for CFTR in cAMP-stimulated endosome-endosome fusion.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	157	 They labeled endosomes of CFTR-expressing and control 3T3 cells with fluorophores such that a fluorescence signal would be detected if endosomes from separately labeled cell populations fused with one another.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	158	 These investigators asked whether the presence of CFTR in these endosomes, and its stimulation by cAMP, influenced the fusion process.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	159	 Endosomes from nonstimulated CFTR-expressing cells fused with each other at a rate that did not differ from that observed in control cells not expressing CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	160	 The endosomes isolated from CFTR-expressing cells that were stimulated by forskolin, however, showed a 2.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	161	 This was abolished by endosomal Cl depletion, suggesting that a CFTR-mediated Cl flux, or the conformational changes in CFTR associated with Cl conduction, somehow contribute to this process.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	162	 These data are consistent with the concept that CFTR stimulation can alter membrane traffic in endosomal recycling pathways.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	163	Recent findings have been able to establish certain structural features of CFTR that govern its rapid removal from the cell surface.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	164	 (84) and Weixel and Bradbury (109) have demonstrated that the internalization of CFTR via clathrin-dependent mechanisms depends on the presence of a YXX motif (where is a bulky hydrophobic residue) at the CFTR COOH terminus.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	165	 Similar tyrosine-based endocytic motifs are present on other proteins that are rapidly retrieved from the cell surface (see Ref.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	166	 In vivo cross-linking and in vitro pull-down assays showed that CFTR binds to the plasma membrane endocytic adaptor complex AP-2.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	167	 The CFTR COOH terminus was able to bind AP-2 but did not bind the Golgi-specific adaptor complex AP-1.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	168	 Mutation of the tyrosine residue at position 1424 of CFTR significantly reduced the ability of an isolated CFTR COOH terminus to bind AP-2.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	169	 The YDSI sequence of CFTR interacts specifically with the  micro2 subunit of AP-2 (108), a site implicated in adapter binding to similar endocytic motifs (74).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	170	 Protein binding studies showed that the COOH terminus binds selectively to this adapter subunit.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	171	 Cells expressing either a dominant negative  micro2 or a CFTR lacking the tyrosine-based internalization motif at the COOH terminus (Y1424A) fail to endocytose CFTR efficiently.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	172	 These studies indicate that the interaction of CFTR's COOH terminus with AP-2 guides it into the clathrin-mediated endocytic pathway, as observed for many cell surface receptors.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	173	 Although these studies provide compelling evidence for specific protein interactions that mediate CFTR retrieval at the cell surface, they do not yet provide an indication of how this process may be regulated by cAMP/PKA.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	174	 We have speculated on possible mechanisms for regulated CFTR endocytosis (see MECHANISMS OF REGULATED CFTR TRAFFICKING: PERPETRATOR OR BYSTANDER? and Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	175	View larger version (30K):    Fig.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	176	 Model for molecular interactions regulating endocytosis of CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	177	 A: the COOH terminus of phosphorylated (asterisks) CFTR is not free to bind the adapter protein complex AP-2, limiting its internalization.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	178	 B: phosphorylated AP-2 adapter (see text) associates with the plasma membrane and with the COOH terminus of dephosphorylated CFTR.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	179	 Small blue "bubbles" indicate the CFTR site of AP-2 binding.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	180	 Binding of AP-2 to the plasma membrane initiates assembly of the clathrin lattice (structure simplified for this 2-dimensional representation).
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	181	 C: AP-2-bound CFTR is sequestered in the forming clathrin-coated pit.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	182	 D: after the clathrin-coated vesicle has been internalized, coat and adaptor proteins are shed.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	183	Functional studies of exocytosis.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	184	 (13) on CFTR-dependent endocytosis also examined CFTR-dependent exocytic recycling to the cell surface.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	185	 To monitor exocytosis, the plasma membranes were pulse-labeled with a biotinylated lectin (WGA), and after its removal from the bath, the cells were allowed to take up lectin into intracellular compartments.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	186	 Remaining cell surface WGA was blocked with unlabeled avidin, and at various times the recycling of internalized WGA to the cell surface was assayed using Texas Red-labeled avidin.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	187	 In cells expressing wt CFTR, recycling and exocytosis of internalized marker was increased approximately threefold by forskolin, whereas cAMP stimulation had no effect on WGA recycling in either the parental CFPAC-1 cell line or in empty vector controls.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	188	 Importantly, these studies showed that cAMP-responsive recycling/exocytosis required CFTR expression.
0.65036243.12777252.html.plaintext.txt	189	Similar findings were obtained in human airway cell lines (94) where recycling/exocytosis was monitored as the release of previously internalized FITC-dextran (a fluid-phase marker of endocytosis) from human airway cells.
